title: Coil Extends Bob Bafferts Domination of the Haskell
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  Bob Baffert likes this little race on the Jersey Shore. It is worth a cool million dollars, and eight times over the past decade the winner of the Haskell Invitational has gone on to be named 3-year-old champion. And three of them came from Bafferts barn: Point Given, War Emblem and Lookin at Lucky.

title: Progress Hits Snag: Tiny Chips Use Outsize Power
description: For decades, the power of computers has grown at a staggering rate as designers have managed to squeeze ever more and ever tinier transistors onto a silicon chip  doubling the number every two years, on average, and leading the way to increasingly powerful and inexpensive personal computers, laptops and smartphones.

title: A Last Night Among the Spirits at the Chelsea Hotel
description: Her head was shaved on both sides, her Mohawk bleached and dyed blond and blue. As she leaned over the front desk of the Chelsea Hotel on Saturday night, her lower lip pierced with a ring and her Doc Martens tapping the floor, Kitty Ramona, a bass player from Baltimore, was every bit the nostalgic punk girl seeking refuge in a place dripping with history and on the verge of being swallowed by time.

title: Furor Over Giving Rape Suspect Explicit Tapes

He used his high-priced toys, including a sea plane, a helicopter and a boat, to lure them, they say, then molested them and beat them. He captured much of the sexually explicit action with his video camera.

But instead of exchanging vows with the smiling, attractive, effervescent blond, Gulati was left at the altar. Each time he had to settle for his second choice  the often scowling, track-suit-wearing, reclusive Bob Bradley.

description: After an anxious weekend spent glued to their BlackBerrys and iPhones, bankers and investors breathed a sigh of relief Sunday as lawmakers forged an agreement to raise the nations debt ceiling ahead of Mondays trading.

title: Boehner Outlines Debt Agreement
description: As President Obama was announcing an agreement on raising the debt ceiling to the nation on Sunday night, House Speaker John A. Boehner was presenting it to his caucus. Though he has not spoken publicly yet, aides released excerpts of his conversation, during which he also delivered a PowerPoint presentation outlining the deal.

title: Drug Kingpin Wanted in U.S. Is Held in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  A principal leader of a drug gang who the authorities believe was the mastermind behind the killings of three people connected to a United States consulate in northern Mexico last year and other bloody attacks has been captured, Mexicos federal police said Sunday.

title: Becoming the Party of Freedom
description: Republicans began the Civil War as the party of Union, not the party of Freedom. They did not become the celebrated destroyers of slavery until almost two years into the war, with the Emancipation Proclamation, issued Jan. 1, 1863. But during the summer of 1861 the direction of change was unmistakable, as Republicans took the first, crucial steps in a mounting attack on the Souths peculiar institution. Long-held beliefs about the immorality of slavery combined with the challenges posed by an escalating conflict, explain the evolving outlook of the Republicans.

title: Audit Faults M.T.A. on Subway Service Changes
description: New York City Transits poor management of subway service diversions leads to tens of millions of dollars in cost overruns and leaves the public ill-informed about when and where maintenance is happening, according to an audit by the city and state released on Sunday.

title: Its Getting Better
description: It has been a very good few weeks in the fight for gay equality. Last Tuesday, two days after same-sex couples began marrying in New York, the states attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, filed a brief in federal court challenging the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act, the odious law that bars federal recognition of same-sex unions. It was the latest in a welcome string of developments promoting fairness for gay men and lesbians.

title: Retirees Say Players Shouldnt Have Negotiated for Them
description: With the N.F.L. and the players required to finish the final terms of a collective bargaining agreement by Thursday, retired N.F.L. players plan to file a letter with the National Labor Relations Board on Monday raising concerns about how the then-decertified players union negotiated retiree benefits.

title: Gov. Cuomos Subway System
description: For two years, Jay Walder, an internationally known transportation expert, has been running the antiquated New York City mass-transit system with quiet efficiency. He has limited the failures dramatically, started new countdown clocks in subways and cut costs  $500 million last year, more than $600 million in 2011.

title: About That Salmon
description: In 2007, a virus called infectious salmon anemia started killing millions of farm-raised salmon in Chile and devastated Chilean aquaculture. The virus was first detected in 1984  long before salmon farming had spread around the globe  but what made it so lethal in 2007 was overcrowding in the offshore salmon pens and the fact that salmon were being raised in the midst of their own pollution. No one knew how the virus was transmitted, but a 2008 study at the University of Bergen determined it was carried in salmon eggs exported from Norway to Chile.

title: N.R.C. Safety Proposals
description: To the Editor:

title: Ohio: Man Kills 1 and Hurts 3 Near Outdoor Concert
description: A man fired several shots from a handgun in a fight near an outdoor concert in Cleveland that featured the funk artist George Clinton, killing a 16-year-old boy and wounding three other people, the police said Sunday. The fight erupted before 10 p.m. Saturday at an intersection near Luke Easter Park, where the eighth annual Unity in the Park festival was held. The police did not give a description of the gunman, and they said that no arrests had been made. It was unclear how long after Mr. Clinton or other musicians had performed that the shooting happened or what prompted it. The police said they did not know if those involved in the fight were among concertgoers leaving the area. The teenager died early Sunday of a gunshot wound to the head, the authorities said. The conditions of the three other three were not available. They were a 20-year-old woman shot in the neck, and a 14-year-old boy and 23-year-old man, each hospitalized with leg wounds. (AP)

title: The Diminished President
description: By rights, Barack Obama should be emerging as the big political winner in the debt ceiling debate. For months, hes positioned himself near the center of public opinion, leaving Republicans to occupy the rightward flank. Poll after poll suggests that Americans prefer the presidents call for a mix of spending cuts and tax increases to the Republican Partys anti-tax approach. Poll after poll shows that House Republicans, not Obama, would take most of the blame if the debt ceiling werent raised.

title: Heading Overseas in Name of Solidarity May Prove Divisive
description: Deron Williams appears headed to Turkey. Carmelo Anthony and Chris Paul have spoken of a possible duet in China. Kobe Bryant said Sunday that he will play anywhere. Dwight Howard and Kevin Durant have suggested they might like to have their visas stamped, too.

title: To Escape Chaos, a Terrible Deal
description: There is little to like about the tentative agreement between Congressional leaders and the White House except that it happened at all. The deal would avert a catastrophic government default, immediately and probably through the end of 2012. The rest of it is a nearly complete capitulation to the hostage-taking demands of Republican extremists. It will hurt programs for the middle class and poor, and hinder an economic recovery.

title: Hopeful, but Wary at Money Markets
description: WASHINGTON  Money market funds, stuffed with Treasury notes and other short-term government securities,have long been consideredthe safest of harbors by millions of investors and institutions alike. But with the prospect of a default or a downgrade in the nations creditworthiness, billions of dollars have fled the funds as investors grapple with uncertainty.

title: How Far Will Republicans Go to Avoid Defense Cuts?
description: One of the only negatives for Republicans in a debt ceiling deal that otherwise looks very favorable to them is the possibility of heavy cuts to defense spending. Roughly $600 billion in cuts to the Pentagons budget would be triggered if Congress is unable to agree to the deficit-reduction recommendations made by a special Congressional Joint Committee.

title: Exciting New Sources of Contradictory Advice
description: I have always been a better reader than athlete, and as a teenager, I imagined that I could improve my golf game just from studying a book, Five Lessons: The Modern Fundamentals of Golf, by Ben Hogan. It took me years, during which I may have done myself permanent damage, before I realized that the Hogan swing, with its emphasis on pronation (whatever that is) and rapidly unwinding the hips, only makes sense if youre Ben Hogan. If youre me  and if youre you, probably  the Hogan swing works about as well as a car engine that has thrown a rod.

Not after he caught up with five birdies in seven holes, then drove his ball into the water at the 17th hole.

Lower, who as president of ABC News in the 1960s and early 70s greatly expanded its coverage, making it more competitive with the network powerhouses CBS and NBC, and recruited reporters who became among the most respected in the business, died on Tuesday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 98.

Pharr Davis set out from Mount Katahdin in Maine on June 15 and reached the top of Springer Mountain in Georgia at 3:26 p.m. Sunday.

title: Madrid to Gather for Annual Religious Festivals
description: Despite the often oppressive temperatures, Madrileos take to the streets from Aug. 3 to 15 to honor the saints Cayetano and Lorenzo and the Virgin of Paloma in some of the most popular and traditional fairs of the year. Held in some of the citys oldest neighborhoods  Lavapies, La Latina and las Vistillas  the spirited celebrations feature processions, plays, games, food, races and concerts, often with people dressing up in old-fashioned costumes. Films and magic shows entertain the children, while adults enjoy chess tournaments and art exhibitions.

The trio then refused for hours to board a return flight home in the confrontation, which has laid bare longstanding animosities between the two countries rooted in Japans colonialist past.

title: Complaint Box | Water Wasters
description: There are many gripes one can have about the gym  guys who dont rack their weights, who grunt so forcefully youd think they were giving birth, who hog the equipment, or who sing aloud to their iPods oblivious that they are off key and audible to the whole world. But its in the locker room where, for me, the worst offenders reside: the guys who leave the water running while they shave (their faces, heads, backs, whatever).

title: Why the Jets Picked Plaxico Burress Over Braylon Edwards
description: So the deed is done. The Jets made a big splash by signing wide receiver Plaxico Burress to play opposite Santonio Holmes. Edwards, a key player for the Jets in the last two seasons, will not be back. And the speculation? Its that the Jets wanted Burress over Edwards primarily to grab attention in the New York market and get one-up on the Giants, their co-tenants at the New Meadowlands Stadium. The reasoning hints that Edwards wasnt flashy enough for the Hard Knocks Jets. They even gave Burress the No. 17 worn by Edwards.

title: The Hawks Dilemma
description: Theres plenty to be said about the details of the debt ceiling deal, but lets start with the provision thats making conservatives unhappiest: The use of broad defense cuts as part of the trigger mechanism that would automatically slash spending if the latest deficit commissions recommendations cant pass Congress. (See Rich Lowry, Bill Kristol, Yuval Levin, and others for expressions of concern and/or outright alarm.) In effect, defense cuts assumed the role that liberals wanted revenue increases to play in these negotiations, becoming the place where Republicans would give a little in order to get the deal they wanted done.

title: A Broken Record
description: The record has fallen. As expected, Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty set an attendance record for a fashion exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art over the weekend. As of Sunday night, more than 582,000 people had seen the show, surpassing the previous record of 576,000 set by Superheroes: Fashion and Fantasy in 2008. And McQueen still has a week to go, with plans to keep the show open until midnight on its final two days, Aug. 6 and 7.

title: For Him, Amateur Night at the Apollo Is Anything But
description: To someone stepping off a stifling hot 125th Street, the Apollo Theater  cool, dark and empty, as it was on a recent afternoon  felt like hallowed space. A tap-dancing man in a fedora beat out rhythms onstage, while a few musicians stood together collectively improvising a new song.

title: A Bigger Battle of the Buildings
description: Imagine the TV show The Biggest Loser, only the contestants are big buildings, and instead of competing to shed unwanted pounds, its a race to reduce unnecessary energy consumption.

title: Meanwhile, in the Global Economy
description: Bad news all over. In the US, Manufacturing growth hits lowest level in 2 years. In Europe, my favorite current indicator of the eurozone crisis, the Italy-Germany bond spread, has blown out again. And while part of this is due to falling German rates  which, like falling US rates, reflect growing pessimism about growth  the Italian bond rate is once again at 6 percent, a level that invites a self-fulfilling debt spiral.

title: Giants Allow Umenyioras Agent to Seek a Trade
description: The Giants have given Osi Umenyioras agent permission to seek a trade.

title: Small City, Big Debt Problems
description: Even as officials in Washington pledged to cut domestic spending, the city of Central Falls, R.I., landed in bankruptcy court on Monday, a stark reminder that some American cities have debts so overwhelming that no amount of belt tightening can set things right.

title: N.C.A.A. Penalties Erase Wins but Not Memories
description: The University of Hawaii won a mens volleyball championship in 2002. Or did it? Coach John Calipari earned his 500th college basketball victory last season. Or did he?

title: The Ultimate Memento for Katharine Hepburn Fans
description: The Connecticut home where Katharine Hepburn retired and lived until her death in 2003 at age 96 is up for sale, according to The Associated Press. The estate, in Old Saybrook on Long Island Sound, is on the market for $28 million. The house  which the owners have by combining rooms created larger, more open spaces  can be purchased separately for $18 million. Seven years ago, the property sold for $6 million. Hepburn won four Oscars and received 12 nominations over her 60-year career.

title: Westwood One and Dial Global to Merge
description: Westwood One, a radio network that distributes talk show hosts including Dennis Miller and call-in programs including Loveline, is merging with Dial Global, a radio syndication and advertising network, the two companies announced on Monday.

title: American Airlines Hopes for a B.A. Merger
description: Could another big airline merger take off? The president of American Airlines parent company hopes so.

title: Israel Kills Two Palestinians as Raid in West Bank Refugee Camp Goes Awry
description: KALANDIA, West Bank  Israeli forces killed two Palestinians in a refugee camp here early Monday after raiding several houses and being set upon by stone-throwing Palestinians.

title: If I Were In The House
description: I guess I have to be explicit at this point: yes, I would vote no.

title: The Fine Print on the Debt Deal
description: If Democrats read the fine print on the debt deal struck by President Obama and Congressional leaders, theyll find that its a little better than it appears at first glance.

title: Leading Off: Two Sides of New York Football
description: It doesnt take much deep thinking to divine the differences between New Yorks two N.F.L. teams. One is a league stalwart, steered by a legendary football family, so buttoned down and traditional it refuses to employ cheerleaders. The other is the team of Broadway Joe, the all-you-can-eat bluster buffet that is Rex Ryan, a virtual halfway house of players with overflowing N.F.L rap sheets.

title: Long Battle on Debt Ending as Senate Set for Final Vote
description: WASHINGTON  After months of partisan impasse, the House on Monday approved a budget agreement intended to head off a potential government default, pushing Congress a big step closer to the conclusion of a bitter fight that has left both parties bruised and exhausted.

title: States and Cities Brace for Less Federal Money
description: LOS ANGELES  The deficit reduction deal reached in Washington produced some relief across the country on Monday, as the nation appeared to have avoided default. But it also produced a sharp wave of anxiety among governors and mayors worried about how the cuts might hurt already beleaguered states and cities, and it sowed anger and cynicism among many Americans about leaders in Washington.

title: A race to the bottom of the ocean, an extinct marsupial comes to life and the psychology of addiction.
description: William J. Broad on plans by billionaires to explore the deepest parts of the ocean; molecular biologist Sean Carroll on signs of the existence of an extinct marsupial near Australia; and Denise Grady with Dr. Richard Friedman, psychiatrist at Weill Cornell Medical Center in New York, about the science of addiction.

title: The Federal Debt: When Compound Interest Is Crushing
description: The showdown over increasing the federal debt limit got me thinking about the power of compound interest. Its always been one of the most powerful forces in the financial universe. And in the case of the debt ceiling, it appears that compound interest has the potential to become a crushing enemy.

title: Google Acquires Dealmap
description: Google may have failed in its takeover attempt of Groupon last year, but its not giving up on the social shopping market.

title: Could This Deal Raise Budget Deficits?
description: It is virtually impossible to think of the impact of the debt deal as doing anything to help the economy. But give Mr. Kroszner credit for trying, in todays front-page article by Binyamin Appelbaum and Catherine Rampell.

title: Talbots Attracts a Private Equity Firm
description: Talbots, the struggling womens retailer with a stuffy image, has fallen out of favor with shoppers. But it looks attractive to private equity.

title: Look of the Moment | Emma Roberts
description: The Look: Lined up  wide white-on-white stripes add texture and intrigue to a clean, long-sleeve column dress.

title: Packard Sells for $1.1 Million at Ex-Meadow Brook Concours
description: A custom-bodied Packard Twelve led sales at the auctions held by RM this past weekend at the Inn at St. Johns in Plymouth, Mich. The inn is the new site of the Concours dlgance of America, which relocated this summer after 32 years at Meadow Brook Hall.

title: U.S. Military Claims Success Curbing Attacks in Iraq With Iranian Weapons
description: MOSUL, Iraq  Attacks by insurgents using what American analysts say are advanced Iranian weapons have dropped significantly over the last few weeks, senior American military officials said Monday, citing a two-track campaign of allied raids on Iranian-backed militants and official Iraqi protests to Tehran.

title: Life Before and After a Childs Diagnosis
description: For every parent of a child with a disability there is the moment they are given the news. And then there are the years spent responding to it.

title: Hired to Fix U.S. Team, Klinsmann Says Its Not Broken
description: After some of the recent performances by the mens national soccer team, most notably in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa, in a friendly match against Spain and in the Gold Cup, many fans are convinced that the United States is an undeveloping soccer country, devolving instead of evolving.

title: If It Aint Broke
description: The recent results for the United States mens national team have brought much gnashing of teeth among fans. But according to Juergen Klinsmann, the new coach, there is nothing wrong with this team. Klinsmann was introduced at a news conference Monday morning. Is Klinsmann correct, is this a case of fans impatience with a still maturing program, or is the coaching change just the first of several?

title: Improve Your Backstroke While Staying Dry
description: Speedo has created a new interactive, online club for swimming enthusiasts that it hopes will help their training efforts and, more importantly, inspire them to buy merchandise.

title: Interrupting Violence, on Screen and on the Streets
description: The men in orange and white Save Our Streets T-shirts were in a good mood.

title: Buy This Apartment, and Get a Used Car Absolutely Free!
description: The offers crop up in listings and advertisements everywhere: Closing costs covered! A vintage car for the weekend! Money for summer camp!

title: A Teachable Moment for Young Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  Crossing a generational divide in politics can be difficult, as former Gov. Jon M. Huntsman Jr. of Utah, a candidate for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, made clear when he referred to the Google in a speech to kick off the annual convention of the College Republicans National Committee over the weekend.

title: Oh Baby Answers Its Chicken-and-Egg Question
description: Last summer I wrote about Fran Free, founder of Oh Baby Foods. She faced the start-ups classic chicken-egg dilemma. She wanted to land a large contract with a major retailer, but lacked the resources to fulfill it, partly because she worked out of a leased restaurant kitchen, where her maximum output was 300 cases of organic, locally sourced baby food a year. On the other hand, she couldnt ramp up production without the promise of some much-needed business. Oh Babys 2010 monthly sales were about $2,000. While its customers are devoted, the company has not turned a profit.

title: The Caucus | Politics of the Debt Deal
description: Aug. 1, 2011 - John Harwood and Jeff Zeleny on what the debt deal means for the 2012 election; and a sample of political reaction.

title: In Middle East, a Restive First Day of Ramadan
description: Videos and messages posted online on Monday testified to a restive first day of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month, as a brutal crackdown continued in Syria, Egypts army destroyed a protest camp in Cairos central Tahrir Square and opposition fighters and government forces clashed in Yemen.

title: Peak Performances Season Offers Eight Premieres
description: The Peak Performances series at Montclair State University in New Jersey will include eight world and American premieres starting Sept. 17. The season, which runs through May 5, will include premieres by, among others, Companhia Urbana de Dana|Sonia Destri of Brazil, Wayne McGregor|Random Dance and the Akram Khan Company from Britain, the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and Miguel Zenn from the United States.

title: Hanna Segal, Who Popularized Play Therapy, Dies at 92
description: Hanna Segal, a British psychoanalyst who helped change child psychology in the United States by explaining and popularizing the play therapy techniques developed by her mentor, the seminal psychoanalytic thinker Melanie Klein, died on July 5 at her home in London. She was 92.

title: Caucus Video: The Politics of the Debt Deal
description: John Harwood and Jeff Zeleny analyze what the debt deal means for the 2012 election cycle. Also, a sample of the the reaction from across the political spectrum.

title: Upper Half, Talking
description: Doing Bloomberg TV at 3, from the Princeton studio. Time to put on jacket, tie, shorts and sandals.

title: Braising Vegetables, a Turkish Delight
description: AMONG the culinary crimes committed by mid-20th-century American cooks, few were more heinous than the long, slow torture administered to boiled vegetables: green beans cooked to a gray mush, zucchini so squishy it was barely recognizable, tomatoes stewed into a formless mass.

title: Help Wanted Ads Bode Ill for Jobs
description: If the debt deal passes on Monday in time to avert a federal default, all eyes will turn to the July jobs report coming Friday from the Labor Department. The last report, as you remember, was dismal: employers added just 18,000 net nonfarm payroll jobs in June.

title: Winehouse Tops Album Chart in Britain
description: It is a sad truth, eloquently expressed by Joni Mitchell, that you dont know what youve got until its gone. And judging by sales, the record-buying public seems to feel that way about Amy Winehouse, the troubled British soul singer found dead in her London home on July 23.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 1
description: A view of the day in sports, with fans showing up all over the world and N.F.L. training camps heating up.

title: Battle of the Bands: Couples vs. Siblings
description: On paper, Mates of State have a few serious strikes against them. Theyre a two-person band, which Ive always found a little lame. Theyre married. They live in the Connecticut suburbs. Theyve not only toured with their child; theyve also written an online diary about it called  oh, no  Band on the Diaper Run. I mean, cmon: what more could they possibly do to desecrate the spirit of rock?

title: A Worker With No ID and Great Medical Need
description: In San Francisco, where bicycle commuters often wear full-body spandex suits, my patient Carlos could easily be spotted: the Mexican man in mustard-colored work boots and painters overalls stained with gear grease, furiously pedaling an adolescents red Huffy.

title: Bradshaw Reaches Deal With Giants
description: The Giants signed running back Ahmad Bradshaw on Monday afternoon, solving one of their major problems on offense. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: In Iraqi Village, a Raid Sows Distrust of Americans
description: AL RUFAIT, Iraq  The American and Iraqi soldiers came to this village of grape farmers and tribal traditions in the dark in search of a suspected insurgent, and left in the morning sunlight.

title: A Sons Demons
description: Todays guest posts are focusing on how different families respond to a diagnosis of something life-altering but not life-threatening in their children. Anon in the Midwest is a regular in the comments here on Motherlode. She often gives advice when others ask. In this essay she is not looking for answers, just some understanding and support. She asked that I send people who are interested in learning more to two Web sites, BipolarKids.org and the National Alliance on Mental Illness.

title: Mission Motors R: an E.V. Bike That Runs With the Fastest Gas Burners
description: Electric-power road-racing motorcycles have been competing against each other on the world stage since 2009, when they first took to the track at the Isle of Man TT. But they have, for the most part, been seen as a silent, slower sideshow to gas-powered racebikes.

title: Wall Street Continues to Spend Big on Lobbying
description: As the Dodd-Frank Act reaches its one-year anniversary, Wall Streets army of lobbyists continue its aggressive campaign to tame the financial regulatory law.

title: Court Overturns 5 Gen Re and A.I.G. Fraud Convictions
description: 8:22 p.m. | Updated

title: Really? The Claim: A Normal Heart Rate Is 60 to 100 Beats a Minute
description: THE FACTS

title: PBSs Masterpiece Picks Up a New Sponsor
description: The PBS program Masterpiece is celebrating the fact that it has a title sponsor for the first time in seven years.

title: Fruit Smoothies for Summer
description: When I go to a farmers market in summer, I cant resist buying more fruit than I need. I blame those cut fruit samples  one taste, and Im filling my bag.

title: Visiting Artists | Luke Gilford
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#54", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Drawing Dance: Cunningham at Home in the West Village
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the seventh in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from the Cunningham Studio at Westbeth.

title: Student Reading Contest Winner | China, Norway and Orwell
description: This is it: our fourth and final winner in our monthlong New York Times Summer Reading Contest. This week, Shannon Doyne and Amanda Christy Brown helped me judge, and their help and insights were invaluable  it was hard to choose from among the more than 100 thoughtful entries on topics that included healthy food, math camp, e-books and the attacks in Norway.

title: The Airport Experience Now Includes Shopping for the Family
description: After visits to malls plummeted during the recession  and have yet to bounce back  many mass-market retailers stepped up their search for other locations to lure shoppers.

title: Were on Hiatus This Week
description: We hate to be a reminder that summer is ending, but were taking a break this week so that we can get our blog ready for academic year 2011-12. Well be back with regular daily posts on Aug. 8.

title: Chvez, Battling Cancer, Appears With Shaved Head
description: The Venezuelan president, Hugo Chvez, appeared on national television on Monday for the first time with a shaved head, a stark visual reminder of the treatment he is currently receiving for an unspecified cancer.

title: Ancient Moves for Orthopedic Problems
description: With the costs of medical care spiraling out of control and an ever-growing shortage of doctors to treat an aging population, it pays to know about methods of prevention and treatment for orthopedic problems that are low-cost and rely almost entirely on self-care. As certain methods of alternative medicine are shown to have real value, some mainstream doctors who think outside the box have begun to incorporate them into their practices.

title: App Smart Extra: Sheet Music for Your Smartphone
description: The latest App Smart column rounds up the top classical music apps  at least for listeners. For creators of classical music, there are fewer choices, especially for those on Android, where music software developers have yet to tread in large numbers.

title: Legal Fees Keep Surging in Lehman Class-Action Suit
description: Patrick Andrade for The New York TimesLehman Brothers former headquarters in 2008.

title: The Doctor Will See You ... Eventually
description: How much of human life is lost in waiting! Ralph Waldo Emerson lamented in his 1841 essay Prudence.

title: Eugene McDaniels, Singer-Songwriter of Soul and Blues, Dies at 76
description: Eugene McDaniels, whose mellifluous voice brought him high onto the Billboard charts several times in the early 1960s, and who wrote Feel Like Makin Love, which Roberta Flack took to the top of the charts in 1974, died on Friday at his home in Kittery Point, Me. He was 76.

title: Delta Says It Will Refund Airfare Tax
description: 6:30 p.m. | Updated with I.R.S. statement.

title: Insurance Coverage for Contraception Is Required
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration issued new standards on Monday that require health insurance plans to cover all government-approved contraceptives for women, without co-payments or other charges.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Creamy Rice Casserole
description: This rice casserole, studded with fresh corn kernels, peas and poblano chiles, and made creamy with sour cream and cheddar cheese, is Mexican comfort food. People love it because its creamy, crunchy and cheesy, said Zarela Martinez, a cookbook author and until this year, owner of Zarelas, the pioneering Mexican restaurant on Second Avenue. Its Mexican baby food. Like rice and beans. She said her 3-year-old granddaughter, Violeta, eats it.

title: Harry Reid Misses His Pomegranates
description: How much do the stressed-our, bleary-eyed lawmakers on Capitol Hill want to go home?

title: Why Climate Scientists Are So Perturbed
description: Climate scientists have long called for steps to limit the buildup of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, and they are growing more and more worried about the slow pace of action. Yet their sense of urgency has not permeated society at large, and it certainly does not seem to be influencing the course of events in Washington, where climate legislation stalled last year.

title: Pairings: Nectarines and Berries in Wine Sauce
description: I have kept a box of white wine in my refrigerator and red in the pantry almost since these easily dispensed wines first became available. Need a half-cup, a cup or more for a recipe? Its at hand, ready to go into the pot, and theres also some always ready to go into the cook.

title: Thinking Inside the Box
description: ITS the epitome of dclass, the vinous equivalent of trailer trash, the wine snobs worst nightmare. No, I dont mean the screw cap. Im talking about boxed wine.

title: Reconsidering Boxed Wine
description: Its taken a long time, but discerning American wine drinkers are slowly getting used to the idea of drinking wine from a box. No doubt, that is partly because the quality of boxed wines is improving, as the wine panel found.

title: The Chelsea Guest Who Wouldnt Leave
description: When guests at the Chelsea Hotel learned that it was abruptly shutting down, they reacted with anger, sadness and disappointment  but ultimately with resignation. One by one, they dutifully checked out of the storied hotel on 23rd Street by midday Sunday.

title: The Pink and the Blue
description: Q. What influences the color of hydrangea blossoms? If it is soil acidity, why can a single bush have different-colored flowers?

title: Numberplay: The Keys to Freedom
description: Mathematical folklore is rife with legends of imprisoned people who won their freedom or escaped death by solving a mathematical problem. Weve featured a number of such problems here including the Josephus Problem, which, according to legend, allowed the 1st-century Jewish historian Flavius Josephus to save himself from death. (In our version, it was a firing game featuring Donald Trump and Ryan Seacrest.) Weve also featured the Prisoners and Light Bulb problem and the Prisoners and the File Drawers problem, in both of which prison authorities give their detainees a mathematical problem to solve to gain their freedom. Todays puzzle features a similar scenario. It concerns a medieval king who, in a rare fit of potential mercy, promises to free 5 of his prisoners on condition that they solve a problem. This problem is based on a submission by the prolific Numberplay contributor Ravi Kumar Meduri, from Hyderabad, India.

title: In With the New (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: How Men Mourn (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The March of Alzheimers (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Good Night for CBS in the Ratings
description: CBS scored another ratings victory on Sunday night, beating out the other broadcast networks in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. Big Brother is particularly starting to look like a ratings juggernaut on Sundays, doubling every other show on the broadcast schedule in the 18-to-49 group except for a repeat of Family Guy on Fox. It also accumulated more than 8 million total viewers, up from 6.9 million last week. 60 minutes did its part as well for CBS, as it was once again the most-watched program of the night with 8.8 million viewers. Meanwhile, The Bachelorette: The Men Tell All Special won the 9 p.m. time slot for ABC in total viewers with 5.1 million but was down considerably compared with last seasons edition, which drew 8.9 million. Still, it gave ABC its best summer Sunday rating with entertainment programming in five years (the 2010 special appeared on a Monday).

title: Into the Abyss
description: Several new craft are being developed to reach Challenger Deep, the deepest part of the Mariana Trench.

title: Who Falls to Addiction, and Who Is Unscathed?
description: Shortly after the singer Amy Winehouse, 27, was found dead in her London home, the airwaves were ringing with her popular hit Rehab, a song about her refusal to be treated for drug addiction.

title: A Birthday Celebration for Philip Glass at Park Avenue Armory
description: The Park Avenue Armory will present a mini-festival dedicated to Philip Glass, putting on four performances of his music and of works by artists who have inspired him, on Feb. 23-26, the armory said on Monday. Those performing include Patti Smith and her band, as well as the jazz guitarist Bill Frisell.

title: Ambitions as Deep as Their Pockets
description: A new generation of daredevils is seeking to plunge through nearly seven miles of seawater to the bottom of a rocky chasm in the western Pacific that is veiled in perpetual darkness. It is the oceans deepest spot. The forbidding place, known as the Challenger Deep, is so far removed from the warming rays of the sun that its temperature hovers near freezing.

title: Dyslexia May Be a Hearing Problem Too
description: New research suggests dyslexia may be more than just a reading problem, but also an issue of how the brain processes spoken language.

title: Study Sheds Light on Auditory Role in Dyslexia
description: Many people consider dyslexia simply a reading problem in which children mix up letters and misconstrue written words. But increasingly scientists have come to believe that the reading difficulties of dyslexia are part of a larger puzzle: a problem with how the brain processes speech and puts together words from smaller units of sound.

title: The Caucus | Politics of the Debt Deal
description: Aug. 1, 2011 - John Harwood and Jeff Zeleny analyze what the debt deal means for the 2012 election cycle.

title: Activist Investors Take Stake in McGraw-Hill
description: 8:57 p.m. | Updated

title: Europe: Increase in Tropical Diseases Is Aided by Migration and Weak Economies
description: Worm infestations, food parasites, Chagas disease, sand fly-transmitted infections and other neglected tropical diseases usually found in Africa and Asia are turning up more often in Europe, according to a new study.

title: TimesCast | The Tea Party's Impact
description: Kate Zernike reports on the significant role Tea Party legislators played in shaping the latest debt ceiling deal.

title: As Dust Settles, Cowboys & Aliens Shoots Down Smurfs
description: With the last ticket counted, Cowboys & Aliens ended up winning the weekend box-office race by a Smurf-sized whisker.

title: G.O.P. Hopefuls, Minus One, Line Up Against Budget Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Courting the partys faithful, the Republican candidates for president in 2012 have embraced Tea Party sentiment and lined up against their leaders in Congress by opposing the debt ceiling compromise reached with President Obama.

title: Arrests in House Visitors Gallery
description: About 15 people in the visitors gallery overlooking the House floor were arrested Monday afternoon after disrupting a debate on the debt-limit proposal by chanting, Boehner, get off it; its time to tax corporate profit.

title: The Belle of the Concours, and Her Car, Turn Heads in Michigan
description: For an innocent little country gal, as she described herself, Margaret Dunning was a rock star at Sundays Concours dlgance of America, where the 101-year-old showed the Packard she has owned for six decades.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Italy, Egypt, West Bank and Turkey.

title: Tracing Social Networks of the Asian Elephant
description: Socialites know how hard it is to juggle friendships  there just doesnt seem to be enough time for everyone.

title: TimesCast | August 1, 2011
description: The House and Senate have yet to vote on the debt ceiling deal.

title: Screening: Mammograms Seen Ineffective in Europe
description: An analysis of data from six European countries suggests that mammography screening has had no effect on breast cancer mortality.

title: Lightning Cripples Long Island Train Service
description: Updated, 5:30 p.m. | Long Island train commuters may face a difficult trip home on Monday after an apparent lightning strike crippled a swath of Long Island Rail Road track east of the city, officials said.

title: Eurofile | Poland by the Sea
description: Sopot is one of the sweetest places Ive ever been, Charlotte said as the Baltic seaside light began shading to sepia and tinting the waves amber. We were heading back to the wonderful Sofitel Grand Sopot Hotel, after lunch at Tomo Sushi, strolling along Europes longest wooden pleasure pier. As we walked and ate some of the worlds best strawberry lody (ice cream)  made with fresh, ivory-colored cream and wild berries  we were stopped regularly to snap photos of bashfully beaming families who wanted proof of their summer sojourns as warming souvenirs during Polands long winter.

title: Breaking Bread Everywhere, Plentifully or Pitifully
Most Students Spared Big Cuts in Debt Bill
description: It could have been worse.

title: Particle Accelerators Full of Spin and Fury, Signifying Something
description: In the sidewalk con game known as three-card monte, you have to try to follow one of three cards (the red ace, say) as a dealer shuffles them back and forth face down. Its easy until you actually put down money, and suddenly all your guesses are wrong.

title: Does Debt Bill Gut Military? Depends Whom You Ask
description: Did the Joint Chiefs know something the rest of us didnt?

title: Douglaston, Queens, 4:15 P.M.
The 3 Women of Mountain Man, in Perfect Harmony
description: There were a few moments of truth during Mountain Mans austere, engrossing performance at the Mercury Lounge on Thursday night. One came after midnight, just before the encore, as the three young women in the group  Molly Erin Sarle, Alexandra Sauser-Monnig and Amelia Randall Meath  gathered at the lip of the stage.

title: How Can It Feel This Wrong?
'Invasion of the Body Snatchers'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at the 1956 paranoid fantasy.

title: In This Video Game, You Can Make Real Cash Through Virtual Trading
description: How much would you pay for a magic sword that leached the life force from your enemies? Or an eldritch staff that let you unleash tempests of lightning? Or enchanted slippers that made you invisible to all but the sharpest senses?

title: Birdlike Dinosaur Fossil May Shake Up the Avian Family Tree
description: In the 150 years since its discovery in Germany, Archaeopteryx has perched high on the avian family tree as the earliest and most primitive bird, somewhere near the evolutionary moment when some dinosaurs gave rise to birds. But recent fossil finds cast doubt on this interpretation: Archaeopteryx may be only a birdlike dinosaur rather than a dinosaurlike true bird.

title: Sign of Advancing Society? An Organized War Effort
description: Some archaeologists have painted primitive societies as relatively peaceful, implying that war is a reprehensible modern deviation. Others have seen war as the midwife of the first states that arose as human population increased and more complex social structures emerged to coordinate activities.

title: After Horror Stories, Airbnb Unveils New Policies
description: Airbnb, a service that lets people rent out their spare bedrooms to adventurous travelers, is on the rise, having recently raised $112 million in financing. But over the last few days, the company has run into trouble.

title: LuPone and Patinkin Coming to Broadway
description: A mere 32 years after she played Eva Pern to his Che Guevara in Evita, Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin will reunite on Broadway for 63 performances of a theater concert, beginning Nov. 16. The production, An Evening With Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin, at the Barrymore Theater, is directed by Mr. Patinkin and includes musical staging consulting by his fellow Broadway veteran Ann Reinking. The Broadway premiere follows appearances across the United States and in Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Evita has not been revived on Broadway since the production that earned Ms. LuPone and Mr. Patinkin Tony Awards, but a version starring Elena Roger and Ricky Martin is to open next year.

title: Call of the Thylacine: Protect the Wild
description: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK, Australia  Eleven thousand miles from my home in Wisconsin, this national park is one of my favorite places on the planet  a vast area of wetlands, woodlands and rock formations that is home to a fantastic array of wildlife.

title: Taxi-Industry Battle Continues, With Echoes of 1971
description: This yellow-streaked city is no stranger to bitterly fought wars within its taxi industry, a saga that at times can resemble a daytime soap opera. Call it As the Taxi Turns.

title: A Bare Market Lasts One Morning
description: It was an early Monday morning like any other on Wall Street. Before most of the blue-shirted financiers descended, there came an army of helpers: the custodians and coffee fetchers, personal trainers and headsetted assistants who make the money street run smoothly. They marched along the sidewalks, in a hurry to start their workweek.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Italy, Egypt, West Bank and Turkey.

title: Exposing Wall Street
description: People get naked as part of a performance art piece about Wall Street transparency.

title: Debt Plans That Failed
description: A look at some of the major proposals to address the nations deficit and why they failed.

title: Criss to Succeed Radcliffe In How to Succeed
description: January is often the cruelest month for Broadway box offices, as holiday tourists head home, students go back to school and New Yorkers hibernate from the cold and snow. Last winter the lead producers of the Broadway revival of Promises, Promises closed the show on Jan. 2 rather than gamble money on recasting their two stars, Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth, and risk a slide in ticket sales. Those same producers are now behind another Broadway revival, How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, but they have opted to replace their star, Daniel Radcliffe, who finishes his run as the scheming executive J. Pierrepont Finch on New Years Day. Confirming rumors that have been circulating for a couple of weeks, the producers announced on Monday that Mr. Radcliffe (of Harry Potter fame) will be succeeded by a lesser-known actor, Darren Criss, who has become popular recently on the Fox series Glee playing a gay high school student and show choir member who exudes charisma and self-confidence. In casting Mr. Criss the producers are seeking to appeal to at least some of the teenagers, women and gay men who often mob Mr. Radcliffe at the stage door after performances. Mr. Criss is scheduled for only a three-week engagement, Jan. 3 through 22. In their statement announcing Mr. Criss the producers did not say if they plan to cast another actor after him, close the $8.5 million production after he departs, or try to extend his run. A spokesman for the musical said the producers had not made decisions about the future of the show after the Criss run.

title: Rock the Casbah
description: Prologue: The Sandstorm

title: Upheaval and Hope in a Land of Turmoil
description: When the longtime Middle East reporter Robin Wrights last book, Dreams and Shadows, was published in 2008, her assessment  that a budding culture of change and empowerment had begun to permeate the region  was greeted as wildly optimistic. Three years later, given the wave of uprisings that began within the past year in Tunisia and Egypt and that has continued to roll through the Middle East, her views now seem extremely prescient.

title: A Faint Sound at a Concert, but Impossible to Ignore
description: This was supposed to be a short review of the free concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening previewing the Mostly Mozart Festival, which opens officially on Tuesday. And I can tell you some of what happened there.

title: Critics Picks Video: Invasion of the Body Snatchers
description: Its the moment when everyone seems perfectly normal that everything goes wrong. That premise is at the heart of the 1956 horror/thriller Invasion of the Body Snatchers.

title: Kindergarten, with Cerebral Palsy
description: David Sexton has been writing for Motherlode regularly about his son, who has cerebral palsy.

title: Hayes to Host MSNBCs Weekend Morning Show
description: Updated | 8:07 p.m. | Christopher L. Hayes of The Nation magazine will host a weekend morning show for MSNBC beginning in September, the channel said Monday.

title: Men Robbed A.T.M. Using Dunkin Donuts Cards, Officials Say
description: Gift cards can be thoughtful. But some people still prefer cash.

title: Fountains of Wayne, Now With Less Smirking
description: FOUNTAINS OF WAYNE

title: To Share Grievances, Microblogging the Frustrations of Flight
description: IM not the most talkative person on airplanes. I used to be much friendlier, but an inevitable question is, What do you do? When I say, Im a professor of computer science, I always wind up doing a lot of free consulting.

title: Even as Financial Fears Mount, Real Love Outweighs Gold
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  We know well the vicious cycle of an opera thats less than an immediate hit. The work is neglected, so it is assumed to be lacking in quality, so its neglected some more. And so on.

title: Indias Widening Iron Ore Scandal Hurts Stocks
description: MUMBAI, India  Indias wave of corruption scandals has hit yet another industry, iron ore mining, implicating companies that include the flagship of one of this nations richest men.

title: Adobe, Creator of Flash, Embraces HTML5
description: Adobe, the software company famous for its Flash software running the online animation, video and graphics on most computers, unveiled an early version of its latest software on Monday called Adobe Edge. The software will enable Web designers to create online content using the Web programming languages HTML5, JavaScript and CSS, instead of Flash.

title: Baseball-Size Hail Damages Cars in Queens and on Long Island
description: A violent summer storm slammed hailstones the size of baseballs down onto eastern Queens and western Nassau County Monday afternoon, shattering windshields in New Hyde Park, Long Island, and damaging cars in Douglaston, Queens, the National Weather Service said.

title: Star Alliance Puts Air India on an Indefinite Standby
description: NEW DELHI  Star Alliance, a global network of airlines that caters to frequent international travelers, said Monday that Air Indias pending membership had been suspended.

title: Playing Hide-and-Seek With a Stash of Cash
description: The police state becomes total when the police become the heroes and the criminals begin policing themselves.

title: House Passes Compromise Debt Bill
description: 7:42 p.m. | Updated The House of Representatives approved the debt ceiling bargain negotiated over the weekend by President Obama and leaders from both parties, sending the measure to the Senate. Final approval that could come Tuesday.

title: Carlos Slim Offers to Buy Full Control of Telmex
description: America Mvil, controlled by Carlos Slim Hel, bid on Monday for the 40 percent of its former parent, Telmex, that it does not already own, aiming to consolidate the Mexican billionaires telecommunications holdings.

title: Adding a Volt of Energy to the Patrol
description: The newest addition to the New York Police Departments fleet of patrol vehicles is not built for high-speed chases, but for the stop and go of city traffic.

title: Kings of Leon Cancel Tour, Citing Exhaustion
description: The Kings of Leon canceled the remainder of their United States tour on Monday, saying their lead singer, Caleb Followill, was suffering from vocal issues and exhaustion after becoming ill at a concert in Dallas last week, said a publicist for the group, Ken Weinstein.

title: The Search for the Thylacine
description: Sean B. Carroll, a biologist from the University of Wisconsin, explores the Australian hinterlands hoping to find ancient rock art of a now-extinct doglike marsupial nicknamed the Tasmanian Tiger.

title: Gulf Dead Zone Is Smaller Than Feared
description: A recent mapping expedition by scientists has shown that a zone of low oxygen in the Gulf of Mexico is above average but not as vast as many had anticipated, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Monday. Flooding in the Midwest had stirred fears that vast amounts of farm chemicals and waste traveling down the Mississippi would create the largest dead zone ever. NOAA said the zone measured 6,765 square miles, which is not a record. But scientists warned that the data could be misleading because a tropical storm had roiled and mixed gulf waters. They said that levels of the chemicals that deplete oxygen were rising year to year, weakening the gulfs resistance to pollution.

title: California: Crystal Cathedral Not for Sale
description: The Crystal Cathedral Ministries board has decided not to sell the campus of the landmark Orange County church, as the ministry works to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings. Potential buyers, including the Diocese of Orange, had offered up to $50 million for the campus, which would have allowed Crystal Cathedral to pay its creditors in full. Instead, the church will try to raise the money through donations, its lawyer told a bankruptcy court on Monday. The church may have only about four months to do so while the creditors committee proceeds with its own plan for a sale of the church.

title: Case Study: The Young Adult Institute
description: A selection of documents pertaining to the Young Adult Institute, a Medicaid-financed nonprofit group.

title: Kenny Baker, Fiddler Steeped in Bluegrass Style, Dies at 85
description: Kenny Baker, an influential bluegrass fiddler whose melodic, fluid style became a signature of Bill Monroe and His Blue Grass Boys, with whom he performed and recorded off and on for more than 25 years, died on July 8 in Gallatin, Tenn. He was 85.

title: Russia Replies Sharply to U.S. Senates Support of Georgia
description: MOSCOW  Almost exactly three years after the brief war between Russia and Georgia, Washington and Moscow are trading challenging statements over its unresolved legacy, in another sign that the reset of relations between the two cold war enemies is coming under pressure.

title: Cattle Tested for Effects of Altitude on Heart
description: JEMEZ SPRINGS, N.M.  For tourists traveling into the mountains, altitude sickness can be an uncomfortable reality. The lightheadedness. The nausea. The vicious headaches.

title: Giffordss Return Marks Moment of Unity in Divided House
description: The clock was running down, and the debt ceiling compromise did not yet have enough ayes to pass. Then, slowly, applause started trickling through the House chamber. The clapping grew over the next half minute, until finally, the person who somehow managed to draw universal admiration from the frayed body came into view.

title: Class of 96: U.S. Hall Inducts Five
description: All five of the 2011 inductees into the United States Hockey Hall of Fame  three players, an announcer and a team owner  played central roles in one of Americas biggest hockey triumphs.

title: Immigrant Advocates File Suit on Petition Signatures
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Until recently, Maryland stood apart from other states that have passed anti-immigrant legislation.

title: When the Numbers Outweigh the Message
description: Can public relations alone rescue a struggling deal? By taking the uncommon tactic of switching communicators in the heat of battle, thats sort of what the reinsurer Validus Holdings is trying with its hostile bid for its $3.2 billion rival, Transatlantic Holdings. Validus shareholders have so far scorned the idea. The trouble is, messaging doesnt win deals, numbers do. On that score, Validus isnt far enough ahead.

title: Guggenheim Outpost as a Pop-Up Urban Lab
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation has long been known for creating landmark museum buildings, from its 1959 headquarters by Frank Lloyd Wright, on Fifth Avenue, to Frank Gehrys 1997 billowing titanium Guggenheim Bilbao in Spain. But this week it is opening a very different kind of structure, a pop-up gathering space on a gritty, city-owned lot in the East Village that until a few weeks ago was all rats and rubble, as one Guggenheim official described it.

title: College Prep for Your Childs Laptop
description: Attention parents of high-school-seniors-to-be. Buy that college laptop right now, this summer, instead of waiting for graduation next year.

title: Mets Begin Key Stretch With a Step Back
description: The Mets play 32 of their remaining 53 games at home. For most teams on the fringes of a playoff chase, that would be a blessing. For the Mets, it seems more like a curse.

title: Did a Storm Distort Mapping of a Gulf Dead Zone?
description: As the Midwest reeled from catastrophic flooding this spring, scientists warned of devastating consequences for the Gulf of Mexico this summer.

description: THE older I get, the longer the list of people I dont want to talk to.

description: Some 20 investors and analysts recently gathered at the Princeton Club in Manhattan, united by one common thread: their frustration over the stock growth of a financial data processor, DST Systems.

title: A Flamboyant Friend Killed in Norway Is Mourned
description: HAMAR, Norway  Like veteran soldiers of an operation gone wrong, about a dozen sleep-deprived young people gathered on a beach of this small lakeside town to reminisce about the comrade they left behind.

title: Judge Wants to Meet on N.F.L. Retirees Claims
description: The N.F.L., its players union and lawyers for a group of retired players have been told to meet later this month with a federal judge, who is likely to order them into mediation to address concerns raised by the retired players.

title: Video: Lincoln, Reagan and Obamas Compromises
description: President Obama refers fondly to Abraham Lincoln as an inspiration for political compromise, but will Mr. Obamas compromises haunt his political future? A discussion with David E. Sanger.

title: Does Philosophy Matter?
description: In a recent essay about moral relativism in The Timess philosophy series The Stone, Paul Boghossian cites a 2001 op-ed of mine as an example of the contradictions relativists fall into. At one moment, he says, I declare the unavailability of independent standards for deciding between rival accounts of a matter, and in the next moment I am offering counsel that is perfectly consistent with the endorsement of moral absolutes. I dont regard that as a contradiction, and I would say that to think of it as one is to fail to distinguish between relativism as a philosophical position  respectable, if controversial  and relativism as a way of life, something no one recommends and no one practices.

title: A Start-Up Produces Infomercials for the Internet
description: The one thing online shopping is missing, says Sukhinder Singh Cassidy, a former Google executive, is infomercials.

description: Apparently, time does not heal all wounds when it comes to the N.B.A. lockout.

title: Pearls, Finer but Still Cheap, Flow From China
description: ZHUJI, China  One of the most feared men in the worldwide pearl industry these days is a muscular, Ferrari-driving 40-year-old who is doing the improbable: growing pearls that are nearing the highest quality and may be affordable for middle-class Americans.

title: Freshwater Pearls, Made in China
description: Innovations in the countrys pearl industry are leading to shifts in the global market for cultured pearls.

title: Apple Reveals iCloud Details and Pricing
description: Apple posted information on its Web site Monday that offers more details about the companys upcoming iCloud software which will sync customers content between multiple devices.

description: WASHINGTON  In a rare symbolic strike against unnecessary government secrecy, the governments former classification czar has filed a formal complaint against the National Security Agency and Justice Department seeking punishment of officials who classified a document that he says contained no secrets.

description: When city inspectors started giving letter grades for cleanliness to restaurants a year ago, restaurant owners were not pleased.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants solved one of their biggest training camp problems on Monday, but another continued to escalate.

title: Full of Confidence, the Jets Swagger Back to Work
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  There they go again, those same old Jets. The wide receiver is proclaiming them as the team to beat in the A.F.C. East. The newly signed cornerback is calling himself the best in football. The head coach is challenging someone else to thump New England, apologizing for piloting only the third-best defense last year, instructing fans not to waste their time attending morning walk-through practices because, Rex Ryan said with an eye-roll, thats about as boring as it gets.

title: Photo Exhibit at Park51
description: Photos from a project by Danny Goldfield, who is creating portraits of New York City children from every country in the world.

title: Process of Elimination for Two Yankees Starters
description: CHICAGO  Phil Hughes and Ivan Nova are friends, two young pitchers who have worked their way through the Yankees minor league system to become important pieces of the major league team. With six starters now on the Yankees roster, however, they know that there is not room for both of them.

title: Developers of Islamic Center Try a New Strategy
description: A year after controversy engulfed plans to build a Muslim community center and mosque in Lower Manhattan, the projects developers are quietly moving ahead: In recent months they have hired a paid staff, started  fund-raising drives and continued holding prayers and cultural events in their existing building two blocks from ground zero.

description: Representative Gabrielle Giffords' return ushered in applause and votes as the House of Representatives voted to raise the debt ceiling.

title: In Neighborhood Thats Diverse, a Push for Signs to Be Less So
description: Taiwanese herbal remedy shops peddle elixirs for indigestion and impotence on storefront signs awash in Chinese characters. Nearby, Shiseido cosmetics boutiques advertise their wares in Japanese. And the imposing Ganesh Temple, one of the largest Hindu temples in the United States, greets visitors in Hindi script.

title: Corrections: August 2
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Focus Turns Back to Fed on Economy
description: WASHINGTON  Even as Congress escapes from its brush with default, political divisions have all but immobilized the levers of fiscal policy, raising pressure on the Federal Reserve to address the nations economic lethargy.

title: Up in the Air
description: The first manned balloon flight took place in France during the early 1780s and, not surprisingly, people began thinking of how to turn the balloon into an implement of war. Within a few years, the French army was using observation balloons in battle, and Benjamin Franklin even suggested that balloons might actually be used to convey soldiers into the fray. In 1849 the Austrian high command sent some 200 unmanned balloons, laden with timed explosives, over Venice. Unfortunately, the wind shifted, carrying them back over the hapless Austrians.

title: A Rift Divides Members of Journalism Groups
description: As the National Association of Black Journalists opens its annual conference in Philadelphia on Wednesday, a topic of conversation is likely to be its recent efforts to get more black anchors on prime-time news programs.

title: Among Conservative Rabbis, a Wide Disagreement Over Same-Sex Marriage
description: Though he approves of New York States new law allowing same-sex marriage, Rabbi Allan Schranz of the Sutton Place Synagogue, a Conservative congregation in Manhattan, will not officiate at a wedding ceremony for same-sex couples, pointing out that his reasons, though partly rooted in Jewish traditions, are mostly rooted in his personal traditions.

title: Shampoo to Match a No-Nonsense Attitude
description: SHAMPOO advertising often promises to add sheen to dull, lifeless hair, but sometimes it is the shampoo brands themselves that lose their luster.

title: Giffords Returns, as Does Unity, Briefly
description: WASHINGTON  With two minutes to go and roughly 20 votes needed to pass a bill to raise the nations debt limit, a smattering of applause rippled from a corner of the House chamber. After a few seconds of confusion, a flash of teal jacket could be seen almost floating among a sea of Democrats.

title: Britains Economic Policies Gain Backing From I.M.F.
description: LONDON  The International Monetary Fund endorsed the British governments tight budget policy and loose monetary stance on Monday, while warning that the authorities should stand ready to change course if growth failed to improve.

title: Turks Question Power of Prime Minister
description: SILIVRI, Turkey  The retired men in this town of rolling hills, red shingles and resentment of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan paused their card game to voice their fears over the protest resignations of most of Turkeys military command, an event that underlined Mr. Erdogans stamp on an era he can call his own.

title: Review Aims to Avert Cheating on State Tests
description: New York State education officials announced Monday that they had begun to review the way they detect and prevent cheating on standardized tests, taking a step to avoid the cheating scandals that have engulfed school systems in other states.

title: House Passes Compromise on Debt Ceiling
description: The House passed a landmark compromise, drawing a solid majority of Republicans and about half the Democrats.

title: Deal Was Forged Over Choices and Chinese Food
description: WASHINGTON  Last Friday night, President Obama called Speaker John A. Boehner just after the Republican House leader had gotten his rebellious Republicans, on the third effort, to pass legislation to address the debt crisis.

title: What the White House Left on the Table
description: I wrote at length earlier Monday about why I think the proper characterization of the deal that President Obama struck with Republicans is pretty bad rather than terrible. (Thats from a Democratic point of view. For Republicans, Id say the deal should be thought of as quite good rather than awesome.)

title: With Lockout Over, One Jet Is Left to Explain It to His Teammates
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For most N.F.L. players, the four-month-long lockout was filled with lonely workouts, saving pennies and waiting for an agreement to be reached.

title: That Monolithic Tea Party Just Wasnt There
description: Few Republicans or Democrats would disagree that the Tea Party and its designs loomed over the debate on the debt limit. But the power of the Tea Party as a singular force may be more phantom than reality.

title: Pentagon Faces Possibility of Hundreds of Billions in Spending Cuts Over 10 Years
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon began grappling on Monday with the possibility that it will have to cut hundreds of billions of dollars from the military budget over the next decade, but there were so few details in the debt ceiling deal reached by the White House and Congress that confusion over the actual size of the reductions was rampant.

title: Revolving Door at S.E.C. Is Hurdle to Crisis Cleanup
description: A senior lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission recently took center stage in a major case involving a controversial mortgage security sold by Goldman Sachs.

title: Housing Deal Ensures Park in Brooklyn Will Expand
description: After months of uncertainty over the fate of the popular Brooklyn Bridge Park, city and state officials plan to sign an agreement on Tuesday that would allow limited private housing to be built there, to help pay an expected annual operating cost of $16 million.

title: Tuesday: Green Machines
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Yesterday we engaged in the sweaty work of helping Joel Fagliano schlep works of ART across the grid, so I say we deserve a day off today. I dont know about you, but Im going to kick back and read a comic book.

title: To Punish Iran, Seize Its Embassy

description: If part of the romance of baseball has often been romance, along comes one from another era.

title: Council Bill Would Curb Assistance by Rikers to Immigration Officials
description: Rikers Island officials have long compiled lists of foreign-born inmates who end up in their custody. They routinely give this information to federal immigration officials, who have their own office at the jail. Deportations often follow.

title: Somalis Waste Away as Insurgents Block Escape From Famine
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The Shabab Islamist insurgent group, which controls much of southern Somalia, is blocking starving people from fleeing the country and setting up a cantonment camp where it is imprisoning displaced people who were trying to escape Shabab territory.

title: Tea Partys War on America
description: You know what they say: Never negotiate with terrorists. It only encourages them.

title: As We Seek Nature, We Wall It Out
description: Graced by beautiful rings and ridges on their shells, diamondbacks look like a field of galaxies on the move. They inhabit neither freshwater nor sea, but the brackish slurry of coastal marshes. Mating in the spring, they need to lay their eggs on land, so in June and July they migrate to the sandy dunes of Jamaica Bay. The shortest route leads straight across the tarmac at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Versus Renamed Again
description: First, the channel was called the Outdoor Life Network; then it turned into OLN and then it became Versus. Starting Jan. 2, it will be named the NBC Sports Network (not to be confused with NBC Sports, its broadcast sibling). The name change was prompted by Comcasts gaining control of NBC Universal earlier this year and the continuing efforts to make Versus the cable arm of NBC Sports. NBCs efforts to rebrand Versus have been seen in the production of N.H.L. broadcasts and in the addition of horse racing and Notre Dame football.

title: Cruel Isolation
description: For many decades, the civilized world has recognized prolonged isolation of prisoners in cruel conditions to be inhumane, even torture. The Geneva Conventions forbid it. Even at Abu Ghraib in Iraq, where prisoners were sexually humiliated and physically abused systematically and with official sanction, the jailers had to get permission of their commanding general to keep someone in isolation for more than 30 days.

title: Lawmakers in Both Parties Fear That New Budget Panel Will Erode Authority
description: WASHINGTON  Lawmakers from both parties expressed scorn on Monday for a central feature of the deficit-reduction deal that creates a powerful 12-member committee of Congress to recommend major changes in entitlement programs and the tax code.

title: Amid Famine, Dangers Hinder Aid to Somalia

title: Off Media Radar, Famine Garners Few Donations
description: For better or worse, relief organizations often chalk up their biggest fund raising successes during major humanitarian crises like the famine in east Africa.

title: India and Pakistan, Talking
description: With a relationship as combustible as that between India and Pakistan, its progress just to get the two sides in a room. Last weeks meeting was better. Their foreign ministers announced modest, but very welcome, agreements concerning the bitterly disputed region of Kashmir.

title: Pork? That? What Do You Mean?
description: The road to Washington is paved with broken campaign promises. But few are so rich in hypocrisy as those of House Republican freshmen caught engineering hometown pork even as they vow to slash the federal budget for the supposed good of the nation.

title: Where Rats, Hawks and Children Abide
description: What would John James Audubon do? The naturalist who shot birds before he painted them ended his days, 160 years ago, studying and shooting rats in New York City, vowing not to expose the inhabitants in the vicinity to danger. This citys rats continue to flourish, with particular enthusiasm at Tompkins Square Park in the East Village, where they can be seen scuttling nonchalantly near the childrens swings and inside the sandbox.

title: Forty Years Later, a Tip With Potential in a Famous Case
description: SEATTLE  He smoked Raleigh cigarettes, wore a black clip-on tie and drank whiskey, and when zero hour came, he was one cool cat.

description: TOKYO  The operator of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant said Monday that it measured the highest radiation levels within the plant since it was crippled by a devastating earthquake. However, it said the discovery would not slow continuing efforts to bring the plants damaged reactors under control.

A Lie That Was Literally True

description: Paul Franke, a tenor who was one of the Metropolitan Operas most stalwart, ubiquitous and enduring performers, appearing there nearly 2,000 times in four decades, died on July 21 at his home in Queens. He was 93.

title: Amsterdam Show Combines Corbijns Two Careers
description: Through Sept. 1, the FOAM Amsterdam (Keizersgracht 609; foam.org) photography museum, will celebrate both careers of the Dutch photographer and director Anton Corbijn. The Inwards and Onwards show features a series of photos he took before, during and after the shooting of his films.

title: Fantasy Focus: Trade-Deadline Fallout
description: The Blue Jays somehow converted some middling prospects into Colby Rasmus, a center fielder who thrived in the major leagues a year ago at age 23. Next year Toronto could feature an outfield of Jose Bautista, Rasmus and Travis Snider/Eric Thames, and an infield with Adam Lind, Brett Lawrie and Yunel Escobar, to go along with a power-hitting catcher in J.P. Arencibia. With Ricky Romero and Brandon Morrow developing and Brett Cecil recently building on a solid rookie year, the Jays could crash the Yanks-Sox-Rays triumvirate as early as 2012.The Indians coughed up some top pitching prospects (Drew Pomeranz and Alex White) for Ubaldo Jimenez, and it makes you wonder why the Yankees didnt offer a similar package (including Dellin Betances and Manny Banuelos), or, if they did, why the Rockies didnt want it. Jimenez has a good contract and is under team control through 2014, so unless Colorado suspected there was something wrong with him, this seems like a good price. Its not entirely true that theres no such thing as a pitching prospect, especially when youre talking about players who blew away the high minors like Tim Lincecum and Tommy Hanson or mega-talents like David Price or Stephen Strasburg. But for the next tier down, which is how I view both the Indians and Yankees duos, the failure rate is awfully high. Itll be interesting to see how Jimenez fares with all his starts at sea level, albeit in the American League.

title: Fighter-Jet Cockpit Canopies Tested for Formula One Racecars

title: After a Botched Raid in Iraq, Competing Facts and Unified Blame

Iraqs leaders and soldiers are the ones responsible, and seek American support only as needed. That may be literally true, but the reaction to a botched weekend raid in a village north of the capital that left three men dead, none the targeted insurgent, laid bare another truth: In Iraq, where grievances run deep, America will still bear the brunt of the blame when things go wrong, even if the facts dont completely align.

title: Latest Arrest Highlights a Tabloids Cash Payments

When reporters needed cash to pursue articles, they simply filled out a green form and, after getting authorization from the managing editor, exchanged it at the window for up to tens of thousands of pounds, said several journalists who worked there.

title: All the Pie in Portland
description: Trying to locate this years fifth annual Pie Off in Laurelhurst Park in Portland, Ore., was like a sketch from the TV show Portlandia: first you had to pass by what was billed (in chalk on the asphalt path) as an organic free-range wedding, then a free performance of Shakespeares Much Ado About Nothing. Finally, in the northeast corner of the park  marked by a bluegrass band and pennant banners made from recycled fabric, strung between the linden trees  were four tables spilling with pies. There was everything from the classic (Grandma Janes apple pie, berry with a lattice crust) to the quintessentially Portland (a gluten-free Rawvocado-chocolate  avocado, chocolate, raw macadamias, dates and shredded coconut). Hopeful eaters of all ages clustered around the tables, compostable forks and paper plates at the ready, waiting for four judges to sample all 60 pies that had been entered in one of four categories: savory, sweet non-fruit, sweet fruit and creative.

title: Debt Compromise Is Just First Step, Obama Says

title: Baruj Benacerraf, Nobel Winner in Medicine, Dies at 90

title: A Sneak Preview of the Times Magazine Photo Book
description: We just received our first bound copies of  the book Aperture will publish this fall featuring three decades of photography in The New York Times Magazine. We cant wait for readers to hold this wonderful, heavy book in their hands. Five years in the making, it spans more than 1,700 issues of the magazine, including photographs by 140 key image makers of our time across all genres of the medium: documentary, portraiture, fine art, photo illustration, style and conceptual photography. In the issue of the magazine that comes out on Sunday, Aug. 21, well be republishing some of the pictures from the book, alongside new, updated photographs of the same subjects. Keep your eye out for both the issue and the book.

Still, there are labels that refuse to enter the online arena, and Cline  why, Cline?!  is one of them. I learned this in the winter of 2009 when my need to acquire the king-size Luggage tote escalated to a level bordering on obsession. I loved everything about it  the elegant scrolls, the embossed gold lettering, the rigid structure. But I couldnt find it anywhere.

The mattresses  or crash pads, as some call them  were strapped to the backs of two American rock climbers who are among a growing group of people who in the last decade have practiced and promoted a form of climbing that relies on mattresses, rather than ropes, to catch their falls.
