title: When Youve Got Those First-24-Hour Blues
description: A traveler arrives in London, jet-lagged, throws his bags down in the hotel in Islington and sets out to meet a friend at Kings College, which Google Maps says is a 30-minute walk away. A half-hour later hes lost and caught in pouring rain. Forty-five minutes later hes wandering Fleet Street with a cheap umbrella in hand. An hour and a Tube ride later, this soaked and stressed shadow of his former self gives his impatient friend a hug.

description: The Mets have earned a small reputation this season for stirring comebacks and key hits with two outs. On Sunday and Monday, they combined the two by hitting game-tying home runs with two outs in their last at-bat.

title: El Museo del Barrio Names New Director
description: El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan has appointed Margarita Aguilar, a vice president and specialist in Latin American art at Christies, as its new director, the museum announced on Tuesday. Ms. Aguilar, 54, was a curator at El Museo from 1998 to 2006 before going to Christies. Its a very good homecoming for me, she said in a telephone interview. She said that the museums annual attendance had doubled since she left, to roughly 250,000 visitors, and added that she would like to see it increase still further. We want to be sure that we reach all of our constituents, including New Yorkers, Latinos and Latin Americans, she said.

But the Leopard, which strode fiercely into the moldering Caf des Artistes space on West 67th Street a few months ago, was purring as only the big cats can.

title: ABC Successfully Woos Viewers With Bachelorette Bash

According to Nielsen data, the show gained viewers as the night progressed, beginning with 8.9 million in the first half hour at 8 p.m., where it seemed that Ashleys sister would derail the proceedings entirely with her strong dislike of one of the suitors, and finishing with 10.6 million viewers tuning in to see whose proposal Ashley would ultimately accept by 9:30 p.m.

title: Seeking Consensus in a Squabbling Nuclear Family
description: Months after the triple meltdown at Fukushima Daiichi, an agenda for American reactors is beginning to take shape.

title: Double Crown Will Become Saxon & Parole, Leaving Asia
description: Brad Farmerie and his partners at Double Crown, the AvroKO Hospitality Group, have decided to close the restaurant at 316 Bowery (Bleecker Street) on Aug. 20, after three years, and reopen it in the fall as Saxon & Parole. The soaring space will be redesigned. Mr. Farmerie, who is also the chef at Public, said he had an idea for a restaurant he wanted to create and thought it would work in the space for Double Crown, which has evoked colonial Asia.

title: Most New York City Teachers Satisfactory
description: Nearly all New York City public school teachers received passing grades for their performance in the last academic year, though the small portion with unacceptable work continued to rise, the city said on Tuesday.

title: Tom Colicchios Secret Farm, Right Next to the F.D.R. Drive
description: When it comes to produce, there is local, there is hyperlocal, and then there is the Riverpark Farm at Alexandria Center.

description: Photographs from Kenya, Afghanistan, the Philippines and Egypt.

description: 12:34 p.m. | Updated

title: Bouldering: Beth Rodden
description: An example of bouldering from Beth Rodden.

title: For Stocks, Day 7 Since the Walkout
description: Tuesday was the seventh trading day since John Boehner walked out of talks with Barack Obama at the White House. That move made it clear that the House speaker would not risk alienating the Tea Party and that if a debt default were to be averted, the president would have to capitulate on virtually all issues or defy Congress by claiming the debt limit legislation was unconstitutional. He chose to capitulate.

title: Obama Speaks About Compromises
description: August 02, 2011 - President Obama said that a compromise raising the debt ceiling is the first part of his agenda to improve the economy. (Video: NBC)

title: Exploring the Far Reaches and Forms of the Blues
description: Watching It Aint Nothin but the Blues, a musical revue at Aaron Davis Hall, feels a bit like being on a sightseeing tour with an uninspired guide. The things you see may be appealing or even thrilling, but youre not going to learn much about them that you didnt already know.

title: Bouldering: Randy Puro
description: An example of bouldering by Randy Puro.

title: Want Fresher Produce? Leave Dirt Behind
description: MICHAEL ANTHONY admires the butter lettuce he has been buying for the last month so much that he invented a salad for it. The $12 dish he serves at Gramercy Tavern in Manhattan is also made up of pickled eggplant, ricotta, pickled cherries and heirloom tomatoes, but the greens are the star, and for good reason.

title: Bouldering in Central Park
description: Examples of bouldering from an event in Central Park. Video courtesy of NE2C Productions.

title: TimesCast | Debt Bill Becomes Law
description: President Obama signed into law the bill to raise the government's debt ceiling and cut trillions of dollars in spending.

title: A Day (July 18, 2011) in the Life of Danny Meyer
description: Manhattan restauranteur Danny Meyer is on a roll.

title: Connoisseurs in the Theatrical Import Business
description: When the 2011 Edinburgh Festival Fringe begins on Friday, the theater-obsessed who make the pilgrimage to Scotland for this huge annual, multi-arts blowout can indulge their passion almost around the clock, assuming they have the stamina. Of the more than 2,500 events scheduled through Aug. 29, when the festival ends, almost 800 involve the theater. From Shakespeare for Breakfast to Hotel Medea, an interpretation of that Greek tragedy that runs from midnight till dawn, the opportunities to live, eat and breathe theater appear unlimited.

title: A Fast Way to Chill Ice Pops
description: After putting the new Zoku ice pop maker in the freezer overnight you can make three frozen pops in less than 10 minutes right on your countertop. If you work fast and your mixture is cold, you can make another batch or two. The kit comes with sticks and basic instructions. Making layered or swirled pops is relatively easy. But inserting pieces of fruit or decorations into the sides of the molds, to make the jazzy pops shown on the box, is challenging without a tool kit, sold separately.

title: An Olive Oils Aroma and Taste Say Kalamata
description: There is no mistaking which olives went into Amorettis new oil with the intense aroma and flavor of kalamata. Maral Barsoumian, an owner, said the company infuses Tunisian extra-virgin olive oil with concentrated kalamata essence derived from real olives. A drizzle on tomatoes, grilled fish, pasta or country bread adds a bold punch.

title: When Dieting Becomes a Role to Play
description: SHE calls it wishful shrinking. Last May, Carrie Fisher showed off her 30-pound weight loss, a result of 18 weeks on the Jenny Craig diet, to People magazine  the most recent of the companys series of celebrity spokespeople to reach a major milestone in weight loss.

title: The Liberals Dilemma
description: If the deficit deal should inspire hawkish conservatives to consider the possibility that refusing tax increases effectively guarantees defense cuts, it should also inspire liberals to realize that by turning entitlement cuts into their own version of tax increases  the red line that they absolutely refuse to cross  theyre ultimately putting their own priorities at risk. Heres Mark Schmitt, from a fine piece on this theme:

title: Four Operas at Glimmerglass
description: Two new operas and two classics at the Glimmerglass Festival in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Mercer Issues Employer Survey on Health Coverage
description: Employers continue to say they plan to keep offering health care coverage to their workers, even after all of the provisions of the federal health care law take effect in 2014, according to a new survey by the benefits consultant Mercer. The new law has already succeeded in modestly expanding coverage, the survey found.

title: Santana to Have Shoulder Examined
description: The Mets left-hander Johan Santana, who pitched last week for the first time since having shoulder surgery last September, will be examined this week in New York instead of continuing his rehabilitation assignment in Florida, General Manager Sandy Alderson said Tuesday.

title: The Lot on Tap
description: The High Line at 30th Street (10th Avenue); (212) 206-9922; thehighline.org/the-lot

title: Obama to Visit 3 Sites on Sept. 11
description: On the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11, 2001, President Obama will attend memorial services at the locations of all three attacks: the World Trade Center site in New York, the Pentagon and Shanksville, Pa.

title: Latin Musicians Sue Over the Grammys
description: 6:49 p.m. | Updated

title: Monument Lane
description: Since opening in April, Monument Lane has tried hard to be a good citizen. The restaurants name refers to the neighborhoods Colonial-era cow paths; its menu is deliberately old-fashioned; its huge glass corner windows invite passers-by to window-shop the place before trying it out. The servers are quirky but friendly, the look rustic. If there is an opposite of a velvet rope, Monument Lane has hung it out.

title: The Problem With Serving Sizes
description: According to its label, a pint of Hagen-Dazs ice cream contains four servings. But when was the last time you measured out a fourth of a container of Cookies & Cream, then put the rest away for another day?

title: Reviewing Monument Lane

description: NYSE Euronext, the exchange company that Deutsche Brse is planning to buy, said its second-quarter profit fell on lower revenue from European derivatives and United States equity trading.

description: Time: About 12 hours, plus 8 to 12 hours for brining

title: A Little Yard Work Before Digging In
description: IF you hunger for a project, something to ignite those primal cooking instincts more fiercely than a standard grill ever could, consider getting a group of friends together to build a weekend fire pit.

title: Paying Tribute to Nirvana and the Strokes
description: It took 10 years, 2,400 miles and one whole generational shift in the relationship between indie rock and the mainstream, but the Strokes Is This It, released in 2001, did the thing that Nirvanas Nevermind, released in 1991, was never able to: hide in plain sight.

title: A Text From Woods to Clarke Stays Private
description: AKRON, Ohio  Darren Clarke, the Ulsterman from Dungannon who won the British Open two weeks ago for his first major championship at 42, is as down to earth as the auld sod and solid as the cliffs on the rugged north coast. And when he says he will or will not do something you can bet your last pint of Guinness that he will or will not.

title: Pakistan Uses Patrols to Calm Karachi
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  After at least 26 people were killed in shootings and other attacks in the southern port city of Karachi over the past two days, the Pakistani government on Tuesday authorized paramilitary forces to conduct raids in some of the citys most violent neighborhoods to try to restore order.

title: The Rise Of Distraction-Free Text Editors
description: With the release of Mac OS X Lion, the idea of a full-screen app  not one stuck inside a window  has become a little more palatable for users of many applications. After all, an app that uses the entire screen is, in a way, distraction-free; youre focused on the task at hand.

title: Why Did Facebook Buy an E-Book Publisher?
description: Is Facebook about to get into the e-book business?

description: Q.

title: Stalemate in Senate Leaves 4,000 Out of Work at F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON  After dealing with the debt crisis, Senate negotiators tried and failed on Tuesday to end a stalemate over temporary financing for the Federal Aviation Administration, leaving 4,000 agency employees out of work and relying on airport safety inspectors to continue working without pay.

title: NBC Sees a Future for 30 Rock, Even Without Jack Donaghy
description: LOS ANGELES  Is Alec Baldwin really leaving 30 Rock after the next season, as he said he intends?

title: Slashing the Price of Health With Common Sense
description: As health care costs continue to spiral out of control, its often forgotten that one of the best ways to lower health care expenditures is to reduce the amount of medical care thats needed to keep people healthy. This is no revelation. However, because of the financial incentives in our health system, the things we can do to promote health, and prevent illness, are not prioritized.

title: Out of a Swelter Come Apocalyptic Visions
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Word that scorpions had been sighted on her street clinched it, as far as Nana Beniashvili was concerned.

title: AAA Rating Is a Rarity in Business
description: Hanging over the debt ceiling negotiations in Washington has been the threat that the United Statescould lose itsAAA credit rating, a coveted measure of the federal governments financial strength. But in corporate America, the top rating long ago became an anachronism.

title: Can Big Food Regulate Itself? Fat Chance
description: Life would be so much easier if we could only set our own guidelines. You could define the average weight as 10 pounds higher than your own and, voil, no more obesity! You could raise the speed limit to 90 miles per hour and never worry about a ticket. You could call a cholesterol level of 250 normal and celebrate with a bag of fried pork rinds. (You could even claim that cutting government spending would increase employment, but that might be going too far.) You could certainly turn junk food into something healthy.

title: A Giants Rookie Is Shaking Off a Year in Limbo
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Marvin Austin has heard the critics. He knows N.F.L. teams bypassed him in first round of the draft over concerns about his character. Now, as he competes for a job with the Giants, he is at a place he long envisioned, ready to show he belongs in the N.F.L.

title: Giffords Race Lacks Only the Candidate
description: PHOENIX  A Giffords for Congress campaign organization is in place, with a skeleton staff of strategists and fund-raisers and a sizable bank account. But what the re-election effort lacks is the most crucial element of all for success: an announcement by Representative Gabrielle Giffords that she is willing and able to run.

title: Out of the Ruins: Where Directors Landed

Here is a look at former Enron, Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers directors and their current occupations and public directorships.

title: Ex-Directors of Failed Firms Have Little to Fear
description: Do the former directors of the institutions that collapsed during the financial crisis have anything to worry about? If the experience of Enron is any example, the answer is a resounding no.

title: Gardner Makes It Hard to Take Him Out
description: At the beginning of this season, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had a plan. To ensure that the reserve outfielder Andruw Jones played enough, Girardi was going to occasionally rest the starters Curtis Granderson and Brett Gardner, slotting in Jones against left-handed pitchers.

title: For Faye Dunaway, Real-Life Role in Housing Court
description: She was a brazen bank robber in Bonnie and Clyde, the mysterious Evelyn Mulwray in Chinatown and a scheming television executive in Network, for which she won an Oscar.

description: Like voters everywhere, the people of Nassau County had watched helplessly as Congress and the White House played poker over the nations debt limit, with a potential fiscal and economic catastrophe hanging in the balance.

title: The New Hama Rules
description: What a difference three decades make. In April 1982, I was assigned to be the Beirut correspondent for The Times. Before I arrived, word had filtered back to Lebanon about an uprising in February in the Syrian town of Hama  famed for its water wheels on the Orontes River. Rumor had it that then President Hafez al-Assad had put down a Sunni Muslim rebellion in Hama by shelling the neighborhoods where the revolt was centered, then dynamiting buildings, some with residents still inside, and then steamrolling them flat, like a parking lot. It was hard to believe and even harder to check. No one had cellphones back then, and foreign media were not allowed access.

title: Teenagers Path and a Killing Put Spotlight on Mental Care
description: LOWELL, Mass.  Pericles Clergeau, a tall, sturdy teenager with a troubled past, did not much like it when Kevin Allard, a radiant, sometimes manic youth, arrived at Adolescent Unit 2 at the Westborough state psychiatric hospital early last year.

title: N.F.L. Said to Be Closer to Testing for H.G.H.
description: The N.F.L.s owners and players have figured out how to divide up their money, and have spent a busy week reconstituting rosters and renewing rivalries.

title: A Crisis Merely Postponed
description: LAST month, President Obama and Congressional leaders came close to an agreement that could have set our nation on a sound fiscal path, only to see deal after deal, compromise after compromise, collapse.

title: Gillibrand Broke With Party on Debt Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Breaking with her party, Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York was among six Democratic senators who voted on Tuesday against legislation that will cut trillions of dollars in federal spending and give the government new borrowing authority to avoid default.

title: CBS Reports Quarterly Profit More Than Doubled to $395 Million
description: Shrugging off the economic slump, the CBS Corporation on Tuesday reported that its profit had more than doubled in the quarter that ended June 30, far surpassing Wall Street expectations.

title: Washington Chain Saw Massacre
description: WASHINGTON

title: Smaller Gyms Struggle in a Search for Spaces
description: It took Barrys Bootcamp, an exercise chain based in Los Angeles that has whipped into shape celebrities like Britney Spears and Kim Kardashian, four years to find suitable space for its first New York City outpost. This summer the company opened a 3,200-square-foot studio on the ground floor of a Chelsea office building.

title: Hiding Behind the Budget Act
description: The Budget Control Act of 2011, which President Obama signed on Tuesday after Congress passed it by wide margins, is as contrived as the artificial crisis that spawned it. The bill, like a tired opera production, is full of clumsy staging and failed gimmicks left over from previous decades. It is not only bad policy in its goals of cutting spending too much, but it is bad procedure. It allows members of Congress to avoid responsibility for their actions through a cutout committee, a spending limit and the pretense that this Congress can tell the next one what to do.

title: Agnes Varis, Founder of Drug Company, Dies at 81
description: Agnes Varis, a daughter of threadbare immigrants who parlayed a chemistry degree and $50,000 into a profitable drug company, and in so doing became a prolific philanthropist whose causes included the Democratic Party, access to generic drugs and access to opera, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: A Career Sustained by Unwavering Faith
description: Jack McKeons baseball days begin in a pew. At 8 on Tuesday morning, the Florida Marlins manager attended Mass at St. Patricks Cathedral, less than 12 hours after his team beat the Mets on a 10th-inning grand slam. Such games are testament to his faith in the saint he prays to every game during the national anthem.

title: Spending Cuts Seen as Step, Not as Cure
description: WASHINGTON  There is something you should know about the deal to cut federal spending that President Obama signed into law on Tuesday: It does not actually reduce federal spending.

title: Snap and Send, and Learn More About Toyota
description: TOYOTA MOTOR SALES U.S.A. is adopting interactive bar codes across all its marketing so mobile phone-carrying customers can quickly access sales promotions, vehicle quotes, videos, safety tips and similar information.

title: Lottery Numbers

description: The Eagles have added a lot of talent recently, but as the Miami Heat taught us, talent does not equal a championship, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Airlines and Carbon
description: The worlds leaders should have reached a deal long ago to limit greenhouse gas emissions. In the absence of such a deal, the European Unions plan to regulate the carbon emissions of all airplanes that land or take off from European airports is a reasonable attempt to address an urgent problem.

title: Heat and Fasting Add to Woes of Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqis still live in a nation where bombings are a nearly daily occurrence, government paralysis is routine and corruption is de rigueur.

title: Politics and Prayer
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has underscored an essential boundary between church and state. In a 2-to-1 vote last week, the court found that the board of commissioners in Forsyth County, N.C., violated the establishment clause of the Constitution  Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion  by starting its meetings with prayers endorsing Christianity to the exclusion of other faiths.

title: Russia Reopens Tax Case of Lawyer Who Died in Custody
description: MOSCOW  Russian prosecutors said on Tuesday that they had reopened a criminal tax evasion case against a man who died in 2009  Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer who had accused police officials of corruption and then was arrested.

title: Corrections: August 3
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Voters Nix $400 Million Hockey Tix
description: Voters in Nassau County, showing far better sense and grasp of arithmetic than their elected leaders, have rejected a scheme to raise their taxes so their county could borrow $400 million to build a new hockey arena.

title: Battle for Libya | August 2, 2011
description: As rebels mourned the death of Gen. Abdul Fattah Younes in Libya, Muslims broke their fast with Iftar during Ramadan.

title: Killing of General Vexes Rebels in Libya
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  In a mourning tent for the Libyan rebels top military leader, who was assassinated last week in mysterious circumstances, relatives and members of his tribe warned on Tuesday of dire consequences, including violence, if rebel leaders did not move quickly to find his killers.

title: Telmex Offer Does Little for Shareholders
description: The Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Hels $6.5 billion tender offer for Telmex offers little for shareholders in his Amrica Mvil, the large cellphone carrier, to be happy about. Amrica Mvil is buying out the remainder of Telmex, the countrys shrinking landline business, at a premium valuation relative to its own. That looks like a bad exchange.

title: Aviation Club Secures a Home on Park Avenue, in a Space With Significance
description: In the 1950s, when commercial aviation was growing and space travel captured the American imagination, the Wings Club of New York settled into a first-class home. Over the next several decades, it was a congenial gathering spot for aviators, celebrities and even presidents.

title: Wednesday: Takes a Step Toward Biting
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Are you thirsty? How about a spot of T? How about a whole lot of Ts? Fifty-one of them, to be exact. Every entry in this puzzle, both Across and Down, has at least one T in it, and the theme is made up of three, two-word phrases where both words start with that letter.

title: On TV, if Not on Field, Big East Is Still a Big Deal
description: NEWPORT, R.I.

title: Debt Fight Over, Obama Promises Action on Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Having ceded considerable ground to Republicans in the debt ceiling fight, President Obama set out Tuesday to reclaim the initiative on the economy, promising a new effort to spur job creation while seeking to position himself as a proven voice of reason in an era of ideological overreach.

title: Offenses Escalate as Attacker on Upper East Side Is Sought
description: The most hunted man on the Upper East Side of Manhattan stands between 4-foot-10 and 5-foot-3 and spikes his hair with a considerable amount of gel.

description: Washington, Aug. 3, 1861

title: U.S. Seeks Pressure on Syria, but Options Are Few
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is facing intensifying calls to punish Syria more forcefully for its bloody crackdown on protests, but officials say that without broader international support they have few options to increase pressure on President Bashar al-Assads government.

title: As Chicagos Designated Hero, Slugger Strikes Out
description: CHICAGO  The biggest mystery in baseball this season is a friendly, 6-foot-6, 285-pound slugger with sandy hair, fire-hydrant biceps and the inscrutable nickname Big Donkey.

title: Rights Groups Contend Mexican Military Has Heavy Hand in Drug Cases
description: MONTERREY, Mexico  The marines barged in at dawn and grabbed her 27-year-old son, dragging him away with a look of fear frozen on his face, Maria del Socorro Maldonado said. He was rushed out clad only in orange shorts.

title: Republicans Seeking Election Remain Unsure About Embracing Tea Party
description: WASHINGTON  The success of Tea Party-backed lawmakers in defining the terms of the debt debate in Washington has further cemented the partys identity as part of a conservative movement insistent on deep spending cuts, lower taxes and smaller government.

title: Santana Setback and Blown Lead Create Bad Doubleheader for the Mets
description: Just five days earlier, Johan Santana pitched for the first time since having shoulder surgery in September, and even though the game was played in Port St. Lucie, Fla., and the Daytona Cubs were facing him, the results were encouraging.

description: Property sales could transform Cuba more than any other economic reform announced by the government of Ral Castro.

title: For Big Companies, Little Allure in AAA Ratings
description: Over the last three decades, fewer and fewer American nonfinancial companies have received Standard & Poors highest rating for long-term debt.

title: Cubans Set for Big Change: Right to Buy Homes
description: HAVANA  Jos is an eager almost-entrepreneur with big plans for Cuban real estate. Right now he works illegally on trades, linking up families who want to swap homes and pay a little extra for an upgrade.

title: In a Death, as in a Life, a Cloak of Mystery
description: Thomas Truex harbored a simple ambition, his relatives said: to treat the Earth kindly enough that no one would notice when he left it.

title: Politicians Open Front on Abortion in Bay Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Seeking to stem what they call misleading advertising, San Francisco officials on Tuesday began a two-pronged attack on crisis pregnancy centers, which are billed as places for pregnant women to get advice, but often use counseling to discourage abortions.

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/03/11
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/03/11

title: Norway: War Games and Toys Pulled From Shelves
description: Some stores in Norway are removing certain computer games and war toys from their shelves out of respect for victims of the recent killings on the island of Utoya and in Oslo, Swedish Radio News reported Tuesday. Coop, a supermarket chain, removed the online game World of Warcraft and about 10 other games; Anders Behring Breivik, who claimed responsibility for the murders, was a regular in talk forums for players of World of Warcraft.

title: The Jets Look to Regain Their Edge on Defense
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It took Mike Pettine, the Jets defensive coordinator, about six weeks before he could bring himself to watch the videotape of the teams A.F.C. title game loss to Pittsburgh. When he finally did, reliving all the deflating aspects  the Steelers punishing opening drive, a porous first-half rushing defense, Ben Roethlisbergers game-clinching third-down pass  Pettine remembered feeling as dumbstruck as he did that frigid evening at Heinz Field.

title: Italy: Panel Approves Measure Banning Face Coverings
description: An Italian parliamentary commission passed a draft law on Tuesday to ban women from wearing clothing that covers their faces in public. The draft would prohibit women from wearing any garment, including the burqa and niqab, that covers the face and makes it hard to recognize them in public. Under the proposed legislation, anyone forcing women to cover their faces would be fined and face up to 12 months in jail.

title: Islanders Future Blurred by Rejection of Plan to Pay for a New Arena
description: Charles Wang, the owner of the Islanders, said last week there was no Plan B if Nassau County, N.Y., voters rejected a plan to borrow $400 million to pay for a new arena for his team, a minor league ballpark and new convention space.

title: China: Party Newspaper Warns the Philippines
description: Chinas main Communist Party newspaper sharply warned neighboring nations on Tuesday against asserting their claims to territory in the South China Sea, responding to a news report that the Philippines was building shelter for troops on one of the disputed Spratly Islands, which the Chinese call the Nansha Islands. The commentary accused the Philippines of a little trick by building the shelter shortly after the Association of Southeast Asian Nations called for restraint in actions that might inflame territorial disputes.

title: Keep the Windows and Sunroofs Closed in Bearizona
description: Black bears are in abundance in Arizona, but they are not easy to spot. They scavenge for food over vast distances and generally keep to themselves. For a guaranteed glimpse of them, though, there is a place called Bearizona.

title: Giants Umenyiora Still Searching for New Contract, With Any Team
description: There was no resolution to the standoff between the Giants and the All-Pro defensive end Osi Umenyiora, but his agent, Tony Agnone, said Tuesday that quite a few teams have shown interest in Umenyiora, and he expected the situation to be sorted out quickly.

title: TimesCast | Mubarak To Stand Trial
description: August 2, 2011 - Egypt's ousted president Hosni Mubarak goes on trial Wednesday.

title: Greeting the Unthinkable: Mubarak on Trial
description: CAIRO  The headlines of newspapers on sale in a subway station once called Mubarak, and now renamed Martyrs', captured the moment Tuesday that could prove one of the most remarkable in modern Arab history: The pharaoh in the cage of the accused.

title: Record Numbers Are Receiving Food Stamps
description: The number of Americans receiving food stamps rose to a record 45.753 million in May, up 2.5 percent from the previous month, the Department of Agriculture said. Recipients of Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program subsidies for food purchases were 12 percent higher than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday in a statement on its Web site.

title: Harsh Report on Monitoring of Rapist
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Videos taken by the wife of the convicted rapist Phillip Garrido were released Tuesday by the El Dorado County District Attorneys Office, part of a scathing report on the failings of the criminal justice system in handling Mr. Garrido over the years.

title: How Chocolate Can Help Your Workout
description: For those who worry that fitness requires nutritional denial, there is good news, with caveats. Auspicious new science suggests that chocolate can have a surprisingly large effect on the bodys response to exercise, although not in the ways that many of us might expect, and certainly not at the dosages most might hope for.

title: Needing to Show Something, Hughes Gives Yankees Six Scoreless Innings
description: CHICAGO  With two outs in the bottom of the first inning Tuesday night, Phil Hughes took a breath, steadied himself and peered in against White Sox designated hitter Carlos Quentin, a slugger who has hit 20 home runs this season.

description: GENEVA  The almighty dollar used to be the worlds safest refuge in times of trouble. But what do you do when you are worried about the dollar, as many people are now?

title: At Mubarak Trial, Stark Image of Humbled Power
description: CAIRO  An ailing Hosni Mubarak, who had served longer than any other ruler of modern Egypt until a revolution toppled him in February, was rolled into a courtroom in a hospital bed on Wednesday to face charges of corruption and complicity in the killing of protesters, offering an indelible lesson for Egypt and the Arab world in the humbling of power.

title: When Rome Shuts Down in August, Where to Eat
description: Roman businesses generally shut down in August, as locals shutter their homes and shops and head to the sea for a few weeks, or even the whole month. But because of an increase in summer tourism, and especially the recent rise in staycations, a number of prominent restaurants have elected to stay open during the summer holiday season. This year, a handful of worthwhile culinary destinations will be open for the entire month of August. Here is a selection.

title: The Early Word: Next?
description: Todays Times

title: More Evidence That Supply Matters
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: For a Second Time, Honda Civic Misses Recommendation From Consumer Reports
description: Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, sends out a news release each month summarizing the automotive evaluations of the coming months issue. Rarely does the release generate significant attention, let alone a media scrum, but on Monday a preview of the magazines September issue contained a bombshell: the 2012 Honda Civic LX sedan scored so poorly during testing that the car did not make the magazines Recommended list.

title: Who Made Those NASA Logos?
description: The return of the space shuttle Atlantis to the Earths atmosphere two weeks ago marked the close of NASAs 30-year space shuttle program. Retirement of this popular and very visible shuttle program further strains the already diminished agency. Space experts say the best and brightest often head for the doors when rocket lines get marked for extinction, dampening morale and creating hidden threats, according to The Times. This is not the first time in NASAs history when the agency faced publicity troubles. Back in 1974, after the success of the Mercury and Apollo programs, but before the initiation of the Shuttle Program, NASA was convinced by the National Endowment for the Arts to participate in its Federal Graphics Improvement Program, and do what many companies these days do to revive their image: undergo a redesign.Up until that point, NASA had been primarily using an insignia adapted by James Modarelli, the head of NASAs Lewis Research Center Reports Division. This logo, created in 1959 and affectionately dubbed The Meatball, relied heavily on multiple visual metaphors. According to NASAs Web site, the sphere represents a planet, the stars represent space, the red chevron is a wing representing aeronautics (the latest design in hypersonic wings at the time the logo was developed), and then there is an orbiting spacecraft going around the wing. Although charming in its quirkiness, the meatball proved difficult to reproduce given the printing technology available at the time and the variety of applications it would need to adorn.

title: Security Firm Sees Global Cyberspying
description: SHANGHAI  An American cybersecurity company issued a report on Wednesday saying that it had identified a single perpetrator of cyberattacks that lasted up to five years on a wide range of governments, American corporations and even United Nations groups, and that the pattern of targets suggested the attacker was a state actor.

title: Video From the Trial of Hosni Mubarak
description: 12:15 p.m. | Updated The former president of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, was wheeled into an Egyptian court on Wednesday to face charges of corruption and murder in the deaths of protesters. A conviction could carry the death penalty.

title: Has Perky Jerky Lost Its Perk?

title: Officials Sent to Prison in Shanghai Tower Fire
description: SHANGHAI  A Shanghai court has sentenced nearly two dozen government officials, construction workers and contractors to jail for their role in a high-rise fire here that killed 58 people and injured 71 last November.

title: Japan Passes Law Supporting Stricken Nuclear Plants Operator
description: TOKYO  Japans Parliament passed a law on Wednesday that will allow the use of public funds to shore up the company operating the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, and help it pay what is expected to amount to billions of dollars in compensation claims.

title: Can the Debt Ceiling Genie Be Put Back in the Bottle?
description: If there was any doubt that Washingtons acrimonious debt fight created a new political reality, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky dashed it on Tuesday.

description: Socit Gnrale, the second-largest French bank after BNP Paribas, on Wednesday reported that income fell 31 percent in the second quarter compared with the period a year earlier, driven by a write-down on Greek sovereign debt.

title: Teaching Kids How to Break Up Nicely
description: Late last month, 200 teenagers from Boston-area schools gathered to discuss the minutia of Facebook breakup etiquette. Should you delete pictures of your ex after splitting up? Is it O.K. to unfriend your last girlfriend if you cant stop looking at her profile? And is it ever ethically defensible to change your relationship status to single without first notifying the person whose heart youre crushing?

title: The Words We Live By
description: Among the many things to marvel over in Talk to Me, a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art about how people and objects communicate, is a device called the communication prosthesis. Its a rigid mouthpiece that stretches the lips wide, exposing the wearers teeth and gums. It forces timid people to look as aggressive and unhinged as Heath Ledgers Joker in The Dark Knight.

description: Its been more than two weeks now since anyone has reported seeing Violet the red-tailed Hawk Cam hawk, mother of Pip, mate of Bobby.

title: Casting Aside World Criticism, Syria Invades Town
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Ignoring mounting condemnations, the Syrian military sent tanks, armored vehicles and snipers on Wednesday into the symbolic center of Hama, a rebellious city that has emerged as a linchpin of the nearly five-month uprising, in what appeared a decisive step by President Bashar al-Assad to crush opposition to his rule.

title: Countdown to a Nuclear Renaissance?
description: After hitting various bumps in the road, the design for the new Westinghouse AP-1000 reactor is approaching approval by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Congratulations to John Quiggin
description: The author of Zombie Economics has received a full sliming from the Murdoch empire. Thats a badge of honor. But if I were John, Id be careful; the zombies will eat his brain if they can.

description: Visitors to the city may know the routine: Arrive on an early flight. Do some window gazing on Fifth Avenue. Spend a night at an expensive uptown address.

title: A Place in the Shade
description: Summers heat wave has many of us running for cover. Here, cool portable cotton Sombrillas from the Australian company Hollie and Harrie are a delightful alternative to unwieldy stick-in-the-sand umbrellas. Designed by Skye Hollingsworth and Claire Harris, longtime friends,the cheerful beach tents fold up to roughly the size of a yoga mat and come with a clever matching carrying case.Clean lines, 95 percent UV protection and three pitch-perfect summer colors  Moroccan blue, French stripe and a sunny yellow  ensure that our last days of summer will be stylish and sunburn free.

title: British Arrest 6 and Seize 2,600 Pounds of Cocaine

title: Glaad Report Likes ABC Family Values
description: An annual report by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation commended the ABC Family cable channel for its representation of gay, lesbian and bisexual characters in its programming and for the racial diversity of those characters. In its fifth annual Network Responsibility Index, which Glaad issued on Wednesday, the organization gave a rating of Excellent to ABC Family, whose shows include Pretty Little Liars, The Secret Life of the American Teenager, Greek and Switched at Birth, and said that 55 percent of that channels 103 hours of original programming from June 2010 through May 2011 included LGBT-inclusive images. Herndon Graddick, the senior director of programs at Glaad, said in a statement, Viewers expect to see television environments that accurately reflect what its like to be a young adult, and today that includes young adults who happen to be gay.

title: Wednesday Reading: Obama Promises Action on Jobs
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Motion Picture Academy to Honor Oprah Winfrey and James Earl Jones
description: LOS ANGELES  Oprah Winfrey will receive the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award and the actor James Earl Jones and the makeup artist Dick Smith will receive honorary Oscars for lifetime achievement this year from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the academy said late Tuesday. The awards will be presented at a Governors Awards banquet, to be held in the Hollywood district of Los Angeles on Nov. 12. The academys governors, who give up to four special awards each year, did not grant an Irving Thalberg award for lifetime achievement by a film producer this year.

title: Australia Gripped by Story of Collar Bomb
description: 2:08 p.m. | Updated As images of the former Egyptian president in a courtroom cage transfixed much of the world on Wednesday, Australian television and online media were consumed by a bizarre and slowly unfolding drama in a suburban Sydney home.

title: California Air Resources Board Sees Reasonable Compromise in CAFE Standards
description: Proposed fuel economy standards for 2017-25 model-year vehicles, announced last week by President Obama, should reduce greenhouse gas emissions at a pace consistent with targets set by the California Air Resources Board, according to agency representatives.

title: Art Odyssey
description: A bit magically unpretentious, a bit Disney in its polished quaintness, Hydra, a car-free Greek island, has long been home to Athenian nobility and far-flung laureates alike: Leonard Cohen emigrated in the 1960s; Brice Marden has kept residences here since the 70s. But as of late, the island is perhaps best known to the art world as the site of the annual events of the ber-collector Dakis Joannous Deste Foundation, which were inaugurated three years ago with an epic performance collaboration between Matthew Barney and Elizabeth Peyton. This June, Deste hosted more than 300 international guests for Doug Aitkens video-enhanced stage show set on a repurposed freight ship, Black Mirror, starring Chloe Sevigny.

title: The Education of an American Soccer Player: Year 2
description: Hey, Tim Ream, youve played against two of the biggest and best teams  Manchester United and Arsenal  in English and world soccer in the past week. What do you do for an encore?

description: Over the past seven months, The Times reviewed several thousand pages of documents related to natural gas extraction, focusing on a case where hydraulic fracturing is believed to have contaminated a familys water well. The most important of the documents are provided here.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Former Directors of Failed Firms Have Little to Fear | A look at how onetime Enron directors have fared in recent years suggests that directors of institutions that collapsed during the financial crisis have little to fear. In fact, the Enron example indicates that the former directors of Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers will likely continue their prominent careers.

title: Its Over for Broadway Musical Baby Its You!
description: Mama said thered be days like this, but she didnt say that such a day would come so soon for Baby Its You! That Broadway jukebox musical, about the Scepter Records founder Florence Greenberg and her discovery of the girl group the Shirelles, will play its final performance on Sept. 4, its press representatives said on Wednesday.

title: A Tainted Water Well, and Concern There May Be More
description: For decades, oil and gas industry executives as well as regulators have maintained that a drilling technique known as hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, that is used for most natural gas wells has never contaminated underground drinking water.

title: How to Beat the High Costs of Dialing Abroad
description: ITS hard not to feel ripped off when you get hit with unexpected roaming charges while traveling abroad  whether they come from making phone calls or checking e-mail. Take it from Jeff Gardner, who received an $11,000 bill from Verizon after spending four days in Jamaica. Before the trip, Mr. Gardner, who runs a fly-fishing business in Grayling, Mich., said he called Verizon to find out what it would cost to use his cellphone for calls and his wireless air card to check e-mail on his laptop while in the Caribbean. He said he was told that calls would be about $2 a minute and that there would be no extra charges for data as he was on an unlimited plan. The latter part turned out to be wrong.

title: A Picture Book About Surviving Katrina
description: Can the enormity of a large-scale tragedy like 9/11, the Japanese tsunami or Hurricane Katrina be conveyed to school-age children without frightening them? How to describe the emotional toll without imposing a burden? Its a difficult balance.

title: Excerpt: 'Clybourne Park'
description: A scene from Bruce Norris's play "Clybourne Park" at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco. (Video: Flying Moose Pictures)

title: Basics of Accounting Are Vital to Survival for Entrepreneurs
description: Few people start a business because they are good with numbers. In fact, the terms accounting and financial analysis tend to put business owners to sleep or send them screaming from the room. But to run a business effectively, most owners need to have some understanding of their finances.

title: Notes From the Underground | Nightmare and the Cat
description: Its unusual for an opening act to outshine the headliner, but for Nightmare and the Cat its becoming par for the course. Led by the barely legal frontman Django James and his brother Samuel Stewart, the Los Angeles group is a rock n roll force to be reckoned with. With moves not seen since Elvis Presley last took the stage, James and his cohorts are utterly captivating to watch and bring an energy to their live show that is increasingly rare. Nightmare performed at Mercury Lounge recently, celebrating the release of their self-titled EP, and held a dancing crowd under their spell from start to finish. Their showmanship is a testament to the brothers rightful position in the royal court of pop music as the children of the Eurythmics Dave Stewart and Bananaramas Siobhan Fahey.

title: Mubarak Trial Rivets Egyptians
description: Egypts ousted president, Hosni Mubarak, was wheeled into a courtroom cage in a hospital bed on Wednesday, in an image few Egyptians thought they would ever see.

title: Do You Know Enough About Accounting?
description: In a small-business guide to accounting that weve just published, Darren Dahl writes about Bart Justice, who started a document-destruction business, Secure Destruction Service, in 2004. The business, based in Huntsville, Ala., grew from $70,000 in annual revenue its first year to $500,000 four years later. To finance his growth, Mr. Justice kept borrowing money from the bank, not realizing that the more he grew, the more he needed to borrow because his revenue was not covering his expenses. The loans meant he had money in his accounts  but it was borrowed money. I knew how to print a financial statement from QuickBooks, but I couldnt tell you what it meant, he said. It took the intervention of business owners in a peer group Mr. Justice joined to convince him that if he didnt master his finances he was going to lose his business.

title: Germany Investigating Facebook Tagging Feature
description: BERLIN  A German regulator said Wednesday that he had asked Facebook to disable its new photo-tagging software, saying he was concerned that its facial recognition feature amounted to the unauthorized collection of data on individuals.

title: Supervisor Held in Death of Autistic Man in S.I. Center
description: Updated, 1:49 p.m. | A supervisor at a state-run psychiatric center on Staten Island surrendered to the police on Wednesday to face homicide charges in the death of a 27-year-old man who was asphyxiated while being restrained last December, the authorities said.

title: Playing on a Bigger Court: Lysistrata Jones Taking Its Game to Broadway
description: Lysistrata Jones, a musical comedy about sex and college basketball that had a well-received production Off Broadway in the spring, will transfer to Broadway and begin performances on Nov. 12 and open on Dec. 14 at the Walter Kerr Theater, the shows producers said on Wednesday. The music and lyrics are by Lewis Flinn and the book is by the playwright Douglas Carter Beane, a three-time Tony Award contender who most recently shared a nomination in June for the book of the musical Sister Act.

title: Good Earnings and Perhaps Higher Prices From Sirius XM
description: Sirius XM Radio may raise its subscription fees next year, following the expiration of a federal rule that restricted its pricing, according to comments made by Mel Karmazin, the companys chief executive.

title: French Union Halts Help Into Inquiry in Jet Crash
description: PARIS  Air Frances largest pilots union suspended cooperation on Wednesday with investigators seeking to identify the causes of a fatal 2009 crash of a Rio de Janeiro-to-Paris flight, in protest of what it said was a decision by investigators to play down the role of the planes stall-warning system in an interim report last week.

title: Cherchez la Femme
description: Like corpses in a bad horror movie, the women in the D.S.K. scandal pile up behind every door and under every bed. But the woman behind the man, Anne Sinclair, has remained a somewhat shadowy figure. Vanessa Grigoriadiss piece in New York magazine, borrowing heavily from interviews in Le Monde, Le Nouvel Observateur and the biographyMadame DSK, which is currently available only in French,is filled with details of the marriage (both left spouses for each other; she prefers Paris, he their riad in Marrakesh; she broke off a friendship when her friend suggested D.S.K.s affairs were too numerous to be forgivable even by a Frenchwoman). It also reminds us of Sinclairs striking readiness, past and present, to stand behind and by her man, despite having a prominent career as a TV host and holding the purse strings.For those of you hankering for more of the other woman, its worth reading the account of one Marie-Victorine M. in the Daily Beast, who claims to have found D.S.K. irresistibly magnetic (their eyes met across a room and for four months they had a torrid affair), and yet who believes the account of the Sofitel maid is true. What convinced her? When I read the first articles in the American press containing for example the detail that he was supposed to have taken his presumed victim from behind, that encouraged me to believe this woman.

title: State Panel to Review Pay of Leaders at Nonprofits
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Wednesday the creation of a task force to investigate executive compensation at nonprofit organizations that receive taxpayer subsidies from the state.

title: The Global Food Crisis, Mapped
description: Oxfam, the antihunger group, has been running a campaign to call attention to the global food crisis, its consequences and its potential solutions. The Times outlined the challenge of future food security on a warming planet in this article several weeks ago, and this week my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman described the appalling famine unfolding in Somalia. The Somalia situation has a drought component, although the causes of the suffering seem to be primarily political.

title: N.R.A. Sues Over Bulk Gun Sales Rule
description: WASHINGTON  The National Rifle Association filed a lawsuit on Wednesday challenging a new federal regulation requiring gun merchants along the border with Mexico to report bulk sales of certain semiautomatic rifles, contending that the Obama administration exceeded its powers by imposing the rule last month without Congressional permission.

title: Lauren Ambrose Will Be Fanny Brice in Funny Girl
description: The actress Lauren Ambrose, best known as the rebellious Claire Fisher in the HBO series Six Feet Under, was not an obvious first choice for the Barbra Streisand role in the Broadway-bound revival of the musical Funny Girl. But a combination of acting skill, comic timing, singing talent  including the high belt that is critical for well-known numbers like Dont Rain on My Parade  and a quirky, surprising fearlessness (in the words of the director Bartlett Sher) helped win Ms. Ambrose the role, the revivals producers said on Wednesday.

title: Graphic Content | Typonine
description: Type specimen books are the plumbing-parts catalogs of graphic design. They show graphic designers the ways in which different sizes and weights of letters sit together as typeset words, and how they showcase typographic form and style. A specimen book enables a designer to visualize the mix and match new and old typefaces. Although digital type foundries now sell their fonts online, most still issue the occasional specimen books and booklets, as a nod to tradition.

title: New H.I.V. Cases Steady Despite Better Treatment
description: Despite years of great progress in treating AIDS, the number of new infections with the virus that causes it has remained stubbornly around 50,000 a year in the United States for a decade, according to new figures released on Wednesday by federal officials.

title: Panetta Issues Warning on Pentagon Cuts
description: Only a month into the job of defense secretary, Leon E. Panetta warned that a round of dangerous across-the-board defense cuts could compromise the countrys security if a Congressional panel does not reach consensus on ways to cut the deficit.

title: The Caucus | The President's Next Steps
description: Mark Landler discusses how President Obama is, again, turning his focus to jobs, and Jeff Zeleny looks at the votes of the debt deal.

title: Caucus Video: Obamas Focus on Jobs, and a Closer Look at Some Debt Votes
description: Mark Landler on how President Obama is, again, turning his focus to jobs. Also, Jeff Zeleny takes a closer look at the some votes on the just-passed debt deal. Some provide clues about the 2012 election.

title: More Talk of a Formula One Race in New York
description: The U.S. Grand Prix in Austin feels years away, but will run next year. The race in Indianapolis from 2000 to 2007 never took off. Now, before Austin has even happened, let alone proved itself, there is again talk of another Grand Prix in the United States  in New York.

title: Kutcher to Play a Billionaire on Two and a Half Men

title: Q. and A.: Whats So Funny in Brazil?
description: The Brazilian comedian Rafinha Bastos, recently named the most influential person in the Twitter universe, is spearheading a comedy explosion in his home country. He is part of a new generation of humorists out there who are acid, vibrant and clever, said lvaro Paes de Barros, the general manager for Viacom in Brazil, who is supervising the opening of Comedy Central there.

title: Russia Becomes a Magnet for U.S. Fast-Food Chains
description: MOSCOW  Earlier in his career, Christopher Wynne put his Russian expertise to work researching arms proliferation for the American government. Now hes engaged in geopolitics of another sort: deploying American fast food for the emerging Russian middle class.

title: Climate Change an Extra Burden for Native Americans, Study Says
description: Because tribal lands are particularly prone to drought, flooding, wildfires and other weather extremes, American Indian tribes suffer disproportionately from the impacts of climate change, a new study from the National Wildlife Federation and other groups reported Wednesday.

description: ROME  As markets continued to hammer Italy, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Wednesday rebutted calls for his resignation, saying Italys economic fundamentals were strong and pledging that his government was up to the task of fostering economic growth.

title: The Friend Should Be Euthanized; the Dog Should Pay the Vet Bills

The question up for debate was this: If while walking a friends dog as a favor, someone neglects to take the agreed-upon precautions  and if as a result the dog breaks free and mauls another dog  who is responsible for the damage? The dog walker or the dog owner?

description: A slide show depecting the removal of enlarged veins around the anus.

description: A two-bedroom penthouse with views of Lake Geneva and the Alps is on the market for $4 million.

title: Ankle Sprain
description: A slide show explaining the three types of ankle sprains.

title: Documentaries at Toronto to Include Premieres by Herzog, Wiseman and Spurlock
description: For documentary fans, this years Toronto International Film Festival will bring a variety of new films from familiar names. The festival said today that new work from Werner Herzog, Nick Broomfield, Morgan Spurlock, Frederick Wiseman, Alex Gibney and Wim Wenders will screen, many as world premieres.

title: The Manifesto of a Hedge Fund King
description: Dealbook's Evelyn M. Rusli and Azam Ahmed discuss Paul Singer's latest letter to investors. In it, he attacks U.S. and European government officials for fiscal recklessness.

title: Bruise Healing
description: A slide show explaining bruise healing.

description: A slide show depicting heart valve surgery, which is used to repair or replace diseased heart valves.

description: A slide show about heart transplants.

description: A slide show depicting an ear tube insertion.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Aug. 4
description: The Maison Martin Margiela capsule collection produced in collaboration with Opening Ceremony; store openings and sales in New York and more.

title: Graduate Teaching Jobs Harder to Find
description: Earning a doctorate while working as a teaching assistant sounds like a great deal: Get your Ph.D. for free!

title: Manhattan as Warhol Knew It
description: ON this summer afternoon, the Andy Warhols New York City Tour does not begin at any location where the artist lived, worked or partied. Instead, it starts at 1060 Park Avenue.

title: Huntsman Steps Up Critiques of Rivals
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Perhaps it was a measure of Jon M. Huntsman Jr.s struggles in his race for the Republican presidential nomination that when he arrived here for a meeting with Mayor Ted Gatsas, it was the mayor who showed up late.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Norway, the Philippines and Israel.

title: The Manifesto of a Hedge Fund King
description: DealBooks Evelyn M. Rusli and Azam Ahmed discuss Paul Singers latest letter to investors, and whether his views have greater significance for the world of hedge funds.

title: Is Dodd-Frank Overdue or Overkill? 2 Dueling Views
description: Will the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory overhaul thwart a future crisis?

title: Still Playing Catch-Up, Across the Economy
description: Given that the downturn began nearly four years ago, and that the population has grown significantly since then, the economy should instead be bigger than it was before the financial crisis. But Calculated Risk, a finance blog, makes a good observation: On most major measures of economic health, the economy is still worse today than it was before the recession began.

title: The Art of Being a Character
description: THE art-fashion crowd struck a cool pose at the opening party for On Shuffle, an indie rock-themed show at the Lehmann Maupin Gallery in Chelsea. Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth nonchalantly stepped around her installation, a circle of glitter on the floor. Cecilia Dean, a founder of the avant-garde fashion bible Visionaire, sailed in wearing a black Margiela jersey.

title: Homes for $680,000
description: An adobe house in New Mexico, a contemporary house in Minneapolis and a 1790 house in New Hampshire.

title: What You Get for ... $680,000
description: SHARON, N.H.

title: Face to Face
description: Images from the Talking Head series at Anthology Film Archives

title: Beauty Spots
description: ARCH ANGELS Blink, the chain of walk-in brow-threading bars found in British stores like Selfridges, Harvey Nichols and Space NK, has opened its first branch in the United States, at Henri Bendel. With two cream-colored nappa leather chairs for clients, the small salon also sells Blink products like a soothing pure rose gel ($45) and eyebrow pencils in five shades ($26). Eyebrow shaping costs $32, eyelash perming is $90 and a threading of the entire face is $110. Dread the thread? Consider Chella Brow Tool Kit, which comes with scissors, tweezers, a razor, brush and comb tool and a shaping guide ($40 at chella.com).

title: The Salahis Still Want In
description: SPOTTING Michaele Salahi at a recent polo match in Greenwich, Conn., was no easy task. In that crowd, a waifish striking blonde of a certain age  even one who stood at 5 foot 11 before slipping into her Louboutin heels  was not exactly an anomaly.

title: Giants Sign Another Andrews for Offensive Line
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants were not without the services of one of the N.F.L.s Andrews brothers for long.

title: TimesCast | August 3, 2011
description: A rare interview with Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader's son; the trial of the former Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak; and Syrian tanks enter Hama.

title: On Location
description: The 15th-century walk-up apartment, once with small, narrow rooms, was renovated to create the feel of a loft.

title: New York in Design and African in Dcor
description: FLORENCE, Italy  In a 15th-century, second-floor walk-up apartment here, Adam Gaon and Loredana Tarini have created a home where New York meets Africa.

title: Channeling Inner Peace, With Air-Conditioning
description: RUSSELL SIMMONS sat cross-legged, yogi style, in his wood-shingled portico, watching as the first guests strutted for the cameras. He was a lone beacon of Zen, as some 700 partygoers swarmed his estate in East Hampton, N.Y., last Saturday for the annual Art of Life Benefit.

title: PH-D
description: FOR those who have spent years absorbing life lessons from Entourage, PH-D is Xanadu: a glittering room of celebrities, beautiful women and cresting credit-card bills. The nightclub, which opened in June on the roof of the Dream Downtown hotel, is the latest endeavor from the impresarios behind Marquee, Tao and other successful playgrounds for the well heeled.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Fixing Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Philips Wins Energy Departments Lighting Prize
description: Philips, the Netherlands-based consumer electronics giant, is now $10 million richer, having just won the L Prize, awarded by the federal Department of Energy in a contest to invent the next generation of solid-state lighting.

title: Feuds: Hugh Hefner and Crystal Harris
description: THE breakup between Hugh Hefner and Crystal Harris quickly turned from amicable to ugly when Ms. Harris ended a round of press interviews by going on Howard Sterns radio show and telling him that she never saw her ex-fianc in the nude and that sex between them lasted like two seconds. As with many modern-day spats, the disintegration of the relationship was largely played out on Twitter.

title: Mubarak Spectacle Captivates the Middle East
description: Hosni Mubaraks televised trial transformed Egypt and much of the Middle East into a vast living room on Wednesday, with millions of viewers, from the shops of Amman and Jerusalem to the hovels of impoverished Yemen, mesmerized by the live broadcasts of a once-unthinkable spectacle beamed from a Cairo court.

title: Crispy Fried Chicken
description: Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to make succulent, delectable fried chicken.

title: Good Technique Means Great Fried Chicken
description: You dont need a recipe to make crunchy, juicy, excellent fried chicken. Its not about adding the right amount of this and a tiny pinch of that, or tossing in some secret ingredient (though a chicken is, of course, de rigueur). Great fried chicken depends above all on good technique.

title: Scene City: Russell Simmons and the Art of Giving
description: The hip-hop impresario holds his annual Art for Life benefit in the Hamptons.

title: Libya Allying With Islamists, Qaddafi Son Says
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  After six months battling a rebellion that his family portrayed as an Islamist conspiracy, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis son and one-time heir apparent said Wednesday that he was reversing course to forge a behind-the-scenes alliance with radical Islamist elements among the Libyan rebels to drive out their more liberal-minded confederates.

title: Hulu to Host Its First Original Series
description: For the first time, the online video Web site Hulu is going to be the exclusive home for a television-style series.

title: To Split or Not to Split
description: It felt to me like a whole new level of bungling was needed before I met my standard of a new entry for the Beekeepers Journal. Yes, I had lost both hives during an exceedingly cold snap in the preceding winter. Yes, I had gone through the process of ordering packaged bees from Georgia and had even managed the workaround of securing two northward-trucked hives when the Georgia apiaries delayed shipment because of a devastating southern winter. Yes, I had somehow installed the queens and hives, which involved the usual banging and subsequent pouring of nearly 3,000 bees into their new home, even though I was sure I had broken my hand earlier that day (a gangly kid on Nature Walk at school got tangled in my feet and dropped me to the pavement). Yes, I watched in June as a cluster of 10,000 bees swarmed from one hive and coagulated on a tree branch sixty feet above the ground. None of these events taken alone seemed to merit an instructive tale. It was the swarm, however, that lay the groundwork for my recent mid-Summer bungle.

title: Q&A: Beating the Heat and Saving the Battery
description: Q.

title: A Change in Taxes for Married Gay Couples
description: The state tax department has recently issued guidance for married gay couples. The New York Timess Tara Siegel Bernard gets into the details in her post on the Bucks blog. While gay couples in New York are now treated like any other married couple under the state tax law, things get more complicated when filing federal taxes. She writes:

title: Tiny Camera Performs Like a Pro
description: After 20 years, the digital camera makers are finally giving the world what it really wants: spectacular, professional-looking photos  from a tiny camera. Theres only one problem with this new category: nobody knows what to call it.

title: Made in Germany
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#477", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: A Climate Scientists View of a Famines Roots
description: Chris Funk, who is in the Climate Hazard Group at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and is affiliated with the U.S. Geological Survey, has a compelling commentary on the roots of the famine in southern Somalia on the Nature Web site under the headline We Thought Trouble Was Coming.*

title: Excerpt: Rafinha Bastos
description: An excerpt from the comedy act of Rafinha Bastos.

title: Dendreon Lowers Sales Projections for Provenge
description: Sales of Dendreons prostate cancer drug Provenge are falling well below expectations, forcing the company to abandon its financial guidance for the year and to cut its work force.

title: Housewives at Every Turn in the Hamptons
description: A LOT of people are secret Real Housewives fans, said Norah Lawlor, a Park Avenue publicist with an impressive Hamptons client list.

title: New BlackBerry Phones and an Almost-New Operating System
description: Research In Motion unveiled five new BlackBerry phones and a revised version of its operating system on Wednesday. But dont get too excited. Buyers still have to wait at least a year to get phones based on a truly new operating system, which, in the view of most analysts, will either make or break the company.

title: Excerpt: Rafinha Bastos
description: An excerpt from the comedy act of Rafinha Bastos.

title: Calculating the Real Age of Your Dog
description: Most people think that one dog year equals seven human years. But according to WebMD, your dogs real age is not that simple:

title: A Craigslist Experience That Is Better Than Craigslist
description: For many people, Craigslist is less of a Web destination than an addiction.

title: Suspect Identified in Purse-Snatching From Woman in Wheelchair
description: The police have identified the teenager they say snatched the purse of a wheelchair-bound 78-year-old woman on a Brooklyn street.

title: Top Adviser Leaves Pawlenty Campaign
description: Al Hubbard, a former Bush administration official who two months ago became a top policy adviser to Tim Pawlenty, has stepped down from Mr. Pawlentys presidential campaign.

title: Rivals in G.O.P. Struggle to Woo Bushs Donors
description: The calls come at least once a week these days, with growing urgency: friends of the Republican presidential candidates, aides to the candidates, and often the candidates themselves, wondering if Al Hoffman Jr. might be ready to lend a hand.

title: A Double Game Swing Missed, a Title Won
description: Two major titles were decided on Sunday, the last day of the Summer North American Championships in Toronto.

title: A Study of Time, Love and Decay in Genoa
description: The places we walk through are an excavation of memory  forbidden remembrances of a lost world, muses the unseen occasional narrator of Pietro Marcellos impressionistic, extravagantly poetic documentary The Mouth of the Wolf.

title: For a Harlem Theater, Hope Amid the Hurdles
description: The Henry V that begins this Friday in the newly renovated amphitheater at Mount Morris Park is quintessential Classical Theater of Harlem: a gritty, hyperactive production of a Shakespearean drama, featuring a mostly black cast. Not as apparent are the lofty ambitions this play (and the companys other plans) represent, or the daunting hurdles it faces.

title: Everybody Wants Her, Whoever She May Be
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Femme Fatale. Temptress. Sexy Assassin. Those were the verbal self-descriptions Britney Spears projected onstage at Nassau Coliseum here on Tuesday night.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: iPads for Pilots
description: Airlines are starting to see the iPad as a helpful tool for pilots. On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein chats with Alaska Airlines director of flight standards, Jim Freeman, about how its pilots are using the iPad in the cockpit. Mr. Freeman, who also flies for the airline, says that the device can serve as an electronic flight bag, allowing pilots to ditch many pounds of paper they have to carry  manuals, charts and other documents that must be on board the aircraft. He said pilots keep the devices on airplane mode during takeoff and landing.

title: Nature Paints Backdrop for City Ballets Stars
description: VAIL, Colo.  The only scenery for much of New York City Ballets repertory is a plain blue backdrop suggesting the sky. At the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater here, however, theres no backdrop. Visible behind the stage is a small rock garden and the steep pine-clad slopes of the Rockies. The auditorium and stage have side walls and a canopy, but what you remember are the gaps through which you see the mountaintops. The balletgoer who thinks he knows Jerome Robbinss Dances at a Gathering or George Balanchines Duo Concertant finds that he sees them anew in such a setting.

title: NYCB MOVES
description: Images of the dancers in the new company taken by fellow dancers in Vail, Colo.

title: Hey Kids! Robots!
description: New from Radica, a division of Mattel: Fijit Friends ($50 each, fijitfriends.com, for girls 6-9), a set of four chatty robots that can dance to music, detect voice prompts and hear sonic chirp codes embedded in videos or sites.

title: Mom and Dad and the Two Kids They Damage
description: The little boy and girl sing plaintively for a crowd. In front of them an open guitar case bears a handwritten note reading: Our dog needs an operation. Please help us save him. The audience members show sympathy for these two sad kids until, out of the blue, a man starts heckling. Youre terrible! he shouts. Suddenly, the scene turns contentious, split between cries of Keep playing, children and Dont quit your day job.

title: Where to Get the Worlds Best Service
description: International travelers weigh in on the level of service they experienced in 24 countries.

title: Excerpt: Mostly Mozart Festival
description: Louis Langre conducts the festival orchestra, with Christian Tetzlaff, violin, and Antoine Tamestit, viola, performing "Sinfonia concertante in E-flat major for violin and viola."

title: Judge Explains Letting a Reporter Protect His Source
description: A federal court on Wednesday unsealed a judges opinion from last week explaining why she had issued an order on July 29 largely quashing a subpoena to the writer of a book on the Central Intelligence Agency. The ruling protected the writer - James Risen, who is also a reporter for The New York Times - from testifying in the trial of a former C.I.A. official who is accused of leaking information to Mr. Risen about the agencys effort to sabotage Iranian nuclear research a decade ago.

title: Showcasing the Viola in Updated Mozart
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival opened on Tuesday night with its music director, Louis Langre, conducting the festival orchestra in a Mozart program amid the trappings that have re-energized this popular summer offering in recent seasons.

title: A Veteran Sideman Takes the Lead
description: Rufus Reid took the lead on just one tune in his early set at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night, but he made it count. Arms wrapped around his upright bass, he played If You Could See Me Now, the jazz ballad by Tadd Dameron, with a slow, sumptuous ease, applying a wide vibrato to most of his notes. His tone was hearty and resounding, and his technique nimble enough to seem utterly natural.

title: Where to Get the Worlds Best Service
description: International travelers weigh in on the level of service they experienced in 24 countries.

title: Three Receivers Are Seeking a Second Opportunity With the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants will give a wide receiver a second chance this season. It just wont be the one many fans wanted.

title: Sending Your Tunes Around the Home
description: Its a question as old as the hills: How do I move music off of my computer or smartphone and into the speakers in my house?

title: Summer at Camp Couture
description: COLOR wars at camp are a common American pastime, but the one that took place in a small building on East 53rd Street in Manhattan on a recent Tuesday was of a different stripe.

title: Fashion Camp
description: Young women forgo fresh air and campfires to create their own designs at Fashion Camp.

title: A Dashboard for Your Body
description: ONE recent morning, I woke up at 6:45, spent about 20 minutes preparing for the day (mainly this involves my persnickety multistep coffee-making process), and then strolled down the hall to my home office.

title: Facing the Loss of a Home, and a Quirky Experiment
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response) {data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: '+ data +', cropType: 'blog480', appendTo: 'embeddedSlideshow', showHeadLine: 'false'}

title: Security Council Rebuke of Syria Ends Prolonged Deadlock
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Security Council on Wednesday broke its protracted impasse over responding to the bloody repression of the protest movement in Syria, issuing its first denunciation of the violence there since the uprising began five months ago and putting the onus on President Bashar al-Assads regime.

title: The Tenant
description: Photos of a rehearsal of the latest site-specific work from the Woodshed Collective.

title: No Space Too Dilapidated for a Show
description: FOR about three years the West-Park Presbyterian Church, at the corner of 86th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, sat abandoned as architects, congregants and preservationists squabbled over a plan to build condominiums above the rosy, Romanesque Revival structure. When landmark designation last year quashed development plans, worshipers returned to a building much in need of repairs. In the parish house that abuts the chapel, paint peels, damp patches spread, and musty odors rise from the basement.

title: A Desert House That Soaks Up the View
description: A 1,200-square-foot house in Nevada looks out on an almost limitless landscape.

title: In the High Nevada Desert, Sleeping in Star-Surround
description: SCOTTYS JUNCTION, Nev.

title: KO, OK
description: On Keith Olbermann tonight.

title: At Mia Hamms Celebrity Challenge, the Hero Wore Cargo Shorts
description: WASHINGTON  A young man in a yellow polo shirt stood in the middle of the futsal court, surrounded by his family, and even with his sunglasses on, you could tell that he was crying.

title: The Truth About Fundamentals
description: Herewith I offer a fundamental law about fundamentals:

title: Hope Is Not A Plan
description: Nor is it good politics. So what the heck are they thinking?

title: Star Departs Roundabouts Death Takes a Holiday
description: The British actor Julian Ovenden, whose powerful tenor and leading-man looks positioned him as a star attraction in the new Off Broadway musical Death Takes a Holiday, has departed the Roundabout Theater Company production and will be replaced by an understudy, a Roundabout spokesman announced on Wednesday night.

title: Airline pilots using iPads; Cowon's Plenue D3 and C2 media players; Photo stitching; news
description: The iPad as the new best friend of pilots? Bettina Edelstein chats with Alaska Airlines's director of flight standards, Jim Freeman, about pilots using the iPad as an electronic flight bag. Yes, you can recapture that big wide view from your vacation trip. J.D. Biersdorfer explains how to make photo panoramas. Pedro Rafael Rosado, who can't stay away from portable media players, checks out two new ones from Cowon: the Plenue D3 and the smaller C2.
