The news roundup includes Adobe's preview of an alternative to Flash for Web designers; Android malware that can intercept phone calls; Verizon Wireless phones turning into digital wallets; iTunes movies and shows streaming on Apple TV; more on the Windows XP deathwatch. J.D.'s tip of the week: how to use search engine settings to filter unsavory query results.

title: 100 or So Danish Modernist Classics, on View
description: The prolific Danish furniture designer Hans Wegner created some of the best modernist design of the 20th century. And his collaboration with the master cabinetmaker Johannes Hansen, which began in the 1940s, resulted in a number of significant pieces. Now, about 100 are on display at Wyeth, in Wainscott, N.Y., an exhibition curated by John Birch, who owns this showroom and the Wyeth store in SoHo.

title: Sales at Angela Adams, Aero and Others
description: Angela Adams is offering 30 percent off one-of-a-kind prototype rugs, through Saturday, and 20 percent off every item online, with the checkout code SUMMERSALE, through Monday (the Canopy Indigo 8-by-10-foot hand-tufted wool rug, originally $1,800, is $1,260, pictured); information: (800) 255-9454 or angelaadams.com.

title: Michele Oka Doners Microscopic Wallpaper
description: When Michele Oka Doner was a teenager, her favorite book was Microbe Hunters by Paul de Kruif. I loved the microscope, said Ms. Doner, a Manhattan artist known for sculpture, furniture and home accessories that celebrate nature. My heroine was Madame Marie Curie.

title: Plastic Sharks in the Fountain: The Next Chapter in Greg Lynns Toy Story
description: Toys abound in the 1904 Craftsman-style home in the Venice district of Los Angeles that the architect Greg Lynn shares with his wife, Sylvia Lavin, and their two children. Vinyl Japanese action figures and vintage Godzillas crowd the shelves, and even the furniture, some of which Mr. Lynn designed, is playful, charged with color and much of it made of plastic.

title: Paper, Pleated and Clipped for Shelter
description: Molo, a Canadian company that makes furniture, lighting and a flexible partition system called Softwall, has created an indoor emergency housing system called Softshelter. The pleated paper partitions stand 6 feet high and expand as wide as 15 feet, connecting with other partitions to create a room that sleeps four. No tools are required for assembly, which takes about five minutes.

title: Finding the Potential in Vacant Lots
description: CLEVELAND

title: A Luggage Valet, Toughened With Steel
description: Jim Zivic, a furniture designer known for masculine pieces like tables carved out of chunks of coal and rugs with thick leather links, has turned his attention to the lowly luggage valet.

title: Looking for Rationality in Bond Markets
description: Demand for U.S. bonds has been strong, leading to ever lower yields. Graham Bowley speaks to Ajay Rajadhyaksha about why U.S. treasuries are still an appealing safe haven.

title: Cargill Recalls Ground Turkey Linked to Outbreak
description: Cargill, a major United States meat processor, said Wednesday that it was recalling about 36 million pounds of ground turkey produced at an Arkansas plant after it was linked to a nationwide outbreak of salmonella sickness. It appeared to be one of the largest meat recalls ever.

title: Photos Taken by the Cameras
description: New cameras from Sony and Olympus offer professional results despite their tiny size.

title: Christie Hefners Husband Is Accused of Insider Trading
description: The son-in-law of Hugh Hefner, the founder of Playboy Enterprises, was accused on Wednesday of trading in the shares of the magazine publisher with insider information.

title: Shopping for Magazine Racks With Carrier and Company
description: The interior designers Jesse Carrier and Mara Miller shopped for racks that can double as accent pieces.

title: Magazine Racks
description: TO keep abreast of design trends and new products, Jesse Carrier and Mara Miller, the husband-and-wife team behind the New York interior design firm Carrier and Company, read a lot of magazines. We have 12 or 13 subscriptions and try to page through everything, said Ms. Miller, 39.

title: A Scene From 'American Boy'
description: A scene from Martin Scorsese's "American Boy," featuring Steven Prince. (Martin Scorsese Collection)

title: Large Banks in Europe Struggle With Weak Bonds
description: LONDON  Ever since the European debt crisis began, the risk of contagion  of problems spreading from smaller countries to bigger ones, like Italy and Spain  has worried government officials and investors.

title: How Democrats Can Win Back Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Rory McIlroy Feels Americas Balmier Weather Calling
description: AKRON, Ohio  Rory McIlroy was not kidding after the British Open when he said he did not care much for the weather there and liked playing American-style golf courses better than Britains seaside links.

title: Hughes Takes Lead in Rotation Competition
description: CHICAGO  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had been evasive for days, refusing to commit to any sort of a plan for his two young starters, Phil Hughes and Ivan Nova, beyond the starts that each was scheduled to make this week. With six starters currently on the roster, Girardi had said he wanted to see each pitcher one more time before deciding which one would remain in the teams rotation.

title: Shark Feast for Viewers on Discovery
description: Its that magical time of year again. Sunday marked the beginning of the 24th annual Shark Week on Discovery Channel with the comedian Andy Samberg presiding over the festivities. Great White Invasion kicked things off for 3.3 million viewers, followed by Jaws Comes Home with 3 million, which was also good enough to make it the No. 2 program in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic on cable, trailing only HBOs True Blood.

title: Medical Device Approval
description: To the Editor:

title: Skewering Afghan Officials by Holding Up a Mirror
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the decrepit buildings that house Afghanistans ministries, one office is always new: the ministers. It is also often where corrupt deals are done, incompetence often reigns and favoritism is the primary currency.

title: Brands Now Direct Their Followers to Social Media
description: MARKETERS promoting their products online have followed a fairly standard arc historically, first buying digital ads and building their own Web sites in the early years of the Internet, and more recently amassing followers on social networks like Facebook and Twitter.

title: For Disabled Man Left in Van, Cause of Death Is Unclear
description: The dark Ford Econoline van sat on a busy avenue in East Harlem through a warm morning and well into a hot afternoon on Tuesday, with Alonzo Eason, a developmentally disabled man, slumping in the rear seat, according to police and state officials.

title: Pentagon Sounds Alarm on Threat of Budget Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon pushed back aggressively on Wednesday against what senior officials warned was the prospect of $1 trillion in military budget cuts and thousands of layoffs, furloughs and reductions in military programs over the next decade.

title: Taliban Hint at Interest in Negotiated Settlement
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban have begun to send signals that they are interested in a negotiated settlement, potentially offering an opening for the West and the Afghan government, several Western officials said.

title: Building in Flood Zones
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Pull Their Unhappy Defensive End Off the Market, for Now
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The trade window for the disgruntled defensive end Osi Umenyiora has closed.

title: Bluegrass Archetypes, With Gentle Voices of Ardor and Melancholy
description: Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, just before Bonita and Bill Butler, the dobro player Jerry Douglas tapped Alison Krausss shoulder and whispered something in her ear. She laughed a bit, then stepped ever so slightly away from center stage, so that Dan Tyminski, the guitar and mandolin virtuoso in her band Union Station, could take on lead singing duties for the song.

title: TimesCast | Qaddafi's Son Speaks
description: August 3, 2011 - In a rare interview, the son of Libya's Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi, Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, remains defiant.

title: Improving Maternal Care
description: To the Editor:

title: TimesCast | Syrian Tanks Storm Hama
description: August 3, 2011 - Syrian president Bashar al-Assad sends tanks into Hama to crush the opposition.

title: Actress Says She Cant Be Evicted Because She Moved Out
description: The day after court records revealed that Faye Dunaway would be joining the masses of New Yorkers braving housing court for a landlord-tenant showdown, it was time for the Oscar-winning actress to share her side of the story.

title: Conduct and Drug Policies Remain as Final Hurdles
description: The N.F.L. players union remained confident Wednesday afternoon that players would be able to vote to ratify a new collective bargaining agreement Thursday.

title: Bloggingheads: Where's the Fed?
description: Brad DeLong, left, of the University of California, Berkeley, and Brink Lindsey of the Kauffman Foundation debate the Federal Reserve and the bad economy.

title: Woman Says Her Uncle Was a Famous Hijacker
description: SEATTLE  Marla Cooper stepped forward Wednesday to claim that her uncle Lynn Doyle Cooper was the famed D. B. Cooper who mesmerized the world by hijacking a plane almost 40 years ago and bailing out somewhere over the rugged terrain of southwest Washington. His body was never found.

title: Daily Deal Web Sites Become Players in Their Own Deals
description: One maxim rings true in the burgeoning world of online coupons: Everybody wants a deal.

title: TimesCast | Mubarak's Trial Begins
description: Aug. 3, 2011  Hosni Mubarak, the ousted Egyptian president, in court on a hospital bed.

title: Immigrant Identities, Preserved in Vinegar?
description: TENSIONS over immigration in Europe are flaring this summer, along with questions about what  whether language, dress or diet  makes a foreigner a citizen. Of course, these questions also have a long history in America.

title: Worry Grows Over Delays in F.A.A. Pay
description: WASHINGTON  Airport operators said Wednesday that a prolonged delay in restoring federal funds for airport construction projects would eventually endanger airport safety and lead to more passenger delays.

title: Bloomberg to Use Own Funds in Plan to Aid Minority Youth
description: The administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in a blunt acknowledgment that thousands of young black and Latino men are cut off from New Yorks civic, educational and economic life, plans to spend nearly $130 million on far-reaching measures to improve their circumstances.

title: Bill Bergens Awesome Record of Baseball Futility
description: Todays lesson, gleaned from baseball history, is that if you are going to be bad at something, be spectacularly bad. And if you are spectacularly bad enough, people might be talking about you 100 years after you retire.

title: In Israel, the Rent Is Too Damn High
description: Tel Aviv

title: Battling Longer Odds, but Still Courting Fans
description: AKRON, Ohio  When Phil Mickelson pulled into a tie for the lead by playing the front nine at Royal St. Georges Golf Club in five under par three Sundays ago, he looked very much as if he was about to win his first British Open.

title: Iraq to Open Talks With U.S. on Troop Presence Past 2011
description: BAGHDAD  American officials said Wednesday that an announcement by the Iraqi government that it was ready to open formal discussions with the United States about keeping some troops in Iraq after the end of the year was a positive first step toward resolving the question about the American militarys future presence here.

title: With Rally, Christian Group Asserts Its Presence in 12 Race
description: TUPELO, Miss.  To its admirers on the religious right, the American Family Association is a stalwart leader in a last-ditch fight to save Americas Christian culture and the values of traditional families. To its liberal critics, it is a shrill, even hateful voice of intolerance, out to censor the arts, declare Muslims unfit for public office and deny equality to gay men and lesbians because they engage in sinful aberrant sexual behavior.

title: New Breed of Leaders Helped Guide Fuel Standards, Chrysler Says
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich.  New leadership from outside Detroit was a deciding factor in the Big Three automakers acceptance of strict new fuel-economy standards, the chief executive of Chrysler said Wednesday.

title: Alex Rodriguez to Be Asked About Poker Games
description: Once again, officials for Major League Baseball want to meet with Alex Rodriguez. This time, though, it is not about performance-enhancing drugs. In the coming weeks, baseball officials plan to question Rodriguez about reports of his participation in illegal poker games.

title: Celebrating the Girls of Summer
description: As the millions of readers who made The Help a publishing phenomenon know, the novel explores the poignantly modest aspirations and profound humiliations of black maids in Mississippi in the 1960s. Its a story of racial injustice, reconciliation and sweet, overdue revenge.

title: Bubba Smith, N.F.L. Star and Actor, Dies at 66
description: When hearing tales of Bubba Smith, you wonder, is he man or myth? Ogden Nash

title: Scoring Outside the Lines
description: I.

title: For High-End Goods, a Recovery
description: Apparel stores are struggling to get customers to spend, even with sales and coupons. But luxury retailers are beginning to raise prices to pre-recession levels.

title: Who Will Help the Syrians?
description: As many as 1,600 courageous Syrians have been slaughtered since pro-democracy demonstrations began in March. On Wednesday, after three days of shelling, President Bashar al-Assad ordered his military to storm Hama, the city where his father killed up to 20,000 people three decades ago.

title: Corrections: August 4
description: FRONT PAGE

title: New Jockeying in Congress for Next Phase in Budget Fight
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans and Democrats maneuvered for advantage on Wednesday in the next battle over federal spending, trying to influence the choice of members and frame the agenda for a powerful supercommittee that is supposed to recommend at least $1.5 trillion of additional deficit reduction measures.

title: Rainout Means Mets Dont Lose
description: The Mets did not end their four-game losing streak Wednesday night, but not because of any bullpen meltdowns or fielding gaffes: their scheduled game against the Florida Marlins at Citi Field was rained out.

title: Even Marked Up, Luxury Goods Fly Off Shelves
description: Nordstrom has a waiting list for a Chanel sequined tweed coat with a $9,010 price. Neiman Marcus has sold out in almost every size of Christian Louboutin Bianca platform pumps, at $775 a pair. Mercedes-Benz said it sold more cars last month in the United States than it had in any July in five years.

title: Why Do Russians Hate Ice?
description: A Russian acquaintance of mine who grew up in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, recently told me that her father microwaved his orange juice. Her grandmother also used to heat her ice cream in a saucepan on the stove. She remembers once asking her grandmother why it was even called ice cream, when by all rights it should be called warm cream, or maybe hot cream. Things have all kinds of crazy names, her grandmother snapped back. How should I know?

title: Seeking Balance on the Mideast
description: Congress periodically showcases the warts of democracy, occasionally even the deformities and disfigurements, and it might seem difficult to top the latest debt ceiling horrors. But theres one area where Congress has been even more obstructionist: the Middle East.

title: The Down Side of Corzines Promise
description: Jon Corzine makes no secret of the fact that politics is his passion. Now buyers of debt in MF Global, the firm he runs, are set to get a boost if the former Democratic politico and Goldman Sachs chief should leave the broker-dealer to decamp to Washington.

title: To Fight Radical Islam, U.S. Wants Muslim Allies
description: WASHINGTON  Rolling out a new strategy for combating radicalization, White House officials on Wednesday warned that casting broad suspicion on Muslim Americans is counterproductive and could backfire by alienating a religious minority and fueling extremism.

title: Time Warner Reports 10% Revenue Increase and Raises Its Outlook
description: Time Warner, the owner of Warner Brothers, Turner Broadcasting and Time Inc., on Wednesday reported a 10 percent rise in revenue for the quarter that ended in June  its highest growth rate since 2007  and slightly revised upward its earnings guidance for the year.

title: Obama, on Verge of 50, Returns to Fund-Raising
description: CHICAGO  For many men, turning 50 can be a day of reckoning, marked by graying hair, a slowing step and the wistful recognition that you are probably never going to make it to the corner office. What could be better, at such a melancholy moment, than to celebrate at home, among old friends?

title: Lottery Numbers
NBCUniversal Helps Lift Comcasts Quarterly Results
description: It has been six months since Comcast gained control of NBCUniversal from General Electric, and the Comcast chief executive Brian L. Roberts says he continues to believe that our timing was just right.

title: The Woods Watch Turns Into Rubbernecking
description: Ending a three-month layoff, Tiger Woods will return to competitive golf Thursday, beginning the latest in a series of long-shot comebacks since 2009, a time in which his golfing empire has been battered by scandal, his loyal entourage purged and his once-exemplary physique betrayed by serious injury.

title: Medtronic Giving Yale Grant to Review Bone Growth Data
description: Facing intensifying scrutiny over one of its bone growth products, Medtronic announced Wednesday that it was giving a $2.5 million grant to Yale to oversee a complete review of the study data that examined the products safety and effectiveness.

title: Thursday: Beginning to Knock
description: Administrivial Out of Town Alert! Did you know that when you send your kids to sleep away camp, they actually make you take them back?? Neither did I, but thats where Im headed this weekend, and comments will be temporarily moderated by some lucky, lucky staffers at The New York Times. Please be patient with them, and I will see you all Sunday evening for the Monday post.

title: To Relieve Tension, Mind the Spine but Do Not Relax
description: Michael Ostrow was studying Buddhism at the San Francisco Zen Center, searching for a career that dovetailed with his philosophy degree from Brandeis University, when he began to experience severe back pain during meditation sessions. A fellow student told him about the rejuvenating properties of the Alexander Technique, and after several lessons, he switched from Zen to studying the technique and ultimately trained to teach it. Mr. Ostrow, 55, and his wife, Laurie Kline, 54, a dancer turned Alexander instructor, have run the New York Center for the Alexander Technique near Union Square since 1990. They live in North Bergen, N.J.

title: The F.A.A., After the Republicans
description: Here is what has happened since the Federal Aviation Administration lost its authorization on July 23, courtesy of House Republicans. The agency has not collected more than $300 million in taxes (money the airlines have mostly pocketed). It has had to furlough some 4,000 workers and halt construction projects worth $11 billion in 241 airports, putting 70,000 more people out of work.

title: A Precedent for Press Freedom
description: Faced with prosecutorial demands to know journalists confidential sources, judges bow too often to the governments wishes without considering carefully enough whether a need for the information to make the governments case outweighs the needs and rights of reporters and an informed public.

title: New York and the Eighth-Month Lull
description: Where is the August of yesteryear? It seems almost mythical now, that leisurely month when Manhattan emptied out like a scene from The Seven Year Itch. In those days, the weekend annexed Mondays and Fridays, and the business cycle pulled over to the curb and lowered its kickstand. Book publishing shut down almost entirely, and the citys psychiatrists trooped away from their couches for the month. The days were torpid, and, at night, a martini moon hung in a seersucker sky.

title: Indian Point May Enlist Giuliani as Defender
description: This has been a tough year for the long-beleaguered Indian Point nuclear plant. In January, a longtime critic, Andrew M. Cuomo, was sworn in as governor, and proceeded to push for the facility to be shuttered because of its proximity to New York City and its susceptibility to earthquakes and terrorist attacks. Then, in March, a tsunami precipitated a reactor meltdown in Japan, stoking new fears about the safety of nuclear power plants, especially those near population centers.

title: Pfizer Is Said to Pursue Nonprescription Lipitor
description: Pfizer hopes to introduce an over-the-counter version of Lipitor, the worlds best-selling drug, after it loses patent protection in November, a person close to the situation said Wednesday.

title: Pressured by White House, Treasury Secretary Is Expected to Stay at Post
description: WASHINGTON  Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary and dean of President Obamas economic team, is expected to stay through the presidents term after intense White House pressure, according to officials familiar with the discussions.

title: The Mets Latest Problem: Finding a Position in the Field for Murphy
description: The steady, unexpected resurgence of Daniel Murphy, in which an extraneous player has transformed himself into an essential one, has provided the Mets with a welcome story line in a season in which they are battling to stay relevant.

title: Network That Preyed on Children Is Broken
description: WASHINGTON  Federal investigators announced on Wednesday that they had dismantled a sophisticated global network of pedophiles who traded pornographic videos and images of children as young as infants over the Internet, using encryption and proxy servers to evade detection.

title: Swedish Nationalists in Struggling City See Rival Parties Steal Their Thunder
description: LANDSKRONA, Sweden  The Ahlgren family in this struggling industrial city offers one lens to view both the festering anger that has fueled the rise of anti-immigrant parties in Europe, including Scandinavia, and the potential for a backlash.

title: Obama Takes Steps to Help Avert Atrocities
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, looking for ways to strengthen the American response to genocide and other mass atrocities, on Thursday will announce a ban on visas for people who the State Department finds have been involved in human rights violations, White House officials said.

title: Battle for Libya | August 3, 2011
description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said Wednesday that he was reversing course to forge a secret alliance with radical Islamist elements among the Libyan rebels.

title: France: Noriega Extradition Approved
description: France approved the extradition of the former dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega to his native Panama, an official at the prime ministers office said Wednesday. According to his lawyer, Yves Leberquier, Mr. Noriega will not be extradited before September. Last year, Mr. Noriega, left, who ruled Panama from 1983 to 1989, was sentenced by a French judge to seven years in prison for laundering $3 million in Colombian drug money through international banks and into French accounts. He had previously been jailed in Miami on charges that included cocaine trafficking. The government of Panama has requested that Mr. Noriega be extradited from France in order to serve three 20-year prison terms for human rights abuses and involvement in the disappearance of political opponents.

title: Japan Buys Dollars to Weaken the Surging Yen
description: TOKYO  Japan said Thursday that it had intervened in the foreign exchange market, selling yen and buying dollars in a bid to reverse a punishing spike in the value of the Japanese currency.

title: Death of Homeless Man After Beating by Police Stirs Outrage
description: LOS ANGELES  In one video, the sound of a Taser going off is followed by a man screaming in pain. In another, footage from a security camera on a public bus, riders describe police officers beating a man to death in graphic terms. They beat him up, and then all the cops came and they hogtied him, and he was like, Please God, please Dad!, one said.

title: Gay Candidate Drops Out of Irish Presidential Race
description: David Norris, a frontrunner for Ireland's presidency who is openly gay, dropped out of the race on Tuesday, after it was revealed that he once appealed for clemency for a former partner who had been convicted of the statutory rape of a 15-year-old boy.

title: A Do-It-Yourself Green Home
description: Jerome Johnsons house in Flatbush, Brooklyn, is an artifact of do-it-yourself green architecture. However, he is about to lose it to foreclosure.

title: Collar Bomb Was a Fake, Australian Police Say
description: After the police in Sydney, Australia, spent 10 hours trying to free an 18-year-old from what she had been told was a bomb chained to her neck, as we wrote here on Wednesday, officials said the device contained no explosives. The Associated Press reports that tests revealed the bomb was a fake, according to Mark Murdoch, the assistant commissioner of the New South Wales police.

title: Yankees Rise Above Burnetts Shortcomings to Rout White Sox
description: CHICAGO  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had been evasive for days, refusing to commit to any sort of a plan for his two young starters, Phil Hughes and Ivan Nova, beyond the starts that each was scheduled to make this week.

title: White House Names a New Chief of Information Technology
description: Steven VanRoekel, a former Microsoft executive, will become the next chief information officer for the federal government  a bigger, more policy-oriented technology job than any he held at the software giant.

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/04/11
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/04/11

title: Senator to Block a Confirmation
description: Senator David Vitter, a Louisiana Republican, said Wednesday that he would block the confirmation of an Interior Department official until the government extended leases for oil exploration in the Gulf of Mexico. Mr. Vitters spokesman said he wanted a blanket extension of all leases that expire this year to compensate for delays from last years oil spill; until then, the senator will block confirmation of Rebecca Wodder as assistant secretary for fish and wildlife and parks. The Interior Department has issued instructions on seeking more time on the leases; a spokeswoman said the administration had not declined requests for extensions so far.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,672 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Double Dip or Not, Economy Is Falling Further Behind
description: While Washington was busy debating whether or not to sabotage the recovery by failing to raise the federal debt ceiling, the economy seemed to be doing everything in its power to demonstrate that its in feeble health to begin with.

title: Joining Switzerland, Japan Acts to Ease Currencys Strength
description: TOKYO  As global investors flee the dollar and euro for refuge in stronger currencies, those havens have started to send out a message: enough.

title: Japans Prime Minister Fires Three Nuclear Energy Officials
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Naoto Kan removed three top officials in charge of Japanese nuclear energy policy on Thursday, taking aim at the cozy ties between regulators and the power industry that were exposed after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant accident.

title: Where Children Sleep
description: If your computer permits you to view these photographs in full-screen mode, we recommend it.

title: Gay Pride Festival Comes to Prague
description: Starting Aug. 10, Prague will hold its inaugural gay pride festival with a tag line that nicely sets the tone: Drink Beer, Be Queer!

title: Moving China Up the Value Chain
description: SHANGHAI  In Run of the Red Queen, a new book about Chinas innovation drive, Dan Breznitz and Michael Murphree lay out a contrarian view of this countrys path. They argue that China should worry less about coming up with breakthrough technologies and focus more on what it already does best: making incremental innovations in everything from manufacturing to logistics.

title: The Early Word: Moves
description: In Todays Times:With the United States clear of imminent fiscal crisis, the markets are watching Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner. Jackie Calmes reminds us that Mr. Geither has said he would decide whether to stay with the Obama administration after the White House and Congress reached a deal to raise the debt ceiling. Ms. Calmes says President Obama wants Mr. Geithner to stay through 2012, and the secretary is expected to oblige. Just in case that changes, she looks at potential replacements if he leaves.

title: Kraft to Split Its Snacks and Grocery Businesses
description: 7:39 a.m. | Updated Kraft Foods said on Thursday that it would spin off its North American grocery business from its global snacks group, a decision that comes 18 months after it bought Cadbury, the European candy maker.

title: Remembering Bubba Smith, the Football Player
description: A few thoughts about Bubba Smith, who died yesterday at 66. He may be best remembered today as an actor and television pitchman. But he made his name on the football field, first at Michigan State, then as a Baltimore Colt. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down.

title: BMW Guggenheim Lab: A Showcase for Urban Culture, and Carbon Fiber, Takes Shape in New York
description: Wednesday was the first public day for a novel building tucked between older structures on Manhattans Lower East Side. But the BMW Guggenheim Lab, a pavilion of video screens and gathering spaces aimed at investigations of urban life, barely looks like a building at all.

title: This, I Believe, Says It All
description: Spotted on 95th and Amsterdam.

title: Can IndieReader.com Muster Enough Traffic to Sustain a Business?
description: Last week, I asked you to take a look at Indiereader.com, a site dedicated to fans of independently published books and the authors who produce them.

title: A Single Voice, a Single Face, a Single Story
description: ON screen just as on the stage the monologue lets us zero in on one characters psychology and worldview. But the technique is usually selectively applied, temporarily isolating one player from the larger context of other actors and the production as a whole. Rarer is the film that, start to finish, is a one-person show: an extended aria, trading a scene-to-scene narrative for solitary storytelling and eschewing landscapes and sets for the power of one face and body.

title: River Sand in Bedrock
description: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

title: G.M.s Profit Jumps 89% as U.S. Sales Grow Quickly
description: DETROIT  General Motors built surprisingly strong second-quarter results on the most basic automotive arithmetic  higher prices plus lower incentives.

title: Debt Talk Over, Republicans Head to Iowa
description: After weeks of the all-consuming debt debate in Washington, the political conversation is about to take a sharp turn back to the 2012 presidential election as Republicans gather in Iowa for the first real test of momentum and organization.

title: Pacific Islands Band Together on a Shark Sanctuary
description: As Americans tune in to TV programs like Top 5 Eaten Alive and Jaws Comes Home as part of Discovery Channels Shark Week, leaders in the western Pacific have taken a big step toward nurturing the predator: deciding jointly to create the largest shark sanctuary in the world.

title: Skepticism Over Indias Anticorruption Bill
description: NEW DELHI  After a four-decade battle, Indian lawmakers took the first formal step toward creating an independent anticorruption agency on Thursday, introducing a bill in Parliament that would appoint a powerful ombudsman, or Lokpal, to investigate wrongdoing by government officials.

title: A Brazilians Comic Mania: Social Media
description: SO PAULO, Brazil -- When an Internet research group recently released a study concluding that the most influential person in the Twitter universe was Rafinha Bastos, a Brazilian comedian who came in well ahead of President Obama, Conan OBrien and Kim Kardashian, the English-speaking world was predictably baffled. Who is @RafinhaBastos? Wired magazine asked.

title: Supplying Brazils Laugh Track
description: var mmVideoPlayerOptions = {autoPlay : false,controlsBelow: true,fullScreen: false,skin: "light"};var mmVideoPlayer = new NYTMM.VideoPlayer($("embed365"),480,270,null,mmVideoPlayerOptions);mmVideoPlayer.setSources(['100000000981079','']);mmVideoPlayer.setPoster('http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2011/08/03/arts/bastos/bastos-blog480.jpg'); SWFObject.dispatchEventToSWF('nytmm_flashVideoPlayer0',{type:'setcaptions',url:'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/arts/20110803-artsbeat-movie-captions/movie2srt.xml'});Rafinha Bastos is a ringleader of sorts for a diverse group of Brazilian comedians who are irreverent and fearless. Theyre not afraid to do social criticism and commentary, said lvaro Paes de Barros, the general manager for Viacom in Brazil, who is supervising the start of Comedy Central there. Really, they are quite gutsy.

title: Dear FloFab: My Friends Dump Their Stuff on My Counters
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Earnings at Fortress Drop 37%
description: The Fortress Investment Group, the publicly traded alternative asset manager run by Daniel H. Mudd, reported that earnings declined nearly 37 percent in the second quarter, as some hedge funds were hit hard by a volatile global trading environment.

title: I.M.F. Chief to Face French Investigation
description: PARIS  A French court on Thursday ordered an investigation into charges that the International Monetary Funds new managing director, Christine Lagarde, had abused her authority in a 2007 dispute involving a multimillion-dollar payout to a French tycoon while she was the finance minister of France.

title: Wrong And Right
description: Bruce Bartlett and others send me to this eloquent David Frum piece, which concludes:

title: Why People Say Eeh! When They Learn About the ECB, Redux
description: ECB to halt rate hike cycle, pressured on bond buys.

title: Sonia Gandhi in the U.S. for Operation
description: NEW DELHI  Indias most powerful politician, Sonia Gandhi, has flown to the United States for surgery, said a spokesman for the governing Congress Party, which Mrs. Gandhi leads.

title: New Yorks Ultimate Clock Watcher (and Painter)
A Better Way to Keep Patients Safe
description: Not long ago, a few colleagues and I were discussing the challenges of improving health care quality and patient safety. We debated the merits of clinical benchmarks that payers and regulatory groups now require, crude proxies of quality care like giving antibiotics at certain times, ordering specific tests at set intervals or permitting our results to be reported publicly.

title: Nicholson Baker: The Mad Scientist of Smut
description: Nicholson Baker does not look like a dirty-book writer. His color is good. His gaze is direct, with none of the sidelong furtiveness of the compulsive masturbator. He wears round, owlish glasses, and in early book-jacket photographs, when his beard was darker and more closely trimmed than it is now, he reminds you of one of those earnest Russian intellectuals of the 19th century. Nowadays, with the beard grown out and nearly white, he could easily get seasonal work as a shopping-mall Santa.

title: A Movable Feast: Danny Meyer on a Roll
description: Danny Meyer scaled the subway stairs two at a time, emerged on Lexington and 77th, lengthened his stride and called over his shoulder: Have I told you about the Meyer Street-Crossing Method? Meyscrom. He scanned traffic. Cut off every possible angle without being killed.

title: The Weight
description: Since their debut record, North Hills, came out two years ago, the Los Angeles-based folk-rock band Dawes has been eliciting breathless comparisons to some pretty illustrious names  Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, the Eagles, the Band. Partly it has to do with their origin myth: they recorded the album at the renowned producer Jonathan Wilsons studio in Laurel Canyon after playing a run of small hootenannies there. But mostly it has to do with their sound, which has a warm, stripped-down Americana feel frequently described as vintage. Recently, the group got about as big a nod as four guys playing folk rock could hope for: Robbie Robertson, the somewhat reclusive songwriter from the Band, asked them to back him in a series of rare performances. Now in the middle of an East Coast tour to promote their follow-up record, Nothing Is Wrong, which was released this summer, Dawes seems both honored and amused to have been credited with leading a revival of the Laurel Canyon sound.

title: Morning Buzz
description: For more local news from The Times, including Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs partly self-financed plan to aid minority youth (announced after Mr. Bloomberg and donors he gathered saved January Regents exams), the Indian Point nuclear plants potential advertising campaign starring former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Faye Dunaways insistence that she has not been evicted, see the N.Y./Region section.

title: Concrete Tests Faked Again, Officials Charge
description: In 2008, a company hired to test the strength of the concrete used at major public works projects in New York, including the Second Avenue subway and the new Yankee Stadium, falsified results, prosecutors concluded, and construction executives scrambled to find a replacement.

title: Cleaning Up After the Storms
description: In Alabama and Missouri, residents and government agencies face the daunting task of removing the debris from this years tragic abundance of tornadoes.

title: The Cleanup Grinds On for Months After Disasters
description: Mother Nature is not like typical moms who tell their kids to clean up their messes. Mother Nature makes messes, and big ones.

title: The Alternate Lives of Lauren Ambrose
description: Scientific theory and philosophy suggest that an infinite number of alternate realities may be possible, and that a new universe is created at every decision-making juncture in our lives, no matter how small or significant. And the above video suggests that in at least one such universe, the onetime Star Search contestant Lauren Ambrose grew up not to be the dark, complicated soul we know from the HBO series Six Feet Under but instead some sort of latter-day answer to Shirley Temple. (What was it that steered Ms. Ambrose as we know her off this trajectory? Was it being stuck in a bathroom with Seth Green in Cant Hardly Wait?)

title: Stocks Plunge on Fears of Global Turmoil
description: What began as a weak day in the stock markets ended in the worst rout in more than two years, as investors dumped stocks amid anxiety that both Europe and the United States were failing to fix deepening economic problems.

title: What Does Buffett Think?
description: Warren E. Buffett lodged plenty of complaints last year when Kraft moved to buy Cadbury. But the billionaire investor told CNBC that he had no problem with the companys decision to split in two.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Kraft Foods to Spin Off Grocery Business | A year and a half after buying Cadbury, Kraft Foods said on Thursday that it would split into two companies by spinning off its North American grocery business from its global snacks enterprise. The separation is expected to take at least 12 months, and be completed before the end of 2012.

title: A Family Risk for Macular Degeneration
description: Does macular degeneration run in families? Several readers of the Consults blog had questions about the genetics of macular degeneration. Stephen Rose, chief research officer of the Foundation Fighting Blindness, responds.

title: Blackstone to Buy Emdeon for $3 Billion
description: The Blackstone Group agreed on Thursday to buy Emdeon, a medical data services provider, for about $3 billion, including debt, in the latest takeover within the health care services industry.

title: Thursday Reading: Calculating the Real Age of Your Dog
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Democrats Hit Back in G.O.P. Districts
description: Stung and enraged after a legislative beat down in the deal to raise the nations debt ceiling, House Democrats are hoping to get a summertime lift from the group that helps elect them.

title: Lockdown Issued at Virginia Tech Campus
description: 1:34 p.m. | Updated  Virginia Tech continued to be locked down as police searched for an armed man reported walking around the Blacksburg, Va., campus Thursday morning.

title: How Danny Meyer Crosses a Street, and Other Subtleties
description: In a long profile in The Times, Sean Wilsey trails Danny Meyer around Manhattan and Miami, attempting to distill the restaurateurs philosophy. There is an explication of the Danny Meyer Street Crossing Method (Meyerscrom), an observation of a brainstorming session with Floyd Cardoz over the menu for their forthcoming restaurant in Battery Park City (What if vegetables were the main course?, and a three-part rationale for his refusal to clone one of his fine-dining restaurants in Las Vegas:

title: Morgan Stanley C.E.O. Buys $2 Million of Firms Stock
description: It is no secret that James P. Gorman is one of Morgan Stanleys biggest supporters. Now the Morgan Stanley chief executive is putting his money where his mouth is, buying 100,000 shares on Thursday, a purchase valued at roughly $2 million.

title: James Ford Seale, Imprisoned Klansman, Dies at 76
description: James Ford Seale, a former Ku Klux Klansman who was convicted on federal kidnapping charges more than 40 years after the abduction, torture and drowning of two black teenagers near the Mississippi-Louisiana border in 1964, died Tuesday at the federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind. He was 76.

title: Looking Apocalypse in the Eye
description: Rise of the Planet of the Apes, an amusingly cheerful film about the end of humanity thats PETA and critic approved  no animals were harmed in its making, and neither was James Francos career  is precisely the kind of summer diversion that the studios have such a hard time making now. Its good, canny-dumb fun. Employing bleeding-edge technologies in the service of old-fashioned entertainment, it insists on the emotional truth of its absurd story, its tongue in cheek (and in check), while offering self-aware asides, like the ritual bow to Charlton Heston, the lockjaw hero of the original 1968 Planet of the Apes.

title: My So-Called Adulthood
description: Long before we had much life to look back on, North Americans my age knew that nostalgia was a sickness. Its not that we were aware the term was coined to describe the crippling melancholia that overcame many 17th-century Swiss soldiers when war took them away from the bucolic mountain landscapes of home. It was that, being in our teens and 20s in the early 1990s, we had grown up in the penumbra of the great eclipsing nostalgia of the baby boomers, with their 1950s Happy Days; their 1960s (the Greatest Decade Ever Told); and their serial losses of innocence, via the Kennedys assassinations, Vietnam, Watergate, etc.  a record of revirginization to rival any evangelical chastity-pledge campaign.

title: Seeing Things | Size Matters
description: The New York architecture firm Lewis.Tsurumaki.Lewis (LTL) is taking up residence on Hollywoods Walk of Fame with 4 Projects: 4 Scales, a new exhibition at Woodbury Universitys Hollywood outpost, at 6518 Hollywood Boulevard. Riffing on Rem Koolhaass iconic 1990s book S, M, L, XL, the exhibition focuses on projects that range in size from the micro to the massive, in a mix of built and speculative work. For the site-specific installation, LTL inserted a three-sided container with etched and printed surfaces into a long, narrow gallery space. Visitors entering the container make their way through the exhibition from the largest of the four projects on view to the smallest, walking on a white-painted wood floor that is laser-etched with the plans of each project. Canted walls of backlit panels provide photographs, architectural drawings and descriptive text. Water Proving Ground, at 69 million square feet, is LTLs extra-large project. This visionary master plan for the northwest corner of New York Harbor was conceived as part of MoMA/P.S. 1s recent Rising Currents initiative, which studied the impact of anticipated sea-level change on the city. The other projects in the show are all built works: Arthouse, a contemporary art center in Austin, Tex.; the Sullivan Family Student Center at the University of Wyoming in Laramie; and Lobby Wall, a site-specific sculpture for the lobby of Memorial Sloan-Ketterings new Manhattan building, which is the smallest of the projects at 108 square feet.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Its time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

title: Civilian Toll Is Mounting in Assault on Syrian City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian human rights activists said Thursday that Syrian government forces had killed more than 100 people in the rebellious city of Hama in the first 24 hours since seizing control of its central square with armored columns and snipers.

title: Mexican pop singer Ximena Sariana; a visit from the band we dare not name; and a Song of the Week.
description: This weeks Popcast: three killer new albums, miles between styles. Jon Pareles on the Mexican pop singer Ximena Sariana; Damian Abraham and Jonah Falco, from the opera-writing Toronto punk band whose name we cant say, visit with Ben Ratliff; and a Song of the Week by gospel powerhouse Donald Lawrence. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: Republicans Set Sights on Balanced Budget Amendment
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans, feeling they have scored significant fiscal victories, are moving on to an even bigger challenge: persuading voters, state legislatures and Democrats to alter the Constitution with a balanced budget amendment.

title: Trans-Atlantic Inspiration: Adele Says Next Album Will Have a Country Flavor
description: If you detected an Appalachian twang in the opening verse of Adeles smash hit Rolling in the Deep, you may have gotten a taste of the British singers future work. She told the Sun newspaper in Britain this week that she became hooked on American country music and bluegrass while touring in the United States earlier this year and that she wants to write the songs on her next album in that vein.

title: BRD: Another West Coast Start-Up Takes Fight to Gas-Engined Dirt and Street Bikes
description: A San Francisco start-up is looking to muscle in on the West Coast boomlet of electric motorcycle manufacturers. Like the outwardly similar S and DS from Zero Motorcycles, built in the Bay Area, and the Brammo Engage series from Oregon, the BRD Redshift MX and Redshift SM are designed around the sit-up architecture of traditional dirt bikes, with the knobby-tired MX version designed for track and off-road riding and the smooth-tired SM intended for general short-range street use.

title: New York Film Festival Prefers My Week With Marilyn for Centerpiece Gala
description: Marilyn Monroe will make an unexpected appearance at the New York Film Festival in the form of Michelle Williams, who portrays the cinematic bombshell in My Week With Marilyn, a biographical feature that will be presented as the festivals Centerpiece Gala selection, its organizers said on Thursday.

title: Labors Decline and Wage Inequality
description: The decline in organized labors power and membership has played a larger role in fostering increased wage inequality in the United States than is generally thought, according to a study published in the American Sociological Review this month.

title: Arthur Murray, Test Pilot, Is Dead at 92
description: I begin to feel weightless, and Im flying so fast my instruments cant keep up  they show what happened two miles ago. Im climbing so steeply I cant see the ground, and I feel confused. I have a sense of falling and I want to grab something for support.

title: For Chicago Actress, a Broadway Debut Opposite Connick in On a Clear Day
description: Jessie Mueller, a rising star in Chicago musical theater, will get a notably big break this fall when she makes her Broadway debut as the love interest opposite Harry Connick Jr., in the provocative re-conception of the 1965 musical On a Clear Day You Can See Forever.

title: Rates of Wrath
description: Not good news in stock markets  but you really have to look at the bond markets to get the full awfulness of the situation.

title: Haunting Unpredictability
description: BERLIN

title: So You Think You Can Judge Dance
description: TILER PECK, the New York City Ballet principal, is rarely praised for her swag. So she watched with amusement recently as a judge on So You Think You Can Dance used the expression to applaud a hip-hop performance. Ms. Peck was in an apartment in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, with four other New York-based professional dancers who had gathered for a viewing of that Fox reality show.

title: Will the Debt Deal Force Higher Taxes on the Rich?
description: During the 2008 campaign, President Obama and his rivals for the nomination used to talk a lot about how they were going to rid the world of both Osama bin Laden and the Bush administrations tax cuts for the wealthy. Turns out that, of the two, Bin Laden was a whole lot easier to kill.

title: Magic Trip
description: The Times's Ed Marks describes rare footage of the author Ken Kesey, whose 1964 cross-country, LSD-fueled road trip has recently been salvaged, and turned into a documentary.

title: Gen X Golden Oldies
description: Once upon a time, making a personal mixtape was the purest expression of kinship. Or maybe thats just my age showing. In my teens and early 20s, nothing seemed more important. I slaved over mixes for girls and best friends. Bad choices still haunt me. I cringe recalling a couple ofDas Damen songs I dumped on a mix for a friend, especially considering he had made me a tape that included Which Way to Go, by the Big Boys, and Best Friends, by the Outlets, two all-time keepers.

title: Levi Aron Called Fit for Trial in Leiby Kletzky Murder
description: Levi Aron, the man accused of kidnapping, murdering and dismembering an 8-year-old boy from Borough Park, Brooklyn, in a case that traumatized the Hasidic population, is competent to stand trial, according to the results of a psychological exam requested by his defense team that were revealed in court on Thursday.

title: Retail Sales Rise at Expensive Stores but Are Mixed Elsewhere
description: New data from July shows that the retail economy is locked on two tracks: one for businesses that cater to the well-to-do, and the other for everyone else.

title: Aug. 7  13
description: Theater

title: Regulators Finalize New Derivatives Rules
description: After missing deadlines for several new derivatives rules last month, financial regulators are now bearing down on the freewheeling industry.

title: Delois Barrett Campbell, Gospel Singer, Dies at 85
description: Delois Barrett Campbell, whose subtle phrasing and silvery soprano helped define the sound of the Barrett Sisters, a prominent Chicago gospel trio featured in the 1982 documentary Say Amen, Somebody, died on Tuesday in Chicago. She was 85.

title: When They Wont Spend the Money
description: My friend Cynthia, who works as an independent home care aide in Northern California, told me about her latest client, a 93-year-old widow who broke a hip in a fall and underwent replacement surgery. After two months in a hospital and in rehab, she returned home with instructions to hire home care four hours a day, seven days a week  a reasonable-sounding compromise between safety and independence.

title: Centenarians Have Plenty of Bad Habits Too
description: For those of us relying on healthy habits to get us to age 100, the findings from a new study of centenarians may come as a bit of a blow.

title: M.L.S. Sends Five to Group Stage of Champions League
description: Seattle and Dallas advanced to the group stage of the Concacaf Champions League Wednesday night, giving M.L.S. a league-record five teams still alive in the regional club championship.

title: Alan Mulally, Ford C.E.O., Brings the Focus Electric to Late Show
description: Alan Mulally, the Ford Motor Company president and chief executive, took his pitch for the electric car to late-night television just after midnight on Thursday, with an appearance on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS.

title: Kraft, From Roll-Up to Spinoff
description: Krafts decision to split into two is the latest in a long history of deal-making involving the food manufacturer and its corporate siblings.

title: For Former Huntsman Aide, a Second Political Drama
description: The story that is stirring the most conversation in Republican presidential circles on Thursday comes from inside the campaign of Jon M. Huntsman Jr., where a long-simmering conflict has boiled over into public view.

title: Tigers Back! Well, at Least Hes Playing.
description: Tiger Woods is back! Isnt this awesome?! Hes playing actual golf. Hes staging really boring news conferences, but hey, hes creating intrigue with his caddie search. Isnt this just so exciting? Dont you all want to tune into our tournaments again, lean in close when our announcers whisper reverently, then rush out to buy everything our sponsors are hawking? You want to do that, right? Tigers back!!

title: 2011 Carolina Panthers Season Preview
description: This is the first of 32 season previews by Andy Benoit of NFLTouchdown.com and CBSsports.com. He can be reached at andy.benoit@NFLtouchdown.com.

title: Theater Talkback: Is It Fair to Jeer?
description: This summer ArtsBeat is inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. Recent posts have examined the challenges of casting the role of Fanny Brice in Funny Girl; unusual settings for Shakespeare stagings; and the buzzkill of pre-show announcements.

title: Europe Opens Broad Review of Deutsche Borse-NYSE Deal
description: 7:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Few Reports From Hama as Fears of Massacre Mount
description: Very little information appeared to be making it out of the restive Syrian city of Hama on Thursday as activists and international media struggled to assess the situation after tanks rolled in to take control.

title: Fans of the Flashing Leather
description: The tale of the offensively challenged Bill Bergen in todays Times reminded of the days when players could survive in the major leagues based almost solely on their defensive ability.

title: Designed Not to Last
description: Have you ever had the desire to get the word mother tattooed on your forearm, but were more concerned about it being properly kerned in Helvetica than about how it would make your mother totally freak? Tattly, a new e-shop, features ultra-designy temporary tattoos created by graphic designers and illustrators like Jason Santa Maria, James Victore, Frank Chimero and Jessica Hische.

title: The (Pipe) Dream of Opening Our Own Retail Stores
description: Since the inception of TerraCycle, I have dreamed of having our own chain of retail stores. Instead, we have always relied on stores like Wal-Mart and Whole Foods to sell our products. In the last decade, even as we shifted from selling home-and-garden products to selling a wide range of consumer products, and even as we shifted from manufacturing all our products to licensing them to assorted manufacturers, weve continued to sell most of our stuff through big-box retailers.

title: Mixed Ruling in Title IX Case
description: A federal judge ruled that the University of California, Davis, which was sued by a group of female wrestlers charging sex discrimination, failed to offer enough athletic opportunities to women.

title: Stoned Archive: Wild Ride Of the Merry Pranksters
description: If you have ever agreed to baby-sit for a friend who needed a sympathetic watchdog while experimenting with psychedelics, you know how boring it can be to observe someone else in the throes of an acid trip. Unless, heaven forbid, the friend freaks out and has to be carted off to a psych ward, there is nothing interesting about it, not even the addled oh-wow remarks of the person under the influence. Meaningful communication is possible only if youve also ingested hallucinogens and are flying side by side. Then you might share the clammy fantasy of crawling around inside each others heads.

title: New Site to Buy and Sell Remodeling Supplies
description: You know theyre out there, in your garage: Boxes of tiles, left over from that bathroom remodeling project; old doors; maybe even an odd chandelier that doesnt fit your current dcor. You keep thinking youll have a yard sale and get rid of all that stuff but never get around to it.

title: The Power of Dress
description: Today on Morning Joe, Mika Brzezinski lamented how buyers of $1,500 shoes were shameless. She pointed to the front-page article in The New York Times about buoyant luxury-goods spending in a weak economy. Before the co-host Joe Scarborough teased her off the soapbox, Ms. Brzezinski unloaded some indignation. Her aim was off, though. Sensible people might agree that its shameful to spend that kind of money (and more) for shoes or an article of clothing, but the wealthy and young people with decent enough jobs have been doing that for months, as retail numbers indicate.

title: E.P.A. Is Greening the Apple
description: A belated welcome to the blogosphere, E.P.A.

title: With 4 Names, Turkey Marks a New Era
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys civilian leadership appointed four new commanders on Thursday, decisively strengthening its control over its armed forces less than a week after the military leadership abruptly resigned in frustration over the continuing prosecution of officers accused of plotting to overthrow the government.

title: Jerry Lewis Dropped From Labor Day Telethon
description: Jerry Lewiss appearance on the Muscular Dystrophy Associations annual Labor Day telethon has been scrapped, the organization said Wednesday night.

title: Wheelies: The Monza-on-Hudson Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Levi Aron Pleads Not Guilty
description: Arraigned in a Brooklyn courthouse Thursday morning, Mr. Aron pleaded not guilty to the charge of killing eight-year-old Leiby Kletzky

title: Captured on Video, and Then by the Police
description: Our colleagues at the Local East Village caught an interesting moment on video: a police National Night Out Against Crime event on the Lower East Side interrupted by a suspect fleeing the scene of a nearby gang assault. The man ran right into police listening to the precincts commanding officer as she addressed a crowd of local residents and elected officials, the police tell the Local. He and six other suspects were arrested. Read more on the Local East Village

title: Donation to Romney-Tied Group Draws Scrutiny
description: What it sells, buys, or makes is a mystery. It has no known shareholders, nor does it have a chief executive.

title: Mile After Mile of Tornado Debris
description: People might think that a disaster is no time to be thinking about recycling. But as my article on the enormous challenges involved in removing this years tornado debris reflects, the Environmental Protection Agency and state environmental officials take seriously the goal of cleaning up disasters in a responsible way. That means burning less of the debris than communities might have in the past and putting it in safe landfills.

title: Deal Ratified by N.F.L. Players
description: N.F.L. players ratified the new 10-year collective bargaining agreement Thursday, which includes blood testing for human growth hormone, making the N.F.L. the first major American sports league to start such testing with the consent of its players union. According to the league, the goal is to begin testing by the first week of the regular season, which starts Sept. 8, and players will be tested annually and randomly.

title: In Kraft Split, a Boon for 3 Banks
description: Kraft Foods plan to break itself into two pieces isnt just good news to shareholders. It is also a win for the three banks that are advising the food giant.

title: Teenager Arrested in Wheelchair Purse-Snatching
description: The teenager wanted in a purse-snatching from a 78-year-old woman in a wheelchair in Brooklyn was arrested on Thursday, the police say. The teenager, Cody Santiago, 18, of Bushwick, was charged with grand larceny. On July 20, the police have said, Mr. Santiago was caught on video grabbing the handbag off the womans lap as she rode along the sidewalk in Bushwick. The purse contained $15 and medication.

title: Huntsman Stands by His Strategist
description: If Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is upset with his campaigns chief strategist, John Weaver, hes not showing it.

title: In Divorce Case, Judge Refuses to Hear Evidence of Genius
description: It is a high-class problem facing a New York judge: How do you divide $450 million in a divorce?

title: Klinsmann Picks Roster for U.S.-Mexico Friendly
description: Introduced at a morning news conference on Monday, Juergen Klinsmann checked off the first item on his to-do list by releasing the 22-man roster he has selected for the United States national teams exhibition game against Mexico in Philadelphia on Wednesday.

title: Spicy Shrimp Salad With Mint
description: In a recipe from the Minimalist archives, Mark Bittman tosses seared shrimp with arugula and mint to make an elegant salad that's not fussy.

title: Eyes on Woods, but Scott Refuses to Blink
description: AKRON, Ohio  As opening rounds go, the one that unfolded Thursday at a benign Firestone Country Club could hardly have been better.

title: No Biking in the House Without a Helmet
description: Its time for a laugh-out-loud selection for the Motherlode Book Club. Something you can take to the beach.

title: Five (and Then Some) Tech Tips for Travel
description: In the big airports, you sometimes see three different lanes for the X-ray machines. Theyre marked by a black diamond (expert travelers who know the routine and have their laptops out and shoes off), blue square (casual travelers) and green circle (families and people who need extra help).

title: No Mush, Please
description: The other day I lugged home the summer issue of Acne Paper, occupying my office in-box like a hibernating bear. Ive been on vacation. Yippee! Anyhow, there was Acne Paper, and suddenly, it flopped open to a piece called My Own Private Hollywood, with a photograph on the opposite page of a cute young man standing on the steps of a pool. The caption said by Montgomery Clift. Id just finished reading Manny Farbers analysis of why Clift was at his best in Howard Hawkss Red River and not in, say, From Here to Eternity. Mr. Farber wrote: One feels that this is the first and last hard, clamped-down, imaginative job Clift does in Hollywood  his one nonmush performance. Afterward, he goes to work for Zinnemann, Stevens, Hitchcock.

title: Miu Mius Super-Sparkle Sneakers
description: The glitter-coated pumps on Miu Mius fall runway werent the only stars in Miuccia Pradas sky. Five lace-up low-tops bedecked in crystal appliqus, metal studs, little bits of lam and layer upon layer of gold glitter are shining complements to this seasons dressier selection of shoes. Rubber soles and leather insoles mean happy, trek-friendly trails. And bread crumbs? Please. Were leaving dazzling tracks of silver speckles in our wakes. Walk on!

title: Poetry for Tough Guys
description: Bruce Smiths new poems move fast and travel far, from Newtonian physics to the fiery . . . riderless horse of Christian apocalypse, from the jet engine / as it gins the clouds to the hand-iron press and the sewing machine. Most of those poems, though, begin in one place: a notion of blue-collar manhood, full of rough edges, frustration, defiance and pride. Smiths Vietnam-era draftees, present-day stevedores, touring musicians and Iraq war veterans, along with their black, white, sallow, olive, red, black kids, inspire grand flights, tumultuous catalogs, as in a poem about drought: Wherever there was water  the upended lid of a mayonnaise jar / in the gutter, the gutter, the sober silver puddle, the frenzied lake, / the tear ducts, the dew, the beveled rain  we drank. When Smith is not speeding through such cascades of nouns, he revs up other repetitions: They come like rats. . . . They want to save you. They want to slap you silly. They pet / the kitty. They bring gossip. . . . Theyve got questions for further study. The plural noun to which each They refers is an obscenity most poets would not use.

title: Digging Around for Snails
description: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

title: Three Pakistan Naval Officers to Be Court Martialed Over Base Attack
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Three officers of the Pakistan Navy are facing a court martial on charges of negligence in connection with the audacious May 22 attack by small band of Islamist insurgents on a naval base in the southern port city of Karachi, a senior naval official said Thursday.

title: Another Chance to Get 9/11 Memorial Passes
description: People locked out of reserving tickets to visit the 9/11 Memorial during its opening week are getting another opportunity to secure passes. The memorial released more tickets on Thursday morning for dates that were previously unavailable, including the first weekend.

title: Google and Microsoft in a Tit for Tat Over Patents
description: Updated 10:59 a.m. Friday:  Added Microsofts comment to Googles response.Updated 4:30 p.m. Thursday: Added a response from Google.

description: The first sight of the shimmering scallop-shaped bay will sweep you off your feet.

title: Summer Lows for TV Networks
description: Your average channel surfer obviously found better things to do with leisure time on Wednesday night, as many shows on the broadcast networks posted summer lows in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic.

title: 36 Hours in San Sebastin, Spain
description: TO visit San Sebastin, on Spains northern coast, is to fall in love. The first sight of the shimmering scallop-shaped bay, replete with crescents of golden sand and turquoise waves, will sweep you off your feet. Pairing this natural beauty with the unrivaled local cuisine  from decadent Michelin-starred feasts to delectable bite-sized pintxos (Basque-style tapas)  may leave your head spinning. A spruced-up seaside promenade, a renovated museum and a forthcoming culinary school all add to the citys allure. But this love affair doesnt have to be a fling. In June, the city secured a coveted designation as a 2016 European Capital of Culture, ensuring that it will put its best foot forward for years to come.

title: In Its Final Quarter, Warner Music Reports a Loss
description: In its final full quarter as a public company, the Warner Music Group reported increased revenue yet a loss of $46 million.

title: Some Advice for Democrats
description: The narrative that Republicans behaved like terrorists during the debt ceiling negotiations has become pretty well entrenched among Democratic partisans, and I doubt that any counter-arguments will dislodge it. Before we turn the page on this particular episode, I just want to highlight a few points, all from left-of-center writers, that suggest a slightly healthier way that liberals might look at recent events.

description: Unsatisfied, the Replacements (1984)

description: A view of the day in sports, with spikes, pines and sails.

title: Stocks Are Still Expensive
description: The main problem for the stock market is obviously the economy. But its not the only problem. Stocks are also under pressure because they are fairly expensive right now relative to earnings.

title: The Small Boys Came Early to the Hanging
description: I was out of the country last week and therefore unable to do my usual sentence harvesting. In my absence, the 6th Floor blog asked Times readers to step in and propose their own favorite sentences of the week. The result was nearly 100 candidates, drawn from all kinds of sourcesnovels, blogs, poems, Wikipedia entries, Korean T-shirts and, of course, The Times itself.

title: Popcast: Mexican Pop, Canadian Punk
description: In this weeks Popcast, New York Times pop music critics look at two acts with tough-to-pronounce names that are staking out new ground this summer.

title: The Minimalist: Spicy Shrimp Salad With Mint
description: This shrimp salad is one of those early Minimalist recipes,from 1998, that I look at today and think about how things have changed. Not that theres anything wrong with shrimp marinated with cayenne and paprika, seared, then tossed with arugula and mint. Its elegant but not fussy, and it sounds delicious.

title: California Police Warn Against Tunneling on Beaches
description: Matt Mina was digging his way under more than six feet of sand beneath Newport Beach, Calif., on Wednesday afternoon when suddenly the crumbly walls of his makeshift tunnel collapsed. The weight trapped him and, for roughly 20 minutes, he was buried in the sand.

title: Former Sullivan & Cromwell Partner Pleads Guilty to Tax Evasion
description: 4:56 p.m. | Updated

title: AARP Files Another Reverse Mortgage Suit
description: In recent months, AARP Foundation Litigation has prodded the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development to reverse a rule change that had made it harder for some surviving spouses of reverse mortgage holders to stay in their homes. Now, the foundation is turning to the financial institutions that own and service the mortgages.

title: Spare Times for Aug. 5-11
description: Museum of the City of New York: Whose Park is It? Financing and Administering New Yorks New Parks (Tuesday) Creating and maintaining green spaces during a budget crunch is not exactly a walk in the park. An urban oasis designed today is very different from one designed in the days of Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux; you need only look at the High Line on the West Side of Manhattan, or Brooklyn Bridge Park, above, at the waters edge in Brooklyn. A planned expansion there is expected to include several buildings of private housing  along with tennis courts, a swimming pool and other amenities  with payments from the buildings used to support the parks operating expenses. On Tuesday at 6:30 p.m. Adrian Benepe, the New York parks commissioner, will discuss the history of the citys parks and some issues surrounding park creation with Alexander D. Garvin, of the Yale School of Architecture, and Catherine Nagel, the executive director of the City Parks Alliance, an advocacy group based in Washington. Among the questions: Where will the money come from? What makes a park successful? The talk is part of an Urban Forum series at the museum (Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street) on the citys infrastructure. It costs $12 ($8 for 65+ and students and $6 for members) and requires reservations: (917) 492-3395. Seating will be provided, so theres no need for blankets or lawn chairs, and please, no picnics. For events at Brooklyn Bridge Park: brooklynbridgeparknyc.org. (Anne Mancuso)

title: Goldsmith Quits as Deputy Mayor After 14 Months
description: Stephen Goldsmith, who oversaw operations as a deputy to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, announced on Thursday that he would resign after just 14 months in the position.

description: MACYS FISHING CLINICS

title: Keseys Kool Trip
description: Its hard to believe that during a two-week-long trip across the country  which was heavily fueled by LSD, set aboard a psychedelically painted bus labeled Further and filled with characters with names like Generally Famished, Gretchin Fetchin and Stark Naked  there was time or energy or a steady enough hand to capture 40 hours of footage on 16-millimeter film. But then again, Ken Kesey was in charge.

title: When Friends Drift
description: Last year, a close friend confided that he had joined Alcoholics Anonymous. He never seemed alcoholic, but I supported him because it was important to him. We grew even closer. Then he began pushing me away for A.A. friends, who exclude me because Im not part of the program. I dont want a dramatic showdown, but I cant pretend were still close. Well probably keep drifting. What should I say to friends who ask about us and may try to mend fences?

title: Rooms Furnished With Memories
description: YAIR NOAM, an 88-year-old retiree in Tel Aviv, had a common coming-of-age experience as a Jewish teenager in 1930s Berlin. With little warning and few belongings, Mr. Noam  born Manfred Nomburg  was forced to leave his family and home to find safe haven in a foreign land. He was able to emigrate to Palestine and his brother to Britain; their parents werent as lucky.

title: Bill Would Require Car Rental Companies to Fix Recalled Vehicles Immediately
description: Under a bill introduced by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, car rental companies would not be allowed to rent recalled vehicles that havent been fixed.

description: Images from Rise of the Planet of the Apes.

title: TimesCast | August 4, 2011
description: August 4, 2011 - Stocks fall on economic worries; Tiger Woods returns to competitive golf; and happy 50th birthday, Mr. President.

title: The Cosmos Head to Old Trafford, Some Eyes Wider Than Others
description: When the New York Cosmos take the field at Old Trafford on Friday in a friendly to commemorate the final game for Manchester Uniteds Paul Scholes, the roster will include many names familiar to Scholes and many who even the most die-hard fans wont recognize. Thats because the Cosmos, in trying to revive the most storied franchise in U.S. soccer history, have tried to instill a New York flavor on their visit to the storied stadium.

title: A Call to Rethink Internet Search
description: We could soon view todays keyword searching with the same nostalgia and amusement reserved for bygone technologies such as electric typewriters and vinyl records.

title: Cotchery Is Released by the Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Not long before Jerricho Cotcherys tenure with the Jets came to an end with his release on Thursday, his thoughts drifted to an August afternoon in 2008. With Brett Favre en route to his introductory news conference in Cleveland as the Jets new quarterback, Chad Pennington stood before the Jets offense and, in one of his final acts as their starting quarterback, gave a heartfelt and emotional speech.

title: For Its Farewell, M. Wells Will Hold Friday and Saturday Dinners
description: Diners Journal got a nice email just now from Sarah Obraitis, who with her husband, the chef Hugue Dufour, is closing their charming French-Canadian diner M. Wells in Long Island City, Queens, at the end of August. The couple had a short lease with their landlord, she said, and negotiations to extend it fell apart. But they are far from done with M. Wells. Were focused on creating a better future and a dope restaurant, Ms. Obraitis wrote in the email, and added that they would re-open the business in Long Island City.

title: Lagerfeld for the Masses, Again
description: Macys unveiled its newest fast-fashion collection, this one designed by Karl Lagerfeld, on Wednesday evening in a SoHo gallery that had been decorated with multiple portraits of Mr. Lagerfeld in the front and images from a related ad campaign in the back. The ads show Coco Rocha, photographed by Mr. Lagerfeld, wearing his clothes in a library setting, not that they seemed particularly bookish.

title: The Mets Next Blockbuster Is Expected to Stay for 10 Years
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Arts flair for the dramatic will not end when the blockbuster Alexander McQueen exhibition closes at midnight on Sunday. Its encore will be theatrical, but in an entirely different way. A colossal statue of a pharaoh weighing more than nine tons is heading to the Met by ship from Germany. When it arrives in New York in the next 10 days, it will go on view in the museums Great Hall.

title: Familiar (Winning) Formula for Braves
description: Heading into the stretch run of baseballs regular season, the Atlanta Braves are playing like their playoff teams of the 1990s, with the National Leagues second-best record and the postseason in sight. Nowhere to be found, though, are legends like Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine, John Smoltz, Andruw Jones and Javy Lopez. The only leftover from the Braves playoff run from 1991 to 2005 is Chipper Jones, the should-be Hall of Fame third baseman.

title: The Global Economic Mess; President Obama Pushes Job Creation; and the Iowa Republican Straw Poll

Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, Washington correspondent Edward Wyatt, chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris and Nate Silver, writer of the 538 political calculus blog, join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: Shell Gets Tentative Approval to Drill in Arctic
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of the Interior on Thursday granted Royal Dutch Shell conditional approval of its plan to begin drilling exploratory wells in the Arctic Ocean next summer, a strong sign that the Obama administration is easing a regulatory clampdown on offshore oil drilling that it imposed after last years deadly accident in the Gulf of Mexico.
