title: American in Bosnia Discovers the Horrors of Human Trafficking
description: In the lineage of real-life David-and-Goliath movies in which intrepid seekers of the truth investigate malfeasance in high places, The Whistleblower deserves an honorable mention. This earnest film may not be as dramatically coherent or as gripping as Serpico, All the Presidents Men, Erin Brockovich and Silkwood, to name four much-decorated Hollywood prototypes. But its revelations are, if anything, more devastating and far more immediate than the dirty deeds uncovered in those predecessors.

title: Another Musical Post Is Vacated at City Opera
description: The music staff of the New York City Opera continues to dwindle. Kevin Murphy, a widely respected vocal coach, said on Thursday that he would leave his position as the companys director of music administrationto take a faculty post at the Indiana University School of Music this fall.

title: All Hail Bodega Cats. And Show Us Yours.
description: Few things have moved us in a more profoundly positive direction recently than the Internets Celebrities probing video exploration of the ultimate predator: the Bodega Cat.

title: Ice Cold, 42 Flavors of Nostalgia
description: RIFFLE back through your memories, and youre bound to recall an old friend who has been there through all the milestones, whose very name is synonymous with simpler times. Russell Irushalmi has that kind of dear pal, whom he muscles through Queens traffic to see as often as possible: the Lemon Ice King of Corona.

title: Demonstrating How a Special Choreographer Made Men Special
description: Beaver Creek, Colo.  When the choreographer George Balanchine was running New York City Ballet, there were two sides to being one of his male dancers. Much of the time, as successive men have related, it was as if they just werent there. Sometimes, when teaching, he was so focused on exclusively female exercises that he omitted to give the men anything to do until they reminded him of their presence.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Corona
description: For 67 years, the Lemon Ice King of Corona, a temple to the Italian ice, has helped to cool the neighborhood. Forty-two flavors are available, and peanut butter is a favorite.

title: The Least and the Most in a Tanglewood Series
description: LENOX, Mass.  An attraction of the Tanglewood Music Centers annual Festival of Contemporary Music is an unpredictability that makes guessing which of the many competing species of modernism will dominate a largely fruitless exercise.

title: Summer Styles | Moody Florals
description: A look at whos staying cool and looking cooler this season.

title: About That Wish: What if It Came True?
description: Within the first three minutes of the body-swapping, farcical bromance The Change-Up, a gurgling baby boy unleashes a projectile explosion of poop into his daddys face during a morning diaper change. That muddy moment tells you exactly where youll be during the movies next hundred-plus minutes: toddling back and forth between the toilet and a sandbox stocked with inflatable sex dolls.

title: MATTHEW RONAY: Between the Worlds
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

description: Susan Teller Gallery

title: Populating the Landscape With Idealism
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  If you stumbled into a meeting of French Impressionist painters in the mid-1870s, youd get some frosty looks. Edgar Degas would eye your clothes. Paul Czanne, born suspicious, would scowl. Claude Monet might size you up for a sale.

description: Artists Space

description: Marlborough

title: Are We There Yet? Who Cares! Enjoy the View
description: A SHADED two-lane road  narrow, bumpy and without lines in stretches  hugs the Delaware & Raritan Canal as it meanders through virtually unspoiled countryside no more than 10 miles west of the wide and rumbling New Jersey Turnpike corridor.

title: The Stock Market Is the Least of Obamas Worries
description: 6:53 p.m. | Updated  Theres some Twitter sentiment to the effect that todays crash in stock prices is bad news for President Obama. That doesnt seem like a terribly controversial conclusion  but Im not so sure its true.

title: A Souped-Up Romance Turns Demolition Derby
description: That American pastime of chopping cars is just one of the many true details that distinguish the seductive, grubby-beautiful, low-budget movie Bellflower from the usual indie chaff. The basic story sounds as dire as a quick read through a Sundance Film Festival catalog: Sensitive boy meets sexy girl. Happy and sad follow amid tears and beer, mumbled dialogue and openhearted sincerity, except that here they add up to an authentic slice of life, though one hopped up with an exuberant visual style and lurid excesses. Blood flows, fire belches, a devil car roars into the frame, and a couple meet cute over mouthfuls of live crickets.

title: Saddled Up for Serious Strumming
description: The air was getting thick downstairs at Union Hall in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, and the members of the Band of Heathens were making themselves at home. Ed Jurdi, seated at a keyboard, was belting a Southern soul number called The Other Broadway, in his high, tremulous rasp. Colin Brooks, at the other end of the stage, attacked his electric guitar, uncoiling blues licks in a coarsened tone. Between them was Gordy Quist, blithely strumming a rhythm-guitar riff. The band played the song and then extended it, pushing an ecstatic four-bar vamp, louder and wilder with each turnaround but without ceding any control.

title: Saving Scrapbooks From the Scrapheap
description: Woody Guthrie saved paperwork documenting his peripatetic life, from utility bills for New York apartments to fliers protesting shanty demolitions in Seattle and lyrics for folk songs performed at a Los Angeles radio station. He and his family put some of the artifacts in scrapbooks, but that did not fend off damage over the years.

title: Following a Painters Options Beyond the Canvas
description: The German painter Blinky Palermo got his art training from Joseph Beuys and his pseudonym from an American gangster  a pair of tough guys, in other words. But intimidation wasnt his style, to judge from a two-part survey of his work on view in upstate New York.

title: A Songwriter, Still on the Line
description: Jimmy Webb may have been performing his greatest hits for decades, but you could never call his show at Feinsteins at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening an example of phoning it in. A more accurate description of his treatment of By the Time I Get to Phoenix, Wichita Lineman, MacArthur Park and All I Know would be impassioned deconstruction. There were many moments when Mr. Webb, who turns 65 on Aug. 15, suggested the singer-songwriter equivalent of a famished wolf howling in the wilderness. Instead of embracing the niceties of a polished pop crooner, he eviscerated his own songs, laying out their raw emotions  mostly a young mans desperate romanticism  with such intensity that I wondered how anyone could feel so much.

title: Its Not Just the Degree, but What You Study
description: Readers of Economix are familiar with the case for why a college education is worth it in the labor market. Quite simply, if you have a college degree, you will probably earn more than someone who doesnt.

title: Testing the Waters of Abstraction
description: The art of John Marin is easy to respect and hard to love. Compared with his vanguard associates of the between-the-wars era  Georgia OKeeffe, Arthur Dove, Charles Demuth and Marsden Hartley  he was a flinty pragmatist. In the watercolors for which he was, and remains, most renowned, there is a hectic, sometimes luminously beautiful but often murky struggle between Cubist order and dynamic flux. Applied similarly to Manhattan cityscapes and Maine land- and seascapes, his touch is brusque, and his colors range from garish to drab. The invariably modest scale feels claustrophobic, despite the expansive subjects. Emotion is muted. An astringent pantheism is often suggested, but he was no visionary, and eros, whether carnal or mystical, is almost wholly absent.

title: The Art and Heart of the Dealer
description: Summer is the time when New Yorks commercial galleries break away in large numbers from the monthly grind of one- and two-artist exhibitions, almost as if let out of school. Art dealers of every stripe embrace the group show, whose wonderfully elastic format accommodates all manner of ambition and desire, curatorial and otherwise, serious and not.

title: Ice Cold, 42 Flavors of Nostalgia
description: Riffle back through your memories, and youre bound to recall an old friend who has been there through all the milestones, whose very name is synonymous with simpler times. Russell Irushalmi has that kind of dear pal, whom he muscles through Queens traffic to see as often as possible: the Lemon Ice King of Corona.

title: A Book of Secrets

title: In the Fast Company of Women on the Edge
description: Theres a small, nearly perfect comic moment not far into Michael Holroyds new book, A Book of Secrets: Illegitimate Daughters, Absent Fathers, when this esteemed biographer, now in his 70s, describes being locked in a car on a research trip with a woman who drives through Italy as if shes just robbed a bank and is being chased by carabinieri.

title: Scientists Find Signs Water Is Flowing on Mars
description: Shifting dark streaks on the surface of Mars are signs that water is flowing there today, scientists said Thursday.

title: Apple Closer to Most Valuable Company Title
description: Stocks fell drastically on Thursday as investors showed fears of a deeper economic slowdown and a debt crisis that is now spreading quickly through Europe. Apple, one of the best-performing stocks of the year, also took a hit.

description: Plaxico Burress would be wise to make the most of his second chance my using it as a teaching moment for young people, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Vita and Violet: The Greatest Bloomsbury Love Story
description: Heaven preserve us from all the sleek and dowdy virtues, such as punctuality, conscientiousness, fidelity and smugness! So wrote Violet Keppel in her unruly call to arms to the great ruling passion of her life, Vita Sackville-West. What great man was ever constant? What great queen was ever faithful? Novelty is the very essence of genius and always will be. If I were to die tomorrow, think how I should have lived! And indeed, how this woman, this unexploded bomb, as Vita called her, lived!

title: A Portuguese Tale of Time, the Revealer
description: A masterly tale about lives and stories and the art of their telling, Mysteries of Lisbon is also an elegiac meditation on love lost and rediscovered through misted memory. Directed by the Chilean filmmaker Ral Ruiz and set mainly in Portugal, with detours to other European corners, it is a period picture based on a work by the prolific Camilo Castelo Branco (1825-90), who was born in Lisbon, illegitimate and orphaned, and flirted with the priesthood before finding his calling in writing, running off with a married woman, landing in prison and finally committing suicide. Mr. Ruizs Mysteries are just as outlandish, gloriously so.

title: Pissarros People
description: Images from the exhibition at the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass.

title: Levi Aron Confession in Leiby Kletzky Killing
description: The confession of Levi Aron, charged with the kidnapping and murder of 8-year-old Leiby Kletzky, contains graphic descriptions of brutal acts.

title: Disapproval Rate for Congress at Record 82% After Debt Talks
description: The debate over raising the debt ceiling, which brought the nation to the brink of default, has sent disapproval of Congress to its highest level on record and left most Americans saying that creating jobs should now take priority over cutting spending, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Hurricane Season Is Looking More Serious
description: On average, 11 named storms strike the Atlantic basin each year, six of which become hurricanes and two major hurricanes with winds exceeding 111 miles an hour. In May, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said there was a 65 percent chance that the 2011 hurricane season, which began on June 1, would be above average. It predicted 12 to 18 named storms and six to 10 hurricanes.

title: Documents: The Full Results From The New York Times and CBS News Poll
description: A New York Times and CBS News Poll shows that in wake of the debt-ceiling debate, most Americans surveyed said creating jobs should now take priority over cutting spending.

description: During my teenage years  most of which I spent living and working on a quarter-section, corn-and-soybeans, last-of-a-dying-breed Iowa family farm  I began to notice that my particular reality was not often reflected on screen.

A lawsuit filed late Thursday accuses Bank of New York of fraud in its role as trustee overseeing the pools for investors.

title: As Markets Tumble, What to Do?
description: As stock markets tumble, Graham Bowley, a business reporter at The New York Times, takes a look at what options are on the table to ease investor fears. Will the turmoil in the American financial markets lead to another round of quantitative easing, and if so, will it have the intended effect?

title: Memorabilia Dealer Accused of Selling Fake Jerseys
description: A Minnesota memorabilia dealer was arrested by a United States postal inspector Thursday at the National Sports Collectors Convention in Rosemont, Ill., and accused of selling jerseys that he fraudulently claimed were worn in games by the major league stars Alex Rodriguez, Mark McGwire and Albert Pujols.

description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, a potential Republican presidential candidate, has for the past two months been working toward laying the groundwork for the commercialization of adult stem cell therapy, a highly controversial treatment which Mr. Perry underwent a month ago.

description: TIGHTER lending requirements and an unstable job market have made it tougher for some people, especially those just starting out, to qualify for a home mortgage on their own; finding a family member or close friend with good credit to co-sign a home loan may seem like the good solution.

title: Learning to Live With Debt
description: Debt can kill. But you cant live without it.

title: To the Victors, Vengeance
description: The German-Czech-Austrian production Habermann is being marketed  with the tagline War is over; vengeance has begun  as a look at a corner of history that is little known in America: the expulsion of millions of ethnic German civilians from parts of Europe after World War II. Its a tricky tale to tell; the films opening and closing scenes of Germans in Czechoslovakia being rounded up and loaded onto trains consciously echo the familiar imagery of Jews being sent to Nazi concentration camps.

title: Developers Building for Todays Gatsby
description: LANDS END, the decaying 1902 Colonial Revival mansion overlooking Long Island Sound at Sands Point, was razed in April, its 13 acres subdivided for a new gated cul-de-sac. But the aura of The Great Gatsby may linger around the estate, which was once owned by Herbert Bayard Swope, the publisher of The New York World, and is thought to have inspired the setting for F. Scott Fitzgeralds novel about the Roaring 20s.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  A Northern California woman has been accused of knowingly killing her infant son by breast-feeding him shortly after ingesting large amounts of methamphetamine, which rendered her milk toxic.

title: Russian Villages Self-Defense Underlines Failures of Police
description: SAGRA, Russia  When Sergei the Gypsy wanted to show who was boss in this tiny settlement on the edge of the Ural Mountains, he gathered a posse of armed men and drove down a narrow road through the night, illuminating the forest with his headlights.

title: Mike Kirby
description: Mr. Kirby, 50, is a founder and the chairman of Green Street Advisors, an independent research and consulting firm that tracks the commercial real estate industry, with an emphasis on real estate investment trusts, or REITs, public companies that disburse most of their income as dividends. Mr. Kirby, who started the company in 1985, also serves as its research director.

title: Afghans Who Risked Lives for U.S. Are Left in Dark on Visas
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Thousands of Afghans who have worked with American troops and diplomats here, often at great risk, have become stranded for years in a murky wait to emigrate to the United States, despite government efforts to speed them from potential threats in Afghanistan.

title: Deutsche Bank Executive Puts Up a Fight
description: At first glance, Richard J. Byrne, the chief executive of Deutsche Bank Securities, doesnt look much like a warrior.

title: Habitats
description: Thanks to inherited family treasures, extensive travels and two excellent pairs of eyes, a couples SoHo loft has evolved into a veritable primer on craftsmanship.

title: A Loft That Waited for Its Muse
description: BACK in the mid-70s, when Sigrid Burton was a young artist living in a rented loft on Walker Street in what was coming to be called TriBeCa, she used to pore over the real estate ads in The Village Voice with almost religious fervor. Ms. Burton did this despite the fact that she was living so modestly, she used to ask taxi drivers taking her home late at night to drop her at the corner, to save the cost of circling around the block to her front door.

title: With Floodwaters Ebbing, Long Haul of Sandbags Awaits
description: MANDAN, N.D.  Homes alongside the Missouri River here have been guarded for months by millions of sandbags, assembled in an urgent and cooperative effort last spring by the National Guard, local governments, residents and other volunteers. And now, as the floodwaters slowly recede, comes the unglamorous and expensive aftermath of cleaning up after another disaster, but here with a back-breaking twist.

title: Questions About Urging Interim Mayor to Run
description: From the bustling alleys of Chinatown to the sleepy neighborhood of West Portal, dozens of youthful volunteers in bright yellow Run Ed Run T-shirts fanned out across San Francisco this summer to gather signatures as part of a campaign to entice the interim mayor, Edwin M. Lee, to join the mayors race.

title: Living In | Hyde Park, N.Y.
description: It is the unscathed, understated beauty of this 37-square-mile river town that has been a draw for many people.

title: The Exurbs, Too, Appreciate an Oasis
description: An analytical computer tool developed by Jordan Baris realty -- which it unveiled to the National Association of Realtors, and recently sold for use to a Long Island agency (but says it will keep proprietary in New Jersey).

title: Ailing Father and Son Behind NFL Films Find Strength in Hall Journey
description: Few father-and-son acts have endured longer than Ed and Steve Sabols. Ed founded NFL Films in 1962, and Steve perpetuated it with a creative buoyancy that matched his fathers entrepreneurial zeal.

title: Off the Train, and Onto a Wave
description: MANY New Yorkers may not think of surfing as a way to spend a summer day. After all, riding the waves typically means a flight to someplace exotic or at least a jitney ride to the Hamptons. But the only ticket you really need is a MetroCard: Rockaway Beach in Queens is an A-train ride away from prime surfing.

description: LAS VEGAS  The Web site of ManTech International, a $2.6 billion computer security company that won a major F.B.I. contract, sells its services this way:

title: Governing New York by Writing a Check
description: It began years ago as a toss-off laugh line in City Halls marble halls: Hizzoner, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, might consider solving his most intractable problems with a quick tap-tap-tap on his personal savings account.

title: Officials in China Seized Infants for Black Market
description: At least 16 babies were seized by family planning officials from 1999 to 2006 in a Hunan Province county; parents say the babies were used as a source of revenue.

title: Chinese Officials Seized and Sold Babies, Parents Say
description: LONGHUI COUNTY, China  Many parents and grandparents in this mountainous region of terraced rice and sweet potato fields have long known to grab their babies and find the nearest hiding place whenever family planning officials show up. Too many infants, they say, have been snatched by officials, never to be seen again.

title: A Mets All-Star Makes a Foray Into Music
description: On the field, Jose Reyes has been a revelation this season, taking his already respected skills as a hitter to a significantly higher level. The All-Star shortstop leads the National League in batting (.339 average), hits (142), runs (79) and triples (16) and will be the recipient of an enormous new contract, from the Mets or someone else, at some point in the off-season.

title: Time to Say It: Double Dip Recession May Be Happening
description: Double dip may be back.

title: Among Those It Would Help, Doubts That a Plan Can Tame Inequality in New York
description: The problems that face young black and Latino men in New York City are deep-seated and diverse, officials who work in minority neighborhoods say. They vary not only from neighborhood to neighborhood, but also from family to family and man to man.

title: With Rodriguez Out, Lineup Hardly Lacks Punch
description: CHICAGO  While the Yankees prepared to conclude their series with the Chicago White Sox on Thursday, their cleanup hitter, Alex Rodriguez, was in Tampa, Fla., beginning his on-field rehabilitation from knee surgery amid another round of controversial headlines.

title: Classical Music Moves From Concert Halls to Cafes
description: Ever since Classical Revolution, a loose collective of top-notch, classically trained musicians, started playing chamber music at the Revolution Cafe a few years ago, this Mission District bar has been packed on Mondays  not generally a big party night in town.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,673 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Egyptians See Signs of a Reckoning in Mubarak Trial
description: MIT KENANA, Egypt  In this town of unfinished brick buildings, along parcels of corn and rice watered by the Nile, the elation, suspicion and introspection of a country played out along one street a day after residents witnessed the unthinkable: former President Hosni Mubarak put on trial.

title: Panetta Pleads for No More Cuts in Defense Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta effectively told Congress on Thursday to raise taxes and cut Social Security and Medicare before taking another swipe at the Pentagon budget beyond defense cuts already called for in the debt-ceiling deal.

description: My name is Levi Aron, the writer began.

title: Time For A Little Self-Indulgent Calm
Major Libyan Rebel Group Seeks Shake-Up in Ranks
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Rebel leaders, still reeling from the assassination of their top military commander last week, braced for a reshuffling in their ranks on Thursday, while law enforcement officials said a full-fledged investigation into the murder of the rebel general had gotten under way.

title: The Lion of the Day
description: On Aug. 3, 1861, Harpers Weekly published the astounding account of William Tillman, a 27-year old African-American sailor born a free man in Delaware. Tillman had been on the crew of the Yankee merchantman the S. J. Waring. On July 6 the 300-ton schooner, manned by a crew of eight under the command of Captain Francis Smith, had left New York bound for Montevideo, Uruguay, with a cargo of foodstuffs and a single passenger. Three days into its voyage, the ship was captured by a Confederate privateer, the Jefferson Davis.

title: Nervous Investors Chase Low-Risk Assets
description: It was a frantic flight to safety.

title: Brett Ratner Takes Producing Role at the Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  If those who give the Oscars are looking for laughs, action and the occasional outrage from their annual awards show, they are on the right track. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Thursday said Brett Ratner, a filmmaker known for directing the raucous Rush Hour series and for producing Horrible Bosses, will join Don Mischer in producing the next Oscar show, which is set to air Feb. 26 on ABC. Last years broadcast, produced by Mr. Mischer and Bruce Cohen, had soft ratings and was widely criticized for a lackluster performance by one of its hosts, James Franco. If energy is the issue, Mr. Ratner should be able to provide a fix. He is known as a film aficionado and an ambitious filmmaker whose is currently making a Snow White project for Relativity Media, and has dozens of projects in development. Recently, Mr. Ratner directed Tower Heist. That action picture, due Nov. 4 from Universal Pictures, has uncertain Oscar prospects, but counts Ben Stiller, Eddie Murphy, Matthew Broderick and Gabourey Sidibe among its stars.

title: Calls for CNN Host to Testify in Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  Piers Morgan, the CNN talk show host and a former editor of the British tabloid The Daily Mirror, faced calls on Thursday from prominent British lawmakers to appear before a parliamentary committee investigating the illegal hacking of cellphone messages.

title: Kraft Foods, in Split, Is Keeping Oreos but Not Velveeta
description: After years of mergers and takeovers, Kraft Foods is undertaking its biggest deal yet: breaking itself apart.

title: For NASA, Return Trip to Jupiter in Search of Clues to Solar Systems Origins
description: The last time we saw Jupiter up close, it was 16 years ago, when a probe from NASAs Galileo spacecraft took a death plunge through the cloud tops and radioed back tantalizing data that all but screamed, To be continued...

title: Before a Walk Across Niagara Falls, a Balancing Act
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario  Nik Wallenda is a seventh-generation circus performer, scion of the famed Flying Wallendas. He set the world record for farthest distance traveled by bicycle on a high wire. And now he has set his sights on a new deed of daredevilry  walking the 1,800 feet across the gorge of Niagara Falls while balancing on a two-inch-diameter steel cable.

title: Poland Fires Military Officials Over 2010 Crash
description: The prime minister of Poland dismissed more than a dozen top air force officers and Defense Ministry officials on Thursday after an Interior Ministry report on a devastating plane crash said that poor crew training, lax safety regulations and unprofessionalism were to blame.

title: For Playoff Spice, Add a Pair of Wild Cards
description: Bud Selig has a plan but needs to act on it fast. He is dying to add another wild-card team to the playoffs in both leagues and to spare us the charade of making games like this weekends at Fenway Park between the Yankees and the Red Sox out to be much bigger than they are.

title: The Right Way to Trim
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: In a Pageant, a Boroughs New Face
description: Inside a karaoke bar in Midtown Manhattan the other night, Tolulope Ibrahim, 17, and Olayinka Idowu, 17, both daughters of Nigerian parents who live on Staten Island, were wearing green shirts emblazoned with Miss Africa New York and singing hip-hop songs at high volume. In the glittering lights of a rotating disco ball, they leaned over to chat with Ama Kwakye, 19, the daughter of parents from Ghana who also lives on Staten Island, about the pageant in which they were all competing.

title: The Wrong Worries
description: In case you had any doubts, Thursdays more than 500-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average and the drop in interest rates to near-record lows confirmed it: The economy isnt recovering, and Washington has been worrying about the wrong things.

title: End the Debt Limit
description: It has long been clear that the federal debt limit is far too dangerous and unstable for lawmakers to use as a political weapon. Allowing that to happen in the last few traumatic weeks created an artificial national crisis that put the economy and the savings of Americans at risk and helped produce a loss of confidence that lingered as a cause of Thursdays stock-market plunge.

title: Friday: What Might Send Rover Right Over
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  By the time we solvers get to Friday, were ready to sink our writing implements into some toothsome, long entries and wrestle with some clues that really make us think. Thats the kind of puzzle Barry Silk offers us today, along with some Scrabbly consonant mashups to help slow you down a bit.

title: Results From Markets
description: Closing levels of three exchanges.

title: In Need of Deficit Plan, Congress Opts for Several
description: WASHINGTON  Congress says it has a plan for addressing the governments deficit problems. But it does not. Instead, it merely has a plan for a plan for a plan, effectively commanding Congress to continue fighting over budget priorities through the 2012 elections.

title: Matt Dodge Hoping to Move Past Inconsistency and a Blunder
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Punters, for better or worse, enjoy a blanket of anonymity on the field. They may shank a kick or miss a tackle on a return, but rarely do their mistakes  or successes  become the story, unlike their place-kicking brethren.

title: Isolated, Vulnerable And Broke
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Johan Santanas Recovery Hits a Setback
description: The optimistic hopes that the Mets ace, Johan Santana, could return this season were put into further doubt after it was determined Thursday afternoon that he had fatigue in his surgically repaired left shoulder.

title: S.E.C. Needs More Clout, Not Less
description: At least one lawmaker seems to want the Securities and Exchange Commission to become irrelevant. The regulator has had its problems. But a Republican bid to reshape it seems meant to hinder, not help. Theres room for improvement, but with its duties growing, the watchdog needs more staff, more money and a buffer against Congress.

title: Stocks Tumble Amid Global Worry
description: Investors dumped stocks amid anxiety that the United States and Europe were failing to fix deepening economic problems.

title: Bloomberg Deputy Hired With Much Fanfare Steps Down
description: Stephen Goldsmith, a high-profile deputy to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg who came under fire for the citys poor response to a crippling blizzard in December, announced on Thursday that he would leave his position after just 14 months in office.

title: Familiar (Winning) Formula for Braves
description: Heading into the stretch run of baseballs regular season, the Atlanta Braves are playing like their playoff teams of the 1990s, with the National Leagues second-best record and the postseason in sight. Nowhere to be found, though, are legendary players like Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine, John Smoltz, Andruw Jones and Javy Lopez. The only leftover from the Braves playoff run from 1991 to 2005 is Chipper Jones, their likely Hall-of-Fame third baseman.

title: How Safe Are Medical Devices?
description: A prestigious medical group is concerned that most medical devices are cleared for sale without evidence that they are safe and effective. That should give everyone pause. A panel of experts assembled by the Institute of Medicine found the current regulatory approach so flawed that it called for it to be scrapped and replaced with a system better designed to protect the publics health.

title: The Voters Need to Know
description: Just before President Obama hit the trail for a birthday binge of campaign fund-raising, 62 House Democrats sent him a pointed reminder that he has not yet signed the proposed executive order requiring federal contractors to disclose donations to the stealth campaign machines now undermining national politics.

title: Some Carriages Should Not Be Horseless
description: The horses and carriages were missing from Central Park South on Monday, midafternoon. Too hot, explained a salesman trying to lure disappointed tourists into pedicabs instead. Over 90, they go.

title: Battle for Libya | August 4, 2011
description: A spokesman for NATO said Thursday that it was looking into accusations that its planes had hit a civilian home, killing a mother and two children, in an early morning airstrike on the town of Zlitan, Libya.

title: A Country Haven for Brooklynites
description: The Hudson River Valley is becoming home to refugees of New York City seeking a quieter life, but one that is still rich in culture.

title: This Astronomical Recession
description: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

title: Volatile Wall Street Ends the Day Mixed
description: Like a battered boxer, stocks were knocked down and kept dragging themselves up through trading Friday, closing flat in the end, but capping the worst weekly decline since November 2008.

title: Are You Reading This? That Is So Cool.
description: WHATS up, Times readers? Normally right now youd be nodding off over a very thoughtful prescription for offering Qaddafi an honorable exile at a plastic surgery teaching hospital. But not today, people! Because I deleted that snoozer when I hacked my way in here.

title: Xiong Chao at Play
description: Xiong Chao, who was dropped from a second story balcony as an infant during a struggle between his mother and officials, plays with friends at his house. He is mentally handicapped from the fall.

title: Salvaging Medical Cast-Offs to Save Lives
description: When Dr. Bruce Charash arrived in Cotonou, Benin, in May 2007, he went from the airport to Hubert Maga Hospital. Charash is the founder of a Brooklyn-based organization called Doc2Dock, which collects surplus medical equipment from hospitals in the United States and ships it to hospitals in poor countries. As Charashs plane was landing, a container of medical equipment and supplies had docked, destined for Hubert Maga.

title: Raw Food Co-op Is Raided in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Raw food enthusiasts fit right in here, in the earthy, health-conscious beach communities of Venice and Santa Monica, along with the farmers markets, health food stores and vegan restaurants.

title: Juergen Klinsmann Names U.S. Roster
description: Juergen Klinsmann checked off the first item on his to-do list as United States national team coach by releasing the roster he has selected for an exhibition game against Mexico in Philadelphia on Wednesday.

title: Student Protests in Chile
description: Students across Chile have taken an unusually confrontational stance toward the government and business elite, demanding wholesale changes in education, transportation and energy policy, sometimes violently.

title: With Kiss-Ins and Dances, Young Chileans Push for Reform
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A blanket stretched over their legs, Johanna Choapa and Maura Roque, both 17, sat in front of the stage in a chilly school auditorium last week as more than 300 parents and teachers debated whether to continue supporting their hunger strike aimed at pressuring the Chilean government to reform the countrys education system.

title: An Opinion by Judge on Spy Law Creates a Stir
description: WASHINGTON  Proponents of press freedom have praised a ruling last week by a federal judge who protected a writer from being forced to testify in court about his sources for a book on the Central Intelligence Agency. But her opinion included a little-noticed passage: a suggestion that many journalists could be charged with a felony.

title: Seoul Warns of Latest North Korean Threat: An Army of Online Gaming Hackers
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The North Korean leader Kim Jong-il has found a novel way of raising badly needed cash, according to the South Korean authorities: unleashing young hackers on South Koreas immensely popular online gaming sites to find ways to rack up points convertible to cash.

title: A Painters Unfinished Tribute to the Many Clocks of New York
description: Amir Wahib quit his job to look at clocks.

title: Striking Change in Bedford-Stuyvesant as the White Population Soars
description: Mark Dunlea and his wife, Judith A. Enck, moved to Brooklyn from upstate New York two years ago. Last March, they breached the blurry Clinton Hill border to buy an apartment in a four-story condominium that had replaced an abandoned warehouse in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: So Hopeful in April, So Glum in August
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Corrections: August 5
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Aldermen in Upsets Face Decision on Ward Post
description: The once-mighty 36th Ward Regular Democratic Organization, rocked by losing the aldermans seat in an April run-off election upset, will soon undergo its first leadership change in 30 years.

title: One Nation, One Chicago Strives for Interfaith Understanding
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Fighting Crime and Pressuring the Mayor, via Shoe Leather
description: By day, Palmer Park in Roseland hums with life: children splashing in the pool, teenagers shooting baskets and politicians holding news conferences with television crews in tow.

title: Helping a Few to Vote, With Unintended Effects
description: Ross Ramsey, managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Drought Effects Extend Far Beyond Water Restrictions
description: When a wildfire chewed through power lines at a field of water wells in late June, Lubbock lost nine million gallons of water a day during the nearly two weeks it took to finish repairs.

title: Students Pressure Chile to Reform Education System
description: In the more than two months since education protests began in Chile, students have organized rallies drawing up to 100,000 people.

title: In Front of the Stove at 7 and Loving Every Minute
description: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Thomas McNaughton, chef at Flour + Water restaurant, addressed a room full of attentive grade-school-age children.

title: Jail Time Yields a Clash on Vegetarian Meals
description: What started as the dubious drug bust of a beloved, elderly Mill Valley merchant  a case that rattled many in this bucolic burb  is morphing into a clash about vegetarian rights. Dave McDonald, 70, of Mill Valley, has been a vegetarian for 42 years. But when he was jailed recently for 99 days on drug-related charges (most of which were later dropped), Mr. McDonald was denied vegetarian meals.

title: Recipes: The Proper Ways to Treat an Heirloom
description: A fresh tomato is a beautiful thing  which is all the more reason to slice it, mash it, crush it, or stuff it.

title: The Proper Way to Treat an Heirloom
description: From the less-is-more department: A perfectly ripe, local summer tomato eaten with a drizzle of olive oil, a sprinkle of salt or nothing at all has become a bit of a culinary clich. Your superior appreciation of the superior tomato relies on a distinct lack of meddling.

title: Family Guy Creator Part of Cosmos Update
description: Cosmos, the 1980 documentary mini-series that encouraged a generation of viewers to contemplate the origins of the universe and their place in it, and made an unlikely television personality out of the astronomer Carl Sagan, is poised to return to terrestrial airwaves. Only this time the starship is being steered by a pilot whose identity you might not surmise even if you had billions and billions of guesses.

title: Pepsi Takes Active Role in X Factor
description: SIMON COWELL has not just switched television shows; he has switched soft drinks.

title: Resource at Risk
description: With Gabons oil reserves depleting, the countrys vast rain forests are facing new perils.

title: Family Planning Officials Seized Infants in China
description: Many parents in Longhui County, China, say too many infants have been snatched by officials, never to be seen again.

title: M.J. Perry Jr., Legal Pioneer, Dies at 89
description: Matthew J. Perry Jr., who as a young lawyer had to wait in the balcony of his segregated local courthouse before a judge would hear his case, then went on to win hundreds of civil rights legal battles and to become the first black federal judge from the Deep South, died on July 29 at his home in Columbia, S.C. He was 89.

title: Campers Wounds Werent Caused by Bear
description: For the two boys who were awakened when a bear poked around their tents while on a camping trip on Wednesday in New Jersey, the ordeal must have been scary.

title: NYT Front Page for 08/05/11
description: NYT Front Page for 08/05/11

title: Yingluck Shinawatra Is Elected Thai Prime Minister by Parliament
description: BANGKOK  Thailands Parliament on Friday elected Yingluck Shinawatra the countrys first female prime minister, a month after her party won a landslide victory over a coalition backed by the nations military and traditional elites.

title: Havens  Genoa, Nev.
description: This town in Nevadas Carson Valley prides itself on its Old West heritage.

title: $2.3 Billion Loss Posted by Royal Bank of Scotland
description: 7:44 p.m. | Updated

title: The Art of Tea
description: A show at the Yale University Art Gallery aims to evoke the look and spirit of an intricately choreographed social convention in Japan.

title: Outsize Roles
description: Photos from Mabou Mines DollHouse at St. Anns Warehouse.

title: A Preview of the New Alice Tully Hall
description: A look inside the renovated concert hall at Lincoln Center, which will reopen in less than a month, as musicians test the acoustics.

title: Picasso, Images and Language
description: A dense and busy show on Picasso at Yale University investigates the importance of words  written, painted, printed, spoken  in Picassos art.

title: Through Plexiglas Barriers, a Noirish New York
description: Michael Kirby Smith, 31, is a New York-based freelance photographer. Since late in March, Mr. Smith, who grew up in Dallas, has been exploring the notion of barriers in New York  their role in the citys past and present, as well as the human interactions they inspire.

title: Cabinet Shuffle in Cyprus Seeks Backing for Austerity
description: ATHENS  The president of Cyprus, Demetris Christofias, shuffled his cabinet on Friday, but he failed to attract members of the opposition whose support is needed to impose crucial austerity measures.

title: Tip of the Week: Filtering Search for Children
description: Search engines bring all kinds of results back in response to queries  including some that may not be suitable for children. While no software filter replaces parental supervision, most of the major search sites (Google, Yahoo and Bing) include the filters for safer searching that can help screen out pages with adult content from results.

title: Pod Cars, Moving Silently at Heathrows Terminal 5
description: LONDON  Travelers passing through Heathrow Airport have an opportunity to experience the not-so-distant future of airport transportation systems in Terminal 5, where a curious row of pod cars connects the terminals two business parking lots.

title: Night Life and More Along Romes Tiber River
description: Every night this summer, the banks of Romes Tiber River come to life for the 10th edition of Lungo il Tevere (Along the Tiber). The city-sponsored event, which runs through Aug. 28, features hundreds of venues, with theaters, cinemas, musical events, artisans, bars and restaurants offering the summers largest nighttime attraction to locals and travelers alike.

title: The Early Word: Dissatisfaction
description: Todays Times:

title: 2011 Atlanta Falcons Season Preview
description: The Falcons told us everything about their intentions for 2011 on April 28. That night General Manager Thomas Dimitroff traded a kings ransom to Cleveland to move up and draft Alabama wide receiver Julio Jones with the sixth overall pick. Dimitroff initially carved out a name for himself during a five-year run as the director of college scouting for the New England Patriots; at his core, trading two first-round draft picks, a second-rounder and a pair of fourth-rounders just to move up 21 spots had to feel almost like trading a piece of his soul.

title: Long Story Shortlist, Growling Stomach Edition
description: Bad Food? Tax It, and Subsidize Vegetables,by Mark Bittman (July 23, 2011)What will it take to get Americans to change our eating habits? The need is indisputable, because heart disease, diabetes and cancer are all, in large part, caused by the Standard American Diet. (Yes, its SAD.) Read more

title: I.C.B.C. to Buy Controlling Stake in Argentine Bank
description: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China said Friday that it had agreed to pay the South African lender Standard Bank $600 million for control of three financial units in Argentina.

title: Further Thoughts on the Very Picky Customer
description: Id like to thank everyone who took the time to write a response to my post The Very Picky Customer. The points raised by commenters were interesting, and Id like to add a little more information and some further thoughts.

title: Broadcasting Hama Ruins, Syria Says It Has Ended Revolt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias state news media broadcast stark images of the destruction in the besieged city of Hama for the first time on Friday, showing burned buildings, makeshift barricades and deserted streets strewn with rubble in footage that appeared designed to show that government forces had put down a rebellion in the city.

title: Hes a Soulful Survivor With New Music to Make
description: In a career that spans nearly 50 years Booker T. Jones has worn many hats: leader of the celebrated 1960s soul group Booker T. & the MGs, a writer of hit songs like Green Onions and Born Under a Bad Sign, sideman, producer and arranger. Until very recently, though, he had neglected the one facet that many musicians value above all others, that of the solo artist.

title: Fresh Ricotta, a Fleeting Pleasure
description: FRESH artisanal ricotta cheese  the real thing, not the supermarket version, which is not a reasonable facsimile  can be a delight. Sweet and creamy on the tongue, yet light, it is one of lifes simple luxurious pleasures.

title: Live Blog: The Markets
description: Will the rout continue? Global stocks tanked on Thursday on pessimism over the state of economic affairs in both the United States and Europe. Recession-weary investors are losing hope for a recovery, and big European countries have still not wrestled their debt problems to the ground. The Lede blog is tracking developments in the markets Friday looking for clues to the near-term direction of stocks and bonds.

title: Ricotta Worth Hunting For
description: Fresh ricotta is the subject of this weeks City Kitchen column. When I think about fresh ricotta, I think of Sicily. It was there that I learned how delicious it could be on nearly everything  added to a pasta with eggplant and tomatoes, spread on toasted semolina bread and drizzled with oil, or eaten just plain with a spoon.

title: Poll Shows Negative View of Tea Party on the Rise
description: Little more than a year ago, most Americans did not know enough about the Tea Party to have an opinion. Now, more people have opinions, and they are hardly positive.

title: DST Denies Activist Investors Board Bid
description: DST Systems, a data processor, said on Friday that its board had decided to deny a request by Russell D. Glass, an activist investor in the company, that he and two others be appointed to the companys board.

title: In Market Slide, Obama Loses an Economic Asset
description: For more than a year, there has been one economic indicator that President Obama could always count on as a good-news salve to the festering sore of grim unemployment and jobs data.

title: U.S. Posts Stronger Job Growth in July
description: The United States economy continues ona wobbly course, but there was a momentary sigh of relief on Friday as the government reported that employers added 117,000 jobs last month, slightly more than expected.

title: Liquidity Trapped
description: Some readers may recall that back in 2008, when I began writing about the dangers of a liquidity trap and all that implied, I got a lot of angry pushback from the usual suspects. The liquidity trap is nonsense, they said; printing money is always inflationary; someone, I think Alan Reynolds, referred to liquidity claptrap.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: As Markets Tumble, What to Do? | As stock markets tumble, Graham Bowley, a business reporter at The New York Times, takes a look at what options are on the table to ease investor fears. Will the turmoil in the American financial markets lead to another round of quantitative easing, and if so, will it have the intended effect?DealBook

title: Friendly Workplace Linked to Longer Life
description: Getting along with your colleagues at work may do more than boost your productivity. It may also be a boon to your health.

title: Euro Zone | London Alfresco
description: By this time next year, London will be choked with Olympic tourists. So nows the time to make the most of this years quiet London summer, when the weather is mild and the population manageable.

title: Friday Reading: When the Elderly Can Afford to Pay, but Wont
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Pulling Rank
description: John Quiggin has some fun with an economist named Stephen Williamson who attacks his work from a position of robust ignorance; Noah Smith has even more fun.

title: Vandaag Loses Its Chef
description: The chef Phillip Kirschen-Clark, whose Dutch-influenced cooking helped Vandaag in the East Village earn two stars from Sam Sifton last September, has left. Mr. Kirschen-Clark said that Vandaags management had different views on the direction they wanted the restaurant to take. They wanted a more neighborhood approach but I prefer doing more elaborate food. He is exploring his next move, he said.

title: A Homemade Drone Snoops on Wireless Networks
description: It flies. It spies. It is the color of sunshine, and it has googly eyes.

title: Giants Sign Amukamara
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  With all eyes on Osi Umenyiora at Giants camp this week, it was easy to overlook a quieter drama: the absence of the first-round pick Prince Amukamara. That smaller mystery has been solved: Amukamara became the final first-round pick of the 2011 draft to agree to a contract.

title: Seasonal Joys in the Jobs Report?
description: The job numbers on Friday were better than expected, at least if you look at the seasonally adjusted figures. They still were not very good, but any good news is welcome.

title: Pilfered Peppers in City Gardens; Tomatoes, Too
description: AT the 700 community gardens sprinkled through the city like little Edens, the first commandment should be obvious: Thou shalt not covet, much less steal, thy neighbors tomatoes, cucumbers or peppers. But people do.

title: Bridgewater Fights Back in Dartmouth Flap
description: 3:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Has Someone Taken Your Tomatoes?
description: Its harvest season in the citys community gardens, which means it is high season for garden theft, too, as Robin Finn writes in this weeks Metropolitan section. At the West Side Community Garden on 89th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam, Linda Cardonas cucumbers disappeared two weeks ago. Now all thats left on her vines are shrimp-size cukes that will not mature until mid-August  if they make it that long. She said she planned to eat them sooner than that, just in case.

title: Private Sector Up, Government Down
description: As weak as the economy has been in recent months, the private sector has still been adding jobs at a faster rate than the adult population has been growing. Over the last 12 months, the private-sector employment has grown by 1.7 percent, while the adult population has grown about 1 percent, according to Haver, a research firm, and the Bureau of Labor Statistics:

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Fruit Smoothies Without the Dairy
description: Depending on how you make it, a smoothie can end up with more milk and yogurt than fruit. This week, Martha Rose Shulman eliminates the dairy and creates five smoothie recipes that are all about the fruit.

title: TimesCast | Economy Adds Jobs in July
description: August 5, 2011 - The job growth figure, reported by the Labor Department, was the strongest since April, but may still not be high enough to relieve fears of a renewed recession.

title: On the Shark Beat
description: Juliet Eilperin, a Washington Post reporter who shifted in 2004 from covering Congress and politics to writing on the environment, has written Demon Fish, a captivating, world-spanning (and much praised) exploration of the difficult human relationship with sharks. I recently had an e-mail exchange with Eilperin* about the book and her reporting adventures. With Shark Week nearing an end (I still think whats needed is Human Week), this seemed an appropriate time to post our Q&A. Here it is, with some shorthand cleaned up:

title: Honda Recalls 1.5 Million Accords, CR-Vs and Elements to Reprogram Transmission Software
description: Honda is recalling about 1.5 million vehicles to make a software change to reduce the chance of automatic transmissions being damaged, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Hotels Take Fitness Into Guest Rooms
description: For regular exercisers, keeping up isnt always easy when traveling. Some hotels dont have facilities, and those that do often have inconvenient hours or gyms that are small and dark.

title: It Aint Necessarily Porgy
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: In Syria, Live Fire and Dueling Narratives
description: After seeking to impose a communications blackout on the besieged city of Hama, Syrian state television aired its own footage of rubble-strewn and deserted streets as evidence, it said, of a campaign to restore normal life.

title: Where to Get the Worlds Best Service
description: The guidebooks tell you never to tip in Japan. But when my partner and I traveled there last December, and our 90-pound bellhop insisted on carrying our overstuffed suitcases to our room, we thought a few hundred yen was more than appropriate. She politely refused our money. And over the course of the next week, so did the hotel clerks who equipped us with umbrellas at the first sign of drizzle, the concierges who booked us tables at mind-blowing sushi restaurants too off the grid to be listed on the Internet and the restaurant owners who presented us with a souvenir menu  in English  to commemorate all the delicious food we had just eaten. No tipping meant no tipping, period.

title: The Supreme Courts Painful Season
description: Its against my interest as a professional Supreme Court obsessive to say this, but the last term was straight-up dull. There were some weighty outcomes  for example, in a pair of cases about workplace discrimination and consumer rights, the court gave corporate defendants a road map for evading class-action lawsuits. On the whole, though, the term lacked drama: no news-cycle-eating cases or base-enflaming confirmation battles to be found.

title: Speaking Ill
description: A person in our company recently committed suicide. Of course, it was shocking. But now colleagues are recalling harsh words that were exchanged between the employee and a supervisor, and they are blaming management. What the colleagues dont know is that the employees work had been subpar for years and that much of it had to be redone (by management). Setting the record straight would help people make sense of what happened. It may seem unkind, but would it be unethical? NAME WITHHELD

title: The Phantom Menace of Sleep-Deprived Doctors
description: Last month something extraordinary happened at teaching hospitals around the country: Young interns worked for 16 hours straight  and then they went home to sleep. After decades of debate and over the opposition of nearly every major medical organization and 79 percent of residency-program directors, new rules went into effect that abolished 30-hour overnight shifts for first-year residents. Sanity, it seemed to people who had long been fighting for a change, had finally won out.

title: The Trivialities and Transcendence of Kickstarter
description: We had this idea, some friends and I, for a small public art project in New Orleans last year. The problem was, it involved some professional printing that would cost a few thousand dollars, which none of us had. Usually thats where such conversations end: it would be cool if we could do X, but were not going to get a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, even if we knew how to pursue such a thing. So lets get another round of beers.

title: Hello, Lauren! A Former Fanny Brice on the New Funny Girl in Town
description: In June the singer and comedian Marilyn Michaels wrote a guest Theater Talkback post for ArtsBeat about the challenges of casting the role of Fanny Brice in the musical Funny Girl. (Barbra Streisand originated the part when the show opened on Broadway in 1964; Ms. Michaels played it in the original national touring company.) On Wednesday it was announced that Lauren Ambrose would play the role in the Ahmanson Theater revival in Los Angeles, which is expected to end up on Broadway. That left Ms. Michaels wondering: Has the right Fanny been found?

title: Multiple Fears Weigh on Markets
description: Aug. 5, 2011 - Concerns about Europe's sovereign debt crisis and fears of a double-dip recession in the U.S. are weighing heavily on markets.

title: Preconceptions
description: A few years ago, when I knew I was heading toward becoming a parent, I began to think about what sort of parent I wanted to be. And I began to weigh whether or not I should spank. I grew up in the 70s and was spanked  quite a bit. I think the vast majority of black children of my generation were spanked, and nearly all the black kids in my parents generation were. Spanking seemed like a black cultural imperative: black people tell one another, Spare the rod, spoil the child.

title: Atheist Event to Be Held at Fort Bragg
description: Fort Bragg in North Carolina has reached a truce of sorts with a group of Army atheists that opens the door for an event called Rock Beyond Belief on post next spring featuring music and speeches by noted secular humanists, including the writer Richard Dawkins .

title: Questions for Cornel West
description: Cornel West flunks Race Relations 101. I have admired West for many years; I am dismayed, however, at his statements about smart white brothers and smart Jewish brothers. Judaism is a religion, not a race. West wouldnt refer to smart Catholic brothers or smart Mormon brothers or smart Protestant brothers, so why does he do so in reference to Jewish brothers? This racial/religious reference perplexes and offends me and displays ignorance.

title: You Are Making Your Biscuits Wrong
description: You have solved a 65-year family mystery! I have tried to replicate my Tennessee mother-in-laws fabulous biscuits. I thought it was because she made them every single day. Now I know it was just the flour she used.

title: Ladies, We Have a Problem
description: Rebecca Traister misses an essential point in her recent, compelling article on womens sexuality and power, Ladies, We Have a Problem. Namely, theres a growing worldwide movement to prosecute rape, child pornography and gender violence as crimes against humanity. Under the Rome Statute of 1998, the International Criminal Court defines crimes against humanity to include rape, sexual slavery, enforced prostitution, forced pregnancy, enforced sterilization or any other form of sexual violence of comparable gravity. Forget the Toronto policeman; ladies, we have a growing worldwide movement behind us.

title: Yemen on the Brink
description: In the 1980s, when the U.S. helped overthrow the government of South Yemen and then installedSaleh, the president of North Yemen, as our proxy dictator in a united Yemen, we sowed the seeds ofour own defeat in a Middle Eastern country  again.

title: Magically Resistant to the Ego-Bloating Properties of Hollywood Life
description: Heather Havrilesky in her recent Riff has it backward: puerile vicarious celebrity thrills and pursuit of [sexual] pleasure is indeed the coin of the realm on Entourage.

title: Ex-Leader of Ukraine Is Held for Contempt; Activists See Purge in Progress
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The former prime minister of Ukraine was arrested in a courtroom here on Friday for contempt, during her trial on what rights advocates say is a trumped up charge that centers on whether a document was stamped correctly.

title: Lbecks Spires, a Quick Hop From Hamburg
description: WITH its soaring spires, ubiquitous crow-step gables and dozens of courtyards lined with centuries-old houses, its easy to see why Unesco placed a large swath of the northern German city of Lbeck on its list of World Heritage Sites.

title: Of Spires, Gables and Courtyards
description: Explore the citys myriad alleys and courtyards to discover Lbecks most enchanting buildings.

title: Mark McNairy Makes Us Smile
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#221", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Williamsburg on the Hudson
description: Millerton, N.Y.

title: Following an Artist Into His Labyrinth
description: PARIS

title: Woods Sputters in Second Round, Cant Threaten Leaders
description: AKRON, Ohio  On a still Friday, hot, humid and ideally suited to having a go at a soft Firestone Country Club, many players did. Tiger Woods did not, but again saw positives about his golf game not visible to the untrained eye.

title: Strategies for Acing the Open House
description: WITH the help of the Internet, prospective buyers can gather a heap of details about properties before stepping near any one of them.

title: Challenges Ahead on Arctic Drilling
description: As John Broder and I report in The New York Times, Shell won a big victory by gaining conditional approval from the Interior Department for its plan to drill for oil in the Beaufort Sea off the North Slope of Alaska. The decision takes the company a giant step closer to drilling oil wells in the Arctic after five years of trying to break through court and regulatory hurdles. But the battle is not over, and environmentalists will surely redouble their efforts.

title: Length of Unemployment Continues to Break Records
description: The average worker who is unemployed has been searching for a job for 40.4 weeks, or more than nine months, according to new Labor Department figures.

title: Resisting the Urge to Run Away From Home
description: In market moments like these, its always tempting do something really big and bold with our investments.

title: When the National Pastime Imitates the Countrys Politicians
description: What a spectacle of undignified behavior, of hypocrisy, of extremism, of civility abandoned, of epic brattiness. Could a disgraced city possibly have proved itself more worthy of its reputation?

title: The State of Zombie Literature: An Autopsy
description: Zombies, traditionally, do not move with great speed or agility. As the sheriff in George A. Romero's classic 1968 movie, "Night of the Living Dead," astutely observes, Theyre dead, theyre all messed up. But theyre also mighty persistent, and, apparently through sheer doggedness, the reanimated deceased have managed to occupy increasingly large areas of the popular imagination in the past few years. They dont, of course, reproduce in the usual way. The Romero-type zombie, very much the dominant form these days, multiplies by contagion, like a virus: it feeds on flesh, and its bite is lethal, so even those semi-fortunate humans who arent wholly devoured, but merely gnawed upon, die and come back as shuffling, hollow-eyed flesh-eaters themselves.

title: In Brooklyn, Blurring the Wealth Boundary
description: WHEN the developers of Atlantic Terrace, an 80-unit co-op in Fort Greene, began planning, they envisioned occupants reflecting the populace on the sidewalks of Brooklyn  that is, diverse in all ways, but especially economically.

title: Reservation Road, Revisited
description: John Burnham Schwartzs 1998 novel, Reservation Road, was acclaimed by critics and readers alike, translated into many languages and, almost a decade later, turned into a well-regarded movie of the same name. Ricocheting in brief, staccato chapters among the perspectives of its main characters, Schwartzs narrative depicted the shattering consequences of a hit-and-run accident on two Connecticut families. It ended with Dwight, the driver who killed a 10-year-old boy, about to confess to the police and go off to jail. But it also hinted that the families two surviving children  Dwights son, Sam, and the dead boys sister, Emma  would suffer the true emotional fallout of this tragedy.

title: A Writer Investigates Madness, His Own and Others
description: I write this knowing from experience that when you publish a memoir, the reviews tend to be not of your writing ability, but of your personality. In The Rules of the Tunnel, Ned Zeman  who chronicles his attempts to control clinical depression through myriad doctors, hospitals, psychiatric meds and finally electroconvulsive therapy, all while juggling a high-profile career as an editor for Vanity Fair  shows that he is a gifted writer, capable of the kind of cut-glass prose to be carried into sunlight and admired from all angles:

title: Lenience for Some Off-Season Violations
description: N.F.L. players got some good and bad news about their off-field conduct during the lockout.

title: Tracking Somali Pirates to Their Lair
description: On April 8, 2009, the Maersk Alabama, a 17,000-ton United States cargo vessel, was hijacked by four Somali pirates several hundred miles east of Mogadishu. Bobbing in a lifeboat with the skipper, 53-year-old Richard Phillips, they began negotiating with the ships owners via cellphone for a multimillion-dollar ransom. For five days, the pirates and their hostage drifted in the Indian Ocean, shadowed by the U.S.S. Bainbridge, a destroyer that arrived at the scene not long after the hijacking. At dusk on April 12, Navy snipers killed three of the Somalis, and Phillips was rescued unharmed. The surviving pirate was seized and taken to the United States, where he pleaded guilty in a Manhattan courtroom to a host of charges and was sentenced to 33 years and nine months in a federal prison.

title: The Pirates of Somalia
description: Prologue

title: A Novel of Jazz, Soul and Civil Rights
description: Clyde Edgertons slim, charming 10th novel is set in the rural South, as the spring of 1963 turns into summer. It is a fraught moment in American history, but in the town of Starke, N.C., the rhetoric and rupture of the civil rights movement are still felt only as distant tremors. Change may be blowing in the wind, as the idiom of the day had it, but it still has to travel across the ground.

title: Up Front: Adam Mansbach
description: If you know anything about Adam Mansbach, you probably know that his daughters bedtime routine makes him entertainingly cranky. Mansbach is famous these days for his best-selling childrens book, Go the _ to Sleep, but before he was a father he was a novelist (his playful, complicated novels about race include Angry Black White Boy and The End of the Jews), and before he was a novelist he dreamed, 25 years ago, of becoming a hip-hop star.

title: The Night Train
description: PART I

title: The Mathematics of Changing Your Mind
description: Sharon Bertsch McGrayne introduces Bayess theorem in her new book with a remark by John Maynard Keynes: When the facts change, I change my opinion. What do you do, sir?

title: Which Way to the Garden of Eden?
description: Most people probably think the search for a real Garden of Eden was abandoned centuries ago. With so many modern scientific advances, the discovery of fossil evidence from early ages and, of course, the advance of Darwins theory of evolution, surely no one would be so mad as to look for an actual Eden. Brook Wilensky-Lanfords first book, Paradise Lust, suggests just the opposite.

title: Our Spy War with China
description: In May 2004, the F.B.I. special agent James J. Smith found himself in an uncomfortable spot: he had to tell a federal judge about an affair hed had with an informer, Katrina Leung, a San Marino, Calif., businesswoman with jet-black hair, while his wife and son were sitting in the courtroom. Argh! he later wrote to friends.

title: Tiger Trap
description: Chapter One

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 5
description: Subjects include foraging in New York City parks, a rare seagull in Coney Island, and a stuntman who wants to walk a tightrope over Niagara Falls.

title: Too Greedy to Fail
description: If reality exists only in each individuals warped consciousness, then there is no such thing as objective truth. Thats how some artists see it, anyway  and also, apparently, some bankers. The title of Justin Cartwrights acerbic and entertaining new novel, Other Peoples Money, comes from the gleeful shout heard in dealing rooms  O.P.M.!  as bankers lose bad bets on behalf of their clients. Cartwright illustrates the folly, showing how the recent financial collapse resulted from speculative fantasies and from an attitude that none of the risks were quite real.

title: Reading Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Writing Behind Bars
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharpshooters
description: To the Editor:

title: Grimm Lessons
description: Those blood-lusty Jacobean dramatists could have picked up a few pointers about betrayal and revenge from Reginald Hill, who turns a contemporary crime of greed into a timeless morality tale in THE WOODCUTTER (Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99). For all its elaborate narrative artifices, theres a fairy-tale simplicity to this story of a Cumbrian woodcutters son who accomplishes three difficult tasks (Get elocution lessons, get educated, get rich) and is granted his hearts desire  the hand of the beautiful princess glimpsed dancing on the castle lawn.

title: Editors Choice
description: THIS BEAUTIFUL LIFE,  by Helen Schulman (Harper/HarperCollins, $24.99.) In this timely novel, a familys Manhattan life comes crashing down when their 15-year-old forwards a sexually explicit video made for him, unsolicited, by a girl two years younger.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE SHALLOWS: What the Internet Is Doing to Our Brains,  by Nicholas Carr (Norton, $15.95.) In 2008, Carr, a technology writer, published an article in The Atlantic titled Is Google Making Us Stupid? The Shallows expands on that article, arguing that we are trading away the seriousness of sustained attention for the Webs frantic superficiality.

title: Mobilizing Help for People Accused of Hacking
description: When Senator Joseph R. McCarthy held hearings in the 1950s to question witnesses about their supposed ties to communism, critics accused him of fomenting a Red Scare hysteria.

title: An Ex Blogs. Is it O.K. to Watch?
description: I HAVE a good friend who, like countless others, is addicted to Googling ex-boyfriends. Instead of coffee breaks, she goes on periodic search sprees where she looks up old lovers, passing fancies and mere crushes.

title: Boss Reaches Deal With Raiders
description: The free-agent tight end Kevin Boss agreed to a four-year deal with the Oakland Raiders on Friday morning. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Father and Son Plead Guilty to Energy Deal Insider Trading
description: 8:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Outdoor Pools: Sun. Splash. Repeat.
description: LIKE iced tea, perhaps, or casual Fridays, outdoor pools are in many minds forever linked with summer. After all, the sensation of sun on wet skin after a few dips in the deep end just about sums up the season.

title: Inside the List
description: WONDERFUL TOWN: Amor Towles, whose first novel, Rules of Civility, hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 16, arrived in New York in 1989 with diplomas from Yale and Stanford and dreams of becoming a writer. But he quickly noticed that all his friends who were waiting tables and pursuing art on the side looked just as tired as the office drones they were serving. So he joined an investment firm instead and took seven years off from writing. Towles, today a principal in a money management concern, says the novels success, though wonderful, has been less important than simply finishing something he thought was good. I wouldve sold it for a penny, just to be able to say O.K., I did it,  he said in a telephone interview. I always thought I was a writer on the inside, but after a few years of not writing you cant make that claim anymore.

title: A Boss Worthy of the Name Muscles Its Way Into the Family
description: Gardena, Calif.

title: A BMW 6, Riding on 2 Wheels
description: REVIEWS of BMWs new luxury-class touring motorcycle, the 2012 K1600, tend to be in agreement: this bike handles well. Yet the evaluations often seem to harbor the same implied asterisk: it handles well for a big bike.

title: For Wild Mustangs, Heaps of Thoroughbred Power
description: Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Closets Even for the Kayaks
description: FOR nearly six years, Ana Del Castillo and Marc Amiel rented a large one-bedroom in the Century building in Spuyten Duyvil, part of Riverdale in the Bronx.

title: You Dont Want to Be an American Idiot
description: As I note in this weekends Your Money column, its times like these that tempt us to send a message to governmental leaders who wont make hard choices and take our stock market money to countries that seem safer.

title: Counting the Ways to Cook an Eggplant
description: FOR the last few summers, Ive been in an eggplant rut. No matter how many times I stand over the pile of the multi-hued beauties at the farmers market, swearing Ill try something new, I always fall back on my standby recipe: toss eggplant cubes with good olive oil and roast until they turn golden at the edges and meltingly soft inside.

title: As Humans Draw Nearer, Leopards Attack in India
description: Several rural villages in India have suffered leopard attacks in recent months, most recently on Saturday in the northeastern state of Assam. In July alone, nearly 16 people were mauled in four different attacks across the country. The most serious was in the eastern state of West Bengal, where a leopard wandered into a village and injured 11 people.

title: Sanity Is Next Issue in Brooklyn Boys Killing
description: Now that Levi Aron has been found competent to stand trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the next step for his lawyers is to determine whether he was sane at the time of the crime he is accused of committing: kidnapping, killing and dismembering an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy, Leiby Kletzky.

title: The search for the Garden of Eden; "A Book of Secrets" by Michael Holroyd; and bestseller news.
description: This week, author Brook Wilensky-Lanford talks about the search for the Garden of Eden in her new book, "Paradise Lust"; Toni Bentley reviews "A Book of Secrets" by Michael Holroyd; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has bestseller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Pagani Huayra Makes Landfall in Southern California
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Horacio Pagani, the Argentine maker of exotic Italian sports cars, officially unveiled his newest creation, the $1.2 million Huayra, to a North American audience of journalists and prospective customers here Thursday evening.

title: The Jam | Prince Language
description: Since house music is all the rage these days, Sean Hanratty chose New Yorks coveted D.J. and producer Prince Language for this weeks playlist. D.J. Prince Language has been spinning house music for a really long time, says Hanratty of the D.J. whose remix work for acclaimed artists like LCD Soundsystem, the Rapture and MGMT put him on the map as one of New York Citys most in-demand remixers in dance music. His is a near-encyclopedic knowledge of both hip-hop and house. Language, who hails from Chicago and now calls Manhattans Alphabet City home, worked on Twin Shadows debut album, Forget, and is currently at bat on a remix for Light Asylum, as well as his own record. If you missed his performance at P.S. 1 last weekend, which he headlined with legendary hip-hop D.J. Stretch Armstrong, hell be at Le Bain on Saturday for Swimming With Sharks.

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/05/11
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/05/11

title: Megan Fairchild and Andrew Veyette
description: MEGAN FAIRCHILD is so petite and sinewy that she looks as if she might weigh about as much as a tutu.

title: Weekend Fare
description: City Winery, 155 Varick Street (Vandam Street), in SoHo, partners with Finger On the Pulse for the first annual Summer BBQ Blow Out Festival on Saturday from 1 to 4 p.m. Ten chefs  including Sam Talbot, Christina Tosi and Noah Bermanoff  have created barbecue-inspired dishes for this feast and dance party, which includes live music. A general admission ticket, $60, gets you samples from all the chefs and two drinks.

title: Baseball Embraces Dry, as in Wit
description: Somewhere along the line, Stephen Colbert figured out that comedy and sports make rather natural bedfellows. Actually, most days, sports produces enough of its own absurdity that contributions from comedians are hardly necessary. But Colbert has not been shy about contributing to the mix. Before the Winter Olympics last year, he not only sponsored the United States speedskating team, he also climbed into a spandex suit and rode with the mens bobsled team.

title: Avery Is Accused of Shoving a Police Officer in Los Angeles
description: Rangers forward Sean Avery was arrested in Los Angeles around 1 a.m. on Friday on a misdemeanor charge of battery on a police officer, the Los Angeles Police Department said.

title: Edwards Ordered to Pay $2 Million
description: The Federal Elections Commission ruled on Friday that John Edwards must pay $2 million because of his failure to accurately declare cash on hand and expenses during his 2008 presidential campaign.

title: NASA Launches Probe to Jupiter
description: The probe Juno will search for clues to the origins of the solar system.

title: The Caucus | An Uneasy Voter Outlook
description: Megan Liberman and Michael Cooper on the present political landscape. Also, a report from Texas on Rick Perry's prayer event.

title: The Caucus | An Uneasy Voter Outlook
description: Aug. 5, 2011 - Megan Liberman and Michael Cooper on the political landscape among economic anxiety and high disapproval of Congress.

title: Caucus Video: Economic Unease and Disapproval of Congress; Governor Perrys Prayer Meeting
