description: Megan Liberman and Michael Cooper on how economic anxiety and high disapproval of Congress is affecting the political landscape. Also, a report from Texas on Gov. Rick Perrys prayer event.

title: Breakdown of How You Bake Your Biscuits
description: Sam Siftons Eat story on biscuits prompted a lot of heated response. We gathered some of the data on biscuits far and wide for our Reply All page in this weeks magazine.

title: Michael Kors to Wed
description: Michael Kors may be the Zelig of American fashion, dropping into viewers living rooms each week, as a judge on Project Runway, chatting with customers at trunk shows across the country, and even playing himself on the small screen now and then as he did in an episode of Gossip Girl. But high profile or no, Mr. Kors is adamant about keeping his personal life under wraps  even as his wedding day approaches.

title: A Cornetists Final Room, 80 Years On
description: Paul Maringelli stepped into Apartment 1G and walked into an empty bedroom that was stifling hot.

title: Banks Face Obstacles With Volcker Rule, Report Finds
description: Wall Street has its hands full with the Volcker Rule, according to a new report by the consulting firm Deloitte.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Spider-Man No. 666
description: Volume two of I Am Here, by Ema Toyama, enters our manga list at No. 10 this week. The series, published by Kodansha Comics, is about an eighth grader named Hikage Sumino who lacks self-esteem. According to the publishers blurb, her only friends are the visitors to her Internet blog. In volume two, her two worlds merge when it seems as if an online friend may very well be someone from her real life.

title: On Project Runway, Bird Seed and Hamster Bedding
description: Words I never thought I would hear coming out of Heidi Klums mouth: I want to pee all over those wee-wee pads.

title: Managing an Investment Portfolio for Risks, Not Only Returns
description: LIKE many Americans, I watched the debate in Washington over the debt ceiling in utter disbelief that lawmakers would risk the sterling credit rating of the United States over something that had been raised 10 times since 2001.

title: Sometimes a Day in Congress Takes Seconds, Gavel to Gavel
description: WASHINGTON  Thonk!

title: Big Deal | Restoring a Vision
description: The penthouse at the Metal Shutter Houses, a condominium designed by the architect Shigeru Ban and located at an epicenter of modern architecture, on 19th Street in West Chelsea, was snapped up immediately after it went on the market in 2007.

title: Blogger Cited by Norway Killer Comes Forward to Denounce Him
description: In composing his 1,500-page, hate-filled manifesto [pdf], the man accused of the massacre in Norway last month, Anders Behring Breivik, drew on a well of anti-Muslim thought in Europe and the United States.

title: History As Viewed From Below
description: NEW BERN, N.C.  There are many ways to make history, but there can be few places where you can watch it being remade with as much intelligence and contrast as here, a North Carolina village that was at one time the states capital.

title: Behind the Scenes With Mark McNairy
description: The Moment goes behind the scenes with Mark McNairy and his new collection.

title: Restaurant Report: Sansho, in Prague
description: After the soft-shell crab sliders on fluffy rice buns dressed with peppery wasabi cream, after the fresh asparagus salad with tangy lime, aromatic mint and a blast of fiery chile, youll probably ask yourself: When, exactly, did we leave Prague?

title: Lessons on Nature From a Cellphone Call
description: ON the way out to explore the rolling white-sand dunes of Fort Ord Dunes State Park, Californias newest state park, pause at the marine sanctuary lookout point to check out an illustrated map of Monterey Bays underwater canyon.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Keen in Palo Alto, Calif.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Trading Tiaras for Calico on the Prairie
description: I WANT to be a pioneer! exclaimed Annie Foley, 9, of Omaha, climbing on a teeter-totter made of old wagon wheels and a wooden board at the Laura Ingalls Wilder homestead in De Smet, S.D.

title: Letters: About Same-Sex Couples in Hotels
description: Same-Sex Concerns

title: Slovenian Rhapsody
description: EVENING was fast approaching in the Slovenian town of Piran when the chimes of the Chiesa di San Giorgio reminded me that the piano concerto was about to begin. As the sun slanted across the Adriatic, I hurried toward the vast Tartini Square  named for Giuseppe Tartini, the Baroque-era Italian violinist and composer  past outdoor cafes, where boisterous groups of Slovenians were devouring Balkan sausages and toasting one another  Na zdravje! (To your health!)  with local Lasko beer.

title: Where Alaskan Adventurers Lay Their Heads
description: WHEN hiking alone in Alaska, Id been told, make noise. The last thing you want is to surprise a bear. And so I was doing my best to fill the woods with song, belting out Broadway tunes as I trekked the Denver Glacier Trail, when an enemy stepped right onto my path. This was no bear, however, but the beady-eyed state bird of Alaska, the ptarmigan.

title: Slovenia: A Bicultural Mash-Up
description: The Italo-Slavic hybrid is just one of many surprises in this tiny nation.

title: Discovering Laura Ingalls Wilder
description: De Smet, South Dakota, has long been a popular family destination.

title: In North Michigan, Cherries Are Just the Beginning
description: Traverse City, best known for its cherry products and wines, has a growing culinary and arts scene that shows theres more to the region than orchards and vines.

title: Samurai Shopper | If the Gloss Sticks
description: This week Andy Warhol would have been 83 years old. As an artist who immortalized mass-produced commercial products, Warhol ruffled the feathers of the fine art establishment with his cheerfully banal connoisseurship. Gore Vidal once said Warhol was a genius with the IQ of a moron. In that, Warhol reminds me of the reclusive simpleton Chauncey Gardener, the character in Jerzy Kosinskis Being There lauded for uttering Zen-like nuggets of wisdom when, in fact, like the quotable Warhol, he was a mere precursor to Forrest Gump.

title: Cabin-Hopping in Alaska
description: The public-use cabins in Alaska are scenically located along lakes, atop mountains or on coastal islands.

title: Telling Fortunes, and, From Time to Time, Also Taking Them
description: My life and my home have been wrecked through a fortune teller! Mary Skaylanski of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, shouted in court.

title: Tech and the San Francisco Rental Bubble
description: Ive recently learned that real estate brokers in San Francisco have reached a consensus on a topic thatentrepreneursand investors cant seem to agree on: that we are in the midst of a technology bubble.

title: Adding to an Already Large Family
description: With the Mustang GT and GT500, along with the Boss 302, Ford is producing more high-performance pony cars.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 5
description: The day in sports, including a hot day at N.F.L. training camps and riding the waves off England.

title: Coheed and Cambria Parts Ways With Its Bassist After His Arrest
description: The progressive rock band Coheed and Cambria announced on Friday that it had parted ways with its bassist, Mike Todd, three weeks after he was arrested on charges of robbing a pharmacy in Massachusetts to obtain prescription painkillers.

title: Robert Ryans Quiet Furies
description: BORN to play beautifully tortured, angry souls, the actor Robert Ryan was a familiar movie face for more than two decades in Hollywoods classical years, his studio ups and downs, independent detours and outlier adventures paralleling the arc of American cinema as it went from a national pastime to near collapse. A little prettier and he might have been one of the golden boys of the golden age. But there could be something a touch menacing about his face (something open and sweet too), which bunched as tight as a fist, and his towering height (he stood 6 foot 4) at times loomed like a threat. The rage boiled up in him so quickly. It made him seem dangerous.

title: Officers Guilty of Shooting Six in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  In a verdict that brought a decisive close to a case that has haunted this city since most of it lay underwater nearly six years ago, five current and former New Orleans police officers were found guilty on all counts by a federal jury on Friday for shooting six citizens, two of whom died, and orchestrating a wide-ranging cover-up in the hours, weeks and years that followed.

title: Desert Tales, Centuries Apart
description: The Egyptian

title: Port Authority Seeks Big Toll Increase
description: The cost of crossing the bridges and tunnels that span the Hudson River to New York City could rise by 50 percent for many drivers under a steep series of toll increases to be proposed on Friday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to two people familiar with the plans.

title: Complaints That Rent Is Illegally High Often Languish
description: Relations between Maria de los Santos and the landlord of her railroad apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, soured after she filed a complaint in 2007 over lack of heat. But they worsened, she said, after she discovered she had been overcharged in rent and appealed to the state housing agency for help.

title: When Parents Fight
description: What is the role of fighting in a marriage? Julie Kennon wonders about that in a guest post today. Join in. But lets try to make it a clean, fair fight

title: Fantasy Football: Free Agency Recap
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Notes on the Un-recovery
description: We spent the day on a family outing, and left before they replaced the exhausted hamsters that power the BLS website. So, some belated commentary on the jobs report and related.

title: Anti-stimulus Politics
description: Via FT Alphaville, Cullen Roche likes what I said in todays column except that its too political, and then asks why I dont call for a temporary cut in payroll taxes, which Republicans, who love tax cuts, would support.

title: Debt Deal Could Be a Job-Killer For Incumbents
description: Initial public reaction to the deficit-reducing deal reached by President Obama and Congress is fairly poor. Although there is some variance from survey to survey, on average approval of the deal registers at 38 percent against 49 percent disapproval across four national polls conducted on it so far.

title: Facebook Groups Made Easy
description: Have you ever e-mailed a bunch of photos to your family? Or written an e-mail to all of your best friends trying to plan a trip? Or have you done the same thing on Facebook, trying to carry on a discussion in a message to a dozen recipients? Facebook has a fix for that  Facebook Groups  explicitly designed to let a small set of people communicate with one another either in public, or in private. Groups are meant to replace mailing lists for people planning weddings, parties or team events.

title: The World Trade Center Ship, From Stern to Stem
description: After finding the stern of an 18th-century sailing vessel in landfill where the new World Trade Center is being constructed, what could be better? Finding the bow  or at least enough to gain a clearer picture of the length of the vessel and how it was constructed; all of which might help solve the mystery of what it was doing anchored off Lower Manhattan in the first place.

title: Tesla-Powered Toyota RAV4 E.V. to Be Built in Canada, Not California
description: When Toyota and Tesla Motors announced an agreement last year to collaborate on electric versions of the RAV4 compact S.U.V., there was much speculation that the battery car would be built at the 5.5-million-square-foot Nummi plant in California that Tesla bought in 2010. The plant, based in the Bay Area community of Fremont, had been jointly operated by Toyota and General Motors, and had sufficient capacity to accommodate production of other vehicles alongside the Model S sedan, expected to begin deliveries in mid-2012.

title: Cycling in Wheat Country (Horse Country, Too)
description: CHENEY, Wash.  A beautiful, difficult three-day ride through the Palouse region of eastern Washington has left me leg-weary and sun-baked, and reminded of how bicycle touring lets you experience the country in intensely felt geographical segments. I made it here, a college town (Eastern Washington University) just south of Spokane, and it feels like a pivot; next I head east, toward Idaho, Montana and the Rockies.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kenya, Israel, Egypt and India.

title: Congressman Seeks Hearing on Benefits Merger
description: The proposed merger between two of the nations largest pharmacy benefits managers, Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions, may soon get even more scrutiny.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kenya, Israel, Egypt and India.

title: Salmonella: What Will It Take?
description: Youre not going to find a better summary of whats happening with the 36 million-pound recall of salmonella-tainted ground turkey than this post by Maryn McKenna at Superbug. She discusses not only the awesome size of the thing, but the problems with antibiotic resistance and (probably of paramount importance) the fact that its not illegal to sell food with salmonella, even though a policy like that could be enacted.

title: Big Deal | Sold for $15,400,000
description: A 25-foot-wide Upper East Side town house that underwent a two-year gut renovation was the highest sale of the week, at $15.4 million, city property records show.

title: The Risks You Can Control
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes that a stock market dive or the debt debate in Washington are events you have no control over. But he says there may be risks in your portfolio that you can control.

title: Postcard From Edinburgh: Getting in Early to a Fringe Favorite
description: EDINBURGH The Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the largest multi-arts festival in the world, began on Friday, but the city was in full Fringe mode well ahead of schedule. On just about every corner  and between them, too  advertisements for Fringe productions adorned fences, lampposts and various other surfaces. And humans, of course.

title: No Prints? Evidence Points to Mutated Gene
description: Fingerprints are used as identity markers. No two are alike. But there are people with a rare condition called adermatoglyphia who have no fingerprints at all. Now, Dr. Eli Sprecher, a geneticist and dermatologist at the Tel Aviv Sourasky Medical Center in Israel, and his colleagues have identified the gene mutation that causes the disease.

title: Euro Builder Ends His Career on a Bitter Note
description: FRANKFURT  Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, has spent much of his career building and defending the euro. But now, in a bitter twist, it looks as if his career may well end with the common currency in shambles.

title: That Was The Inflation Scare That Was
description: A little while back many people made a big deal over the fact that measures of core inflation, if you took monthly data at an annual rate, were running above 3 percent. Some of us tried to make the case that this wasnt really reflecting a big rise in underlying inflation, that it was mainly contamination of the core by transitory effects of commodity prices; but this brought much jeering.

title: Petitioning for Right to Mock British Parliament
description: The international edition of the Daily Show, a weekly compilation of the best clips from Jon Stewarts news satire program, did not air in Britain two weeks ago, as has been well-documented by the blog Mediaite.

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: Mental Health
description: You will have to ask my teeth; I keep my name in my teeth, the woman responded when I asked her name.

title: Heat Sensor Helps Vampire Bat Find Meals
description: Vampire bats need a blood meal every day or two to survive. And an ability to detect infrared radiation with their noses aids them in their search for sustenance by allowing them to pinpoint areas where blood flows near the surface in their prey.

title: A British Admirer of America Finds His Voice
description: LONDON

title: Daughter Leads, Mom Follows in Fashion Sync
description: ONCE upon a time, mothers paled at their daughters fashion choices. Going braless? Horrors! Bare midriff? God forbid.

title: Making Waves, With No Apology
description: HAVING curly hair makes me taller, more literary and better in bed. Perhaps not everyone agrees with me, like, say, my husband and the 500 men I dated before him who dumped me. But forget that. I know its true. Or at least its the story I tell myself every time I have a bout of Straight Hair Envy, when I ponder the possibilities of the Brazilian Blowout (surely formaldehyde seeping into the scalp cant be that bad?) or wistfully cruise the aisles of Rickys jonesing for Fekkai Silky Straight Ironless, Redken Align 12 Ultra-Straight Balm and John Frieda Frizz-Ease Straight Fixation Smoothing Crme.

title: Julys Political Best Sellers
description: A World On Fire by Amanda Foreman makes its debut at No. 10. Ms. Foreman, the acclaimed historian, sheds light on the vast involvement that Britain had in the American Civil War; the fruits of her research shocked her: finding that countless British writers, students, actors and others sympathized with the feudal South. The Storm Of War by Andrew Roberts debuts at No. 13. A British historian, Roberts ponders that if the Axis had strategized and made better decisions, they possibly could have won World War II. And the final debut is The Triple Agent by Joby Warrick at No. 14. This is the first comprehensive account of the C.I.A. blunder that allowed a Qaeda mole, Humam al-Balawi, a Jordanian pediatrician turned spy, to detonate a custom-made vest of explosives that took the lives of nine intelligence operatives at a C.I.A. base in Afghanistan.

title: By One Survey, Fewer Jobs Than 2 Years Ago
description: The job numbers every month come from two different surveys, which sometimes point in different directions. The establishment survey questions employers, and produces one headline number. This month it concluded that, seasonally adjusted, the economy added 117,000 jobs in July. The household survey asks people if they are working, and is used to calculate the unemployment rate.

title: Adding Glitter to Eyeglass Frames
description: IN April, Paula Deen, the television cooking personality, introduced a line of prescription eyeglasses, retailing for about $30 each in Wal-Mart stores nationwide, a few aisles away from her popular casserole dishes. There are a dozen pairs in the collection, each the kind of acetate rectangle thats become ubiquitous.

title: Ethics Panel Takes Action in 3 Cases
description: Representative Jean Schmidt, Republican of Ohio, has been ordered by the House Ethics Committee to repay a Turkish-American group $500,000 for legal services it improperly paid for to help her pursue a defamation lawsuit and other legal proceedings against a Democratic opponent in the 2008 election.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Decades of Danielle
description: Danielle Steel has had 70 books on the hardcover fiction list since 1980.

title: For Transgender Triathlete, a Top Finish in New York Is Secondary
description: After finishing in Central Park on Sunday, participants in the New York City Triathlon will huddle around the results pages, analyzing split times and category rankings.

title: A Well-Mannered Big Boy
description: With a 160-horsepower in-line 6-cylinder engine, the K1600 is powerful, but it is still a plush, responsive ride that tackles highways and twists adeptly.

title: A Battle of Microprocessors Looms
description: WHILE motorcycles typically lead cars in the area of engine performance, they are decidedly playing catch-up in the use of electronic controls. But the two-wheelers are coming on fast, moving beyond conveniences like GPS navigation to adopt functional enhancements.

title: Times Roundtable on the Economy
description: Louise Story and Binyamin Appelbaum talk with Sam Tanenhaus and Motoko Rich about the week's tumultuous economic news.

title: RuPaul: Still Strutting, on Stage and Off
description: ON more than one occasion this spring someone asked me what I thought of Raja. The first time I heard the name, in a blazer-and-tie restaurant on the Upper East Side, I furiously dug through my mental file box of designer and model names.

title: Touring the Island in a Classic
description: Bill Powers and Cynthia Rowley of Manhattan own a surf shack on Long Island, where they keep their 1971 Cougar convertible.

title: A Classic in Hot Pursuit of Long Islands Top Taco
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.

title: Besotted and Repulsed
description: Thursday on Morning Joe, Mika Brzezinski lamented how buyers of $1,500 shoes were shameless. She pointed to the front-page article in The New York Times about buoyant luxury-goods spending in a weak economy. Before the co-host Joe Scarborough teased her off the soapbox, Ms. Brzezinski unloaded some indignation.

title: Now Watching | LightHouse by NewVillager
description: Headed by the Brooklyn-based visual artists/musicians Ross Simonini and Ben Bromley, NewVillager approaches concerts as integrated events; D.J. sets are lectures and weeklong, multiroom gallery installations, like Temporary Culture, their recent show at Human Resources in Los Angeles which was designed for living, sleeping, performing and going through stages of culture, are formal opportunities to shed light on the groups dense, and at times baffling mythology. To put it in laymans terms, NewVillager is a pop band that plays art galleries. Its debut album comes out Aug. 16 on IAMSOUND Records.

title: What Complements a Pink Taco Truck? An Iridescent El Camino, of Course
description: For this Sundays Automobiles section, Auto Ego follows Bill Powers, a co-owner of Half Gallery, a contemporary art space in Manhattan, and his wife, Cynthia Rowley, the fashion designer, as they scour Montauk, N.Y., for a Mexican food truck known as the Montaco.

title: Book Review Podcast: Michael Holroyds Book of Secrets
description: In this Sundays Book Review, Toni Bentley reviews the biographer Michael Holroyds latest book, A Book of Secrets, which revisits the story of Vita Sackville-West and Violet Keppel, but with more depth and context than anyone has before.

title: Home Entertainment Spending Continues To Slide
description: LOS ANGELES  Home entertainment revenue slowed its decline in the second quarter, as total spending in the United States on DVDs, downloads and other formats fell 3.55 percent to about $3.99 billion, down from $4.14 billion in the second quarter of 2010, according to the Digital Entertainment Group. First quarter sales had fallen by about 6.41 percent from the year-earlier period.

title: Channeling a Bombshell, One Jazzy Note at a Time
description: AS a teenager watching old movies on television, Harry Allen heard Marilyn Monroe speak to him.

title: The fallout from the debt ceiling debate and a British fast food restaurant chain gains a foothold in New York
description: The fallout from the debt ceiling debate and a British fast food restaurant chain gains a foothold in New York

title: A Mothers Familiar Optimism, Without the Familiar Letdown
description: The last time most of America saw Katharine Houghton, she was playing the idealistic young white woman announcing her engagement to a noble black doctor (Sidney Poitier) in the 1967 film Guess Whos Coming to Dinner, with Katharine Hepburn, her real-life aunt, and Spencer Tracy as her parents. Now here she is as Amanda Wingfield, Tennessee Williamss faded belle and overbearing mother from The Glass Menagerie.

title: Reddy Kilowatt Works Up a Sweat
description: Its hot out there, and if you are in the electric business, you dont have to look at the thermometer to know it; a quick glance at the power consumption statistics will make it clear. Its been a rough patch for Reddy Kilowatt.

title: TimesCast | August 5, 2011
description: August 5, 2011 - Markets around the world gyrated Friday amid mixed views of the U.S. jobs report and fears that the United States and Europe were not doing enough to stabilize their economies.

title: Chic in Review | The Buzz About Vuitton
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Markets Activity
description: Daily changes in U.S. markets.

title: CBS Invites Viewers to Help Fill Big Brother Vacancies
description: Big Brother on CBS claimed the top spot for total viewers in prime time among programs on the broadcast networks Thursday night, and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, with 7.3 million viewers tuning in according to Nielsen. After the contestants voted to evict another member of the Big Brother household, it was announced that a new twist would be added to the shows long-in-the-tooth format. Fans can now go to CBS.com and vote for a previously evicted resident, and the person with the most votes will get the chance to return to the show. The reality program carried CBS to an overall ratings victory as well, averaging around 6.3 million total viewers for the night. ABC came in second, averaging just under 5.5 million viewers thanks to its reality competitions, Wipeout (6.6 million viewers) and Expedition Impossible. (4.8 million).

title: The Power of Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolyn Peterson, Theodore Nadler
description: Carolyn Ingalls Peterson, the daughter of Virginia I. Peterson and Robert R. Peterson of Greenville, N.C., was married Friday evening to Theodore Harmon Nadler, a son of Pamela Nadler and James Nadler of Manhattan. The Rev. Will Fisher, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, officiated at Eolia, the event space at Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford, Conn.

title: Sheena Chestnut, Eric Greitens
description: Sheena Elise Chestnut and Eric Robert Greitens are to be married Sunday at Beacon Hill, a caterer in Spokane, Wash. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Onstot, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate.

title: Stacey Raclin, Christopher Linn
description: Stacey Curran Raclin and Christopher Alan Brown Linn were married Saturday afternoon at the Hans Fahden Vineyard in Calistoga, Calif. The Rev. Peadar Dalton, who until 1986 was a priest with the Roman Catholic parish of St. Vincent de Paul in Mobile, Ala., officiated.

title: Elizabeth Forsyth, Michael Langan
description: Elizabeth Britta Forsyth and Michael Edward Langan were married Saturday. Kathy Bernstein, an aunt of the bridegroom and a minister of the Universal Brotherhood, officiated at the home of Leslie and Michael Lebeau, friends of the brides family, in Bainbridge Island, Wash.

title: Adiya Dixon, Erin Wiggins
description: Adiya Ayo Dixon and Erin Allen Wiggins are to be married Sunday at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y. The Rev. John L. Wallace, a Presbyterian minister and friend of the family, is to officiate.

title: Patricia Kelly and Michael Dunne
description: Patricia Eileen Kelly and Michael Hammond Dunne were married Saturday at the St. Regis in New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, officiated.

title: Mavia Brown, Andrew Haight
description: Mavia Moira Brown, a daughter of Moira A. MacAvoy of Moon Township, Pa., and George H. Brown of Toledo, Ohio, was married Saturday to Andrew McNicol Haight, the son of Susan Haight and Charles Haight of Amherst, Mass. The Rev. Richard J. Hoar performed the ceremony at St. Gabriels Roman Catholic Church in Hammondsport, N.Y.

title: Myrna Toledo, James Wang
description: Myrna Altagracia Toledo and James Daniel Wang were married Saturday. The Rev. R. John Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Stone Mill, an event space at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Kate Lindsey, Landon Jones
description: Kate Lindsey, a daughter of Nancy R. Lindsey and the Rev. Richard H. Lindsey Jr. of Richmond, Va., was married Saturday afternoon to Landon John Jones, a son of Cathryn M. Jones and Martin J. Jones of Carbon, Iowa. The brides father, a retired pastor of the Southminster Presbyterian Church in Richmond, officiated at the Lake Quinault Lodge in the Olympic National Park and Forest in Quinault, Wash.

title: Andrea Myers and Ejim Achi
description: Andrea Mari Myers, a daughter of Sheila D. Ards and Samuel L. Myers Jr. of North Oaks, Minn., was married Saturday to Ejim Peter Achi, a son of Chinyere P. Achi of Philadelphia and Peter U. Achi of Owerri, Nigeria. The Rev. Kevin McDonough performed the ceremony at the St. Peter Claver Roman Catholic Church in St. Paul. On Friday, the couple had a wedding ceremony following the traditions of the Ibo ethnic group of Nigeria; it took place in the atrium of the University of Minnesotas Humphrey School of Public Affairs in Minneapolis.

title: Alexandra Gladstone, Marcus Passer
description: Alexandra Ludsin Gladstone and Marcus Sage Passer were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Nimmi Chilamkurti and Joseph Ballou
description: Nirmala Chilamkurti and Joseph Reed Ballou are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Westin OHare in Rosemont, Ill., where Rabbi David L. Levinsky is to lead a Jewish ceremony incorporating Quaker and Unitarian elements. Earlier in the day, Pandit Pattabhirama Krishna Jois, a Hindu priest, is to lead a South Indian Hindu ceremony.

title: Jameson duPont, Thomas Collingham
description: Jameson Coffey duPont, a daughter of Onolee C. duPont of Essex, Conn., and Reynolds duPont Jr. of Fishers Island, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Thomas Harry Collingham, a son of Teresa A. Collingham and James C. Collingham of Yonkers. The Rev. Michael D. Spurlock, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Church in New York.

title: Celeste Henderson, Larry Woods Jr.
description: Celeste Kimberly Henderson, the daughter of Carolyn D. Henderson and Biff Henderson of White Plains, was married Saturday to Larry Noble Woods Jr., the son of Mary Louise Woods of Danville, Va. The Rev. Richard A. Kunz, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Melissa Enson, Jonathan Wachman
description: Melissa Beth Enson and Jonathan Thomas Wachman were married Saturday evening by Cantor Kerry Ben-David at the Omni hotel in New Haven.

title: Michelle Pascucci, David Marshak
description: Michelle Rita Pascucci and David Edmund Marshak are to be married Sunday at the Log Cabin, an event space in Holyoke, Mass. Rabbi Saul Perlmutter is to perform the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Holmes, Matthew Stuart
description: Elizabeth Ann Holmes and Matthew McDonald Stuart were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. C. Alfred Patten at Baker Memorial United Methodist Church in St. Charles, Ill.

title: Tara McAllister, Hyun-Sup Byun
description: Tara Kathleen McAllister and Hyun-Sup Byun were married Saturday evening at Christ the King Chapel of Canisius College in Buffalo. The Rev. Michael Tunney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Laurie Nehmen, Oliver Lloyd
description: Laurie Ellen Nehmen and Oliver Morris Lloyd were married Thursday evening at the Bowery Hotel in New York. The Rev. Stephen D. Parker, an Episcopal priest, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Vanessa Mendoza and Brandon Johnson
description: Vanessa Mendoza and Brandon Haywood Johnson are to be married Sunday at the Union League Cafe, a restaurant in New Haven. The Rev. Rick Rocco, a minister of the Frontline Christian Church, is to officiate.

title: Aug. 6-7: Top European Soccer Matchups
description: Its back. And if it seemed that the European soccer summer recess never happened, that is because some clubs spent June and July trying to buy a future while others were on the road in the Far East and North America selling their brand. Read more from Rob Hughes.

title: Nancy King and Andrew Yoon
description: Dr. Nancy King, the daughter of Kou-Chung King and Chun-Hsi King of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married Saturday to Dr. Andrew Yoon, a son of Kenneth Keun Yoon and Yong Suk Yoon of Cherry Hill. The Rev. Dennis Apoldite, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Sacred Heart in Trenton.

title: Elisabeth Diana, Richard North
description: Elisabeth York Diana and Richard Todd North were married Saturday evening at the de Young Museum in San Francisco. The Rev. Don Narin, a minister of the Church of Natural Grace in San Francisco, officiated.

title: Andrea Jepsen, Brett Turner
description: Andrea Lynn Jepsen and Brett Lee Turner were married Saturday. Cassandra J. Netzke, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the home of the bridegroom in St. Paul.

title: Talia Javid, Christopher Dardis
description: Talia Lynn Javid and Dr. Christopher John Patrick Dardis were married Saturday evening. Jamie A. Ross, ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary in Manhattan, officiated at Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Kristine Berzins, Michael Birnbaum
description: Kristine Berzins and Michael Birnbaum were married Saturday at the Elizabeth F. Cheney Mansion, an event space in Oak Park, Ill. Anne Fadiman, a former teacher of the bridegrooms who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Vanessa Zahorian, Davit Karapetyan
description: Vanessa Andrea Zahorian and Davit Karapetyan were married Monday at City Hall in San Francisco by Andrea Goldman, a deputy marriage commissioner. On June 11, the couple had a religious ceremony at St. Grigory the Illuminator Cathedral in Yerevan, Armenia, where Zenon Barseghyan, an Armenian Apostolic Orthodox priest, officiated.

title: Angela Lanzafama and Kyle Sweeney
description: Angela Lanzafama and Kyle Michael Sweeney were married Saturday evening at the Mallard Island Yacht Club in Manahawkin, N.J. The Rev. Kevin W. Wildes, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Happy Birthday to the Income Tax
description: Happy birthday to the federal personal income tax, which turns 150 today.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 5
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include foraging in New York City parks, a rare seagull in Coney Island, and a stuntman who wants to walk a tightrope over Niagara Falls.

title: The Woman Behind Lucys Laughs
description: HAD you met her casually with no clue as to her identity, you would never associate Madelyn Pugh Davis with the outlandish behavior and outrageous situations personified by Lucille Ball in her madcap heyday.

title: Looking for a Date as China Looks On
description: CHANGSHA, China

title: Psychedelia of Many Colors, Doo-Wop in Bluesy Shades
description: Jesse Sykes and the Sweet Hereafter

title: This Sunday: No Financial Gloom Here (Or Not Much Anyway)
description: Nothing makes the arrival of the weekend sweeter than a few days of madness in the stock market. And you may be pleased to learn that this weeks issue aims for pleasurable diversion. I couldnt be prouder of our cover stories from the last two weeks  Andrew Rices exploration of El Paso and Jurez, and Robert Worth in Yemen  but this time, we offer pure treats.

title: Ads and Fees Lift Viacom to a 37% Increase in Profit
description: Viacom, the owner of MTV and Paramount Pictures, on Friday reported a 37 percent increase in profits for the quarter that ended in June.

title: Chalky Chorus of Specters Who Dance and Crush
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival is billing its presentation of Mozarts opera Don Giovanni, featuring the conductor Ivan Fischer, the excellent Budapest Festival Orchestra and an admirable cast, as just a staged concert. While festival organizers deserve respect for their honesty in not inflating the scope of this venture, the Don Giovanni that opened at the Rose Theater of Jazz at Lincoln Center on Thursday night, which was also directed by Mr. Fischer, is more involving, imaginative and theatrically daring than many full productions I have seen.

title: Markets Activity
description: Daily changes in U.S. markets.

title: The Week That Was, in Verse
description: Thought it was safe to go back into the markets after the debt ceiling was finally raised? Wrong! On that note, we run down the top DealBook stories from the week, in poetic form:

title: Where Hip-Hop Meets the Martial Arts
description: What do you get when you mix the formality of martial arts with the brashness of hip-hop? In Hip Hop Kung Fu, at Asia Society on Wednesday night, it was an amateurish display that shed only a superficial light on the relationship between hip-hop and Asian cultures. (It is a worthy topic.) As part of Hip Hop Generation Next: From the South Bronx to East Asia, a festival organized by Dancing in the Streets and Casita Maria Center for Arts and Education, this evening-length show, also presented by Asia Society, sampled a range of styles from both sides of the world.

title: Before Bach Arrived, Others Led the Way
description: The 4x4 Baroque Music Festival has developed a yearly tradition of including a program that puts the career of Johann Sebastian Bach  who for many is still Baroque music entire  into context with the work of his predecessors.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, August 5
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures: August 5
description: More Photographs

title: A Last-Round Win in Toronto Secures the Title for a Team
description: On the last day of the Summer Nationals in Toronto last Sunday, there was a close finish to the Roth Open Swiss Teams. Aaron Silverstein, Chris Willenken, Andrew Rosenthal and Bjorn Fallenius of New York; Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif.; and Peter Fredin from Sweden were leading, with one match to be played.

title: Bike Vacations Offer Freedom and Frugality
description: LIKE many New Yorkers, Alan Tansey is planning an escape this summer  in his case, a 370-mile journey north through New York State, over the Canadian border and into the heart of Montreal.

title: Theorys Designer Shapes a New Future
description: IT was the business equivalent of a blind date.

title: Olivier Theyskenss Past Work
description: The former artistic director for Rochas and Nina Ricci, Olivier Theyskens is trying again with Theyskens Theory.

title: Back to the Simple Life, With Needle and Thread
description: WALK into the modest railroad-style brownstone apartment and it feels less like Brooklyn and more like stepping off the steam train into Little House on the Park Slope Prairie.

title: Without This Ring: Losing a Wedding Band
description: ABOUT a week into Jill Stolls marriage, a colleague grabbed her hand and exclaimed, Lets see the ring, recalled Ms. Stoll, who was teaching photography at the Dalton School. Only then did Ms. Stoll notice that both her wedding band and engagement ring were gone.

title: Law & Order, and Riverside Walks
description: Robin Roberts has not made peace with her 3:45 a.m. wake-up time, but as co-host of Good Morning America alongside George Stephanopoulos, she morphs into an early bird on weekdays in full makeup, heels and no-repeat designer outfits. She is one of the all-time leading scorers for the womens basketball team at Southeastern Louisiana University, and she was elected this year to the Womens Basketball Hall of Fame. A breast cancer survivor, she is the author of From the Heart: 7 Rules to Live By; a revised paperback version with eight rules describes her experience with the disease. Ms. Roberts, 50, lives on the Upper West Side with her wire-haired Jack Russell terrier, K.J.; she also has a home in Farmington, Conn.

title: Obama's Undoing?
description: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate the relationship between Obama and Congress.

title: The Ups and Downs of Attraction
description: THERE has always been something erotically charged about elevators. The tightness of the space, the evocative enclosure, the tension arising from keeping ones gaze from meeting anothers  all contribute to the frisson that can sometimes accompany a ride, even from the ground floor to the mezzanine. The following poems about elevators  and other modes of up-and-down conveyance, like stairs and escalators (which work on a different erotic principle)  were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

title: A.I.G. Unit at Center of Financial Crisis Is Wound Down
description: More than two years ago, fury over the financial crisis appeared to find a single target: an unassuming red-brick building in a suburban Connecticut office park.

title: Sharing Oysters, Wine and New Ideas
description: Along the western edge of Hells Kitchen, nestled amid the many car dealerships is Print, an elegant farm-to-table restaurant in the lobby of Ink48, a Kimpton hotel in a former printing plant. The spot, at 48th Street and 11th Avenue, makes its own butter and limoncello and employs a full-time forager who travels the region and beyond to find fare like 3 Corner Field Farm lamb and Battenkill Valley Creamery milk. A rarity in the neighborhood, it has become something of a go-to place for people who work at Kenneth Cole, Prada, Coach and Ogilvy & Mather, all of which have offices nearby. On Tuesday evening, the crowd included two business associates catching up.

title: Plane Is Evacuated in Philadelphia
description: A US Airways flight from Philadelphia to Anchorage was evacuated at Philadelphia International Airport on Friday afternoon after a threatening note was received saying there was a bomb onboard, officials said. Slightly more than three hours later, the plane was cleared.

title: Group of 7 Will Meet to Address Debt Issue
description: PARIS  As European leaders on Friday tried to calm fears that the regions sovereign debt problems were spinning beyond politicians control, Italys prime minister said finance ministers from the Group of 7 industrial nations would meet within days to discuss the volatile financial crisis.

title: N.F.L. Falls Short of a Leap on H.G.H.
description: The drug-testing programs of major American professional sports leagues have long attracted more attention for their gaping loopholes than for any bold advances that make cheating especially difficult.

title: Searching for a Rock Star, and Coming Up Empty
description: Wanna see my picture on the cover / Wanna buy five copies for my mother / Wanna see my smiling face on the cover of the Rolling Stone ... sang the band Dr. Hook and the Medicine Show in the 1973 hit The Cover of the Rolling Stone, on just how hard it was to get the top spot in the magazine.

title: Fox News Site Calls Obama Party a Hip-Hop BBQ
description: To most news Web sites, what happened at the White House on Thursday night was a private 50th birthday party for President Obama. To an editor at Fox News, it was something a little different.

title: Elisabeth Murdoch Wont Be Nominated to Board This Year
description: In a change to her fathers plans, Elisabeth Murdoch will not be nominated this year to the board of the News Corporation, a member of the board said Friday.

title: Broadway Ticket Booths, Palm-Size
description: APP tkts

title: A Light Fantastic Could Illuminate New York
description: Summer. A long stretch of temperatures in the 80s and 90s. Feels as if were due for a blackout.

title: Jets May Ask Mason to Take Less Money
description: With their options for finding a No. 3 receiver dwindling, the Jets on Friday continued their pursuit of Derrick Mason, the 14-year veteran who played the last six seasons with the Baltimore Ravens.

title: A Murdochs Missed Opportunity
description: When the News Corporation announced it would stop paying the legal fees for Glenn Mulcaire, the private investigator at the center of Britains tabloid phone hacking scandal, the consequences were swift. Mr. Mulcaire could obviously shed light on who at the News Corporation knew about the phone hacking and efforts to conceal it.

title: Vanessa & Davit
description: Davit Karapetyan and Vanessa Zahorian danced as Romeo and Juliet with the San Francisco Ballet. After the curtain call, Davit proposed to Vanessa.

title: Prison Term for Crimes Against Cuba Is Upheld
description: MEXICO CITY  Cubas highest court on Friday upheld a 15-year prison sentence for Alan Gross, an American contractor charged with crimes against the Cuban state for distributing satellite telephone equipment to Jewish groups in Havana.

title: Monitoring Progress of Wollman Rink in Prospect Park
description: Prospect Park Progress

title: Relief Group Stops Work in Bahrain After Raid
description: Bahrain, the tiny but strategically important Persian Gulf monarchy that has sought for months to suppress an Arab Spring-inspired uprising, is engaged in a heated dispute with one of the worlds foremost medical relief organizations, which has stopped working there after accusing Bahraini security forces of raiding its premises last week.

title: Rangers Sean Avery Is Arrested
description: Rangers forward Sean Avery was arrested in Los Angeles around 1 a.m. on Friday on a misdemeanor charge of battery on a police officer, the Los Angeles Police Department said. According to a report on the Web site TMZ, Avery is accused of shoving a police officer who was responding to a complaint about noise from a house party in the Hollywood Hills.

title: Podcast: Double-Dip Fears and Grab-and-Go Food
description: August is off to a rocky start.

title: Texas Rally Renews Debate Over the Boundaries of Perrys Faith
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In April, as Texas reeled from wildfires and a drought, Gov. Rick Perry sought assistance from the federal government, but also from a higher power. He asked the state to pray for rain, issuing an official proclamation that I, Rick Perry, Governor of Texas, under the authority vested in me by the Constitution and Statutes of the State of Texas, do hereby proclaim the three-day period from Friday, April 22, 2011, to Sunday, April 24, 2011, as Days of Prayer for Rain in the State of Texas.

title: Russian President Says U.S. Had Role in Georgian Conflict
description: MOSCOW  In an interview Friday that was timed to the third anniversary of Russias war with Georgia, President Dmitri A. Medvedev said top United States officials played a key role in events that touched off the war, and offered a withering assessment of a recent Senate resolution on Georgias behalf, which he said reflected the personal tastes of certain elderly members of the Senate.

title: On the Street | Dream Maker
description: Holly Golightly, as portrayed by Audrey Hepburn, and her imagery are having their moment with a new generation this summer.

title: Bringing In Diners With Offerings Not on the Menu
description: TEMPERATURES soared outside the Division Street Grill in Peekskill on a recent Saturday night. But inside, the unflappable guitarist Bucky Pizzarelli and his longtime bassist, Jerry Bruno, were playing it cool with well-worn standards like Satin Doll and Tangerine. And their subtle, sly treatment struck a chord with the 40 or so diners, who applauded faithfully between bites of pan-seared tuna and penne Bolognese.

title: Terms of Loan From Baseball Ease Dodgers Fear of Seizure
description: Under the terms of a $150 million loan agreement submitted to federal bankruptcy court on Friday, Major League Baseball cannot seize control of the Los Angeles Dodgers if the team defaults.

title: Battle for Libya | August 5, 2011
description: A religious leader and hundreds of Benghazi residents prayed over the body of a rebel fighter killed at the front on Thursday.

title: S.& P. Downgrades Debt Rating of U.S. for the First Time
description: WASHINGTON  Standard & Poors removed the United States government from its list of risk-free borrowers for the first time on Friday night, a downgrade that is freighted with symbolic significance but carries few clear financial implications.

title: Deep in Slop, Trying to Stop Bigger Disaster in the Hudson
description: All around Stephen Askew was raw sewage, eight feet deep, flooding a crippled waste-treatment plant in Harlem. But Mr. Askew never had a choice; he had to go in.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: Name That In-Law

title: Spanning the Globe, and Melding Cultures
description: The Olympics of contemporary art is happening this summer as nations around the world send artists to represent them at the Venice Biennale. But work that has a biennial flavor  in other words, it addresses a global audience, but with a local accent  can be seen closer to home in two shows at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford: Shaun Gladwell: Matrix 162 and Connections Gallery: Iona Rozeal Brown. One of the artists is even biennial-certified: Mr. Gladwell, along with three others, represented Australia at the 2009 Venice Biennale.

title: Many Questions About Money Remain After Financing Is Restored for F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON  It took the Senate all of about 30 seconds on Friday to approve a bill that will put 4,000 employees of the Federal Aviation Administration back to work on Monday. Calculating the cost of the 14-day standoff will take much longer.

title: For a Standout College Essay, Applicants Fill Their Summers
description: Josh Isackson, an 18-year-old graduate of Tenafly High School in New Jersey, spent the summer after his sophomore year studying Mandarin in Nanjing, China. The next year he was an intern at a market research firm in Shanghai. When it came time to write a personal statement for his college applications, those summers offered a lot of inspiration.

title: Draft Brews to Go
description: Growlers, the reusable glass jugs designed to hold draft beers, are not regularly found in retail outlets. But a new shop in Croton-on-Hudson is now offering a constantly changing lineup of brews in growlers; most of them are not even available in traditional bottles.

title: Tapas and Much More in a Warm Setting
description: LA CAMELIA celebrates its 27th anniversary this year, and may this lovely hilltop restaurant live to be 100. Styled as a European country inn, it is one of the homiest, most inviting restaurants in the county. The cozy dining rooms feature fireplaces (glowing in season), Iberian pottery, votive candlelight, a few modern Spanish prints and lovely views of the surrounding garden.

title: Red Sox Waiting for a Glimpse of the Prized Free Agent They Signed
description: BOSTON

title: Off-Center Fair Forgoes the 4-H for High Heels
description: At the Denver County Fair, the black stiletto pumps in the shoes and accessories category of competition were in trouble. Leslie Armagost, a judge, was feeling critical about the red jewel on the heel, which was a bit off-center, she thought.

title: Bold, With a Long Finish
description: If August heat discourages cooking in favor of spicy Thai takeout, local gewrztraminer would be a fitting partner. Generally this bold, spicy white wine delivers a rose-petal aroma, grapefruit- and litchi-like flavors and a pleasingly bitter finish.

title: Alvin Aileys Mission Inspires Dance Camp
description: NEWARK

title: A Rustic Seafood Spot With a Hometown Chef
description: IT is easy to miss T R Restaurant and Bar in Hampton Bays  it shares a building with Tullys Seafood Market and cannot be seen from the road. But motorists whizzing by on Foster Avenue, on their way to the Ponquogue Bridge and ocean beaches, can see a blue sign for it. Those initials, T R, stand for Tom Rutyna.

title: Is Less Defense the Best Offense?
description: Disastrous. Unacceptable. Doomsday. This is the Pentagons worst nightmare. What is it? Another 9/11? North Korea nuking Seoul? Nope  try budget cuts.

title: S&P and the USA
description: OK, so Standard and Poors has gone ahead with the threatened downgrade. Its a strange situation.

title: Free-Spirited Music With a Tamer Name
description: Richard Rivkin, 55, of Greenlawn, likes to organize musical events and, when possible, to give them catchy names. For example: Elwoodstock, the jam-band festival he started in 2001 in Elwood Park. The event had sort of a throwback-to-Woodstock vibe, he said. I couldnt resist the play on words.

title: They Had a Barn, So They Decided to Put on a Show
description: East Hampton, N.Y.

title: S.&P.s Rationale for Downgrading the U.S.
description: After weeks of of speculation, Standard & Poors downgraded on Friday the credit rating of the United States by one notch, to AA+ from AAA. The agencys outlook on the countrys short- and long-term ratings was also negative, meaning that a further downgrade to AA was possible.

title: The Campaign to Ban Islamic Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairer Share of Tax Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: No New Pledges
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Bikes, Bread and the Dutch Way of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: With 1% Growth and Staggering Debt, Italy Might Have to Cut Its Vacation Short
description: ROME  Italians may have headed to the beach for their sacrosanct summer holidays, but a storm may be brewing offshore. High debt, rising interest rates and low growth are fast eroding Italys solvency at a time when Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis government is weaker and less popular than ever before.

title: The Do-Everything Congress
description: Last week New York magazine, in a list of the worst Congresses in history, highlighted The Inarguably Awful 37th, which ran between 1861 and 1863: The very least that can be said for the other congressional classes on this list is that they did not oversee the eruption of a catastrophic civil war. And thats pretty much all the 37th Congress is remembered for  which is a shame, because it was actually one of the most productive and momentous in American history.

title: A Cafe With a Social Scene
description: The definition of the Portuguese word bolo  sweet baked food  is written in large letters on the wall of Bolo Bakery and Caf. But the words hardly do justice to a family-run business that is a social hub at breakfast and lunch as well as a bakery offering a variety of breads and pastries.

title: Where the River Meets the Salty Sound
description: IT would be hard to find a bad table at Fresh Salt, the new restaurant that replaced Terra Mar in May at the Saybrook Point Inn and Spa. Because the dining room overlooks the mouth of the Connecticut River, the view, through a wall of windows, is reliably fantastic from most vantage points and in every season. Food and service are less consistent.

title: The 111th Congress and the Lobby
description: Though only five former legislators are registered lobbyists now, a significant share will likely register as lobbyists after the one-year ban on lobbying expires.

title: Lottery Numbers
Wild Market Quiets the Buzz for I.P.O.s
description: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg NewsOfferings by well-known brands like Zynga, a maker of online games, might perform well for a time while the rest of the market struggles.

title: Ill Borrow Your Farm, You Keep My Bees
description: MILFORD, N.J.

title: Protesters Yearn for an Israel That Does More to Help Its People
description: JERUSALEM  The tent protest movement dominating Israel for three weeks focuses on the cost of living but is really about something deeper  the nature of the countrys social contract. Many Israelis feel that their sacrifices are not being repaid.

title: C.C. vs. A.J.
description: After the Yankees missed the playoffs in 2008, they invested $243.5 million in C.C. Sabathia and A.J. Burnett, the top two starting pitchers available on the free-agent market.

title: Steep Increases Proposed for PATH Fares and Tolls at Hudson Crossings
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey proposed its steepest toll increase in modern memory on Friday, unveiling a plan that would raise the cost of crossing the tunnels and bridges that span the Hudson River by 50 percent for most drivers and raise the price of a monthly PATH train pass by 65 percent.

title: After Tunisias Revolution, Disenchantment
description: In the wake of widespread unemployment, promises from the government have raised expectations and then led to recriminations.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Saturday: Flibbertigibbety
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I didnt get how funny this puzzle was until I had stared at it for what seemed like forever. At first, it just seemed like a very satisfying Saturday puzzle by Joe Krozel, with excellent 15s squaring off the grid.

title: Mark Sanford Is Still in Love
description: In 2009 you told your family and staff that you were hiking the Appalachian Trail when in fact you were visiting Maria Belen Chapur in Argentina. You called her your soul mate. Is that still the case?  I would say that I have more than well described all of my emotions and feelings toward Maria. And out of fairness to my boys and to folks that Ive hurt, Im not going to say more than this: any of those seemingly goofy feelings that I described a couple years back have intensified, not dissipated, with time.

title: In Tunisian Town of Arab Spring Martyr, Disillusionment Seeps In
description: SIDI BOUZID, Tunisia  It is hard to say for sure who took down the portrait of the revolutions most famous martyr, Mohamed Bouazizi, from its perch atop a garish gold statue on the street where he set himself on fire, touching off a season of revolt across the Arab world. One man said unnamed counterrevolutionaries did it, and another man said it was damaged by rain.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: As Corporate Profits Rise, Workers Income Declines
description: THESE are the worst of times for workers, and the best of times for companies. At least that is one way to read the newly revised national economic statistics.

title: Showing Little Fight, Mets Fall Against Braves
description: For once, the Mets did not lose a hair-raising game in their opponents final at-bat, as they had three times in a row this week.

title: NATO Crew Failed to Aid Migrant Ship, Survivors Say
description: ROME  Italy demanded on Friday that NATO investigate reports that an alliance warship failed to come to the aid of a boat full of migrants fleeing violence in Libya.

title: Bad Days and Weeks
description: Thursday was the worst day for the stock market in more than two years. Despite gains on Friday, the Dow Jones Industrial average ended the week down 5.75 percent, worse than 98 percent of the weeks in its history.

title: Series Against Red Sox Has the Yankees Thinking Pitching, Including Nova
description: BOSTON  Fresh off a strong performance against the reeling Chicago White Sox on Thursday, Ivan Nova went through his normal day-after routine for a starting pitcher because, for now, that is what he remains. As Nova answered questions about his status before the Yankees game against the Boston Red Sox on Friday he wore a big smile on his face, if only because he was still with the team.

title: Libya Rebuffs Qaddafi Son on Alliance With Radical Islamists
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi distanced itself on Friday from comments that his son Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi made the previous day, when he vowed in an interview to strike an alliance with a faction of radical Islamists among the rebels challenging his fathers rule.

title: A Fast Trip Through Washington's Revolving Door
description: The documents provided here illustrate some of Earl Pomeroys lobbying efforts since leaving Congress.

title: Rudolf Brazda, Who Survived Pink Triangle, Is Dead at 98
description: Rudolf Brazda, believed to be the last surviving man to wear the pink triangle  the emblem sewn onto the striped uniforms of the thousands of homosexuals sent to Nazi concentration camps, most of them to their deaths  died on Wednesday in Bantzenheim, in Alsace, France. He was 98.

title: Andrzej Lepper, Polish Firebrand Wary of Europe, Dies at 57
description: Andrzej Lepper, a populist politician who rose from pig farmer to deputy prime minister of Poland but whose career was undone by scandal, was found dead on Friday in his office in Warsaw, the police said. He was 57.

title: How to Respond to Rick Perry and The Response
description: Tuscaloosa, Ala.

title: Mr. Mubarak on Trial
description: For anyone who saw Hosni Mubarak in all his glory  confident and in command during three decades as Egypts president  this weeks photographs were jarring. Hollow-eyed, lying in a hospital bed, surrounded by a cage at his trial in Cairo. The all-powerful modern pharaoh is now powerless and facing justice.

title: Down to the Wire
description: More than 150 years ago, this newspaper took an editorial position on the question of tightrope walkers at Niagara Falls.We were opposed.

title: The Madman Theory
description: I had breakfast this week with one of Hollywoods most ferocious, self-confident and successful doers of deals. He was still steamed about what an unforgivably lousy negotiator his president had been on the debt ceiling agreement.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Still a Friend of Hospitals
description: WASHINGTON  Earl Pomeroy figured that Plan A was his career in Congress, where, over nearly two decades, as a North Dakota congressman he became a powerful advocate for the hospital industry.

title: Johan Santana Not Yet Ready to Give Up on Return
description: Manager Terry Collins conceded Friday that the Mets were running out of time to make up ground on the Atlanta Braves, whom they trailed by eight games in the National League wild card race at the start of the day.

title: Elmer Staats, Comptroller General in 4 Administrations, Dies at 97
description: Elmer B. Staats, who as comptroller general of the United States during four presidential administrations transformed the role of the Congressional agency that oversees federal spending from keeping track of the dollars to evaluating the efficacy of government programs, died July 23 in Washington. He was 97.

title: The Tea Party, Take Two
description: In the four months since I began writing an Op-Ed column, the thing that has most surprised me is how darned liberal I sound sometimes. I know that seems like a strange thing to say, so let me explain.

title: The World This Week, Part 1
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Yankees Winning Streak Reaches Boston and Leads to First Place
description: BOSTON  For the first time since July 6, the Yankees seized sole possession of first place in the American League East, a reward for their gaudy success over the last several weeks.

title: The World This Week, Part 2
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Political Roots in U.S. Economic Crisis
description: By nearly every recent measure  growth, consumer spending, manufacturing, house prices and stock prices  the American economy is struggling. The jobs report for July, released on Friday, was a bit better than expected, but still grim.

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: Pearls for everyone, bankruptcy in Rhode Island, American fast food in Russia, the surging sales of luxury goods, and more.

title: No Better in Europe
description: We were hopeful last month that Europes leaders had bought themselves and the global economy time to address the fundamental economic problems eroding the finances and credibility of the 17-nation euro zone.

title: Giants Sign Their Unexpected Draft Prize
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Prince Amukamara visited New York for the first time in April to attend the N.F.L. draft, he took advantage and did some exploring. Along the way, he checked a couple of items off his to-do list: riding the subway and attending a baseball game for the first time.

title: The Decade of Lost Children
description: One of the greatest casualties of the great recession may well be a decade of lost children.

title: A Wall to Remember an Eras First Exiles
description: BAINBRIDGE ISLAND, Wash.  Frank Kitamoto was only 2 when he and his family  and more than 270 others of Japanese ancestry  were forcibly removed from this forested island and sent to an internment camp after Japan bombed Pearl Harbor in World War II. Mr. Kitamoto, now 72, said he spent many of his younger years in a severe identity crisis, ashamed of his Japanese heritage and wishing he were white. Other young men went so far as to have plastic surgery to disguise their Japanese features. Some committed suicide.

title: Returning Home Again
description: A new memorial will reflect on an era when Japanese-Americans were exiled from their homes and incarcerated by the United States government because of their ethnicity.

title: Polar Bear Kills British Teenager in Norway
description: A 17-year-old British boy was killed on a remote Norwegian island when a polar bear tore through his groups campsite early Friday morning, according to officials and news reports. The bear injured four other people, two of them severely, before it was shot dead.

title: Fannie Mae Seeks More Help as Its Loss Grows
description: Fannie Mae, the mortgage-finance company under government conservatorship, reported a $2.9 billion second-quarter loss on Friday and said it would seek $5.1 billion in Treasury Department aid to balance its books. Fannie Mae requested the money to eliminate a net worth deficit of $5.1 billion for the three-month period that ended June 30, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing by the company, which is based in Washington. The loss, which compares with a $1.2 billion loss a year earlier, was mostly a result of credit-related expenses on home loans made before the 2008 financial collapse. Fannie Mae also made a $2.3 billion payment to the Treasury in the second quarter. As of the second quarter, Fannie Mae has drawn $104.8 billion in Treasury aid and paid $14.7 billion in dividends, the company reported. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac together have drawn about $170 billion in taxpayer aid.

title: Emerging Markets Lift Results at Procter & Gamble
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said Friday that its quarterly profit rose 15 percent as sales gained in emerging markets, and forecast annual revenue that topped some analysts estimates. Net income rose to $2.51 billion, or 84 cents a share, from $2.19 billion, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier, P.& G. said. The average estimate of 19 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg was for profit of 82 cents a share. Sales in the period, which ended June 30 and was the fourth quarter of Procter & Gambles fiscal year, rose 10 percent to $20.9 billion, exceeding the $20.6 billion forecast by analysts. Wood pulp, resin and other materials cost Procter & Gamble $1 billion more than expected this year and prompted price increases, the chief financial officer, Jon R. Moeller, said on a conference call. Procter & Gambles stock rose $1.01, to $60.59 a share.

title: The Caucus | Rick Perry's Day of Prayer
description: Aug. 5, 2011 - A report by Manny Fernandez from Texas on the Texas Governor's upcoming prayer event and possible presidential run.

title: Colbert Takes Over MLB.com Twitter Feed
description: Stephen Colbert is running MLB.coms Twitter feed today until 11:59 p.m. ET today.

title: Academy Award Winners
description: The movie Slumdog Millionaire and the actors Sean Penn and Kate Winslet were the big winners at the 2009 Academy Awards.

title: The Academy Award Ceremony
description: Slumdog Millionaire dominated the 81st annual Academy Awards at the Kodak Theater in Hollywood, Calif.

title: Red Carpet Fashions
description: Stars and designers made a statement on the red carpet at the 81st Academy Awards show.

title: Slumdog Cleans Up at the Oscars
description: Slumdog Millionaire won eight Oscars, including the prize for best picture, at the 81st annual Academy Awards on Sunday.

title: Deal to Share Fingerprints Is Dropped, Not Program
description: Federal immigration officials announced Friday that they were terminating the joint agreements with state and local governments that have been at the center of a controversy surrounding a national fingerprint-sharing program, although they said they would continue setting up the program unilaterally.

title: Army Deployments Will Be Shortened to Nine Months
description: Army deployments to overseas war zones will be reduced to nine months by April, easing stress on a ground combat force that has served for a year and even 15 months at a time in Iraq and Afghanistan. In a statement released Friday, John McHugh, the Army secretary, said some specialized units and individuals with particularly essential skills might still be deployed for a full year.

title: Behold the Mighty Beard, a Badge of Piety and Religious Belonging
description: Go ahead, picture a religious Jew.

title: Corrections: August 6
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Reviewing the 2011 Ford Mustang GT and Shelby GT500
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman reviews the 2011 Ford Mustang GT and Shelby GT500, two cars equipped with V-8 engines that inspire fantasies of tire-smoking mischief.

title: Shabab Concede Control of Capital to Somalia Government
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Shabab Islamist rebel group abruptly pulled out of the bullet-ridden capital of Somalia on Saturday, leaving the entire city in the hands of the government for the first time in years and raising hopes that aid groups could now deliver aid to more famine victims unfettered.

title: Copter Downed by Taliban Fire; Elite U.S. Unit Among Dead
description: This article is by  Ray Rivera,  Alissa J. Rubin and  Thom Shanker.

title: The Weekend Word: Downgrade
description: Todays Times

title: 2011 Tampa Bay Buccaneers Season Preview
description: Were entering Year Three of what has been a top-to-bottom youth movement in Tampa Bay. So far, most would agree, its going better than planned. The teams starting quarterback, running back, wide receivers, defensive ends, defensive tackles, middle linebacker and strong safety enter the season with less than three years of league experience. Yet no eyes rolled when Raheem Morris  who, at 35 on opening day, will still be the youngest head coach in the league  declared this years goal to be to win the N.F.C. South.

title: Its Time to Go Long on Tomatoes
description: When the gang at Marketplace Money, the public radio show, called yesterday wanting to know what I was doing with my money amid the market meltdown, I suggested going long on a fleeting agricultural commodity: tomatoes.

title: China Tells U.S. It Must Cure Its Addiction to Debt
description: SHANGHAI  China, the largest foreign holder of United States debt, said Saturday that Washington needed to cure its addiction to debts and live within its means, just hours after the rating agency Standard & Poors downgraded Americas long-term debt.

title: Dozens Killed as NATO Helicopter Shot Down in Afghanistan
description: KABUL  Insurgents in eastern Afghanistan have shot down a NATO Chinook helicopter during an overnight operation in eastern Afghanistan, Ray Rivera and Alissa J. Rubin report in The Times. At least 37 people on board were killed, according to a coalition military official on Saturday.

title: Syria Forces Extend Siege on Hama as Toll Rises
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces tightened their siege on the restive city of Hama on Saturday, and human rights activists said that at least 24 people had been killed on Friday during demonstrations against the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Maine Moments
description: My wife has roots in the tiny Maine lobster port of Winter Harbor, which means Im fortunate to be able to turn off the wider world for a short while each summer when we visit. On a short walk this week through a patch of beach rose* on the coast, we encountered a solitary cedar waxwing, one of my favorite birds, calling from the top of an eye-high conifer sapling.

title: Barcelona Heats Up: Notes from the Circus
description: MIAMI  With an attractive style of skillful play and trophies backing up its philosophy of homegrown talent, F.C. Barcelona is the undisputed king of club soccer. With eight members of the World Cup champions Spain in its squad, and all three finalists of the world player of the year trophy, Barcelona will defend its Spanish La Liga and European Champions League title, along with the Club World Cup.

title: Prattle and Prejudice
description: Via Mark Thoma, David Glasner marvels at an utterly incoherent op-ed by David Malpass in the WSJ. The fact that the Journal even invites Malpass to write says volumes: this is, after all, the guy who insisted that American savings were plenty high because of all those capital gains on housing.

title: The Best Summary of the S&P Downgrade
description: Atrios:

title: Stagecoach Economics
description: Cultural references! Digby points us to a post about John Fords great movie Stagecoach, citing something I had forgotten: the speech by Jamie Dimon the corrupt, embezzling banker who is the real villain of the piece:

title: Giants Take Some Time to Feel Like a Team Again
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Ask any football coach what is most important at the start of training camp, and you are likely to hear about rhythm. Quarterbacks and receivers must establish timing and rhythm. The whole offense must find its rhythm. Practices must fall into a predictable, up-tempo rhythm.

title: As N.F.L. Stopped, Leonhard Didnt
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On March 12, the N.F.L. awoke to grave uncertainty amid its first work stoppage in 22 years. That morning in Madison, Wis., Jim Leonhard, the Jets do-everything safety, rolled out of bed and continued his recovery from a broken right leg, as if nothing in his life had changed.

title: A Blast From the (Recent) Past
description: Rating Itself: S&P Defends Lehmans A

title: Back to Work Not a Moment Too Soon
description: If you thought the N.F.L. lockout was tough as a fan, imagine being a head coach.

title: Prayer Rally Draws Thousands in Houston
description: 1:20 p.m. | Updated HOUSTON  Standing on a stage surrounded by more than 30,000 Christians on Saturday morning, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas called on Jesus Christ to bless and guide the nations military and political leaders and those who cannot see the light in the midst of all the darkness, in a brief but rousing sermon-style spiritual address at the controversial prayer rally that he sponsored at the same time that he is weighing whether to run for president.

title: As Lochte Raises Profile, Image Makers Dive In
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Ryan Lochte was beat. After finally catching Michael Phelps, whom he had spent nearly a decade chasing, Lochte traveled through several time zones to compete at the United States swimming championships at Stanford University.

title: Klinsmann Will Find There Are No Points for Style
description: When Jurgen Klinsmann makes his debut as  the coach of the United States mens soccer team in a friendly game against Mexico on Wednesday in Philadelphia, he will be closely watched by American fans with high expectations based on his impressive rsum.

title: Variety: A Tantalizing Diagramless
description: The Notepad in the online version reads: This diagramless is 17 squares wide by 17 squares deep and has regular crossword symmetry. 1 Across begins in the 5th square of the first row.

title: The Arithmetic of Near-term Deficits and Debt
description: Amid all the debt hysteria, its worth taking a look at the actual arithmetic here  because what this arithmetic says is that the size of the deficit in the next year or two hardly matters for the US fiscal position  and in fact the size over the next decade is barely significant.

title: Some Concern Abroad About U.S. Downgrade
description: PARIS  Europe was taken aback Saturday at the unprecedented downgrade of Americas sterling sovereign credit rating, as officials of the Group of 7 industrial countries prepared to hold an extraordinary conference call on Sunday to discuss the debt crisis that has beset Europe and the United States.

title: N.F.L. Says Drug Testing Will Be Rigorous and Frequent
description: The N.F.L.s new drug-testing program includes provisions under which all players will be tested for human growth hormone at least once a year, and possibly many more times, the league said Saturday.

title: For the Braves Uggla, Luck Is Not a Statistic
description: Friday night offered a wonderful object lesson in the capriciousness of streaks.

title: August? October? Man, for Swisher Its Always Electric
description: BOSTON

title: Young Japanese Star Steps Into U.S. Spotlight
description: AKRON, Ohio  Ryo Ishikawa, the 19-year-old Japanese star who has carried the golf expectations of his nation since winning his first professional tour event as a 15-year-old amateur, began turning hopes into reality Saturday with a full-on charge into contention in the third round of the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational.

title: Things I Didnt Say
description: Chasing down all the false claims I get about what I supposedly believe and what Ive supposedly said would be an impossible task. But I think right now I should debunk the claim, which Im seeing a lot in comments, that I took the rating agencies seriously when they downgraded other countries, especially in Europe.

title: On Reverie
Soriano Passes First Test in Crucial Situation
description: BOSTON  The Yankees did not make a trade for a relief pitcher at the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline, but in Manager Joe Girardis mind they may have achieved the equivalent if Rafael Sorianos performance Friday night truly is an indication that he has returned to form.

title: Your Opinions Are Respected (and Required)
description: This interview with  Alan Trefler, founder and chief executive of Pegasystems, a business technology company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Amid Criticism on Downgrade of U.S., S.&P. Fires Back
