description: The day after Standard & Poors took the unprecedented step of stripping the United States government of its top credit rating, the ratings agency offered a full-throated defense of its decision, calling the bitter stand-off between President Obama and Congress over raising the debt ceiling a debacle. It warned that further downgrades may lie ahead.

title: The Talk About the Downgrade
description: Standard & Poors downgraded the United States long-term federal debt for the first time in history Friday, dropping the rating one notch to AA+ from AAA.

title: Checkbook Journalism
description: Checkbook journalism has been a persistent and problematic feature of news coverage at even the most powerful and reputable news organizations.

title: Coronation for Basketballs Clown Prince
description: A great oversight will be rectified Thursday when the Harlem Globetrotters star Reece Tatum  better known as Goose  is enshrined in the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass.

title: Atomic Bomb Survivors Join Nuclear Opposition
description: NAGASAKI, Japan  In 1945, Masahito Hirose saw the white mushroom cloud rise from the atomic bomb that incinerated this city and that left his aunt to die a slow, painful death, bleeding from her nose and gums. Still, like other survivors of the attacks here and in Hiroshima, he quietly accepted Japans postwar embrace of nuclear-generated power, believing government assurances that it was both safe and necessary for the nations economic rise.

title: Pressing All the Buttons for a Panic Attack
description: BRADLEY ALFORD, a money manager in Atlanta, just hit the panic button.

title: Revamped Atlanta Course Presents New Challenges
description: The P.G.A. Championship, the last of the years four major tournaments, returns this week to the Atlanta Athletic Club for the first time since 2001, and the gussied-up, slicked-back golf course will be longer, tougher and faster than the one on which David Toms won his lone major by holding off Phil Mickelson a decade ago.

title: At a Hacker Conference, Plenty of Friendly Federal Agents
description: LAS VEGAS  Why are federal agents hobnobbing with hackers?

title: Iraqi Civilians Die in Raid, Complicating Pullout Talks
description: BAGHDAD  For the second time in a week, a joint Iraqi-American raid aiming at insurgents resulted in the killing of civilians.

title: Tollefson Re-Signs and Knows His Place
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A Giants defensive end announced that his holdout was over and that he was looking forward to getting back on the field on Saturday.

title: Wall Streets Tax on Main Street
description: AMID all the talk of debt and default in Washington last week, tiny Central Falls, R.I., went bankrupt.

title: Chandler: Whats Up With That?
description: On Friday, word came down from the United States Soccer Federation that Dallas defender Zach Loyd had been added to Jurgen Klinsmanns roster for Wednesdays friendly against Mexico in Philadelphia.

title: With a Flip of a Knob, He Heard the Future
description: DEL CASHER has done a lot of impressive things with his guitar over the last 50 years. He has performed with Gene Autry, Lawrence Welk, and Frank Zappa and the Mothers of Invention. Hes appeared, strumming, in movies with Elvis Presley and Jerry Lewis. Hes been a featured player on dozens of film and TV soundtracks.

title: In Murder Case, Science May Get Its Day in Court
description: CONROE  Sandy and Charles Trotter already suspected the worst.

title: China Hopes to Bolster the Credentials of a Handpicked Lama
description: XIAHE, China  His name is on the lips of the ruddy-cheeked monks, the anxious hotel owners and the intrepid tourists who make their way to this isolated and starkly beautiful town in the mountains of Gansu Province: will he come to Xiahe, as unverified reports suggest, and how long will he stay?

title: One Site Fits All, Except for Advertisers
description: YAHOO is the granddaddy of all-things-to-all-people Web sites. And the concept still shows surprising life: Yahoo has users, in spades. But it has failed dismally in translating popularity into strong revenue growth.

title: Belatedly Recognizing Heroes of the Holocaust
description: HORASHIM, Israel  When 20 people gathered for a modest ceremony in the tranquil cemetery of this kibbutz in central Israel last month, the intimacy and quiet dignity of the event belied the tumultuous historical forces coursing beneath it.

title: This Time, Corporate Profits May Not Save the Day
description: U NTIL recently, investors had been holding out some hope for the economy because of the surprising health of corporate earnings.

title: Ballrooms and Boardrooms
description: MY father fought in World War II in the First Cavalry Division of the Army and achieved the level of staff sergeant. Later, he started a grocery store in Jamestown, N.Y. My mother was a cashier in the store; they married and had my sister and me. I am the only person in my family who has gone on to college.

title: Supply, Demand and Marriage
description: IN some cultures, romance isnt nearly as important as cash when it comes to choosing a marriage partner. And even when money plays no explicit role in selecting a mate, courtship customs are governed by the venerable economic model of supply and demand.

title: Daring to Stumble on the Road to Discovery
description: AT the recent Aspen Ideas Festival, the New York Times columnist Thomas L. Friedman said that when he graduated from college, he was able to go find a job, but that our children were going to have to invent a job.

title: Another Groping Attack, This Time in Central Park
description: The man suspected by police of having groped at least 10 women on the Upper East Side since May has been accused in another attack.

title: Seeking a Sense of Web Discovery
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Many Rules for Home Loans, or Too Few?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Snooki Fatigue For MTV Audience
description: The first episode of Jersey Shore to be set far from any shore  in Florence, Italy  attracted 8.8 million viewers on Thursday night, making it the highest-rated season premiere in MTVs history. The ratings showed that MTV viewers have not yet tired of Nicole Polizzi, a k a Snooki; Mike Sorrentino, a k a the Situation; or the other members of the cast. Their arrival in Florence was the beginning of the fourth season of the series. The third season began in early January with 8.45 million viewers, peaked later in the month with 8.9 million, and leveled off for the rest of the season, averaging 7.9 million for the 13 episodes. The test for Jersey Shore this season will be to entice the 8.8 million to keep watching.

title: Strasburg on the Mend
description: While the Mets might go all season without using their ace, Johan Santana, the Washington Nationals could get theirs back before the end of September. Santana was shut down last week with fatigue in his surgically repaired left shoulder, but Stephen Strasburg is on course in his recovery from reconstructive elbow surgery.

title: Protest Set Over Arrest of a Leader in Ukraine
description: ODESSA, Ukraine  Supporters of the Ukrainian opposition leader Yulia V. Tymoshenko say they are planning a street protest on Monday to demand her release from jail, where a judge ordered her detained for contempt of court.

title: Perry Leads Prayer Rally for Nation in Crisis
description: HOUSTON  Standing on a stage surrounded by thousands of fellow Christians on Saturday morning, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas called on Jesus to bless and guide the nations military and political leaders and those who cannot see the light in the midst of all the darkness.

title: In Libyas Capital, Straight Talk From Christians
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  For this weeks sermon at the Libyan capitals main Protestant church, the Rev. Hamdy Daoud chose to talk about the trial of Hosni Mubarak.

title: Rating Cut of U.S. Debt Echoes the Nervousness of Global Markets
description: WASHINGTON  The Standard & Poors decision to downgrade the credit rating of the United States for the first time echoed the nervousness of global markets in recent weeks, driven down by the relentless beat of grim economic news and a loss of confidence in the ability of political leaders to navigate challenges.

title: Twirler With a Curl
description: The Phillies Cliff Lee twirled his fifth shutout of the season on Thursday when he blanked the Giants, 3-0. Lee has the most shutouts in a season since 2005, when Dontrelle Willis had five for Florida. No pitcher has recorded more shutouts in a season since Randy Johnson had six in 1998, two with Seattle and four with Houston.

title: Humbling but Valuable
description: With his Pittsburgh Pirates in first place on July 19, Manager Clint Hurdle sounded cautious when asked about his players.

title: M.H. Rindskopf, Submarine Commander, Dies at 93
description: Rear Adm. Maurice H. Rindskopf, the youngest commander of an American fleet submarine during World War II who directed the sinking of 15 Japanese vessels, one of the highest totals in the war, died on July 27 at his home in Annapolis, Md. He was 93.

title: Straight Outta Havana
description: Sujatha Fernandes is an assistant professor of sociology at Queens College and the Graduate Center, City University of New York, and the author of the forthcoming Close to the Edge: In Search of the Global Hip Hop Generation.

title: Downgrade Blues
description: WASHINGTON

title: 30 Seconds With Marshall Faulk
description: Marshall Faulk, who was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday, said he was happy to see the lockout end, if only so he could return to his job as an analyst on the NFL Network and avoid losing another Madden NFL video game to his son.

title: Win Together or Lose Together
description: IN the wake of the hugely disappointing budget deal and the S.& P.s debt downgrade, maybe we need to hang a new sign in the immigration arrival halls at all U.S. ports and airports. It could simply read: Welcome. You are entering the United States of America. Past performance is not necessarily indicative of future returns.

title: The Truth About Taxes
description: A week later and we are still amazed at how the Republicans in Congress pulled it off. They held the economy hostage, won some cheap political points, and all of us will spend the next decade paying the ransom as government programs  $900 billion over 10 years in the first round  are slashed and the recovery is put at risk.

title: What Happened to Obama?
description: Drew Westen is a professor of psychology at Emory University and the author of The Political Brain: The Role of Emotion in Deciding the Fate of the Nation.

title: William Sleator, Fantasy Writer for Young Adults, Dies at 66
description: William Sleator, a writer for young people whose books pitted their heroes against aliens, ghouls and slimy things, not to mention the most malevolent rivals of all  siblings  died on Wednesday in Bua Chet, Thailand. He was 66.

title: Shortchanging Cancer Patients
description: Ezekiel J. Emanuel is an oncologist and former White House adviser who will be a professor of medical ethics and health policy at the University of Pennsylvania beginning in September. He will be contributing regularly to Op-Ed.

title: Race to the Right
description: It is far too simplistic to blame the loose coalition of Republicans known as the Tea Party for the debt-limit debacle. It was not the Tea Party fringe of the Republican Party that dragged the economy to the brink  it was its center. The party has moved so far to the right that there is little difference between fringe and mainstream.

title: Paying for News? Its Nothing New
description: Jeremy W. Peters is a media reporter for The New York Times.

title: Longtime Reds Star Who Nearly Was a Met
description: In his job as an analyst for ESPN, Barry Larkin travels the baseball map, landing in a different spot every Sunday night. Two weeks ago he found himself in Cincinnati, his hometown, where he starred at shortstop for the Reds. He said he was touched by the fans who cheered him on the set.

title: The Arms Race Intrudes on Paradise
description: Gloria Steinem is an author, an activist and a co-founder of the Womens Media Center.

title: The Thrill of Boredom
description: Peter Toohey is a professor of Greek and Roman studies at the University of Calgary, and the author of Boredom: A Lively History.

title: Killing Jeff Davis
description: Weehawken, N.J., Aug. 6, 1861

title: A Moral Flip-Flop? Defining a War
description: Paul Starobin is the author of After America: Narratives for the Next Global Age.

title: After 9/11, an Era of Tinker, Tailor, Jihadist, Spy
description: Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker are reporters for The New York Times and authors of the forthcoming Counterstrike: The Untold Story of Americas Secret Campaign Against Al Qaeda, from which this article is adapted.

title: Pssst. Wanna Know About the New Apple Store?
description: New Yorkers are protective of Grand Central Terminal, that Beaux-Arts masterpiece built in 1913 and restored in 1998. So, when word seeped out that Apple planned a store in the balconies of the great hall, there was bound to be a lot of curiosity. We certainly were curious. What did Apple have in mind? A large glass apple rivaling the great clock?

title: Have You Picnicked at the Tank Farm?
description: Back when colonial New Yorkers first sweltered in their budding city, one peppercorn per year was the bargain fee negotiated for renting Gothams first official park, Bowling Green, in 1733. There were grandiose municipal plans to add grass, trees and a wooden fence for the Recreation and Delight of the Inhabitants of this City.

title: Sunday Dialogue: How to Fix Government
description: A letter on Thursday lamented the state of politics today and urged changes. Readers critique those ideas and offer their own.

title: Take a Knee or Take a Risk
description: It takes a certain amount of chutzpah to be an N.F.L. kick returner, to peer toward the sky, hoping to catch a wobbling ball, while thousands of pounds of opponents thunder toward you. It is going to take more  maybe much more  this season.

title: Criticism of Shale Gas Articles, and of the Critic
description: Two columns on articles by Ian Urbina about the development of shale gas drew strong responses. Heres what some readers said in response to my July 17 piece discussing Mr. Urbinas June 26 article about gas producers allegedly exaggerated claims.

title: Wait Wait... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: When Data Disappears
description: Kari Kraus is an assistant professor in the College of Information Studies and the English department at the University of Maryland.

title: A Mystery We Really Dont Want to Solve
description: Geoffrey Gray is a contributing editor at New York magazine and the author of Skyjack: The Hunt for D. B. Cooper.

title: At Newport, Assessing the Future of a Jazz Festival
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  The Newport Jazz Festival has been running since 1954, with a few gaps, a few different sponsors and a few major changes of consciousness about what a good jazz festival is.

title: Gov. Rick Perry Holds Prayer Rally
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas held a day of prayer and fasting called "The Response."

title: A AAA Q. and A.
description: 7:12 p.m. | Updated to elaborate on bank bailout.

title: Gary Locke
description: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

title: Mason Chooses Jets Over Titans and Ravens
description: 10:30 p.m. | Updated The Jets completed the dramatic refashioning of their receiving corps Saturday, signing Derrick Mason to be their third receiver with Santonio Holmes and Plaxico Burress.

description: Pret A Manger, the veddy British chain, has used tight-knit teams and customer service to find success in the United States.

title: Would You Like a Smile With That?
description: SOMETHING weird is happening inside a Pret a Manger sandwich shop on Broadway in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Republicans Jockey as a Big Week Begins in Iowa
description: TIFFIN, Iowa  At the outset of a crucial week in the presidential campaign, the Republican candidates are increasingly turning on one another as they try to overcome their own weaknesses and capitalize on the vulnerabilities of President Obama.

title: Small Shops Arent Fans of Jay-Zs Distribution Deal
description: Ever since Ron Hill opened Basement Mix Records with his brother in 1997 on a side street in East New York, Brooklyn, he has made it a mission to promote up-and-coming local artists  including, back in the day, the first album by a chart-climbing rapper from a few neighborhoods away by the name of Jay-Z.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 6
description: Golf fans showed their stripes in Ohio as a new soccer season began in Germany and sailors splashed after the Americas Cup in Portugal.

title: Obama Team Turns Its Focus to Tough Re-election Fight
description: WASHINGTON  After a month tied down in Washington by the bruising budget fight, President Obama breaks out to four battleground states this week and next, including a campaign-style bus tour in the Upper Midwest, stumping with a new urgency as global economic fears darken his re-election prospects.

title: True Believers, All of Us
description: ALMOST from the moment it was announced, Saturdays enormous prayer rally in Houston drew widespread attention and remarks  for many reasons.

title: In State Capitals, Officials Take Recovery Into Their Own Hands
description: DENVER  Here is one measure of the nations lingering economic trouble and the political anxiety festering in state capitals over jobs and angry voters: 500.

title: Videos of Flash Flooding in North Carolina
description: Flash floods ripped through Charlotte, N.C., on Friday, damaging roofs, tearing down sheds and leaving two people dead. Then the water receded almost as quickly as it rose.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 7
description: The last week has seen an 11th-hour deal to avert a government default, a stock market plunge, a cautiously positive jobs report and the nations first credit rating downgrade in history. Naturally, the Sunday talk shows will be focused on the economy.

title: Sunday: Good to Go
description: Wordplay congratulates Jeffrey Harris, the winner of Lollapuzzoola 4, as well as all of those who participated!

title: Markets Expected Credit Ruling, but Risks Remain, Analysts Say
description: The hit to the United States prized credit rating may have arrived with a jolt Friday, but many analysts say its not so clear that it will deliver any immediate shock to financial markets or to consumers. That is because it confirmed what the markets, economists and most people already know: the United States has a debt problem and Washington is deeply divided over how to solve it.

title: For Obama, a Record on Diversity but Delays on Judicial Confirmations
description: President Obama made history when he nominated Sonia Sotomayor, the first Hispanic justice on the Supreme Court. He did it again with his second nominee, Elena Kagan, raising the number of women on the nations highest court to three.

title: A Thriving Growth Area in a Weak Economy: Hair
description: CAPITOL HEIGHTS, Md.  In low-slung suburban strip malls, nestled among fast-food restaurants and auto supply stores, hair salons are sprouting like mushrooms.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,678 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Candidates Give Obama an F for AA+ Rating
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  The Republican presidential candidates on Saturday seized on the first-ever downgrade of the nations credit rating as a new line of criticism against President Obama, suggesting that ultimate responsibility rested in the Oval Office even though the rating agency, Standard & Poors, cited the overall political gridlock in Washington as a major cause for its decision.

title: Picking Locks and Hacking Servers at Defcon
description: LAS VEGAS  They sat at tables along the perimeter of a ballroom in the Rio Hotel. Lights were low. Laptops burned like campfires. Men and women hunched over the machines, their backs curved like question marks. Their fingers clicked away furiously.

title: A Month of Record Rain, a Number of Close Calls
description: A summer of endless rain, violent storms and plain, mean heat has left the Midwest doing what it is loath to do, especially in this season: whining about the weather. Then there is Roger Bossard, a man known as the Sodfather, whose livelihood depends on every centimeter of precipitation, every ray of sunshine.

title: Living With Voices
description: Joe Holt, a computer consultant and entrepreneur who has a diagnosis of schizophrenia, describes how he's learned to manage the voices in his head.

title: Learning to Cope With a Minds Taunting Voices
description: LEES SUMMIT, Mo.  The job was gone, the gun was loaded, and a voice was saying, Youre a waste, give up now, do it now.

title: Advice for Perry in National Race: Watch Your Right
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: One Mans Story of Schizophrenia
description: In the latest installment of the Lives Restored series, about people coping with mental illness, Benedict Carey reports the story of Joe Holt, 50, a computer consultant and entrepreneur who has schizophrenia.

title: Airstrike Reportedly Kills Civilians in Southern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A woman and seven young children were killed in southern Afghanistan when a coalition patrol called in an airstrike against insurgents firing on them from a mud compound, Afghan officials said Saturday. NATO said it was investigating the attack.

title: Crazy Girl Takes Eli Young Band to a New Level
description: As the Aug. 16 release of their fourth studio album approaches, life on the road for Texas Eli Young Band is predictably routine: long bus rides and early wake-up calls are quickly followed by phone interviews, sound checks, more interviews, dinners with country radio programmers, and meet-and-greets with fans.

title: Red Sox Batter Yankees C. C. Sabathia Again
description: BOSTON  C. C. Sabathia is the Yankees undisputed ace, a dominant force on the mound, and one of three pitchers considered the leading candidates for the American League Cy Young Award.

title: On the Waterfront, a Pedicab Skirmish Erupts
description: On Tuesday afternoon, bicycle taxis lined up near the Ferry Building, waiting to take tourists for an open-air ride along the San Francisco waterfront.

title: American Steel Studios
description: West Oaklands post-industrial hinterland is home to many active and abandoned warehouses. A thriving arts community has taken root at one such space, American Steel Studios, a giant open warehouse and a smaller adjoining building used by creative types ranging from trapeze artists to soap makers.

title: More Violence Reported in London Neighborhoods
description: 3:55 p.m. | Updated More violence rocked parts of of London Sunday night, a day after demonstrators looted shops and set fire to cars and buildings.

title: A Neighborhood Is Shaken by a Violent Death
description: Last Tuesday, 20-year-old Michael Dawson sat at a computer and watched a young man die. After being shot twice  once by the police  the man, seen on a video, writhed face down in a pool of blood as officers tried to hold back a crowd of outraged bystanders.

title: Its Not Easy Being the Conservative One
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Torre Calls for More Respect as Player Feuds Cross Line
description: BOSTON

title: Protests Grow in Israel, With 250,000 Marching
description: JERUSALEM  At least 250,000 Israelis took to the streets on Saturday night to demonstrate against the high cost of living and lack of affordable housing, the largest in three weeks of protests aimed at forcing social and economic issues onto the governments agenda.

title: TIF Aided Public and Private Projects Almost Evenly, Analysis Shows
description: For years, former Mayor Richard M. Daley heard criticism that City Halls use of a particular economic development tool amounted to little more than a slush fund for him to subsidize corporate Chicago at the publics expense.

title: 3 of Mayors Men Join Forces. Their Goal: Harness Technology to Help the City.
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: A Home Where Strike Up the Band Is No Idle Order
description: Saxophonists are collectors; its an occupational hazard. They amass boxes of reeds to find one that works perfectly; their closets bulge with the secondary saxes, clarinets and flutes they are expected to play in bands and orchestras.

title: A 6-Year-Old Finally Flashes His Speed at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The owner Bill Clifton and the trainer James Bond had been here before, in the paddock of one of the most beautiful racetracks in the world, readying a fast horse to run in one of the most important stakes in American racing: the $750,000 Grade I Whitney Invitational Handicap. They had done pretty well too  Wills Way won in 1997 and Behrens finished second and third in 1999 and 2000.

title: Battle for Libya | August 6, 2011
description: Rebel forces participate in live-fire exercises as the fighting in Libya continues.

title: Citing Stalemate, Verizon Workers Strike
description: Two unions representing 45,000 workers at Verizon Communications announced early Sunday that they were calling an immediate strike because of a lack of progress in contract negotiations.

title: Republican Candidates Converge on Iowa
description: Candidates seek to break from the pack in a debate and a straw poll.

title: Anger Over Credit Rating Resurfaces in Washington
description: The frustration in the air was palpable. Officials from the credit ratings agency Standard & Poors were meeting with Congressional leaders on a stifling late day in late July to discuss the thorniest issue in Washington: the effort to cut the nations deficit and raise the borrowing limit to avert a default.

title: Baseball Warns Players About Deer Antler Spray
description: BOSTON  Curtis Granderson tapped on his cellphone in the Yankees clubhouse Saturday after a 10-4 loss to the Boston Red Sox. He had received two text messages from old friends, asking if he knew that deer-antler spray was supposedly a form of human growth hormone.

title: Amukamara, Giants Top Pick, Breaks Foot
description: Just two days after signing a four-year contract with the Giants, cornerback Prince Amukamara, the teams first round pick in the N.F.L. draft, broke his left foot in practice Saturday night.

title: Corrections: August 7
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: U.S. Widens Role in Battle Against Mexican Drug Cartels
description: WASHINGTON  The United States is expanding its role in Mexicos bloody fight against drug trafficking organizations, sending new C.I.A. operatives and retired military personnel to the country and considering plans to deploy private security contractors in hopes of turning around a multibillion-dollar effort that so far has shown few results.

title: For a Night, Mets Feel Comfortable in Their Own Home
description: The Mets have spent many days this summer pondering a frustrating fact of their recent existence: how can their home field be such a maddeningly inhospitable place?

title: It Was Really No Contest at Two European Events
description: One lesson from the recent Biel Chess Festival in Switzerland and the Sparkassen Chess-Meeting in Germany is that the gap in skills between the worlds best players and those in the second tier is sometimes too big to overcome.

title: Lottery Numbers
Vanishing Spray and the Future of Technology
description: Copa Amrica, which was played in Argentina last month, marked the debut of the vanishing spray in an international tournament for national teams. This technological innovation consists of a can with white spray that allows referees to mark the place where the ball ,as well as the defensive wall,should be located on free kicks. Said marks vanish rapidly, leaving no trace on the field. In addition, the application of the vanishing spray is as easy as is its transportation.

title: The Pageant Winner, Louisville, Ky.
description: Jewel Daily:  Im from Montevallo, Ala., and I dont mind telling you Im 78. From a very young age I knew education was important, so in 1956 I received a Bachelor of Science degree from Alabama A&M College, which was one of the colleges that we were allowed to attend. The South was still segregated when I was growing up, but I didnt really think too much about that. I have two daughters  one is a school principal, and the other is a reading specialist. My husband died in 2003.

title: Riots in North London
description: Clusters of young men hurled bricks and aimed fireworks at riot police officers before a backdrop of burning cars and buildings.

title: Syrian Military Mounts Assault on Another City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian military defied growing condemnation and initiated another assault on the countrys most restive locales on Sunday, deploying dozens of tanks and armored vehicles into parts of a city in eastern Syria that it had long feared provoking, activists and residents said. Dozens were killed, they said, and thousands had fled the city.

title: 2011 New Orleans Saints Season Preview
description: Perhaps no higher compliment was paid to this organization than the collective silence that ensued after the Saints traded a 2012 first-round pick and a 2011 second-rounder to move up and draft Alabama running back Mark Ingram 28th over all. This was a move that seemed to make little sense. The Saints already had two good runners in Pierre Thomas and Chris Ivory. The former had just signed a four-year, $12 million contract and the latter was an undrafted second-year pro with a sub-$500,000 salary each of the next two years.

title: In Paris, Classical Music in a Pastoral Setting
description: Parc Floral de Paris, a pastoral spot in the 12th Arrondissement, will host world-class classical musicians during this years Classique au Vert festival, held weekends from Aug. 6 to Sept. 25.

title: I Heard It Through The Baseline
description: Oh, my. Treasury has a fact sheet explaining that $2 trillion error by S&P; it may sound technical, but to anyone who follows budget issues, its a doozy.

title: Hugh Carey, Who Led Fiscal Rescue of New York City, Is Dead at 92
description: Hugh L. Carey, the governor who helped rescue New York from the brink of financial collapse in the 1970s and tamed a culture of ever-growing spending, died Sunday at his summer home on Shelter Island, N.Y. He was 92.

title: Global Finance Leaders Pledge Bold Action to Calm Markets
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank signaled on Sunday that it would intervene more aggressively in bond markets to protect Spain and Italy, and leading finance ministers conferred about the mounting threats to the worlds economies, as policy makers sought to calm markets unnerved by deteriorating public finances and slow economic growth.

title: Music to Know Festival Is Canceled
description: In the end, it was not the opposition of East Hampton, N.Y., locals worried about a Woodstock in their quiet seaside enclave but lackluster ticket sales that doomed the Music to Know Festival on Long Island next weekend.

title: Downgrade Debate Moves to Talk Shows
description: WASHINGTON  Representatives of the Republican and Democratic parties went on television on Sunday morning to blame the other side for Standard & Poors unprecedented decision to downgrade the credit rating of the United States  a decision that was based largely on a lack of faith in the ability of the political system to forge agreements to reduce the debt.

title: Fiscal Woe Haunting Baltimore Poe House
description: BALTIMORE  Even now, 162 years after his death here, Edgar Allan Poe still seems to be suffering from the kind of bad luck that haunted his life.

title: Berkshire Unit Bids $3.25 Billion for Transatlantic
description: 4:44 p.m. | Updated with statements from Validus and Allied

title: Stuck in the Muddle
description: You wont be surprised to hear that I am very much in sympathy with Drew Westens lament about Obamas unwillingness or inability to change the narrative. I went back to look at my own reactions to the inaugural speech; Im sorry to say that my misgivings at the time have proved all too justified.

title: High Hopes on a Dreary Day at the Newport Jazz Festival
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  The Newport Jazz Festival released its attendance figures for Saturday: 7,500. (The capacity is 10,000, and there will be fewer people on Sunday because it is raining.) I think I also neglected to mention that its main sponsors this year are the Boston-based Natixis Global Asset Management and Alex and Ani, the Rhode Island-based jewelry-maker whose mission statement tells us that Alex and Anis artistry lies in drawing out the beauty that resides within.

title: Last Season for Desperate Housewives on ABC
description: Paul Lee, the president of entertainment for ABC, confirmed at a news conference on Sunday that this would be the last season of that networks longtime comedy-drama hit Desperate Housewives. Mr. Lee called it an iconic show that put the network on the map. He added that the network, in conjunction with the shows creator, Marc Cherry, had decided to make the call before the season started to make sure the show would have a victory lap.Mr. Lee cited the success that ABC had had in making an early announcement that it would end its other hit drama that started around the same time, Lost.

title: Red Bulls Debacle
description: The Red Bulls look like a team waiting around for something, anything, to happen.

title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes Leads at the Box Office
description: Computer-generated primates, yes. Extreme scatological humor? No. That sums up Hollywoods weekend, as Rise of the Planet of the Apes took in about $54 million at North American theaters and The Change-Up, an ultra-crude comedy (it opens with a baby defecating in Jason Batemans mouth), landed with a $13.5 million thud.

title: Lollapalooza Brand Is Heading to Brazil
description: Having successfully extended the Lollapalooza franchise to Chile this year, the founder of the influential alternative rock festival in Chicago has announced that he will start a second sister festival in Brazil next spring. The event, Lollapalooza Brazil, will be held April 7-8 at the Jockey Club de So Paulo, a large horse-racing track in one of Latin Americas largest cities, festival officials said.

title: The Curtain Comes Down on Rent
description: The landmark musical, written by Jonathan Larson, ended its Broadway run after 12 years.

title: Downsizing Rent for a New Run
description: Gone is the two-tone scarf, the crewneck sweater, the eyeglasses: the signature costume for Mark Cohen, a lead character in the musical Rent. During the shows 12 years on Broadway that characters look was so familiar it inspired many Halloween costumes in New York. Now, in the new Off Broadway revival of Rent, Marks stylings are a cap atop his curly mop of hair (its still cold in the East Village) and a plaid shirt (referencing colors in his first overcoat).

title: Giants Amukamara Faces Aftermath of Injury
description: Prince Amukamara had never broken a bone in his body until Saturday night. And he is not exactly sure how it happened.

title: Yemeni President, Hurt in Bombing, Leaves Saudi Hospital
description: Yemens embattled and wounded president has been discharged from the hospital where he was being treated in Saudi Arabia and has moved into a government residence there, Yemens official SABA news agency reported Sunday.

title: Friends in Seals Unit Are Citys Double Loss
description: WASHINGTON  They came from the same town, Shreveport, La. They were high school friends. Both men, Robert James Reeves and Jonas Kelsall, had overcome extreme tests and rigorous training to serve on the same elite Seal team. Both were assigned the same mission, and put in the same helicopter, only to perish together.

title: Reyes Leaves Game With Stiff Hamstring
description: 5:52 p.m. | Updated The air was momentarily sucked from Citi Field Sunday afternoon when Willie Harris emerged from the Mets dugout in the bottom of the second inning to pinch-hit for Jose Reyes. An inning later, the Mets announced that Reyes was feeling stiffness in his left hamstring  yes, the same hamstring that landed him on the disabled list in July. Indeed, in the first inning, he had appeared to pull up gingerly while running out a soft ground ball to Braves third baseman Martin Prado. He played the field the next half-inning and appeared fine on the one ball hit to him, but did not return to bat in the second. Details will be updated here.

title: Giants Get More Help at Tight End
description: The loss of Kevin Boss to the Raiders and the sudden retirement of his replacement Ben Patrick left the Giants with a huge void at tight end.

title: Ellis Is Leaving the Jets to Play for the Patriots
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Shaun Ellis has gone to the other side.

title: How S.&P.s Downgrade Might Affect Standoff Over McGraw-Hill
description: Though telegraphed for weeks, Standard and Poors decision Friday to downgrade the United Statess credit rating surprised more than a few in the market  including the agencys parent company, McGraw-Hill.

title: Playlist: Lykke Li
description: Hours before headlining her first show in Central Park, Swedish singer-songwriter Lykke Li meets up with Melena Ryzik in the tiny music shop where she started her career.

title: S&P Precedents
description: When assessing the downgrade, the question of track record comes up. As I understand it, countries that defaulted in the past were almost always downgraded well before the default happened; but in all such cases, the markets were already signalling big trouble before the rating agencies moved.

title: A Museum Nevermore?
description: The Edgar Allan Poe home and museum in Baltimore may close due to lack of funds.

title: One Mans Gluddle-Luddle Is Anothers Squoosh Squoosh
description: Here is a highly abbreviated chapter from Nicholson Bakers full-throttle pornographic new novel, House of Holes:

title: Excerpt: 'Seasons of Love'
description: A scene from the new Off Broadway revival of Rent." (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Bleak Prospects
description: While we obsess over downgrades by people who should have no standing, the economic outlook deteriorates. The economics team at Goldman Sachs, whom Ive always found very good, now say (no link):

title: Mets Lose Reyes, Murphy and Game
description: The Mets clubhouse felt more like a funeral home than a locker room Sunday, and perhaps rightly so.

title: Streetcar Casting News
description: Following in the footsteps of Vivien Leigh, Cate Blanchett and Marge Simpson, Nicole Ari Parker (Soul Food) has landed the role of Blanche DuBois in the coming Broadway production of Tennessee Williamss classic drama A Streetcar Named Desire, the producers announced Sunday. It will be Ms. Parkers Broadway debut; she previously performed in Off Broadway productions of Chicago, House of Lear and Romeo and Juliet. A graduate of the Tisch School for the Performing Arts, Ms. Parker described the news as a childhood dream come true. She added: Blanche is the role of a lifetime. When I heard, I spun around in my kitchen like Diana Ross in The Wiz. The production, which will feature a cast representative of the plays New Orleans setting, is to open in the spring under the direction of Emily Mann (Anna in the Tropics, Having Our Say) and starring Blair Underwood (The Event). Mr. Underwood will also be making his Broadway debut, as Stanley Kowalski.

title: Footnote
description: The Television Critics Association named Friday Night Lights its program of the year on Saturday night. Jon Hamm was named best actor in a drama for his role in Mad Men, which received the top drama award for a third year.

title: London Sees Twin Perils Converging to Fuel Riot
description: LONDON  As London surveyed the damage on Sunday after a small anti-police demonstration spiraled into looting and violence that left 26 police officers injured and led to more than 160 arrests, many sought to cast the blame beyond the rioters themselves.

title: A Self-Fulfilling Euro Crisis? (Wonkish)
description: There will probably be big action in the euro zone tomorrow; so, some quick analytical notes.

title: Education Needs a Digital-Age Upgrade
description: If you have a child entering grade school this fall, file away just one number with all those back-to-school forms: 65 percent.

title: Chekhovs Slugfest, With Pratfalls
description: WASHINGTON  What blissfully irritating people they are. Cranks, I believe, is the word that keeps coming up to describe them. Under most circumstances Id run a country mile to avoid being trapped in a room with the desperate characters now inhabiting the Sydney Theater Companys production of Chekhovs Uncle Vanya at the Kennedy Center here. Yet I consider the three hours I spent on Saturday night watching them complain about how bored they are among the happiest of my theatergoing life.

title: A Family Reunited After a Rare Return From Deportation
description: A Polish woman will step off an airplane in Chicago on Monday afternoon with a legal visa in her hand, coming back to live in the United States four years after her deportation sundered her family, in a rare case of the return of an immigrant who was expelled.

title: At Newport, Rain Rules the Day
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  Since the beginning of the Newport Jazz Festival on Sunday it has been raining, sometimes hard and loud and overwhelming, sometimes a thick harborside mist. The main stage, where there is no tent for the audience, has it the hardest. Maybe 150 hardy people are out there right now watching James Farm, the co-operative quartet with the saxophonist Joshua Redman, the pianist Aaron Parks, the bassist Matt Penman and the drummer Eric Harland. Theyre playing way back from the lip of the stage to avoid getting wet, huddling closer than they would at a small club. Theyre sounding goodstrolling, right now, through a minor ballad.Hiromi is back for round two on a smaller stage with her trio, wowing them with amiable virtuosity. Earlier, John Hollenbecks 19-piece big band including bass saxophone, vibraphone and two singers played a great set, including songs by Ornette Coleman, Jimmy Webb and Imogen Heap and a version of the traditional Im a Man of Constant Sorrow, with a solo by the tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby that came in chapters, getting destabilized and righting itself, using a few notes of the melody or, or of Hollenbecks strong arrangement, to start a new section. It takes at least a half-hour to start to understand this bands range, from sci-fi to pastoral, loopy to dead serious. Its come a long way over the last 10 years.

title: Celebrating a Twisted, Elegant Versifier
description: Dan Zanes started Shelebration!, a concert tribute to Shel Silverstein on Saturday night at SummerStage, with Youre Always Welcome at Our House. Its a smiley, bouncy song that could be a childrens ditty except that its about serial murder, with a new victim in each verse. It was a canny choice that pulled together some of the many strands of Silversteins career.

title: An Exuberant Conductor and a Starry Violinist
description: It seems entirely likely that many in the large, enthusiastic audience that turned out for a performance by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night were drawn there by the starry soloist, Joshua Bell. A consistently excellent and broadly appealing violinist, Mr. Bell is one of the few reliable marquee names in classical music today.

title: Like Ross, Rachel and Company, but With Faster Hook-Ups
description: Some television shows get buried. Friends With Benefits was shot in the back of the head, driven to the Meadowlands and dumped in a ditch.

title: All Nooks, Crannies, Bedrooms and Trees Are Backdrops for Art
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y.  Forgive the title, a shameless ploy for attention. The 2011 Bridgehampton Biennial is not actually a biennial; its just the second installment of an annual summer group show done under the auspices of a commercial gallery in a private home. But its a highly entertaining one, with a refreshingly casual attitude.

title: In a Match of Quick Decisions, Deciding to Falsecard Early
description: If you find the regular pace of bridge play, 15 minutes for two deals, too slow, turn to fast pairs. Then you receive only 11 minutes and are speedily fined for finishing a round late.

title: Monday: Terse Four-Star Review
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Its a sailors life in Ian Livengoods puzzle. From the outset we are asked to help him figure out where to find the endings of the theme entries, which are slangy terms for those who sail the HIGH SEAS.

title: Geithner Will Stay for Now, the Treasury Department Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, has told President Obama that he will remain in his position for the time being, the department announced on Sunday, ending speculation that he might step down soon.

title: Target Evokes a Touch of La Dolce Vita
description: CINEPHILES familiar with the Italian films of the 1960s will recall images of fashionably dressed women and men whirling by sidewalk cafes in tiny Fiats, racing along narrow cobblestone streets. Those vignettes are the inspiration for a new ad campaign highlighting the latest high fashion brand to market its line for a limited run at Target.

title: Second Recession in U.S. Could Be Worse Than First
description: If the economy falls back into recession, as many economists are now warning, the bloodletting could be a lot more painful than the last time around.

title: Shop for Spies and Would-Be Spies
description: From its 1,200-square-foot space overlooking 34th Street in Manhattan, Spy Shops offers customized surveillance installations with five-figure price tags for foreign princes, chart-topping rappers, business tycoons and paranoid husbands.

title: I.R.S. Handling of Donations Draws Ire of Both Parties
description: When it comes to things political, the Internal Revenue Service just cannot seem to win.

title: When Knowledge Isnt Written, Does It Still Count?
description: HAIFA, Israel

title: U.S. Agents, an Aerial Snoop and Teams of Hackers
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Hugh L. Carey, 1919-2011
description: As the 51st governor of New York from 1975 through 1982, Mr. Carey led a small group of public servants who vanquished a fiscal crisis that threatened New York City and the state.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers on Lauren Ambrose, and Booing at the Theater
description: ArtsBeat was abuzz last week with two theater-related posts that sharply divided many readers. First, the decision to cast Lauren Ambrose (Six Feet Under) as Fanny Brice in the coming revival of Funny Girl had many people wondering if she has what it takes to step into the shoes of a character made famous by Barbra Streisand. Second, readers debated the etiquette and appropriateness of booing at the theater  the way they do at the opera  in response to a guest Talkback post. Following is a roundup of readers comments on these topics from ArtsBeat, Twitter and Facebook.

title: Golf in the (Backyard) Kingdom
description: On Par columnist Bill Pennington shows how to make the most out of a backyard practice session.

title: Anything Goes on the Streets of New York
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Burress Suits Up, Mason Shows Up at Jets Camp
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Plaxico Burress was in pads and didnt fully participate in practice, and Derrick Mason stood on the sidelines in a grey long-sleeve shirt and shorts, but just having both here Sunday was a welcoming sign for the Jets.

title: Titans Grapple With Governance
description: Sumner Redstone should enjoy watching Rupert Murdoch squirm. Theres no love lost between Mr. Redstone, the 88-year-old chairman of Viacom and CBS, and Mr. Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation. Last year, Mr. Redstone even presciently ridiculed his competitors fondness for newspapers. But as Mr. Murdoch grapples with the misdeeds of one of his British tabloids, Mr. Redstone can delight only so much. He has his own costly governance problems, too.

title: News Corp.s Soft Power in the U.S.
description: Over the last month, many Americans watched from a distance in horror or amusement as it became evident that the News Corporation regarded Britains legal and political institutions as its own private club.

title: Shopper Receipts Join Paperless Age
description: At an Old Navy store in Manhattan the other day, Fabienne Michel made a routine purchase of khaki shorts. But she left the store without something equally routine: her receipt.

title: Long Island's Lost Lobsters
description: For Long Island lobstermen, the good old days ended in 1999 when a great die-off in Long Island Sound rocked the local industry and stumped researchers.

title: New Deals, Young Star, and Hope in Carolina
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  Cam Newton made his first pass as quarterback of the Carolina Panthers recently when he gave up trying to buy jersey No. 2 from Jimmy Clausen and settled on No. 1.

title: Giants Hope to Cover Sudden Shortcomings
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Ben Patrick era at tight end proved brief and uneventful for the Giants: five days, a handful of practices, one sudden retirement.

title: Levis Drive for Water.org via Facebook
description: Levis is adding a hue to its marketing efforts: Facebook blue. The purveyor of all things denim has teamed up with the social media giant on the next phase of its Go Forth campaign.

title: Waiting Hours to See the McQueen Exhibit, in a Line Not Unlike a Runway
description: Even after midnight on a rainy Saturday, they waited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art: a line of about 1,500 people snaking through the Medieval Hall, past the Japanese ceramics and Mesopotamian artifacts displayed along the Great Hall balcony, past centuries of sculptures, paintings and other objects before they finally arrived, giddy from an hours-long wait.

title: The Marketing of Moore Is a Team Challenge
description: To no ones surprise, Maya Moore is having a standout rookie season in the W.N.B.A.

title: On Idyllic Cape Cod, Growing Drug Problem Fuels a Rise in Property Crimes
description: DENNIS, Mass.  In late April, Mildred Duda, 77, woke up in the middle of the night to find three masked men in her bedroom, rifling through her possessions. The police believe that the men had information about when Ms. Duda refilled her prescription for what they wanted: narcotic painkillers.

title: Where Monday Is Caddie Day
description: For decades, country clubs across America have closed on Mondays, largely for maintenance work. At Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y., that means the caddies are allowed to play the holes they walk all week.

title: Ad Money Reliably Goes to Television
description: The economy is faltering and consumers are scared, but you wouldnt know it by watching television, where advertisers are still pouring in money.

title: The Last of the Lobstermen, Chasing a Vanishing Treasure
description: No matter his age, a Long Island lobsterman, thinking back to the good old days, will always describe the same years. That would be pretty much any of them before 1999.

title: Rioting in Tottenham
description: A small anti-police demonstration in a north London neighborhood spiraled into looting and violent clashes that left 26 police officers injured and led to 55 arrests.

title: Medical Journal Wins Business Reporting Honor
description: Most media organizations hunger for recognition for their work. But on Friday, a different kind of publication received an award for its coverage: a medical journal.

title: Reviving a 79-Year-Old Barbarian
description: Back in 2001, Conan the Barbarian, the character that helped make Arnold Schwarzenegger a star, was tripping on his sword.

title: With Prospect of U.S. Slowdown, Europe Fears a Worsening Debt Crisis
description: PARIS  European political leaders have garnered much of the blame for the continuing crisis of the euro, consistently failing to act with enough speed or severity to calm the markets. But the current panic has been partly produced by American politicians, whose noisy squabbling over the debt ceiling has combined with the prospect of another United States recession to undermine the potential for global growth.

title: Death During Swim Renews Questions About Events Safety
description: A 64-year-old man died after having a heart attack during the swimming leg of Sundays New York City Triathlon, race officials said. A 40-year-old woman also had a heart attack during the 1,500-meter swim, according the New York Fire Department. She was in critical condition at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: On Long Island, Disappearing Lobsters
description: Last fall, on a visit to his nearby Long Island fish shop, the New York Times staff photographer Barton Silverman placed an order for some lobster.

title: Swallowed by a Shift
description: Mark Teixeira was sitting at his locker at Yankee Stadium late last month, trying to put into words how his season has gone at the plate.

title: Where Cubans Can Meet the Beatles at Last
description: HAVANA  The hair and accents were wrong, but the audience cared about just one thing: the house band was singing the Beatles, here, in a new bar called the Yellow Submarine, in Cuba, where such an act might have led to arrests in the mid-1960s.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include second-quarter productivity (Tuesday); wholesale trade for June (Wednesday); the trade deficit for June and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and retail sales for July, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for August, and business inventories for June (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Strange Calm Permeates Usual Frenzy of a Storied Rivalry
description: BOSTON

title: In Sentencing, Just What Did the Judge Say: 3 Years, or 2?
description: Jerry Herrington spent about a year trying to convince anyone who would listen that the court system had made a terrible mistake: even though court records had him down for a three-year sentence, he was sure that the judge in Manhattan had given him only two years.

title: S.&P. Downgrade Is Seen as Adding Urgency to Debt-Cutting Panel
description: WASHINGTON  The downgrade of the United States governments credit rating by Standard & Poors is almost sure to increase pressure on a new Congressional supercommittee to mute ideological disagreements and recommend a package of deficit-reduction measures far exceeding its original goal of at least $1.5 trillion, lawmakers said Sunday.

title: Athletes With a Rope to Hold, and Water to Stand On
description: SCOTIA, N.Y.  It was almost showtime along the banks of the Mohawk River. Young women in grass skirts and hot pink spandex braided one anothers hair. Men cinched black hats beneath their chins. The shows director implored: Big smiles!

title: For Scott and Caddie, a Victory to Savor
description: AKRON, Ohio  It happens in all sorts of ways, in business, politics and sports. A top guy fires a loyal lieutenant only to have the lieutenant come back to haunt the hallways, or, in the case at hand, the fairways.

title: Racing Along, and Above, the Mohawk River
description: The United States Water Ski Show Team wows the crowd with an annual summer show on a river near Albany.

title: Dont Gut the S.E.C.
description: SOME of our Congressional leaders, especially in the Republican Party, seem to want the federal government to cease operations. After all, their brinkmanship over the raising of the debt ceiling suggests that they dont really care whether anything ever gets done in Washington.

title: Across Globe, Traders Brace for a Downturn
description: Traders and bankers are braced for another volatile week in global markets  and the wildest ride is likely to be in stocks, not the Treasury bonds that were downgraded by Standard & Poors on Friday.

title: For Now, Posada Seems Out as Designated Hitter
description: BOSTON  Something about nationally televised night games against the Red Sox seems to evoke lineup issues surrounding Jorge Posada. On May 14, a Saturday night, Posada asked out of the starting lineup when he was written in to bat ninth by Yankees Manager Joe Girardi.

title: Credibility, Chutzpah and Debt
description: To understand the furor over the decision by Standard & Poors, the rating agency, to downgrade U.S. government debt, you have to hold in your mind two seemingly (but not actually) contradictory ideas. The first is that America is indeed no longer the stable, reliable country it once was. The second is that S.& P. itself has even lower credibility; its the last place anyone should turn for judgments about our nations prospects.

title: Waiting for a Landslide
description: In 1955, a political scientist named V. O. Key published an essay entitled A Theory of Critical Elections. He argued that realignments in American politics are usually punctuated by transformative elections, in which the old order suddenly gives way and a new majority emerges in its place.

title: Palestinians and the U.N.
description: In little more than a month, the Palestinians are expected to ask the United Nations to recognize their state. We have sympathy for their yearning and their frustration. For years, they have been promised a negotiated solution  President Obama called for a peace deal by September  and they are still empty-handed. But the consequences could be profoundly damaging for all involved.

title: Huntsman Runs on His Name, and His Fathers
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Jon M. Huntsman Jr. was 10 years old when his father packed up their growing family to move east in 1970, leaving behind his fledgling company to work for President Richard M. Nixon.

title: How Congress Devastated Congo
description: Washington

title: Escape to New York Festival Cancels Last Day
description: The final day of the Escape to New York music festival on Long Island was cancelled Sunday after overnight rains drenched the Shinnecock Indians meeting grounds where the main stage was erected, creating hazardous conditions, the organizers announced.

title: Every Mistake Has a Caddie Whos Seen It
description: SCARBOROUGH, N.Y.  Teaching professionals and well-traveled players see all kinds of golf swings, good and bad. But perhaps no one bears witness to more golfers mistakes than caddies at private clubs.

title: Heres an Easy $100 Billion Cut
description: If the Republicans are truly determined to slash the budget and end government waste, they will start with two obvious and long overdue cuts: ending the web of tax breaks enjoyed by the rolling-in-dough oil industry and terminating the ethanol subsidy. Together these cuts would save up to $100 billion over 10 years, without hurting the poor and middle class or slowing the economy.

title: Ohio and the Death Penalty
description: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio postponed for a month the states next execution. The decision is an admission that Ohios management of the death penalty is broken and further proof that the machinery of death cannot be operated responsibly anywhere.

title: When August Was Cold and Dark
description: A century ago this month, three wind-battered, frozen men quietly stepped into a hut on Cape Evans in the shadow of Antarcticas Mount Erebus. They were Edward Wilson, Henry Bowers and Apsley Cherry-Garrard. Their sledge contained a precious cargo: three emperor penguin eggs, the first ever collected. To obtain them, these men  part of Robert Scotts polar expedition  had walked 60 miles to Cape Crozier and back again, dragging a heavy sledge over impossible terrain in the Antarctic winters nearly complete darkness, howling winds and temperatures as low as 77 below zero.

title: Sharp Rift in a Strike at Verizon
description: The decision by 45,000 workers at Verizon Communications businesses to go on strike Sunday over proposed benefit cuts reflects sharp battle lines. On one side is a highly profitable telecommunications company that is eager to trim costs in its declining businesses; on the other are unionized workers who fear that the many concessions demanded by their employer will force them to give up decades of hard-won gains.

title: Watching Those Who Treat the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

Attack Adds to Signs of an Unstable Afghan Region
description: PORAK, Afghanistan  The devastating attack on an American helicopter in eastern Afghanistan over the weekend has heightened attention on the harsh reality that even now, at the height of the NATO troop presence and not far from Afghanistans capital, large stretches of the country are perilous and heavily infiltrated by insurgents.

title: In Suit, Housekeeper Says Buddhist Monk Enslaved Her in His Queens Home
description: A Korean immigrant housekeeper has accused her former employers  a Korean Buddhist monk and his family  of keeping her as a prisoner in their homes in Queens for 12 years and forcing her to work as their slave under threat of death, according to a lawsuit filed in federal court in Manhattan.

title: Chinas Premier Seeks Reforms and Relevance
description: This article was reported by  Jonathan Ansfield,  Michael Wines and  Sharon LaFraniere and written by Mr. Wines.

title: Stocks Suffer Sharpest Drop Since 2008
description: The stock market resumed its free fall Monday on mounting fears about the stalling economy and worries that the government had few options to increase growth, dual concerns that overshadowed the downgrade of long-term United States government debt.

title: Atlanta School Year Begins Amid a Testing Scandal
description: ATLANTA  After a summer of scandal, Michele Alford will welcome her new third-grade class on Monday the way she always has: with a test. After her students realize that the school year has begun and their grumbling subsides, she will ask the children, Where did I go to college? and What are my interests?

title: Atlanta Teachers Prepare for Classes After Summer of Scandal
description: One month after Atlanta was rocked by revelations of a widespread school cheating scandal, teachers are bracing for difficult questions from students this year.

title: Jane White, Actress and Singer Who Found Racial Attitudes to Be an Obstacle, Dies at 88
description: Jane White, an actress who made her reputation in the 1960s and 70s in Shakespearean and classical Greek drama in New York but who felt hampered by the racial attitudes of casting directors toward light-skinned black performers like herself, died on July 24 at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 88.

description: Until a few weeks ago, it seemed that the protest movement rolling across the Middle East, upending presidents and launching millions into the streets, might pass Israel right by. No longer.

title: Mark O. Hatfield, Republican Champion of Liberal Causes, Dies at 89
description: Mark O. Hatfield, a liberal Republican who challenged his partys positions on the Vietnam War and on a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution during his 30 years as a senator from Oregon, died on Sunday in Portland, Ore. He was 89.

title: Rivera Falters in Ninth and Yankees Fall Out of First
description: BOSTON  C. C. Sabathia and Mariano Rivera are the Yankees two best pitchers, and under normal circumstances when they are on the mound good things happen. But playing the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park hardly constitutes normal circumstances, and good things did not happen for Sabathia or Rivera this weekend.

title: Aug. 8, 1974 | President Nixon Announces His Resignation

title: Americans Abroad: Armbands, Golazos and Transfer Rumors
description: Now that the flood of summer tournaments and exhibitions is receding into memory, foreign leagues are springing back to life. Player hopes and club aspirations  as unrealistic as some of them might be  are back in blossom.

title: Even Berkshire Falls Short in Deal Battles
description: 5:58 p.m. | Updated

title: Complaint Box | Raucous at the Movies
description: I am a terrible film critic. Im indiscriminate about the flicks I watch, and I find something sensational about every one of them, including mindless summer blockbusters. A third Transformers movie! Im there. Rise of the Planet of the Apes? Ticket, please.

title: The Governments Calling About a Table. Should I Take the Call?
description: The end of summer brings a surge in calls from government clients, mostly from the military, looking to spend remaining dollars in their budgets before the fiscal year ends on Oct. 1. This year is no exception. The surge has started and is most likely to peak at the end of August. Just last week we got calls from the State Department, the Army and the Marines. The person on the phone is generally a low-level officer, responding to a request from a superior for pricing on a large and fancy table. Our bid will be presented to the upper ranks as one of a number of ways to spend their remaining money. Consequently, we sell a much lower percentage of these inquiries than those from private clients. But August is usually a slower month for private business, so we take the time to write proposals anyway.

title: Wall Streets New Normal
description: The world is a much different place than it was when Wall Street went home on Friday afternoon.

description: Some wonder if, in pursuing the presidency, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is chasing his fathers dream. He says he is pursuing nobodys dream but his own.

description: HOW many Americans were killed in an attack on a Chinook transport helicopter on Saturday?HOW many Afghans were killed in that same attack?

title: What Are the Basic Rules for Handling Breakups?
description: In late July, the Boston Public Health Commission hosted a one-day conference in which 200 teens and adult facilitators gathered to discuss the role of social media like Facebook in ending romantic relationships. According to the events organizers, teens arent getting enough guidance when it comes to the etiquette of breaking up. What do you think about that? How have Facebook, other social media sites and texting played a role in breakups you have experienced or witnessed?

title: Constructing a Portrait of Pakistan Through the Stories of Its People
description: During her travels across Pakistan, Pamela Constable, a veteran foreign correspondent for The Washington Post, dropped in on the campus of Punjab University in Lahore, a city of 10 million, the scene of terrorist bombings and the cultural capital of the nation. By cultural capital, residents generally refer to the fading Mughal monuments and, to a lesser extent, the lively contemporary art scene at the National College of Arts.

title: Styled to a T | Blanca Surez
description: The Trend

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Fregola With Corn
description: Fregola are tiny, toothsome balls of pasta that marry happily with fresh corn, peas or asparagus. Just keep everything small, said Lee McGrath, the executive chef at Po in Manhattan. The end result is kind of like macaroni and cheese, he said. The pasta is cooked. The vegetables, along with scallions, simmer in a lively fashion for a few minutes, and everything is tossed together with a handful of Parmigiano-Reggiano.

title: Rio and Mitsubishi Bid $1.6 Billion for Coal & Allied
description: Rio Tinto said on Monday that it was making a joint bid with the Mitsubishi Corporation for all the shares in the Australian mining company Coal & Allied they dont already own for about $1.6 billion.

title: Saudi Arabia Ramps Up Pressure on Syria
description: Syria came under new pressure on Monday from a widening clamor of criticism by Gulf Arab states over its brutal crackdown on a five-month-old antigovernment uprising, with Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Bahrain recalling their ambassadors and issuing statements calling on President Bashar al-Assad to change his ways.

title: Monday Reading: Beat the High Cost of Dialing Abroad
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Morning Buzz
description: For more local news from The Times, including the story of a man who may have been wrongly held in prison for a year past his sentence, the scene at the line on the final Saturday of the popular Alexander McQueen exhibit at the Met, and how independent Brooklyn record stores are critical of a new Jay-Z distribution deal, see the N.Y./Region section.

title: 2011 Dallas Cowboys Season Preview
description: The Dallas Cowboys got to their typical late-season meltdown much faster than usual last year. By the second week of November they were 1-7 and handing Coach Wade Phillips his walking papers. Though there were questionable tactical measures, the losing was primarily a consequence of sloppy execution. Many players simply lost their focus.

title: The Red Shoes Are Coming
description: In trying to marry the prissiness of the Victorians with the sexual revolution of the 1960s, Tabitha Simmons has come out with an English heritage collection that is a hybrid hoot. Like rockabilly shoes, the English designer says of her inspirations, but  more gothic. The 49 styles are indeed evocative of the British Isles, with a smattering of high-heel brogues, evening sandals with chandelier trim and suede boots that look like they stepped out of Bedknobs and Broomsticks. Compared to previous collections, it is slightly more macabre, yet Simmons, now in her fifth season, continues to demonstrate an ability to imbue classic styles with a modern twist. For example, the Edna heel, a reimagined stiletto loafer, is beetle-crusher when its in black and white, she says, and then we did a red and leopard version that has an element of Victoriana. Shes certainly got a bead on the new monarchy. A pair of nude silk slippers looks fit for a duchess or a Park Avenue princess.

title: Smith Will Meet With Giants
description: Giants fans are sure to like Steve Smiths Facebook status.

title: CIT Names Nelson Chai President
description: Commercial lender CIT Group has named Nelson J. Chai as its president, the firm announced on Monday. Mr. Chai, who formerly served as chief administrative officer and head of strategy, will keep his current responsibilities and lead the firms corporate finance and vendor finance businesses.

title: Who Trusts Governments?
description: The European Central Bank rode to the rescue today. But there was a limit to how much it could do.

title: Liquidity Traps in the WSJ
description: David Wessel has a pretty good summary. Two things worth noting.

description: The European Central Bank is in an unenviable position. Its only stated mandate is to fight inflation. These days inflation is not the important issue, to say the least.
