description: TOP STORIES

title: Gay Synagogue Finds a Home, Full of Ancient Assyrians
description: When King Pekah ruled the northern kingdom of Israel, the Assyrians invaded, occupied its cities and took its people captive to Assyria. (2 Kings 15:29.) Adding insult to grievous injury, the Assyrians later demanded of Hezekiah, ruler of the southern kingdom of Judah, a payment so large that he had to cut off the gold from the doors and doorposts of the first temple in Jerusalem. (2 Kings 18:16.)

title: Aaauuuggghhh! Market Commentary Edition
description: Carnage in stock markets as I write  and all of the headlines I see attribute it to S&Ps downgrade.

title: An Interview With the Treasury Secretary
description: CNBC/The Times Reporter John Harwood sits down with Secretary Timothy Geithner. Video Courtesy of CNBC.

title: Postcard From Edinburgh: Spirits of Fringe Festivalgoers Remain Undampened
description: EDINBURGH  Was there some sort of biblical event this weekend? The Escape to New York music festival on Long Island canceled a slate of concerts on Sunday due to rain, and in Newport, R.I., rain pelted musicians and concertgoers at the Newport Jazz Festival. Here, too, it was awfully drizzly, making the opening weekend of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe a soggy one. Two days of relentless rain seemed to have little impact on the crowds though. All over town audience members huddled in line under umbrellas as they waited to enter some of the more than 250 locations playing host to festival performances.

title: 10 Questions for Geithner
description: Shortly after announcing that he would remain on the job as President Obamas Treasury secretary rather than leave the administration and return home to New York, Timothy F. Geithner sat down with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC on Sunday to discuss Standard & Poors decision to downgrade the United States governments credit rating and Americas economic road ahead. Below is a condensed, edited view of their conversation.

title: Judge Keeps Ukraine Opposition Leader Jailed, Sparking Protest and Petitions
description: KIEV, Ukraine  A judge on Monday declined to release Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the Ukrainian opposition leader who was jailed last week on contempt of court charges, even as a few thousand of her supporters protested on the streets outside the courtroom.

title: McQueen: The Final Count
description: When all was said and done at the close of Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty on Sunday night, the final attendance count reached 661,509 visitors since the show opened on May 4, making it the eighth biggest show on record at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (Of course, some of us saw it five or six times, so that helped.)

title: Santorum Takes His Message to Iowa Voters
description: AMES, Iowa  Rick Santorum quickly admits that he is the only Republican presidential candidate whose name recognition has barely budged since he began campaigning for the Oval Office.

title: Top Sun | Michael Bastian + Randolph Engineering
description: Randolph Engineering, purveyor of high-performance sunglasses, is getting a fashion boost from the 2011 CFDA Menswear Designer of the Year, Michael Bastian. Turning his prep-American flair on the United States military and air forces longtime supplier of sunglasses by framing classic aviators in primary colors, Bastian says, Ive always loved what Randolph Engineering does. Theyre pretty much the perfect, masculine sunglasses. Available at Barneys New York and other select stores, the Michael Bastian for RE Signature Series sunglasses come in five different frame designs, all of which are variations of current and vintage models.

title: By Helping a Girl Testify at a Rape Trial, a Dog Ignites a Legal Debate
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  Rosie, the first judicially approved courtroom dog in New York, was in the witness box here nuzzling a 15-year-old girl who was testifying that her father had raped and impregnated her. Rosie sat by the teenagers feet. At particularly bad moments, she leaned in.

title: The Golden Years, Polished With Surgery
description: At age 83, Marie Kolstad has a rich life. She works full time as a property manager and keeps an active social calendar, busying herself with 12 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren.

title: More From the Mark Sanford Interview
description: We had so much interesting material left over from my two-hour interview with South Carolinas former governor Mark Sanford that weve decided to publish a longer-than-usual outtakes post. Since the bits are drawn from different points in the conversation, weve numbered these five excerpts for clarity while also providing a bit of context.

title: Assessing a Downgrade
description: Fears about the potential economic impact of the sovereign debt crisis roiled markets worldwide. The Times's Graham Bowley assesses the impact.

title: 26,000 Ford Mustangs Investigated for Sticky 6-Speed Manual Gearbox
description: Complaints about the 6-speed manual transmission on about 26,000 Ford Mustangs from the 2011-12 model years have prompted an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The agency said it received 32 complaints from owners who said they were unable to get the transmission into gear.

title: Moodys: Why the U.S. Is Still AAA
description: Virtually unnoticed last week was that Moodys kept a Triple A rating on the United States.

title: Predictably, the Shorts Are Blamed
description: This just in from the Associated Press:

title: Ex-Officer in Rape Case Gets Jail Term for Misconduct
description: A former New York police officer was sentenced on Monday to a year in jail in a case that drew headlines for its shocking allegations of rape at the hands of two on-duty officers, and then garnered more attention for their acquittals on all but a few lesser charges.

title: Pawlenty Says Hes Not Out to Get a Cable TV Show
description: URBANDALE, Iowa  Tim Pawlenty is filling the television airwaves here, with his interviews running during the morning news and his commercials scattered throughout the day, but he declared on Monday that he was not running for president simply to end up on television.

title: Selena Gomez and Taylor Swift Are Teens Choices
description: Selena Gomezs five wins at the Teen Choice Awards mean that she won one more than her boyfriend, Justin Bieber. Ms. Gomez, the star of Wizards of Waverly Place was selected as the Choice TV actress, female hottie and music group with her band The Scene, the Associated Press reports. The group was given the Choice single trophy for Who Says and the Choice award for love song for Love You Like a Love Song, which the 19-year-old Ms. Gomez performed at the Sunday ceremony.

title: Wilbur Ross Raises His Exco Stake to 12%
description: Wilbur L. Ross Jr. has increased his stake in Exco Resources into the double digits. The question now is, what will the billionaire investor do next?

title: Weight Loss Improves Sex for Diabetic Men
description: Losing just a small amount of weight can improve the sex lives of men with diabetes, new research shows.

title: Britain Urges Zimbabwe to Examine Diamond Torture Camp Report
description: LONDON  Britain has urged the authorities in Zimbabwe to investigate a BBC report that its security forces are beating and raping prisoners at two camps in the Marange diamond fields in the east of the country. International monitors voted to allow exports from the fields to resume in June despite objections from the United States, Canada and the European Union.

title: How Hated? Kanye West Likens Himself to Hitler
description: Kanye West, the multiplatinum-selling rapper, took his notorious self-pity and feelings of persecution to a new level during an onstage rant in England when he said he sometimes feels as hated as Adolf Hitler.

title: After World Cup Thrills, Players Return to Unstable Womens League
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Three weeks after losing in the final of the Womens World Cup, the players on the United States national team have returned to their professional soccer league. They have been welcomed home as if they were champions, handed roses and plaques calling them extraordinary heroes, an embrace that they appreciate and find somewhat baffling.

title: Match.com
description: It started when my very Parisian friend, staying at my New York apartment, hand-washed her lingerie and neatly hung the coordinating pairs along the shower rod. Bras and panties in tandem styles: frilly florals by Only Hearts, nude sheers from Eres and a hot pink number that could have only been from Agent Provocateur. So French, so chic. I squirmed in my mismatched red cotton briefs and orange satin bra. Why had it never dawned on me to match? I only started buying sets when I got married, says the author and Vogue contributing editor Plum Sykes, remembering a pistachio and cream lace combo she fell in love with on the Rue des Saints-Pres in Paris. Young women today seem to be more aware of the trend for beautiful matching lingerie, says Cynthia Gabay, Mylas creative director. Your underpinnings say as much about you as a person as your choice in clothing or accessories. My early-20-something self now officially desires grown-up glamour  and one trip to Bergdorfs later, taps and teddies are joined at the hip.

title: Its a Growth Scare
description: FTalphaville has been saying this all day, and its right. The action in the markets looks nothing like worries about US solvency; it looks exactly like what you expect to see when markets suddenly realize that the economys growth prospects look terrible.

title: Never Too Old for Plastic Surgery
description: If you think youre too old for a few nips and tucks, consider the story of 83-year-old Marie Kolstad.

title: Stop! Youre Killing Me!
description: I hear on the grapevine that some people are shocked, shocked I tell you, that I compared S&P to a murderer. Um, no. Thats the funniest thing Ive heard since Niall Ferguson accused me, somewhere or other, of dismissing confidence as a mere fairy.

title: Traveling by Bike, Practically Speaking
description: SANDPOINT, Idaho  To judge from reader comments on this blog, tweets from those who are following me, e-mails to my New York Times address and inquiries from people Ive been meeting along the way, the practical aspects of a cross-country bike trip are of real interest. People want solid facts. Not just where did you start and where are you going, but whats your route, how many hours a day do you ride and when do you think youll be finished? How do you do your laundry, how many flat tires have you had, what sort of GPS are you carrying? Then theres one Ive been asked three or four times recently: Whats your favorite thing about the trip so far?

title: McQueen Show Builds Met Membership
description: When all was said and done at the close of Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty on Sunday night, the final attendance count reached 661,509 visitors since the show opened on May 4, making it the eighth biggest show on record at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (Of course, some of us saw it five or six times, so that helped.)

title: After Bad Luck Leaves, Miss Africa New York Emerges
description: Bad luck has been following us today! said Munah Manneh, one of the main organizers of the Miss Africa New York pageant, which was held Friday in St. Pauls Elementary School on Staten Island.

title: City Students Improve Slightly on Statewide Tests
description: City students posted modest gains on elementary and middle school statewide tests this year, showing more improvement than students in the state as a whole and in New York States other large cities, officials said Monday.

title: Romney Is Back, With S.&P. Ratings on the Brain
description: CONCORD, N.H.  On his first day back on the campaign trail, Mitt Romney wasted no time in blaming President Obama for Americas recent credit downgrade.

title: 3 Arab Countries Recall Ambassadors to Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Kuwait recalled their ambassadors from Damascus on Monday, joining a chorus of global criticism of Syria, as Syrian forces pressed ahead with President Bashar al-Assads brutal crackdown on the most restive areas.

title: Private Messaging Network Is Said to Link London Rioters
description: The authorities in London arrested scores of people late Sunday and early Monday in hopes of heading off further violence after this weekends street riots, as evidence emerged suggesting that the unrest had been organized, at least in part, over private online messaging networks.

title: Bernadine P. Healy, a Pioneer at National Institutes of Health, Dies at 67
description: Dr. Bernadine P. Healy, the first woman to lead the National Institutes of Health and the first physician to lead the American Red Cross until she was forced out in a storm of criticism over flawed responses to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, died on Saturday at her home in Gates Mills, Ohio. She was 67.

title: The Caucus Click: Candidates and Reporters Make Iowa Push
David Bohrman Named President of Current TV
description: Signaling that it wants to compete directly with Fox News, MSNBC and CNN, Current TV on Monday hired a prominent CNN executive, David Bohrman, and put him in charge of all programming and production.

title: Your Neglected Stock Market Backup Plan
description: The recent market decline, and the media (over)reaction that followed, reminded me that we still have not learned a very simple lesson: the time to prepare for a crisis is long before you find yourself in one. Its not a good idea to figure out how a parachute works after you jump out of the plane.

title: Bank of America Shares Fall to Lowest Point in 2 Years
description: 10:34 p.m. | Updated 8:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Tribeca Film Festival Announces 2012 Dates
description: The Tribeca Film Festival said on Monday that its 11th annual festival would be held April 18  29 in Manhattan. The festival has asked for submissions for narrative and documentary features as well as for short film entries. The Tribeca Film Institute, the year-round nonprofit arts organization, said it would take submissions starting on Monday for its Tribeca All Access program, TFI Documentary Fund, Latin America Media Arts Fund and the TFI Sloan Filmmaker Fund. Starting Sept. 19, submission forms and information regarding eligibility for the 2012 festival will be available on the Tribeca Web site. Submission forms and information regarding eligibility for the film institute programs are available at tribecafilminstitute.org.

title: 75 Year Anniversary of Citys W.P.A Pools
description: In the summer of 1936 11 pools were built by the Works Progress Administration where opened in New York City.

title: 3 More Deaths From Heat Bring Citys Toll to 7
description: Three people have died this month because of the heat, the medical examiners office said Monday, bringing this summers heat-related death toll to seven.

title: Oil Sands to Raise Emissions, Canadian Report Says
description: The Canadian government has long fought efforts by politicians and environmentalists in other countries, including the United States, to characterize oil sands production as dirty oil. But an analysis quietly released late last month by its environmental agency indicates that the tar-like deposits will become an increasingly significant source of the countrys greenhouse gas emissions by the end of the decade.

title: Andy Cohen of Bravo Plans a Memoir
description: Andy Cohen, the Bravo channel executive who doubles as a talk-show host for the network, will soon double  or is that triple?  as an author. Henry Holt and Company said on Monday that it would publish Mr. Cohens first book, a memoir about growing up with a love of pop culture and landing a job in the television business, which enabled him to meet many of the stars he admired. The as-yet untitled book will also detail how Mr. Cohen, who is gay, suppressed his sexuality as a boy. It is to be published next summer.

title: David Krop on the U.S.S. Monitor
description: The conservation project manager for the U.S.S. Monitor talks about the restoration of a gun turret.

title: Pawlenty Lures Straw Poll Voters With Politics and Food
description: AMES, Iowa  There is one objective for Republican candidates this week: getting their supporters to come to the straw poll here on Saturday.

title: The Insider | Emerson Bethany Fry
description: If youve read an indie fashion blog lately, youve probably found yourself on the Web site of the studio EmersonMade, whose chief designer and model, Emerson Bethany Fry, seems to have inspired 1,000 girl crushes. First it was her fabric flower brooches; next the New Hampshire farm to which she and her husband, Ryan Fry, a photographer, had relocated from New York; and then the introduction of her clothing line, with the spring 2011 lineup of shift dresses and scalloped skirts causing particularly feverish obsession. Readers of Frys travel journal know that her continuous search for inspiration and textiles takes her to some far-flung places. Here, she shares a few of her favorite spots.

title: Famine in Somalia
description: Nearly three million people are in urgent need of assistance as Somalia endures one of its worst droughts 60 years.

title: Morris Quickly Makes His Mark at Sony Music
description: One month into his new job as the chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment, Doug Morris has already begun to reorganize the company, shuffling label divisions and naming new lieutenants.

title: A Brief Dry Spell for the U.S.S. Monitor
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va.  Military secrecy was a bit lax during the Civil War, by todays standards, but contractor deadlines were a lot tighter.

title: Numberplay: Nim for (a) Change

Today, we have a variant contributed by Patrick Vennebush, the author of the book Math Jokes 4 Mathy Folks and its extended online blog. Heres the story of the games invention, in Patricks words:

description: For some, having a live-in house guest who can also help is the perfect solution for aging at home.

title: S.&P. Negative on Berkshire Hathaway
description: Not long after Berkshire Hathaway uncharacteristically entered the takeover fray for Transatlantic Holdings, offering $3.25 billion, the credit ratings agency Standard & Poors had a surprise of its own: It lowered its outlook on Warren E. Buffetts company.

title: Michael Cerveris to Play Juan Peron in Evita Revival on Broadway
description: Michael Cerveris, the Tony Award-winning actor (Assassins), will star as Juan Peron in Evita, a revival of that Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber musical opening on Broadway in the spring of 2012, the shows producers said on Monday. Mr. Cerveris joins a cast that includes the singer Ricky Martin as Che and the Olivier Award winner Elena Roger in her Broadway debut as Eva. Mr. Cerveris made his Broadway debut in 1993 as the title character in The Whos Tommy, and his credits include playing John Wilkes Booth in Assassins and the title character in the 2005 revival Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.

title: Gun Query Off Limits for Doctors in Florida
description: As a primary care physician, I regularly ask patients questions that many people would consider rude, inappropriately nosy or just irrelevant in polite conversation.

title: Jazzs Present Gets Its Chance at Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  Leaving the Newport Jazz Festival on Sunday evening, hearing Rudresh Mahanthappa and Bunky Greens bright and brilliant alto saxophone sounds recede as you walked in the rain toward the water, you could feel a couple of contradictory things. One: The Newport Jazz Festival still matters. Two: That was pretty good for the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: Environment Poses a Knotty Challenge in Autism
description: Parents of children with autism often ask pediatricians like me about the cause of the condition, and parents-to-be often ask what they can do to reduce the risk. But although there is more research in this area than ever before, it sometimes feels as if its getting harder, not easier, to provide answers that do justice to the evidence and also offer practical guidance.

title: A Lion With Buffalo Horns? Must Be the New BMW Campaign
description: The North American division of BMW Group Financial Services is turning to humor and social media to promote its extended vehicle protection services.

title: One More Honor for Joe D: Finally, a Stamp

title: Picky Palates
description: Q. Why am I such a fussy eater? Does each person have a distinct set of taste buds, or is my fussiness just in my head?

title: Nothing New in Obama Remarks
description: Presidential addresses on days of market panics seldom accomplish very much, but it is not really easy to see why the one President Obama gave this afternoon was scheduled. He got there later than promised. He announced nothing new. He had the same old suggestions for what the government should do  some of them quite reasonable  but gave no reason to hope that the Republicans would agree to any of them.

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at Rest
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the eighth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from a week off in New York City.

title: On Arctic Ice and Warmth, Past and Future
description: Aug. 9, 8:00 p.m. | Updated Heres an update on Arctic ice trends, starting with a fast-motion video portrait of sea ice conditions near the North Pole, provided by one of two automated cameras deployed there in April (keeping in mind that the camera is on ice thats drifted hundreds of miles since then):

title: Groups Call for Scientists to Engage the Body Politic
description: When asked to name a scientist, Americans are stumped. In one recent survey, the top choice, at 47 percent, was Einstein, who has been dead since 1955, and the next, at 23 percent, was I dont know. In another survey, only 4 percent of respondents could name a living scientist.

title: Witness Feels Betrayed as U.S. Plans to Divide Family
description: WASHINGTON  About a decade ago, a federal prosecutor in Texas asked Edmond Demiraj to testify against an Albanian mobster charged with human smuggling.

title: Fox Draws Teenagers and Falling Skies Ends on a High
description: The Teen Choice Awards on Fox on Sunday night managed to ensnare its elusive target demographic thanks to squeal-inducing appearances by Taylor Swift, Robert Pattinson and Justin Bieber. The ceremony was the highest rated telecast of the summer for Fox among teenagers. Adults didnt quite follow suit, flocking to somewhat older fare on CBS. 60 Minutes garnered 8.7 million total viewers and Big Brother had 7.8 million, giving the station another Sunday win in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old segment.

title: Citi and American Airlines to Offer an E.M.V. Card
description: Add another credit card to the list of those offering affluent customers the more-secure E.M.V. chip technology thats becoming dominant in Europe.

title: Frogs Songs Attract Females, and Predators
description: Male tngara frogs gather in shallow pools of water at night and let out long mating calls. Females visit these pools, listen to a few calls and then quickly pick mates. Its a bit like speed dating.

title: The Presider and the Fighter
description: The Daily Beasts Leslie Bennetts has a story about prominent New York Democrats (all anonymous, of course) who wish that Hillary Clinton were president instead of the man they voted for three years ago:

title: Rick Perry to Make Clear He Intends to Run
description: DES MOINES  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is preparing to make clear his intentions to join the Republican presidential race, two associates said, by visiting South Carolina and New Hampshire on Saturday  the same day several of his potential rivals are taking part in the Iowa Straw Poll.

title: Catching Obesity From Friends May Not Be So Easy
description: Does obesity spread like a virus through networks of friends and friends of friends? Do smoking, loneliness, happiness, depression and illegal drug use also proliferate through social networks?

title: The Director Formerly Known as Vincent Gallo
description: The man who gave us Buffalo 66 (when Cristina Ricci still had breasts) and The Brown Bunny (a must for those who like seeing Chloe Sevigny sink to her knees) has announced that his latest,Promises Written in Water, will never be screened again. I do not want my new works to be generated in a market or audience of any kind, he was quoted as saying in The Guardian. As The Guardian points out, he is in illustrious company. Promises Written in Water is to take its place in the same sealed vault many miles underground, housing that other movie locked away from prying eyes by its own obsessive mastermind, Jerry LewissThe Day the Clown Cried. Perhaps, like Lewis, Gallo will end up inducted into the Lgion dHonneur.

title: House Leaders to End Page Program
description: WASHINGTON  There will be far fewer blue polyester jackets seen darting through Capitol Hill. John Boehner, the speaker of the House, and Nancy Pelosi, the minority leader, announced on Monday that they have decided to end the House page program. The decision, based on a cost analysis by an outside consulting firm, was largely driven by costs, and because advances in technology have rendered obsolete some of their tasks, such as taking phone messages.

title: A Seasonal Thirst for a Good Read
description: BEACH reading doesnt actually require a beach. You could just as easily be at the pool or on a breezy porch, or simply trying to stay cool on the couch, but if its summer, and you have a good book, in my mind it qualifies as beach reading. These four provocative wine books will no doubt inspire beachlike thirsts. Its up to you to quench them.

title: An Updated Sifty Fifty
description: Whos in, whos out? As summer comes to a close weve made some additions to my ever-evolving list of 50 favorite restaurants in New York City. Head over to The Scoop to download the free app. Or read it in your browser. Then get eating. Collect them all!

title: The Newport Jazz Festival
description: The festival took place at Fort Adams State Park in Newport, R.I., where casual jazz and music fans made up the majority of the crowds.

title: Focus on Insider Trading Becomes More Intense
description: The first week of August usually heralds the dog days of summer, but it also appeared to be insider trading week, as the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department unveiled three high-profile securities fraud cases, with the prospect for more. And another case, involving a former McKinsey & Company managing director, Rajat K. Gupta, took an interesting turn when the S.E.C. dismissed its administrative complaint and is likely to proceed in federal court in the near future.

title: Cuomo Appoints Panel to Choose New Transit Chief
description: It may be the toughest job listing in state government: lead an underfinanced, underappreciated mass transit system that is a regular punching bag for politicians, an emblem of bureaucratic inertia, and, incidentally, crucial to the lives of the millions who depend on it each day.

title: JPMorgan Hires Senior Insurance Banker From Bank of America
description: JPMorgan Chase has hired Paul Brown, a senior insurance deal-maker, from Bank of America Merrill Lynch, the firm announced in an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook on Monday.

title: Sherman Takes Over at Recording Industry Group
description: The Recording Industry Association of America, the music industrys biggest lobbying group, announced new leadership on Monday.

title: Hospitality Boutiques
description: The hotel shop, with its practical mix of sundries, souvenirs and candy bars, has been a predictable if uninspired lobby fixture for years. But as hotels scramble to distinguish themselves, many are rethinking their shops, upgrading and expanding merchandise and fashioning shops as destinations for both guests and local residents, much as they did with restaurants a decade ago.

title: Risks: Heart Risks May Hasten Mental Decline
description: Cardiovascular risk factors in middle age are associated with brain deterioration and a decline in mental function later in life, a new report has found.

title: Chinese Fault Beijing Over Foreign Reserves
description: HONG KONG  It is not just many Americans who are upset about the Standard & Poors downgrade of United States debt. A lot of people in China are angry, too. But they are aiming their venom at the Chinese government.

title: Sandwiches for Summer
description: Whenever I fly, I like to go armed with lunch, as the food in airports tends to be both appalling and expensive. Lately Ive hitting the road with sandwiches that combine produce with canned fish, like sardines, herring, trout or smoked salmon  all of them high in omega-3 fatty acids, packed with protein and delicious.

title: The People Who Should Sell Stocks Now
description: The temptation to do something, anything, is overwhelming when stock prices are falling. Watching the market decline while youre just standing there feels overwhelmingly foolish.

title: Longevity: Habits May Extend Life Only So Much
description: The eating, drinking and exercise habits of extremely old but healthy people differ little from those of the rest of us, a new study has found.

title: Regimens: Soy Does Little for Menopause Symptoms
description: Fears about the risks of estrogen replacement therapy have led many women to turn to soy products to treat the symptoms of menopause. But a clinical trial published on Monday in Archives of Internal Medicine has found them no more effective than a placebo.

title: TimesCast | August 8, 2011
description: President Obama addresses the downgrade of the United States' credit rating; Arab countries increase pressure on Syria; and rioting and looting continue in London for a third day.

title: When the Wife Is a Lucky Charm, Dont Leave Home Without Her
description: IHAVE to say that I love flying. Theres something very intimate about being on a plane. You never know who youll be seated next to and what their stories may be.

title: Noose Hour
description: Ill be on along with Ken Rogoff and someone from the investment world. Well be talking about sports statistics, or something. Unless, you know, something happened today.

title: A P.G.A. Course Is Made to Take the Heat
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Clutching two golf balls, Ken Mangum hopped out of the cart and strolled onto the eighth green. He rolled an orange ball that briskly covered about 20 feet and stopped level with the hole. A white one, dropped straight down from knee high, bounced slightly, almost imperceptibly.

title: Second Triathlon Swimmer Dies, Prompting Review of Race Protocol
description: A second competitor died Monday after apparently having had a heart attack during Sundays New York City Triathlon.

title: Epidemics: AIDS Cases Increasing in Muslim Countries
description: AIDS is on the rise in many Muslim countries, driven by men having sex with other men in secret because of homophobia, religious intolerance and fear of being jailed or executed, according to a new study.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, London, Kenya and Somalia.

title: Salad Bars in Pork City
description: Cincinnati isnt the only town in the country thats bringing salad bars to its public schools (theres New Haven, and New Orleans), but it has the rare distinction of once being known as Porkopolis, from the time  the early-to-mid 19th century  when herds of hogs roamed its streets, and it was the biggest pork-packing center in the country.

title: What Once Seemed Too Far Is Now Just Right
description: Many years ago, back when 96th Street was the bright-line border separating the upper reaches of the Upper East Side and East Harlem, Darin White, an executive at a major search firm, had a friend who lived in a nice prewar building on East 98th Street.

title: Battle for Libya | August 8, 2011
description: A look at developments in Libya.

title: One on One: Brian X. Chen, Author of Always On
description: Brian X. Chen, a reporter and editor for Wired.com, is the author of a new book, Always On: How the iPhone Unlocked the Anything-Anytime-Anywhere Future  and Locked Us In. Mr. Chen discussed with me whether smartphones are good or bad for society and if we will all look like cyborgs in the near future.

title: London Riots Continue
description: Reporter Ravi Somaiya reports from the London suburb of Hackney where a third day of rioting, looting and street fights with the police was getting underway.

title: Was That Mr. Margin On The Line?
description: Interesting: John Hempton suggests that what just happened was that

title: An Economist for Nature Calculates the Need for More Protection
description: COTO BRUS, Costa Rica  Dawn is breaking over this remote upland region, where neat rows of coffee plants cover many of the hillsides. The rising tropical sun saturates the landscape with color, revealing islandlike remnants of native forest scattered among the coffee plantations.

title: An East Hampton Festival That Wont Be
description: The promoters of the Music to Know Festival on Long Island had a magic number in mind last week: 5,500. That was how many tickets they would have to sell to break even on this two-day event in East Hampton.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, London, Kenya and Somalia.

title: Chimpanzees Clear Some Doubt After Generosity Is Questioned
description: When it comes to the evolution of humans, a lot depended on the kindness of strangers.

title: Medicare Extends Experiment in Paying Doctors
description: After five years of testing the idea, Medicare officials said Monday that they believe that doctors who coordinate care and keep their patients out of the hospital can help reduce the nations health care costs.

title: Scientists mixing it up in the political arena, facelifts and breast implants for the over-65 crowd, and do your friends make you fat redux.
description: Scientists mixing it up in the political arena, facelifts and breast implants for the over-65 crowd, and do your friends make you fat redux.

title: Hotel Housekeeper Sues Strauss-Kahn
description: The hotel housekeeper who has accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her in his 28th-floor suite sued him in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on Monday, seeking unspecified damages for a violent and sadistic attack that humiliated and degraded her and robbed her of her dignity as a woman.

title: Demand Growing for Giving Birth at Home
description: When Kelly Brown gave birth three years ago, she labored for 22 hours, much of the time hooked up to an IV line that restricted her movement. Repeatedly offered pain medication she did not want, she narrowly avoided getting a Caesarean section.

title: Wait Your Turn (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Rethinking Normal (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Problems Upon Problems (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: TimesCast | Condemning Syria
description: The Times's Anthony Shadid on Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Kuwait recalling their ambassadors from Damascus to protest the Syrian president's deadly crackdown on demonstrators.

title: An Interior Design Deal-Maker Leaves His Mark
description: THE blond, brainy young decorator Celerie Kemble often seems to be everywhere on the Manhattan society circuit, but her name is not yet echoing outside its crown-molded corridors or emblazoned on bathmats in the Midwest.

title: A Colorful Way to Watch Evolution in Nebraskas Sand Dunes
description: VALENTINE, Neb.  The nearest ocean is a thousand miles away. Yet across central Nebraska, peeking out from rolling hills of prairie grass, is sand  beige and reminiscent of a Caribbean beach. Nebraskas sandhills are the largest sand dunes in North America, spreading for more than 20,000 square miles, over more than a quarter of the state. The sand hails from the Rocky Mountains: tiny specks of eroded quartz that blew east and landed here, 8,000 years ago.

title: Coup de Glass
description: For its fall collection of icicle-drop necklaces and pendants, Kora, the L.A.-based, African-made jewelry line, teamed up with glass makers in the Kenyan village of Kitengela. A mere two years old, Kora has dedicated itself to creating trade not aid jobs by designing and marketing hand-fashioned pieces made from recycled bone, aluminum, brass, horn and now glass. The colors of the glowing green glass are incredible; its so unlike animal horn, says Koras co-founder Maxandra Short (above, left). Her partner, Amy Walker, adds, Glass necklaces still have an organic feel, because every piece is different. Indeed the latest offerings, like the necklace at right ($220; go to koradesigns.com), are a softer addition to the lines usually more brawny designs, which in the past have included tribal-inspired manacles and industrial-looking chains. I think were even going to be playing with color in bone, Walker says. Color is our thing now.

title: 'Annie' Audition Tape: Caroline Ellis
description: Caroline Ellis, 11, auditioned for the Broadway revival of "Annie" by singing "I Know It's Today" from "Shrek the Musical." (Video courtesy of Laurel Wilson.)

title: Q&A: Online Photos for the Family
description: Q.

title: On New Yorks Low Seas: Day 1
description: Francois Guillet, 68, caught my bow line and tied my boat to his steel-hulled work boat.

title: At Mozart Festival, Dvorak and Others Shine
description: The Kaplan Penthouse, one of Lincoln Centers smallest performance spaces, isnt that high up. Its just on the 10th floor. But at night, with its silvery 1980s-ish columns and twinkling high-rises all around, it definitely has romance. Its a microcosm of New York, simultaneously intimate and expansive, cool and warm.

title: New Music From Gucci Mane and Waka Flocka Flame
description: GUCCI MANE & WAKA FLOCKA FLAME

title: Where Musicians Bask in the Luxury of Time
description: MARLBORO, Vt.  On a recent Saturday evening at Marlboro College here, the dining room resembled that of a rambunctious boarding school, as scruffily dressed musicians of all ages energetically tossed paper napkin balls at one another across long tables.

title: Fred Imus, Radio Personality and Songwriter, Dies at 69
description: Fred Imus, a country songwriter and radio personality who appeared frequently on his older brother Dons radio show, was found dead in his trailer in Tucson, Ariz., on Saturday. He was 69.

title: Austerity Plan Might Not Work for Spain and Italy
description: ONCE again Europes leadership has been forced to put up billions in cash to halt the spread of contagion to the Continents weaker economies, this time in the form of a potentially vast purchase of Italian and Spanish government bonds by the European Central Bank. And once again the condition for rescue is more austerity.

title: An Easter Egg for Instagram Photos
description: Instagram, the insanely popular free iPhone photo-sharing app, has passed 150 million postings, which just goes to show how devoted iPhone users are to both photography and sharing. But there are a couple of lesser-known Instagram features that even the most enthusiastic users might have missed.

title: Footnote
description: The Tribeca Film Festival said on Monday that its 11th annual festival would be held April 18-29. The festival has asked for submissions for narrative and documentary features as well as for short film entries. Starting on Sept. 19, submission forms and information regarding eligibility for the festival will be at tribecafilm.com.

title: Their Stock Portfolios May Be Bleeding, but Consumers Get a Break on Gas Prices
description: HOUSTON  The growing gloom about the economy has pushed down oil and gasoline prices, along with the prices of an array of other commodities. And while that could mean more spending power for consumers, perhaps tempering any possible downturn, the steep drop in energy prices reflects worries that economic activity is headed in the wrong direction.

title: Recording Industry Chairman Named to Lead Automotive Trade Group
description: As reported by our colleagues at Media Decoder, the chairman and chief executive of the Recording Industry Association of America, Mitch Bainwol, has stepped down to lead the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, a lobbying group that represents the interests of the 12 largest automakers in the United States.

title: Groups Advocating for the Arts Feel the Pinch
description: The Alliance for the Arts, which has served New Yorks cultural world through research and advocacy for 35 years, is transferring its primary activities to the Municipal Art Society and to WNET, two deals in the process of being completed that illustrate how arts advocacy and service groups in New York are struggling to sustain themselves at a time of scarce resources.

title: What Will Stop the Drop?
description: What will stop this?

title: Creating an International Sound Without Compromising Their Roots
description: African music gone international, 21st-century style, filled Live From the Continent, the Sunday night concert at Damrosch Park. That meant a merger with hip-hop for Blitz the Ambassador, originally from Ghana; a merger with dance-music electronics for Spoek Mathambo, of South Africa; and a merger with R&B for Iyadede, originally from Rwanda.

title: Down Two Players, and Four Runs, Mets Rally to Win
description: In a season already best described as erratic, it seemed only fitting for the Mets to have a Monday like this one. They began their day by announcing the latest batch of grim injury news only to end it, hours later, with the exuberance of a victorious dog pile out near second base.

title: Bowing to Citadel, E*Trade Hires Goldman Sachs
description: E*Trade is bending to Citadels will.

title: Libyan Rebels Dissolve Cabinet Amid Discord
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Rebel leaders dissolved their own cabinet on Monday, in an effort to placate the family of an assassinated rebel military leader and quiet discord in a movement already struggling to remove the countrys leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, from power.

title: Under Armour Applies Its Muscle to Shoes
description: IN recent years, Under Armour apparel has become a must-have for legions of professional and amateur athletes looking for sweat-absorbing sportswear. Now the company is introducing the biggest campaign yet for its athletic shoes in hopes of matching that success in footwear.

title: Black Journalist Groups Members Want Talks on Rejoining Alliance
description: Leaders of the National Association of Black Journalists may be rethinking their decision to leave an alliance with three other minority journalist groups, in response to calls from N.A.B.J. members for reconciliation.

title: Achoos of Death Are Films Scourge
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Earthquakes. Tornadoes. Debt Downgrade. Double dip.

title: A Dramatic Sell-Off in the Markets
description: The Dow Industrial Average fell more than 600 points in the first day of trading after Standard & Poor's downgraded the U.S. sovereign debt rating. The Times's Graham Bowley examines the volatile day.

title: In Brooklyn, a Happy Birthday to a Simple Pleasure
description: Picture a Monday in August: A bad day on Wall Street. Spain in the headlines again. More hot, dry weather in this country. The mayor was complaining that New York was not getting the federal money it should.

title: Critics' Picks: 'MASH'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Robert Altman's irreverent film about an army hospital near the front lines in the Korean War.

title: Egyptian Bloggers Parse London Riots in Real Time
description: Tuesday, 11:10 a.m. Update: The morning after this post was published, Sarah Carr, a Cairene blogger who is a dual citizen of Egypt and Britain, wrote a blog post about the riots, Love Me, Im a Looter, which began with the observation that she is from a south London suburb where riots broke out on Monday. Im from Croydon, she explained. Someone has to be.

title: One Cost Increase Ends, but Others Trend Upward
description: BOARDING pass and ID? Check. Hotel and rental car reservations? Liquids in 3.4-ounce containers all zipped inside a one-quart bag? Check.

title: TimesCast | Obama Addresses Instability
description: President Obama tried to calm the markets as stocks on Wall Street plummeted.

title: A Visual Chronicle of Stock Traders Agony
description: The tumult in the stock market has been a boon for The Brokers With Hands on Their Faces Blog.

title: Recall Elections in Sharply Divided Wisconsin Are Ending on Frenetic Note
description: SAYNER, Wis.  Wisconsin voters go to the polls on Tuesday to decide whether to remove six Republican state senators, more recall election efforts of state legislators in a single day than have ever taken place in Wisconsin and the latest chapter in what has been one of the most polarized, vitriolic political years in memory.

title: Arizona: State Sues Marijuana Clubs
description: State Attorney General Tom Horne filed a civil suit Monday against four cannabis clubs in the Phoenix area that he said violated the states medical marijuana law, which voters approved in November. The state has not issued any licenses to marijuana dispensaries pending a federal court review. The result has been the creation of unlicensed cannabis clubs, which charge membership fees but give away marijuana to approved patients. That type of deception and blatantly illegal activity must be stopped, Mr. Horne said.

title: El Salvador: Suspects in Killings of Priests Turn Themselves In
description: Nine former soldiers and officials have turned themselves in to a court in El Salvador after being indicted in Spain for the 1989 massacre of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter in San Salvador. The Supreme Court now has 45 days to decide whether to extradite the men to Spain. American officials and analysts, however, say an extradition is unlikely. The court is expected to rely on Salvadoran law, including a 1993 amnesty for crimes committed during its civil war.

title: App Smart Extra: An App Aimed to Curb Distracted Driving
description: My recent App Smart column briefly mentioned a new Android and BlackBerry app, PhoneGuard, which disables a phones texting functions whenever it detects the user moving more than 10 miles per hour.

title: In Baghdad, Closing a 5-Star Retreat
description: CAMP VICTORY, Iraq  If the combat zone in Iraq were not so completely dry, some soldier on the staff of the palatial J.V.B. would be ringing last call.

title: Order Dismisses a Priest Trying to Ordain Women
description: The Rev. Roy Bourgeois, who refused to renounce his increasingly public campaign to see women ordained as priests in the Roman Catholic Church, has been notified of his dismissal by his religious order, the Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers.

title: Chargers Fans Fear Losing Their Team
description: SAN DIEGO  Here is a view of the between-life, or afterlife, known as limbo, for a professional sports team.

title: Late Entry Into a Race for Mayor: The Mayor
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Adding a dose of intrigue to a race that has been as dreary as this citys summer weather, Mayor Edwin M. Lee said Monday that he would run for a full term, after months of saying he did not want the job.

title: Transatlantic Seeks Talks With Berkshire Unit
description: Aug. 9, 9:44 a.m. | Updated

title: Back on Stump, Romney Faults Obama on Downgrade
description: CONCORD, N.H.  After a weeks vacation, and facing questions about a relatively subdued campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, Mitt Romney kicked off his busiest week yet on Monday and wasted no time in blaming President Obama for Americas credit rating downgrade.

title: Unafraid to Put Money Where His Mouth Is
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Seven years ago, Jason Blewitt was a kid in shirt-sleeves who handed out entries and the occasional betting tip in the New York Racing Associations press boxes. One memorable May afternoon, he pointed to a horse on the program by the name of Multiple Choice and declared: Hes a quality animal. Thats the horse to bet.

description: The Times's Corey Kilgannon explores New York City by boat to meet the people along its waterways.

description: Mike Konczal, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and Timothy Carney of The Washington Examiner debate whether higher inflation could help the economy.

description: Charles Wyly, who amassed a fortune building and trading companies that sold products as diverse as crafts supplies and electricity, died on Sunday in a traffic accident in Colorado. He was 77.

description: NASHUA, N.H.  On a day when Gov. Rick Perry of Texas announced that he was going to announce his intentions to announce his likely campaign for the Republican nomination on Saturday, Mitt Romney remained largely silent about his potential competitor from down South, who political analysts say could pose a possible threat to Mr. Romneys candidacy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Does Philosophy Matter? (Part Two)
description: Some of the readers who were not persuaded by my argument that abstract moral propositions do not travel into practical contexts (see, Does Philosophy Matter?) offer what they take to be obvious counterexamples. Joe (187) cites the Philosophers Brief on assisted suicide that was submitted to the Supreme Court. The example, however, counts for my side.
