description: To the Editor:

title: House Shuts Down Its Page Program
description: WASHINGTON  In the more than 175 years since young people began coming to Washington to work as Capitol messengers, the experience of being a Congressional page has marked the start  and on occasion the scandalous end  of many a political career.

title: Disaster Movie Gets a Sequel, With Subtitles
description: It is beginning to feel a lot like 2008 all over again. But its not the same.

title: Feds Elusive Prescriptions for an Erratic Ailment
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is back in the spotlight, with investors anxiously wondering if the central bank will end a two-month hiatus and announce new measures to support the economy on Tuesday.

title: A Gem Starts to Show Worrying Flaws
description: This much is undisputed about Jose Reyes: he is an extraordinary player. Bud Black, the manager of the San Diego Padres, compared him Monday to the greatest leadoff man in history.

title: As Debate Goes On, Amputee Will Break Barrier
description: The moment that the sprinter Oscar Pistorius had hoped for and trained for finally came Monday when he was named to South Africas team for the track and field world championships, which will make him the first amputee to compete at the event.

title: Before Taking on Albany, Raising 14 Children in 1960s Brooklyn
description: For one boisterous decade in the 1960s, the three-story brick house in Park Slope, Brooklyn, on the corner of Second Street and Prospect Park West, was the vibrant epicenter of politics and family life for Hugh L. Carey.

title: For-Profit College Group Sued as U.S. Lays Out Wide Fraud
description: The Department of Justice and four states on Monday filed a multibillion-dollar fraud suit against the Education Management Corporation, the nations second-largest for-profit college company, charging that it was not eligible for the $11 billion in state and federal financial aid it had received from July 2003 through June 2011.

title: The Giants Hope They Are Close to Getting Umenyiora Off His Bike
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Osi Umenyiora was back riding his customary stationary bike in the shadow of the teams indoor practice facility on Monday. He was joined by the rookie defensive tackle Marvin Austin.

title: The Games the Nazis Played
description: Bozeman, Mont.

title: Japan Held Nuclear Data, Leaving Evacuees in Peril
description: FUKUSHIMA, Japan  The day after a giant tsunami set off the continuing disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, thousands of residents at the nearby town of Namie gathered to evacuate.

title: On Volatile Day, Traders Weigh Their Scant Options
description: The trader sat quietly behind a wall of eight monitors in a Midtown Manhattan trading room, enshrined in a cockpit of light, as he struggled to complete a trade.

title: Obama Counsels Calm, but No Deal Is in Sight
description: WASHINGTON  If ever there was a time for contrition in this town, it might be after the events of the last few days: a deeply embarrassing downgrading of the nations credit rating, poll numbers showing public support for Congress at record lows, topped on Monday with a bracing plunge in the stock market.

title: State Comptroller to Propose a Hydraulic Fracturing Fund
description: The New York State comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, will propose legislation on Tuesday that would create an industry-supported fund to pay for potential environmental damage caused by hydraulic fracturing, a controversial method used to extract natural gas from shale.

title: Behind S.&P.s Downgrade, a Committee That Acts in Private
description: A committee of about a half-dozen largely unknown people made a decision last Friday that has roiled Washington and Wall Street.

title: The Downgrading of a Debtor Nation
description: THE Treasury can cry foul all it wants, but the decision by Standard & Poors to downgrade Americas credit rating by one notch last Friday, and the subsequent plunge in the stock market, are serious symptoms of a loss of confidence  an assessment that is fundamentally political, not economic.

title: 2 on Judicial Pay Panel Press for Big Raises
description: Two members of the commission reviewing judicial pay in New York State pressed for substantial raises at a public session on Monday, but the seven-member panel has not yet made a decision.

title: Stocks Plunge in Global Sell-Off
description: Markets around the world saw sharp declines on Monday in the wake of the S&P downgrade of the United States credit rating.

title: A Wave of Worry Threatens to Build on Itself
description: Employers delaying or suspending hiring. Home buyers getting cold feet. Shoppers pulling back on spending.

title: Perry Signals Intent to Enter Race, Sending a Jolt to G.O.P. Candidates
description: DES MOINES  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas delivered a long-distance jolt to the Republican presidential campaign on Monday by signaling that he intends to join the race and visit South Carolina and New Hampshire on Saturday, the same day his rivals are battling for survival in the Iowa Straw Poll.

title: Jets Sanchez Welcomes New Receivers, Again
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The free-agency frenzy dust has settled at Jets training camp, and what emerged in a matter of two weeks is the third wide receiver corps for Mark Sanchez in three years.

title: Evolutions Gold Standard
description: Feeling low? According to a new study in the Journal of Consumer Research, when people feel bad, their sense of touch quickens and they instinctively want to hug something or someone. Tykes cling to a teddy bear or blanket. Its a mammal thing. If young mammals feel gloomy, its usually because theyre hurt, sick, cold, scared or lost. So their brain rewards them with a gust of pleasure if they scamper back to mom for a warm nuzzle and a meal. No need to think it over. All they know is that, when a negative mood hits, a cuddle just feels right; and if theyre upbeat and alert, then their eyes hunger for new sights and theyre itching to explore.

title: In Afghanistan, a Village Is a Model of Dashed Hopes
description: ALICE-GHAN, Afghanistan  This tiny village rose from the rocky soil with great hopes and $10 million in foreign aid, a Levittown of identical mud-walled houses built to shelter some of the hundreds of thousands of Afghans set adrift by war and flight.

title: Democrats Challenging Administration on Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON  In an unusual break with the White House, the Democratic leaders of Congress told the Supreme Court on Monday that President Obama was pursuing a misguided interpretation of federal Medicaid law that made it more difficult for low-income people to obtain health care.

title: Past Time for a New Agenda
description: President Obama tried on Monday to restore the plunging confidence of investors, insisting the United States remains a triple-A country whatever Standard & Poors might think. It didnt work with the stock markets, which sank again, and it did nothing to reassure the most important shareholders: ordinary Americans living from one paycheck to another, worried about their jobs or wondering how they will replace the one they lost.

title: Virginia Goes to the Birds
description: In late July 1861, the noted lithographer John Bachmann published a captivating visual picture of Virginia, offering Northerners a powerful and intuitive way to follow the ongoing conflict. Of course, there were already lots of maps of the Old Dominion. What set this one apart? Perspective: looking westward with the Chesapeake Bay in the foreground, it offered a birds eye view, an intuitive but, for many, novel look at the unfolding conflict. His wide angle lens approach enabled viewers to follow not just the actual location of the battles, but the terrain of the conflict and a larger sense of the geography of the eastern theater.

title: The Arab States and Syria
description: It took far too long, but the cruelty of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has finally registered with his Arab neighbors. They are speaking out against a reign of terror that has claimed the lives of as many as 1,600 courageous Syrians since pro-democracy protests began in March.

title: Fire Dept. Reduced Bias Unit While Being Sued for Bias
description: The New York Fire Department office that handles discrimination complaints shrank during a period when the federal government was suing the agency on the grounds that its hiring tests were biased, an assistant fire commissioner testified in United States District Court on Monday.

title: A Necessary Condition for Arctic Drilling
description: The Obama administrations decision on Thursday to give conditional approval to Royal Dutch Shells plans to begin drilling four shallow-water wells in the Beaufort Sea off Alaska alarmed many environmentalists. Cleaning up an oil spill in the frigid, turbulent waters of the Arctic Ocean is likely to be far more complicated than it was in the comparatively benign waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: As Cheers Fade, Clock Ticks on W.P.S.
description: After thrilling fans at the Womens World Cup, many of the worlds top players returned to their teams in Womens Professional Soccer and resumed wondering how long the league would be there for them. Jer Longman looks at the boost the World Cup brought the league, and at some of the serious challenges it still faces. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

title: Lottery Numbers
Perhaps It Was the Campaign Tooth Fairy
description: The secretive world of deep-pocket political giving does not get much murkier than the $1 million dropped on Mitt Romneys presidential boosters by a company apparently created solely to make the gift then quickly dissolve.

title: While the Markets Swoon ...
description: Its hard not to feel a certain contempt for Standard & Poors in the wake of its downgrade of American debt. Its sole job as a credit-rating agency is to gauge the creditworthiness of bonds, yet like its competitors, Moodys and Fitch, it has consistently fallen short. It downgraded Enron days before the company went bankrupt. Its willingness to slap a AAA rating on securitized subprime junk was the foundation upon which the entire financial crisis was built. And now, to show that its got some spine, S.&P. decided to downgrade the United States? From a purely economic standpoint, the likelihood of a U.S. default is nil. As my friend Daniel Alpert, a founding managing partner of Westwood Capital, put it: The size of the U.S. economy, the wealth of its inhabitants and the assets of the sovereign entity itself are unquestionably more than adequate to repay, with interest, all of the $14 trillion or so of the nations debt. He added, Anyone with a rudimentary understanding of finance and economics can figure that out. On Monday, with the market collapsing, where did investors rush to put their money? In the one security they still considered safe: U.S. Treasuries.

title: Tuesday: Words to Swear By
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  When veteran constructors mentor new ones to publication, the veterans humor and creativity often takes a back seat to the neophytes, and thats the way it should be, in my opinion. After all, the whole point of mentoring someone is not to foist your style on them, but to help them create their own.

title: After Day of Tumult, Dow Closes Up 430 Points
description: In another wild day on Wall Street, stocks climbed, then dropped, then rocketed as traders did a double take on the Federal Reserves much-awaited statement on the economy Tuesday afternoon.

title: In Boston, Rivera Revisits a Nemesis
description: Marco Scutaro may have ensured himself a spot on any Boston Red Sox postseason roster Sunday night when he foiled Mariano Rivera for the second time in his career.

title: Identical Twins, One Charged in a Fatal Shooting, Create Confusion for the Police
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  At first, the murder case against Orlando Nembhard seemed solid, as witness after witness came forward to say they saw someone that looked just like him brandish a pistol in February outside a crowded nightclub and fire on a young clubgoer, who later died.

title: Marshall Grant, Bass Player With Johnny Cash, Dies at 83
description: Marshall Grant, a bass player who, as an original member of Johnny Cashs band, the Tennessee Two, helped create the groups pulsing boom-chicka-boom sound, died on Sunday in Jonesboro, Ark. He was 83.

title: Video Intensifies Interest in a Mississippi Killing
description: ATLANTA  At first, the early-morning death of James C. Anderson, 49, appeared to be a hit-and-run accident.

title: Libyan Berbers Re-emerge as a Political Force
description: A Berber city shows signs of a nascent sense of self-determination  a step, the people hope, toward full national and regional recognition.

title: Libyan Street Art: Freedom, Defiance and Troubling Signs
description: Sitting in the ruins of a Libyan government building in Yafran that had been shattered by violence, Abdul Ghassem recalled his feeling within when he first began to paint murals expressing his disgust for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. That was in early June, soon after the Qaddafi military was driven out of his city. Abdul Ghassems paintbrushes moved along the interior walls. As a huge mural took shape, Libyas longtime leader came to resemble a vampire watching over a world troubled by blood, suffering and fire.

title: Bank of America Is Back in an Abyss
description: Bank of America is leading banks back into the mortgage abyss. The nations largest financial institution by assets shed over $16 billion of market value on Monday as its shares fell 20 percent after the downgrade of the United States credit rating, and a home loan lawsuit filed by the American International Group, the insurer. Other mortgage-heavy lenders were hit, too, but none as bad as Bank of America.

title: Special Operations Veterans Rise in Hierarchy
description: WASHINGTON  A growing number of veteran commandos in Special Operations are rising to top positions in traditional military units and across the national security bureaucracy, reflecting the importance of their specialized training to fight unconventional wars that defined the past decade.

title: Inflation Climbs in China on Higher Food Prices
description: HONG KONG  Inflation in China accelerated last month to its fastest pace in three years, with consumer prices up 6.5 percent from a year earlier mainly as a result of rising food prices.

title: Amid a Berber Reawakening in Libya, Fears of Revenge
description: YAFRAN, Libya  In the evening, as the searing desert temperatures subside, the residents who have returned to this rebel-held city near the front lines appear on the streets. Some of them carry cans of paint, and begin to decorate murals with the characters of an ancient language that had been forbidden by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Hopefuls Sing Out From Afar as Broadway Scouts Go Online
description: Julia Tan, a 10-year-old actress who dreams of belting like Barbra, auditioned for her first Broadway show last month  2,500 miles away, in her family room in Kuna, Idaho. As her older sister fumbled with a video camera and her mother beamed nearby as a cue (keep smiling!), Julia performed Born to Entertain from the musical Ruthless! for one of the three-minute audition tapes that little girls worldwide are sending in to the online casting call for the 2012 revival of Annie.

title: Mike Baxter, Batting 1.000 for His Hometown Team
description: Mike Baxter was 14 years old when the Mets reached the National League Championship Series in 1999. He was an infielder then, a Queens native who would star at Archbishop Molloy, and he admired the way Rey Ordonez played shortstop. A left-handed hitter, Baxter loved to watch John Oleruds swing.

title: Village for Afghanistans Displaced Is Largely Abandoned
description: Alice-Ghan was built with foreign aid to house Afghans set adrift by war and flight. But with few services or jobs within reach, hundreds of residents have moved away.

title: Rosemary Harris and Carla Gugino to Star in Athol Fugard Play on Broadway
description: Rosemary Harris (The Royal Family), Carla Gugino (Desire Under the Elms) and Jim Dale (Threepenny Opera) will star in the Roundabout Theater Companys production of Athol Fugards play The Road to Mecca, the theater announced Tuesday. Gordon Edelstein is directing the production, which will begin previews on Dec. 16 and open on Jan. 17, 2012, on Broadway at the American Airlines Theater.

title: Publishing Gives Hints of Revival, Data Show
description: The publishing industry has expanded in the past three years as Americans increasingly turned to e-books and juvenile and adult fiction, according to a new survey of thousands of publishers, retailers and distributors that challenges the doom and gloom that tends to dominate discussions of the industrys health.

title: Word of the Day | demur
description: demur \di-mr\ verb

title: Bachmann Cover Controversy Prompts Response From Newsweek
description: Splashed across the cover of this weeks Newsweek magazine is a picture of the Republican presidential candidate and Tea Party favorite Representative Michele Bachmann. Her eyes are open wide  very, very wide  focused intensely somewhere off in the distance, just a smidge too high above the camera. At the bottom of the page, floating across her torso in bold white letters, are the words The Queen of Rage.

title: Corrections: August 9
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Giants James Brewer Is Injured
description: Another practice, another injury to a Giants rookie.

title: What Happened to My Bahrain Friend
description: I wrote recently about an old friend, Hasan al-Sahaf, a Bahraini artist who had been imprisoned nominally for economic offenses, but in reality for standing up to the regime. My column was an appeal to King Hamad to release him, and recently Hasan was indeed released. He telephoned with the good news, and I invited him to write a post on my blog about what happened. He courageously agreed, and heres what he wrote:

title: NYT Front Page for 08/09/11
description: NYT Front Page for 08/09/11

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 9, 2011
description: Todays question was written by Susan Behrens, who is a professor at Marymount Manhattan College and the author of Grammar: A Pocket Guide. Her question comes from the article Ruling Upholds Gene Patent in Cancer Test.

title: News Quiz | August 9, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Aug. 9, 1945 | U.S. Drops Atomic Bomb on Nagasaki, Japan
description: On Aug. 9, 1945, three days after the bombing of Hiroshima, the United States dropped a second atomic bomb on the city of Nagasaki.

title: Cameron Deploys 10,000 More Officers to Riots
description: LONDON  With 10,000 additional police officers deployed across London on Tuesday night, looting and arson dipped sharply from the anarchic scenes that shook Britain over the previous three days, even as violence ticked up again in several other major cities, including Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool.

title: The Top Ten Reasons to Keep Going to Citi Field
description: Thanks to injuries and trades over the last 10 days, the Mets have gone from likable overachievers with some plucky young players on the fringe of the wild-card race to an undermanned bunch trying to keep Citi Field awake over the next two months (they did so Monday night, rallying to beat the Padres 9-8 in the ninth inning). Still, its summer and its baseball, so The Times asked online readers to act like Late Show writers and help us put together this list, and these were our favorites:

title: Freezing the Fluid Emotions of Dance
description: Some feelings and even some thoughts are too deep for words and have to be seen to be believed.

title: The Atlanta Testing Scandal
description: HOW many teachers and principals in Atlanta have admitted to tampering with standardized tests to raise students scores?

title: Does Your School Value Students Digital Skills?
description: Do you think your school is preparing students for a world that doesnt exist by ignoring the digital skills you and your peers already have in favor of asking you to do tasks more suited to the early 20th century? For instance, do you think you should be asked to create videos, write blog posts and contribute to Wikis at least as often as youre asked to write research papers? Why or why not?

title: Tokyo Electric Posts $7.4 Billion Loss
description: TOKYO  The operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, Tokyo Electric Power, said Tuesday that it lost 572 billion yen in the latest quarter, largely because of costs related to the cleanup after the nuclear disaster and the compensation of victims.

title: Five European Teams to Keep an Eye On
description: Manchester United won the Community Shield on Sunday, but its always winning something. Heres a look at five European clubs who may be in position to succeed, or surprise, this season.

title: Has Sculpture Become Just Another Pretty Face?
description: We seem to prefer the multicolored distractions of illusionism on flat surfaces, whether filmed, digital or painted on canvas, to traditional European examples of sculpture.

title: An Experiment in Austerity
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

title: Famed Berlin Club Now Hosts Restaurant
description: Berghain, the famed Berlin techno club, is housed in a cavernous former power station. Inside, youll find strobe lights, dark rooms, international D.J.s, and people in line for the bathroom who will tell you, if you ask, that they havent left the club in days. Outside, right next to what was the power stations pressure boiler, youll now find a European bistro-style restaurant.

title: 2011 Giants Season Preview
description: Thus far, the story of the 2011 Giants has centered on Osi Umenyiora. He is looking for the new contract he says General Manager Jerry Reese had promised him. Umenyiora accused Reese of lying in a sworn affidavit during the lockout. After the lockout, he surprisingly showed up to training camp, with the Giants having given him permission to seek a trade. The first-round price tag, however, was too steep for the rest of the league.

title: Fantasy Focus: Setup Men to Pursue
description: The July nonwaiver trade deadline brought little movement on the closer front, as rumored-to-be-available guys like Leo Nunez, Andrew Bailey, Drew Storen and, most surprisingly, Heath Bell all stayed put. Owners who had stashed their probable replacements were left disappointed, but that doesnt mean we wont see current setup men become closers this season. Some almost certainly will.

title: The Early Word: Blame Game
description: Todays Times

title: Circus to Take Over Prague Park
description: In a couple of weeks, a group of people with tents will move into a Prague park for two weeks, setting up their homes and offices. These people, though, are specialists in entertainment: From Aug. 21 to Sept. 9, Letni Letna, an annual festival of new circus and movement theater, ensconces itself in a corner of Letna Park.

title: A Prepaid Phone So Fancy, Only Your Phone Company Will Know
description: Prepaid phones still suffer from an image problem. They are thought of as being cheap, unsophisticated and for people who cant afford a contract plan.

title: Well Show You Ours if You Show Us Yours
description: On the occasion of Charles McGraths profile of the novelist Nicholson Baker, we thought it would be fun to round up the favorite dirty books of some of our most illustrious literary critics at The Times. Below, their spicy replies.

title: Viddy: Like Instagram, but for Videos
description: Most of the worlds video is now shot on smartphones, but hardly anyone shares their videos widely. Thats partly because it takes too many steps and results in too many error messages, but also because many people arent convinced their hand-shot clips are worthy of the Internet.

title: Is God a Marketing Strategy?
description: Recently while searching online for a new refrigerator, I came across a Web site for a local appliance store that featured the Ichthus, or Christian fish symbol, in its logo. The personal side of me that grew up watching Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker tearfully separating people from their money on Sunday television hesitated. The marketer side of me wondered if companies that invoke religious symbols are simply sharing their values  or trading on the intrinsic values of the brand that is the Bible? Lots of businesses align themselves with religion (without going through any kind of certification process from a higher authority).

title: From Koch, a Childs Tale of Health and Self-Acceptance
description: As mayor, Edward I. Koch would often deflect insults by insisting that he was not, among other things, a wacko, a dope or a punching bag. But he now admits that the taunt that stung most was inflicted well before he acquired a politicians thick skin.

title: HSBC in Talks to Sell Credit Card Portfolio
description: HSBC Holdings said on Tuesday that it was in talks over the sale of its credit card business in the United States.

title: Grim Headlines Hang Over Iowa Campaigning
description: AMES, Iowa  The Republican straw poll here is usually anything but a somber event.

title: Morning Optimism
description: The great sell-off may be taking pause.

title: Q&A: Skype Videochats With a Group
description: Q.

title: Researching Safer Nuclear Energy
description: The nuclear power industry faces hard times, with tough competition from natural gas for meeting new electricity needs and a prevailing nervousness about nuclear safety after the Fukushima Daiichi accident in March. On Tuesday, the Energy Department, handing out research grants in all kinds of energy fields that are low in carbon dioxide emissions, is announcing that it will give $39 million to university programs around the country to try to solve various nuclear problems.

title: Tim Pawlenty in Johnston, Iowa
description: Governor Pawlenty speaks on the challenges facing the United States at a coffee shop in Johnston, Iowa on Monday.

title: Ralcorp to Buy a Sara Lee Unit for $545 Million
description: Sara Lee and Ralcorp are both food companies that have been busy trying to remake themselves this year. On Tuesday, they reached a deal toward that mutual end.

title: Michele Bachmann in Des Moines
description: The Minnesota Congresswoman prays for military families at the end of a rally in Des Moines on Sunday.

title: The Benefits of Exercise After Cancer
description: Many people who have had cancer may be inclined to rest and take it easy after treatment, but a new report by a leading British cancer charity is strongly urging some patients to increase, not reduce, their levels of physical activity.

title: Vain Glorious | Create Your Own Spa Night at Moomah
description: Moomah, the downtown arts and crafts spot and cafe, has firmly established itself as the chic and relaxed place to go with a tot. (We love the coffee, Balthazar croissants and even the thoughtfully edited wine list). Many customers dont even have kids  no, really. Now Moomah is introducing its own spa nights.

title: Thinking Cap: Preventing Groupthink
description: Irving Janis Groupthink and the Sanhedrin of Ancient Israel by Eliezer Schnall, a psychologist at Yeshiva University, and his student, Michael Greenberg. Presented at the American Psychological Associations Annual Convention in Washington on Aug. 7.

title: Apollos 2nd-Quarter Profit Jumps
description: Apollo Global Management said on Tuesday that its second-quarter profit more than quintupled, as all its businesses showed marked improvement.

title: Criticized Philippine Art Exhibit Is Closed
description: MANILA  Officials shut down a controversial art exhibition on Tuesday after a storm of public protest that included criticism from President Benigno S. Aquino III, who called the artwork offensive to the countrys Christian majority.

title: Global Sell-Off Eases; U.S. Futures Slightly Up
description: After stocks in Asia continued a sell-off, European stocks rallied before turning mixed. Futures on United States stocks indicated they would rise when trading begins.

title: Goldman Gives Details on Lackluster Quarter
description: Goldman Sachs lost money on 15 days in the second quarter, one of the worst trading performances the bank has posted in some time, according to a regulatory filing released on Tuesday.

title: Morning Buzz
description: For more local news from The Times, including a legal debate about Rosie, New Yorks first therapeutic courtroom dog, the growing use of video performances for young people to audition for Broadway roles and new rules and a one-year jail sentence for a former police officer, see the N.Y./Region section.

title: Updates on Financial Market Upheaval
description: The Lede tracked the global financial markets on Tuesday.

title: Fall Fashion Preview | Digital Media
description: Text or tweet in gloves that mix the lush textures of leather, pony, hair, wool and cashmere.

title: Black-and-White Struggle With a Rosy Glow
description: THIS year I took Highway 80 from Montgomery to Selma, Ala., reversing the journey of activists in three separate civil rights marches in March 1965. My destination was the Edmund Pettus Bridge and the National Voting Rights Museum at its base. The infamous Bloody Sunday protest, March 7, 1965, in which several hundred marchers were beaten by state troopers at the bridge is commemorated at the museum, a long one-story building dedicated to the foot soldiers of the movement, the husbands and wives, schoolkids and churchgoers who overcame their fear to dramatize their desire for the unimpeded right to vote.

title: Times Books to Publish Account of British Hacking Scandal
description: Times Books will publish the definitive account of the hacking scandal swirling around Rupert Murdoch and News International, the publisher said on Tuesday, written by Sarah Lyall and Don Van Natta Jr., longtime reporters for The New York Times.

title: The Risks in Jarring a Complex System
description: Paul Fisher, a Dot Earth reader from New Jersey who recently expressed cogent concerns here about dealing with the risks in a complex engineered system  nuclear power plants  has offered similar observations about a complex biogeophysical system in a comment on my post on Arctic climate change, past and future.

title: Tuesday Reading: Tummy Tucks and Face-Lifts in Your Golden Years
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Critics Picks Video: MASH
description: Does America have a fascination with rebels? This week A. O. Scott looks into this idea by discussing Robert Altmans 1970 film MASH, about a group of Army doctors near the front lines during the Korean War. Mr. Scott sees the film as a celebration, and perhaps a send-up, of the anti-authoritarian and sometimes antisocial tendencies of a certain type of American male.

title: Increased Scrutiny of Immigrants Returning to Mexico
description: U.S. Immigration agents have increased checks on immigrants trying to return to Mexico.

title: Republicans Hold On to Wisconsin Senate After Recall Vote
description: SAYNER, Wis.  Two Republican state senators lost their seats in recall elections around Wisconsin on Tuesday, but Republicans maintained their control of the State Senate, ultimately handing a defeat to union groups and Democrats who had spent months and millions of dollars trying to wrestle away at least some of the states political power.

title: Face Time | Katrina Bowden
description: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

title: Mixing Drinks on Your Lap With No Spills
description: Now subway riders can use their iPads not just to catch up on the latest best seller, but to prepare for the cocktail hour that awaits them at home.

title: Financial Stocks Hold On
description: 3:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Man Quizzed in Groping Attacks on Upper East Side
description: Updated, 3:19 p.m. | This post has been updated with an interview with the mans employer.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: What to Tell About an Absent Father
description: There are countless ways to create a family now: many planned, others less so. A reader, Kate, finds herself in one of the unexpected configurations, and is looking for advice. She writes:

title: Southbound Border Checks
description: Marc Lacey looks at how new federal guidelines are snaring many illegal immigrants trying to go back home to Mexico.

title: London Riots Widen
description: Riots spread to more affluent neighborhoods and outside London.

title: Mexico-Bound Immigrants Face Scrutiny at Border
description: NOGALES, Ariz.  An American immigration agent bounded up the steps of a bus about to cross the United States-Mexico border recently and demanded to see the papers of all those aboard. Papers! he shouted, eyeing passengers warily as he walked up and down the aisle.

title: Long-Term Investors Can Relax (a Little)
description: The short-term fluctuations in the stock market obviously can be maddening to anyone with more than a few pennies invested. In the time that Ive been working on this article, futures prices on the Dow Jones Industrial Average have fluctuated greatly, showing everything from a 300-point loss to a 300-point gain to open Tuesday. The next few days and weeks, and possibly also the next couple months and years, are liable to be turbulent.

title: Student-Athlete Equation Could Be a Win-Win
description: Joseph Agnew was once a Friday night superstar. A defensive back, he led his Texas high school football team to consecutive state titles in 2004 and 2005. He was also an A student.

title: Fiscal Forecasting at S.&P.
description: In cutting the rating of the United States government, Standard & Poors complained that the predictability of American government actions is not what it used to be.

title: International Paper Extends Temple-Inland Bid
description: International Paper said on Tuesday that it was extending its $3.3 billion hostile offer for Temple-Inland by a month, as it seeks control of the corrugated packaging maker.

title: Ex-Youngstown Mayor Tackles the Work of Revitalizing Automotive Communities
description: Two years ago, when President Obama ordered the establishment of the Office of Recovery for Auto Communities and Workers, the nations automotive industry, like much of the economy, seemed headed into the nadir. General Motors and Chrysler were broke, new-vehicle sales had tanked and the prospect of hiring was improbable.

title: An App Puts the Twin Towers Back in Sight
description: Brian August stood on the roof of a building on the Greenpoint, Brooklyn, waterfront on Thursday, facing Manhattan and squinting at his iPhone in the sun. As he swept the phone from south to north, the skyline across the East River showed up on its screen, with one difference. The whitish outline of two boxy skyscrapers rose from the spot where, until Sept. 11, 2001, the World Trade Center stood. The buildings towered above everything else in Manhattan, including the Freedom Tower directly to their north. One tower obscured the other slightly, and an antenna pushed far into the sky.

title: LearnVest: A Money-Management Site for Women
description: Alexa von Tobel wants to change the way women handle their money.

title: Turkish Minister and Other Envoys Press Syrian Leader
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria rebuffed an appeal from Turkey on Tuesday to end the Syrian crackdown that has emerged as one of the bloodiest chapters in the Arab uprising and has plunged his country into its deepest isolation in years.

title: Magazine Sales Slipped at the Newsstand
description: Circulation trends for weekly magazines were largely flat over the last six months, with a few notable exceptions among the biggest brands in a business that has undergone considerable restructuring and downsizing in recent years.

title: Yak Butter Tea and Tibetan Culture
description: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

title: My House, Our Home
description: Faced with the usual options for senior housing and elder care, some older adults are inventing their own grassroots versions  do-it-yourself senior living thats friendlier, more autonomous and less expensive. In the coming weeks, fellows in the News21 program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism will offer video reports on four of these: a shared housing arrangement in White Plains, a senior co-housing development in Virginia, an urban village in Chicago and an R.V. community in East Texas.

title: Sewage Routinely Taints Hudson, Study Shows
description: Sewage routinely contaminates the Hudson River throughout the year, rendering the waterway unsuitable for swimming and other recreational activities for at least one and a half days a week,  a report based on four years of water testing shows.

title: Cuba-to-Florida Quest Defeats Swimmer at 61
description: MIAMI  Three miles off Havana on Sunday evening, the Florida Straits were still glasslike when the 61-year-old marathon swimmer Diana Nyad felt her right shoulder seize up with pain. But she kept swimming.

title: London Riots Widen
description: Continued rioting in England moved to more affluent neighborhoods and outside of London.

title: News Corp.s Independent Directors Have Strong Ties to Murdoch
description: When the News Corporation board convenes on the 20th Century Fox Studios lot Tuesday for its first meeting since a phone hacking scandal overseas plunged the company into turmoil, the participants will include many people with deep and personal ties to Rupert Murdoch.

title: Q&A: A Side Trip to China From Hanoi?
description: My husband and I will be in Hanoi this fall, and were wondering if its feasible to make a side trip to China. Well have about five days (maybe a week), and we wonder if you could suggest someplace to visit, preferably in southern China. We enjoy train travel but would consider flying somewhere from Hanoi. We like outdoor activities (hiking, biking, boating) but wouldnt mind a visit to a small city.

title: Reviewing Uncle Zhou
description: A look inside the restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, serving the cuisine of Henan province.

title: Another Breakthrough for Oscar Pistorius
description: Several weeks ago, Eric Wilson wrote an article for Thursday Styles about the budding fashion career of Oscar Pistorius, the South African athlete who has become a world-class competitive runner despite being a double amputee. (He runs on J-shaped prosthetics made of black carbon fiber and has been dubbed the Blade Runner.) Mr. Pistorius, shown shirtless and running at full speed, has started appearing in ads for a new fragrance from Thierry Mugler. Now, Juliet Macur reports in todays Sports section of The Times that Mr. Pistorius has achieved another milestone in his athletic career: He has been named to South Africas team for the track and field world championships, which will make him the first amputee to compete at the event. Ms. Macur reports that he will race in the 400 meters and 4 x 400 relay.

title: July Was the Fourth-Warmest on Record
description: Results are in from the first stage of this summers heat wave, and its one for the record books. July was the fourth-warmest on record in the United States, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reports.

title: Train Derailment Outside Penn Station Snarls Service
description: Update, 2:45 p.m. | Tuesday mornings derailment just outside Penn Station is expected to cause delays on New Jersey Transit, Long Island Rail Road and Amtrak through the evening rush.

title: The Caucus Click: Hook Em Horns?
Adventureland
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#623", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Weak Stocks, Weak Economy?
description: Amidst the sell-off on Monday and the calmer waters this morning, heres a thought from Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at the High Frequency Economics research firm: a weak stock market is not always a sign of a weak economy.

title: Ten Years Later, The Guys Will Return to Commemorate 9/11
description: The Guys, one of the first dramatic responses to 9/11, will return for a series of performances to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks. Sigourney Weaver and Tom Wopat will star in the play, by Anne Nelson, which the Flea Theater will bring back to Lower Manhattan from Sept. 6 to 9.

title: Riots in London and Paris: Plus a Change?
description: Seen from Paris, the images of charred cars and the silhouettes of urban young people battling with police in London called to mind the 2005 riots in France.

title: The Fed to the Rescue?
description: Joe Gagnon has a widely-discussed proposal for dramatic Fed action. Im for it  not because we know it would work, but because it might, and we desperately need to do something.

title: Ppd., Real World Events
description: The sports news and chatter offer a classic choice today, a case of pure diversion versus its place in the real world. There isnt anything right or wrong about which way your attention leans, but it might tell you something about your sports DNA. Its sort of like your movie DNA, which either pushes you to gripping, real-life dramas or to Cowboys and Aliens.

title: Six Questions for Brian Moynihan
description: Bank of Americas chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, who has been under fire for his banks dismal performance, has agreed to field questions from investors on Wednesday.

title: Record Labels Hit Hard as Fire Set by London Rioters Destroys Warehouse
description: Independent music labels were hit hard after rioters in London set fire to a 215,000-square-foot warehouse owned by the Sony Corporation on Monday night, destroying vast amounts of compact discs, vinyl albums and other stock, Reuters and the BBC reported.

title: Table 1 at Elaines Is Available. Art Is for Sale, Too.

title: The Self-Justification Trap
description: Brad DeLong has an upsetting post about thinking within the Obama administration. I dont know if its right, but it feels right. As Brad tells it,

title: An Early Surge in an Injury the N.F.L. Wasnt Expecting
description: When the N.F.L. lockout ended last month and players streamed into training camps on short notice after no supervised off-season workouts, many expected a series of nagging hamstring strains and quadriceps pulls to result, the normal early-season indicators of overexertion and uneven fitness.

title: The Pawlenty Mystery
description: Matt Yglesias listens to Tim Pawlenty so the rest of us dont have to.

title: Response From the Mother of a Son With Demons
description: I received the following from Anon in the Midwest, who wrote so wrenchingly of her young sons struggle with mental illness earlier this week. Motherlode readers responded with wisdom and compassion, and a lot of good advice. You also had many questions, and Anon has sent the following, which includes answers to many of those, along with her thanks.

title: A Dramatic Entrance: Kelli OHara to Play Regan in King Lear
description: Kelli OHara, best known for sunny roles in musicals like South Pacific and The Pajama Game, is taking on Shakespeare  and a not-so-sunny role at that. Ms. OHara, a three-time Tony nominee, will play the betraying daughter Regan in a new production of King Lear at the Public Theater, with Sam Waterston (Law and Order) in the title role.

title: Taking the Bait: Permits, Reservations, Drinking on the Job
description: Time to take stock. As always, many of the comments are more entertaining and insightful than the posts. Herein, we respond to the responders of the last month on scuffling for permits, canceling reservations, and drinking on the job.

title: Live Nation Bounces Back With Strong Earnings
description: Live Nation Entertainment, the music and ticketing giant that includes Ticketmaster, reported strong results for its second quarter on Monday, with profits up on increased ticket sales and concert attendance.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Opens Investigations of 40,000 Volkswagen Jettas and 120,000 BMW 7 Series Models
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened investigations into possible diesel fuel leaks on about 40,000 Volkswagen Jetta TDIs and reports of rollaways on 120,000 BMW 7 Series sedans because the automatic transmission may not secure the vehicle in Park.

title: F1 Films on Your Holidays
description: Formula One news is scarce as the series is in the middle of its annual summer vacation, with four weeks between races to give the traveling teams a brief break. That means a break for fans too, of course, but the biggest fans, like the team members, never turn off. And this summer is a great time for the fans to look at Formula One in from different perspective.

title: F1 Films on Your Holidays
description: Formula One news is scarce as the series is in the middle of its annual summer vacation, with four weeks between races to give the traveling teams a brief break. That means a break for fans too, of course, but the biggest fans, like the team members, never turn off. And this summer is a great time for the fans to look at Formula One in from different perspective.

title: Elaines Table No. 1 and Artwork Will Be Auctioned
description: As City Room reports, table No. 1 from Elaines, the Upper East Side restaurant that closed in May, will be auctioned on Sept. 20, along with the posters and artwork that lined the restaurant and books and memorabilia from the nearby apartment of its longtime owner, Elaine Kaufman, who died last year.

title: Lens: Dance Photography From the 20s Through the 90s
description: Some feelings and even some thoughts are too deep for words and have to be seen to be believed.

title: On Selling Poison
description: Michele Simon has written a comprehensive and interesting piece about the law and salmonella. Im going to do my best to post the salient points here for those who would like some kind of summary. (Apologies to Michele for oversimplifying but I think its important that people see at least this much.)

title: Syfy, in Reversal, Pulls Plug on Eureka
description: Reversing what it had said just last week, Syfy now says it has canceled Eureka, a playful science-fiction series that the channel has broadcast since 2006.

title: Obama Visits Dover to Honor Troops Killed in Crash
description: President Obama traveled to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware on Tuesday to pay his respects to the 30 American servicemen killed in a helicopter crash in eastern Afghanistan over the weekend.

description: BERLIN  Sometimes on a whim I stop into the Bode Museum here to commune with a tiny clay sculpture of John the Baptist.

description: Jessica Rinaldi/ReutersJeffrey Gundlach is in a legal fight with his former employer, TCW.

title: Memoir by Obamas Half-Sister to Be Published in U.S.
description: A memoir by Auma Obama, a half-sister of President Obama, will be published in the United States in May, St. Martins Press said on Tuesday. The book was released in Germany last fall with a title that translates as Life Always Gets in the Way or Life Happens.

title: Heavy Trucks to Be Subject to New Rules for Mileage
description: WASHINGTON  Big tractor-trailer trucks will have to get 20 percent more miles per gallon by the 2018 model year under the first-ever fuel economy rules for heavy vehicles, announced Tuesday by President Obama.

title: Good Behavior? Iraqis React to Release of Ringleader of Abu Ghraib Abuse
description: BAGHDAD  Seven years have passed since it was revealed that detainees at Abu Ghraib prison were abused by American soldiers.

title: Perry to Visit Iowa for Sunday Speech
description: DES MOINES  The specter of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has been hanging over Iowa for weeks, but on Sunday afternoon he will pay his first visit to the state with a speech in Waterloo.

description: A knitwear designer gets discovered. A post from our upcoming Fall Womens issue.

title: Wire Actress, Caught on Wiretap, Pleads Guilty to Heroin Charge
description: What is that saying about truth being stranger than fiction? An actress who played a killer for a Baltimore drug gang in the HBO series The Wire pleaded guilty Monday to conspiring to distribute heroin. She was caught on a wiretap in a joint federal-state investigation of a suspected drug gang, The Associated Press reported.

title: U.S. and North Korea May Discuss Recovering Remains of Americans
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States has proposed to meet with North Korea to discuss for the first time in six years bringing home the remains of any American soldiers buried there.

title: London Police Use Flickr to Identify Looters
description: As rioting continues to roil the streets of London, local police forces are turning to the Web to help unmask those involved in the torching and looting.

title: Its Forecast Dim, Fed Vows to Keep Rates Near Zero
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve made a rare promise on Tuesday to hold short-term interest rates near zero through at least the middle of 2013, in a sign that it has all but written off the chances of an expansion strong enough to drive up wages and prices.

title: Apple Is the Most Valuable Company
description: 4:02 p.m. | Updated At the end of regular trading Tuesday, Exxon was again the most valuable company. Apples market cap was $346.74 billion vs. Exxons $348.32 billion.

title: Nandan Nilekani, 56, Chairman of the Unique Identification Authority of India, talks about how Indians benefit from enrollment in the national identity database.
description: An interview with Nandan Nilekani

title: Home Again, Home Again
description: Its the return-from-travel trifecta: sleeping in your own bed, sharing pictures and stories from your trip and appreciating the wonderful place you call home.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 9
description: Temperatures in the mid-90s greeted P.G.A. Championship fans and golfers in Johns Creek, Ga., while rain, lots of it, greeted womens tennis fans in Toronto for the Rogers Cup.

title: Reviewing Boulud Sud
description: Daniel Bouluds latest opening on the Upper West Side.

title: Two Titans Share the Seat of Power
description: EVENTS in hip-hop feel smaller than they used to. This is the age of the regional hit, the no-budget viral video, the Twitter star. Hip-hop, so long the most vibrant force in pop music, could always be counted on for big spending, a boon to producers, directors, fashion stylists, car dealers and so on, to say nothing of the marketing specialists, brand synergists and secondary industries it fueled. But in recent years the center has been weakening, and the genre is readjusting to life built from the bottom up.

title: Dissident Chinese Artist Speaks Out Using Twitter
description: HONG KONG  Ai Weiwei, the Chinese artist and dissident, on Tuesday broke his silence on political topics for the first time since he was released from detention in China nearly two months ago, denouncing in Twitter postings the treatment of business colleagues who had been detained with him and expressing support for two other incarcerated dissidents.

title: Gavin DeGraw Attacked Outside His Club
description: 4:49 p.m. |Update: Details From Police

title: A Lineup for the New York Comedy Festival
description: Louis C.K., Tracy Morgan, Sarah Silverman, Ricky Gervais, Bill Maher, Wanda Sykes, Russell Peters, Kathy Griffin and Norm Macdonald are among the stars who will go straight for the funny bone around New York City during the eighth annual New York Comedy Festival from Nov. 9 to 13, festival officials will announce Wednesday.

title: Boulud Sud
description: TO the list of terrific Daniel Boulud restaurants in Manhattan, add thisLyonnais chefs first significant gesture toward the sea that laps at the South of France and Spain to its west, then stretches across to Africa and east to the Levant. Boulud Sud is the Manhattan equivalent of a private yacht anchored off Monaco, serving the food of Sardinia, Greece, Tunisia, Gibraltar, Beirut. And you are invited along.

title: Portugal Faces Challenges in Meeting Bailout Terms
description: LISBON  The smell of fresh paint wafted recently inside a mansion on the grounds of the So Bento Palace, the official residence of the Portuguese prime minister.

title: Bachelor Pad Rides Bachelorette Coattails
description: The three-hour season premiere of Bachelor Pad on ABC  where previous contestants from the Bachelor compete for a second chance at love and $250,000  averaged 6.9 million total viewers on Monday. It was enough to give ABC the most viewers for the night, but was a far cry from the audience numbers for the recently completed Bachelorette season, which frequently cracked the 8 million mark, according to an analysis of Nielsen ratings data by TV by the Numbers.

title: Central Bank Props Up Spain and Italy, for Now
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank has succeeded at least temporarily in pushing down the effective interest rates on Spanish and Italian government debt. But analysts say the bank must still convince investors that it has the stamina to withstand what could be a long struggle against market turmoil.

title: Swiss Near Tax Treaties With Germany and Britain
description: LONDON  Switzerland is close to signing sweeping tax treaties with Germany and Britain intended to ensure that assets belonging to citizens of those countries held in Swiss banks will no longer escape tax.

title: The Fed Splits
description: There is more than meets the eye to the split at the Federal Reserve. There must be.

title: After 7 Years, Wal-Mart Closes Its MP3 Store
description: 3:41 p.m. | Updated After more than seven years of selling digital music, Wal-Mart Stores will shut its MP3 store at the end of August, the company says.

title: Visa Wants U.S. Cards to Catch Up With the World

description: Photographs from London, Kenya, Libya and India.

title: DNA Profile of Ted Bundy Gives Hope to Old Cases
description: The serial killer Ted Bundy confessed to 30 murders before he was executed in Florida in 1989, but he hinted that the true body count was far higher.

title: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from London, Kenya, Libya and India.

title: What Digital Maps Can Tell Us About the American Way
description: Life, liberty and the pursuit of  mappiness? That is the humorous rubric for a new series of digital maps created by the Scholars Lab, an office and Web site run by the University of Virginia Library about developments in the digital humanities.

title: TimesCast | August 9, 2011
description: The Federal Reserve says it will hold interest rates; Britain deploys 10,000 more police officers as rioting widens; and Tim Pawlenty woos evangelical Christian voters in Iowa.

title: The Caucus | Tim Pawlenty Woos Iowans
description: Aug. 9, 2011 - Former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty looks for support from Evangelical Christians ahead of Saturday's straw poll in Iowa.

title: Reviewing Uncle Zhou
description: This is not your fathers Hunan restaurant. Uncle Zhou (pronounced Uncle Joe) features the cuisine of Henan, breadbasket of China, especially the provinces well-known wheat noodles. Knife-shaved noodles are brusquely cut from a lump of dough, boiled until wonderfully chewy, and deposited in cool bowls dressed with tomato and egg. Thin, hand-pulled noodles swirl at the bottom of spicy soups; their ribbonlike cousins are great for swabbing the plate. Other are stretched to the fineness of angel hair, baked, then deposited as a crisp thatch atop a whole fish, swimming in a pool of sweet-and-sour sauce. Noodles and fish soak up the sauce; you and your friends soak up the lively atmosphere.

title: Uncle Zhou
description: WHEN the summer air hangs on you like hot and sour soup, keep cool and listen to Uncle Zhou.

title: The Fed States the Obvious
description: OK, count me unimpressed by the Fed statement  although for some reason markets went wild.

title: The Maids Now Have Their Say
description: Theres a scene in The Help, the new movie based on Kathryn Stocketts novel, that cracks open the early-60s world of strained smiles and gentility that rarely leaps out of this big, ole slab of honey-glazed hokum. Its after hours, and Aibileen, a maid played with determined grace by Viola Davis, is going home. Suddenly the bus stops, and a white man orders the black passengers off, explaining that a black man has been shot  except that he doesnt say black, Negro or colored. In a pool of dreadful night, Aibileen and a young man trade goodbyes and rush off. And then this sturdy, frightened woman starts running as if her life were in danger, because its Mississippi, and it is.

title: Robert H. Lessin, Jefferies Vice Chairman, Dies at 56
description: Robert H. Lessin, a longtime Wall Street banker and technology angel investor, died on Monday evening. He was 56.

title: Mormonism and Mitt Romneys Weirdness
description: Thanks to the current spate of awful economic news, we pretty much know what kind of re-election campaign Barack Obama is going to wage: A relentlessly negative one, which, like George W. Bushs re-election campaign against John Kerry, will focus almost exclusively on making the challenger seem unacceptable rather than defending the sitting presidents accomplishments. Thanks to Ben Smith at Politico, we also know roughly how the White House plans to destroy Mitt Romney, if he turns out to be that challenger: By attacking him as inauthentic, unprincipled and, in a word used repeatedly by Obamas advisers in about a dozen interviews, weird.'

title: Good News From Europe
description: No, you didnt misread that. Amid all the turmoil here, its worth noting that so far the ECBs attempt to stop a self-fulfilling panic is going pretty well:

title: Klinsmann Era Dawns for U.S.
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the 35th coach in the history of the United States mens national team, will coach his first match with his new team Wednesday night against Mexico in Philadelphia.

title: Disney Profits Beat Wall Street Predictions
description: After two wild quarters  leaping in the first and missing big in the second  the Walt Disney Company returned to its calm and collected ways on Tuesday, reporting profit slightly above Wall Streets predictions.

title: Madmen In Authority
description: Just a reminder: back in the spring of last year conventional wisdom in Europe, although fortunately not at the Fed, was that it was time to start raising interest rates, with the OECD calling, I think, for 350 basis points by the end of 2010.

title: The Office, L.E.S. Style
description: The slyly prescientgang of techno-corporate fetishists behind the website DIS Magazine are spending their summer in meet space: a real-life office on the Lower East Side! DIS HQ is occupying Invisible-Exports gallery for the month of August with a multiplatform workspace installation created by the artist Lizzie Fitch in her signature Ikea vernacular. One of the gallerys walls has been repainted as a green screen for digital embellishments to the 24/7 surveillance the collective will stream to the Web. The office will also be open to corporeal visitors for performances, events and DISs day-to-day business, which includes casting sessions scouting for seniors to be made over as tweens, professional bodybuilders and pop-locking tribal belly dancers for the sites end of summer Poprally event at MoMA PS1.

title: Networks Step Up Coverage in Famine Zones
description: Television networks in the United States have stepped up their staffing in Somalia and Kenya in recent days amid what the United Nations calls a worsening humanitarian crisis there.

title: TimesCast | Riots Spread in Britain
description: August 9, 2011 - After looting and riots spread beyond London, Prime Minister David Cameron deployed 10,000 additional police officers to quell unrest.

title: Free Money!
description: Source.

title: Fighting Cleavage Wrinkles
description: BACK when Lisa Barr wore a size 34B bra, she didnt know from cleavage wrinkles. But soon after she got breast implants in 1999, augmenting her measurements to a 36C, she started waking up with thick lines on her chest where one breast had fallen against the other as she slept on her side.

title: On New Yorks Low Seas: Day 2
description: If the Statue of Liberty ferry passed right by Lady Liberty and took a five-minute detour farther to the west, the tourists  and even most seen-it-all New Yorkers  would get an eye-opening take on glamorous New York Harbors gritty, hard-working side.

title: Stock Advice for These Uncertain Times
description: It may be a good time to start investing in baseball-batmanufacturers. According to Amazon U.K.,  sales of bats have climbed wildly. Billy clubs jumped an amazing 48,621 percent in Amazons sales ranks, to No. 14 from No. 6,821, as British citizens began taking the law into their own hands.

title: TimesCast | Federal Reserve Holds Rates
description: The Federal Reserve announced interest rates will remain at "exceptionally low" levels for another two years.

title: When Two Thumbs Down Are a Sign of Approval
description: HAND gestures can be vulgar, but recently a demure, loving one has risen to popularity. To make it, curl the index fingers on both hands with the thumbs pointing down and join them to make a heart shape. Two people can make it together: a human version of those best-friends-forever lockets that break apart to be shared.

title: FRED Excels!
description: One of Issawis Laws, which I cant seem to find online, explained the laws of progress or lack thereof. First, the total amount of good and evil in any system remains constant. Second, most things get steadily worse. In particular, people get worse as they grow older, because they become more like themselves. The second proposition does not contradict the first, because some things get much better.

title: Fuel Economy: Its Not Just for Cars Anymore
description: The Obama administration issued fuel economy standards on Tuesday for medium and heavy trucks, the first time the government has regulated vehicles over 8,500 pounds.

title: Elaines Auction
description: Some of the items from Elaine Kaufmans estate that are up for auction.

title: Test Can Tell Fetal Sex at 7 Weeks, Study Says
description: A simple blood test that can determine a babys sex as early as seven weeks into pregnancy is highly accurate if used correctly, a finding that experts say is likely to lead to more widespread use by parents concerned about gender-linked diseases, those who are merely curious and people considering the more ethically controversial step of selecting the sex of their children.

title: Boy or Girl? A Home Test Can Tell You
description: Many parents find out they are having a baby by using a home pregnancy test. Now, home tests can reliably determine a babys sex as early as seven weeks into the pregnancy.

title: A Foreign Correspondent in Nazi Germany Who Interpreted It for the World
description: It is impossible to realize, Nora Ephron wrote in 1973, how much of Ernest Hemingway still lives in the hearts of men until you spend time with the professional war correspondents.

title: In Court, the Citys Fire Commissioner Defends Efforts to Diversify the Ranks
description: Under firm, if generally polite, examination, New York Citys fire commissioner defended his efforts to recruit minority candidates in court on Tuesday, saying the Fire Department has measurably increased its number of black applicants while rebuilding its ranks a decade after the losses from 9/11.

title: Trying to Live Forever
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: Rock Steady
description: As natural attractions go, Norways Pulpit Rock makes a jaw-dropping first impression on visitors.

title: A Group Determinedly Finding a Spot Right in the Middle of Things
description: In 2007 Claire Chase, an accomplished flutist and an ambitious, industrious organizer, spelled out her hopes for the International Contemporary Ensemble, which she founded in 2001 with a group of fellow graduates of the Oberlin Conservatory in Ohio.

title: Obama Forsakes Air Force One for Bus Tour
description: WASHINGTON  Who says presidents live the life of luxury?

title: G.M. Sees Cost Cuts Continuing for Years in Effort to Sustain Long-Term Growth
description: DETROIT  General Motors, already much leaner and more efficient after going through bankruptcy and a painful reorganization, still has to undertake years of sharp cost cuts to ensure it remains profitable, its executives said Tuesday.

title: Two Musicians at One With the Basics
description: Guitars and drum machines are very blunt instruments in the hands of the Kills, the two-member band that started a two-night stand at Terminal 5 on Monday night. Alison Mosshart, an American singer, and Jamie Hince, a British guitarist, write songs pared down to absolute basics: beat, riff and vocal.

title: Reading the Wisconsin Recall Vote
description: Wisconsin residents on Tuesday voted on whether to recall six Republican state senators, whose backing of Gov. Scott Walker in the dispute over collective bargaining rights this year made them targets for Democratic-aligned groups. Two Democratic state senators face a recall vote next Tuesday. (A third Democratic senator, Dave Hansen, easily survived a recall election on July 19.) Democrats will need to win three of the six Republican seats  without losing either of their own next week  to take control of the state senate.

title: Touring an Artists Pre-Apocalyptic Realm
description: The movie Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow is a portrait of the artist at work, though one that says as much about its British director, Sophie Fiennes, as about its stated subject, the German-born artist Anselm Kiefer. In 1993 Mr. Kiefer, perhaps the most celebrated and divisive artist of his generation  he was born in 1945 shortly before the end of World War II  moved to a swath of land outside Barjac, a town in the South of France. He and his assistants then began creating installations on the property that, at least to judge from this movie, are a monument to the human will to self-annihilation and a rehearsal for the apocalypse.

title: Coaches New Friends
description: Norm Roberts took only one season off after coaching mens basketball at St. Johns, but when he returned as an assistant at Florida in April, he entered a new era. Roberts could not believe how hard it had become to contact high school prospects by telephone.

title: Productivity Falls for 2nd Quarter in a Row
description: The productivity of workers dropped from April through June for the second consecutive quarter, leading to an increase in labor costs that may restrain gains in profits.

title: AOL Shares Fall on Report of Weak Gain in Ad Sales
description: Timothy M. Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, is trying to transform the onetime Internet service giant into an online media company, but the market seemed to lose patience Tuesday, driving the stock down by more than a quarter of its value, from $15.07 to close at $11.19.

title: Soil Samples and Peanut Butter
description: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

title: Boathouse Restaurant Workers Walk Off Job
description: A lunchtime walkout by workers at the Boathouse restaurant in Central Park on Tuesday caught managers and customers by surprise and forced the closing of the rowboat rental concession, which the restaurant runs.

title: G.O.P. Phone Campaign Blames Democrats for Downgrade
description: Republicans and Democrats moved quickly to blame each other publicly for causing the S&P downgrade of the nations credit, and Republicans are now taking to the phone lines.

title: Unarmed Officers on Londons Front Lines
description: Last Updated | Wednesday | 9:44 a.m. As British officials promised to end days of widespread riots with more robust policing, and 16,000 officers fanned out across London, American readers might be surprised to learn that most members of the force charged with ending the rioting remain unarmed.

title: Pass the Ketchup Could Bring Surprises
description: THE chef Jos Andrs says that its time for America to face a hard truth, one that all of Alice Waterss goat cheese salads and Thomas Kellers fried chicken cannot change.

title: Green Radicchio in the Markets
description: The small, tight heads of what look like lettuce at the Paffenroth Gardens stand in the Union Square Greenmarket, pale green and white with an occasional streak of burgundy, are radicchio wearing a warm-weather wardrobe. Radicchio needs cold to set the color, and the flavor also gets sharper and more bitter, said Alex Paffenroth, the owner. The radicchio, grown from Italian seeds, should last into the fall.

title: Portuguese Breads Sold at Alfama Restaurant
description: Unusual breads of Portugal are being sold at a kiosk at Alfama, the Portuguese restaurant that opened in Midtown in May, with Francisco Rosa, above, as its chef. Along with broa, made with cornmeal, there are po de forma, a white loaf baked in a mold; ethereal po de Deus buns with a coconut garnish; and small baguettes called po de bico (beaked bread) for their pointy ends. And do not leave without the tiny custard tarts, pastis de nata.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Name Your Treat

title: A Boat-to-Table Initiative Brings Fish to Chefs
description: GALILEE, R.I.

title: Soda With a Jolt of Ginger
description: Following on the success of his Q Tonic, which has more bite than most tonic waters, Jordan Silbert has introduced Q Ginger. Clean, sharp and yet subtle, it makes an excellent refresher or mixer. Real ginger juice is bolstered with coriander, cardamom and cayenne, and the restrained sweetness comes from organic agave syrup.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: The New and the Newer; Hold the Preconceptions
description: LENOX, Mass.  The musicians who run the Tanglewood Music Centers Festival of Contemporary Music tend to be less concerned with unifying themes, musical or extramusical, than with offering an overview of the composition worlds many competing styles.

title: Riots Spread on Social Media, as Does the Cleanup
description: After three nights of riots and looting in a handful of London neighborhoods, volunteers used Twitter and Facebook to help mobilize hundreds of people today to clean up the mess.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Settle Charge Over Drugs Marketing
description: Johnson & Johnson reached an agreement in principle to settle a misdemeanor criminal charge related to the marketing of its antipsychotic drug Risperdal, the company said in a regulatory filing on Tuesday.

title: Hazards of Borrowing Money From Hedge Funds
description: Harry Campbell

title: 3 Senators Named to Deficit Panel
description: Senator Patty Murray of Washington will be co-chairwoman of a powerful new Congressional committee that is supposed to recommend at least $1.5 trillion of additional deficit-reduction measures, the Senate majority leader announced Tuesday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons From the Financial Turmoil
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Solitary Confinement Inhumane? Or Indispensable?
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Catch Me If You Can to Close on Sept. 4
description: Based on a Steven Spielberg movie and reuniting much of the creative team that won eight Tonys for Hairspray, Catch Me If You Can came to Broadway with everything going for it  except, as it turned out, audiences. The musicals producers announced on Tuesday that it would close on Sept. 4, after 32 previews and 170 performances.

title: Game-Day Tests Not Disruptive, N.F.L. Says
description: Adolpho Birch, who oversees the N.F.L.s drug-testing program, said Tuesday that he was confident that game-day testing, which can take place before or after games, would not be disruptive to teams. That has long been a concern among players and coaches.

title: The Contrapuntal Sounds of Gridlock
description: A red-white-and-blue sign at the corner of West Broadway and Watts Street in SoHo reads, Dont Honk  $350 Penalty. It is, shall we say, not always heeded. This corner is a five-way crossing, where Broome Street forks into Watts, which leads to the Holland Tunnel, and crosses West Broadway, which has two-way traffic. The tunnel entrances themselves run smoothly, if slowly; traffic police officers are there. But the New Jersey exodus has to back up somewhere, and this corner is one of those places. Amid this gridlock is a whole lot of self-expression via car horns and the occasional, ah, verbal admonition.

title: London Riots Put Spotlight on Troubled, Unemployed Youths in Britain
description: LONDON  I came here to get my pennys worth, said a man who gave his name as Louis James, 19, a slightly built participant in the widening riots that have shaken London to its core. With a touch of guilt on Tuesday, Mr. James showed off what he described as a $195 designer sweater that he said he took during looting in Camden Town, a gentrified area of north London.

title: Rodriguez Nears Return
description: Alex Rodriguez could play in a minor league rehabilitation game as soon as this weekend, which increases the likelihood that he will return to the Yankees during next weeks seven-game trip that begins Monday in Kansas City, then moves to Minnesota.

title: Battle for Libya | Aug. 9, 2011
description: People sifted through the debris of a destroyed home that Libyan loyalists say was hit by a NATO bomb in the town of Majar, near Zlitan.

title: Project Runway, on 4 Legs
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  J. J. Crupi is the horseflesh man. Eddie Rosen is the pedigree guy. Dr. Randy Brandon is the veterinarian who makes sure that the horse whose looks Crupi is enamored with, with the regal bloodlines Rosen vouches for, is, indeed, a healthy yearling worth the hundreds of thousands that Mike Repole might spend on him.

title: Al Jazeera Changes Plan to Rerun Documentary
description: Al Jazeera English has quashed several planned rebroadcasts of Shouting in the Dark, an hourlong documentary about Bahrains crackdown on pro-democracy protesters that had its debut last week and brought complaints from Bahraini authorities.

title: In an Enclave of Small Firms, Big Developers Knock
description: When Nancy Aber Goshow opened her architecture firms offices on 25th Street between Broadway and Sixth Avenue about 25 years ago, walking to work from her apartment on 16th Street was a lonely and at times even harrowing experience. Vacant properties and parking lots, she recalled, gave much of the area a desolate quality despite its location near the heart of the city.

title: A Mass Grave, 70 Years Later
description: Khotyn, Ukraine

title: Unanimous Yes Vote on Los Angeles Stadium
description: The Los Angeles City Council on Tuesday unanimously approved a tentative agreement with a private developer to build a $1.2 billion football stadium, in hopes of attracting an N.F.L. team back to downtown.

title: The Revenge of the Rating Agencies
description: Washington

title: In Siding With Leaders, Freshman Found a Voice
description: WASHINGTON  From her spot on a podium at a recent news conference on Capitol Hill, Representative Renee Ellmers, Republican of North Carolina, looked slightly nervous.

title: Redefining the Hot Dog, a Cart at a Time
description: GET this: There are children in New York who have never eaten a hot dog.

title: How Do You Want That Hot Dog?
description: To say that I grew up eating those dirty-water dogs on the street is an understatement, Alexandra Guarnaschelli told me when we got to talking about New York hot dogs for this weeks Dining article. I have a very important memory of my father picking me up from school every day, and we would walk to the corner and we would eat a hot dog together.

title: Charges Against Ugandan Opposition Leader Are Dropped
description: A Ugandan court has dropped charges against an opposition politician, Kizza Besigye, who organized and led street protests against the government in the spring.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,685 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: California: Los Angeles Stadium Plan Is Approved
description: The Los Angeles City Council on Tuesday unanimously approved a tentative agreement with a private developer to build a $1.2 billion football stadium, in hopes of attracting an N.F.L. team back to downtown. The terms of the agreement with the developer, Anschutz Entertainment Group, allow for the demolition and relocation of part of the Los Angeles Convention Center to make room for the 72,000-seat stadium, which could open as soon as 2016. The citys approval of the downtown stadium plan is a blow to a competing plan to build a N.F.L. stadium in the nearby City of Industry. Anschutz Entertainment Group has promised to finance the stadium and two parking lots without any cost to Los Angeles taxpayers. Over the next nine months, the City Council will negotiate terms and then vote on final approval.

title: Returning Ground Zero to New Yorkers
description: If you have not laid eyes on the World Trade Center site for a while, the view now is nothing short of astonishing. It looks like a space for human beings. Much of the plaza has been set up; swamp oaks have been planted; fountains are running inside the two giant squares that were the footprints of the towers destroyed 10 years ago; the names of the dead are inscribed along the borders of the squares.

title: London Rioting Prompts Fears Over Soccer and Olympics
description: Fearing for the safety of players and fans amid the rioting in London, soccer officials on Tuesday canceled two international matches and may postpone the opening weekend of the English Premier League, prompting questions about the citys ability to secure high-profile events like soccer matches and next summers Olympics.

title: New York on a Bun
description: The citys hot dogs through the years, both the classic specimens and more newfangled inventions with fussier toppings and upgraded meat.

title: In Tumult, New Hope for Palestinian Cause
