description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila, a corner of Beirut bearing the scars of massacres and an enduring despair, the words of a young barber hinted at an emerging optimism about what the Arab revolts could mean for a central issue of the last half century in the Middle East: the fate of Palestinians.

title: A Caddie Speaks Out, and Some Players Say Hes Speaking Out of Turn
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.

title: A Debate on Death Spirals and Arctic Resilience
description: Joe Romm haspredictably assailed my rejection of his death spiral depiction of Arctic sea ice trends, straying into discussions of melting permafrost (which is an entirely different issueladen with its own questions  one being why the last big retreat of permafrost, in the Holocenes warmest stretch,didnt have a greenhouse-gas impact) and my refusal to proclaim a magically safe level of carbon dioxide (which I discuss here).

title: Hardball Played as a Slow-Pitch Game
description: Baseballs rule book says pitchers can take no more than 12 seconds between pitches with the bases empty.

title: Half-Measures From the Fed
description: It came as no surprise on Tuesday when the Federal Reserve said that the economy was in a more precarious state than it had previously believed. It was refreshing that the Fed stopped blaming transitory factors like supply-chain disruptions from Japan and acknowledged, in effect, that this years rising joblessness and slowing growth are more than temporary setbacks.

title: New York City Will Mandate Sex Education
description: For the first time in nearly two decades, students in New York Citys public middle and high schools will be required to take sex-education classes beginning this school year, using a curriculum that includes lessons on how to use a condom and the appropriate age for sexual activity.

title: Serving Shareholders and Democracy
description: When the Supreme Court ruled that the government may not ban campaign spending by corporations in the landmark Citizens United decision last year, it argued that disclosure of contributions would protect American democracy from hidden corporate agendas.

title: Timely Help for the Port Authority
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York have both expressed concern about the Port Authority of New York and New Jerseys proposed 50 percent increase in bridge and tunnel tolls  from $8 to $12 as soon as next month, with another $2 jump in three years. Mr. Cuomo called the increase a nonstarter but promised to study it. Mr. Christie said his first reaction was: Youre kidding, right?

title: Apple May Be Underpriced
description: Could Apple be worth $1 trillion? Its conceivable. The $347 billion maker of iPhones and iPads became  if only briefly  the most valuable company in the United States when it overtook Exxon Mobil on Tuesday. Yet Apples sales have been surging 80 percent a year, and its profit faster. Whats more, it trades roughly in line with the growing stock market  and at less than half the price-to-earnings multiple it fetched in 2006, when revenue growth was much slower.

title: No Plans for 2013, but an Actor Seems Focused on the Mayors Office
description: Alec Baldwin is not running for mayor of New York  yet.

title: Keseys Trip, in Living Color
description: Ken Keseys cross-country bus trip with the Merry Pranksters in 1964 was supposed to be a movie. The worlds first acid film, as Tom Wolfe explained, taken under conditions of total spontaneity barreling through the heartlands of America, recording all now, in the moment. Thats why the bus was packed not just with LSD, speed and grass, but also speakers, mikes and wires.

title: Cuomo Weighs Ending State Limits on Casino Gambling
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, suggesting it was time for the state to come to grips with the proliferation of gambling in New York and neighboring states, said Tuesday that he was weighing the legalization of commercial, non-Indian casinos in New York State.

title: These Arent the Angels You Remember
description: The Philadelphia Phillies traded Bobby Abreu in 2006, and soon they won a championship. Then the Yankees let Abreu go, and they won, too. Fifteen years in the majors, a glittering rsum, and no World Series to show for it.

title: The Day Our Leaders Got Unstuck
description: This is a scary economic moment. The response we need is not easy, but it is totally obvious. We need a Grand Bargain between Americas two parties  and we need it right now. Until you read the following news article, well be stuck in a world of hurt.

title: Pagan Looks for Better Results From Leadoff Spot
description: The loss of Jose Reyes, who was put on the disabled list this week with a strained left hamstring, is particularly painful for the Mets because they lack a natural replacement for him in the leadoff spot.

title: Unusual Summer of Political Calm Is Enjoyed by a Disputed Region
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  By this time last summer, this beleaguered city was a war zone. Dozens of people had been killed in clashes between stone-throwing protesters and heavily armed security forces. Each death prompted a fresh set of angry demonstrations that prompted even tougher crackdowns, leading to more bloodshed.

title: 10 Years and a Diagnosis Later, 9/11 Demons Haunt Thousands
description: In the safety of her therapists office in late 2001, Dr. Margaret Dessau made a tape reliving what it was like to look out her living room window after she heard the boom of a hijacked plane eight blocks away.

title: We Bled in the Corn
description: Writing about the Battle of Wilsons Creek, the Civil Wars second major battle, from the perspective of a common foot soldier, Herman Melville described the conflict this way: We fought on the grass, we bled in the corn.

title: Briefly, Apple Reigns as the Most Valuable Company
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For several hours on Tuesday, Apple surpassed Exxon Mobil, the energy company, as the stock markets most valuable company.

title: Hunt Ends for Groping Suspect, but 12 Lineups Must Follow
description: Hours after detectives had tracked down a suspect on Tuesday in a string of sexual attacks on the Upper East Side, they faced a logistical challenge: conducting 12 separate lineups, one for each of the episodes attributed to the same man.

title: Sample of NBC-Bloomingdale's Partnership
description: In an except from NBC's 2011 Fall Primetime Preview, the host goes on a shopping spree at Bloomingdale's, which has a marketing partnership with NBC this fall.

title: Making Medical Donations Work
description: In Fridays Fixes column I wrote about organizations that collect usable surplus equipment and supplies from hospitals in the United States and ship it to hospitals that need them in poor countries. Readers were generally enthusiastic about the environmental and health benefits of this idea, but some offered important cautions. Homira from Wash, D.C. (15) wrote: There are a slew of complex issues that make donations of any kind aside from financial really poor practice for trying to help developing countries. When it comes to medical equipment donations, the consumables necessary to operate many of these machines, such as x-ray film, reagents, etc, are often not considered prior to the donations; nor is life-cycle costing and maintenance and operational costing and support figured in. Subsequently we see a lot of discarded medical equipment lying around clinics, hospitals and dump sites in low-income countries we work in.

title: Abundance of News, but Mixed Sales, for News Magazines
description: The first six months of 2011 brought the kind of news explosion that can be a boon for major news organizations: the Arab Spring, nuclear catastrophe in Japan, a royal wedding and the killing of Osama bin Laden.

title: Withholder in Chief
description: DES MOINES

title: Disney Beats Expectations, Posting 11% Rise in Profit
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company, reporting a profit of $1.48 billion in its most recent quarter, told analysts that whipsawing financial markets and fears of a double-dip recession were not hurting theme park bookings  so far.

title: Murray Is Chosen as a Leader of Deficit Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, will be co-chairwoman of a powerful new Congressional committee that is supposed to recommend at least $1.5 trillion of additional deficit-reduction measures, the Senate majority leader announced Tuesday.

title: A Network and a Retailer Seek Synergy
description: WHAT do NBC and Bloomingdales have in common?

title: Young Australian Matures Along With His Game
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Jason Day has played in only five major championships in his brief professional career, but he is among the top 10 favorites going into the seasons final major, the 93rd P.G.A. Championship at the Atlanta Athletic Club.

title: Sewage Frequently Fouls Hudson River, Report Says
description: Sewage routinely contaminates the Hudson River, according to a report released on Tuesday after four years of water testing in which one-fifth of the water samples indicated that the river was unsuitable for swimming and other recreation.

title: Pawlenty Courts Evangelicals in Iowa
description: Tim Pawlenty has narrowed his campaign focus to religious conservatives who live near Ames, the site of the Iowa straw poll.

title: Lionsgate and Tyler Perry Said to Be in Cable Venture
description: LOS ANGELES  Lionsgate is betting that Tyler Perry has the star power to carry an entire cable channel, Oprah Winfrey style.

title: S.&P., Accused of Faulty Math, Fights Error Disclosure Rule
description: WASHINGTON  Three days after Treasury Department officials discovered what they called a mistake in the assumptions used by Standard & Poors to justify the downgrade of United States debt, the president of S.& P. wrote to securities regulators saying that ratings agencies should not be required to publicly disclose all errors in their calculations.

title: A Selection of Poems by Philip Levine
description: What Work Is

title: Voice of the Workingman to Be Poet Laureate
description: The Library of Congress will announce on Wednesday that Philip Levine, best known for his big-hearted, Whitmanesque poems about working-class Detroit, is to be the next poet laureate, succeeding W. S. Merwin.

title: Making Rare Appearance: People and Their Appetites
description: Louis Untermeyer, who held the job we now call poet laureate from 1961 to 1963, spoke out against the idea that Americas laureates should engage in literary boosterism. He felt that from his office armchair, he was merely meant to act as a poetic radiator, radiating a love of poetry over as many miles as possible.

title: Wednesday: You Have My Word on It
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  You thought this was a golf theme, didnt you? Go on, admit it.

title: Acrobats Meet Skateboards and Basketballs (Watch Out!)
description: In the midst of this slow, soggy shuffle we call August in New York, when lifting one foot (and another) off the sidewalk feels like a Herculean effort, it is hard to believe in those more typical, energized Manhattan months, when the city has a spring in its step. But if youre looking for a pre-Labor Day fix of pure urban adrenaline, I can introduce you to this dealer on Union Square.

title: The Kid From Queens Comes Home
description: When Mike Baxter was a boy growing up in Whitestone, Queens, he and his father, Ray, would often hop in the car and take a tour of the local ball fields, searching not for games but for empty diamonds.

title: U.S. Is Seeking Maximum Prison Term in Galleon Case
description: Federal prosecutors recommended on Tuesday that Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund manager convicted of running a huge insider trading scheme, be sentenced to as many as 24 and a half years in prison.

title: Irked Neighbor Wins: West Side Bar Closes
description: For more than two decades, Tim Tomlinson has toiled in a city of honking cabs and crying children, screaming sirens and drunken revelers.

title: On Its Own, Europe Backs Web Privacy Fights
description: MADRID  All 90 people wanted information deleted from the Web.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jets Turn to Mentors and Rookie on the Line
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets defensive linemen spent most of Tuesdays practice in the corners of the teams indoor facility, doing unglamorous tasks like slamming into sleds, reacting to a football on a stick being snapped and dodging bags thrust at them.

title: Ragtag Mets Benefit From Late-Inning Magic
description: Manager Terry Collins has learned by now that his Mets are unusually resilient, stubborn by nature but also hardened this season by a level of adversity bordering on absurdity.

title: Chinas New Wealth Spurs a Market for Mistresses
description: BEIJING  Jian, a 42-year-old property developer in the booming southern metropolis of Shenzhen, had acquired just about everything men of his socioeconomic ilk covet: a Mercedes-Benz, a sprawling antique jade collection and a lavishly appointed duplex for his wife and daughter.

title: Technology Investors Turn Wary on Ventures
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.  Even as Wall Street trembles, the market for investing in tech start-ups remains white-hot. Still, some investors are proceeding with extreme caution.

title: Money Savers and Crowd Pleasers With Cloven Hooves
description: LOS ANGELES  With brown, dusty grass lining the hillside, this scrubby patch of land in the middle of downtown is not that much to look at.

title: China: Agency Reports 500,000 Cyberattacks in 2010
description: A government agency said Tuesday that Chinese computers were the targets of nearly 500,000 cyberattacks in 2010. Nearly half the attacks originated outside China, and the most common type employed so-called Trojan Horse malware, according to the agency, the National Computer Network Emergency Response Coordination Center of China. In a report, the agency said that the largest number, or 15 percent, of those malware attacks originated in the United States. Trojan Horse malware is software that appears to be a useful application but is actually malevolent.

title: States Pitch a Lifestyle to Lure Gun Makers From Their Longtime Homes
description: For more than a century, the nations firearms industry, including iconic brands like Colt, Smith & Wesson and Winchester, has been concentrated in Northeastern and Midwestern states that now have restrictive gun-control laws.

title: For Murdoch, a Board Meeting With Friendly Faces
description: When Rupert Murdoch sat down with his board on Tuesday for the first time since a phone hacking scandal overseas plunged his company into turmoil, he was surrounded by a lot of familiar, friendly faces.

title: Roman Opalka, an Artist of Numbers, Is Dead at 79
description: Roman Opalka, a leading conceptual artist who, beginning with the numeral one in 1965, methodically painted consecutive numbers on canvas in a march toward infinity, died on Saturday near Rome. He was 79.

title: A Test for Obamas View of a One-Term Presidency
description: WASHINGTON  It was a year and a half ago when President Obama told Diane Sawyer of ABC News in an interview that he would rather be a good one-term president than a mediocre two-term president.

title: Text of Statement by Federal Reserve
description: The following is the full text of the statement released Tuesday by the Federal Reserve:

title: Credit Union Regulator Accuses Goldman
description: The Goldman Sachs Group was sued on Tuesday by the National Credit Union Administration over claims that the bank violated federal and state laws in the sale of mortgage-backed securities to corporate credit unions that subsequently failed.

title: Another Group Helps Rick Perry Out
description: On the Rick Perry front, while he has not yet announced his presidential candidacy, the Perry for President shadow campaign is thriving.

title: Harry H. Wellington, Dean at Yale and a Labor Law Expert, Dies at 84
description: Harry H. Wellington, whose half-century of studying and teaching law included a decade as dean of Yale Law School and eight years as dean of New York Law School, died last Monday at his home in New York. He was 84.

title: New Jersey Transit Delays to Last Through Morning Commute
description: Riders on New Jersey Transit may face crowded trains on Wednesday morning in the aftermath of a derailment that disrupted service on Tuesday. Other service in and out of Pennsylvania Station was expected to be normal.

title: Japan May Lift Advisory on Edge of Nuclear Evacuation Area
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government said Tuesday that it may lift an evacuation advisory for some areas near the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant as soon as next month, in what would be the first areas reopened since the nuclear accident in March.

title: Angels Tag Rivera and Granderson, Handing Yanks Third Straight Loss
description: The Yankees and Mariano Rivera had a full day to recover from their upsetting loss to the Boston Red Sox late Sunday night, when Rivera blew a save opportunity in the ninth inning and the Red Sox went on to win in the 10th.

title: Shares Suffer Again in a Blow to Market Confidence
description: The stock market resumed its downward trajectory on Wednesday as American investors looked with renewed trepidation at the debt problems plaguing Europe and the United States sputtering economy.

title: NYT Front Page for 08/10/11
description: NYT Front Page for 08/10/11

title: For Better Grades, Try Gym Class
description: If you want a young person to focus intently in school and perform well on tests, should you first send him or her to gym class? That question, which has particular relevance for school districts weighing whether to reduce or ax their physical education programs to save money, motivated a number of stimulating new examinations into the interplay of activity and attention. Some of the experiments studied children; others looked at laboratory rats bred to have an animal version of attention deficit disorder. For both groups, exercise significantly affected their ability to concentrate, although some activities seemed to be better than others at sharpening attention.

title: Two Marriott Brands Are to Share Space in Manhattan Tower
description: Construction will start soon on one of New Yorks largest hotel projects, a 68-story high-rise at the northwest corner of Broadway and 54th Street with more than 600 rooms, according to officials of Granite Broadway Development and Marriott International.

title: Word of the Day | simian
description: simian \si-me-n\ adjective and noun

title: China Trade Surplus Rises Sharply
description: HONG KONG  Chinas exports and imports both rose faster than expected in July, producing a trade surplus of $31.5 billion, the largest in more than two years, Chinas General Administration of Customs announced in Beijing on Wednesday morning.

title: Capital One to Buy HSBCs U.S. Card Unit for $2.6 Billion
description: Capital One Financial agreed early Wednesday to buy the United States credit card business of HSBC Holdings for $2.6 billion in cash and stock, in what will be Capital Ones second major deal with a European firm in recent months.

title: Corrections: August 10
description: NATIONAL

title: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 10, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Oana Pascu at Math for America from the article From Zappos, an Unadorned Approach.

title: Britain Debates Riots and Fears They Set a Pattern
description: LONDON  Still reeling with shock and anger over the worst rioting in decades, Britain turned on Wednesday to a tough reckoning with the perpetrators, even as the police and political leaders worried about a potentially explosive new pattern of interracial violence that could be set off by the past four days of mayhem.

title: 2 Asian Carriers Disclose Big Orders
description: HONG KONG  Two of the largest airlines in Asia, Cathay Pacific and Singapore Airlines, announced aircraft orders worth billions of dollars Wednesday, in a sign that high oil prices and the recent market turmoil have not dented the willingness of Asian carriers to make sizable investments.

title: China Begins Sea Trials of Its First Aircraft Carrier
description: BEIJING  Chinas first aircraft carrier began sea trials on Wednesday, the state-run Xinhua news service reported, a highly symbolic step in what is certain to be an effort of many years to create a carrier presence in the Pacific waters off its coast.

title: News Quiz | August 10, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: South Korea Returns Fire After Shots From North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean military returned fire on Wednesday after North Korean artillery shells fell in waters near a South Korean island the North attacked last year with a lethal artillery barrage, Defense Ministry officials said.

title: Aug. 10, 1977 | David Berkowitz, Son of Sam, Is Arrested
description: On Aug. 10, 1977, David Berkowitz, the serial killer who signed his letters Son of Sam, was captured.

title: Dismal Thoughts
description: To be an economist of my stripe these days  basically a Keynes-via-Hicks type, who concluded as soon as Lehman fell that we were in a classic liquidity trap with all that implied  is a bittersweet experience, with the bitter vastly greater than the sweet.

title: On Second Glance, a Prize-Winning Image
description: Jussi Leinonen, 27, lives in Rovaniemi, Finland; works as a staff photographer at the daily newspaper Lapin Kansa; and hopes to finish a degree in audiovisual media culture at the University of Lapland before he dies. He was named Finlands Press Photographer of the Year in 2008. The image above was designated Portrait of the Year. His conversation with Kerri MacDonald in the Turning Point series has been edited and condensed.

title: Riots in London
description: Note: This edition of 6 Qs draws from a number of Times reports. Answers for each question can be found in the article to which that question is linked.

title: Do You Choose Summer Activities to Look Good on Applications?
description: According to this article, more and more students are thinking about how their summer activities can be used to make their college applications more interesting. Do you, or do people you know, plan your vacations around building a better rsum for college or a future career? If not, what else determines how you spend your time off?

title: Q&A: Lending Out an Electronic Book
description: Q.

title: High-End Hamam Opens in Historic Istanbul Location
description: For years the domed structure between the Aya Sofia (Hagia Sophia) and the Blue Mosque was used as a state-run carpet shop. Kilims and halis were strewn every which way across marble navel stones under huge domes that let shafts of light illuminate the structure built in 1556 by the famed architect Sinan to house the baths of Roxelana, known locally as Hurrem. (Hurrem was the slave who became the powerful wife of Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent.) Now, thanks to a $10 million restoration, the marble-clad space is once again a Turkish bath house, with separate facilities for men and women.

title: The Early Word: The Fed
description: Todays Times

title: 2011 Washington Redskins Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. This week, he has looked at the N.F.C. East, with the Eagles to come on Thursday.

title: The Debt Downgrade and Stock Prices
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Westinghouse Reactor Takes a Step Forward
description: The reactor at the leading edge of what has been cast as a nuclear renaissance has taken a step forward.

title: Tragic Racers BMW M1 Art Car Heads to Pebble Beach Auction
description: A hitchhiker found the body in the sand beside Highway A1A near Jacksonville, Fla., next to the fatal .38. A briefcase held the sales receipt for the pistol and a suicide note, timed 2:30. Precise as ever, even in death, was Peter Perfect, the golden boy race driver, Peter Gregg, dead at age 40.

title: What Is the Ultrabook?
description: Since May there has been a nearly constant, subcellular buzz on the Internet about something called an Intel Ultrabook. But what, exactly, are we looking at here?

title: Swiss Central Bank Tries Again to Weaken Franc
description: LONDON  The Swiss National Bank announced new monetary measures Wednesday to weaken the surging franc, which it regards as greatly overvalued.

title: In Atlantic City, Dj Vu All Over Again
description: Our photo director, Kathy Ryan, happened to be in Atlantic City and she sent us this trippy photograph. There she is holding a copy of the magazine with the photo feature shot on this very same spot.

title: Big Banks Shrinking as S.B.A. Lenders
description: The Small Business Administrations guaranteed business loan program is back. Nudged by stimulus provisions that reduced fees and increased guarantees, American banks made a record amount of S.B.A.-backed loans in 2010 (measured in dollars), reversing a demoralizing four-year slide. But theres something noteworthy about who was doing that lending: while banks as a whole loaned more government-backed money than ever, the biggest banks loaned less.

title: A Battle for Toilet Supremacy
description: The showdown reads like a rejected Hollywood script: ninjas and Brooklynites facing off in a battle for toilet supremacy.

title: Off the Grid, Where the Living Is Good
description: Three weeks ago, my wife and I moved with our three boys, two cats, five bikes and canoe from the New Jersey suburbs to a cabin in the Maine woods. Well be here for a year, and from time to time Ill be updating you on our experiment in living in tune with our surroundings and off the grid.

title: Romneys Covert Iowa Campaign
description: DES MOINES  Mitt Romney will dip his big toe in the Iowa waters on Wednesday, even as he continues to treat the political activity here like a sideshow that he can afford to ignore, at least for now.

title: Groupon Drops a Criticized Accounting Measure
description: 8:17 p.m. | Updated

title: Speak & Spell for the iPad Generation
description: Word Wizard ($3.99) turns your iPad into a talking typewriter, and a powerful language-learning tool that is ideal for a child learning to read.

title: The Two-Minus-One Pregnancy
description: As Jenny lay on the obstetricians examination table, she was grateful that the ultrasound tech had turned off the overhead screen. She didnt want to see the two shadows floating inside her. Since making her decision, she had tried hard not to think about them, though she could often think of little else. She was 45 and pregnant after six years of fertility bills, ovulation injections, donor eggs and disappointment  and yet here she was, 14 weeks into her pregnancy, choosing to extinguish one of two healthy fetuses, almost as if having half an abortion. As the doctor inserted the needle into Jennys abdomen, aiming at one of the fetuses, Jenny tried not to flinch, caught between intense relief and intense guilt.

title: To the Trade | Jacket Required
description: Its about time. London should have a show like this.

title: Morning Buzz
description: For more local news from The Times, including more on a citywide mandate to teach sex education in public middle and high schools, the tenacity of an Upper West Side resident in shutting down a local bar, and Alec Baldwins political ambitions, see the N.Y./Region section.

title: Interest Rate Follies
description: I dont have time to do all the references, but heres a quick summary of what Very Serious People have been saying over the past 2 1/2 years:

title: Wednesday Reading: A Test For Fetal Gender at 7 Weeks
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Lost in a Daydream
description: Once there was this English showgirl and she used to take the stage right before Archie Rice came on, but now she is old and can barely get up from her rocking chair  but there is a trunkful of her tattered dance shoes up in the attic. And maybe she was your grandma and you just discovered them. Or maybe your granny (great-granny?) was a weathered-but-gorgeous sharecropper, a Dust Bowl refugee in frayed frock and battered boots, only  wait!  what if those boots were splattered with glitter?

title: Got to Boogie on the Disco Round: Studio 54 Radio on SiriusXM
description: 6:13 p.m. | Updated  Disco may have died, gone undercover or been lying in wait along with other 1970s fixtures like oil crises, economic malaise and wide-legged pants. In any case, it is being recalibrated for SiriusXM, the satellite radio broadcaster, which is starting a four-on-the-floor channel called Studio 54 on Aug. 15, the company will announce on Wednesday.

title: Times Readers React to the London Riots
description: In response to the riots in Britain, NYTimes.com readers have largely divided into two camps. Many of our British readers view the riots as the sum of a materialistic culture and a welfare state that has spoiled its citizenry. Others, while refusing to support violent tactics, believe the rich have hoarded their nations wealth, and the resulting social unrest is inevitable. Here is a sampling of some of the nearly 700 comments we received on yesterdays articles and blog posts.

title: In Britain, Central Bank Cuts Outlook on Growth
description: LONDON  The governor of the Bank of England, Mervyn A. King, gave a gloomy outlook for the British economy on Wednesday but said he would not make a vow like the one by the Federal Reserve in the United States to keep short-term interest rates near zero for some time.

title: Race for Weiners Seat Tightens, Siena Poll Finds
description: The race to succeed former Representative Anthony D. Weiner is much closer than anticipated, according to the first public poll for the Sept. 13 special election.

title: Bank of New York Mellon to Cut 1,500 Jobs
description: Bank of New York Mellon said on Wednesday that it was planning to cut 1,500 jobs, or about 3 percent of its global work force of 48,900.

title: City Ballet Offers New Discount Program
description: Subscribers to New York City Ballets Fourth Ring Society will be offered a new discount program for the 2011-12 season starting on Aug. 29. The program, called Society NYCB, will be the same as it was last season for the Fourth Ring Society, which was discontinued. There will be a $20 annual membership fee, and tickets will cost $15 (plus a $2 facility fee). They can be purchased by phone or at the box office; the standard ticket service fee of $7 will be waived and tickets will not be available online.

title: Latest Updates on the Financial Markets
description: The Lede followed the global financial markets on Wednesday.

title: Beard Foundation Honors Visionaries in Sustainable Food
description: And now, the first James Beard Foundation Leadership Awards, announced Wednesday, for 10 visionaries in the business, government and education sectors who have helped create a healthier, safer and more sustainable food world.

title: Subsidies and Suspicion
description: LANCASTER, Calif.  This city in the high desert, at the far northern edge of the Los Angeles sprawl, is filled with cozy cul-de-sacs, stucco homes, green lawns and gleaming sedans.

title: U.S. Says Strike Killed Taliban Who Downed Copter
description: WASHINGTON  An American airstrike has killed the Taliban fighters believed responsible for shooting down a Chinook helicopter and killing 38 people aboard, including 30 American military personnel, the senior American commander in Afghanistan said Wednesday.

title: Here We Go Again
description: The stock market slid Wednesday morning as fears about Europes debt crisis flared anew.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Support for Assad Government Shows Signs of Weakening
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As Syria continues its most relentless assault yet on a five-month uprising, killing more than a dozen protesters Wednesday, cracks have begun to emerge in a tight-knit leadership that has until now managed to rally its base of support and maintain a unified front, officials, dissidents and analysts say.

title: Timely | Northern Lights
description: In indie rock, its not so much who you know as who knows you. And all the right people have come to know First Aid Kit, a Swedish folk duo made up of the sisters Johanna (left) and Klara Sderberg. They were discovered by Karin Dreijer Andersson (one half of the Swedish sibling duo the Knife), who released their first EP. They met Conor Oberst on the Monsters of Folk tour in Sweden; he introduced them to the producer of their next album. When First Aid Kit passed through Nashville on their American tour, Jack White invited them to record for his label. Part of a proud folk tradition  they enjoy singing older songs, Johanna says  they chose to rework Buffy Sainte-Maries Universal Soldier, a protest song from the 60s, whose message is unfortunately still very relevant today.

title: Suspect Charged in Groping Attacks
description: The man taken into custody Tuesday in connection with a string of groping attacks on the Upper East Side was charged late Tuesday night with burglary, sexual abuse and forcible touching in three of the encounters.

title: How to Beat Roaming Fees While Traveling Abroad
description: LAST weeks column suggested ways to save when calling home from abroad. This week Ill tackle data roaming fees, which wireless providers charge when customers use their phones outside their service area. With travelers using smartphones and other wireless devices abroad in the same way as they do back home (to check e-mail, to update Facebook and Twitter and to pull up online maps), the skyrocketing fees are taking many by surprise.

title: MTV to Start Webcast Devoted to Emerging Bands
description: It has been two years since New York Noise, a beloved public television show devoted to the citys underground rock bands, went off the air. Now an online subsidiary of MTV has hired the producer behind that show, Shirley Braha, to do a half-hour Webcast of indie videos in her humorous and playful style.

title: Claude Laydu, French Actor, Dies at 84
description: Claude Laydu, a French actor best known for his screen debut in the lead role of Robert Bressons critically acclaimed early-1950s film Diary of a Country Priest, died on July 29 in Paris. He was 84.

title: Putting the Cod Back in Cape Cod
description: I love fishing, which was one of the ways, growing up in Rhode Island, that I developed my broader passion for the wider living world outside of the human-built one. As a kid paddling around in a dinghy, I could feel the otherwise invisible seabed by bouncing my weighted hand line off the bottom. While waiting for a bite fishing for mackerel from a floating dock, Id stick my head down close to the water and peer at the fascinating assemblage of small shrimp, sea squirts and other creatures growing on the immersed wood and floats.

title: Francesco Quinn, Actor in Platoon, Dies at 48
description: Francesco Quinn, a television and film actor who appeared in Oliver Stones searing 1986 Vietnam War film, Platoon,, died on Friday in Malibu, Calif. The son of the actor Anthony Quinn, he was 48.

title: Ex-Officer Receives Two-Month Sentence in Rape Case
description: A second former New York police officer was sentenced on Wednesday to jail for his role in a case that involved lurid accusations of rape committed by two on-duty officers.

title: The Hawk Cam Is Going Dark. For Now.
description: The end approacheth  at least for this season.

title: Sakyo Komatsu, 80, Science Fiction Writer, Dies at 80
description: Sakyo Komatsu, one of the leading science-fiction writers of Japan, whose 1973 best-selling book, Japan Sinks, rattled a nation that sits on one of the most earthquake-prone zones in the world, died on July 26 in Osaka Prefecture, Japan. He was 80.

title: Marinated Tofu Sandwich With Asian Greens
description: You wont use all of the marinade for this sandwich, so add more tofu to it for another meal.

title: Imparting Energy Smarts to Young Consumers
description: While some members of Congress lament the prospect of switching to energy-efficient light bulbs, one California nonprofit, Zilowatt, is spreading the energy conservation message at a grass-roots level. The group, whose motto is Start Small, wants to change energy habits by teaching consumers in grades K to 12 that the best light bulb is one thats turned off.

title: With Greener Cars Already on the Road, Why Design a Virtual One?
description: The Union of Concerned Scientists has just introduced its Model E crossover, but you cant buy it, now or ever.

title: In Wisconsin, a Big Recall Push Comes Up Short
description: SAYNER, Wis.  In the end, it fell short of the outcome protesters who had marched in Wisconsins state capital for weeks and weeks had hoped for: Democrats managed to seize two Republican State Senate seats in recall elections on Tuesday, but fell short of the three (or more) they needed to take control of that legislative chamber.

title: Balto to the Rescue
description: Credit the wise publishing executive who scheduled the release of The Incredible Life of Balto for the middle of global warming-baked August, drawing in readers from the opening endpapers, which show a map of the far reaches of Alaska. Even lugging a dog-sled team through a blizzard in the diphtheria-ridden Last Frontier sounds appealing in 102-degree weather.

title: The Briefing
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#999", 592, 450, true, chameleonData);

title: McIlroy Stays Mum Over Olympic Team Allegiance
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland, the 2011 United States Open champion, said Wednesday that he was looking forward to playing in the 2016 Summer Olympics golf tournament, although he did not indicate which nation he planned to represent. It has been a delicate subject for McIlroy, and his countryman Graeme McDowell, the 2010 United State Open champion. There have been veiled indications that they might represent Britain or Ireland in 2016, but recently each golfer seems eager to be vague on the subject.

title: Godspell Finds Its Jesus  in Weeds Co-Star
description: Hunter Parrish has found religion  at least on Broadway. Mr. Parrish, who stars as a hunky troubled teenager on the Showtime series Weeds, and played a hunky mopey teenager in Spring Awakening, will next take on the role of Jesus in a revival of Godspell, its producers announced on Wednesday.

title: On CNN, a Sons Photo Honors a Fallen Soldier
description: 4:05 p.m. | Updated Bryan Nichols, the father of Braydon Nichols, died in Afghanistan on Saturday when insurgents shot down a helicopter carrying 30 Americans and eight Afghans. Braydon, 10, noticed that television newscasts were showing photos of some of the service members, but not of his father. So he sent a picture to CNN.

title: M.L.S. and NBC Sports Announce New TV Deal
description: Major League Soccer and NBC Sports on Thursday will announce a new three-year agreement to televise 45 league matches and 4 United States national team games on the main network and on the NBC Sports Network, which will be the new name of the current cable station Versus. The deal will end the leagues relationship with Fox Soccer, which recently signed a one-year deal to carry matches in 2011.

title: Swapping Meat for Nuts to Lower Diabetes Risk
description: Eating red meat, and in particular processed red meat like bacon and hot dogs, raises the risk of Type 2 diabetes. But replacing just one serving a day with nuts or low-fat dairy can lower the risk, according to a study by Harvard researchers.

title: Harri Holkeri, Northern Ireland Peace Negotiator, Is Dead at 74
description: Harri Holkeri, a former Finnish prime minister who helped shepherd talks that led to the historic 1998 peace agreement in Northern Ireland, died on Sunday in Helsinki. He was 74.

title: Restored Monument Returns to St. Pauls
description: The nations first official monument is back in place after three and a half months of 21st-century restoration on stone and marble that took 10 years to fabricate and deliver in the 18th century.

title: Philadelphia Fights Violent Flash Mobs With Curfews
description: As British leaders struggle to contain spreading violence on their countrys streets, at least one commentator, writing in The Daily Telegraph, has suggested they look to Philadelphia for answers.

title: Stephen Sondheim Takes Issue With Plan for Revamped Porgy and Bess
description: Theres a spanking new version of Porgy and Bess on the way, one that seeks to transform the classic 1935 opera into a commercial Broadway musical. To that end, the director Diane Paulus and the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks have added new scenes, punched up some dialogue, invented biographical details and  most radically  added a more upbeat ending. Such tinkering with the renowned Gershwin work was bound to draw fire from some quarters, and indeed it has, following the publication of an Arts & Leisure article by Patrick Healy about the production, which stars Audra McDonald and Norm Lewis. It begins performances at the American Repertory Theater next Wednesday in Cambridge, Mass., with plans to transfer to Broadway next winter.

title: 12th Suspect in Hacking Scandal Arrested in London
description: As the police in London questioned a 12th suspect in connection with Britains widening phone hacking scandal on Wednesday, Scotland Yard announced that Dick Fedorcio, its longtime director of public affairs, had been placed on extended leave until the criminal inquiries were concluded.

title: All-Nighters for a Football Team During Ramadan
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  The clock reached midnight as Sunday ticked into Monday, and someone yelled, Its go time! Football season could officially begin. New balls appeared, and players at Fordson High School prepared to do what had long been done in this hometown of Henry Ford: build something with assembly-line precision and reliability.

title: Cards That Help Save on Airline Baggage Fees
description: If youve flown anywhere recently, you know that travelers are increasingly trying to cram more luggage into the overhead bins to avoid those pesky checked-baggage fees that generally start at $25 a bag. Some credit cards, though, can help reduce the fee burden  and maybe even reduce time wasted as attendants pry excess bags from the hands of desperate passengers and wheel them away to be checked.

title: Paulson Fund Down 31% for the Year
description: The year keeps getting worse for the hedge fund titan John A. Paulson.

title: Rockefeller Foundation Announces Cultural Grants for New York City Groups
description: The Rockefeller Foundation announced on Wednesday the recipients of its Cultural Innovation Fund grants, which will distribute nearly $3 million over two years to 16 New York City-based organizations.

title: Rookie Hopes to Fill Holes, and Make Them
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Being a member of a vanishing breed has its advantages.

title: Faith and Football Meet in Wee Hours
description: Two-a-day football practices at Fordson High School in Dearborn, Mich., whose enrollment is 90 percent Muslim, coincided this week with Ramadan, leading to an interesting scheduling solution.

title: Ochocincos Next Move
description: In todays bizarre news, Chad Ochocinco would like to move in with you. O.K., maybe not you exactly. Youd have to be a New England Patriots fan, living within a reasonable commute of Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Mass., and presumably in a home with indoor plumbing. Ochocinco also requests you own an Xbox.

title: Woods, Upbeat and Smiling, Says Little About Williamss Remarks
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  When Tiger Woods entered the room, stage right, for his Wednesday morning news conference at the Atlanta Athletic Club, he was greeted by the largest news media contingent of the week by a margin even wider than the smile he wore for the occasion.

title: Six Republicans Named to Deficit Panel
description: The top Republicans in the House and the Senate appointed six more lawmakers on Wednesday to the bipartisan committee that is supposed to recommend steps to reduce federal budget deficits by at least $1.5 trillion over 10 years.

title: Asked & Answered | Sean Patrick Maylone
description: With K-pop groups like the Wonder Girls on the ascent  and sitting front row at the Chlo show in Shanghai  its clear that Korean pop is having a moment. But is there a Korean underground? According to Sean Patrick Maylone, the answer is yes. His Seoul-based booking and promotion agency, SuperColorSuper, has helped to create a South Korean tour circuit for indie bands like Caribou, Das Racist and CocoRosie, blazing a trail not just to Seoul, but also to Busan and Daegu, places the 30-year-old native Californian knew nothing about when he arrived in Korea to teach English four years ago. Here, Maylone discusses South Koreas burgeoning underground music scene.

title: Who Needs Summer Homework?
description: Have you finished your homework?

title: Growing Concern Over Frances Top Credit Rating Spreads Market Anxiety
description: PARIS  With the sense of economic crisis deepening in Europe after the United States debt downgrade, investors have played Whos Next with the shrinking list of nations that still hold the top rating of AAA. And their sights have landed on France.

title: Live Blog: Q.&A. With Bank of Americas Chief
description: Bank of America may not be your top pick  but it is a favorite of Fairholme Capital Management.

title: The Caucus Click: Campaign 2012, Iowa Style
Middle Class? At $9.5 Million, Actors Home Is Far From It
description: The actor Alec Baldwin has not yet begun running for mayor of New York, but he is already saying things that could alienate the great number of voters who cannot afford expensive neighborhoods.

title: Karzai Annuls Afghan Court Reviewing 2010 Polls
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a startling reversal on Wednesday, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan annulled a special court that he had set up to review the results of the 2010 parliamentary elections.

title: Is the House G.O.P. Warming to Tax Increases?
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. - While last months Congressional tangle over the debt ceiling suggested permanent partisan gridlock, signs are emerging that some House Republicans are opening the door to potential revenue increases, as Congressional leaders continued to name their members of a bipartisan committee charged with finding ways to tame the deficit.

title: To Swim or Not to Swim?
description: John Lipscomb, the captain of a boat that regularly plies the Hudson River for the environmental group Riverkeeper, says that on hot sunny days he sees hundreds and hundreds of people swimming in the river off official and unofficial beaches and off drifting boats.

title: Adele Still No. 1, but Jay-Z and Kanye West are in Hot Pursuit
description: This week on the Billboard charts Adele continues her remarkable run with a 12th week at No. 1, but big competition from Jay-Z and Kanye West is right behind her.

title: Nervously Watching as the Economy Churns
description: Wall Street, we know, is roiling. The extraordinary events of the last two weeks  the brinksmanship in Washington over raising the federal debt limit, the downgrade of the governments credit rating by Standard & Poors, and the debt trouble across the Atlantic in Europe  have pummeled stocks and dizzied traders.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 10
description: Francesca Schiavone advanced at the Rogers Cup womens tennis event in Toronto and golfers completed their final practice rounds ahead of the P.G.A. Championship in Johns Creek, Ga.

title: Cooking Classes, Live on Google+
description: Google Hangouts, a feature of Google+, Googles new social network, lets people video-chat, watch YouTube clips together and even take turns belting out rounds of karaoke.

title: A Nurse, a Patient and a Television
description: Hospital patients watch a lot of television to pass the time. As a result, nurses often catch glimpses of news and entertainment programs while walking in and out of patient rooms.

title: From Alpinestars, a Motorcycle Suit That Inflates to Protect the Rider
description: When Jorge Lorenzo, the Yamaha factory racer, was catapulted from his bike in a crash while practicing at Laguna Seca on July 22, sensors in his suit read that he hit the pavement with the force of 25.3 Gs. Its the kind of impact that can shatter bones and careers, but Lorenzo not only walked away from the crash, he placed second at the track two days afterward in the Red Bull United States Grand Prix.

title: Are You Prepared for a Double-Dip Recession?
description: We just published an article that surveyed small-business owners on the impact of recent financial news, and their coping strategies for a possible double-dip recession. Weve been through this before, said Elizabeth Lunney, who is co-founder and chief executive of the language school ABC Language Exchange and who shared her experiences with daily deal Web sites in a previous post. Heres what she had to say:

title: Designer Named for Final Cunningham Performances
description: The final visual artist to collaborate with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company  a list that includes heavyweights like Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg and Andy Warhol  will be Daniel Arsham. For his fourth collaboration with the company, Mr. Arsham, an artist who has designed sets, lighting and costumes for Merce Cunningham, will fill the Park Avenue Armory with clouds of colored spheres; the design will be used in the companys final performances, on Dec. 29 to 31 at the armory.

title: TBS Cancels Lopez Tonight
description: 3:50 p.m. | Updated TBS on Wednesday cancelled George Lopezs late-night show, less than a year after the network moved Lopez Tonight from 11 p.m. to midnight to make room for Conan OBrien.

title: Hi Mark! Its the F.T.C. Calling
description: A couple of representatives of the Federal Trade Commission, evidently stung by my column last week (in which I called the agency spineless), scheduled a phone call to remind me that the F.T.C. doesnt have the ability to pass legislation that determines how Big Food markets to children.

title: The Caucus | Romney and Perry Face Off
description: Two men not competing in the Iowa Straw Poll this weekend are nonetheless garnering most of the attention. Also, the view from the political columnist at the Des Moines Register.

title: Filing Challenge to Census, City Says 50,000 Werent Counted in 2 Boroughs
description: Invoking the Census Bureaus own data and other evidence, New York City officials argued on Wednesday that the 2010 count had overlooked at least 50,000 residents of Brooklyn and Queens living in homes and apartments that the bureau incorrectly concluded were vacant.

title: China Releases Dissident Blogger, With Conditions
description: BEIJING  One of Chinas more prolific bloggers, whose introspective musings on democracy, human rights and fatherhood earned him tens of thousands of followers but also charges of inciting subversion, was unexpectedly released after nearly six months in police custody, his wife said Wednesday.

title: As Markets Swing, HomeStreet and WageWorks Delay I.P.O.s
description: This week was supposed to be a hectic one for public offerings, with 12 companies expected to price.

title: Caucus Video: Romney and Perry Prepare to Face Off; A Look at Straw Poll History
description: Jeff Zeleny reports from Iowa on two men who arent competing in the straw poll this weekend but are garnering most of the attention nonetheless. Also, Kathie Obradovich, the political columnist at The Des Moines Register, sits down for an interview about the field and lessons from Iowa political history.

title: Childrens Museum of Manhattan Receives Grant for Muslim Exhibition
description: The Childrens Museum of Manhattan has received a $40,000 planning grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to develop a major exhibition on Muslim culture, the museum said on Wednesday. The exhibition, planned for 2014, will be called Muslim Worlds and will emphasize the diversity of Muslim culture.

title: Slumping Goydos Waits for a Chance That May Not Come
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  The P.G.A. Tour pro Paul Goydos waited until his peers had cleared the Atlanta Athletic Club Highlands course Wednesday afternoon before squeezing in nine practice holes solo. Same routine Tuesday.

title: Who Says Turtles Dont Eat Pasta?
description: This red-eared slider, scarfing down what appeared to be some sort of takeout noodle dish by the lake at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, on Wednesday afternoon, seems to take a broad dietary view.

title: Trains Back to Normal, Day After Derailment
description: After a day, a night and a morning of widespread delays and cancellations, trains are now running normally into and out of Pennsylvania Station.

title: Sun, Surf and 14 Acres of Sand
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#946", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: 'Two Voices'
description: Philip Levine read his poem "Two Voices" at the Library of Congress in 2007.

title: S.E.C. Sues Stifel Nicolaus Over Wisconsin School Investments
description: 4:12 p.m. | Updated The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Stifel, Nicolaus & Company on Wednesday, accusing the Midwestern brokerage firm of duping five Wisconsin school districts into buying $200 million in dubious investments.

title: The War Memoirists Dilemma
description: In a detailed article last month, The Associated Press reported that a former Army captain, Luis Carlos Montalvan, distorted several of his Iraq war experiences in a memoir he co-authored. Ever since, I have been thinking a great deal about the dilemma of truth in war memoirs.

title: Congressman Questions White House on Bin Laden Film
description: 6:02 p.m. | Updated Is the Obama White House planning an October surprise for next year to give the presidents re-election campaign a boost?

title: Gen X Golden Oldies: Teenage Girl Edition
description: I was a teenager in the 1990s, and after reading Hugos Gen X Golden Oldies mix, I felt like I had to represent for the Gen X (ugh) girls. If there was ever a great musical moment to be an awkward, angst-ridden teenage girl, it was the early 90s. So I made my own I know 90s nostalgia isnt cool, but here are all my favorite 90s songs anyway mix. This is what the girls were listening to while the boys were off air-guitaring to the Grifters.

title: Rock Steady
description: As natural attractions go, Norways Pulpit Rock makes a jaw-dropping first impression on visitors.

title: 2nd Ex-Officer in Rape Case Is Sentenced for Misconduct
description: A former New York police officer who was convicted of official misconduct in a case in which his partner was accused of raping a drunken woman was sentenced on Wednesday to two months in jail.

title: Wisc. Results Suggest Recall of Governor Would Be Close
description: Close doesnt count in elections  just ask Al Gore or Norm Coleman.

title: Obama as a Hope, and as a President
description: To the Editor:

title: Beauty Spots
description: LETS TWIST Known for sunglasses and flowing animal-printed maxi-dresses, Rachel Zoe, the stylist and reality-television star, is now promoting a new line of lipsticks and glosses, Exude, with a slanted applicator made of crystal. Users twist the case so that the product, which has a creamy gel-like consistency, is pushed up through a hole; anything extra is then sucked down into the tube for later use, avoiding the kind of crushing that can happen with traditional sticks. In nine creme colors including coral, nude and red, and five gloss shades, among them crimson and dusty pink. Both formulas are mint-scented and contain Vitamin E ($29 each at exudelipstick.com).

title: A New York Poem by the New Poet Laureate
description: Philip Levine,  the new United States poet laureate, grew up in Detroit and lives in Fresno, Calif. As Dwight Garner writes in his appraisal, Mr. Levine is known for his emphasis on the voice of the ordinary workingman and the industrial heartland.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: World Trade Center, 11:27 A.M.
Under an Economic Glare, the Italians Are Perplexed
description: ROME  Concerns about the stagnant Italian economy and its heavy public debt have buffeted global financial markets in recent weeks. But for ordinary Italians, the prevailing emotion is more bafflement than anxiety.

title: Some in Germany Want Greece to Temporarily Exit the Euro Zone
description: FRANKFURT  If the European debt crisis were an old survival movie, there would be a scene in which the passengers in a lifeboat realize that they dont have enough food and water for everyone and that someone needs to go over the side. Were looking at you, Greece.

title: Westway Club in the West Village
description: CONTRARY to earlier reports, you wont find any stripper poles (or topless women) at Westway, the new club from Matt Kliegman and Carlos Quirarte, the masterminds behind the Smile and the Jane Ballroom parties.

title: NBC Snags Most Viewers as Fox Lands Younger Ones
description: It was another split night among the broadcast networks on Tuesday as the cooking combo of Hells Kitchen and MasterChef helped Fox win the 18- to 49-year-old ratings category. Meanwhile, Americas Got Talent on NBC was the most watched program of the night with 11.2 million total viewers, boosting the overall average of viewers for NBC to 8.9 million.

title: How Serious a Crime Is Insider Trading?
description: Peter Foley/Bloomberg NewsRaj Rajaratnam leaving federal court during his trial in the spring.

title: Bubba Remembers Bubba
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  If Bubba Watson wins his first major Sunday in the P.G.A. Championship at the Atlanta Athletic Club, he could dedicate it to the memory of his nickname-sake.

title: An Ice Expert Muses on Greenhouse Heat
description: Ignatius G. Rigor, a ocean, ice and climate researcher at the University of Washington, has long been on my go-to list when grappling with studies of sea ice and climate. I sent him my post on new insights about Arctic ice retreats in the last big northern warm period  a 2,500-year optimum, ending around 6,000 years ago, when the region was several degrees warmer on average than today. He and I exchanged some thoughts about his scientific and personal reactions to the study and broader trends and I invited him to consolidate them in a Your Dot contribution:

title: Designer Loses Bid to Protect Signature Shoes
description: The signature red soles on Christian Louboutin high heels, so famous they inspired a song by Jennifer Lopez and made countless cameos on Sex and the City, could one day show up on shoes sold at Payless.

title: Amazon Releases Web-Based Kindle App and Store
description: Apple has aknackfor turningfriends into frenemies.

title: Proposed: A One-Page Checking Disclosure Form
description: About three-fourths of Americans with checking accounts agreed that banks should be required to better disclose the terms of the accounts, including bounced check fees, a recent survey by an arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts found.

title: Fill-In | High School Football During Ramadan
Santa Fe Opera to Present Three New Works
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Charles MacKay, the general director of the Santa Fe Opera, announced on Wednesday that at a time of economic hardship and cutbacks among many arts institutions, his company would present a new opera in three consecutive seasons, starting in the summer of 2013. These include the first commissioned works of Mr. MacKays tenure, which began in 2008.

title: In U.S. Stress Tests, a Tool to Gauge Contagion in Europe
description: Tiziana Fabi/Agence France-Presse  Getty ImagesPrime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, left, with his finance minister, Giulio Tremonti. American banks hold sizable amounts of Italian debt.

title: Summer Styles | Leg Action
description: A look at whos staying cool and looking cooler this season.

title: Curl Up With a Soothing Smartphone and Relax
description: Unless youre listening to Dark Side of the Moon on your smartphone, its hard to see them as devices for relaxation. More often, theyre for aggressive thumb-tapping, Angry-Birding exercises.

title: Fans With Cellphones Welcomed at the P.G.A.
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  The P.G.A. of America, resigned to the tethering of spectators to their cellphones, has lifted a ban on mobile devices. This weeks P.G.A. Championship at the Atlanta Athletic Club becomes the first of golfs majors to allow lifes latest 24/7 necessity inside the gates.

title: In Iowa, Romney Is Comfortable at the Round Table
description: PELLA, IOWA  Mitt Romney returned to Iowa on Wednesday for the first time since announcing his bid for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, striding into a conference room at the headquarters of the Vermeer Manufacturing Company for a business round table, saying he was there to listen.

title: Utter Wrongness
Ron Paul Declines to Gloat About His Prescient Warnings on Debt
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  Ron Paul has none of the bravado of his Republican presidential rivals. At a town hall meeting here on Wednesday afternoon, he spoke for 35 minutes and then promptly apologized.

title: Follow the P.G.A. Championship Here
description: As the P.G.A. Championship gets set to tee off Thursday morning at Atlanta Athletic Club, inquiring golf minds want to know:

title: Short Night for Rays and Royals
description: Major League Baseballs goal is to keep games from exceeding three hours.

title: TimesCast | August 10, 2011
description: Suspected British looters appear in court; the Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen on Britain's frustrated youth; and instability in European banks drives the latest stock sell-off.

title: Around the State, Exhibits Will Mark 9/11 Anniversary
description: ALBANY  Artifacts from ground zero will go on display at 30 sites around New York this month as part of a statewide effort that the Cuomo administration unveiled on Wednesday to mark the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: A Month of Roman Polanski Films
description: It looks like September will be Roman Polanski month. First the New York Film Festival announced its opening-night selection, on Sept. 30, would be the directors latest project, Carnage, based on the play God of Carnage. Now comes news that the Museum of Modern Art is mounting what it is billing as a complete retrospective of the directors work.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, London, India and Kenya

title: In Madrid, a Tiny Penthouse
description: A diminutive one-bedroom penthouse in Salamanca, a neighborhood in Madrid, is on the market for $963,976.

title: Tiny Screens Bearing Tiny Delights
description: Put Sifteo cubes in front of someone whos never seen them before, and youll think somebody is reading the thesaurus. Cool! Neat! Awesome! Serendipitous!

title: On Trial, Gundlach Stands Defiant
description: LOS ANGELES  In the entranceway to DoubleLine Capitals office here stands a statue of a warrior, a full-scale replica of one of the terra-cotta sculptures that were buried alongside the first Chinese emperor, in order, the legend goes, to guard his treasure in the afterlife.

title: Irish Theater Festival to Offer Premieres and Vegetables
description: Premieres, imported and homegrown works, and at least one vegetable circus will be part of 1st Irish, the annual festival of Irish theater, its organizers announced. The fourth-annual program, which runs from Sept. 5 to Oct. 3, includes work by 16 contemporary Irish playwrights, panel discussions and a film screening.

title: Surface to Air Comes to New York
description: WE chose the name because we thought it was a nice metaphor for creativity, said Jrmie Rozan, the founder of a multidisciplinary creative group whose name, Surface to Air, caused some confusion when it first opened in Paris.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kyrgyzstan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kyrgyzstan, Britain, the West Bank and India.

title: The Hobbit House
description: A rural guesthouse in Montana, along with several much smaller structures dotting the property, was inspired by the Tolkien novels.

title: Perry to Visit Bachmanns Hometown in Iowa
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  Its probably no accident that in his first trip to Iowa, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is going to Michele Bachmanns hometown.

title: House Hunting in ... Madrid
description: A PENTHOUSE WITH PANORAMIC VIEWS OF MADRID

title: Cooking Classes, Live on Google+
description: On Bits, Jenna Wortham visits Lee Allisons Google+ Cooking School, hourlong cooking classes conducted over video chat.

title: Go Ahead, Call Him Chief
description: A look at newspaper editors of stage and screen.

title: Taking Stock and Decluttering
description: Suffering from social networking burnout? Here are some tips to help manage your digital life.

title: For the Plugged-In, Too Many Choices
description: WHEN Jessica H. Lawrence left her job with the Girl Scouts of San Gorgonio Council in Redlands, Calif., to pursue a new life in New York City, she arrived in late January without a job, an apartment or someone to keep her warm through the winter nights.

title: Parcells Returns to ESPN
description: Bill Parcells was hired by ESPN as an N.F.L. studio analyst on Wednesday. Again.

title: Drill, Bb, Drill
description: Sometimes dentists are lion tamers. Kings and presidents open wide for Bernard Touati, but he is careful, he says, to keep his own mouth shut.

title: Homes for $965,000
description: A cabin with a guest house on a Maine island; a 1904 house in Virginia; and a house on the Manatee River in Florida

title: What Befits a Leader in Hard Times? An Intimate Knowledge of Insanity
description: The premise of Dr. Nassir Ghaemis book about leadership and mental illness is simple. It need not be reiterated as frequently as Dr. Ghaemi repeats it. But he begins A First-Rate Madness by writing, This book argues that in at least one vitally important circumstance insanity produces good results and sanity is a problem. To put it only a shade differently: When our world is in tumult, mentally ill leaders function best. Or: In the storm of crisis, complete sanity can steer us astray, while some insanity brings us to port.

title: All the Editors That Are Fit to Spoof
description: IF youre a newspaper editor on stage or screen, you are, as often as not, crusty, loud and easily exasperated.

title: Common Sleep Problem Raises Dementia Risk
description: Sleep-disordered breathing, or sleep apnea, is a common condition characterized by repeated awakenings and pauses in breathing during the night. People with the disorder often snore and gasp during sleep, and it has been associated with hypertension, cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Now a new study suggests it may also be associated with mental decline and dementia.

title: Citys Cable Deals Will Bring Wi-Fi to 32 Parks
description: Frustrated by the fits and starts of trying to make wireless access to the Internet available in parks and other public spaces, city officials have leaned on cable-TV providers to get the job done.

title: The Hobbit House
description: A rural guesthouse in Montana, along with several much smaller structures dotting the property, was inspired by the Tolkien novels.

title: Literary Lions, by Their Cubs
description: IT can be a blessing and a burden to be the daughter of a literary luminary. Miltons daughters secured a kind of immortality by transcribing their blind fathers lengthy masterpiece, Paradise Lost (of which the writer and critic Samuel Johnson wrote, None ever wished it longer than it is). Mary Shelley, the daughter of the political philosopher William Godwin (who encouraged her creativity), grew up to marry the poet Shelley, wrote the novel Frankenstein and transcribed her friend Lord Byrons poems.

title: Japans Tsunami Gave Birth to Faraway Icebergs
description: Japans 9.0-magnitude earthquake in March was so powerful that it shifted the island of Honshu eight feet to the east and caused the deaths of at least 15,600 people. The resulting tsunami also produced a wave that radiated throughout the rest of the worlds oceans.

title: What You Get for $965,000
description: RICHMOND, VA.

title: Eleanor M. Josaitis, Housewife-Turned-Urban Activist, Dies at 79
description: DETROIT  Eleanor M. Josaitis, a former suburban housewife who in 1968 moved her family into a city scarred by riots and helped create a highly regarded nonprofit organization to combat poverty and racism, died on Tuesday in Livonia, Mich. She was 79.

title: Deciding on a Book, and How to Read It
description: I just read a book!

title: TimesCast | U.S. Stocks Drop
description: The Times's Nelson Schwartz on fears over weakness in European banks creating a shaky session for U.S. stocks.

title: At Nationals, a Bid Promises What a Hand Doesnt Deliver
description: At the Summer Nationals the two-day Mixed Board-a-Match Teams was won by Judith Bianco and Win Allegaert of New York, Peggy Kaplan of Minnetonka, Minn., and Petra Hamman and Hemant Lall of Dallas. They finished three and a half points ahead of Lisa and David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Fla.; Josef Blass of Chapel Hill, N.C.; and Ewa Harasimowicz, Anna Sarniak and Marcin Lesniewski from Poland.

title: Profit Slides on Soft Sales, but Cisco Stays Upbeat
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Cisco Systems managed to encourage investors Wednesday despite sliding quarterly profits and flat revenue growth, prompting a nearly 7 percent run-up in its shares during after-hours trading.

title: A new app from the F.B.I.; the NYTs new beta620 site for experimental software projects; tech news.
description: A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation introduces the agencys very first smartphone app, Child ID, which is intended for parents to use in case a child goes missing. Several members of the team on beta620, the new site for experimental features at The Times, stop by to chat about the projects goals and current offerings for Times readers. The weekly serving of technology news includes a look at social medias role in the London riots and a new survey on mobile app security.

title: Turning a Water Tower Into a Home
description: Patrick Mets and his partner, Valrie Lecherf, live with her two daughters in a nearly 100-foot-tall water tower that he converted into a home.

title: Sleepless in Atlanta, Director Is Confident in His Course
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Ken Mangum slept two and a half hours Tuesday night, but not from tossing and turning over concerns about the P.G.A. Championship course that he shepherds.

title: Waging War in Somalia, a Country in Chaos
description: As debate continues in the United States over how to help Somalia, a country whose government is in transition, fight back against Shabab militants, private security companies backed by Washington financing have stepped in to train the African recruits counterterrorism efforts.

title: One Cruel King, by Way of Vivaldi
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Vivaldi would surely find it frustrating, if not a little strange, that his achievement as a composer today is distorted by the cultlike popularity of The Four Seasons. He was indeed a master of Baroque instrumental music. Still, from his early days he was powerfully drawn to the theater and to the voice. He wrote nearly 50 operas. Yet productions are rare. The mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli brought overdue attention to Vivaldis operas with a successful album of arias in 1999 and a subsequent concert tour.

title: One Night Heralds One Day
description: SUMMERS flings may be on their last legs, but not for Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess. Their romance is just blossoming on the silver screen anyway. The attractive co-stars were promoting their romantic film, One Day, based on the best-selling novel of the same title by the English author David Nicholls, on Monday night.

title: Scene City: Post-Premiere Party for One Night
description: The film leaves guests teary-eyed, but the after-party doesnt.

title: Portraits of Grief
description: Explore the Portraits of Grief archive  more than 2,500 impressionistic sketches of the lives lost in the Sept. 11 attacks. With videos by Matthew Orr of six families 10 years later.

title: Waging War in Somalia, a Country in Chaos
description: As debate continues in the United States over how to help Somalia, private security companies backed by Washington financing have stepped in to train the African recruits counterterrorism efforts.

title: Nurturing Weird Families in Tennessee
description: SEWANEE, Tenn.  When writing his first novel two years ago Kevin Wilson didnt have to look far for inspiration. It was running back and forth above his study.

title: A new comedy by Zach Braff, "All New People, and "The Patsy" starring David Greenspan.
description: A new comedy by Zach Braff, "All New People, and "The Patsy" starring David Greenspan.

title: Palin Joins the Iowa State Fair Party
description: The Iowa State Fair just got its newest, late-breaking attraction  and its not even on a stick.

title: A Young Music Executive Takes Over at Motown
description: The fate of Motown, the storied record label now owned by the Universal Music Group, has been the subject of music-industry gossip since May, when news reports surfaced that Sylvia Rhone, its president and one of the most powerful women in the industry, was stepping down. One of the labels biggest stars, Erykah Badu, stirred further controversy when she wrote on Twitter that Motown had folded.

title: The Facebook Scare That Wasnt
description: This may have popped into your Facebook feed Wednesday:

title: Chilling Video of Tanks in Hama, Where Syrian Protesters Rallied Before Crackdown
description: Updated | Friday, 3:12 p.m. As my colleagues Anthony Shadid and Steven Lee Myers report, the Syrian government announced on Wednesday that military forces were being withdrawn from the central city of Hama, apparently marking a pause in the offensive there.

title: Mozarts Jupiter, Still Celestial but More Personal
description: New York classical music audiences are getting to know the Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer, and that, it turns out, is all to the good.

title: On New Yorks Low Seas: Day 3
description: On Wednesday morning, a 79-year-old, shirtless man basked in the sun at the waters edge, reclining on a broad sloping rock at the very northern tip of Manhattan.

title: Left the Volga, Kept the Vulgar
description: If the Soviet authorities had wanted to torture Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn beyond endurance, they would have forced him to watch Russian Dolls.

title: Waging War in Somalia, a Country in Chaos
description: As debate continues in the United States over how to help Somalia, a country whose government is in transition, fight back against Shabab militants, private security companies backed by Washington financing have stepped in to train the African recruits counterterrorism efforts.

title: Handbook on Elegance Takes Form and Flight
description: The San Francisco troupe ODC/Dance actually planted its roots at Oberlin College in Ohio in 1971. (The cryptic initials stand for Oberlin Dance Collective.) In 1976 the company relocated to the West Coast, establishing a strong presence in the Mission District of its home city: along with a theater there are studios, a school and a health clinic for dancers.

title: U.S. Relies on Contractors in Somalia Conflict
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Richard Rouget, a gun for hire over two decades of bloody African conflict, is the unlikely face of the American campaign against militants in Somalia.

title: Lyricism With a Dash of Soft Rock
description: Genius! someone cried from the audience. She meant it; no fooling. Genius!

title: Postcard From Edinburgh: In the Belly of the Beast
description: EDINBURGH  One very recognizable sight at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for the past several years is a giant purple cow lying on its back in Bristo Square on the grounds of Edinburgh University.

title: All-Natural Terraces
description: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

title: Moderate Democrats Ask to Cut Recess Short
description: Recess is usually a time for members of Congress to distance themselves from Washington, in every sense. So its remarkable, especially in this venomously anti-incumbent environment, that four of the Houses most precarious incumbents want to come back to Washington ASAP.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Aug. 11
description: Lisa Perry has designed a series of dresses using Roy Lichtenstein images; what the actress Krysten Ritter is wearing how and other items.

title: Scouting Report
description: POP-UPS

title: A Road Not Taken Leads Back to the P.G.A.
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Steve Stricker played at the University of Illinois in 1989 on a team captained by Mike Small. Their paths have diverged, even as each was lined with golf course grass, and they stayed close enough to serve as best man in each others wedding.

title: When East Met West Under the Buddhas Gaze
description: After what seemed like an endless run of geopolitical roadblocks, The Buddhist Heritage of Pakistan: Art of Gandhara has finally come, six months late, from Pakistan to Asia Society. Is the show worth all the diplomatic headaches it caused? With its images of bruiser bodhisattvas, polycultural goddesses and occasional flights into stratosphere splendor, it is.

title: A Cottage Just Right for Frodo
description: TROUT CREEK, Mont.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: The F.B.I.s App
description: This weeks episode of the Bits: Tech Talk podcast looks at a new smartphone app created by the Federal Bureau of Investigation can help panicky parents get personal details to the authorities. As an F.B.I. spokesman, Paul Bresson, explains on this weeks show, the agencys very first iPhone app is called Child ID. The free app lets parents compile a miniature mobile database of photos and written descriptions of a child right on the phone  where the information can be quickly pulled up and shared with police should that child ever go missing.

title: Art of Gandhara
description: Images from a new exhibit at the Asia Society in New York City.

title: Almost Time to Change the Bulb
description: YOU may have heard that the federal government wants to limit your choice of light bulbs, starting in January.

title: Two Charged in Missing iPhone Prototype Case
