description: It has been over a year since a public spectacle unfolded surrounding a prototype iPhone 4 that waslost in a bar and ended up featured on Gizmodo, the technology blog.

title: Life in a Belgian Water Tower
description: STEENOKKERZEEL, Belgium

title: What Is Driving the Riots?
description: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen talks about the possible motivations of Britain's disgruntled youth.

title: A Star of Animal Planets Tanked on the Art of the Aquarium
description: Fish in the wild can make for compelling television, as evidenced by the Discovery Channels popular Shark Week programming, but how about the domesticated version? Tanked, a new reality show on Animal Planet, follows two high-end aquarium builders, Wayde King and Brett Raymer, who run a family business in Las Vegas called Acrylic Tank Manufacturing (Mr. King is married to Mr. Raymers sister, Heather, another employee). In the Aug. 19 premiere, the men are approached by a casino to build perhaps the worlds first mob-themed fish tank for a new gangland attraction; later, they transform a phone booth into a home aquarium for a married couple.

title: Shopping for Hurricane Lamps With Deborah Ehrlich
description: The designer shops for both high- and low-end hurricane lamps, a staple of outdoor entertaining.

title: Making Design Out of Rubbish
description: TRENTON

title: In St. Petersburg, a New W Hotel
description: The W St. Petersburg, which opened in Russia this spring, is like a Faberg egg, said Mike Tiedy, the senior vice president of global brand design and innovation for Starwood Hotels and Resorts, the company that owns the hotel. It opens up to reveal itself. From the outside, it looks typical of the city, but inside, you see layers of warmth and of reflection.

title: Sales at ABC Carpet & Home and Others
description: Modani Furniture is taking $300 off all king-size beds in its Flatiron store through Aug. 21 (the black Cavali storage bed with hydraulic lift, originally $1,730, is $1,430); 40 East 19th Street; (212) 796-6926 or modani.com.

title: Wood and Leather Pieces, the Old-Fashioned Way
description: Daniel Heer may be genetically predisposed to his line of work. More than 100 years ago, his grandfather Benedikt Heer founded a saddlery in Switzerland, where he also made horsehair mattresses and leather goods. Mr. Heer, 33, also makes horsehair mattresses, leather goods and furniture, albeit from a studio in Berlin. His latest collection to be introduced in the United States is a series of handwoven leather and wood pieces  a stool, a daybed and a table, above  called Keil, or wedge.

title: Hurricane Lamps
description: HURRICANE lamps are a staple of outdoor entertaining, in part because the glass cylinder that surrounds the candle keeps it from burning down too fast, providing hours of flickering light.

title: Animal Farm Chip Clips From David Weeks
description: Created by David Weeks, a designer known for high-end modern light fixtures, Animal Farm chip clips are intended to give one pause while grazing in the kitchen. It came from a kind of humor, Mr. Weeks said. Is this chip clip judging me as I eat more and more potato chips?

title: Roy Mackeys Hammer Art
description: A few years ago, Roy Mackey, a Canadian sculptor who works with sheet steel, began thinking about the hammer-and-nail relationship, and the way one is always driving the other  unfairly, he thought. So he created a Mastercraft hammer with a head impaled by a nail, calling it Revenge.

title: Sample of NBC-Bloomingdale's Partnership
description: In an except from NBC's 2011 Fall Primetime Preview, the host goes on a shopping spree at Bloomingdale's, which has a marketing partnership with NBC this fall.

title: Bloggingheads: American Riots
description: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Reihan Salam of Economics 21 debate the possibility of London-style riots in America.

title: As the Sun Rises, Two Legends Murmur
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The horses look like shadows at dawn as they cross Union Avenue, stopping traffic to shuttle between the Saratoga Race Course on the west side of the street and a timeless oasis on its east side: the Oklahoma training track. Think of it as a Club Med for horsemen who prefer spending their working vacation with their own kind amid an oasis that evokes a bygone year.

title: Waging War in Somalia, a Country in Chaos
description: As debate continues in the United States over how to help Somalia, a country whose government is in transition, fight back against Shabab militants, private security companies backed by Washington financing have stepped in to train the African recruits counterterrorism efforts.

title: Setting Industry Guidelines for Marketing Junk Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Middle-Class Families Face Evictions in Azerbaijan
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan  Before the notices started to arrive, Eldostu Elman had a pretty clear idea how his life would unfold, at least as far as the living arrangements. He would live in the apartment where he was raised, along with his parents, his sons and, when they eventually marry, their families.

title: Isringhausen Is on Verge of a Milestone
description: Jason Isringhausen recorded his first major league save on July 6, 1999. He was then a failed starter in his final weeks on the Mets roster. And he was about to bounce around to three teams in the 11 seasons that followed, making exactly zero starts.

title: Yankees Looking Up, and Down
description: For the past several weeks, as the Red Sox and Yankees have jockeyed for top position in the American League East, the consensus projection has been that the loser would end up with a clear path to the playoffs through the wild card anyway.

title: Members of the Bipartisan Deficit Panel
description: How the deficit panel members have voted on recent budget bills.

title: Italys Government Grapples With Deficit, Its Will Still Uncertain
description: ROME  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis government has kicked into high gear, working over the August holidays to find ways to eliminate Italys budget deficit by 2013 as it pledged to do last week after the country was caught in the crosshairs of the sovereign debt crisis.

title: Coping With Swimmers Sudden Death
description: CRYSTAL LAKE, Ill.  Fred McCullough felt a fathers strongest fears, but he stopped short of panicking when he learned that his daughter, Amy McCullough Martich, had been pulled from the water unconscious and taken to a hospital during the swimming portion of the New York City Triathlon on Sunday.

title: All the Towns a Stage Where the Bards Works Inspire Street Names
description: OTHELLO, Wash.  Zounds! Who goes there? Why, it is Othello, the Moor of Venice. Unlikely as it seems, this is his town  his name is plastered all over this small agricultural community about three hours southeast of Seattle.

title: U.S. Seeks Ideas on Renting Out Foreclosed Property
description: WASHINGTON  Uncle Sam wants you  to rent a house from Uncle Sam.

title: Rachels Last Fund-Raiser
description: Perhaps every generation of geezers since Adam and Eve has whined about young people, and today is no different. Isnt it clear that in contrast to our glorious selves, kids these days are self-absorbed Facebook junkies just a pixel deep?

title: Priest for Womens Ordination Fights His Dismissal
description: A Roman Catholic priest who is campaigning to open the priesthood to women says he will contest a move by his religious order to dismiss him for his dissent. The priest, the Rev. Roy Bourgeois, said he had retained the Rev. Thomas Doyle, a canon lawyer best known as a whistleblower in the priest sexual abuse scandal, to press the case with the Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers. Father Doyle said he would argue that Father Bourgeois had a right to follow his conscience, and that the prohibition on womens ordination was not an infallible church teaching, despite Vatican declarations. A Maryknoll spokesman said its general council would decide the next step.

title: Macys and Polo Ralph Lauren Deliver Strong Quarterly Results
description: So far, at least, the tumbling stock market has not hurt one of the countrys biggest department store companies nor one of its most popular specialty retailers.

title: A Familiar Brand Promotes a New Line of Cheesy and Easy
description: IN a commercial for Velveeta Cheesy Skillets, a new line of just-add-meat pasta dinner kits by Kraft, a casually dressed woman in a suburban home says, Lets go, kids, opens the front door and gasps.

title: Stop Using Chimps as Guinea Pigs
description: Washington

title: U.S. Charges Former Executive of Marvell With Fraud
description: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg NewsMarvell Technology headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: In Auto Test in Europe, Meter Ticks Off Miles, and Fee to Driver
description: EINDHOVEN, the Netherlands  As Sander Van Dedem recalled watching the charges tick up every 10 seconds on the dashboard meter on the way to the airport, he resolved to try public transportation next time. Looking at the money makes you realize that a car isnt always a good idea, said Mr. Van Dedem, a commercial sales manager for I.B.M. here.

title: Verizon Landline Unit at Heart of Strike
description: In the nations largest strike in four years, Verizon Communications and its unions are deeply divided over the companys assertions that its traditional landline business is performing so badly that it needs large-scale concessions.

title: How the Brixton Riot Unfolded
description: How the riot unfolded in the London neighborhood of Brixton.

title: While Reporting Robust Profit, Murdoch Vows to Stay Head of News Corp.
description: While defending his company as it faces accusations of widespread phone hacking in Britain, Rupert Murdoch insisted on Wednesday that he had the backing of News Corporations board and would stay on as its chief executive for the foreseeable future. Meanwhile, his company reported a drop in fourth-quarter profit but a gain for the year.

title: True Throwback: Rays and Royals Play in Under 2 Hours
description: Major League Baseballs goal is to keep games from exceeding three hours.

title: New York Archdiocese Criticizes Sex-Ed Mandate
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York called a new city requirement that sex education be taught at all public middle and high schools troubling on Wednesday, and some Catholic officials said they would advise Catholic parents not to let their children participate.

title: Klinsmann Makes Debut as U.S. Coach
description: PHILADELPHIA  In and around Lincoln Financial Field on Wednesday night, the scent of lighter fluid, grilling meat and spilled beer mixed with something else in the air: curiosity.

title: Hispanic Organizations Give Obama and Congress a C
description: Leaders of the nations major Hispanic organizations, issuing their first progress report on their priority issues, gave C grades on Wednesday to President Obama and to Congress for their performance over the last two years. But they warned that even the small gains Hispanics have seen are at risk of being erased in negotiations by the bipartisan committee that will recommend ways to reduce the federal deficit.

title: Ray Anderson, Businessman Turned Environmentalist, Dies at 77
description: Ray C. Anderson was chairman and chief executive of the worlds largest carpet-tile manufacturer when he read a book that described people like him as thieves and plunderers of the planet. He saw the authors point. He even wept. Then he set out to change things.

title: U.S.-Mexico: The Lineups
description: PHILADELPHIA  The starting lineups for the United States exhibition game against Mexico on Wednesday night at Lincoln Financial Field.

title: Camerons Broken Windows
description: OUR son lives next to a Turkish mosque on Kingsland Road in Hackney, where some of Londons worst mob violence has occurred. When looters rampaged through Hackney last weekend, there were few police officers to stop them and residents had to chase them off with butcher knives, truncheons and baseball bats. Vigilante action succeeded where normal policing failed.

title: As Investors, Chinese Turn to New York
description: Chinese banks have poured more than $1 billion into real estate loans in New York City in the past year. Investors from China are snapping up luxury apartments and planning to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on commercial and residential projects like Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn. Chinese companies have signed major leases at the Empire State Building and at 1 World Trade Center, which is the centerpiece of the rebuilding at ground zero.

title: Even Rivera Has to Face the Ultimate Closer: Time
description: Poke around the database at any newspaper office, and you can find obituaries of the living. For famous people who are old or in poor health, it only makes sense to prepare.

title: A Fund and Its Former Star Clash in Their Legal Battle
description: LOS ANGELES  Jeffrey Gundlach, as the manager of highly successful fixed-income funds, first at Trust Company of the West and more recently at his own business, has been called the king of bonds.

title: Heavily Chaperoned, Mainland Tourists Flock to Taiwan
description: Last year 1.6 million mainland Chinese citizens visited Taiwan, an increase of nearly 70 percent from 2009.

title: As Chinese Visit Taiwan, the Cultural Influence Is Subdued
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  As two dozen anxious Chinese travelers began their maiden voyage across the Taiwan Strait, their tour guide called an impromptu meeting in the airport departure lounge.

title: Board Orders a Repeat of a California Union Election
description: The National Labor Relations Board said Wednesday that it was ordering a rerun of an election by 43,000 Kaiser Permanente employees in California to decide which union should represent them.

title: 6 Republicans Named to Deficit Reduction Panel
description: WASHINGTON  The top Republicans in the House and the Senate appointed six lawmakers on Wednesday to a powerful new Congressional committee that is supposed to find ways to reduce federal budget deficits by at least $1.5 trillion over 10 years.

title: Where Will Growth Come From?
description: Never has the world economy depended so much on the success of developing nations. A misguided focus on budget cutting has plunged the European Union and the United States down paths that will prolong their economic stagnation and perhaps tip them into another recession. The International Monetary Fund was forecasting 2 percent growth in the euro zone before the financial crisis spread to Italy. The Japanese economy is shrinking. Some top economists put the odds of a double-dip recession in the United States at 1 in 2.

title: Statue of Liberty Interior Will Close for a Year
description: After the 9/11 attacks, the federal government closed the Statue of Liberty National Monument, the symbol of a nations dreams and one of the citys best-known and most-visited tourist attractions. Allowing people inside would be unsafe, the National Park Service said, because rescuers might not be able to get them out in an emergency.

title: At the P.G.A. Championship, the Pros Play With the Pros
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  There are golf professionals, and there are professional golfers. The former teach lessons, run local tournaments and take cash for greens fees and other services at the pro shop counter. The latter travel the world on a pro tour, usually have a personal coach or two, and frequently cash some hefty competition checks.

title: Wisconsins Warning to Union-Busters
description: Five months after Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin pushed through a law stripping public unions of their bargaining rights, the Republican Party has paid a price. Two of the state senators who backed the law were thrown out of office by voters on Tuesday and replaced with Democrats. Mr. Walkers opponents did not succeed in turning over the Senate, but it was still an impressive response to the governors arrogant overreach.

title: Bridge Repairs by a Company Tied to Beijing
description: It is, perhaps, an odd juxtaposition: the construction company in charge of the $407 million renovation of the Alexander Hamilton Bridge, named after a founding father and the nations first Treasury secretary, is controlled by the Chinese government.

title: Plan to Deal With Seekers of Asylum Roils Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Just how tough should Australia be in its campaign to dissuade asylum seekers from undertaking perilous voyages to its shores?

title: Lottery Numbers
Sex Education, Long Overdue
description: For nearly 20 years, New York City failed to require sex education in all public schools. Individual schools decided whether students were provided vital programs that could help them avoid disease and teenage pregnancy.

title: A Governor
description: Ive always liked bridges and been a bit phobic about tunnels, particularly those that run under water. So when I read late last year that the Queensboro Bridge was being named after New Yorks former mayor, Edward I.Koch, and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel for Hugh L. Carey, I felt that the former governor was being cheated. After all, the Tappan Zee Bridge, still majestic in its sweep across the Hudson even in its current dilapidated state, was named after Malcolm Wilson, the man Carey defeated for governor in 1974. And Robert F. Kennedy got the Triborough Bridge.

title: 1969-70 Sex Education Curriculum for New York City Schools
description: A New York City Board of Education publication from 1969-70 outlining the sex education curriculum.

title: No Shortage of Intrigue at Last Major
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  The 93rd P.G.A. Championship begins Thursday on the 7,467-yard, par-70 Highlands Course at the Atlanta Athletic Club, where the pressure of competing in the seasons final major championship combined with temperatures in the 90s will create sizzling drama.

title: The U.S. Dollar Is Still the Top Choice
description: It will take more than a debt downgrade and two years of ultra-low interest rates to knock the dollar from its perch as the worlds reserve currency. Despite multiple setbacks, the dollar remains the lingua franca of global commerce and the currency of choice for foreign central banks.

title: Psychiatric Disorder Found in Defendant
description: The man charged in the murder of an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy has a psychiatric disorder that includes schizoid tendencies, doctors evaluating him found in a preliminary examination, according to one of the mans lawyers, Pierre Bazile.

title: Race-Day Medications Face a Ban
description: Race-day medications will be banned in graded 2-year-old stakes beginning in 2012, the American Graded Stakes Committee announced Wednesday.

title: Hedge Funds Get Unfamiliar Taste of Losing

title: Hugh L. Carey, Statesman, Wit and Cook
description: Signing legislation to save Yonkers from default in earlier hard times, Gov. Hugh Carey raised his voice in song: Who cares what banks fail in Yonkers? he trilled at his cabaret best. Long as youve got a kiss that conquers?

title: Fugitive Florida Siblings Arrested After Colorado Crash
description: They were quickly dubbed the Dougherty gang, three gun-toting, fast-driving and allegedly bank-robbing siblings whose exploits invited media comparisons to Bonnie and Clyde.

description: Sarah Lemp is ready for her close-up.

title: Prepare to Kiss, a Bar Mitzvah Is Coming
description: After reading the bio of Ruby Rae Spiegel, a playwright in Series A of the annual new American play festival, this year titled Summer Shorts 5, I confess my first thought was that she must be the daughter of someone rich. How else could a teenager who just graduated from high school get her play produced alongside veterans like Neil LaBute and Christopher Durang at 59E59 Theaters?

title: Living With Loss
description: Shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks, reporters at The New York Times began interviewing friends and relatives of the people whose lives had so suddenly been ended. The result was Portraits of Grief, a collection of brief sketches of the victims. These fresh visits with some of the families were written by Glenn Collins, Anthony DePalma, Robin Finn, Jan Hoffman, N. R. Kleinfield, Maria Newman and Janny Scott, all contributors to the original Portraits of Grief project in 2001.

title: Giants Lose Prolific Receiver to Eagles
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In less than two weeks of training camp, the Giants have dealt with a high-profile contract dispute with one of their best players, a major injury to their first-round pick, the departure of their free-agent tight end and the sudden retirement of a player who spent a couple of days in a practice jersey.

title: Banking Sector Punished Over European Debt

title: With Return to Iowa, Romney Heeds Call of G.O.P. Strategists
description: PELLA, Iowa  Mitt Romney has kept a cautious distance from Iowa after Republicans here helped dash his presidential aspirations four years ago, but he stood before a lush soybean field on Wednesday and declared that his second White House bid depended on a path through this state.

description: There has been market speculation over which of the remaining AAA-rated countries might be next in line for a downgrade.

description: Major League Soccer and NBC Sports on Wednesday announced a three-year agreement to televise 45 league matches and four United States national team games on NBC and the NBC Sports Network, which will be the new name of the current cable channel Versus. The deal will end the leagues relationship with Fox Soccer, which had a one-year deal to carry matches in 2011.

title: Booking Criminals and Comparing Ink
description: PHOENIX  Along with his police-issue pistol and baton, one Phoenix officer has a lightning bolt with him at all times, although it is more ornamental than anything else. Another has a concealed strand of barbed wire. A third has a scorpion, its pincers extended.

title: The Ungarnished Truth

It was Paula Peck, author of the once-invaluable and now-quaint The Art of Good Cooking, who brought to my attention the notion that parsley could play a better, more varied role in cooking if you used it by the handful.

description: PHILADELPHIA  The mystery of the no-name, strictly numbered United States national team jerseys for their game against Mexico on Wednesday night was really not a mystery at all.

title: News Quiz | August 11, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Aug. 11, 1965 | Riots in the Watts Section of Los Angeles
description: On Aug. 11, 1965, rioting broke out in the primarily black neighborhood of Watts in Los Angeles. The violence was sparked by false rumors of police brutality during a traffic stop, though the root causes were long simmering racial tension and anger over poor living conditions.

description: WHO on President Obamas staff are reportedly feeling angry and morose?

title: After a Decade, Moving On From Adolescence
description: Paul Moakley was a sensitive, intellectual 14-year-old when he first arrived at Monsignor Farrell High School, an all-boys Roman Catholic school on Staten Island. For the next four years he studied alongside other adolescents, all of them struggling with what it means to be a man. At an age when fitting in is most important, Mr. Moakley didnt.

title: How Did You Learn About Sex?
description: New York City has mandated that middle school and high school students take sex education. Have you been taught about human sexuality in school? If so, in what grades? What were you taught? How was the material presented? What was left out? If not, do you wish your education had included sex ed?

description: If you see a sleek blue bus rolling into an Amsterdam canal near the Nemo Science Center in Amsterdam, its no accident. The Floating Dutchman, which began service last month, is a tour coach and canal boat rolled into one smart ride.

title: Metropolis II': a Sculpture Moving at 200 M.P.H., Scaled
description: Metropolis II, an installation by the artist Chris Burden, wont be on view at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art until November, but thanks to a film by Henry Joost and Ariel Schulman, it already has become one of the most discussed pieces of art this year.

title: Bali Bombings Suspect, Extradited From Pakistan, Arrives in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA  One of Southeast Asias most wanted terrorism suspects was flown back to Indonesia on Thursday, months after his arrest by the Pakistani authorities in the same town where Osama Bin Laden was killed.

title: In the Good Company of Siblings
description: We were pleased to see Susan Dominuss article on conjoined twins included on Longform.orgs list of sibling-related coverage culled from various magazines and newspapers. Max Linsky, who helped found the Web site, writes: What happens when the sibling bond is that strong? Incredible works of art. Tremendous professional success. And, at least occasionally, cold-blooded murder. Well, the Hogan twins are only 4 years old, so give them a break. But check out their story and the other fascinating ones on this list.

title: An iPhone TV Remote Priced Right
description: There are any number of apps that turn your iPhone into a remote. My problem with them is that they generally require the purchase of hardware that costs as much as a versatile remote like the Harmony 650, which can be programmed to run a complex stack of various gear.

title: Chinas Rail Safety Review Unlikely to Stop Existing Projects
description: HONG KONG  Chinas response to a deadly high-speed rail accident on July 23 is closely mirroring its reaction to meltdowns at three Japanese nuclear reactors after a powerful earthquake and tsunami in March.

title: One Way to Close the Sale of a Business
description: I once worked with a man whose license plate read BCRE8VE (translation: Be Creative). It was the perfect mantra for a director of advertising  and equally fitting for business owners and deal makers navigating todays business-for-sale marketplace. While there has been a slight uptick in business sales of late, getting a deal done with tight credit markets, depressed valuations and skittish investors continues to require as much art as science.

title: Chinese Let Currency Rise Against the Dollar
description: HONG KONG  Chinas currency staged a small but unexpected rally this week, as the countrys central bank allowed it to rise 0.72 percent against the dollar, with most of the move coming Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Five Things to Watch for in Iowa Debate
description: AMES, Iowa  Eight Republican presidential contenders will gather on a stage here Thursday night for a two-hour, high-stakes exchange just two days before the first real contest of the nominating process.

description: You could feel the disappointment. It was palpable.

title: To Stem Its Value, Swiss Central Bank Considers Pegging the Franc to the Euro
description: PARIS  Switzerlands central bank signaled Thursday it was prepared to consider a once-unthinkable step: pegging the nations massively overvalued currency to the euro, at least temporarily.

title: Four European Nations to Curtail Short-Selling
description: A European market regulator announced Thursday night that short-selling of stocks in several countries would be temporarily banned in an effort to stop the tailspin in the markets.

title: AOLs Sinking Stock Feeling
description: I think if you buy some AOL stock right now, youre going to make a lot of money, Arianna Huffington told Michael Arrington of TechCrunch at a conference in New York on May 23.

title: Finding Ancient Treasure: Just Another Day for Putin

title: The Trouble With Financial Stocks
description: Sell now  ask questions later.

title: Can Jeremy Grantham Profit From Ecological Mayhem?
description: Sitting in a Panera in Bostons financial district in early July with Jeremy Grantham, I suddenly found myself considering how I might safeguard my childrens and notional grandchildrens future by somehow engineering the U.S. annexation of Morocco. Grantham, the founder and chief strategist of the asset-management firm GMO, was reading aloud from a rough draft of his next quarterly letter to investors, in which he ranks some long-term crises of resource limitation along a scale from merely serious to dangerous.

title: The September Issue
description: Like many women nowadays, I shop for my bikinis in the snow and boots in the blistering heat. You could say Ive adapted. There is a despairing time lapse between when collections are shown (spring in September and fall in February) and when those pieces are sold. (Fall hits stores as early as July, and spring in February.) And thanks to instantaneous gratification sites like Moda Operandi and Gilt Groupe, avid customers can now begin preordering directly from their favorite designers. I start planning the moment they walk down the runway, says the designer Margherita Missoni. But some months, like September, linger in a sort of shopping purgatory. The idea of scouring the racks while waiting for sales and holiday items to hit the floor seems outdated. And tired. So while we dally in the off-season, how does one find (and love) things to buy now?

title: Thelonious Monk Institute to Honor Aretha Franklin
description: Aretha Franklin will be honored at a gala concert in Washington to mark the 25th anniversary of the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz, the institute announced Thursday. The concert will be held Sept. 12 at the Kennedy Center.

title: Thursday Reading: Salmonella Lurks In Pet Food, Too
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Wiring Roaches, the Better to Teach Them to Dance
description: Wednesday morning, in a corridor of Cooper Unions trendiest academic building, a three-inch-long cockroach  thin wires protruding from where antennas normally would, miniature circuit board attached squarely to its head  lay surrounded by teenagers.

title: Morning Buzz
description: For more local news from The Times, including a surge in Chinese investments in New York City real estate, the impending closing of the Statue of Liberty for the next year for renovation and an apparently random attack on an assemblymans sport utility vehicle as he drove with his 7-year-old son in Brooklyn, see the N.Y./Region section.

title: Stew in Africa: Colors and Collaborations That Wont Fade
description: Stew, the singer-songwriter behind the musical Passing Strange, was recently in East Africa to serve as a creative adviser for the Sundance Institute Theater Program on Manda Island, off the coast of Kenya. The two-week program provided East African artists with support and creative guidance, and was modeled on a similar program run by the Sundance Institute in North America.

title: Stricker Leads, Woods Capsizes in P.G.A. First Round
description: The first round of the P.G.A. Championship gave few hints of drama when it started Thursday morning. But as the day got hotter and a little bit of chaos broke out, Steve Stricker was one of the few to steer completely clear of it. He not only came a stroke shy of setting a major championship record with a 63, he played Atlanta Country Clubs most diabolical holes without a hiccup.

title: Time Ramps Up Synergy for 9/11 Anniversary Coverage
description: Sometimes a magazine and a Web site just arent enough to do justice to a truly arresting story. Thats when being part of a giant media conglomerate like Time Warner  with a movie studio, television channels and cable news outlets  helps.

title: Chinas Chosen Lama Visits Monastery Town
description: BEIJING  A Chinese-designated Buddhist lama who Communist Party officials hope will become a spiritual leader for Chinas five million Tibetans arrived in a monastery town in the northwestern province of Gansu on Thursday accompanied by a formidable police presence, and a skeptical crowd was forced to greet him with prayer flags and smiles, residents and exile groups said by telephone.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Hedge Funds Get Unfamiliar Taste of Losing | For hedge funds, just one week can change their entire year.

title: Theater Talkback: Unforgettable Summer Kisses
description: Sam  the piano player who stirred up painful memories by singing As Time Goes By in Casablanca  might disagree. But in the theater, as in life, a kiss is hardly just a kiss. Whether bestowed on the lips, the cheek, the hand or any other part of the anatomy, the simple application of the lips to someone elses body can illuminate all sorts of different, and often contradictory, feelings.

title: Listen Up | Foster the People
description: On stage, Foster the People could easily be mistaken for a hipster rock group from Brooklyn, except that the musicians are just a bit too muscular to qualify as Williamsburg hipsters. The band comprises the lead singer and songwriter Mark Foster, the drummer Mark Pontius and Cubbie Fink on bass, who came together in Los Angeles in 2009 when the trio began making music that Foster jokingly describes as if Bryan Wilson and the Aphex Twin had a band baby that grew up in Motown.

title: More Children Hospitalized With Skin Infections
description: Severe skin infections that resist antibiotics have become one of the most common reasons children are hospitalized, new data show.

title: Franc Thoughts on Long-Run Fiscal Issues
description: Regular readers of comments will notice a continual stream of criticism from MMT (modern monetary theory) types, who insist that deficits are never a problem as long as you have your own currency. I really dont want to get into that fight right now, because for the time being the MMT people and yours truly are on the same side of the policy debate. Right now it really doesnt matter at all whether the United States issues zero-interest short-term debt or simply prints zero-interest dollar bills, and concern about crowding out is just bad economics.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Is France In Trouble?
description: I continue to be frustrated by reporting on financial turmoil that seems determined to portray this as a sovereign debt thing despite lots of contrary evidence. The latest is the talk about France on the brink.

title: AMR Plans American Eagle Spinoff
description: American Airlines plans for American Eagle have sometimes seemed like a departure on the flight board that never quite gets to the runway. Since 2007, the company has said several times that it was considering a sale or a spinoff of American Eagle, its regional airline unit.

title: Bragging About the Kids
description: What was the last story you told about your children? Whom did you tell it to? Did they think you were making conversation, or boasting?

title: On Race and Hollywood
description: Nelson George discusses the ways American movies portray race relations during the struggle for civil rights.

title: Graffiti Exhibition Sets Attendance Records at Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles
description: An exhibition that explored the history of graffiti and street art brought record-setting crowds into the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, the museum said. The show, Art in the Streets, drew 201,352 visitors from April 17 through Aug. 8, the highest exhibition attendance in the museums history.

title: Silver Lining
description: Dirk Schoenberger walks into the lobby of the Bowery Hotel wearing Pradas infamous platform espadrille wingtips  an odd choice considering that Schoenberger is the creative director of the sports style division at Adidas, a company known for its footwear. What he likes about the Pradas, he explains, is the mix of sharp tailoring and casual leisure. Having held his post for little over a year, he has pushed Adidas to hybridize in a similar manner. When Im in Berlin and I see how the young guys and girls are dressing, none of them are wearing sneakers anymore. So you think, if these are the target consumers, and we are only selling sneakers, well, what are we going to do? The answer may be found in Adidas SLVR. Priced somewhere between Originals and Y-3 (also under Schoenbergers purview), the line has been reimagined for fall under his personal design stewardship. Its amazing for such a big company to be so open for discussions, he says. With SLVR, it is a new approach but still very much in the language of Adidas.

title: The Good, the Bad, Not the Ugly
description: Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer your questions in a monthly column that appears in print and online. Here they take on questions about actors and stars. You can write them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: Met Cancels Plans to Loan Works to Moscows Kremlin Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has officially canceled plans to loan works by the fashion designer Paul Poiret to Moscows Kremlin Museum, as part of the ongoing fallout from a legal dispute that has halted all loans from Russian to American museums. Its really a matter of fairness and equity, the Mets spokesman, Harold Holzer, said. As long as Russias loan embargo is in place, Mr. Holzer said, this museum believes it can no longer lend to Russian museums. The Met was to lend 35 Poiret works to the show, which is scheduled to open at the Moscow museum on September 6. The cancellation of the loans was first reported by the New York Observer.

He listened intently to every detail of their travails and always ended the visits by asking if they still had any unanswered questions.

title: Now Playing | Plastique Ludique
description: At Les Arts Decoratifs in Paris, the summer crowds have gravitated to the Hussein Chalayan show and the exhibition of highlights from Ralph Laurens car collection. I was glad to see both on a recent trip, but I was also lucky to spot a sign for another, less-heralded exhibition at the museum. Plastique Ludique (Playful Plastic), which runs until Nov. 6, presents the work of the Czech toy designer Libuse Niklova (1934-1981), whose work with plastics, particularly in the 1960s and 70s, changed the look  and the nature  of toys in her native country. Niklova believed that children should be able to play as creatively as possible, and the development of plastics after World War II offered a helpful tool. Her inflatable buffalo, giraffe and elephant, with their simplified, graphic silhouettes and bright, pop colors, could be used as chairs or pool toys for small children. (The three have been reissued in limited numbers and are for sale at the museums shop.) And Niklovas ingenious use of pleated plastic piping produced animals with accordion-like midsections that squealed when squeezed. In contrast to the Chalayan and Lauren exhibitions, which are about the more expensive pleasures of the material world, Plastique Ludique offers a surprising, refreshing look at a more modest  yet no less inventive  endeavor.

And in Los Angeles, ecologists studying the citys ecohydrology have calculated that planting a million new trees, an idea with fairly universal appeal, would have the drawback of increasing water consumption by 5 percent.

title: Really Now, Whats So Bad About Auto-Tune Pop?
description: One thing you learn when you spend a bunch of time on YouTube looking up songs that use the electronic pitch-correction algorithm known as Auto-Tune is that a lot of people really hate Auto-Tune. Which is weird. Its just a sound  obnoxious in the hands of the untalented, occasionally amazing in the hands of the amazing. Hating it is like hating falsettos, or the accordion. And, O.K., given the current omnipresence of the sound in pop music, its like hating the accordion during some strange period of accordion-fascism during which everyones paying top dollar to sound like early Los Lobos or Weird Al. Rap and R&B may have run with Auto-Tune more than other genres, but these days you cant get away from it, even by listening to metal, country or Moroccan music.

title: 36 Hours in Marseille
description: FIRST the bad news: Marseille is not Paris. Unlike its culture-rich rival, Frances second-largest city has no world-class museums, must-see monuments or internationally renowned chefs. Now the good news: Marseille is not Paris. Kissed by the Mediterranean, Marseille can claim an un-Parisian combination of near-constant sun, miles of beaches and an ethnic mix  French, North African, Italian, Corsican, Armenian  that lends a flavor unlike anywhere else in the country. No wonder the rest of France calls it Plante Mars. And the news gets better: Named a European Capital of Culture for 2013, the historically gritty port is looking up, thanks to a waterfront renovation, a sleek new tram system, a first wave of design hotels, a generation of young restaurant and night-life impresarios and a homegrown fashion scene. More than ever, there is life on Mars.

But that hasnt happened yet. Shes still at home, her hair a nest of blond curls, speaking longingly into a make-up mirror: I always dreamed to be onstage. And people was looking at me.

But when the noted course toughener Rees Jones completed a configuration in 2001, Mickelson was no fan of the finished product. He seems to have never forgiven Jones, later disapproving of a makeover at another cherished greensward, Cog Hills Drubsdread in suburban Chicago.
