title: The Caucus | Romney Pushes Back
description: Jeff Zeleny reports from Iowa on an unusual authentic moment for Mitt Romney and outlines the stakes for the Republican candidates at Thursday night's debate.

title: The Struggles of Rivera Cast a Pall Over a Win
description: On a normal day, a late tie-breaking grand slam by Robinson Cano, another big home run from Curtis Granderson and a record-tying save by Mariano Rivera would leave Yankees fans with feelings of joy and satisfaction.

title: Indians Winter Event Makes Room for College Hockey
description: Indians fever has returned to Cleveland this season, something the team hopes to keep burning during the frigid winter months. For the second year in a row, the Indians will host Snow Days, a winter sports wonderland, at Progressive Field.

title: Learning About the Marketplace and Entering It
description: In a metaphorical land not far from reality, a beautiful palace rises from a desolate plain of want and envy. It is surrounded by an invisible but impregnable wall and a moat full of sharks and crocodiles. Inside, successful artists work in spacious, light-filled studios and dally in sensual pleasures.

title: Rediscovered at the Altar of Art
description: Any visual artist fated to be a one-hit wonder would be beyond lucky if that hit were as marvelous as The Fulbright Triptych, Simon Dinnersteins overlooked masterpiece of 1970s realism. This crackling, obsessive showboat of a painting, dreamed up during a decade when the medium supposedly teetered on the brink of death, is a three-panel autobiographical allegory of life, love and art that measures 14 feet across.

title: Travel Adventures From Your iPad
description: TRVL, an interactive app for the iPad, is not your traditional magazine. More than a digital alternative to glossy travel magazines, each issue is a self-contained feature story.

title: Out-Magritting Magritte, or at Least Coming Close
description: La Carte dAprs Nature at the Matthew Marks Gallery in Chelsea is the kind of magical, intuitive show that could only have been devised by an artist. Using the Belgian surrealist painter Ren Magritte as a kind of divining rod, it finds surrealism in some unlikely places.

title: When Agents Play Two Roles
description: DO you know whom your broker is really working for? The natural assumption is that the agent is working for you, but the situation may not be that simple. There are sellers agents, buyers agents, brokers agents, dual agents and even dual agents with designated sales agents  which all sounds more like the cast of characters in a spy film than people involved in a real estate transaction.

title: Shining New Light on a Modernist
description: MONTREAL  The architect Pierre Jeanneret spent his career in the large shadow of his famous cousin, Charles-douard Jeanneret, better known as Le Corbusier. These Swiss-born men set up a Paris office in the 1920s, and Jeanneret, whose archive is only now becoming publicly accessible, contributed to renowned Le Corbusier designs like tubular steel chairs and cubic villas on stilts.

title: New Jersey Trains Hobbled by Derailment in Queens
description: Another evening commute, another schedule-snarling commuter train derailment.

title: Goodyear Claims Breakthrough in Tire Self-Inflation Technology
description: Motorists who never experienced the delights of central tire inflation afforded by the Hummer H1, Arnold Schwarzeneggers favorite S.U.V., may yet have their opportunity.

title: Newest New Yorkers at Play
description: THEY are young, talented and driven: artists who want to make their mark on the world. You see them in New York more than any other city in the country, and their New York is different from yours and mine. Its hipper and faster paced, open to experience. If they want to see a folk-singing duo, and their iPhones tell them to cross two highway lanes on foot to get there, consider them crossed.

title: A Spectacular Rise and Fall
description: Vroom. Senna, Asif Kapadias documentary biography of the Brazilian racecar driver Ayrton Senna, a three-time Formula One world champion, virtually puts you in the lap of its subject as he hurtles like a speeding bullet along the fastest tracks.

title: Warren Edges Closer to Senate Run
description: BOSTON  Elizabeth Warren has enlisted two former aides to Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts to help her assess whether to run for the United States Senate and will make a decision after Labor Day, a Democrat familiar with her efforts said Thursday.

title: Planet of the Hominids
description: 6:35 p.m. | Updated Last weekend, I took my two sons, 13 and 21, to see Rise of the Planet of the Apes, which we thoroughly enjoyed on several levels. Its a rousing slave revolt, an entertaining techno-thriller, a drama about a dysfunctional household (chimp included) dealing with disability and job-related stresses (in the conflicted genetic engineer played by James Franco). (Manohla Dargis liked it, too, as did my sons favorite critics, the team at Spill.com.

title: Romney Heckled at Iowa State Fair
description: At the Iowa State Fair, a small group of angry hecklers called on Mitt Romney to support raising taxes on the wealthy to help fund social entitlement programs.

title: Okra Stew
description: Mark Bittman makes a stew with pork that will appeal to okra lovers and haters alike.

title: Borrowing in Retirement
description: HOUSEHOLDS headed by people 65 and older make up the largest segment of the population of homeowners in this country, and many of them will continue to make home purchases in or near retirement  in many cases, trading in a larger suburban house for a smaller apartment or town house in a more urban area.

title: The Marilyn Catalog, Revisited Whimsically
description: Has any love goddess had more firsthand experience being a plaything coveted and discarded by spoiled male collectors of beauty than Marilyn Monroe? In 1920 Irving Berlin wrote After You Get What You Want, one of the best songs ever written about the heart of a fickle playboy, which Monroe sang 34 years later in the movie Theres No Business Like Show Business.

title: TimesCast | East Jerusalem Housing
description: August 11, 2011 - Israel approves construction of a contentious 1,600-apartment complex in East Jerusalem, which could undercut efforts to salvage long-stalled Middle East peace talks.

title: C.I.A. Is Disputed on Civilian Toll in Drone Strikes
description: WASHINGTON  On May 6, a Central Intelligence Agency drone fired a volley of missiles at a pickup truck carrying nine militants and bomb materials through a desolate stretch of Pakistan near the Afghan border. It killed all the militants  a clean strike with no civilian casualties, extending what is now a yearlong perfect record of avoiding collateral deaths.

title: Q&A: Boosting the Speed of a Windows 7 PC
description: Q.

title: Hints of a Bachmann-Perry Clash
description: AMES, Iowa  With news Thursday that Rick Perry is making his presidential campaign official, the coming clash between him and Michele Bachmann is quickly moving into the open.

title: The Minimalist: Okra Stew
description: If you like okra, which is in season now, youll probably like this recipe for okra stew, because, well, its okra. If you hate okra, youll also probably like this recipe for okra stew, because the okra practically disappears.

title: Perry Fund-Raising Team Goes on the Offensive
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas wont officially announce his presidential campaign until Saturday. But his fund-raising team isnt wasting any time.

title: Latest Insider Trading Case Tied to Disney Deal
description: 8:57 p.m. | Updated

title: Two Interpretations of New York, One Layered With Tart Observations
description: If classical music in its traditional forms is scarce at Lincoln Center Out of Doors, the series has always had a place for new music of the Downtown persuasion. Its principal offering from that world this summer was a double bill of idiosyncratic violinist-composers on Wednesday evening. Todd Reynolds opened the program, sharing the stage with Sxip Shirey, a composer and multi-instrumentalist, and Adam Matta, who makes percussion sounds vocally. Laurie Anderson closed the show with The Real New York, a work that she wrote in recent weeks.

title: 'Crazy Sexy Cancer' Trailer
description: Kris Carr documented her battle with Stage 4 epithelioid hemangioendothelioma and her crazy, sexy life following the diagnosis. Video courtesy of Kris Carr.

title: The No-Surprises Move
description: MOVING your worldly possessions to a new home is always fraught with potential complications, but in New York City, seemingly simple tasks like packing, parking and unloading are complicated by street-cleaning regulations, unexpectedly narrow doorways and rules about using the elevator.

title: On New Yorks Low Seas: Day 4
description: Bounding through the lively chop on the Long Island Sound on Thursday, the Manhattan skyline seemingly soaked by salty spray, it seemed a world of watery wonder. And then suddenly came an abrupt wake-up call.

title: Caucus Video: Romneys Authentic Moment; Iowa Debate Preview
description: Jeff Zeleny reports from Iowa on an unusual authentic moment for Mitt Romney when he responds to a question regarding social security. Also, a look at the stakes for the many Republican candidates at Thursday nights debate.

title: The Lonely I.P.O. of Carbonite
description: David Friend's business is built around preparing for the worst-case scenario. Perhaps that's why Carbonite was one of the few scheduled initial public offerings that went ahead this week.

title: In Between the Terrorist Threats, Plenty of Time for Hanky-Panky
description: Cinemax  the network and the punch line  has always had a businesslike approach to original programming. Sex-businesslike, that is. The Best Sex Ever, Sex Games Cancun, Zanes Sex Chronicles: its late-night offerings have made it the soft-core cathouse of premium cable.

title: A Weekday Place for a Weekending Man
description: FIFTEEN years ago, when Warren Dakin was transferred to New York from Toronto, he and his wife, Jennifer, checked out a two-bedroom rental in a prewar building on East 86th Street. A friend from New York accompanied them, and told them that we had to take it right away because it had a stackable washer and dryer, Mrs. Dakin said.

title: Late-Night Audience Splinters
description: With George Lopez becoming its latest casualty, the war for late-night ratings supremacy rages on without a clear victor.

title: TV Cameras and Falling Rocks
description: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

title: The Lonely I.P.O. of Carbonite
description: David Friends business is built around preparing for the worst-case scenario. Perhaps thats why his company, Carbonite, was still willing to go public during an especially volatile week for stocks. Mr. Friend talks about Carbonite and its market debut.

title: A Gay Oasis, With Beer and Barbecue
description: Walk past the low-ceilinged bar, the jukebox and the pool table. Keep going, beyond the stage where Queeraoke erupts every Tuesday, and right out the back door. Feel the sunshine on your face and inhale the relatively fresh air (this is New York, after all) that makes Metropolitan the most popular gay hangout in Brooklyn on summer Sunday afternoons.

title: Victory, the Personal Kind
description: ICUDDA been a contenduh was how Marlon Brando once put it.

title: In Future Math Whizzes, Signs of Number Sense
description: Children as young as 3 have a number sense that may be correlated with mathematical aptitude, according to a new study.

title: Contrasting Reports of Drone Strikes
description: Obama administration officials say the Central Intelligence Agencys drone program in Pakistan has killed about 600 militants and no civilians since May 2010. The Bureau of Investigative Journalism in London, a Web-based reporting project, counted at least 45 civilian deaths. Below are the contrasting accounts of four strikes. SCOTT SHANE

title: Living Around | Gramercy Park
description: Though proximity isnt the same as access, the privately owned parks quiet presence in the neighborhood lends the surrounding blocks a certain hominess.

title: In Southern Heat, Ishikawa Finds Water, but No Relief
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Ryo Ishikawa made quite a splash Thursday at the P.G.A. Championship. In fact, he made a half-dozen of them.

title: Feel Free to Use the Name, at Least
description: PASSERS-BY peeking through the iron fence into the two-acre 19th-century gem known as Gramercy Park may find plenty to tantalize: statues ringed with landscaping, elaborate birdhouses and pathways invitingly empty of other New Yorkers. Polite-but-firm signs just inside the gates make clear what kind of rowdiness is not allowed: dog-walking and stepping on the grass, among other things.

title: Brooklyn Library Branches Will Extend Hours
description: Despite a $1.1 million budget cut this year, Brooklyn Public Library branches are increasing, not cutting, their hours.

title: Inside Nicholson Bakers Sexual Utopia
description: There are many ways into the House of Holes, and they are all holes. Such is the logic that guides Nicholson Bakers hilarious and extremely dirty book of raunch, House of Holes, and its more than enough. One woman enters this novels sex spa extraordinaire through an O-shape made by the fingers of a severed arm. Others fall through the hole in a golf green, or a peppermill. Somebody is funneled through a cocktail straw. Next thing, they all arrive at one of the loopier spots in literary memory  Platos Retreat by way of the Magic Mountain, or maybe the Oneida Community via Fantasy Island.

title: Portraits and Stone
description: A look at the work of the photographer Mariana Cook.

title: New Eyes at Play
description: Members of PigPen Theater find adventure on Governors Island.

title: A TV Host Seeks Fluff, but Real Life Intrudes
description: Resetting The Arabian Nights in modern-day Cairo, Scheherazade, Tell Me a Story presents an environment of oppressive politics and repressed women.

title: The Teenage Years in the Tumult of Afghanistan
description: In 2002 Phil Grabsky went to Afghanistan and made The Boy Who Plays on the Buddhas of Bamiyan, a documentary about a year in the life of Mir, an 8-year-old with boundless energy and a blinding smile. His family, dislocated by war, lived in grinding poverty in a cave near where the Taliban had destroyed centuries-old stone Buddhas; the family granted Mr. Grabsky an alarming degree of access, and the resulting film had a sharp focus, a fluid rhythm and a touch of strange beauty, abetted by the towering cliffs with their empty alcoves for statues.

title: A Perp Walk on Twitter
description: Lifting a page from the hackers handbook, the Greater Manchester Police in Britain are naming and shaming rioters on their Twitter feed.

title: Scenes From the Iowa State Fair
description: In the hours before they would offer rhetorical red meat during a debate on Thursday, several Republican presidential contenders encountered the other white meat at festivities in Des Moines.

title: A Battle for Indias Soul
description: Nothing less than Indias soul is at stake in Prakash Jhas Aarakshan, a Hindi movie about the battle  as intense as any gang war  between a righteous teacher and the hucksters who would make education a commodity available only to the privileged.

title: One Last Bow for Violet and Bobby
description: They came back for a curtain call.

title: Cellphone Market Share Shifting
description: Nokia is about to drop from its position as the leading cellphone maker in the world, according to the latest sales estimates made by the technology analysts at Gartner.

title: A Brush With Internet Fame
description: It would be easy to be lulled into thinking that Damn!, a documentary about a fringe New York gubernatorial candidate, is just a mindless profile of a quirky guy. But by the end of this smart, subtle film by Aaron Fisher-Cohen, you realize that its actually a deft look at flash-in-the-pan fame and the emptiness at the heart of it.

title: Postcrisis, New Investment Tactics to Lure the Ultra Wealthy
description: Funds of hedge funds are changing their ways.

title: The Year the East Cried 'Freedom!'
description: A cascade of historic events climaxed in November with the fall of the Berlin Wall as East Europeans broke free of Communist rule.

title: Recalling When a Wall Split a City Apart
description: BERLIN  Gnter Schlusche stood in what was once the foundation of Bernauer Street 10A, right in front of the cinder blocks and mortar that remained, just as they had half a century earlier, when East German workers bricked up the houses windows the day the Berlin Wall went up.

title: Young Tourists Marooned in a California Town
description: A Japanese brother and sister, tourists in America, are momentarily stranded in a rural California town; the brother resumes their trip, but the sister, who speaks no English, stays on for a while, interested in the residents and flattered by their interest in her. Thats the premise of Mike Otts second feature, Littlerock, an out-of-pocket production shot on video and partly improvised, using mostly nonprofessional actors.

title: Death Will Not Be Cheated
description: The fifth installment of the Final Destination series begins with the usual 10 minutes of fun. An elaborately choreographed disaster, in this case a bridge collapse, eliminates a group of teenagers in entertainingly disgusting ways before being revealed as a premonition. This allows some of the group to avoid death, so that they can be killed again  in slower, more stomach-churning fashion  over the rest of the film.

title: Both Sides Promote Romneys Heckling Response
description: AMES, Iowa  It took the Democratic National Committee only seven hours to turn comments by Mitt Romney at the Iowa State Fair into an attack video.

title: The Gloves Come Off at Iowa Debate
description: AMES, Iowa  Fox News anchors are testing the microphones. Reporters have assembled in a cavernous room with hundreds of folding tables and chairs. Senior aides to the candidates are finishing up their efforts at pre-debate spin.

title: Nigerians Receive First Payments for Children Who Died in 1996 Meningitis Drug Trial
description: The first payments were made Thursday to Nigerian families who lost children during a 1996 trial of an experimental meningitis drug, and Pfizer, which had tested the drug, a new antibiotic, said it was pleased that payments were finally being made under a settlement reached two years ago.

title: Outsiders in Albuquerque
description: The first thing you notice about Bad Posture is that its unstudiedly cool: laid-back, observant and rather shady, it cares so little for your attention that you cant stop watching.

title: How to Make That College Essay Special
description: To the Editor:

title: A Town Built for 30
description: The 30-odd residents of the tiny town of Darwin, Calif., prefer to keep themselves to themselves, as evidenced by the No services ahead sign theyve erected to discourage visitors. We can only marvel, then, at their candor when faced with Nick Brandestinis camera in Darwin, a droll and dusty portrait of a place where privacy is prized and boundaries respected.

title: Send Us Your Tailgate Recipes
description: Last year, we asked readers to share images of their college tailgating experiences, and we got a sweeping look at the sometimes extravagant fun going on before games. This season, we thought we would zero in on whats being served before kickoff on Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Libya and the Legal Adviser: A State Dept. View
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighborhood Joint | Metropolitan Bar
description: The lush backyard at Metropolitan Bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, makes it a popular gay summer hangout.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Downtown New York can be a revolving door for entertainers, all hoping to find an audience before their turn is over. Some move up. Others move out. Either way, its an excellent place to find the next great talent, and usually at little cost.

title: Corporations Are People, Romney Tells Iowa Hecklers Angry Over His Tax Policy
description: DES MOINES  Emerging on the campaign trail in Iowa after largely shunning the state, Mitt Romney was confronted on Thursday by hecklers on corporate tax policy and told one of them, Corporations are people, my friend.

title: Republicans Debate in Iowa
description: Eight Republican presidential contenders gathered on a stage in Iowa Thursday night for a two-hour, high-stakes exchange just two days before the first real contest of the nominating process.

title: The Bigger Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets and Burress Are Taking Baby Steps
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan said Thursday that he planned to play receiver Plaxico Burress for a few snaps in Mondays preseason opener against the Houston Texans, even though Burress continues to be limited in practice because of an ankle injury.

title: The 30 Who Died Together
description: The faces of the 30 American military personnel killed when the Taliban shot down a Chinook helicopter in Afghanistan.

title: Rick Perrys Unanswered Prayers
description: A few months ago, with Texas aflame from more than 8,000 wildfires brought on by extreme drought, a man who hopes to be the next president took pen in hand and went to work:

title: A Disservice to Theology
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Road, and Out of the Red
House Tour: New Fairfield, Conn.
description: S. P. Wijegoonaratna and his wife, Michele, bought a 1920s house and transformed the property into a modern waterfront escape.

title: House Tour: New Fairfield, Conn.
description: WHAT Two-bedroom house and a two-bedroom cottage on Ball Pond

title: What the Ravens Wrought
description: WHEN Amanda Curtis was a little girl growing up in Kennebunkport, Me., she inhabited something of an enchanted world, albeit one tinged with sadness.

title: Battle for Libya | Aug. 11, 2011
description: A Libyan rebel fighter lay in an ambulance at a field hospital near Bir al-Ghanem after being shot in the stomach during a firefight in western Libya.

title: Syrian Security Forces Kill 12 People in Attack on a Western Town, Activists Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces killed 12 people on Thursday in an attack on a western town near the border with Lebanon and stormed another town in the northwest, human rights activists in Syria reported, and President Bashar al-Assad faced new pressure from Turkey and the United States to stop his harsh repression of the protest movement challenging his rule.

title: Bloggingheads: Perry the Executioner
description: Tim Fernholz, left, of Good magazine and Kevin D. Williamson of National Review debate a controversial death-penalty case in Texas.

title: Preparing for State Tests, to a Hip-Hop Beat
description: The team of six high school girls new to America sat frozen waiting for the next missing lyric, whiteboard and marker at the ready. They glanced toward their classmates, who sat nearby, in two competing teams.

title: No Room in the P.G.A. Field
description: At a typical Grand Slam event, three to five players who are on site withdraw before Thursdays opening round, most often citing injuries or personal issues.

title: We Want Cake, Too
description: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

title: Sometimes, Inflation Is Not Evil
description: Sometimes, you have to unlearn your lessons.

title: Nordstrom and Kohls Expect Profit to Rise More
description: Despite this weeks stock market gyrations, two more retailers said on Thursday that not much had changed in their stores and that the rest of the year continued to look promising.

title: The Hijacked Crisis
description: Has market turmoil left you feeling afraid? Well, it should. Clearly, the economic crisis that began in 2008 is by no means over.

title: The Risk of Parking in Safe Havens
description: Financial lifeboats are starting to get crowded. Investors in droves have been seeking safety from sinking stocks. But some vessels of refuge have shown how quickly they can be rocked when too many investors pile in.

title: Turning the Wrong Page
description: DURING the summer of 1995, just after my 17th birthday, I served as a page in the House of Representatives. It was a heady time to be in Washington: the country was reeling from the Oklahoma City bombing that spring, while Newt Gingrich, the newly elected speaker of the House, and his Republican Revolutionaries were promising to remake Capitol Hill.

title: Lobster Salad, but a Key Ingredient Was Missing
description: Only the name has changed. The ingredients remain the same: wild freshwater crawfish, mayonnaise, celery, salt and sugar.

title: Big Losses for Giants, and They Havent Played Yet
description: It was a few hours before Steve Smith defected to Philadelphia on Wednesday, setting off the latest deafening alarms surrounding the Giants, when Coach Tom Coughlin pondered the oddity of this seasons training camp.

title: New Yorks Urban Aloha
description: WHEN the worlds best surfers come to Long Beach, N.Y., next month to compete for a record million-dollar purse in the Quiksilver Pro New York, a new event on professional surfings world tour, they might be forgiven for using Google Earth to locate the place. Compared with Australia and California and Hawaii, where Quiksilver established its pre-eminence as a beachwear company, New York barely registers on the surfing atlas.

title: Protests Force Israel to Confront Wealth Gap
description: TEL AVIV  They are mainstays of the society pages and glossy magazines. Some are praised for the hospital wings they have built, others are gossiped about for their quirks.

title: How to Lose Allies and Alienate People
description: One of the more common misconceptions about the Civil War is that the world (meaning Europe and, in particular, Britain) favored a Southern victory because of its dependence on cotton. The economic data appears to provide incontrovertible evidence: the livelihood of one in five Britons was connected in some way to the textile trade.

title: Positive Report Lifts Hopes for Umenyiora
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The two lingering issues hanging over Giants camp have been resolved, just in time for the team to travel to Charlotte, N.C., for its preseason opener.

title: Trucks That Are Bigger and Badder, but Perhaps Not Better
description: HEAVY-DUTY pickup trucks are the supercars of the truck world. They have more power than drivers are likely ever to exploit, and bragging rights depend on statistics that are, in practical terms, theoretical.

title: A Scalpel, Not an Ax, for Medicaid
description: Many states are struggling to balance their budgets by curbing spending on Medicaid, a joint state-federal program that provides health insurance for the poor and disabled. They have little choice because Medicaid is one of their biggest, fastest-growing expenses. The risk is that injudicious cuts could harm their most vulnerable citizens.

title: A Retreat for Roosevelt in Georgia Burns Down
description: WARM SPRINGS, Ga.  It was the home where Franklin D. Roosevelt, ravaged by polio, learned to walk with a cane and leg braces.

title: Starving in Somalia
description: The worst famine in 60 years is devastating the Horn of Africa. In Somalia, where the problem is most acute, 3.9 million people are at risk of starvation and as many as 12 million throughout the region. Some 29,000 Somali children are believed to have died in the last 90 days alone. The casualties will only grow without an urgent and generous international response.

title: Politicians and Protesters Assail British Police
description: LONDON  Britains latest convulsion of rioting and looting began with a protest against the police handling of a killing in north London, but it soon turned into something much bigger  a challenge to state authority that shook the political elite, and, for the police itself, one more bleak entry in a catalog of crisis and condemnation.

title: A Washington State Indian Tribe Approves Same-Sex Marriage
description: PORT MADISON INDIAN RESERVATION, Wash.  There were no protests and not much politics when the Suquamish Tribe quietly confronted one of the most tender social issues of the day.

title: Stanley Bosworth, Iconoclastic Head of Brooklyn School, Dies at 83
description: Stanley Bosworth, a self-described old wizard who shaped his own Hogwarts in Brooklyn in the form of Saint Anns School, which rapidly gained national prominence for its free-form approach to education and its success in sending graduates to top colleges, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 83.

title: For Some, Budget Pain Doesnt Hurt
description: Summer is draining from the calendar, and across the city, school principals are swallowing hard and sending out notes to their staff. They go something like this: No yearbook. No dance team. No drama group. No basketball. No field trips.

title: Investors Fret at Costs if Rescues Are Needed
description: LONDON  Ever since Lehman Brothers collapsed nearly three years ago, Europes leaders have repeatedly vowed to prevent any major European bank from failing.

title: Taking a Gamble, McIlroy Is Forced to Play With Pain
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Apparently no major championship this year will be uneventful for Rory McIlroy. There was the spectacular collapse on the final day of the Masters. Then he stormed to victory at the United States Open, and last month he wobbled conspicuously out of contention at the British Open.

title: The Salmon Deserve Better
description: Last week, for the third time in nearly a decade, Judge James Redden of the United States District Court in Portland, Ore., rejected as inadequate a federal plan claiming to save imperiled salmon species in the Columbia River basin. These fish have been listed as endangered or threatened under the Endangered Species Act since the early 1990s, their once-remarkable annual runs reduced to a trickle by habitat destruction and by the hydroelectric dams that impede their passage to the sea.

title: Lottery Numbers
Judge Wont Order Inquiry Over Psychologists Role in Guantnamo
description: New York State cannot be forced to investigate a psychologist accused by a human rights organization of overseeing coercive interrogation tactics at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, a judge in Manhattan ruled on Thursday.

title: In Court, Gundlach Denies Using Trade Secrets
description: Pool photo by CVNJeffrey Gundlach of DoubleLine Capital testified in a Los Angeles court.

title: A Missed Chance for Accountability
description: In a disappointing ruling, a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan failed to hold the Central Intelligence Agency to account for a notorious attempt to cover up the torture and abuse of prisoners.

title: Friday: Language With No Word for Hello
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  When most people sit down to solve a crossword puzzle, they are generally not thinking about how fresh the entries are (how many times that word or phrase has been used in a crossword) or how many cheater squares there are (how many extra black squares have been placed in the grid that do not affect the overall word count). Solving is an escape to some, a personal contest to others. But my guess is that most of you dont spend a whole lot of time thinking about these things.

title: That Ragtag Bohemian Army Returns
description: Maybe they should call it Sublet. The young ensemble members who inhabit the new production of Jonathan Larsons Rent, which opened on Thursday night at New World Stages, never seem to feel truly at home. It is as if they had taken over the show for a couple of months of fun, as they might an older siblings house on Fire Island, and are now hesitant to treat it as their own.

title: Father of Man Killed in Unrest Helps Calm Tense English City With Call for Peace
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  With one senseless act, the fragile peace this city had maintained while London was convulsed with violence was suddenly threatened.

title: A Controversial Cancer Treatment, Step by Step
description: A cancer patient underwent the Hipec treatment, a controversial process that involves surgery to remove visible tumors in the abdomen, followed by the dousing of the abdominal cavity in a hot chemotherapy bath.

title: Hot Chemotherapy Bath: Patients See Hope, Critics Hold Doubts
description: SAN DIEGO  This is cancer therapy at its most aggressive, a treatment patients liken to being filleted, disemboweled and then bathed in hot poison.

title: Big Swing at the P.G.A.: 7 Under (Stricker) to 7 Over (Woods)
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  At one point on a hot Thursday morning in the first round of the P.G.A. Championship, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods were tied at the top, each at three under par and playing flawlessly. They had three birdies apiece after starting 30 minutes apart on the tough back nine of the Highlands Course at the Atlanta Athletic Club.

title: Fact Check: The Republican Debate
description: Updated  As they tried to blame President Obama for the nations lowered credit rating, the Republican presidential candidates who squared off Thursday night in Iowa made several misleading, incomplete or simply false claims.

title: Some Stealth Marketing by a Hot Chemo Company
description: Dr. Jason M. Foster, a University of Nebraska surgeon, extolled the virtues of heated chemotherapy delivered directly into the abdominal cavity in a Web presentation in June. What he did not mention was that the Web site on which he appeared, HipecTreatment.com, is a marketing tool for ThermaSolutions, the leading manufacturer of equipment used for the controversial treatment.

title: The Less Famous Faces of Housing Court
description: At first glance, the scene in Manhattan housing court was as casual as an August afternoon beach party.

title: Massachusetts: Bulgers Friend Charged
description: Catherine Greig, the girlfriend of the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger, was indicted by a federal grand jury for assisting Mr. Bulger during the couples 16 years on the run. Ms. Greig, 60, of Quincy, was charged with one count of conspiracy to harbor and conceal a fugitive, which carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The indictment replaces a criminal complaint that the authorities used to arrest Ms. Greig when they apprehended the couple in Santa Monica, Calif., in June. The indictment says that Ms. Greig, a former dental hygienist, posed as Mr. Bulgers wife, used false identification and tried to prevent his discovery and arrest. Mr. Bulger is charged with 19 murders and other crimes.

title: Citadel Chief Gives Up Dream for Investment Bank
description: It was to have been the summit of a spectacularly ambitious and rapid ascent in finance: turning what began as a $4.6 million hedge fund into an investment bank that could rival Goldman Sachs.

title: For Mullin, Entering the Hall of Fame Means Saying Thanks
description: Three to five minutes, Chris Mullin was told, and this made him happy, a little bit relieved. He would not have to speak all that long, notwithstanding how far his oratory skills have come since the days when he mostly spoke a sign language of his own, with a ball or a beer.

title: As Election Approaches, Sarkozy Faces Daunting To-Do List for French Economy
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy faces an uncomfortable political predicament. He must satisfy an anxious market, preserve Frances AAA credit rating, defend French banks, cut the budget to fixed targets in a time of slowing growth and make it all palatable enough to win an election only nine months away.

title: E.P.A. Bans Sale of Tree-Killing Herbicide
description: The Environmental Protection Agency banned the sale on Thursday of Imprelis, a weed killer introduced this year that landscapers link to thousands of tree deaths around the country.

title: As Dizzying Week Ends on Wall Street, Dangers Linger
description: One of the most tumultuous weeks on Wall Street ended on Friday with the markets not that far from where they started, but with worries about the United States economy and the threat of a financial crisis in Europe undiminished.

title: Horseflesh and High Society
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  They started descending from the clubhouse 20 minutes or so before post time, owners and breeders and racing officials and whoever else secured a much-coveted pass. They parted gamblers and picnickers and strode purposefully into one of the most venerable enclosures in American sports, the paddock at the Spa.

title: Fight Harder, Voters Telling Congressmen
description: VIRGINIA BEACH  Taking in the highly unfavorable view most Americans have about Congress right now, it might be assumed that what voters seek is a lowered volume, thoughtful bipartisanship and legislative compromise. But in meetings with voters across the country this week, many members of Congress are seeing a mirror of the House floor.

title: In Alabama, No Verdicts of Guilty in Graft Case
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  A sprawling federal investigation begun nearly two years ago into corruption at the highest levels of state politics concluded Thursday with acquittals or mistrials, ending, at least temporarily, a case that could have put sitting politicians and powerful campaign donors behind bars.

title: British Prime Minister Faces Questioning in House of Commons Over Rioting
description: LONDON  When Prime Minister David Cameron faced an emergency session of the House of Commons on Thursday to account for his governments handling of some of Britains darkest days since World War II, he was, in a sense, a man on trial.

title: Small Investors Recalibrate After Market Gyrations
description: Small investors faith in the stock market is being tested again.

title: Four Consecutive Days of Market Volatility Are Rare
description: Occasions when the S.&P. 500 rose or fell more than 4 percent in each of four sessions.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: First Outdoor Ohio Game
description: The Cleveland Indians winter sports festival at Progressive Field, Snow Days, will include a hockey game between Ohio State and Michigan, the first outdoor college hockey game in Ohio. The game, to be held Jan. 15, will be a home game for Ohio State, which has a devoted fan base in the Cleveland area. Michigan set an attendance record for a hockey game in December when it hosted Michigan State in the Big House.

title: Delight and Unease Over Law on Student Vaccinations
description: Among the things 22-year old Jamie Schanbaum could not have anticipated three years ago was standing two inches taller, winning a national Paralympic gold medal in cycling and reveling in the Texas Legislatures passage of two bills in her honor. Those gains, however, came after significant losses  most noticeably of both legs below the knee and much of each finger, the result of a bout with meningococcal septicemia in her sophomore year at the University of Texas.

title: Abbott Occupies Catbird Seat in Officeholders Hierarchy
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Pelosi Appoints 3 on Her Team to Complete the Deficit-Reduction Committee
description: WASHINGTON  The House Democratic leader, Nancy Pelosi, rounded out the membership of a powerful new deficit-reduction panel on Thursday by appointing three of her top lieutenants who have led opposition to cuts in Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid.

title: Supreme Court Is Elected, but Bears Perrys Stamp
description: In Texas, virtually all judges are elected. But since he took office in 2000, Gov. Rick Perry has picked most of the winners on the states highest civil court, the Texas Supreme Court.

title: Freddy Adu Returns to U.S.
description: Freddy Adu is coming back to Major League Soccer. The Philadelphia Union is expected to announce his acquisition on Friday. Adu, now 22, signed with the league at age 14 in 2004. He will be reunited with Peter Nowak, his coach at D.C. United. Nowak has the Union in second place in the Eastern Conference in the teams second year in existence.

title: Buying and Selling
description: Retail investors are cashing out more often than bought into the stock market.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense on Thursday announced the deaths of 30 service members who were killed Saturday in Wardak Province, Afghanistan, in the crash of their CH-47 Chinook helicopter. Their deaths bring the number of American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations to 1,715.

title: Republicans Debate in Iowa

description: WHILE marketers may debate the value of advertising, Shira Levenson knows exactly what it is worth: $391.

title: New Rules and Old Plants May Strain Summer Energy Supplies
description: WASHINGTON  As 58 million people across 13 states sweated through the third day of a heat wave last month, power demand in North Americas largest regional grid jurisdiction hit a record high. And yet there was no shortage, no rolling blackout and no brownout in an area that stretches from Maryland to Chicago.

title: 8 From G.O.P. Trade Attacks at Iowa Debate
description: AMES, Iowa  A withering critique of President Obamas handling of the economy was overshadowed by a burst of incivility among the Republican presidential candidates who gathered here for a debate on Thursday night and fought to stay alive in the partys increasingly fractious nominating race.

Rush, stretched for more than half a mile under a blazing sun across the campus of Chicago State University on the South Side.

title: Negative Image Aside, Asian Carp Are a Boon
description: When federal and state environmental regulators spent a few days at Lake Calumet in Chicago earlier this month fishing for Asian carp with stun guns and half-mile-wide nets, their hunt seemed to underscore the carps status as the Midwests ecological enemy No. 1.

title: Brief Test of Military Aircraft Said to Yield Much Data
description: WASHINGTON  The militarys latest test of the fastest aircraft ever built ended Thursday with the hypersonic vehicle crashing into the Pacific Ocean, although officials said they were able to gather unique data that will guide the development effort.

title: Chinese Artist Confirms Details of Detention
description: HONG KONG  Ai Weiwei, the prominent Chinese artist and dissident, said Friday that he had been kept in a tiny room throughout his nearly three-month detention last spring and was watched 24 hours a day by shifts of two uniformed military police sergeants who never left his side.

description: HONG KONG  Ai Weiwei, a prominent Chinese artist and dissident, said on Friday that he had been kept in a tiny room throughout his nearly three-month detention last spring and watched 24 hours a day by shifts of two uniformed military police sergeants who never left his side.

title: British Leader Seeks Public Housing Evictions for Rioters and Their Families
description: LONDON  As Britain begins to weigh the costs of the rioting of recent days and ponder measures to prevent a recurrence, the government of Prime Minister David Cameron put forward on Friday a new way of punishing the looters and vandals who rampaged through many of the countrys cities and towns: kick them and their families out of their government-subsidized homes.

title: Aug. 12, 1898 | Spanish-American War Ends
description: On Aug. 12, 1898, the  United States signed a cease-fire agreement with Spain  that brought an end to the Spanish-American War. Spain agreed to grant independence to Cuba and hand over Guam, Puerto Rico and the Philippines to the United States.

title: On the Road, Embracing the Distance
description: I want to identify with people. I want to be able to say:

title: Who Are Your Favorite Movie Stars?
description: Do people still go to the movies to see their favorite stars on the screen? Is Keanu Reeves a good actor? Why are female foreign-film stars generally unknown in the United States? Can an actor be too good in a performance? Two New York Times film critics recently answered these reader questions. Which brings us to the question: Who are your favorite film and television actors and stars?

title: Tip of the Week: Mobile Weather Options
description: From heat waves to hurricanes, August can be a month for dangerous weather. Smartphone owners have several custom app choices for getting a steady flow of weather-related information, but any phone with a Web browser and Internet connection can also get important storm alerts, forecasts and updates. For example, most of the major weather-focused Web sites offer streamlined versions for mobile users  just point the phones browser to sites like m.accuweather.com, m.weather.com or m.weatherbug.com for a quick look at the latest conditions. If you do not want to keep checking an app or site, you can also have the information find you when a storm is coming. Some commercial sites like Weather.com offer free e-mail or text-message alerts, as does the National Weather Service.

title: Do Congress and the White House Deserve an AA+ Rating?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Prague Music Festival Season Continues With Verdi and More
description: After two months of seemingly nonstop music festivals, Prague is gearing up for the summers grand finale: the State Opera Houses wildly popular Verdi Festival, which opens on Aug. 18.

title: 2011 Buffalo Bills Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. The A.F.C. East is up next, starting with the Bills.

title: Love-Letter to Auto-Tune, Part II
description: Were singing the praises  in weird high-pitched computer voices, naturally  of Auto-Tune, the much-maligned and increasingly ubiquitous vocal-processing technology thats become one of the defining sounds of 21st-century pop. Yesterday, we discussed the Auto-Tune pioneer Cher and the now-ex-Auto-Tune-superfan T-Pain, who brought the technology into diva-driven dance music and hip-hop, and Kanye Wests album 808s and Heartbreak, on which a lovelorn millionaire used Auto-Tune to make people feel as sad for him as they did for Wall-E. Today, a few examples of how rappers, reggae singers, futuristic party-girls, D.J.s and cartoon rodents have used and abused Auto-Tune in ways undreamt of by its creators. Plus: Ne-Yo gets cranky!

title: Republican Debate Frames Race Ahead
description: AMES, Iowa  Thursday nights contentious debate opened the door to a new phase in the Republican Partys nomination battle, as rivals engaged each other in arguments that will sharply define the choices voters face as they pick a challenger to President Obama.

title: Pakistani Soldier Sentenced to Death Over Fatal Shooting of Teen
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani court handed down a death sentence on Friday in the case of a paramilitary soldier who shot an unarmed teenager in the southern port city of Karachi in June, a killing captured on a widely circulated video that sent shock waves through the country.

title: Aftershock to Economy Has a Precedent That Holds Lessons
description: Like earthquakes, financial crises seem to be accompanied by aftershocks, like the one weve been living through this week. They can feel every bit as bad as the crisis itself. But economic history and academic research suggest they can set the stage for a sustainable recovery  and eventual sharp stock market gains.

title: Virtuosos Becoming a Dime a Dozen
description: THE latest young pianist from China to excite classical music audiences and earn raves from critics is the 24-year-old Yuja Wang, a distinctive artist with a comprehensive technique. That Ms. Wang is already a musician of consequence was made clear this year when Deutsche Grammophon released her first recording with an orchestra: performances of Rachmaninoffs Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini and Second Piano Concerto with the Mahler Chamber Orchestra. The conductor is Claudio Abbado, no less, a towering maestro who is extremely discriminating in his choice of collaborators.

title: In Premier League, Spending Is as Important as Scoring
description: London

title: Squeezing Humidity Out of the Air
description: Its not the heat, its the humidity, they say. And according to one company with a distinct take on air-conditioning challenges, buildings can cut cooling costs substantially by dealing with the humidity separately.

title: Arthritis and the Exercise Gap
description: Exercise can help ease joint pain and stiffness for arthritis sufferers. But despite urgings from health officials and plenty of science documenting its benefits, many men and women with osteoarthritis do not engage in any meaningful physical activity in a typical week, according to new research.

description: For Wall Street, T.G.I.F.? | A wild and at times frightening week in the global stock markets  evoking the dark days of the 2008 financial crisis for some  appears to be drawing to a close on a much calmer note.

title: Kris Carr: Crazy Sexy Entrepreneur
description: Please note that nearly every person at the vegan cafe in Woodstock, N.Y., was looking at Kris Carr. The waiter was trembling a little. This has been happening to her a lot lately. In New York City, in Denver, in San Francisco, in Portland, Ore., she cant get a green drink at an organic juice bar or pick up goji berries at the Whole Foods Market and remain incognito. Somebody will see the giant, slightly googly green eyes and the hair whipped into a folded-over ponytail with a trademark streak of hot pink, and thats enough for the tweeting about another Kris Carr sighting to begin.

title: Do Those Pants Make You Look Fat? Ask the Internet
description: There is a reason that women go shopping in groups  they like to ask their stylish friend, mother or the stores dressing room attendant whether something looks good.

description: A strange combination of chaos and parity hit the second round of the P.G.A. Championship on Friday, with a decidedly non-star-studded leader board in a near-constant shuffle all afternoon at Atlanta Athletic Club.

title: Another View: A Path to Fiscal Responsibility
description: Herald L. Ritch is chief executive of Sagent Advisors, a boutique investment bank based in New York.

title: Compound Interest
description: In Los Angeles, everyones a hybrid. Caterer-dancer. Shop girl-singer. Bartender-drama student. Take Justin Kern: model, screenwriter and now fashion designer. Kern and his partner, Stephanie Danan, film producer and fashion designer, have founded Co, a collection of luxurious mega-basics: slip dresses, silk tanks and skirts, L.B.D.s, skinny leather pants and the kind of big old fancy furs that Margot Tenenbaum would adore. The Royal Tenenbaum, in fact, is the personification of the Co customer  a woman who pictures herself in a variety of cinematic situations. To illuminate this idea, Kern and Danan (far right) collaborated with the actress lodie Bouchez and the director Thomas Bangalter of Daft Punk on a four-minute film that they describe as a period piece with a sci-fi twist. (The film will have its premiere on Ts Web site during Fashion Week.) We wanted to give the clothes an identity through the characters that we imagine inhabiting them, Danan says. Margot, fictional character-muse, are you listening?

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: French Economy Ground to Halt in 2nd Quarter
description: PARIS  The French economy ground to a halt in the second quarter, the government reported Friday, posing a challenge to President Nicolas Sarkozy as France grapples with the growing costs of managing Europes debt crisis.

title: Friday Reading: Are Tanning Beds Addictive?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Yemens President Appears Healthier in Video
description: The president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, appeared on state television this week looking healthy and walking confidently in the first such footage of the wounded leader since an early July speech in which he appeared dazed and disfigured.

title: Do Patients Have the Toughest Job in Medicine?
description: The physician blogger known as Dr. D, from the Ask an M.D. blog, writes about doctor and patient issues from the doctor side of the equation, as he puts it. But after recently suffering a severe leg break, he wrote about medical care from the patients point of view.

title: Security Forces Kill at Least 15 People in Cities Around Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Tens of thousands of Syrians in cities and towns around their country took to the streets on Friday after noon prayers shouting We will not kneel in a strong show of defiance against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, and at least 15 protesters were killed by security forces, human rights activists and residents said.

title: Facing Complaints, S.E.C. Opens Whistle-Blower Office
description: Get your whistles out, corporate employees.

title: Prayer, and Bug Juice, at a Summer Camp for Jews of Color
description: PETALUMA, Calif.  On Sabbath morning, as fog still hung over the valley, the campers walked past the Torrey pines and blackberry bushes toward the garden. There, several rows of chairs had been arranged in front of an altar fashioned from a folding table covered with Senegalese cloth and a Torah scroll on loan from an Orthodox synagogue.

title: In Every Tongue
description: Camp Bechol Lashon (In Every Tongue) in the hills of Marin County about 35 miles north of San Francisco, brings Jewish summer camp to an emerging population of Jews of color.

description: Is nothing sacred in this town? Zabars lobster salad, it turns out, has been made from crawfish for years.

title: Spies to Brides: Fall Fashion Books
description: Two years ago, everybody seemed to be making a movie about the fashion world. Now, everybody is writing a book. Three new biographies of Coco Chanel are coming out, in case youve never heard of the lady from the Rue Cambon. There are also a number of designer monographs, quirky memoirs, style tomes and elegant surveys from magazine archives. Its a huge season for fashion books  huge, as Diana Vreeland would have insisted, herself the subject of a new work.

title: Latest Stop on the Art Circuit? Hydra, Greece
description: THE long communal table stretched out down a craggy path overlooking the Saronic Gulf. It had the cluttered look of a Renaissance painting, with remnants of grilled lamb, carafes of wine and abundant cutlery. But the overall effect was more minimalist; the sky was black save for a string of white party lights affixed to a telephone pole illuminating a barren hillside of rocks and prickly shrubs.

title: An Artists Enclave
description: The island of Hydra is home to several world-class contemporary art spaces, found on the labyrinthine back streets or in repurposed commercial buildings.

title: Offices of Activist Bulldozed in Azerbaijan
description: MOSCOW  Authorities in the Azerbaijani capital, Baku, bulldozed the offices of Leyla Yunus, an activist who has long campaigned against forced evictions in the city, hours after a report on her efforts was published in The New York Times.

description: Speaking of the prospects of Medicare cuts or reconfigurations  as we just were, and as we probably will continue to do, since it remains vulnerable under provisions of the debt deal  heres some news from the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston about one thing that doesnt reduce Medicare costs.

title: Nicholson Bakers House of Holes; Deborah Soloman on the letters of Georgia OKeeffe and Alfred Stieglitz; best-seller news
description: This week: Sam Lipsyte on Nicholson Bakers House of Holes; Deborah Soloman on the letters of Georgia OKeeffe and Alfred Stieglitz; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

description: Pamela Paul, the Book Review's children's books editor, sits down with Laurent de Brunhoff, who has kept his father's Babar character alive for 80 years.

title: The Sandwich Gets a Makeover
description: Too few people understand a really good sandwich, once declared James Beard, the famed American chef and food writer.

title: Bedside Table Suggestions for Congress
description: As part of his column this week, Bill Keller asked me if I could think of some poems that might be helpful (inspirational, cautionary, exhortative, instructive) to a deadlocked, polarized and apparently lost Congress. Heres the somewhat hastily assembled list I sent to Bill, along with a couple of poems that occurred to me later.

title: Twisting Body And Mind
description: GAGA is not just a lady.

title: Sister Act
description: A rising star in black letters, the Tulane prof Melissa V. Harris-Perry talks about her controversial new book, Sister Citizen (Yale, $28), which argues that deep-seated stereotypes dog both struggling and successful black women, including the first lady.

title: A Controversial Treatment, Step by Step
description: The following photographs show a cancer patient undergoing the Hipec treatment, a painful, invasive process that some patients believe represents their best chance of survival though it has not been clearly proven to work.

title: I Yield My Time to the Gentleman From Stratford-Upon-Avon
description: Eleven summers ago I was sent to a management program at the Wharton School to be prepped for bigger things. Along with lectures on finance and entrepreneurship and the like, the program included a delightfully incongruous session with Al Filreis, an English professor at the University of Pennsylvania, on poetry.

title: Theres Gold in That Scrap
description: It was 9 a.m. but already sweltering when Dave Petersen pulled his red pickup truck into S. D. Richman Sons Inc., a scrap-metal yard in Philadelphias industrial northeast. In the back of his truck were two old hot-water boilers, a rusty mattress frame and several lengths of outdated cast-iron pipe. Im a plumber, and the work is slow, so my plumber friends put me onto scrap, Petersen said, his T-shirt soggy with sweat. I brought a load yesterday and got $154. I expect to get about a deuce for this.

title: Life on the Line
description: Andrew Rice did a wonderful job in Life on the Line describing the misunderstood binational bubble that is El Paso, Tex., and Jurez, Mexico. His picture is incomplete, however. Virtually every one of the sources he quoted was someone who had more than enough money to pay for an investors visa or take other measures to flee the violence in Mexico and remake their lives on the U.S. side with very little disturbance to their family life. But what about the hundreds of thousands of poor Juarenses who escape with nothing more than the clothes on their backs and horrible stories haunting them? Its not so easy. There are no visas to keep them safe, no work permits, and the U.S. government is reluctant to give them asylum, granting less than 2 percent of petitions from Mexican nationals.

title: The Rollicking Life of Larry Hagman
description: I gather youve tried pretty much every drug, including mescaline, which you ate on an Indian reservation.  Well, I was in a hut with about 10 young Indian boys. I took this stuff and got real sick, but after a while that passed, and I looked down and I had birds claws, birds feet and fur instead of feathers. I thought, Well, golly, this is interesting. I flew around the hut, and then I flew through the wall and flew around the reservation and came back. It was a heavy-duty spiritual thing. I wouldnt particularly want to do it again, but it was a wonderful experience.

title: Watch Yourself
description: I believe that my name is on a Transportation Security Administration watch list. Often when I fly, the letters SSSS on my boarding pass alert gate agents to pull me aside for extra screening. But on a recent trip, a T.S.A. employee failed to notice the SSSS. Im fairly certain that I am on the T.S.A. list because of my animal rights activism. I am not a threat to civil aviation. I was happy to avoid yet another bothersome search, but should I have spoken up? I wouldnt want the guy to miss an actual threat. NICK A., FLORIDA

title: The Regrets of a Semiprofessional Potterphile
description: Sometimes I feel as though Ive written more words about Harry Potter than has J. K. Rowling herself. I reviewed installments in the movie series for two different newspapers. I assembled two separate Internet slide shows ranking all of the films. I led multiple book clubs about Harry Potter novels  one, discussing the sixth book, over e-mail with friends, and the other, about the seventh book, in an online magazine. I narrated a video critiquing Daniel Radcliffes acting. I penned blog posts on Good Snape versus Bad Snape. I mashed up Harry Potter with Tony Soprano. I created Ron Weasleys Facebook page. I wrote an obituary for Hedwig the owl. I visited the Wizarding World of Harry Potter and whined publicly that it wasnt magical enough. I wrote about Dumbledore coming out, Antonin Scalias resemblance to Snape and copyright-violating Asian knockoff books with titles like Harry Potter and the Filler of Big.

title: Becoming a Model Force
description: The Los Angeles Police Department has become transformed, offering itself up as a model police agency for the United States.

title: In Los Angeles, a Police Force Transformed
description: LOS ANGELES  It had all the makings of another turbulent moment for the Los Angeles Police Department, an agency once notorious for an L.A. Confidential style of heavy-handed policing, hostile relations with minorities and corruption. Two months after triumphantly announcing the arrest of a suspect in a brutal beating at Dodger Stadium, the police admitted that they had arrested the wrong man, and charged two other people with the crime.

title: P.G.A. Fitness Director Says McIlroy Risks Further Injury
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  As the P.G.A. of Americas director of fitness, David Donatucci, watched Rory McIlroy endure Thursdays first round with an aching right wrist, he made a wish.
