title: Low-Profile Candidate Hires High-Powered Fund-Raiser
description: Among the likely candidates for mayor in 2013, Tom Allon is a decided long shot, given that in a field likely to be crowded with familiar names, most New York voters probably have no idea who Mr. Allon is.

title: Cholera Outbreaks Spread Across Somalia, U.N. Says
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A cholera epidemic is sweeping across Somalia, the United Nations said on Friday, as thousands of starving people flee famine zones and pack into crowded camps in the capital, Mogadishu.

title: Qatari Fund in Deal for Olympic Village
description: LONDON  A real estate unit of Qatars sovereign wealth fund and a British developer agreed on Friday to buy the Olympic Village of the 2012 Games in London for 557 million, or $906 million.

title: A Building is Bulldozed in Azerbaijan
description: Authorities in the Azerbaijani capital, Baku, have bulldozed the offices of Leyla Yunus, an activist who has long campaigned against forced evictions in the city. (Video via RFE/RL's Azeri Service).

title: Cains Iowa Pitch: Reduce Tax Rates in 3 Months
description: DES MOINES  The procession of presidential candidates through the Iowa State Fair started Friday morning with Herman Cain, who declared that he was running for president because of a deficiency of leadership in Washington.

title: The 80th Anniversary of Babar
description: This year marks the publication of an unusual number of new elephant books for children. But one literary elephant not only precedes them all but will also probably always tower over the rest: the intrepid, fair-minded, fatherly and eternally stylish Babar. Eighty years and 40-odd books after his debut, Babar continues to captivate young children.

title: The Cultural Osmosis Pop Quiz: Harry Potter Edition
description: This weeks Riff by Dan Kois touched upon his regrets as a Harry Potter-obsessive. Below, I quiz a muggle on her knowledge of the series.

title: Not Just Kurt Cobains and Courtney Loves Little Girl
description: IT is one of the most anticipated comings of age in recent pop cultural history: Frances Bean Cobain, daughter of Kurt Cobain and Courtney Love, has arrived. A series of sultry black-and-white photos of Ms. Cobain, whom most of the world remembers as either an infant in her fathers arms or awkward adolescent, has been lighting up the Web after Hedi Slimane, the photographer and former Dior Homme designer, posted them just over a week ago. And the fashion world is begging for more.

title: Debate Showcases Pandering That Repels Voters
description: If you really want to know why voters keep dumping incumbents of both parties and registering an alarming disdain for Washington generally, then go back and watch a scene from Thursday nights Republican debate in Iowa.

title: Meet the Goldman Sachs Banker Behind @GSElevator
description: The media world was set ablaze last week by @CondeElevator, a now-discontinued Twitter account that posted overheard snippets from the elevator bank at Cond Nasts Times Square headquarters. (Example: Girl: Omigod I love your dress so much I wish there was a like button I could press.)

title: Palin Spotted  and Swarmed   at Iowa State Fair
description: 1:09 p.m. | Updated  DES MOINES  Sarah Palin arrived at the Iowa State Fair even as Rick Santorum was speaking on the fair soap box and Tim Pawlenty was grilling pork on a stick.

title: Popcast: Supergroups A Go-Go
description: This weeks Popcast analyzes two new supergroups, one epic and the other more esoteric.

title: Tough Day for Aspiring Screenwriter as Script Is Blown Up
description: Everyone knows that Los Angeles is a rough place to be a writer. Rarely, however, does getting a movie script rejected involve an explosion.

title: Walking Tall on Project Runway
description: The things that the judges on Project Runway  including the guest judge Kim Kardashian  talked about last night:

title: Zooming In on Coney Island, 1929
description: In order to view this feature, you must download the latest version of flash player here.

title: Private Equitys Elevator Problem
description: The private equity world ground to a halt Friday morning, and not just because because it was a glorious summer day.

title: A Writers Beginnings in Kenya
description: Harried reader, Ill save you precious time: skip this review and head directly to the bookstore for Binyavanga Wainainas stand-up-and-cheer coming-of-age memoir, One Day I Will Write About This Place. Although written by an East African and set in East and Southern Africa, Wainainas book is not just for Afrophiles or lovers of postcolonial literature. This is a book for anyone who still finds the nourishment of a well-written tale preferable to the empty-calorie jolt of a celebrity confessional or Swedish mystery.

title: One Day I Will Write About This Place
description: Chapter One

title: Choosing to Stay in the City
description: Four older New York residents are among those deciding to retire in Manhattan.

title: A Good Man Is Impossible to Find
description: From the opening sentences of Donald Ray Pollocks violence-soaked first novel, The Devil All the Time, its clear that blood will out. The West Virginia and southern Ohio landscapes of this book seem riven by one long, coal-smeared and hell-harrowed gash in the earth, and the stories that vent from it file past in a crimson procession of evils so brutally creative, and so exactingly and lovingly detailed by Pollock, that over the course of the novel it becomes unclear whether theyve been spawned for the purposes of plot or purely for atavistic pleasure.

title: Charting Brain Growth in Humans and Chimps
description: Although baby humans and baby chimpanzees both start out with undeveloped forebrains, a new study reports that the human brain increases in volume much more rapidly early on.

title: A Novel of Nigeria, Scotland and the Quest for Perfect Silence
description: There was once a time, centuries before Internet shopping, when buyers and sellers could honorably carry out their exchanges without ever meeting. In the gold-for-salt commerce of Saharan and Sahel tribes, for example, the Saharans would leave a salt pile by the banks of the Niger, then remove themselves so their clients could, in seclusion, deposit a sum of gold. At that point, the merchants would return, but if the payment was deemed insufficient, they would leave it with the salt and withdraw. The Sahel merchants would approach again, and this good-faith dance of advance and retreat would be repeated until both parties felt content with the deal.

title: A Hacker Tells All
description: Considering the fact that Windows 95 hadnt even been released when federal agents finally caught up with the computer hacker Kevin Mitnick, one might assume his new memoir would be full of stale old tech-and-techniques that no one in 2011 could possibly care about. But as Mitnick makes clear here, dont jump to conclusions.

title: Dragons Ascendant: George R. R. Martin and the Rise of Fantasy
description: Its a high time for high fantasy. Novels about wizards outsell (and often outshine) the most glittering literary fiction titles; the contemporary romantic hero generally sports a pair of fangs; and even now the five remaining earthlings who havent read The Lord of the Rings are being hunted down and put to the sword. Yet for all of fantasys successes, there remains a chip on the spaulder of the genre. As Michael Agger put it in 2009, reviewing Lev Grossmans Harry Potter-influenced novel The Magicians: Perhaps a fantasy novel meant for adults cant help being a strange mess of effects. . . . Sounds like fun, but arent we a little old for this? And with that, hundreds of years of fantastical writing are reduced to 20-sided dice, pencil nubs, half-filled Coke cans and the crushing realization that no, your elven rogues dagger is not going to be effective against green slime.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: HALFWAY TO HOLLYWOOD  Diaries 1980-1988  By Michael Palin  Thomas Dunne/St. Martins, $32.50.

title: Up Front: Sam Lipsyte
description: Sam Lipsyte, who reviews Nicholson Bakers House of Holes on our cover this week, knows something about sex writing: when his novel The Ask came out last year, Michael Dirda of The Washington Post wrote that its rants become arias, and vulgarity sheer poetry.

title: Love, the Many-Splendored Emotion
description: The news about love  if anything can be said to be new when it comes to love  is that it affects us on more levels than we realized. Poets and artists have long viewed love as a prime mover, but by the beginning of the last century, scientists and philosophers were dismissing it as socially and scientifically irrelevant. Love was confined to private life, where only women and novelists and psychoanalysts were supposed to pay much attention to it. Then, a little more than half a century ago, biologists and economists and psychologists decided that love mattered after all, and began conducting experiments to determine how much.

title: A Rough Rider Tackles a Rough Sport
description: Perhaps the National Football League executives who were heavily criticized by fans and players last season for trying to remove dangerous hits from the game can take solace: they have something in common with Theodore Roosevelt.

title: The Curse of Musical Nostalgia
description: Five years ago, a young Scottish woman named Sandi Thom reached No. 1 on the British charts with her song I Wish I Was a Punk Rocker (With Flowers in My Hair). She delivered it with a voice of pleading and with a cappella sincerity, as if she were trying to sell you something. Perhaps that was why I found it irritating; or else it was the suggestion that punk rockers would break bread with someone who had flowers in her hair. Thanks to Simon Reynoldss Retromania, I now understand that she purposefully conflated 1967 and 1977 to speak to the vague nostalgia felt by many young people for a lost golden age when music had power and integrity.

title: Lethal Lessons in Misurata
description: C. J. Chivers provides analysis from Misurata, Libya, where rebels in a firefight with pro-Qaddafi forces demonstrate courage, but a serious lack of training.

title: Explaining it All: How We Became the Center of the Universe
description: David Deutschs Beginning of Infinity is a brilliant and exhilarating and profoundly eccentric book. Its about everything: art, science, philosophy, history, politics, evil, death, the future, infinity, bugs, thumbs, what have you. And the business of giving it anything like the attention it deserves, in the small space allotted here, is out of the question. But I will do what I can.

title: OKeeffe and Stieglitz: Intimacy at a Distance
description: Georgia OKeeffe never seemed to mind having wrinkles. When we think of her, we are most likely to think of her later years, when she owned a ranch in Abiquiu, N.M., and roamed the red hills. She lived to be 98, and even after her hair went white, she was not shy about posing for photographs. As if to play up the pantheistic spirit of her art, she presented herself as an American natural, an exemplar of unbuttoned, un-Botoxed authenticity.

title: An African Chief in Cabbys Clothing
description: BEFORE dawn, when most New Yorkers are fast asleep, Isaac and Elizabeth Osei have already been working for hours. On a recent morning, Mr. Osei drove his wife from New Jersey to the half-abandoned outer blocks of Midtown Manhattan to oversee the 4:30 a.m. transfer of their fleet of 50 taxis. With Ms. Osei leading the way and a sliver of moon still hanging in the sky, they scouted three square blocks to make sure all of their taxis had been picked up by drivers. Then, over the screeches emanating from auto-body shops and the smell of gasoline wafting from a Hess station crammed with cabs, they surveyed their troubled taxis just as sunlight faintly appeared over Manhattan.

title: Race, Inheritance and Returning to the South
description: It takes less than a day to drive from Philadelphia to Beaufort County, S.C., but to Alonzo Rayne, the 30-year-old protagonist of If Sons, Then Heirs, the journey spans more than a hundred years. From the very start of Lorene Carys latest novel, when Rayne sets off to visit Nana Selma, the great-grandmother who raised him, hes enveloped by a sense of home. Taking along his girlfriends 7-year-old son, Rayne has high hopes for what the trip will give the boy: How good it would be for him to have the experience of earlier generations, to spend time in a rural setting, to know from their own experience that black people . . . owned land and barns and silos, that they had rights to water from creeks and streams.

title: A Second Home for Affluent Chinese
description: WEALTHY buyers from mainland China, a rapidly expanding economy of 1.3 billion people, are increasingly turning to Manhattan for their luxury real estate purchases, brokers say.

title: Byredos New Mister Is Simply Marvelous
description: These days men are being called many things, especially in certain circles of politics and publishing. So it is refreshing to hear that the Swedish fragrance house Byredo is introducing a cologne called Mister Marvelous, inspired by a man who is nothing less than that.

title: Editors Choice
description: A BOOK OF SECRETS: Illegitimate Daughters, Absent Fathers,  by Michael Holroyd (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) The noted biographer retells the story of Vita Sackville-West and Violet Keppel, but with more depth and context than anyone before.

title: N.C.A.A.s Talk of Reform Only Skims the Surface
description: The N.C.A.A. is infamous for having meetings about subcommittees and subcommittees about meetings. So when about 50 college presidents, along with other athletic officials, gathered in Indianapolis this week to discuss the sordid state of college athletics, they surely produced new blisters while wringing their hands.

title: When Spot and Fluff Fly the Friendly Skies
description: Pet Airways has been named the most pet-friendly airline in North America by Petfinder.com, an organization that provides an online database of animals who need homes.

title: A Berth in the City: Resources for Elderly New Yorkers
description: A NUMBER of public and private organizations and agencies provide help for elderly New Yorkers in the area of housing. Following are some of the resources:

title: Romantic Mischief in 1930s Manhattan
description: The saying May you live in interesting times has undeniable resonance for the investment executive-turned-novelist Amor Towles. In 1989, he was set to go to China for two years to teach. When the Tiananmen Square massacre put an abrupt end to that plan, he headed for Manhattan. On his first night in the city, he met two strangers. One would become his brother-in-law; through the other, he found the job in which he has worked for 20 years. What would have happened if hed hit town a day later? This is the kind of improbable-but-true serendipity that plots the lives of people in their 20s  in whatever epoch  before they know the weight that decisions made in a moment might have.

title: Paperback Row
description: MEMORY WALL: Stories,  by Anthony Doerr (Scribner, $14.) Doerrs brooding tales move gracefully back and forth between distant times and places  South Africa, Germany, Lithuania, China, the United States  and are linked by a preoccupation with the way memories are eroded by the depredations of time.

title: A Rocking Chair Called Manhattan
description: BACK in the 1940s and 50s, Isabel Morton used to stride onto the stages of hotels in the Catskills, wearing shimmering beaded gowns and belting out Gershwin classics like The Man I Love. The gowns were made by her husband, Irving, who worked in the garment industry.

title: Investing in Volatility, to Cash In or to Hedge Bets
description: THE stock market in the last week has been the very definition of volatile, up one day, down the next, then up again the day after.

title: First Measure of Each Campaigns Strength
description: The geography of the Republican contest at the Iowa Straw Poll.

title: Inside the List
description: REQUIRED READING: Can a peaceable literary vegetarian from Brooklyn bring together what a bloody Southern basketball rivalry has torn asunder? That was surely the hope of administrators at Duke and the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, when they chose Jonathan Safran Foers Eating Animals as the joint summer reading for this falls incoming freshmen. So far, the carnivore-unfriendly choice does not seem to have elicited any complaints from the local barbecue industry, though the states educators have courted controversy before. In 2002, conservative pundits and state legislators howled when U.N.C. assigned Michael Sellss Approaching the Quran, calling it an insult to the memory of Sept. 11. In 2003, a student group called The Committee for a Better Carolina denounced that years choice, Barbara Ehrenreichs Nickel and Dimed, as a classic Marxist rant and intellectual pornography with no redeeming characteristics.

title: G.O.P. on Defensive as Analysts Question Partys Fiscal Policy
description: WASHINGTON  The boasts of Congressional Republicans about their cost-cutting victories are ringing hollow to some well-known economists, financial analysts and corporate leaders, including some Republicans, who are expressing increasing alarm over Washingtons new austerity and antitax orthodoxy.

title: Amazon Cracks Down on Some E-Book Publishers
description: Amazon makes it extremely easy to take a bunch of words and publish them as a book for the Kindle e-reader. And longtime professional writers like Edward Jay Epstein, the author of books on Hollywood, diamonds and the assassination of John F. Kennedy, are refashioning their collected works into electronic format.

title: Farewell to a Recovering Plunderer
description: Ray C. Anderson, who passed away thisweek, was a special American. Its worth remembering him here, and to consider ways to build on his accomplishments and ideas. Below you can read the eulogy delivered at a service for Anderson in Atlanta on Thursday by the environmentalist and entrepeneur Paul Hawken, whose writinginspired Andersons shift toward business practices that work for the long haul.

title: The Smallest Details
description: Preparing a classic Ferrari for the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance, where perfection is par for the course.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The Beekman Beer Garden Beach Club, 89 South Street (on the north side of Pier 17), at the South Street Seaport, hosts a benefit for the Surfers Environmental Alliance and autism awareness today from 2 to 6 p.m. Tickets are $35 and include food, live music and an open bar of Dos Equis beer.

title: Retromania
description: 1: 'NOW'

title: Finding Comedy in Britains Riots
description: LONDON  As Britain examines holes in the fabric of its culture as days of rioting subside, its clear that one tradition at least has held  a dry and laconic wit.

title: All the Ways That Stocks Churn Your Stomach
description: If the stock market is a reflection of the stew of our emotions, its pretty clear that nobody knew how to feel this week.

title: As Favorites Fall, Djokovic Marches On
description: MONTREAL  After Frances Jo-Wilfried Tsonga toppled Roger Federer of Switzerland late Thursday night at the Rogers Cup to advance to the quarterfinals, reporters wondered if Federer, who turned 30  gasp  this week, seemed less impressive.

title: Effort to Fight Police Misconduct Is Imperiled
description: Facing an anemic flow of city money, a heralded program to empower outside lawyers to prosecute police officers in certain misconduct cases is in jeopardy of being eradicated, officials said.

title: All Consuming | The Ann Demeulemeester Lace-Up Heel
description: Call them the ones that got away. Spring 2009: Ann Demeulemeesters open-toe lace-up heels came down the runway and the quiet, almost suspicious stirring that precedes a full-blown frenzy began. Everyone wanted them. And, why wouldnt they: hefty heel, combat-boot-like lacing that left just the right amount of skin showing, options in black or brown leather. But despite the hype  countless credits in fashion magazines, followed by colleagues professing how comfortable they were while wearing them with everything from jean shorts to Sunday dresses  I didnt buy a pair. My reason (aside from the $965 price tag)? I wasnt going to let myself fall for another of-the-moment shoe.

title: Fantasy Football: Stock Watch
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

description: Aug. 12, 2011 - Jeff Zeleny reports on the dynamic in Iowa just one day before the important Ames straw poll. Ashley Parker on Mitt Romney's campaign trail style.

title: Revisiting a Childhood Home
description: In this months Motherlode Book Club selection, No Biking in the House Without a Helmet, Melissa Fay Greene writes about building a family. Her construction materials go beyond genetics, as four of her children are biological, while four were adopted from Ethiopia, and one from Bulgaria.

description: To the Editor:

title: Reich Drops 9/11 Photo From Album Cover After Complaints
description: Steve Reich, the eclectic composer, has dropped plans to use a photograph of the burning World Trade Center with a hijacked plane about to hit it on the cover of his new album. The move came after some critics called his use of the photo insensitive.

title: The debate in Iowa provides the narratives for this Republican presidential campaign and when will we know were in a double dip recession?
description: The debate in Iowa provides the narratives for this Republican presidential campaign and when will we know were in a double dip recession? Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, Washington correspondent Binyamin Appelbaum, and chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: Money No Obstacle as Perry Joins G.O.P. Race
description: When Gov. Rick Perry of Texas arrives in South Carolina on Saturday to begin his presidential campaign, he might claim any number of credentials for the countrys top office: Creator of jobs. Cutter of taxes. Defender of gun rights.

Remembering a Land Speed King
description: A new documentary celebrates the life and accomplishments of Ab Jenkins, who set numerous speed records at the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah.

title: Film on Climate Refugees Strikes a Chord
description: During the shooting of his 2010 documentary Climate Refugees, the Irish-American filmmaker Michael Nash visited nearly 50 countries in about 18 months, interviewing politicians, scientists, health workers and victims of floods, cyclones, hurricanes and droughts.

title: Burress Wont Play in Jets Preseason Opener
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan said Friday that wide receiver Plaxico Burress would not play in the teams preseason opener on Monday against the Houston Texans.

description: WENDOVER, Utah

title: Tribute to a Champion of the Salt
description: POLE position on the grid of racecar drivers whose names youve probably never heard almost certainly goes to the driver born as David Abbott Jenkins.

title: All Your Feelings About the Stock Market
description: If youre like me, you couldnt help but feel a range of emotions this week as the stock market bumped up and down  even if youre a long-term investor who ought to know better.

title: N.F.L. to Test Extra Official in Busiest Part of the Field
description: Kenny Phillips, like all N.F.L. defensive backs, is used to performing his job with a lot of people paying very close attention. But the extra set of eyes that will watch him this weekend gives him pause.

title: A Big Love Creator Takes on a Different Family
description: This years Summer Shorts series at the 59E59 Theaters includes new works by playwrights ranging from established talents (Christopher Durang and Tina Howe) to an incoming freshman at Yale (Ruby Rae Spiegel). Running in the programs Series B is a new drama by Will Scheffer, a creator of the acclaimed television series Big Love, which came to its conclusion this year. Titled The Green Book, Mr. Scheffers play, which opened Thursday, deals with a Queens family. We chatted Friday about the play, families and TV projects to come. Here are excerpts:

title: Setting Kernels Loose in the Heat of Summer
description: YES, it may be hot. But a little cooking is usually required if you want dinner on the table. My advice, if you cant stand the heat, is to keep the cooking simple, fast and in one pan.

title: iPhone Game Players Move Into Tiny Tower
description: On a recent Sunday afternoon in Central Park, several of my friends were all hunched over their iPhones, busily tapping at their phones, deeply engrossed in game play. I peered over their shoulders and realized they were playing the same game. But it wasnt Angry Birds, Plants vs Zombies or even GagaVille.

description: Time: About 15 minutes, plus time to roast and peel the poblano chiles

Jacques Beaumont and Richard Townsend
description: MANY years ago, when Richard Townsend was still a student at Tufts, he was clever enough to score an interview with the young Audrey Hepburn, then touring Boston in Gigi.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: How Crimes Have Changed
description: JUST as hemlines rise and fall, so do fashions in crime  or, at least, its fictional representation  evolve from decade to decade and even from year to year. Bracketing the 1950s a group of four crime films recently released by the Warner Archive Collection suggest just how radical those shifts can be. A pair of films from 1949, Richard O. Fleischers Follow Me Quietly, and The Threat, directed by Felix E. Feist, reflect an entirely different set of concerns from two movies produced at the end of the 50s: The Purple Gang (1959), directed by Frank McDonald, and The Rise and Fall of Legs Diamond (1960) by Budd Boetticher.

title: Bond Brush Fires Spreading in Europe
description: HOW many fires can one central bank deal with?

title: Christina Aguilera and Smokey Robinson On Board for Michael Jackson Tribute
description: Christina Aguilera and Smokey Robinson will be among the musicians performing at a concert in Britain on Oct. 8 to pay respects to Michael Jackson, the organizers have announced.

title: Film on Affirmative Action Banned in Three Indian States
description: NEW DELHI - A Bollywood film about affirmative action in education has been banned in three Indian states from opening on schedule. Politicians are riled up about the film. Protestors have been arrested, while security was beefed up at the residence of the cast and crew.

title: Snedeker, Late to the Tee, Is Penalized 2 Strokes
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Brandt Snedeker mixed up his designated tee time Friday, believing it was 8:20 a.m. instead of 8:10. He discovered the misunderstanding while on the practice putting green and sprinted to the tee, arriving two minutes late. The P.G.A., sticklers for punctuality, slapped him with a two-shot penalty.

title: After 500 Miles, Hitting a Wall
description: WHEW!

title: Hotel Review: Thompson Toronto
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Letters: Planning a Vac(cin)ation
description: To the Editor: Re the Practical Traveler column (July 31): Having traveled abroad a number of times, I have sought methods to avoid incurring large expenses when getting vaccines. Many travel clinics charge more than $80 for a consult as their vaccine prices are often artificially inflated (Havrix for hepatitis A has a wholesale price of about $73, not $90). I typically read mdtravelhealth.com to find out what vaccines I need, ask my primary care doctor to call these into a good pharmacy that charges wholesale on vaccines (e.g. the Cure, 1025A Third Avenue, at 60th Street, Manhattan; thecureshop.com), then pick them up at the pharmacy and go to my physician who administers them for a normal insurance co-pay. David Pelavin

title: Walking Marthas Vineyard
description: DOWN a looping path deep in the Marthas Vineyard woods, history keeps a muted vigil. It was here at Waskosims Rock, more than 300 years ago, that leaders of the native Wampanoag tribe met with the Mayhews (named after one of the areas first settlers, Thomas Mayhew) to create a Middle Line division of property. Southwest of the boundary would remain in native control; north and east would be Mayhew territory. The great natural monument, lichen dappled and framed within a modest clearing, always surprises me when I approach it. There are no special signs along the trail. Nor will you find one of those historical markers, in cast iron, lettering raised, once you arrive. In fact, count yourself lucky to find the trailhead at all. Waskosims Rock, just off North Road in Chilmark, Mass., and the rest of the many splendid walking trails on Marthas Vineyard, are a casually well-kept secret.

title: In Halifax, an Old Market Gets a New Home
description: THE Halifax Seaport Farmers Market, in the Nova Scotian capital, is the oldest continuously running farmers market in North America, in operation since 1750. But it suddenly feels very modern in its new 56,000-square-foot harborside home. After spending time in 14 different locations, including church basements and a brewery, the market reopened last November in a specially constructed multilevel space that features every conceivable aspect of sustainable design, and highlights the local bounty of the region.

title: High in the Hills of Corsica
description: WHEN people find themselves at a loss for words to describe Corsica, its usually the islands staggering beauty that trips them up.

title: A Bicycle Journey Across America
description: At 500 miles into the journey, Bruce Weber has learned some things and made some adjustments.

title: A Madrid Barrio Where Boutiques Are Replacing Brothels
description: The TriBall neighborhood of Madrid, long associated with drugs and prostitution, has been cleaned up; the result has been a flowering of (aboveboard) commerce, including a flurry of new restaurants, shops and watering holes.

title: Behind Bachmanns Debate Disappearance
description: The fictional woman of mystery Carmen Sandiego may have met her match at the Republican debate in Iowa Thursday night, as viewers at one point were left wondering: Where in the world is Michele Bachmann?

title: Long Story Shortlist: Topsy Turvy Markets
description: Can Europe be Saved? by Paul Krugman (Jan. 12, 2011)Theres something peculiarly apt about the fact that the current European crisis began in Greece. For Europes woes have all the aspects of a classical Greek tragedy, in which a man of noble character is undone by the fatal flaw of hubris. Read more

title: Eurofile | August Eats in Paris
description: In a delicious but surprising departure from the traditional rhythms of la vie Parisienne, the food news from Paris this summer is that theres actually a lot of news. Not only has the capital seen a flock of restaurant openings during the traditionally quiet season when many Parisians are away on vacation, but some of these new places are even staying open during the dog days of August.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Manga Mania
description: The manga list is filled with change this week as eight titles make their first appearance on the list. The series are all published by VIZ Media and they feature stories about an exorcist academy (Blue Exorcist, Vol. 3, at No. 2); a young creative team who wants to make it in the manga industry (Bakuman, Vol. 6, at No. 3); a princess of a moon kingdom (Sakura Hime, Vol. 3, at No. 6); and a couple of star-crossed romances (Ai Ore-Love Me, Vol. 2, at No. 7, and Otomen, Vol. 11, at No. 8). Congrats to VIZ who has nine out of the 10 titles this week.

title: Debate Cross Talk
description: Word usage among presidential candidates in Thursdays Republican debate.

title: Following the Parade of Accused British Rioters on Twitter
description: Britains magistrates courts, the lowest level court where defendants often first appear, have filled in recent days with accused rioters from London and several other British cities. Cameras are not permitted to capture the proceedings, but that does not mean the sobbing statements and defiant defenses stayed in the courtroom.

title: Palin, in Iowa, Draws Crowds and Speculation
description: DES MOINES  Sarah Palin refused to reveal anything about her presidential plans. And then she refused again. And again.

title: Corn Off the Cob  Sweet
description: Having grown up in the American Midwest, I know a little something about summer corn, farm stands and, yes, even those funny little corn-holding devices you poke into both ends of the cob, for eating corn daintily.

title: Indie Sounds Abound: Some Playful, Some Pop
description: Blood Orange

description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Incredible, Inevitable Shrinking Album Cover
description: WHEN the album designer Michael Carney submitted his proposed cover for the Black Keys album Brothers last year, he and the band were a little anxious. Seeking a change from their previous, illustration-driven packaging, which hed also designed, Mr. Carney devised the simplest of covers: two sentences  This is an album by the Black Keys. The name of this album is Brothers  set against a black background.

title: At 63, a Grateful Nelson Is Done With Majors
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Larry Nelson appreciates the no-expiration-date exemption for past P.G.A. Championship winners. He prefers its policy to the more restrictive United States Open, which cuts off former champions from automatic entry 10 years after they earned their titles  though, with life expectancy surpassing 80 in most developed nations, who can blame the Open?

title: The Cracked Conservative Mirror
description: This morning, FT Alphaville linked to a post by Mike Shedlock on the failure of Keynesianism. Im not sure why: the post was a standard-issue evidence-free rant. But there is something interesting about it, all the same: none of the alleged policy mistakes used to declare Keynesian economics a failure have anything to do with Keynesian economics.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 12
description: The day in sports, including images from the second round of the P.G.A. Championship and pole-vaulting in Berlin.

title: Seeking Drama In a Conflict Thats Still Raw
description: THE director Renny Harlin is better known for his contributions to the Die Hard and Nightmare on Elm Street franchises than he is for anything to do with the real world. So the emotionally charged environment on the set of his reality-inspired action thriller, 5 Days of War, in the conflict-scarred nation of Georgia, grabbed his attention.

title: Downgrade Downgraded
description: A week ago, before the S&P downgrade, the interest rate on US 10-year bonds was 2.56 percent. As I write this, its 2.24 percent, with the yield on inflation-protected bonds actually negative.

title: Soylent Green Is Corporations!
description: Or maybe its Mitt Romney.

title: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
description: Fiscal calamity? Deceased former governor? Middling Jay-Z album?

title: Grooming a Thoroughbred for the Pebble Beach Ring
description: East Kingston, N.H.

title: The Cyberdog Ate It
description: Hmm. I was doing comment moderation, with almost a hundred still in the queue, when the system declared that I had zero comments remaining. Not sure what happened, but if you wonder why your comment wasnt published, it might be that the cyberdog ate it.

title: British Reporters, Not Ad Men, in 50s, Not 60s
description: London -- ONE surprising notion that might strike you while watching The Hour  BBC Americas six-part series about a hard-hitting television news program in 1956 Britain and the men and women who work for it  is that Peggy Olson didnt have it so bad. At least on Mad Men, the midcentury-period AMC drama, one gets the impression that Peggy  the peep-voiced, wide-eyed advertising copywriter struggling to establish herself in a mans world  has a few equally ambitious girlfriends to gripe with about the boys club. On The Hour, however, the shoulder that the head producer Bel Rowley (Romola Garai) ends up crying on is that of Freddie (Ben Whishaw), a tenacious reporter who is also in love with her.

title: Steinems Story, for a New Generation
description: SHEILA NEVINS, the longtime president of HBOs documentary film division, calls Gloria Steinem next to my mother, the most important woman Ive ever met. But when asked about Ms. Steinem, the most familiar face of the womens movement, her staff had a different reaction. We went up and down the halls of HBO and half the kids on the floor didnt know who she was, Ms. Nevins said.

title: A Good Night For Obama
description: At last nights Republican debate, all of the candidates were asked if they would accept a deficit deal that included 10 dollars in real spending cuts for every dollar in revenue increases. All of them said no. I liked Kevin Williamsons spluttering response:

title: On the Street | In Flower
description: Vincent van Goghs fascination with sunflowers is reflected in the many shades of yellow setting off summer tans.

title: The Jam | Alain Levitt
description: Where theres a solid restaurant, a solid playlist can most likely be found. For this weeks Jam, Sean Hanratty of Santos Party House has chosen Alain Levitt, whohelps run his wifes Venetian restaurant, Bacaro, in Manhattans Chinatown district. The music is always amazing in there, and the environment and dcor is incredible, saysHanratty, who is a regular at the intimate vento Italian restaurant on Division near Ludlow. Alain is usually behind the bar smiling and just being wonderful. Hanratty quickly learned Levitt recently started a super-high-energy duo, which usually involved costumes called Bubbles. (Already, Levitts synth-pop outfit with the vocalist Jason Grisell has opened up for Florence and the Machine at Central Park Summerstage and played on a boat with Gang Gang Dance.) The band, who says they just want to make everyone dance, is hard at work on a new release. I knew Alains playlist would be a super-diverse set, with songs I personally have always gravitated towards, says Hanratty of the beat maker who hails from California. Check out Bubbles in the basement of Santos tonight.

title: N.F.L. Exhibitions Give Networks a Ratings Kick
description: Local-market coverage of National Football League exhibition games inflated preliminary Nielsen estimates for the Big Three broadcast networks on Thursday night, suggesting a large boost for CBS in particular. Big Brother won the top spot in total viewers at 8.6 million and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, where it rose 14 percent from last week.

title: Readers Worry About and Express Hope for Down Syndrome
description: This week on our Reply All page, we quantified the Facebook response to our story on a fathers search for a drug to treat Down Syndrome.

title: The Elderly, at Home in Manhattan
description: The Times on Friday published an interesting piece online about why so many elderly residents choose to remain in Manhattan. (Hint: an abundance of services and company help.) Read the full article, A Rocking Chair Called Manhattan, and share your thoughts in the comments section.

title: Watery Subway Woes Snarl Evening Commute
description: Update, 5:39 p.m. | As of 5:37 p.m., the B line is back in business from Brooklyn up to 59th Street-Columbus Circle. But glitches remain. The B and D are operating local northbound from 145th Street to Bedford Park Blvd, and express in the downtown direction from 170th Street to 59th Street-Columbus Circle. A and C trains are running local between 125th Street and 168th Street.

title: 2011 Pebble Beach Events Calendar
description: Each August the Monterey Peninsula becomes a mecca for lovers of vintage automobiles, from well-heeled collectors to those who just like to stand around and gawk. Here are some highlights of this weeks events:

title: TimesCast | August 12, 2011
description: Rare footage from Libya shows the struggle for Misurata; Syrian protesters remain defiant; and Republican economists question the fiscal direction of party leaders.

title: Romneys Assets Top $190 Million
description: Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, reported net assets of between $85 and $264 million in financial disclosure papers filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday.

title: Our Plugged-in Summer
description: WE had all the ingredients for a campfire. We had the wood, the kindling, the newspaper. We had the graham crackers, the marshmallows and the chocolate bars. We had the songbook. We even had T-shirts my mother-in-law had made with the nickname we voted on for the campfire nook behind her house on Cape Cod, Snug Harbor Hollow.

title: Shrinking Sales, Shrinking Art
description: The digital revolution has already reduced record sales. Now its impact is being felt in packaging.

title: Appeals Court Ruling Against Health Law Mandate
description: The federal appeals court ruling against the requirement in President Barack Obamas health care package that Americans must carry health insurance or face penalties.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nicholson Bakers House of Holes
description: In this Sundays Book Review, Sam Lipsyte reviews Nicholson Bakers latest book, House of Holes, a hideously glorious filthfest that leads readers into a bizarre sexual fantasyland.

title: Palin Comes to Iowa
description: August 12, 2011 - Sarah Palin showed up at the Iowa State Fair and met an immediate crush of reporters and crowds.

title: Spelling Out How She Feels
description: IN Hollywood, those who cannot remember the past are condemned to do remakes of it.

title: TimesCast | Republican Economics
description: August 12, 2011 - Republican economists question their party's current fiscal policy of cutting spending at a time of economic uncertainty.

title: Poland Regrets Helping Belarus Arrest Activist
description: MOSCOW  Polands foreign minister was forced to hastily apologize on Friday after it emerged that his government had apparently unwittingly aided in the arrest of a prominent human rights activist in Belarus by supplying banking information to officials there.

title: Nina Sankovitch, Allaying Grief Through Books
description: FOR three years after the death of her adored eldest sister, Anne-Marie, Nina Sankovitch mourned by staying relentlessly busy. She felt a guilt-strafed survivors obligation to live life enough for two.

title: Good Fortune Brings Bad-Guy Roles
description: THE news that Conan the Barbarian was being screened for journalists in New York brought a mischievous grin from the ferocious warlord Khalar Zym, a k a Stephen Lang. Do I own it? he asked. Its an innocent question. Id like to think I could do a romantic comedy, you know? But villains are a necessity. Without them, whats your hero got?

title: A Wineglass Fills in for a Period Instrument
description: When ensembles that play mostly standard repertory take on contemporary works, they think of it as stretching, a broadening of their horizons. Perhaps its the same for a group like the International Contemporary Ensemble when it turns its attention to Mozart and, in the context of its usual wet-ink repertory, Schoenberg, as it did in a Mostly Mozart concert on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Or maybe not: however these players spend their time now, they lived and breathed the standard repertory during their student years, which were not long ago.

title: In the Village, Nothing but Tiramisu
description: Nadia Tade, a tiramisu enthusiast from Italy, and her partner, Alessandro Radici, who is in the graduate business school at Columbia, hope to make tiramisu the next gelato. With Dolce Vizio Tiramisu, which opens Saturday, they will tap into what appears to be a growing trend in Italy, variations on tiramisu, the traditional Venetian dessert made with a type of lady fingers layered with a mascarpone custard and flavored with espresso and cocoa.

title: Love Letter to Auto-Tune, Final Installment
description: In the first and second installments of our guide to Auto-Tune pop  check them out here and here  weve tried to make the case that, when its used creatively, Auto-Tune can be a tool for artists, rather than a crutch. But the biggest criticism Auto-Tunes critics level against it is that its the sonic equivalent of plastic surgery or roids, a digital fix that lets lousy singers skip over that whole learning-to-carry-a-tune thing (boring!) and cut straight to pop stardoms V.I.P. room. And theres some truth to that  while the listening publics acceptance of Auto-Tune has undeniably opened up new avenues of expression for rappers and singers, its also enabled some of the worlds most annoying famous people to annoy us in new ways. (Note: We mean no disrespect by including Drake here  his Auto-Tune songs are actually pretty great. But he started out as an actor, so technically he belongs in this category. Hopefully the fact that he is a rich, beautiful man will soften the blow.)

title: TimesCast | Syrian Protesters Defiant
description: August 12, 2011 - In Syria, bold protests continue even in the face of a brutal crackdown by government forces.

title: Look of the Moment | Anja Rubik
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#744", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: On New Yorks Low Seas: Day 5
description: As we trolled toward the craggy rocks off South Brother Island, the sun-basking cormorants took umbrage and then took flight, forming a big wing-beating flock wheeling away from their leafy refuge here in the middle of the upper East River.

title: Rendering Grinders Toothless
description: NO one forgets their first time. Its like your first kiss, though hardly something every girl dreams about, said Lilli Beard, 19, an incoming freshman at an Ivy League university, recalling her first grind at the tender age of 13.

Dan McCampbell officiated, and Steven Schwartz assisted. They are the bridegrooms godfathers, and became Universal Life ministers for the event.

Lucas of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Uri Lev Friedman, the son of Reena Sigman Friedman and Aryeh S. Friedman of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Friedman, the bridegrooms paternal grandfather.

Cook and James D. Cook of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Susan M. Craig, a cousin of the bride and a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Bardon-Goodbody Farm, the brides family farm, in Hope, N.J.

title: Lili Ruane and Winthrop Smith Jr.
description: Elizabeth Arnold Ruane and Winthrop Hiram Smith Jr. were married Thursday. Patricia A. Hill, a Universal Life minister, officiated at Sugarbush, a ski and golf resort in Warren, Vt., of which the bridegroom is an owner.

Massie, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, and A. V. Srinivasan, a Hindu priest, participated in a ceremony incorporating Catholic and Hindu traditions.

title: For Fish, Being Top American Comes With Questions
description: MONTREAL  The rise of Mardy Fish continued Friday, as he dispatched Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland, 6-3, 6-7 (8-10), 6-0, to advance to the semifinals of the Rogers Cup. En route to his best showing ever here, Fish continues to drive home one key point: no American is playing either as much, or as consistently, at present.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Aug. 12
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Son of a Salesman': Andrew Garfield Will Play Biff Loman in Broadway Revival
description: The producer who is mounting a revival of Death of a Salesman on Broadway next year has tapped Andrew Garfield to play Biff, the wayward son of Willy Loman, a spokesman for the production said on Friday.

title: Iran Opens New Front in War on Fun
description: While the young Syrian activists who use the Web to organize and document antiregime demonstrations across the country are once again counting the cost, in lives, of continuing to pour into the streets, their counterparts in Iran, who helped to pave the way for such protests, are living with a form of repression that is less violent but in some ways far more efficient and demoralizing.

title: Ice Cream Sundaes With Warm Maple Butter Rum Sauce and Toasted Walnuts
description: Time: 15 minutes plus cooling

title: Ice Cream Favorites Grow Up
description: IT all started with grasshopper pie. Shockingly green, made from mint chocolate-chip ice cream slathered with crme de menthe-flavored whipped topping, it was a specialty of one of our neighbors when I was growing up and a block-party staple.

title: The Roles of Stephen Lang
description: Images from some of the films, television programs and plays featuring Stephen Lang.

title: Intuitions Unsaid but Issued in Rhythms
description: The Rez Abbasi Acoustic Quartet began a new tune at Iridium on Thursday night with Mr. Abbasi alone on guitar, sketching a three-note pattern over a seven-beat cycle. Then, having set a groove in motion, he handed it like a spinning plate to the vibraphonist Bill Ware, who obligingly carried it onward. Bass and drums struck up a crosscurrent, clattering and oblique, as Mr. Abbasi introduced a flinty melody, darting through the stir.

title: Faces and Artifacts at Old Zharu
description: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

title: Italy Agrees on $65 Billion in Austerity Measures
description: ROME  Scrambling to fend off a sovereign debt crisis, the Italian government on Friday approved $65 billion in additional emergency austerity measures over the next two years, including tax increases and cuts to local government in an effort to balance the budget by 2013.

title: A Big Crowd for Bachmanns Brief Remarks
description: DES MOINES  After making a large crowd wait in the sun for almost an hour, Michele Bachmann spoke for just two minutes and 22 seconds at the Iowa state fair Friday afternoon.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 12
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include water skiing, studying with the help of rap music, and a Russian grandmother turned television star.

title: For Public Art, Taking the Crowds Into Consideration
description: Elizabeth Allison and her husband went for a picnic last month in Riverside Park South. She knows the 13-block-long greensward in the shadow of the West Side Highway south of 72nd Street well: She created a sculpture there  two figures on a bench facing the Hudson River.

title: A Lifetime Quest to Finish a Monumental Encyclopedia of Iran
description: Ralph Ellison wrote for 40 years without finishing his novel Juneteenth. Antoni Gaud labored 43 years on the Sagrada Famlia basilica in Barcelona, but construction continues today. And in the annals of grand quixotica, Ehsan Yarshater also deserves a prominent chapter.

title: Transatlantic and Berkshire Begin Talks
description: Transatlantic Holdings said on Friday that it had begun deal discussions with a unit of Berkshire Hathaway, officially adding a third party to the competition for the reinsurance company.

title: Celebrations Over, a Sobering Reality for Clarke
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  In the vernacular of his homeland, Darren Clarke of Northern Ireland is a good bloke who fancies a pint. He has acknowledged fancying quite a few after winning his first British Open last month, and he has not been a good golfer since.

title: This Years King of Bridge Had Played Just 18 Months
description: The American Contract Bridge League has awarded this years King of Bridge title to Blake Sanders of Jonesboro, Ark.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Aug. 12
description: More Photographs

title: This Sunday: Three for Two
description: I think were done with twins for a while, a colleague told me as we were closing this weeks issue. She had a point. For the third time this year, we have a cover story that involves multiples. The first was Melanie Thernstroms story about the two surrogate children she had at the same time (she calls them twiblings); the second was Sue Dominus on little Krista and Tatiana Hogan, who are joined at the head; and now we have Ruth Padawer on parents who are expecting twins but decide to have only one.

title: Market turmoil; riskier risk free investments; doing good by doing well, and economic lessons from World War II
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Julie Creswell and Floyd Norris on market turmoil, Phyllis Korkki on riskier risk free investments, Steve Lohr on doing good by doing well, and Christina Romer on economic lessons from World War II.

title: Plan C is Not All Play
description: Plan B, leaving the corporate world to work on your own, has its upsides, but it comes with pitfalls, too. The dream job is a job, not just a dream.

title: Maybe Its Time for Plan C
description: RONA ECONOMOU was a lawyer at a large Manhattan law firm, making a comfortable salary and enjoying nights on the town when she was laid off in 2009, another victim of the recession. At first, she cried. Then it hit me, said Ms. Economou, now 33. This is my one chance to pursue a dream.

title: Chic in Review | A Model Lohan
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: G.O.P. House Majority at Risk
description: There has been various circumstantial evidence that the publics dissatisfaction with the performance of Congress, particularly during the debt ceiling debate, could threaten the Republican majority in the House of Representatives. Disapproval ratings for the Congress are at record highs, as are disapproval ratings for the Republican Party. Other polls show record numbers of Americans saying that their representative should not be re-elected, that most members of Congress should not be re-elected, or both.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 12
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include water skiing, studying with the help of rap music, and a Russian grandmother turned television star.

title: Invasion of the Pop-Ups: Time for a Smackdown
description: Somebody get me a large mallet.

title: For Theater Lovers, a City Is the Stage, and a Purple Cow Is a Prop
description: EDINBURGH  Julian Sands stands alone onstage at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, dressed in an impeccably tailored suit that seems all the more natty in contrast to the tattered copy of Various Voices, a compilation of the writings of the playwright Harold Pinter, that he clutches. The book is bursting with Post-it notes. Mr. Sands spends about an hour there, recounting anecdotes about his personal experiences working with Pinter, the Nobel Laureate, who died in 2008.

title: A Wild Ride in the Markets
description: Looking back at a week of confusion.

title: Santa Fe Celebration Includes New York
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  For its 39th season this summer, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival is presenting 78 artists and ensembles performing more than 100 works in 42 programs over 5 weeks. But for a critic from New York and, I would guess, some vacationing New Yorkers in the audience, two recent programs made this important festival seem almost an outpost of the New York music scene.

title: Where Feet, Beat and Joy All Soar Funkily

But while the first half of the evening  featuring Debo Band with the special guests Fendika  was characterized by startling and thrilling particulars, the dance and music in the second half  David Dorfman Dance with the Family Stone  was little more than exercises in mood.

title: China: Maker Recalls 54 Trains
description: One of Chinas high-speed train manufacturers, the CNR Corporation, announced Friday that it was recalling 54 of its trains from the Beijing to Shanghai route to test sensors that may be causing the trains to stop unnecessarily, such as when a passenger lights a cigarette in a restroom. The Rail Ministry announced separately Thursday that the number of high-speed trains each day between Beijing and Shanghai would be reduced to 66 in each direction starting next Tuesday, from 88 in each direction now. The moves, coming after the government announced a safety review of high-speed rail on Wednesday, seemed to reflect heightened concern after a deadly high-speed rail crash last month.

description: Howard Schultz, the chairman and chief executive of Starbucks, has always been the kind of boss who wears his heart on his sleeve. So it came as no surprise to Starbucks employees when, on Monday, he sent out a long, passionate, companywide e-mail entitled Leading Through Uncertain Times.

title: Relaxing Under Libertys Shadow
description: David Luchsinger, 61, the superintendent of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, lives with his wife, Debbie, in a small brick house on Liberty Island, which is almost 15 acres. The closest thing they have to a neighbor, Lady Liberty, is obscured by trees on their plot of the island, as are the approximately 3.5 million tourists who visit the monument each year. (Mr. Luchsinger will remain on the island and on the job during the statues renovation, which starts in October.) Sunday is for taking the boat to church or to shop, and for relaxing on the island  under surveillance.

title: Enrollment Plunge for DeVry Sends Stock Lower
description: DeVry, the operator of DeVry University, said new undergraduate enrollment fell 26 percent, setting off a 17 percent loss in its share price. New summer enrollment dropped to 15,566, from 20,935 a year earlier, DeVry said. State and federal officials have been investigating profit-making colleges, and the Education Department has put new restrictions on financing for education companies. Adjusting to the regulations created distractions for employees, DeVry said Thursday. Enrollment has been most impacted by the prolonged economic downturn and continued high unemployment, which has led some potential students to defer or refrain from making the commitment to enroll in college, the company said. Stock in DeVry, which is based in Downers Grove, Ill., fell $8.90 to $44.49 a share.

title: Saturday: Celebrity Guest Blogger Daniel Okrent
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Before anyone accuses me of being a troublemaker, I would like to say that Daniel Okrent is appearing here today as our celebrity guest blogger of his own free will and because he simply loves solving crossword puzzles. His contribution has nothing, and I mean nothing* to do with the fact that TIME Magazine contributor Joel Stein, who appeared here in June (Across Lite, Solution, blog), accused him of being smug or perhaps even too smart for his own good. This is a blog about crossword puzzles, after all, and it would certainly not be appropriate to use this forum to stoke the fires of competitiveness or to provoke two renowned journalists into a public face-off, no matter how much fun I could have doing it.

By a unanimous vote, the A.B.A.s House of Delegates approved a resolution calling for states to adopt clear new rules for recusal to cover instances when campaign spending by litigants or lawyers causes a judges impartiality to be questioned.

title: Urban Forager | Amaranth in Abundance
description: I recently stumbled upon a hardy patch of mature, leafy amaranth, flowering in a tree bed in Williamsburg. The tree had long been uprooted, but the amaranth was in full force  one of the few green plants on the block. I was lucky enough to find some younger, reddish-stemmed specimens later that week while walking to my office on Staten Island. The very next day, I spied more young amaranth, this time growing through the cracks in a Park Avenue sidewalk.

description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Considering that golfs expanding parity became the theme of this week, it seemed perfectly fitting that the P.G.A. Tour rookie Brendan Steele and 10-year journeyman pro Jason Dufner would find themselves sharing the lead in the waning holes of Saturdays third round of the P.G.A. Championship. The entire leader board has been a reason to wonder if this really is a major championship, and Steele and Dufner made themselves right at home at the top.

title: The Making of a Debt Spiral
description: DEBT spirals: the term sounds ominous. As it should these market vortexes are posing grave dangers to the global economy right now. A national debt crisis is a bank run writ large, says Kenneth Rogoff, an economics professor at Harvard and co-author with Carmen M. Reinhart of This Time Is Different, a history of financial crises. When a country like Greece goes deep into debt, bond investors start to worry they wont get their money back. What can happen next is a debt spiral, a vicious circle of sinking confidence, rising borrowing costs and, ultimately, rising debt burdens. As investors lose confidence in a country, its bond prices drop, its bond yields rise and its government must pay higher interest rates to borrow. That, in turn, deepens the debt problem and the whole thing starts over again. Debt spirals are dangerous, but they arent inevitable. Country debt crises are essentially political, Mr. Rogoff says. Governments can often stem the crisis by reducing spending, raising taxes or both. But such steps are particularly difficult and politically unappetizing when growth is slack, as it is now in much of the world. Tightening the belt slows growth even more, eroding tax revenue and you guessed it increasing the debt burden, at least in the short term. Of course, the best way to avoid a debt spiral is to avoid running up a lot of debt in the first place when the economy is doing well. If you walk outside without a raincoat and the sun is shining, you are fine, Mr. Rogoff says. But if it starts pouring, you are going to get wet. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

title: Conventional Fed Wisdom, Defied
description: NEWS last week that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates near zero until mid-2013 was welcomed by many investors, but the bleak message about the economy still came through loud and clear.

title: Buy, Sell, Hold (Tight): Eight Days of Market Frenzy
description: ONE of the most harrowing stretches in Wall Street history began with the loss of the AAA credit rating of the United States and ended with fears of a new recession. In between, the wild swings in the financial markets captivated the nation, and the world.

title: In Milwaukee, a Fake Personality Turns Into a Real Phenomenon
description: ST. LOUIS  Milwaukee Brewers General Manager Doug Melvin thought he was getting a speedy backup outfielder with a checkered history when he acquired Nyjer Morgan from the Washington Nationals late in spring training. When Morgan arrived, Melvin discovered Morgan had not come alone.

title: Country Singer, Songwriter and C.E.O
description: This interview with  Kenny Chesney, the country music singer, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: First, Make Money. Also, Do Good.
description: CORPORATE social responsibility efforts have always struck me as the modern equivalent of John D. Rockefeller handing out dimes to the common folk. They may be well-intentioned, but they often seem like small gestures at the margins of what companies are really trying to do: make money.

title: Their Mission: To Build a Better Toilet
description: NO wonder they are called conveniences. Flush toilets swirl human waste down the drain quickly and neatly. But the convenience comes with a rising price for all that follows the flush  a cost that is often paid by municipal water and sewage treatment systems.

title: Whatever Happened to Risk Free?
description: ITS been dizzying. The markets have been swinging madly up and down  mainly down for equities, as anyone in the stock market knows too well.

title: The Hope That Flows From History
description: AFTER the grim economic developments of the last few weeks, its easy to lose hope. Could the Great Recession of 2008 drag on for years, just as the Great Depression did in the 1930s? Adding to the despair is the oft-repeated notion that it took World War II to end the economic nightmare of the 30s: If a global war was needed to return the economy to full employment then, what is going to save us today?

title: Own Horn, Tooting Of
description: Matt Rognlie has been doing a series of posts on how the academic literature on liquidity traps relates to recent Fed actions, and why some kind of credible commitment to expansion after the liquidity trap ends is necessary to gain traction. He cites fine work by Eggertsson and Woodford, Svensson, and more.

title: At Ohio State, Football Scandal Rattles a Reformer
description: For E. Gordon Gee, the athletic scandal that humbled the mighty Ohio State football program overshadowed an otherwise normal, productive January, a month bookended by the Buckeyes Sugar Bowl victory and a business trip overseas. Still, Gee boarded the flight home from China firmly behind his football coach.

title: SEC to Discuss Admission of Texas A&M
description: Eleven of the 12 Southeastern Conference presidents will meet Sunday at a secret location to discuss the admission of Texas A&M to the league, according to a high-ranking SEC official with first-hand knowledge of the talks.

title: Inside the Greek Volcano
description: GOVERNMENT debt has been top of mind this summer. As Congress and the White House played a dangerous game of political brinkmanship over the federal debt ceiling, and, last week, as Washington tried to digest a lowering of the nations credit rating, we could better understand that Americas fiscal indebtedness had broad consequences for the global economy as well as our own.

title: Queuing Up for the Straw Poll
description: AMES, Iowa  The line has formed for folks at thestraw poll to begin voting. The candidate tents are rocking with music. And Teddy Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln are walking around.

title: A Lipstick Autograph, 85 Dropping Hammers and an Aria for a Dying Poodle
description: Merle Hubbard didnt need much prompting to tell a story. Another sentient human being in the same room would do.

title: Variety: A Life-Affirming Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon are beginning to cost me a lot of money. Every time I do one of their acrostic puzzles, I get reeled in and want to buy the book to read for myself. I can think of worse habits.

title: From Cola to Carrots
description: IM the youngest of five brothers. I learned strategy early; if I couldnt figure out where they all were and avoid them, one would always give me a job. My nickname was Remote Control because they would always make me get up to change the TV channel.

title: A Short Course in Miracles
description: Funny how Deval Patrick isnt running for President on the strength of the Massachusetts economic miracle.

title: Working at Making the Most of Your Vacation
description: THE workplace can be stressful  even more so in a difficult economy. Thank goodness employees can relax fully during their vacations.

title: The Only Thing That Rules College Football Is Anarchy
description: No one is in charge.

title: Argentine President Overcoming Doldrums
description: BUENOS AIRES  President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner unveiled a 10-story-high tribute to Evita Pern last month, dedicating the forged-steel portrait on the side of a government building to the memory of a woman she has often invoked in speeches to supporters.

title: Bishops Criticize Tough Alabama Immigration Law
description: CULLMAN, Ala.  On a sofa in the hallway of his office here, Mitchell Williams, the pastor of First United Methodist Church, announced that he was going to break the law. He is not the only church leader making such a declaration these days.

title: Alabama Religious Leaders Sue to Stop Immigration Law
description: Leaders of several religious denominations have filed a suit opposing Alabamas immigration law.

title: Designing Course Is Tricky Art of Strokes and Balance
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Golf course architects hold a special place in the fraternity of those who design sports playing fields.

title: Promising Better Direction, Perry Enters Race
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas announced Saturday that he was running for president, declaring it was time to get America working again as he sought to offer the Republican Party a candidate who appeals to both fiscal and social conservatives.

title: U.S. Economic Woes Loom Over Biden Visit to China
description: WASHINGTON  Over the winter, officials in China and the United States were trying to turn a new page in relations. In January, during a state visit to Washington by President Hu Jintao, leaders worked hard to dispel the rancor that had been slowly building. Soon after, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. committed to an earlier proposal to meet this summer with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, who is expected to succeed Mr. Hu next year.

title: Padres Have Found Relief in Unexpected Places
description: The San Diego Padres signaled a new direction last off-season when they traded their signature star, Adrian Gonzalez, to the Boston Red Sox for three prospects. The Padres have not won much this season, but they still have a strong bullpen, even if it looks a lot different from what most people expected.

title: A Long, Cold Summer at Mount Rainier
description: MOUNT RAINIER NATIONAL PARK, Wash.  The calendar says summer, but the conditions are more like winter.

title: Eagles Spree Was Years in the Making
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa.

title: A Conversation With Anthony Bourdain
description: Chef, author and television host Anthony Bourdain takes more questions.

title: An R.B.I. Leader, but Not an Elite Hitter
description: Philadelphia Phillies first baseman Ryan Howard is once again at the top of the National League with the most runs batted in with 95. Since 2006, Howard has driven in 775 runs, 93 more than the closest player, Albert Pujols.

title: English Historian Blames Black Culture for Riots
description: During a televised discussion of the past weeks riots in England on Friday night, a prominent English historian sparked outrage by insisting that black, Afro-Caribbean culture was to blame for the mayhem and looting, even when the rioters were white.

title: Heads I Win, Tails You Lose
description: The preseason games may have started, but N.F.L. coaches are in midseason form in reciting clichs. They hoped to see some specific generalities from their squads in the opening games.

title: Bridge to Cubas Baseball Past
description: Conrado Marrero established himself as the most successful amateur league pitcher in Cuban history during the 1930s and early 1940s, then pitched for five seasons with the Washington Senators. Now the oldest former major leaguer at 100, he has fallen off the radar in North America.

title: Ream on Klinsmann: A Fresh Start
description: The first camp with Jurgen Klinsmann at the helm of the United States national team was a chance for a fresh start and clean slate for all the players involved.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Straw Poll Begins in Iowa, and Perry Has His Moment in South Carolina
description: AMES, Iowa  The Republican presidential candidates made their final pitches for support in front of several thousand Iowa activists in a basketball arena here as voting in the partys straw poll got under way.

title: Judge Throws Out Lawsuit by Opponents of Upper West Side Charter School
description: A plan to establish a charter elementary school on the Upper West Side, a subject of fierce debate in the neighborhood, has cleared a critical hurdle after a State Supreme Court justice dismissed a lawsuit challenging the approval process for the schools opening.

title: A Necessary Vanity
description: While living in Rio de Janeiro in 1999, I saw something that caught my attention: a television broadcast of a Carnival parade that paid homage to a plastic surgeon, Dr. Ivo Pitanguy. The doctor led the procession surrounded by samba dancers in feathers and bikinis. Over a thundering drum section and anarchic screech of a cuica, the singer praised Pitanguy for awakening the self-esteem in each ego with a scalpel guided by heaven.

title: E. Gordon Gees Not-So Greatest Hits
description: Gee calls himself the master of the one-liner, but he admitted in a recent interview that it is one of his great strengths and one of his great weaknesses. In fact, Gee makes enough of what he called dumb statements in public that he keeps a list of them. Gee declined to show the list in its entirety, but acknowledged that some of the following statements made the cut.

title: Missing City Police Officers Body Is Found in Long Island Sound
description: The search for a missing New York City police officer who disappeared during a father-and-son kayaking trip on Friday ended a day later with the recovery of the officers body, the authorities said.

title: How Will Perry Play in Portsmouth?
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  On optics alone, a New England coastal hub might seem like hostile territory for a Texas governor. Street musicians lug their instruments across the main drag downtown. Sedans funnel toward the waters edge, with kayaks strapped to their roofs. And, most conspicuously, the city square teems with blue-state transplants from Boston and New York.

title: Perry Releases New Campaign Video
description: AMES, Iowa  On the heels of his official presidential announcement, Rick Perry has unveiled a new, two-minute campaign video.

title: Amid Rise of Multiculturalism, Dutch Confront Their Questions of Identity
description: AMSTERDAM  Anders Behring Breivik, the Norwegian who admitted to mass killings last month, was obsessed with Islam and had high praise for the Netherlands, an important test case in the resurgence of the anti-immigrant right in northern Europe.

title: Tribal Rifts Threaten to Undermine Libya Uprising
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Saddled with infighting and undermined by the occasionally ruthless and undisciplined behavior of its fighters, the six-month-old rebel uprising against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is showing signs of sliding from a struggle to overthrow an autocrat into a murkier contest between factions and tribes.

title: Jeter Is Honored in Pregame Ceremony
description: The Yankees held a small but elegant ceremony to honor Derek Jeter for reaching 3,000 hits before Saturdays game against the Tampa Bay Rays.

title: In Britain, Soccer Crowds Are Welcome Sights
description: LONDON  Daily life in Britain over the past week might have morphed into a hideous pageant of riots, murder, fires and pillage, played out to a soundtrack of police and fire-truck sirens, but there is a certain inevitability to the English Premier League. The show always goes on.

title: Starved Budgets Inspire New Look at Web Gambling
description: The District of Columbia is not thrilled that its residents are traveling to Maryland, Pennsylvania and West Virginia to gamble in casinos. Starved for cash, like states across the country, the district wants some of the millions in revenue that gambling generates each year.

title: Professor Garfield Goes to War
description: Hiram, Ohio, Aug. 14, 1861

title: A Walking Tour of the Iowa Straw Poll
description: The Times's Michael D. Shear leads a walking tour of the Iowa straw poll, where G.O.P. candidates jockeyed for attention.

title: The Caucus Video: Straw Poll Walking Tour
description: The Timess Michael D. Shear leads a walking tour of the Iowa straw poll, where G.O.P. candidates jockeyed for attention.

title: After Troubles, a Storm Insurer Is Remade, but Vocal Critics Remain
description: The Texas Windstorm Insurance Association, a quasi-public insurer of last resort for Texas coastal residents, has been at the center of a political disaster zone since Hurricane Ike hit in 2008.

title: Power to the Corporation!
description: DES MOINES, Iowa

title: Adrift in Iowa: Tired Rituals in Tough Times
description: Ames, Iowa WAS it a debate or a horticultural seminar? The eight Republicans who gathered on a stage in this fecund state last week spoke of the federal government as if it were some monstrous plant, each of them essentially promising to come at it with shears sharper than any rival would wield. Their mantra was cut, cut, cut.

title: The Age of Outrage
description: Paris

title: A Growing Gloom for States and Cities
description: States and cities had already endured a harrowing three-year financial slide when the debt-ceiling crisis darkened their outlooks even further. In the space of just a few weeks, the Republican-led standoff on spending and taxes brought them a triple dose of bad news: a budget deal that will probably lead to a significant reduction in federal aid; a bond downgrade that could eventually trickle down to the local and state level, making borrowing more expensive; and a stock market plunge that is bleeding state employee pension funds.

title: Howard G. Paster, Clinton Aide Who Helped Pass Nafta, Dies at 66
description: Howard G. Paster, a consummate Washington insider whose effectiveness as a corporate lobbyist took him to the White House as President Bill Clintons liaison to Congress, where he helped push through the North American Free Trade Agreement, died on Wednesday in Baltimore. He was 66 and lived in Washington.

title: The Elusive Big Idea
description: Neal Gabler is a senior fellow at the Annenberg Norman Lear Center at the University of Southern California and the author of Walt Disney: The Triumph of the American Imagination.

title: I Wont Have the Stomach for This
description: Anna Stoessinger is a writer who works in advertising.

title: The General Theory of Anti-Mulliganism
description: One of the odder sideshows of the Lesser Depression has been the ongoing crusade of Chicagos Casey Mulligan, who has repeatedly tried to convince everyone via his blog that contrary to all appearances, we are not suffering from an overall lack of demand. One of his arguments was that since employment of teenagers continues to expand in the summer, when those teenagers are in fact able to work, supply must be the constraining factor. Another was that the growth in Texas employment similarly shows that demand cant be the factor limiting national employment. The latter argument, of course, has new relevance now that Rick Perry is going to run on his alleged economic miracle.

title: You Want Compromise? Sure You Do
description: Sheryl Gay Stolberg is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: An Iranian Cult and Its American Friends
description: Elizabeth Rubin is a contributor to The New York Times Magazine, where her article "The Cult of Rajavi" appeared in July 2003.

title: Mexicos Drug War, Feminized
description: Damien Cave is a New York Times correspondent who covers Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean.

title: Anthony Bourdain
description: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

title: A Russian Plot? No, a French Obsession
description: Robert Zaretsky is a professor of history at the University of Houston, Honors College, and the author of Albert Camus: Elements of a Life.
