title: In St. Louis, Im a Failure
description: Matt Richtel is a technology reporter for The New York Times.

title: As Texas Dries Out, Life Falters and Fades
description: Richard Parker is a journalist in Texas who writes for McClatchy-Tribune Information Services.

title: The C.I.A. and Drone Strikes
description: Perfection is rare in life; in war, rarer still. Yet the Central Intelligence Agency says it has a yearlong perfect record of no civilian deaths from its campaign of drone strikes in Pakistan. We find that hard to believe. So do many Pakistanis, journalists and independent experts, including those who support the drone program. Lacking proof, the claim fuels skepticism about American intentions and harms United States-Pakistani relations.

title: Holding Rumsfeld Accountable
description: In a courageous decision last week, a federal appellate court ruled that two Americans who say they were tortured by American military forces in Iraq in 2006 can sue former Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld and others for violating their constitutional rights.

title: The Pentagon Puzzle: What to Cut First
description: Military spending has soared by 35 percent in the past decade  and that is not even counting the more than $1 trillion spent on the Iraq and Afghan wars, which are budgeted separately. This years $537 billion basic Pentagon budget is $140 billion higher, in inflation-adjusted terms, than in 2001.

title: Sunday Dialogue: How to Heal the Economy
description: A letter on Wednesday called on President Obama to take immediate decisive action. Then readers offered their ideas.

title: In an Age of Vitriol, What Is Out of Bounds?
description: JUST four months into his new job as a New York Times Op-Ed columnist, Joe Nocera banged out a blistering screed against Tea Party Republicans who have waged jihad on the American people.

title: Reads & Reactions
description: In this edition: debt ceiling deals, debt downgrades and recall elections.

title: The Mutual Fund Merry-Go-Round
description: David F. Swensen is the chief investment officer at Yale University and the author of Unconventional Success: A Fundamental Approach to Personal Investment.

title: Voting Day at the Iowa Straw Poll
description: Iowa Republicans mingled with presidential hopefuls as they began voting in the first test of how the candidates trying to unseat President Obama are faring with their base.

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: Presto, Instant Playground
description: Alec Appelbaum writes about urban design and public policy.

title: Sunday: Hack Saws
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Heres how to tell whether you are a total crossword geek: you get to a clue like 110 Down (It has a period of 2[pi]), despair because your brain shuts down like the jaws of a bear trap when it is confronted by math, and then sigh in relief because the crossing that enables you to solve it is ANSAE, an obscure example of crosswordese that is actually a part of another example of crosswordese, the infamous EWER. Its a peculiar form of relief, but it works for me.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, August 14
description: After the votes have been tallied at Saturdays straw poll in Iowa, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota will make the rounds on the Sunday shows, appearing on six different channels.

title: In Queens, Hockey Is a Day at the Beach
description: Roller Hockey has long been a staple of growing up in Rockaway, Queens. A league that plays next to Rockaway Beach, on the Atlantic Ocean, has seen a resurgence.

title: Voting Day at The Iowa Straw Poll
description: Iowa Republicans mingled with presidential hopefuls as they began voting Saturday in the first test of how the candidates trying to unseat President Obama are faring with their base.

title: A Theory of Everything (Sort Of)
description: LONDON burns. The Arab Spring triggers popular rebellions against autocrats across the Arab world. The Israeli Summer brings 250,000 Israelis into the streets, protesting the lack of affordable housing and the way their country is now dominated by an oligopoly of crony capitalists. From Athens to Barcelona, European town squares are being taken over by young people railing against unemployment and the injustice of yawning income gaps, while the angry Tea Party emerges from nowhere and sets American politics on its head.

title: After British Riots, Conflicting Answers as to Why
description: LONDON  Outside a London court last week, as those accused of looting and rioting in the most destructive and widespread violence in recent British history faced justice, a mother turned to her 11-year-old son, accused of theft, and asked simply, Why?

title: Sharp Cut in Program for Needy
description: For nearly 30 years, a federal initiative has helped ensure that the Bay Areas needy have sustenance and a roof over their heads, if only for a night.

title: When Friday Night Is Not Enough Texas Football
description: I am not a museum curator. I am a writer and a historian. Yet last week I had the pleasure of standing before several hundred folks at the Bob Bullock Texas State History Museum in Austin to show them the special exhibit I have spent the past two and half years curating: Texas High School Football: More Than the Game.

title: Pursuing the Grail of an Earthquake Predictor, but Facing Skeptics
description: A Silicon Valley company is assembling a sprawling network of electrical contraptions across California that its investors hope will prove many seismologists wrong and become a valuable public-safety tool that reliably predicts earthquakes.

title: For Pier 70, Tech Offices and Restored Shipyard Buildings
description: From the Dogpatch neighborhood where she has lived for 30 years, Janet Carpinelli has an up-close view of San Franciscos past and future.

title: With No More Cowboys Taking Vows, Monastery Quits the Cattle Business
description: RICHARDTON, N.D.  The lowing of cattle seemed a perfect prelude to the chants and hymns that followed at evening prayers, an unlikely pairing of soothing sounds that the monks of Assumption Abbey say they will miss.

title: Public Speaks Out Against Process of Schools Budget
description: As Chicago Public Schools officials scramble to complete the districts 2012 budget, parents, teachers and taxpayers made one thing clear in a series of public hearings last week: they must have a voice in developing the budget and not be asked to comment only after it has been released.

title: At a Monastery, the End of an Era
description: The Assumption Abby, which has helped sustain itself through its farming and ranching, will sell off its herd this fall.

title: Chinese Interns Approve of Old Journals and Twitter
description: This summer, a group of college students from China interned atthe office of the city clerk, Susana Mendoza, and found City Hall, well, a lot different from what they were used to at home. But their comparisons may not be what some Americans would expect.

title: Bachmann Wins Iowa Straw Poll
description: AMES, Iowa  Michele Bachmanns high-intensity, Tea Party-inspired critique of President Obama propelled her to a first-place finish in the straw poll here Saturday, giving her presidential campaign a boost even as the field of rivals expanded to include Texas governor Rick Perry.

title: Gus Discount Tackle
description: For 50 years, patrons have shopped Gus Discount Tackle in the Outer Richmond for supplies and to swap fish stories. Gus is one of the few remaining family-owned fishing stores in the Bay Area. Stephanie Ernst-Scott, 60, the daughter of Gus Ernst, the shops founder, runs the register, as she has since childhood.

title: Center Typifies New Face of Pregnancy Services
description: Nearly 180,000 Texas women and men are likely to lose access to birth control and preventative examinations next month because the Legislature recently slashed financing for family planning services by two-thirds.

title: Campaign Against Sex Trafficking Is Gaining
description: Kennette Thomas was 15 when she married a man she thought was a gentleman. Instead, he spent the next 30 years as her pimp.

title: Loving Groupon but Dating Others
description: David Greising writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: The Overlooked Scenario of Defeats at the Top
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Nancy Wake, Proud Spy and Nazi Foe, Dies at 98
description: Nancy Wake did not like killing people. But in wartime, she once told an interviewer, I dont see why we women should just wave our men a proud goodbye and then knit them balaclavas.

title: Children With Autism, Connecting via Transit
description: Ravi Greene can tell you how to get anywhere in New York City by transit  like the beach, on the 6 train.

title: Two Americans Abroad, With Vastly Different Results
description: Two of Americas best players recently returned from trips abroad after having very different results in international competitions.

title: Safety of Medical Devices: Views From the Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Filming China's Dark Side
description: Zhao Liang's films, which explore the relationship between the Chinese government and its citizens, have received critical acclaim abroad but are not screened in China.

title: Posada Gets to Leave Bench and Turn Back Clock
description: It has been a difficult, almost painful season for Jorge Posada, capped by an agonizing week in which he endured his first benching since he became an established star more than a decade ago.

title: Dissecting an Actors Mayoral Aspirations
description: At Representative Charles B. Rangels birthday party at the Plaza Hotel on Wednesday night, guests like Edward I. Koch, the former mayor, and Scott M. Stringer, a mayoral hopeful and Manhattan borough president, responded to a recent article in The New York Times detailing Alec Baldwins political aspirations.

title: A Heads-Up
description: After Zhao Liang pulled a film of his from the 2009 Melbourne Film Festival, Ai Weiwei, another Chinese director, confronted him to ask about his motives.

title: Old Dog, New Tricks
description: One of baseballs most enthusiastic bloggers and Tweeters is a 55-year-old grandfather with eight children who last worked for a major league team in 1993. He is Dale Murphy, a two-time most valuable player who starred for the Atlanta Braves in the 1980s and is now, officially, technologically advanced.

title: Chinese Directors Path From Rebel to Insider
description: BEIJING  The documentary film Petition by Zhao Liang is considered by many of its viewers to be a fearless work of art. Shot over 12 years, it shows how the authorities muzzle and brutalize Chinese who, following an age-old tradition, travel to Beijing seeking redress for wrongdoing by local officials.

title: Fish Carries Flag for U.S. And Faces Djokovic
description: MONTREAL  The best American tennis player at the moment, the highest ranked, the most consistent, is not Andy Roddick, John Isner or either of the Williams sisters. It is a 29-year-old journeyman who once nearly ate himself into early retirement.

title: Battle for Libya | August 13, 2011
description: To the east of Tripoli, at Brega and near Misurata, at least 21 rebels and six soldiers were killed in the past two days, with some 50 rebels wounded.

title: For Leaders, Experience Is in Short Supply
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  With the majority of golfs marquee players stumbling and crumbling down the stretch of Saturdays third round of the P.G.A. Championship, the spotlight and the stage at the Atlanta Athletic Club have been seized by three lesser lights. Each of them has earned a chance for fame, fortune and his first major championship.

title: Celebrity Bows to Futility as Veterans Bids Fizzle
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  They were the guys people had heard of, and sooner or later, it seemed as if one of them would surely shake the P.G.A. Championship from its no-name slumber.

title: Iowa Poll Goes to Bachmann; Paul Is Second
description: AMES, Iowa  The race for the Republican presidential nomination came into sharper focus on Saturday as Gov. Rick Perry of Texas declared his candidacy in South Carolina and Michele Bachmann won a closely watched poll of voters in Iowa.

title: In Defense of Roddick
description: MONTREAL  Earlier Saturday, in response to a question about Mardy Fish, the American ranked eighth over all who advanced to the Rogers Cup final, the analyst and former player Darren Cahill turned his attention instead to Andy Roddick. Or, more specifically, he gave an impassioned defense of Roddick, who had not been mentioned at that point.

title: Perry Kicks Off Presidential Campaign in New Hampshire
description: GREENLAND, N.H.  Introduced as the next president of the United States, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas allowed himself a smile, stepping to a podium assembled hours earlier in a Greenland, N.H., backyard.

title: Shell Tries to Control North Sea Oil Leak
description: Oil is seeping into the North Sea after a platform flow line in the seabed sprung a leak, dumping several hundred barrels of oil into the water, according to the British subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell and a Scottish official.

title: White House Debates Fight on Economy
description: WASHINGTON  As the economy worsens, President Obama and his senior aides are considering whether to adopt a more combative approach on economic issues, seeking to highlight substantive differences with Republicans in Congress and on the campaign trail rather than continuing to pursue elusive compromises, advisers to the president say.

title: The Caucus | Bachmann Wins Straw Poll
description: Aug. 13, 2011 - Michael D. Shear reports on the scene and Representative Michele Bachmann's win in the important Iowa straw poll this weekend.

title: Caucus Video: The Scene From the Straw Poll
description: Michael D. Shear reports on the scene and Michele Bachmanns win in the important Iowa Straw Poll this weekend.

title: Loss and Healing in Norway
description: Scenes of grief and consolation played out in Norway as the nation attempted to recover from the scars of the massacre on July 22.

title: Heat Keeps Atlanta Athletic Club Medical Team Busy
description: The weeklong oppressive weather at the Atlanta Athletic Club has kept the onsite medical team busy.

title: Better Balance May Lead to More Options for Ryan and Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For Rex Ryans first two seasons as the Jets coach, his philosophy was similar to what he saw as an assistant with the Baltimore Ravens: avoid mistakes on offense by running the football and rely on an elite defense to win games. That combination helped the Jets reach two straight A.F.C. championship games.

title: For Dufner, Its Cool to Have Fans
description: In the late 1990s, the Auburn University golfer Jason Dufner and his buddies, fueled by beer, would fetch a few irons from their bags and hit balls late at night  from their front porch.

title: McIlroy Has His Reasons to Bear Down
description: A four-over 74 freshly in the books, Rory McIlroy clickety-clacked past his manager, Chubby Chandler, en route to the scorers shed.

title: U.S. Grand Slam Slump May Be Over
description: Forget America the Beautiful. It has been America the ordinary, bordering on the ugly, at recent Grand Slam events, with Europeans and South Africans hogging the last half-dozen.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Teeing Team Akin to Twins
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Nobody scored better Saturday at the P.G.A. Championship than David Ben Toms-Crane.

title: Jered Weavers Woes
description: As the manager of the Los Angeles Angels, Mike Scioscia is obviously biased toward his ace, Jered Weaver, as a contender for the American League Cy Young Award. But Scioscia made an interesting point last week about the stress of Weavers innings.

title: Youve Just Won the Ames Straw Poll; What Are You Going to Do Next?
description: This morning I introduced a formula that projects a candidates vote total in the Iowa caucuses based on their finish in the Ames Straw poll as well a couple of other factors. The straw poll historically does have some predictive power, particularly if you look at the share of the vote that each candidate finished with rather than simply who won and who lost.

title: A Tumultuous Day for Pelfrey, and Another Loss by the Mets
description: PHOENIX  The stream of weirdness that flows generously from the Mets adheres to a certain ebb and flow.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 13
description: The day in sports, including images from the third round of the P.G.A. Championship and the World Badminton Championships in London.

title: Cricket Team Attacked in Pakistan
description: The brazen attack on the Sri Lankan team by a dozen gunmen killed six police officers and two bystanders.

title: Mets Bay Reflects on a Difficult Season
description: PHOENIX  Jason Bay knows that a stretch of decent games does not salvage a disappointing season. For now, he is just happy not to have an endless loop of insecurities running through his head whenever he steps to the plate.

title: Rigging Falls at Indiana State Fair, Killing Four
description: At least four people were killed and 40 injured after whipping winds sent metal stage rigging crashing down onto the crowd at a concert at the Indiana State Fair on Saturday night, according to the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department.

title: Nadia & David
description: In this homemade video, David Rawlinson recalls that upon proposing he took out newspaper ads in every city that Nadia Johnson had lived in.

title: Youth Quake | Tokyo
description: What do you wear when protest and mayhem rock your world? Reports from three epicenters of street style: London, Cairo and Tokyo.

title: Darwins Endless Forms
description: Images from the exhibition Endless Forms: Charles Darwin, Natural Science and the Visual Arts at the Yale Center for British Art.

title: Corrections: August 14
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Amsterdams Urban Beaches
description: The Dutch summer weather might be a bit unpredictable, but even if the weather isnt agreeable, Amsterdams urban beaches provide some worthwhile destinations. A bit more hidden than their Parisian counterparts, they have more to offer than chilling in the sand, even on a rainy day.

title: 2011 Miami Dolphins Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. Its Miamis turn today, followed by the Jets and New England.

title: Mr. Senna Goes to New York City
description: Formula One may not have made the foothold in the United States that it has in many other parts of the world, but you would not know that this weekend in New York City.

title: Mr. Senna Goes to New York City
description: Formula One may not have made the foothold in the United States that it has in many other parts of the world, but you would not know that this weekend in New York City.

title: Attack Is Latest to Jolt a Usually Quiet Afghan Area
description: CHARIKAR, Afghanistan  The governor of Parwan Province, Abdul Basir Salangi, convened a meeting Sunday morning with his top aides to find out why security had not been improved around his offices, 10 days after reports that a group of suicide bombers was planning an attack.

title: Suspect in Norway Reconstructs Killings for Police
description: MOSCOW  Wearing a bulletproof vest and a leash held by a police guard, Anders Behring Breivik returned this weekend to the pristine Norwegian island where, he has admitted, he slaughtered 69 people last month, leading the police through a simulation of his actions, Oslo police officials said Sunday.

title: Pawlenty Drops Out of Republican Race
description: DES MOINES  Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, dropped his bid for the Republican nomination for president on Sunday morning, saying his disappointing performance in Iowas straw poll convinced him that his campaign had run its course.

title: Loss and Healing in Norway
description: Scenes of grief and consolation played out in Norway as the nation attempted to recover from the scars of the massacre on July 22.

title: Remembering Don Chandler, Former Giant and Packer
description: A few thoughts about Don Chandler, who began his career on the 1956 N.F.L. champion New York Giants and ended it on the 1967 Super Bowl champion Green Bay Packers. In between he was one of the best punters and place-kickers of his era. Chandler died Thursday in Tulsa, Okla., at age 76.

title: Stage Rigging Falls at Indiana Fair; at Least 5 Dead
description: Just hours after lights and rigging on a concert stage at the state fair in Indianapolis toppled into a crowd, killing five people and injuring at least four dozen more, Indiana officials opened an investigation on Sunday to learn the cause of the calamity and what role the weather, including a wind gust that topped 60 miles per hour, may have played.

title: Little or Nothing
description: Calculated Risk says it perfectly: this report in the Times on economic debate within the White House shows a fierce argument between those who want to do very little on jobs and those who want to do nothing at all.

title: Missing Pawlenty
description: OK, Im going to miss Tim Pawlenty, now that hes dropped out of the Republican race. He was, after all, an econopundits dream.

title: Bradley Grabs P.G.A. Championship
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  The final round of the P.G.A. Championship turned into a classic battle of the tortoise and the hare. In this case, the tortoise was the seemingly unflappable Jason Dufner who had played so steadily for most of the final two rounds, it appeared he had no nerves at all. The hare was 25-year-old rookie Keegan Bradley, who alternated spectacular birdies and an eagle with wild detours like a triple bogey on No. 15.

title: Tax-Cap Tales
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had a remarkable legislative rookie season. He pushed through same-sex marriage, ethics reform and a 2 percent property tax cap. The cap got the least attention downstate (it does not apply in New York City) but could forever rework the face of town and city finances in the rest of the state.

title: Setbacks May Push Europe Into a New Downturn
description: FRANKFURT  Economists may still be debating whether Europe is headed for a sharp slowdown or even a recession, but Steve Knott, who installs home heating systems in Barrow-in-Furness, a port town in northwest England once known for its iron mills, is convinced he already knows the answer.

title: The Help Impresses, but Glee Does Not
description: A lavish marketing campaign and positive reviews powered The Help to better-than-expected results at the weekend box office, but moviegoers ignored a Glee concert movie, a troubling sign for that TV musicals hopes of continued cultural dominance.

title: Stand Clear of the Screaming Shakespeareans, Please
description: It takes a lot to rattle New York straphangers. They have seen and heard (and smelled) it all. And they mostly ignore it.

title: Bachmann Faces Tough Questioning on Sunday Shows
description: DES MOINES  Michele Bachmann quickly became the target of fresh scrutiny Sunday morning as her victory in the Iowa straw poll propelled her into the top tier of a rapidly evolving Republican presidential contest.

title: The Caucus Click: Perry Bus Makes Its Debut in Iowa
Perrys Full-Court Press to Get Donations
description: Rick Perry, the Texas governor, has been in the presidential race for all of one day, but he is already promising his top donors perks for a Republican National Convention that will not be held for more than a year.

title: Syrian Navy Joins Attack on Key Rebellious Port City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In yet another escalation of its crackdown on dissent, the Syrian government unleashed navy vessels, tanks and a mix of soldiers, security forces and paramilitary fighters against the port city of Latakia on Sunday, killing at least 25 people, including three children, activists and residents said.

title: The Lone Ranger Is Holstered, for Now
description: Disneys high-profile remake of The Lone Ranger has ridden into the sunset, at least in its current configuration. That long-gestating movie project  starring Johnny Depp as Tonto, produced by Jerry Bruckheimer and directed by Gore Verbinski  was expected to start shooting in October in New Mexico. But Walt Disney Studios pulled the plug late Friday after reaching an impasse with the filmmakers over costs, according to an industry official briefed on the matter who asked for anonymity because the details of the shutdown were considered private.

title: More Music for the Perry Campaign
ConAgra Presses $5.2 Billion Bid for Ralcorp
description: ConAgra confirmed on Sunday that it had offered nearly $5.2 billion for Ralcorp Holdings, days after Ralcorp rejected the bid.

title: Will the ECB Change Course?
description: Just a quick note on the euro situation. The rescue operation to head off a self-fulfilling panic in Italy and Spain has succeeded, for now. But meanwhile the real economies continue to suffer; the latest is France, where growth has stalled.

title: SEC Decides Against Adding Texas A&M
description: In a surprising decision that showcased how complex it would be for Texas A&M to leave the Big 12, a group of presidents of universities in the Southeastern Conference decided Sunday against taking immediate action on conference expansion.

title: The Incredibly Shrinking Sixth Hole
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  It looked like a typographical error. The yardage sheet for the final round of the P.G.A. Championship listed the par-four sixth hole at a length of 289 yards, shortened substantially from the 431, 417 and 432 yards it played over the first three days.

title: Rock Radio Station in New York Shifts to FM News Format
description: Listeners to 101.9 FM in New York, until recently a struggling alternative rock station, got a taste over the weekend of what its new owners hoped would be a successful new format: FM news.

title: Jazz Fusion Heroes of the 1970s Resurrect Their Intricate Dynamics
description: Return to Forever IV showed off every which way on Friday night at the Beacon Theater. Otherwise the group wouldnt have been doing its job. Jazz-rock fusion, as pioneered by previous lineups of Return to Forever in the 1970s, glorifies confrontational virtuosity. Composers show off by writing breakneck melodies, sudden meter shifts and quick-change structures; musicians show off by executing every whipsaw maneuver with pinpoint accuracy and improvising with a flourish. Done right, the music is a display of jet-fueled aerobatics; done wrong, it can be exhausting.

title: Evoking Forbidden Love and Flying Ancient Armies
description: The Chinese composer Tan Dun first attracted attention with skillfully wrought concert works in which ancient Chinese folkloric instruments and techniques mingled in potent collusion with a Western avant-garde vocabulary. But it was as a composer of lavish scores for a series of prominent martial-arts films that Mr. Tan, who turns 54 on Thursday, became an international celebrity.

title: Love Beats Science in a Spoof by Menotti
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  When Gian Carlo Menottis Last Savage had its American premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in early 1964, after its introduction at the Opra Comique in Paris, its poor reception was explained by defenders as a case of bad timing. Just two months after the assassination of John F. Kennedy and with the civil-rights movement spawning both courageous demonstrations and brutal crackdowns, audiences were not disposed, it was thought, to an absurd comedy about the perky daughter of an American millionaire who, as a project for an anthropology degree, is determined to find a primitive man, the last savage, and take him to America for studies.

title: In Toronto, an Artful Bid Helps to Secure a Trophy
description: At the Summer North American Championships in Toronto last month David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Fla., received the Fishbein Trophy for accruing the most master points.

title: The Social Economics of a Facebook Birthday
description: Happy birthday!! With two exclamation points, as we do it on Facebook. Its your birthday today, right? I send you many happy returns  and a wish that you are, if only for today, among the 750 million active Facebook users.

title: When Cancer Steals the Joy of Food
description: Cancer steals much from the people it afflicts. For Anna Stoessinger, a gastronome, stomach cancer meant giving up a lifelong celebration of food.

title: Affable Country Odes to Irresponsibility
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For about 15 minutes at the New Meadowlands Stadium here on Saturday night the Kenny Chesney who could be paid a visit to the Kenny Chesney who is.

title: Yankees Have Unscheduled Day Off Before Road Trip
description: The Yankees concluded a stretch of eight games in nine days against some of the American Leagues top teams Sunday by hanging around the clubhouse and packing for this weeks seven-game trip after their meeting with the Tampa Bay Rays was postponed.

title: When the Bass Is Like a Conqueror, Crushing the Guitars and Words
description: Woofers and subwoofers werent the only part of the sound system Bassnectar brought to Governors Island on Saturday for Bass Island, a marathon of dance music and hip-hop. Bassnectars music, and sets by opening acts including the rapper Lupe Fiasco and the disc jockey Z-Trip, also used the midrange of vocals and the highs of synthesizer lines. But the attraction for the roughly 10,000 people who attended the event  in face paint and fluorescent clothes, wearing goofy hats and festooned with glowsticks, carrying tall poles with toys bobbing on top  was the promise of extended exposure to deep, body-shaking bass.

title: Sporting Goods Chain Supports Concussion Testing in Schools
description: IN a new commercial for Dicks Sporting Goods, Jerome Bettis, the former Pittsburgh Steelers star, strolls through one of the retailers stores, but Mr. Bettis never gets around to promoting equipment, clothing or footwear.

title: With Big, Heavy Rocks, a Man Turns a Nuisance Into a Niche
description: Adam Distenfeld was driving by a construction pit on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn a few weeks ago and couldnt resist. Mr. Distenfeld, 48, is a sculptor who prefers granite gneiss - the banded metamorphic rock found beneath swaths of New York City - and in the Nostrand pit he saw a boulder of it. He had never seen one larger. He needed it. But you try convincing your girlfriend that your studio - which already looks like the Flintstones prop room  just needs one more boulder.

title: Monday: Part to Play
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Thank goodness for Mondays. I solve these puzzles in bunches, and by the time I get through the two Sunday puzzles, my brain is fried. Theres nothing like a nice, smooth Monday grid to restore ones self-esteem.

title: Comedy Podcast Inside News Corp. Feasts on a Scandal
description: Sitting in a windowless London recording studio at the start of the phone hacking scandal that engulfed Rupert Murdochs News Corporation, Chris Skinner faced a dilemma.

title: A Novel Updated, for E-Book
description: In his most recent thriller, The Devils Light, Richard North Patterson wrote a detailed plot in which Osama bin Laden tries to drop a nuclear bomb on the United States to coincide with the 10th anniversary of 9/11.

title: Preparing Triathletes for the Chaos of Open Water
description: The deaths of two athletes stricken by cardiac arrest in the Hudson River during the New York City Triathlon on Aug. 7 have focused attention on the dangers of the open-water portion of such events.

title: Gogol Bordello, "Immigraniada" (Bassnectar Remix)
description: Bassnectar's remix of Gogol Bordello's "Immigraniada."

title: Nothing Special From Mickelson
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  An even-par P.G.A. Championship left Phil Mickelson even-tempered after a disquieting week at the Atlanta Athletic Club.

title: As Networks Speed Up, Data Hits a Wall
description: The newest smartphones are intended to run on speedy 4G networks that allow people to effortlessly stream music, watch Netflix movies and tune in live to a Mets game, wherever they are.

title: Who Is to Blame if Shares Continue Steep Declines?
description: It is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.

title: Jockey Club Plans TV and Web Projects to Attract New Fans
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The Jockey Club, acknowledging that the audience for horse racing is in steep decline, announced Sunday a multimillion dollar campaign to increase television coverage and create a racing series to be accompanied by a free-to-play Web site for picking races as well as a social-network game.

title: Reality Show Ricochets Through Brighton Beach
description: Russians are a gossipy bunch. In Soviet times the conspiratorial kitchen whisper  over a glass of tea or a bottle of vodka  was sometimes the only way to share information. Even now Chekhovian monologues, complete with meaningful sighs, spill forth in the confines of the sauna; Have you heard? is the greeting over a cigarette.

title: A Future Wrapped in 1980s Culture
description: Ernest Clines Ready Player One is a book filled with references to video games, virtual reality, 80s pop-culture trivia, geek heroes like E. Gary Gygax, and funny-sounding cult items like Frobozz and Raaka-Tu. Yet it works for people who like books without pictures too.

title: Bass Notes
description: Photos from the Bass Island concert on Governors Island.

title: Divining New Yorks Fate Should a Double-Dip Recession Hit
description: New York City may have recovered from the Great Recession sooner and more strongly than the rest of the nation did, but it is no less likely to slip back into reverse, economists said.

title: A Life Herding Yaks, Modernity on the Horizon
description: Locho and Yama, the Tibetan couple who are the focus of the enthralling documentary Summer Pasture, are nomadic herders pursuing a way of life that has changed little over 4,000 years. For all the hardship they endure, this intimate dual portrait, directed by Lynn True and Nelson Walker, with Tsering Perlo, suggests that their lives are neither more nor less fulfilled than those of any highly stressed upper-middle-class Americans.

title: Finding Beethovens Moods Hidden Between the Lines
description: Just as you can put on a brave face to conceal your suffering, composers sometimes write works whose cheeriness belies a tortured state of mind. Beethoven began composing his vivacious Eighth Symphony in the summer of 1812, when he was enduring a painful affair of the heart with the woman he called Immortal Beloved.

title: Hip-Hop, Folk and Karate Through a Strainer on a Hot Afternoon
description: What is there to do when a dance festival turns into an endurance test? When biting flies become so aggressive that your legs feel as if they have caught on fire? Clearly, opening day of the Downtown Dance Festival  three hours, no intermission  was a tester.

title: Ex-Agents Charter School Is Set to Open
description: LOS ANGELES  When last seen in these pages, in late 2009, the Hollywood power agent Tom Strickler had forsaken fame, fortune and his position as a partner in the Endeavor talent agency  which was then merging with the William Morris Agency  to climb peaks in Perus Cordillera Huayhuash, and to start what he vaguely described as a nonprofit organization in the field of education.

title: A Technique for Photos Real and Surreal
description: The eye can see a much wider range of light and dark than a camera. Thats why windows come out as a blurry masses of white in your daytime indoor shots but it doesnt look that way to the naked eye.

title: China Moves Swiftly to Close Chemical Plant After Protests
description: HONG KONG  Municipal leaders in a northeastern Chinese port city quickly announced plans to shut down a chemical plant on Sunday after thousands of protesters confronted riot police officers and demanded that it be closed because of safety concerns, state news media reported.

title: Flash-Sale Site Shifts Its Model
description: On a recent day on Gilt.com, shoppers could buy 10 round-trip tickets on Virgin America for $3,585, three sessions of laser hair-removal for $352 or eight Alaskan king salmon fillets for $118.95.

title: Urban Foraging in Atlanta
description: Kelly Callahan scours for fruits and vegetables in the yards of her neighborhoods vacant properties.

title: M.L.S. Nurturing Martins Interest in Soccer
description: Curtis Martin is closely associated with football American-style, but these days, he appears to be taking a crash course in soccer. It is too early to say whether Martin may someday seek to become a team owner in Major League Soccer, but his interest in the sport is clearly growing.

title: Nepals Prime Minister Resigns, Citing a Stalemate
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Prime Minister Jhalanath Khanal resigned on Sunday, acknowledging that he had failed to advance a stagnant peace process or agree with the opposition on a new constitution, tasks he had promised to accomplish when he was elected to his post by a parliamentary vote in February.

title: At Vacant Homes, Foraging for Fruit
description: ATLANTA  As she does every evening, Kelly Callahan walked her dogs through her East Atlanta neighborhood. As in many communities in a city with the 16th-highest foreclosure rate in the nation, there were plenty of empty, bank-owned properties for sale.

title: The Mets Lose Their Fifth in a Row
description: Chris Capuano was once something of an unknown quantity for the Mets.

title: The Limitations on Central Banks
description: If the first fear is global recession, the second is that central banks have run out of fixes. They do have means to respond, but only with radical and possibly dangerous policies whose efficacy is dubious. These nuclear monetary weapons might be better kept locked away.

title: Britain Debates a Plan to Turn to U.S. Supercop
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Camerons plan to bring in an American supercop, as the tabloid newspapers here have called him, became a political hot potato over the weekend, with the mayor of London and an array of British police officials publicly opposing the idea, often in blunt terms.

title: Award for Ballet Dancers
description: Twenty-six former and current performers with the New York City Ballet who worked with the choreographer Jerome Robbins will share this years award for excellence in dance from his foundation. The Jerome Robbins Awards are to be presented by Chita Rivera, who collaborated with Robbins on the original production of West Side Story. Robbins, who died in 1998, established his foundation in 1970 to support all aspects of dance and theater. Past recipients have usually been individuals, including the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton, the director Robert Wilson and Mikhail Baryshnikov. The ceremony will be hosted by New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater on Sept. 30.

title: Industry Tries to Streamline Privacy Policies for Mobile Users
description: For many Internet users, online privacy policies are long and difficult to read. Transfer those same policies to a mobile device, where users can find themselves clicking through multiple screens often with tiny type, and the policies can become almost useless to the average consumer.

title: Indian Leaders Illness Prompts Questions, but Also Restraint
description: NEW DELHI  It has been 11 days since the announcement of the disappearance of Sonia Gandhi, the most powerful political figure in India. From all corners of the country, people have offered prayers and good wishes, even her political enemies. Yet what is most intriguing is that so few people are demanding that she be found.

title: Jails Chief Steps Down Amid Inquiry
description: Larry W. Davis Sr., the highest-ranking uniformed officer in the citys Correction Department, resigned over the weekend amid mounting dissatisfaction about his leadership and a new inquiry into his relationships with subordinates.

title: Time Warner Cable Is Said to Acquire Midwest Cable Operator
description: Time Warner Cable, the second biggest cable television company in the United States after Comcast, is near a deal to acquire Insight Communications, a large operator in the Midwest, for about $3 billion, a person with knowledge of the deal said on Sunday night.

title: Obama Shifts Gears From Coaxing G.O.P. to Swaying the Public
description: CANNON FALLS, Minn.  House Speaker John A. Boehner once explained conservatives hard line on the debt limit this way: A lot of them, he told a radio host, believe enough chaos would make opponents yield.

title: Divorce Tourists Go Abroad to Quickly Dissolve Their Italian Marriages
description: ROME  The Italian couple boarded a plane from their home in Bologna for Bucharest, Romania. They were met there by a consultant for an Italian company, who took them to an office where they signed papers applying for residency in the Romanian capital.

title: Israeli Leader Vows Fiscal Reform but No Quick Fixes
description: BEERSHEBA, Israel  As Israels social protest movement spread beyond Tel Aviv and Jerusalem, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday tempered a promise to find concrete solutions to demonstrators concerns with a warning that the global financial crisis precluded quick change.

title: California Scrutinizes Nonprofits, Sometimes Ending a Tax Exemption
description: A growing number of nonprofit groups in California are being denied exemption from property taxes because the states chief tax collector and assessors contend they do not do enough to benefit state residents, according to lawyers representing the groups.

title: 49ers Harbaugh Is Happy Out of His Comfort Zone
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  It is so loud at the San Francisco 49ers training camp, it is hard to hear what the players think. On a recent afternoon, cornerback Carlos Rogers started to explain why he was happy to have joined the team as a free agent when he was drowned out by a plane, which had taken off from the airport in San Jose and was executing an out route overhead.

title: Market Ills Give CNBC a Bounce
description: When Nik Deogun was running the financial coverage of The Wall Street Journal during the crisis in 2008, he kept a constant eye on CNBC as the events played out on television. It was news being made, all the time, in real time, he said.

title: Time Warner Cable to Buy Insight for $3 Billion
description: 9:10 a.m. | Updated Time Warner Cable announced on Monday that it had agreed to buy Insight Communications, a large Midwestern cable television operator, for about $3 billion in cash.

title: U.S. Aides Believe China Examined Stealth Copter
description: WASHINGTON  In the days after the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, Pakistans intelligence service probably allowed Chinese military engineers to examine the wreckage of a stealth American helicopter that crashed during the operation, according to American officials and others familiar with the classified intelligence assessments.

title: Umenyiora Rejects Contract Incentives but Says Hell Practice
description: After 11 practices, a preseason game and dozens of miles logged on a stationary bike, Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora appears ready to end his holdout.

title: Libya Rebels in Zawiyah Threaten Supply Line to Tripoli
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  After a period of political turmoil, fighters opposing Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi advanced on several fronts on Sunday, seizing ground in the strategic city of Zawiyah that placed them on Tripolis doorstep and threatening to cut off an important supply line for the colonels loyalists.

title: Battle for Libya | August 14, 2011
description: Rebels took partial control of Zawiyah.

title: Portraits Redrawn: Alissa Torres
description: To help deal with her grief, Alissa Torres wrote a graphic novel memoir about losing her husband on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Low Rates May Do Little to Entice Nervous Consumers
description: The Federal Reserves announcement last week that it intended to keep credit cheap for at least two more years was a clear invitation to Americans: Go out and borrow.

title: Fish, Pushing Djokovic, Just Brings Out His Best
description: MONTREAL  Throughout this Rogers Cup, Novak Djokovic appeared unbeatable, each victory more dominant, more lopsided than the one before. By Sundays final, his latest title in this increasingly remarkable season seemed inevitable.

title: Russia Arrests a Gadfly Over Some Simple Advice for Voters
description: MOSCOW  It seemed like a good way to make a point.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include housing starts, import prices and industrial production and capacity utilization for July (Tuesday); the Producer Price Index for July (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, the consumer price index, existing home sales and leading economic indicators for July, and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for August (Thursday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: With Post-Its and Checklists, Schools Cut Their Energy Bills
description: Simple yellow Post-it notes with the message When not in use, turn off the juice, pointedly left on classroom computers, printers and air-conditioners, have helped the Mount Sinai School District on Long Island save $350,000 annually on utility bills.

title: Rookie Prevails in Playoff in 1st Major
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  Keegan Bradley, who seemed to be out of chances, out of birdies and out of luck with three holes left in the P.G.A. Championship at the Atlanta Athletic Club on Sunday, came roaring back with two birdies to tie a faltering Jason Dufner and then prevailed in a three-hole playoff to become the first golfer in eight years, and just the third in history, to win a major championship in his first appearance.

title: Will Low Rates Influence Your Behavior?
description: In an article for Mondays paper, my colleague Motoko Rich and I discussed how the Federal Reserves decision to keep interest rates low for the foreseeable future might not be enough to entice consumers to take on more debt.

title: Driven to Distraction, by More Than Just the Car
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Hold On to Your Brie: A Movie-Night Ritual That Starts in a Sprint
description: In the eclectic fellowship of Bryant Park moviegoers, Loren Finkelstein is the Sheet Guy. That means that every Monday night during the summer, when classic films are shown in the green oasis of Midtown Manhattan, he wheels a suitcase with two dozen sheets into the park at 5 oclock sharp.

title: Tour Rookie With Veterans Resolve
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.

title: Mystery Surrounds Death of Police Officer Who Was Kayaking With His Young Son
description: It had the makings of an idyllic summer afternoon on Long Island: a father and son, out on the river on Suffolk Countys north shore. Preparations began in the morning, as the father inflated a kayak, borrowing a pump from a neighbor across the street.

title: A Sunday Full of Rain, and of Changing Plans
description: Ana Ibanezs original plan for Sunday was to go to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and have brunch outside somewhere on a terrace.

title: Smuggling in North Sinai Surges as the Police Vanish
description: RAFAH, Egypt  The smugglers car lot is so brazenly out in the open, it is hard to tell that the business is actually illegal.

title: A Businessman in Congress Helps His District and Himself
description: VISTA, Calif.  Here on the third floor of a gleaming office building overlooking a golf course in the rugged foothills north of San Diego, Darrell Issa, the entrepreneur, oversees the hub of a growing financial empire worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Squeezing the South into Submission
description: Though the Union army was still getting its war footing, by August 1861 the Northern blockade of Southern ports and waterways was almost complete. That month federal ships closed the Mississippi River to commerce between loyal and secessionist states, while naval squadrons were in place off the coast of most Southern cities, from south Texas to the Chesapeake. President Lincoln had approved the blockade, known as the Anaconda Plan, in April. At first it was widely derided in the North and dismissed in the Souththe American navy, people said, was in no shape to clamp down on thousands and thousands of miles of coastline. Nevertheless, this massive operation had an immediate impact on the Confederate economy and, as it tightened its grip on the Southern coastline, began to choke the South into submission.

title: Lottery Numbers
2 Rescued From Water Neck-High in Elevator
description: In his 34 years with the New York Fire Department, Capt. James Melvin has seen his share of stuck elevators. But he had never witnessed anything quite like what happened Sunday on Staten Island.

title: Breaking Bad Is Renewed for Its Final Episodes
description: Can good news ever occur in the life of Walter White without something equally devastating to even it out? On Sunday night, AMC clarified the uncertain future of Breaking Bad, its hit drama about that meth-cooking chemistry teacher, announcing that it has picked up the series for 16 additional episodes and that those segments will be the last installments of the series.

title: A New York Plan to Help Young Blacks and Latinos
description: To the Editor:

title: In Iowa, Bachmann and Perry Cross Paths but Dont Meet
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  Rick Perry and Michele Bachmann had an opportunity for their first face-to-face encounter of the 2012 presidential campaign just a day after Mr. Perry entered the race and Mrs. Bachmann won its first high-profile contest, the Ames straw poll.

title: Enforcement by the S.E.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Traffickers in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Regents Pay a Political Price for Their Free Advisers, Dissenters Warn
description: In December, the chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, Merryl H. Tisch, announced a new program: 13 research fellows would be selected to advise the education commissioner and the 17-member board. The fellows would be paid as much as $189,000 each, in private money; to date, $4.5 million has been raised, including $1 million donated by Dr. Tisch, a member of one of New Yorks wealthiest families.

title: After Iowa, Republicans Face a New Landscape
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  The leading Republican presidential candidates scrambled to take command of a new landscape on Sunday after Tim Pawlenty abruptly ended his campaign and a three-way race began taking shape to find a nominee who can emerge as the strongest challenger to President Obama.

title: Tinkering With the U.S. Tax Code
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheap Robots vs. Cheap Labor
description: Workers in Chinas export heartland of Guangdong make $200 a month assembling the consumer goods Americans hold so dear. In Jiangsu, they make $175. It seems that isnt cheap enough.

title: Gov. Brownbacks Selective Budget Worries
description: In a foolhardy indulgence of partisan ideology, Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas is returning a $31.5 million federal grant that would have made his state a leader in technology development for the new federal health care law.

title: The Widening Dragnet
description: The Obama administration has decided to stick with Secure Communities, the discredited but rapidly growing immigration-enforcement program that has helped it deport a million people in the last two and a half years. And not only stick with it, but force it down the throats of state and local leaders and law-enforcement officials, including the governors of New York, Illinois and Massachusetts, who have rejected the program, saying it is badly flawed and does more harm than good.

title: Drones Alone Are Not the Answer
description: Mechanicsburg, Pa.

title: Hansen Ties for Low Round, but Comes Up Short
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  The banner for foreign-born players at the P.G.A. Championship ended up in the slender hands of Anders Hansen on Sunday. He tied for the days best round by shooting a four-under 66, but finished one stroke out of a playoff as the players ahead of him silenced questions about why Americans have been unable to win a major in recent years.

title: A Jobs Agenda, Anyone?
description: In what can only be described as a triumph of bad policy and craven politics, Congress and the Obama administration have spent the year focused on budget cuts, as the economy has faltered and unemployment has worsened. Official unemployment is 9.1 percent, but it would be 16.1 percent, or 25.1 million people, if it included those who can only find part-time jobs and those who have given up looking for work. For the past two and a half years, there have been more than four unemployed workers for every job opening, a record high, by far. In a healthy market, the ratio would be about one to one.

title: For Branca, an Asterisk of a Different Kind
description: Earlier this summer, Ralph Branca met me at a country club in Westchester where he lives, extending the arthritic hand that 60 years ago this October threw the baseball that became the most famous of home runs, the shot heard round the world.

title: Japanese Economy Signals Rebound From Earthquake
description: The Japanese economy contracted less than economists had expected in the second quarter as companies increased spending, signaling that the nation is rebounding from a slump after the devastating earthquake and tsunami in March.

title: Chris Christies Cue
description: This has been a clarifying week for the 2012 election. Thursdays Republican debate reminded everyone why Mitt Romney is the front-runner, as his rivals left the former Massachusetts governor more or less untouched. Saturdays Ames straw poll disposed of Tim Pawlenty, who not so long ago seemed positioned to give Romney a real challenge. Instead, that challenge will probably come from Rick Perry, whose entrance into the race promises to set up a Romney-Perry slugfest for the nomination, with Michele Bachmann playing spoiler.

title: The Texas Unmiracle
description: As expected, Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, has announced that he is running for president. And we already know what his campaign will be about: faith in miracles.

title: Stop Coddling the Super-Rich
description: Omaha

title: President of Argentina Easily Prevails in Primary Election
description: BUENOS AIRES  President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner far outpolled her rivals on Sunday in Argentinas first national primary, suggesting that she is likely to win re-election easily in the vote on Oct. 23.

title: Bishop in Missouri Waited Months to Report Priest, Stirring Parishioners Rage
description: In the annals of the sexual abuse scandals in the Roman Catholic Church, most of the cases that have come to light happened years before to children and teenagers who have long since grown into adults.

title: State Challenges Seen as Whittling Away Federal Education Law
description: HELENA, Mont.  As hundreds of schools here and across the nation faced being labeled failures under the federal No Child Left Behind law, Montana education officials defiantly informed Washington this spring that they would stop raising testing targets as the law requires, despite warnings that doing so could cost the state millions of dollars in federal aid.

title: On Stage, Knicks Dolan Approaches Anonymity
description: James L. Dolan, the owner of the Knicks and the lead singer of the blues band the Straight Shot, took the stage at Williamsburgs Brooklyn Bowl on Sunday night. Unlike most events there, this concert was free  interesting, because revenue sharing will affect the N.B.A.s next collective bargaining agreement.

title: The W.P.S. Title Jinx
description: The Western New York Flash closed the W.P.S. regular season with a 2-0 victory over the Atlanta Beat on Sunday night. The Brazilian star Marta scored the Flashs second goal, her 10th of the season.

title: Adapting Patti Smiths Just Kids for the Big Screen
description: Patti Smith is variously known as a musician, poet, artist and memoirist. Now add feature film writer to that list. She confirmed Friday that she will be collaborating with the playwright and screenwriter John Logan on an adaptation of her best-selling book Just Kids, which chronicled her early years in New York, focusing on her relationship with the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. She said that she and Mr. Logan were friends and that she had particularly admired his script for Coriolanus, the coming film adaptation directed by a mutual friend of theirs, Ralph Fiennes. She also cited Mr. Logans Tony-winning play about Mark Rothko, Red. It was a beautiful script and hes very knowledgeable about art, Ms. Smith said, speaking by phone, adding later, Hes very knowledgeable about Robert and his work too. Theres no director or financing set, though Ms. Smiths literary agent, Betsy Lerner, said several producers and especially actresses have expressed interest since Just Kids was published last year.

title: Word of the Day | balk
description: balk \bk sometimes blk\ verb/noun

title: NYT Front Page for 08/15/11
description: NYT Front Page for 08/15/11

title: Youth Quake | Cairo
description: What do you wear when protest and mayhem rock your world? Reports from three epicenters of street style: London, Cairo and Tokyo.

title: 2011 Jets Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. A preview of the Patriots on Tuesday will complete the A.F.C. East.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 15, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the Practical Traveler column How to Beat the High Costs of Dialing Abroad.

title: News Quiz | August 15, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: After Riots, British Leaders Offer Divergent Proposals
description: LONDON  With neighborhoods across a wide array of English cities and towns still resounding with the clamor of cleanup crews and with police reinforcements cautiously drawing down, Britains top two politicians ventured Monday into a political landscape profoundly altered by last weeks rioting and offered competing prescriptions that seemed to rupture an uneasy consensus that has prevailed in British politics for a generation.

title: Threat Resurges in Deadliest Day of Year for Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A chilling series of fatal attacks across Iraq on Monday sent a disheartening message to the Iraqi and American governments: After hundreds of billions of dollars spent since the United States invasion in 2003, and tens of thousands of lives lost, insurgents remain a potent and perhaps resurging threat to Iraqis and the American troops still in the country.

title: Aug. 15, 1947 | India and Pakistan Become Nations
description: On August 15, 1947, India achieved her long-sought independence from Britain when Britain partitioned the country into two independent dominions, India and Pakistan. This British Path newsreel shows some of the ceremonies.

title: How Have You Paid Tribute to Loved Ones?
description: After her sister died, Nina Sankovitch kept herself busy with everyday tasks and activities. She eventually decided that the best way to remember her sisterand deal with her griefwas to read one book per day for an entire year. Why do you think she did that? How would you pay tribute to a lost loved one?

title: Scripps to Buy Virgin Medias Stake in UKTV
description: Scripps Networks Interactive agreed on Monday to buy Virgin Medias 50 percent stake in UKTV, a British cable and satellite TV channel operator, for about $552.4 million.

title: On a California Farm Where Marijuana Grows
description: Maureen Drennan does not smoke marijuana. Not when shes surrounded by acres of the leafy greens. Not when its ripe for the picking or piled high in the back of a pickup truck.

title: The 2011 Iowa Straw Poll
description: WHO won the Iowa straw poll?

title: Q&A: Planning Ahead for a Lost Password
description: Q.

title: Weekend Roundup: Fbregas Moving, United Limping, Mexico Celebrating
description: News and notes from the weekend, on and off the field.

title: The Early Word: Conflict
description: Todays Times:

title: The Credit Rating War
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: Hong Kongs Ocean Park Adds New Attractions
description: A scalloped hammerhead cruises the reef above a leopard shark and a huge grouper. A school of yellow-fin tuna rush through their daily circular rounds. The faces of visitors glow with the reflections of digital screens, as they snap photos of each other standing in front of a floor-to-ceiling wall of water.

title: Indonesian Assault Victim Gets Harsher Sentence Than His Attackers
description: DENPASAR, Indonesia  An Indonesian man who survived a deadly mob attack by Muslim hard-liners was sentenced Monday to six months in prison, prompting outrage from rights groups over a sentence harsher than those received by some of his assailants.

title: This Week in Small Business: Downgrades, Upgrades and Doing Business in Britain
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Complaint Box | Road Hogs
description: Several miles outside the city limits, where quiet roads meander over manse-strewn hills and descend to wander the shore, the heat has hatched an unsightly infestation, a blight of clicking, spinning, sweating, spitting intruders that swarm about until the chill winds of November signal a return to their dormant stage. These pests are cyclical  bicyclical, actually  and they are everywhere.

title: Measuring Your Plastic Footprint
description: With climate change and carbon dioxide emissions dominating the environmental conversation much of the time, the issue of plastic pollution tends to get short shrift. Still, the problem is worrying enough to be stirring serious concern among environmental and scientific experts, especially when it comes to plastic that ends up in the oceans, where it never quite biodegrades and can form a swelling gyre of sludge.

title: A Top Libyan Official Appears to Defect, as Rebels Defend Recent Gains
description: CAIRO  A top Libyan security official arrived unexpectedly in Cairo on Monday apparently in a high-level defection, as the rebels challenging Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis rule fought to hold ground in a strategic oil port just 30 miles from the capital.

title: Google to Buy Motorola Mobility for $12.5 Billion
description: 9:16 a.m. | Updated

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Moroccan Stuffed Tomatoes
description: Imagine a juicy red tomato stuffed with sauted slivers of green zucchini, onion, garlic, cilantro and pistachios, and then garnished with even more pistachios.

title: Record Industry Braces for Artists Battles Over Song Rights
description: Since their release in 1978, hit albums like Bruce Springsteens Darkness on the Edge of Town, Billy Joels 52nd Street, the Doobie Brothers Minute by Minute, Kenny Rogerss Gambler and Funkadelics One Nation Under a Groove have generated tens of millions of dollars for record companies. But thanks to a little-noted provision in United States copyright law, those artists  and thousands more  now have the right to reclaim ownership of their recordings, potentially leaving the labels out in the cold.

title: Tickets Available for Le Foodings Return
description: This fall, after two years of running extravagant urban picnics at MoMA PS1 in Queens, with cutting-edge French and American chefs, the French gastronomic group Le Fooding will move to Manhattan and hold a music event with food and drinks, as well as a series of rotating dinners. And you can get the tickets below.

title: Google to Acquire Motorola Mobility
description: Google said Monday that it has agreed to acquire Motorola Mobility, the cellphone handset maker, for $12.5 billion.

title: Monday Reading: Foraging for Produce Outside Vacant Homes
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Wages, Jobs, Texas, and the World
description: Im starting to get reactions to todays column. Some of them are the kind that make me despair: The fact is that free-market Texas is doing great while socialist California is a disaster! Sometimes I really do wonder whether its even worth trying to make rational arguments.

title: Morning Buzz
description: For more local news from The Times, including how the weekends torrential (and record-breaking!) rain affected Sunday plans, the successful reduction of energy consumption in New Yorks schools and the resignation of New York Citys highest-ranking uniformed corrections officer, see the N.Y./Region section.

title: Transocean Bids $1.43 Billion for Norwegian Driller
description: Transocean, one of the worlds largest offshore drilling contractors, said on Monday that it had bid $1.43 billion for Aker Drilling of Norway to expand its fleet by adding rigs and ships.

title: Bank of America Sells Canadian Credit Card Business
description: Bank of America took steps on Monday to exit the international credit card business, agreeing to sell off its $8.6 billion Canadian card venture to the TD Bank Group for an undisclosed amount and putting its remaining European card portfolio on the block.

title: Fading Inflation Fears
description: The Fed dissenters  who oppose telling markets that rates are likely to stay low for a long time  have come in for a lot of well-deserved criticism over their claims that the job market is improving (it isnt) and that inflation is a serious threat. On the latter front, I and others have pointed out that the rise in core inflation in the first half of 2011 is looking very much like a temporary blip driven by commodity prices.

title: In Googles Motorola Deal, Icahn Gets His Wish (Again)
description: Motorola Mobility shareholders are undoubtedly exuberant about Googles $12.5 billion deal for the cellphone maker.

title: Vain Glorious | Ric Pipino Is Dunking It
description: Neon brights have jumped from the runway into hair on the street, thanks to celebrities including Scarlett Johansson (cherry red), Katy Perry (fuchsia), Rihanna and Dianna Agron from Glee, who just went hot pink. But for those of us who arent attention-starved peacocks or rock stars,there is a more subtle option: a splash of color that suggests look at me again, according to the New York-based hair stylist Ric Pipino.

title: Last Men
description: A sci-fi video animation by Adam Shecter, shown in June at the Lower East Sides Eleven Rivington gallery.

title: Fox Signal (No More Suicides)
description: Adam Shecter interprets a poem by Matthea Harvey.

title: T by Adam Shecter
description: The New York City artist Adam Shecter's animation for T Magazine.

title: For Coal Plants, a Game of Chicken
description: In an article in Fridays paper, I described how some companies that operate dirty coal-fired power plants are playing chicken as they face a decision on whether to retire them or install expensive scrubbers and filters. They are waiting to see what their neighbors will do as new environmental rules take effect: as with two restaurants in a town that can support only one, if your neighbor goes out of business, more business comes to you, and prices may well rise.

title: U.S. Stocks Return to Pre-Downgrade Level
description: Stocks swept higher Monday on Wall Street, returning the overall market to where it was before the United States credit rating was downgraded.

title: Is Iowa Irrelevant?
description: The political scientists Charles Franklin and Joshua Tucker have pushed back against my finding that the Ames Straw Poll, which was won by Representative Michele Bachmann on Saturday, is a good early indicator of success in the Republican primaries. Mr. Tucker notes that only two of the six candidates to have won the straw poll have gone on to win the Republican nomination (George W. Bush and Bob Dole, who tied for first with Phil Gramm in 1995).

title: Wells Fargo Brings Citadels Investment Banking Unit Aboard
description: Wells Fargo announced on Monday an agreement to hire 25 investment bankers from Citadel, whose founder, Kenneth C. Griffin, recently decided to sell the unit after a failed attempt to transform the hedge fund into an investment bank in the wake of the financial crisis.

title: Obama Tries to Reclaim Momentum With Midwest Bus Tour
description: CANNON FALLS, Minn.  For most of the summer, President Obama has been under siege in the White House. On Monday, he became a road warrior, kicking off a three-day bus tour of the Midwest that provided him campaign-style opportunities to strike back at Republicans in a region vital to his re-election.

title: A Face From Japans Earthquake
description: The picture of the Japanese woman among the ruins of Natori appeared on the front page of this newspaper and in newspapers around the world after the earthquake and tsunami. She sits on a concrete foundation, sobbing, her red boots lined up neatly to her right. She wasnt identified in the photo, but some information about Akane Ito, which turns out to be her name, later surfaced. The most complete version of her touching story is in this article in The Daily Mail from April. When the picture was taken, Ito later told the newspaper, she thought all 13 of her dogs had been lost. The Daily Mail update shows her reunited with two of them. (Sadly, since the article appeared, none of her remaining dogs have been found, according to news reports.)

title: U Like Pia Coladas?
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#1000", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Best Politics Quotes From the Weekend
description: DES MOINES  Did you miss the incredible political activity in Iowa this weekend? If so, The Caucus has a roundup for you of the best quotes from the weekend, Iowa-style.

title: Fair Officials Defend Moves Before Deadly Storm Struck
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Even as the metal rigging high above a packed concert here began to shudder, Indiana State Fair officials were walking toward the stage, preparing, they said, to order the crowd to evacuate to avoid an arriving storm.

title: Pundit Metrics
description: This seems to be new: the Times most-popular lists now include most viewed as well as most emailed. A welcome addition.

title: In a First, F.T.C. Settles With App Developer Over Childrens Privacy
description: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday announced a $50,000 settlement with a developer of mobile applications for children. The developer had been charged with violating the Childrens Online Privacy Protection Act by collecting information from children who used the apps without their parents permission.

title: Oh! What A Lovely War!
description: World War II is the great natural experiment in the effects of large increases in government spending, and as such has always served as an important positive example for those of us who favor an activist approach to a depressed economy. Christy Romer is very much on the same wavelength.

title: Street Style Photos: Polka Dots
description: The best of readers street fashion submissions for the week of Aug. 8.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: German Media Captivated by Farm Cow on the Lam
description: Germans love Yvonne the Cow.

title: Numberplay: Dont Make a Triangle, Part 1
description: Its game time again. Well be spending the next two weeks with Katherine Cook. You may remember her as half of the Math for Love team that recently brought us Lets Play 1-2-3 Nim. Ms. Cook will guiding us through an exploration of triangles and not-triangles.

title: A Rain That Could Stop a Platoon
description: COMBAT OUTPOST SABARI, Afghanistan  Just about anything can knock an American platoons operations off-course. Enemy fire. A cracked axle. Unusually loquacious tribal elders. New orders from a commander. For one company here in mountainous eastern Afghanistan, it was the rain.

title: Picture This: Cancer
description: Understanding how cancer begins and then grows is fundamental to one day preventing the disease. Here, we explain three new theories for how cancer may form.

title: No Subway, but a Little Silence on Second Avenue
description: Ah, the native sounds of a summer evening on the Upper East Side: hooting owls, honking cabs, chattering crickets. And, occasionally, the banshee-like shrieks of an air horn, followed by rumbling explosions that call to mind a Messerschmitt raid.

title: Governors Group Picks Successor to Perry
description: DES MOINES  Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia has been named chairman of the Republican Governors Association, succeeding Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who stepped down to run for president.

title: Judge Orders Televising of Mubarak Trial to End
description: CAIRO  The spectacle of Hosni Mubarak lying in a cage at his criminal trial will no longer be televised, the Egyptian judge hearing the case ruled Monday.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Cargill Buys Animal Feed Company for $2.1 Billion
description: Cargill, the American agricultural giant, said Monday that it planned to buy a Dutch animal nutrition company, Provimi, for $2.1 billion from the private equity firm Permira.

title: Mazda CX-9 Investigated for Brake-Fluid Leak; Maserati Issues Recall for Tie-Rod Problem
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating brake problems on about 37,000 Mazda CX-9 crossover sport utility vehicles from the 2008 model year.

title: Interpublic Sells Half Its Stake in Facebook
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, which has owned a tiny stake in Facebook since the days the social networking Web site was just for college students, is selling half its holdings for a hefty profit.

title: Cause Collab | Bean Pole and Kim Jones
description: When Kim Jones makes a move, the fashion world takes notice. The British designer, who was recently named menswear director at Louis Vuitton and previously lent his talents to Umbro and Dunhill, counts the stalwart Korean brand Bean Pole among his ever-growing list of collaborators, too. The full range of Bean Pole x Kim Jones mens clothing, which includes shirting, outerwear, knits and pants, combines a traditional fit and palette with enough idiosyncratic details to keep fans feeling comfortably satisfied. Think reversible nylon jackets, classic chinos done over in a raccoon dog print and Ed Ruscha-inspired color blocked button-ups.

title: "Seafarer"
description: William Carlos Williams reads the poem Seafarer at the 92Y in 1954.

title: Summing Up Your Job in Just Six Words
description: Its been a rough month so far, economically and financially speaking. A fun, creative challenge is in order, as a diversion from the doom and gloom.

title: The Ripple Effects of Googles Motorola Deal
description: Shares in Motorola Mobility jumped more than 56 percent on Monday after the companys $12.5 billion sale to Google was announced. But it was not the only technology company to see its shares rise.

title: How Far Should Consumers Unwind Debt?
description: In an article today, Tara Siegel Bernard and I examined whether the Feds announcement that it would keep credit cheap for two more years would inspire more people to borrow and spend.

title: A Vienna Festival Heads to New York
description: The Metropolitan Opera does not have a lock on outdoor, large-screen, high-definition opera transmissions. A popular summertime opera and classical music film festival has been operating for two decades in Viennas City Hall Square. Now a one-evening version, called the Vienna Music Film Festival NY, is heading to Brooklyn Bridge Park on Aug. 29 and will feature filmed excerpts of European opera productions. Austrian tourism and cultural authorities, along with the Vienna-based International Music + Media Center  a nonprofit association founded under the aegis of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization  and Czekaj Artistic Productions, are backing the show. The Met will present H.D. performances at Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5.

title: Takes a Village
description: Senior residents of Lincoln Park, Chicago, find a way to age at home.

title: Cats at the Bodega, Just Doing Their Job
description: Neighborhood celebrity, surrogate pet, mercantile mascot: the bodega cat has long been one of the unsung heroes of the citys civic life.

title: Cancers Secrets Come Into Sharper Focus
description: For the last decade cancer research has been guided by a common vision of how a single cell, outcompeting its neighbors, evolves into a malignant tumor.

title: Conquering the Divide
description: CUT BANK, Mont.  The most direct path through Glacier National Park is called, famously and aptly, Going-to-the-Sun Road. About 51 miles long, it begins in the town of West Glacier, proceeds pleasantly along the wooded southeastern shore of Lake McDonald, providing intermittent glimpses of soaring peaks, and then, as if a giant had stepped on the end of the road, mistaking it for a seesaw, begins ruthlessly, gorgeously climbing. It goes northeast for three miles or so, then makes a hairpin turn and heads southeast along a mountain precipice and up, up, up  endlessly up if youre on a bicycle. From the turn its eight miles to Logan Pass. There, at 6,646 feet, the road crosses the Continental Divide.

title: In Texas Jobs Boom, Crediting a Leader, or Luck
description: HOUSTON  Texas is home to at least one-third of the jobs created nationwide since the recession ended. The states economy is growing about twice as fast as the national rate. Home prices have remained stable even as much of the country has seen sharp declines.

title: No Credit? No Problem
description: One of the most important questions for small businesses hovering through all of the tumult of the last three years is whether theyve been able to get the credit they need. The question has been hotly debated  even becoming a partisan issue last year, when Congress wrestled with the small-business lending fund that ultimately became law in the small-business jobs act. Banks tell anyone who will listen that they are eager to lend to any creditworthy business they can find. Republicans tend to put it slightly differently: small businesses that deserve credit can get it, but many are too cautious to make investments right now. Many Democrats and some small-business advocates say a good loan is hard to find.

title: Former FrontPoint Manager Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
description: 6:06 p.m. | Updated
