title: Monday Motorsports: Wet New Hampshire Speedway Brings IndyCar Crashes and Controversies
description: Wet racetracks have encouraged some of the most memorable overtaking maneuvers in motorsports history. They also have subjected race officials to pointed criticism for allowing competition to go on despite the heightened risk to drivers and crews. At New Hampshire Motor Speedway on Sunday, there was plenty of excitement and finger-pointing to go around.

title: Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater Sign Up for Seminar With Alan Rickman
description: An unconventional writing course taught by Alan Rickman in the coming Broadway comedy Seminar has snared its first two victims  er, students. Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater have joined the production of this Theresa Rebeck dark comedy, it was announced on Monday, playing aspiring novelists who pay $5,000 each for the privilege of working with Leonard, the internationally renowned literary figure played by Mr. Rickman.

title: Original Model Ts | Adam Shecter
description: No. 4 in a series of original artworks.

title: The Caucus | A Three-Way Race Emerges
description: Michael D. Shear on Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and the new dimensions of the Republican presidential race; John Harwood on President Obama's Midwest bus tour.

title: MMT, Again
description: In a way, I really should not spend time debating the Modern Monetary Theory guys. Theyre on my side in current policy debates, and its unlikely that theyll ever have the kind of real  and really bad  influence that the Austrians have lately acquired. But I really dont feel like getting right back to textbook revision, so heres another shot.

title: Why Pawlentys Candidacy Failed
description: There are a number of lessons one could take away from the surprisingly early implosion of Tim Pawlentys presidential aspirations, which not long ago seemed like something to be taken seriously.

title: Caucus Video: Three-Way Republican Race Emerges; Obamas Bus Tour
description: Michael D. Shear on Rick Perry and the new dimensions of the Republican presidential race. John Harwood on President Obamas bus tour through the Midwest this week.

title: Ice Cream Treats Without Ice Cream
description: One of the best things about making your own fancy ice cream desserts, like those I write about in A Good Appetite, is that you dont actually have to use ice cream. There are so many frozen dessert alternatives out there that those who have to avoid ice cream can still partake.

title: Growing Older in an Urban Village
description: Faced with the usual options for senior housing and elder care, some older adults are inventing their own grassroots versions  do-it-yourself senior living thats friendlier, more autonomous and less expensive. Fellows in the News21 program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism are posting video reports on four of these: a shared housing arrangement in White Plains, a senior co-housing development in Virginia, an urban village in Chicago and an R.V. community in East Texas.

title: Still More Rain for New York Area
description: On Day 2 of the midsummer deluge, they put away the rowboats. They pumped basements. And they looked at the steel-gray sky and said, Thats not good.

title: Perry Jabs Romney in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  On his third day in the race, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas wasted little time drawing distinctions on Monday with Mitt Romney, highlighting his experience creating jobs at home.

title: Summer Squash, With a Lighter Touch
description: Recently, I asked for recipe requests on the Recipes for Health Facebook page. There were many for squash, and no surprise: In August, home-delivered produce baskets are filled with pattypans, green and yellow zucchini, yellow crookneck squash and sturdy ronds de Nice.

title: The Locavores
description: Three of Brooklyns greenest beauty queens share their favorite all-natural products, like fancy face creams and organic aphrodisiacs.

title: Second Tibetan Monk Burns Himself to Death in Protest
description: A Tibetan Buddhist monk protesting Chinese policies immolated himself publicly in a Tibetan area of Sichuan Province in southwest China on Monday, an outside advocacy group reported. It was the second such act in the area in the past five months and appeared to reflect resistance to increased Chinese repression of loyalty to Tibets exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama.

title: Washington, Capital of Economic Optimism
description: In case youre wondering why Congress spent so much time twisting itself in knots over the long-term deficit, instead of over the current jobs crisis, this might help explain things: Washington, D.C., is the most economically optimistic area in the nation, according to Gallup.

title: Hugh Dancy Joins Broadway Cast of Venus in Fur
description: When Hugh Dancy made his Broadway debut in the 2007 revival of Journeys End, it was as a British Army captain down in the trenches of World War I. When Mr. Dancy returns to Broadway this fall, he wont be taking on the Central Powers  hell face off against Nina Arianda in Manhattan Theater Clubs coming production of Venus in Fur, the David Ives comedy-drama about an ever-shifting audition encounter between a director and an actress, the productions press representatives said on Monday.

title: Ex-Leader of Thailand Gets a Visa From Japan
description: Japan has granted a visa to Thaksin Shinawatra, the former prime minister of Thailand who was ousted from power by the Thai military in 2006 and who has lived in exile since a Thai court convicted him of corruption three years ago.

title: Tunisian Protesters Watch Mubarak Trial With Envy
description: Seven months after protesters ousted the Tunisian president, Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali, the streets are still restless over the countrys judicial system.

title: In Decline, Stillbirths Continue to Devastate
description: I had been in active labor for 12 hours when my obstetrician said he would have to do a Caesarean because Twin A was stuck and neither twin could emerge naturally. Terrified of losing either baby, I responded, I dont care if I cough them up, just get them out alive!

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 15
description: Players in Hays, Kan., got an early start on the high school football season and Marcos Ambrose won the Nascar race at Watkins Glen, N.Y.

title: Anonymous to BART: We Hack. We Organize, Too
description: Anonymous, the loosely affiliated group of computer hackers, is planning a flesh-and-blood demonstration Monday afternoon in San Francisco to protest the Bay Area Rapid Transit cutting off underground cellphone service to thwart protesters.

title: As the Worm Turns
description: Q. Do earthworms have any sense of place or direction? When they are dug up in the garden and put back down someplace else, do they just return to work, or do they try to get back to their former location?

title: Con Artists Claim Purchases Are Covered by eBay Motors, Crime Center Warns
description: Internet con artists are trying to sell vehicles they do not own, and to impart a look of legitimacy to their enterprise they are touting a fraudulent relationship with the e-commerce site eBay Motors, according to a statement issued Monday by the Internet Crime Complaint Center. The center is a partnership of the National White Collar Crime Center, the Bureau of Justice Assistance and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: These Apartments May as Well Already Have Monograms
description: Growing up on Long Island, Jeremy Noritz says, he was always interested in fine art, especially sculpture and painting. So, when he bought a loft in a converted warehouse on West 29th Street in 2006, he jumped at the chance to transform it.

title: An Index for Ocean Health
description: What has been billed as the Dow Jones of ocean health is six months from release, and Ben Halpern is feeling the pressure. Were frantically wrapping up analyses, Dr. Halpern, a research biologist at the University of California at Santa Barbara, said in a telephone interview.

title: Refuse Collects Here, but Visitors and Wildlife Can Breathe Free
description: Waiting lists for selective colleges, fine restaurants and overbooked flights are familiar enough  but Singapore may have the only landfill with a four-month wait once you sign up to visit.

title: Letting Charlie Bite the Finger Again
description: Gerber is using revamped versions of two wildly popular YouTube videos starring mischievous children to promote its products.

title: Was There Insider Trading on S.&P.s Downgrade?
description: Justin Lane/European Pressphoto Agency

title: The New York Film Festival Employs A Dangerous Method
description: Carl Jung, Sigmund Freud and plastic surgery will all be part of this years New York Film Festival. The Film Society of Lincoln Center announced gala screenings of two new films from directors familiar to the festival scene. One is A Dangerous Method, the latest from David Cronenberg. It will be the Canadian filmmakers first film to screen at this festival, although his previous work has appeared at Cannes, Venice and Toronto. The other, The Skin I Live In, is a thriller from New York Film Festival veteran Pedro Almodvar.

title: Mistakes in Storage May Alter Medication
description: What does extreme heat do to medications? I found out while we were sweating out the recent heat wave in a lake cabin in New Hampshire and my 10-year-old sons allergies kicked up.

title: Barbera: I Knew It When
Ristretto | First Look at Sightglass Coffee Roasters
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#164", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: To Those Who Have Lost Faith in Investing
description: Part of the investors dilemma is that no matter how much data we have about the past, we have no data for the future. No matter what history says about the long-term, upward trend of the stock market, we still dont know for sure what the future will bring.

title: Perks of Cross-Training May End Before Finish Line
description: The question has occurred to many endurance athletes, and it seems so basic: Will cross-training  doing a second sport, or lifting weights on days when you arent running or cycling or swimming  improve your performance in your primary sport?

title: Adolescent Health | General Well-Being and Safety
description: Weve decided to declare this Adolescent Health Week on The Learning Network, because we know how important it is for students to be able to make safe and healthy lifestyle decisions, and because we have a lot of teaching materials to offer on the topic, partly because of the prevalence of teenager-related health topics in the news in the past few years.

title: Turkey Warns Syria to Stop Crackdown
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Turkeys foreign minister demanded Monday that the Syrian government end its crackdown on a five-month-old uprising immediately and unconditionally, warning that unspecified steps would be taken otherwise.

title: Cuomo Opts to Vacation Close to Home
description: ALBANY  After an eventful first seven months in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has decided it is time for a vacation.

title: Scaring, and Scarring, Parents-to-Be
description: I am back from two weeks spent hopscotching around the country, a mix of work and vacation. Among other things, I met scores of wonderful writers at BlogHer in San Diego  many of whom will become guest posters here over the next weeks and months. I also overdid the Mexican food in California, the stuffed pizza in Chicago and the lobster in Montauk.

title: Shorelines, Sandy or Otherwise, That May Not Last
description: If you like a day at the beach  and who does not?  you can find lots of books that will enhance your experience by telling you about the birds, the fish, the plants and even the bugs you will encounter there.

title: Bring It On Screenwriter Alleges Musical Shenanigans
description: In Bring It On, the 2000 movie starring Kirsten Dunst, two cheerleading squads faced off amid accusations of stolen routines. Now that animosity has carried over to a new musical based on the movie.

title: In Search of Customized Homes
description: This week, The Appraisal takes a look at two super-specific apartment renovations, one with a retro-yet-futuristic submarine sort of feel, the other that took the city and the four elements  imagine subway cars, metamorphic rock and a river running through it  as its inspiration. The second one managed to find a buyer after years and a few price cuts; the other has just come on the market.

title: The New Prospectors
description: As gold prices climb, more people are joining the ranks of Australias modern gold hunters.

title: This week: A disease with a mind of its own, looking for the oldest forms of life on Earth and is it a boy or a girl?
description: This week: A disease with a mind of its own, looking for the oldest forms of life on Earth and, is it a boy or a girl?

title: Bookshelf
description: Coinciding with an exhibition at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs in Paris, Hussein Chalayan (Rizzoli, $85) explores the Cypriot-British designers provocative and pathbreaking signatures, including rotting silk dresses and nude models in chadors.

title: Grizzlies Return, With Strings Attached
description: DUPUYER, Mont.  Russell Talmo, a bear management technician, greeted John and Leanne Hayne at their ranch on the windswept edge of this tiny town with a gift: a can of pepper spray to ward off grizzly bears.

title: TimesCast | August 15, 2011
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's interior minister lands in Cairo with his family; Monday is the most violent day in Iraq this year; and a three-way race for the Republican nomination emerges.

title: AMC and CBS Find Ratings Success
description: Just as viewers were easing into their couches on Sunday night to enjoy another tense hour of Breaking Bad, AMC announced that it had renewed the show for what would be its final run of episodes, filling those viewers with joy, followed by dread that the show would soon come to an end. According to Nielsen data, 1.8 million total viewers watched the episode  a 9 percent increase over the same point from last season. That continues an overall trend for the year that suggests a slowly growing audience. But how will viewers (and potential viewers) approach the show now that the end for Walter White is officially in sight?

title: With Early Prep Time, Brunch Is a Breeze
description: A CHEERY weekend brunch provides a most civilized platform for outdoor eating, especially when the dishes can be prepared almost entirely ahead. When all you have to do before you wish to eat are simple assembly jobs, you are left to fill the role of laidback (dare I say glamorous?) brunch hostess.

title: More Than Memories to Keep Spirit of Elaines Alive
description: Not all of the memorabilia from Elaines, the Upper East Side restaurant that closed a couple of months ago, will be up for sale at an auction planned for September: The restaurants yellow-and-black sign and one of the tables that celebrities and celebrity-watchers prized the most are being donated to the New-York Historical Society, according to Diane Becker, the restaurants longtime manager.

title: Google Looks for Vertical Integration
description: Googles acquisition of Motorola Mobility for $40 a share may mean the company thinks the best way to make money with mobile computing is by owning the device. DealBooks editor, Andrew Ross Sorkin, speaks to Tavis McCourt, an analyst with Morgan Keegan, in a CNBC interview about what this might mean for competitors.

title: Penguins Not Counting Crosby Out for Opener
description: Ray Shero, the Pittsburgh Penguins general manager, said Monday that Sidney Crosby was still experiencing symptoms from the concussion that sidelined him in early January.

title: Made in China, but Still Profiting Americans
description: 4:40 p.m. | Updated to correct the name of the organization that released the study.

title: Looking Like A President
description: Steve Benen has a righteous rant about pundits who judge candidates on whether they look like a president. That immediately made me think of two things. First, I remember the Vietnam War  and I remember William Westmoreland, who came straight from central casting, but unfortunately was a pretty bad general. Second, I remember this, which seems especially appropriate for Governor Goodhair:

title: Really? The Claim: To Prevent Migraines, Drink More Water
description: THE FACTS

title: A Night Out for Fashionistas
description: If youve ever dreamed of meeting Oscar de la Renta or Michael Kors  and, really, who hasnt?  then Fashions Night Out is the event youve been waiting for. The lineup for this years event, scheduled for Thursday, Sept. 8, has just been announced, and it includes appearances around New York by most of the fashion industrys most notable figures.

title: Bachmanns Dont Ask Position a Legal Possibility
description: If elected president, Michele Bachmann said over the weekend, she would favor reinstating the ban on openly gay or lesbian people serving in the military, a policy known as dont ask, dont tell. Former Senator Rick Santorum has said similar things in the past.

title: TimesCast | Libyan Minister in Cairo
description: Aug. 15, 2011 - Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi's interior minister, Nassr al-Mabrouk Abdullah, flew to Cairo with his family in an apparent defection.

title: A.I.G. Names New Treasurer
description: The American International Group announced Monday that Brian T. Schreiber, its executive vice president for Treasury and capital markets, had been named to the additional role of the insurers treasurer.

title: Stockholm Syndrome
description: Im off to the European Finance Association meeting, combined with a family trip. No column Friday and next Monday; I might post a bit on the blog, but hopefully not too much.

title: Protest Over Chemical Plant Shows Growing Pressure on China From Citizens
description: BEIJING  More than international prestige or even economic might, the top priority of Chinas leadership is to maintain stability among this nations vast and varied population. President Hu Jintao explicitly reaffirmed that goal just last month, telling a Communist Party celebration that without stability, nothing can be accomplished.

title: The End Comes for Kate Plus Eight
description: Kate Gosselins big family will no longer be followed by TLCs cameras on a regular basis.

title: Watch Your Step While Washing Up
description: The smallest room in the house can be a dangerous place.

title: A Farewell to M. Wells
description: M. Wells, the celebrated little diner in Long Island City, Queens, that opened last summer and announced at the start of August that it would close at months end, has been throwing farewell dinners on Friday and Saturday nights. The first was an evening devoted to the fruits of the Fulton Fish Market in the Bronx. There was another devoted to the joys of melted cheese. On Saturday night, the theme was caviar and magic. Seats ran $200 a head.

title: TimesCast | Widespread Attacks in Iraq
description: August 15, 2011 - Coordinated attacks across Iraq raise questions about the country's ability to maintain security.

title: Regimens: Soothing Melodies for Cancer Patients
description: Listening to music may reduce anxiety and pain in cancer patients, new research suggests.

title: Picture of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Egypt, Somalia and Afghanistan.

title: Who Pays the Supercommittee?
description: The 12 members of the supercommittee that will try to develop yet another bipartisan fiscal policy proposal have now been named. What types of spending programs and tax breaks should we expect these members to care about most?

title: Cross-Training by Lifting Weights
description: Many athletes try to spice up their workouts by cross-training in another sport. A runner might jump on a bicycle, for example, or a cyclist might go for a run.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Libya, Egypt and Somalia.

title: The Most Dangerous Room in the House
description: Whats the most dangerous room in the house? While parents and caregivers for the elderly often worry about kitchen hazards like hot stoves and sharp knives, the riskiest room in the home is the bathroom.

title: Rain, but Little Gloom, at Fiat 500 Movie Screenings in Times Square
description: Fiat turned Times Square into a drive-in of sorts last weekend, parking 36 examples of its 500 coupe and cabriolet to be used as seating for two nights of film screenings.

title: Buffett Takes Stake in Dollar General
description: Warren E. Buffett noted in an op-ed article in The New York Times that most Americans struggle to make ends meet. So it probably makes investment sense that he has taken a stake in a retailer that draws in those very same Americans who are trying to find bargains wherever they can.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: I Light Up My Life
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on Artsbeat between now and the festivals close on August 28. For more information, go to www.fringenyc.org.

title: Hearing the Mystery in Sibelius
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  At one point here this weekend, the opening minutes of a documentary about Jean Sibelius were screened. The films score is the classic, almost unbearably emotional recording Sibelius made when he emerged from retirement to conduct his Andante Festivo over the radio in 1939.

title: Early Plants Grew Wood as Plumbing, Study Says
description: Two small plants, both about 400 million years old, are the oldest known examples of wood, according to a new study. The older of the two plants predates other early examples of wood by at least 10 million years.

title: The Caucus: Bachmanns Dont Ask Position
description: Just in case you missed it, over on The Caucus, James Dao posts on whether Michele Bachmann, if elected president, could reinstate Dont Ask Dont Tell. (Spoiler Alert: Possibly.)

title: Sentence of the Month, A Big Greasy Breakfast of Winners
description: Its been awhile since we held a proper Sentence of the Week contest, which means we have a roiling abundance of sentences to deal with. Just look at them all:

title: A Supergene Paints Wings for Surviving Biological War
description: The gaudy brown Brazilian butterfly known as Heliconius numata has long puzzled geneticists. It has seven different wing patterns, each of which mimics that of a different local species of Melinaea, another group of butterflies.

title: So, Doctor, Isnt There a Pill to Cure Middle-Aged Angst?
description: The title of Josh Koenigsbergs dark new comedy, Herman Klines Midlife Crisis, at the Beckett Theater, is a little misleading. Sure, the lead character  Dr. Herman Kline, the 50-something head of the trauma bay at Mount Sinai Medical Center  is definitely feeling a crisis of confidence. But so is his wife, Liz, trapped as much by her station as a homemaker and doctors wife as by her age.

title: The Right Architect With the Wrong Name
description: A decade after 9/11, Amy Waldmans nervy and absorbing new novel, The Submission, tackles the aftermath of such a terrorist attack head-on. The result reads as if the author had embraced Tom Wolfes famous call for a new social realism  for fiction writers to use their reporting skills to depict this wild, bizarre, unpredictable, Hog-stomping baroque country of ours  and in doing so, has come up with a story that has more verisimilitude, more political resonance and way more heart than Mr. Wolfes own 1987 best seller, The Bonfire of the Vanities.

title: Debt in Europe Fuels a Bond Debate
description: FRANKFURT  The Germans want to bury it. The French say it is a nonstarter. But the idea that the only way to contain the sovereign debt crisis is for Europe to issue bonds backed by all the nations of the euro zone will not go away.

title: Youth Quake | London
description: What do you wear when protest and mayhem rock your world? Reports from three epicenters of street style: London, Cairo and Tokyo.

title: Steve Jobs Biography Set for November Release
description: It is not often that technophiles get as excited about a new book as they do about a new gadget. The release of a biography of Steven P. Jobs, Apples co-founder, might be one of those rare moments.

title: Hot Weather Takes Toll on Medication
description: The recent heat wave may have taken a toll on your medication. Thats what reporter Walecia Konrad learned after her sons allergy medication stopped working after being exposed to high temperatures on a family vacation at the lake.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Dirty Harry'
description: A. O. Scott looks at the themes of justice and vengeance in the 1971 film starring Clint Eastwood.

title: Briton Arrested for Plotting Water Fight by BlackBerry
description: In a demonstration of the kind of zero-tolerance policing of modern criminality that will no doubt impress Irans morals police as much as Egypts military rulers, officers outside London announced on Monday that they had arrested a man for sending text messages encouraging people to take part in a mass water fight.

title: Closer to Her Fans and Further Away From Her Past
description: She is thunder, Beyonc is. Fire and quake. A thing that cant quite be contained. There is not any better advertisement for Beyonc than Beyonc herself, a hard worker who makes effort look like the most glamorous thing in the world.

title: Girl Scout Cookies vs. City Zoning Laws
description: In Hazelwood, Mo., Carolyn Mills and her daughters, Abigail, 14, and Caitlin, 16, have sold Girl Scout cookies from their driveway for years. But after a neighbor complained that the cookie stand created too much traffic and was causing dogs to bark, city officials told the Millses that selling cookies there violated the citys zoning code.

title: Living With a Name That Evokes Pop Stardom, and Curious Glances
description: MY travel has increased quite a bit since Ive become president of DKC. Ive always traveled for business, but now it seems as if Im in an airport all the time, which really doesnt bother me. I like airports.

title: A Feast of Food Links
description: A Harvard study links red meat, especially processed red meat, to an increased risk of Type 2 diabetes: A daily 100-gram serving of unprocessed red meat may increase the risk of developing Type 2 diabetes by 19%, while just 50 grams of processed meat  for example one hot dog, a sausage, or two slices of bacon  is associated with 51% increased risk. Wait for it, wait for it . . . the American Meat Institute says nah.

title: Preserving Old-Time Cuisine and Values
description: Family Restaurant is the General Tsos chicken of reality shows: deep fried and suspiciously sweet, concocted in North America to satisfy Western tastes. Which means it can be pretty satisfying, in half-hour portions, though the MSG (multi-stereotype glutamate) may leave you with a headache.

title: The Dude Sings
description: JEFF BRIDGES

title: A Naval Base in South Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Gold Fever Gripping the Australian Outback
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Four years ago, Marco Nero was on top of the world. He was earning more than $1 million working as a film effects designer for some of the worlds most prestigious digital animation houses.

title: Pathogens May Change, but the Fear Is the Same
description: In House on Fire: The Fight to Eradicate Smallpox, Dr. William H. Foege, one of the conquerors of the virus, describes a grotesque moment in the war: The last victim in Benin, in West Africa, is visited by several fetisheurs  witch doctors  seeking to harvest his scabs.

title: T.S. Eliot Devotees Angered by Plans to Develop East Coker
description: Houses rise and fall, crumble, are extended,/Are removed, destroyed, restored T.S. Eliot wrote in East Coker, a poem in his famed collection Four Quartets. Now a proposal to do the first  build a development with 3,750 houses and an industrial estate on the edge of East Coker, in Somerset  has prompted protests from Eliot devotees.

title: A Conflict Over Conflict Minerals
description: To the Editor:

title: For Some in Menopause, Hormones May Be Only Option
description: For women hoping to combat the symptoms of menopause with nonprescription alternatives like soy and flaxseed supplements, recent studies have held one disappointment after another.

title: Music, Memories and Regret
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  A piano is a dangerous thing in Ten Cents a Dance, John Doyles beautiful, brooding collage of the songs of Rodgers and Hart, now at the Williamstown Theater Festival here. A piano, you see, makes music. And music makes memories. And memories, well, as often as not they make regrets. So a piano can hurt a guy bad, especially in a place like the deserted gin palace where Ten Cents a Dance takes place.

title: The Republican Weekend
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: New Counterterrorism Chief for F.B.I. in New York
description: The F.B.I. has assigned a new counterterrorism chief to its New York field office.

title: Phone Messages Improve Care, Study Finds
description: Using cellphones to broadcast text messages reminding health workers in Kenya how to treat childrens malaria increased the number of cases handled correctly, a new study has found.

title: Romneys Fire on Obama Not Turned on Perry
description: LITCHFIELD, N.H.  Hitting the campaign trail on Monday in New Hampshire, Mitt Romney compared President Obama to Jimmy Carter, said, Hes in over his head when it comes to the economy, and sent out a campaign release calling the presidents swing through Iowa this week a Magical Misery bus tour.

title: Bloggingheads: G.O.P. Moderates D.O.A.?
description: Erica Grieder, left, of The Economist and Evan Smith of The Texas Tribune debate whether a moderate Republican can win the primary.

description: Most dangerous metro areas for pedestrians.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Trader Says He Made Backup Plan Ahead of Firing
description: Jeffrey Gundlach, a prominent bond fund manager, testified on Monday that he began making backup plans in case he was fired by his employer, the Trust Company of the West.

title: Ironclad Solutions (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Superintendents Call State Agency Ineffective
description: Nearly three-quarters of New Jersey school superintendents said the state Education Department did not play an important role in helping districts raise students achievement or prepare graduates for college and careers, according to a survey the department released Monday.

title: George C. Devol, Inventor of Robot Arm, Dies at 99
description: George C. Devol, a largely self-taught inventor who drew from science fiction to help develop Unimate, the revolutionary mechanical arm that became a prototype for robots now widely used on automobile assembly lines and in other industries, died on Thursday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 99.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,722 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Germany Is Flying Above the Economic Storm in Europe
description: BERLIN  There is no one whose thoughts European officials would rather read than Chancellor Angela Merkel, who meets Tuesday at the lyse Palace with Frances president, Nicolas Sarkozy, as they struggle to find a lasting solution to the European debt crisis.

title: Is Google Turning Into a Mobile Phone Company? No, It Says
description: Matthew Staver/Bloomberg NewsLarry Page, a Google co-founder, left, and Eric Schmidt, the former chief executive, in Sun Valley, Idaho, in 2009.

title: Egypt Deploys Soldiers to North Sinai
description: CAIRO  Egyptian soldiers who were sent to crack down on lawlessness in the North Sinai Desert killed a man in a gunfight on Monday and captured a dozen others in a series of early morning raids, security officials said.

title: For the Space Needles Birthday, a Trip to Space
description: SEATTLE  Already, a gender divide seems to be developing over the desirability of being launched into space, at least in the Bordian family, who were visiting the Space Needle here the other day, staring out at the cloudy cityscape and mulling the towers latest promotional contest  for a suborbital spaceflight, 62 miles above the earth.

title: Giants Breathe Easier as Umenyiora Returns
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Ever since training camp began more than two weeks ago, the Giants had strenuously denied that the star defensive lineman Osi Umenyioras holdout was a distraction.

title: Israel: Plans for New Housing Advance
description: Israel has recently advanced plans for the construction of 277 housing units in the Jewish settlement of Ariel, deep inside the West Bank, the defense ministers office said on Monday. The move, the latest in a flurry of settlement activity, comes ahead of Palestinian plans to seek United Nations recognition as a member state in the fall. Last week Israels Interior Ministry announced approval for a contentious 1,600-apartment complex in East Jerusalem and said it would soon approve an additional 2,700 housing units there, prompting Palestinian fury and international criticism for undermining efforts to restart peace negotiations. Israel insists on keeping Ariel under any border agreement. The Palestinians claim that territory, conquered by Israel in the 1967 war, as part of a future state.

title: Even Without a Course of Its Own, St. Johns Produced a Champion
description: St. Johns is perhaps best known for its basketball program, but it has a pretty good golf team, too  one that produced Keegan Bradley, the surprise winner of the P.G.A. Championship on Sunday.

title: Sides in Verizon Strike Trade More Accusations
description: Verizon said on Monday that there had been 143 acts of sabotage to telephone facilities since 45,000 of its workers went on strike Aug. 7.

title: With Hair Pat-Downs, Complaints of Racial Bias
description: TIMERY SHANTE NANCE is an African-American woman who has a thing about her hair. I dont use chemicals or straighteners, she said. Its just my natural texture, and I wear it in a normal-looking puff.

title: A Gold Standard Is Unthinkable No More
description: Fiat money has worked well since Richard Nixon ended the dollars peg to gold 40 years ago this week, but this latest recession must gnaw at believers. If years of ultra-cheap cash give rise to serious inflation or an accelerated retreat of the American currency, the gold standard, however erratic and deflationary, could start to appeal again.

title: Medicaid Pays Less Than Medicare for Many Prescription Drugs, U.S. Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Medicaid gets much deeper discounts on many prescription drugs than Medicare, in part because Medicaid discounts are set by law whereas Medicare prices are negotiated by private insurers and drug companies, federal investigators said Monday in a new report.

title: Hedge Funds Disclose Positions
description: John A. Paulson, the hedge fund manager at the helm of the mighty Paulson & Company, has been bleeding money this summer in his Advantage Plus fund, which was down 31 percent at last count.

title: Young Champions Ready to Move, With No Baggage
description: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.

title: City Selling Space in Brooklyn Building
description: It is unlikely that any visitors to the property assessors office in the stone monolith known as the Brooklyn Municipal Building ever looked around at the clerks poring over tax records and exclaimed, It would be fun to spend my next paycheck here. But the Laboz brothers think it could be just that sort of place.

title: The Phantom Menace
description: Washington

title: A Foot Care Company Shifts to Sell a New Line of Shoes
description: AH, the search for the perfect shoe  comfortable, stylish and able to help you leap tall buildings in a single bound or at least make the elevator in three.

title: Losing Privacy in Route Plans
description: Imagine that every car had a global positioning device and that before every trip, drivers were required to let the traffic authorities know where they were going. And suppose the government released all that data to the public so anyone could follow a cars movements online simply by entering a license plate number.

title: Casting Off Gloom, Deal Makers Are in a Frenzy of Activity
description: Turmoil in the stock market. A downgrade of the United States credit rating. The economic crisis in Europe.

title: Emerald Cities
description: Wastewater Treatment Plant may not sound like a scenic destination. But some ecologically minded towns have been designing a new breed of wildlife preserve, one that gives recycling a lively twist. Instead of dumping treated water, they return it to nature as the essence of an ecosystem that offers food and habitat to animals. Migrating and native birds find a niche, entangled communities of plants and insects take up residence and a hodgepodge of wild animals bustles in.

title: Virtual and Artificial, but 58,000 Want Course
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  A free online course at Stanford University on artificial intelligence, to be taught this fall by two leading experts from Silicon Valley, has attracted more than 58,000 students around the globe  a class nearly four times the size of Stanfords entire student body.

title: No Parking From 6 to 4, but Limos Are Welcome
description: Outside two Trump Place residential buildings on Riverside Boulevard in Manhattan, exclusivity has extended its boundary into the street.

title: Catholic Clergy Protest Popes Visit, and Its Price Tag
description: MADRID  The Rev. Eubilio Rodrguezs church is a prefabricated building in an area of this city hard hit by Spains economic crisis. In front of the altar are a few scraggly potted plants. Behind it, some plastic chairs.

title: Nat Allbright, Voice of Dodgers Games He Did Not See, Dies at 87
description: Nat Allbright was around 8 when he began memorizing lineups for one of the days big-league ballgames. He then pretended to broadcast the baseball game he imagined the men played.

title: Edging to Center, Her Eye on the Mayoral Race
description: Christine C. Quinn was making the rounds at a senior center in Harlem when Scott Bright, a 67-year-old retired security guard wearing a Hawaiian shirt, asked her to pose with him for a photo.

title: Sending the Police Before Theres a Crime
description: The arrests were routine. Two women were taken into custody after they were discovered peering into cars in a downtown parking garage in Santa Cruz, Calif. One woman was found to have outstanding warrants; the other was carrying illegal drugs.

title: What Is Business Waiting For?
description: When the German economy turned south after the 2008 financial crisis, the pain was mitigated by a program known as Kurzarbeit.

title: A Closer Look at Taxes on the Rich
description: With the budget deficit growing and tax rates at a 60-year low, one question will remain near the center of the political debate in the coming months: Should the federal government raise taxes on the rich?

title: After Streak Ends, Braves Uggla Remains Focused
description: ATLANTA  Dan Uggla awoke Monday with a consecutive-games hit streak of zero. For the seasons first three months, that situation had greeted him nearly as often as the risen sun. His batting average scraped the National League floor, bottoming out at .170.

title: On Wide Florida Roads, Running for Dear Life
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  As any pedestrian in Florida knows, walking in this car-obsessed state can be as tranquil as golfing in a lightning storm. Sidewalks are viewed as perks, not necessities. Crosswalks are disliked and dishonored. And many drivers maniacally speed up when they see someone crossing the street.

title: Googles Coup Shifts Mobile Alliances
description: Major telephone makers like Samsung, HTC, Sony Ericsson and LG said on Monday that they supported Googles planned purchase of Motorola. But will they still feel that way in a year?

title: Albert Brown, Survivor of Bataan March, Dies at 105
description: Albert Brown, the oldest American survivor of the Bataan Death March, in which as many as 11,000 soldiers died at the hands of the Japanese in the Philippines in 1942, and perhaps the oldest American veteran of World War II, died Sunday in Nashville, Ill. He was 105 and lived in Pinckneyville, Ill.

title: In the World of Wireless, Its All About Patents
description: Google, in announcing a $12.5 billion deal for Motorola Mobility on Monday, saved its warmest words not for Motorola Mobilitys management or its products, but for one valuable asset: the companys roughly 17,000 patents, as well as an additional 7,500 patents that are under government review.

title: After Making Successful Return to Lineup, Posada Now Hopes He Can Stay
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  In his first game in a week last Saturday, Jorge Posada hit a grand slam and had six R.B.I., his most since 2006. It was an emotional day for him as the fans lavished him with ovations and a request for a curtain call.

title: A Recess Destination With Bipartisan Support: Israel and the West Bank
description: WASHINGTON  Looking for your member of Congress? Try Jerusalem.

title: Republican Extremism, Bad Economics

title: Pondering the Meaning of Brancas Jewish Roots
description: For Shel Wallman, a co-editor of the Jewish Sports Review, the searching question, if rather high profile, was not uncommon: should Ralph Branca, historic goat, get to join the magazines list of official Jewish athletes?

title: The Clear Case for the Gas Tax
description: Unless Congress extends it, the 18.4 cents-a-gallon federal gas tax will expire on Sept. 30. Allowing that to happen would be tremendously destructive. It would bankrupt the already stressed Highway Trust Fund, with devastating effects on the countrys highways, bridges, mass transit systems and the economy as a whole.

title: N.C.A.A. Chief Suggests a Summit on Conference Expansion
description: Mark Emmert, the president of the N.C.A.A., reached out to several top college officials Monday, suggesting a meeting to discuss a less cannibalistic and more collegial way to approach conference expansion.

title: Making the Rounds
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, has been traversing New York City recently as she lays the groundwork for a 2013 mayoral campaign.

title: The Unions Spy Game
description: At the outset of the Civil War, neither the Union nor the Confederacy had a centralized military intelligence department  and yet the need for information on enemy troop movements, political developments and even simple things like geography was immediate. In the breach, they turned to a motley crew of amateur spies who were as untrained and untested as the soldiers who met on the early battlefields at Bull Run and Wilsons Creek.

title: A Confident Perry Lingers to Make Friends at the Fair
description: DES MOINES  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas was about to be overshadowed by yet another heckler at the Iowa State Fair on Monday when he turned to an old cheerleading trick.

description: Rebels and pro-Qaddafi forces battled over the strategic city of Zawiyah.

title: Prosecutors Call Shopping Venture a Sham

title: A Race to Repudiate Government
description: At one level, its ridiculous that 17,000 people in a small Iowa town could cast a vote that ended the campaign of a major Republican presidential candidate, Tim Pawlenty. Given the nature of the Republican primary system  and the mood of its voters this year  it has its own grim logic. Why not let a handful of conservatives and libertarians winnow the field? It will toughen up the candidates for the extremist gauntlet to come.

title: An Industry in Need of Accountability

title: Miles and Miles of Drought
description: This year, Texas has received less than half its normal rainfall: 6.53 inches instead of 16.03. Climatologists say this dry spell is the worst one-year drought since Texas began keeping rainfall records in 1895, and they predict that the cause of the drought  the weather created by the Pacific current called La Nia  may well extend into next year. For farmers and ranchers, this is a disaster. Agricultural losses have already surpassed the record  $4.1 billion in 2006  and could double.

title: Googles Big Bet on the Mobile Future
description: Tim Boyle/Bloomberg NewsSanjay Jha, the chief executive of Motorola Mobility, who has been responsible for turning around the company, will remain as the divisions top executive.

description: On Day Two of the summer deluge, they put away the rowboats but not the umbrellas. They pumped basements. And they looked at the sky and said, Thats not good.

title: In Open Primary Plan for Arizona, a Call for Moderation
description: PHOENIX  The person who recently hurled a padlock out the window of a passing vehicle at a Republican candidate for the State Senate, who was jogging along the side of the road, may have had no political motive at all. But as the police investigate, some here already consider the incident one more example of the politics in this state veering toward the extreme.

description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  If you happen to be the owner of a teenager with a cellphone, you know that the English language is just not what it used to be. Textspeak is a typed dialect unto itself, and sometimes it spreads horrifically into spoken language (You just crack me up, LOLz )

title: Reversing Course, Officials in New Jersey Cancel One-Bid Immigrant Jail Deal

title: Duda, Man of Few Words, Confronts Increased Profile
description: SAN DIEGO  Lucas Duda can cut an intimidating figure, even among the other large men of major league clubhouses. And yet he often slinks in and out of them unnoticed, never having altered their complexion.

title: Nordstrom in New York to Use an Alias

title: Newark Officer Shoots Stolen S.U.V.s Driver During Pursuit
description: A Newark police officer shot a driver during a pursuit on Monday night in which a stolen vehicle struck a pedestrian and began dragging her down the street, law enforcement officials said.

description: The Minnesota Twins had lost eight of their last nine games before Monday, so they did what struggling teams do this time of year: they traded a veteran for prospects. It had to be discouraging to a player like Jim Thome.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  In a major league career that began in 1999, A. J. Burnett had won 23 games in August before Monday, more than in any other month except July, in which he also has 23 victories.

title: In Chrysler Deal, Cellulosic Ethanol Firm Gets a Prominent Partner
description: Chrysler entered into a memorandum of understanding with the cellulosic ethanol producer ZeaChem, it was announced Monday. But though the automaker builds so-called flex fuel vehicles that run on an E85 ethanol formulation, it is unclear exactly what might come of the new partnership.

title: Its the Aggregate Demand, Stupid
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

title: Breaking the Tax-Talk Taboo?
description: Will Warren Buffetts Op-Ed yesterday begging Congress to raise his taxes start a movement? Its kind of fun to imagine the 8,274 Americans who earn more than $10 million a year marching on Washington carrying signs: Slash the Deficit! Raise My Marginal Tax Rates!

title: Getting Ready for Baseballs Week 17
description: One of the hardest things about fantasy baseball is the sheer length of the season. It almost seems as though were in the stretch run, and that if youre near the top of the standings, youve largely done your job, but its not so. Theres roughly 25 percent of the season left to play, plenty of time for the front-runners to fall apart or for those within reasonable striking distance to make up the necessary ground.

title: App Smart Extra: More on Sleeping-Aid Apps
description: The most recent App Smart column, on apps that help you relax and sleep, earned a fair amount of circulation among insomniacs. People who suffer from poor sleep will happily pay a few dollars on an app, if it leads to a few hours of deep slumber. And they are not above trying multiple apps, gadgets or mind tricks to find sleep.

title: In London, Wonders of the World in Miniature

title: Britain Will Force Convicted Rioters to Clean Up
description: LONDON  Rioters and looters convicted following the violent unrest that convulsed Britain this month will wear orange jumpsuits and help clean up areas affected by their actions, Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg said Tuesday, as part of a riot payback scheme.

description: NEW DELHI  An anticorruption protest leader whose arrest on Tuesday morning reverberated across India, inciting outrage at the government, ended the day with a very different twist: He refused an offer to be released from jail.

title: Don Henley Urges Artists to Know Their Rights
description: The drummer, singer and songwriter Don Henley is a founder of the Eagles, one of the most popular of American rock bands from the 1970s onward, and the Recording Artists Coalition, which seeks to protect the rights of musicians and songwriters. Other members of the coalition, which in 2009 became part of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, have included Bruce Springsteen, Madonna, Billy Joel, Elton John, R.E.M., Dave Matthews, Eric Clapton, Sting, Joni Mitchell, Bonnie Raitt and No Doubt. Last month Mr. Henley spoke with Larry Rohter about changes in copyright law that allow artists to reclaim ownership of recordings issued after Jan. 1, 1978, from the record labels that originally released them by invoking their termination rights. Here are excerpts from that conversation:

Election reform advocates welcomed the move, but some analysts expressed skepticism that it would result in significant revisions in time for the next election.

Bernanke, pay a visit to Texas.

I actually thought of that too, but theres a bit of a problem  its hard to get a state-level equivalent of the usual ratio, which shows employment from the household survey relative to the adult population.

description: One morning last week, after appearing on Jay Leno,then catching the red-eye flight to Montreal, Gordon Ramsay stood before a number of reporters and cameramen, smiling and massaging a roast chicken. Behind him, encased in glass, more chickens twirled slowly on a rotisserie spit, flames leaping menacingly from below. It was all very Hells Kitchen.

description: Would-be bed-and-breakfast owners can turn to Airbnb to get their operations off the ground, and basement inventors have Kickstarter  to test the waters and see if their creations have a market.

description: Environmental groups and some legislators are asking Gov. Andrew Cuomo for a longer public review of a New York State plan to permit a controversial method of natural gas extraction that combines hydraulic fracturing with horizontal drilling.

title: Letter Raises New Questions About Internal Inquiry at Tabloid
description: Updated | 5:29 p.m. A disgraced reporter for The News of the World complained in a 2007 letter to his employers that he should not have been fired for phone hacking because the practice was widely discussed in the daily editorial conference, until explicit reference to it was banned by the editor, as my colleagues Sarah Lyall, Ravi Somaiya and Alan Cowell report.

title: Wanted: A Good Job and Some Understanding
description: My father and I dont talk much about my time in the war. Ive told him a little about my frustrations with the experience and about my contradictory feelings of pride and humbleness. During dinner one evening, when we were discussing my difficulties with juggling my civilian job and National Guard responsibilities, my father finished chewing his food and placed his fork down on the table.

title: Court Sides With Trustee Over Madoff Payouts
description: A federal appeals court panel reviewing one of the fiercest legal disputes to arise from Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme ruled on Tuesday that the embattled trustees approach on how to calculate investor losses in the case is legally sound and fundamentally fair.

title: First 5 Minutes: 'Jane Eyre'
description: The opening scene from the latest film adaptation of "Jane Eyre," directed by Cary Fukunaga and now on Blu-ray and DVD.

title: Parliamentary Documents Released in Tabloid Hacking Case
description: Documents from the Home Affairs Committees investigation into phone hacking at the News of the World tabloid. The documents include a letter from former royal correspondent Clive Goodman, who claims the practice was widely discussedin daily meetings and approved by senior editors.

title: A Town Beacon, With a Side of Soft Serve
description: Just outside of Reading, Pa., a proud owner has turned his Dairy Queen into a cornerstone of the community.

title: Reeve Carney to Play Jeff Buckley in Biographical Film
description: Anything You Can Do is not a song associated with the catalog of Jeff Buckley, but it is one that seems to apply to the competitive zeal surrounding two rival film projects seeking to dramatize the life of that singer-songwriter.

title: Good Will to All, With a Side of Soft-Serve
description: KENHORST, Pa.

title: Notes From the Underground | Myla Dalbesio
description: The latest installment of Chelsea Art Walk was arguably hijacked by a rebellious performance piece by the budding artist Myla Dalbesio. Barely clothed in a hot pink bikini and stripper heels, and covered in slimy brown body paint, Dalbesio writhed on a dollar-bill-coated floor of the tiny back room at Ramis Barquet gallery, covering herself, the room and innocent bystanders with sticky, cheap Champagne.

title: Edelbrock Highboy: A Slice of Land Speed History Heads to Pebble Beach
description: One of the cars present at the birth of hot-rodding, the Edelbrock Highboy Roadster, will be offered Friday at the RM Auctions event in Monterey, Calif. This memento from land speed racings roots carries a pre-auction estimate ranging from $350,000 to $450,000. Thats a price that would probably bring an ironic smile to any hot-rodder old enough to remember the humble beginnings of the typical highboy.

title: Take One Dog, Add Water and Shake
description: On a beach outing recently, my friends and I watched a yellow Labrador frolic in the waves and dig with abandon in the sand. Then, to our horror, he bounded toward us and stopped. We all knew what was coming.

title: Watch the Throne Breaks iTunes Record
description: Jay-Z and Kanye West have broken a record set by Coldplay for the most iTunes downloads of an album during its first week of release, as their collaboration Watch the Throne sold more than 290,000 digital copies on Apples music service, a publicist for Mr. West said. The album was released last Monday after months of hype and publicity, and it was exclusively avaible on iTunes for the first three days, doubtless boosting its sales on the service.

title: Chinas Troubled Railway Ministry Fires Spokesman
description: BEIJING  Chinas railways ministry said Tuesday that it had dismissed its spokesman, whose statements after a high-speed train collision in eastern China last month became a target of public ridicule.

title: Sarkozy and Merkel Vow Fiscal Unity for Euro Nations
description: PARIS  Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, and Frances president, Nicolas Sarkozy, on Tuesday called for closer coordination of economic policy among the 17 countries that share the euro currency and proposed that they enshrine in their constitutions an obligation to balance their national budgets.

title: Michael Lewiss Piece is a Luftnummer, and Thats not a Compliment
description: Editors note: Michael Lewis was for many years a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine, and we hold him in very high esteem. But his recent piece about German economics in Vanity Fair has caused some controversy (viz Felix Salmon of The Columbia Journalism Review and Kevin Drum of Mother Jones ), so we asked Stephan Seiler, an Arthur F. Burns Fellow in journalism from Hamburg, Germany, who is currently in residence at the Times Magazine, for his reaction to the piece. Heres his take on it.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: The Day the Sky Turned Black
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festivals close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: A Slitherer Makes a Comeback
description: The Lake Erie watersnake, a harmless critter that can grow to more than three feet in length, has been removed from the federal list of endangered and threatened wildlife after a successful decadelong effort to protect the snake and its habitat, the Interior Department announced this week.

title: At This Library, Check Out the Tomatoes
description: Robert Cox walked into the public library on City Island in the Bronx the other day to read the daily papers and to grab a handful of cherry tomatoes from a bowl of fresh produce next to the checkout counter.

title: A Nice Guy Hits No. 600
description: Chances are you didnt see much more than a highlight of Jim Thome hitting his 600th home run Monday night. And until then, you might not have even been aware he was close to becoming the eighth player to reach that milestone. And even now, you might need to be reminded he plays for the Minnesota Twins. His monumental achievement received less media hype than Derek Jeter on a double date.

title: The Case for Harbinger Group as the Next Berkshire
description: Someone loves Philip A. Falcone.

title: Donating Breast Milk
description: The use of donor breast milk has grown significantly in recent years, according to The Houston Chronicle, which details a breast milk donor program at Texas Childrens Hospital.

title: With Bank Failures Mounting, Some Complain of Harsh Exams
description: Financial regulators have taken a public thrashing for going easy on banks before the financial crisis hit, allowing institutions big and small to dole out dubious loans. Now, according to some community bankers, regulators have abandoned their light touch for a heavy hand at a time when the industry is struggling to recover.

title: Edible Selby | Nordic Cuisine in Stockholm
description: Chefs Fredrik Andersson, Victor Fransson and Peter Goldberg bring a minimalist aesthetic and a whimsical, free-form approach to Swedish cooking. Audio and Photos: Fredrik Andersson on his restaurant, Mistral >>

title: Yankees List of Draft Signings
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Yankees have signed eight of their first nine 2011 draft picks and 19 of their 25. Their top pick, the high school third baseman Dante Bichette Jr., the 51st pick over all, signed on June 18.

title: Theyre Chess Pieces. Theyre Old. O.K. Theyre From Norway. Oh, Yeah?
description: Scholars have long thought that the Lewis Chessmen  eight-century-old chess pieces carved mostly out of walrus tusk that were found on the Isle of Lewis, in the Outer Hebrides, Scotland, in 1831  were made in Trondheim, Norway.

title: Lawyers for Defendant in Giffords Shooting Seem to Be Searching for Illness
description: PHOENIX  Jared L. Loughners grandparents and great-grandparents died years ago, but lawyers defending Mr. Loughner in connection with a Jan. 8 shooting spree outside Tucson are delving into their lives and those of numerous other Loughner ancestors in an apparent effort to show that mental illness runs in the family.

title: Alan Richman, M. Wells and the State of Service in New York Restaurants
description: So Alan Richman has a barn-burner column in the new GQ about how he had a couple of good meals at M. Wells in Queens and then a horrible third one that led to a shocking exchange of e-mails between him and one of the restaurants owners, Sarah Obraitis, in which she accused him of giving a waitress a hardy pat on the backside. The crossfire led to much discussion on Twitter and Eater .

title: Debit Overdraft Fees, While Voluntary, Are Still Steep
description: Even though banks now must get permission from their customers before charging overdraft fees on debit card purchases, the fees they charge are still hefty  and some big banks have increased the maximum number of overdraft fees customers can run up each day.

title: Brooklyn Takes a Bow as a Town of Writers
description: Brooklyn, Brooklyn, take me in, the chorus of an improbably lovely song by the Avett Brothers implores. Are you aware the shape Im in?

title: Gay Malaysian Pastors Wedding Plans Stir Anger
description: Government officials in Malaysia have expressed outrage over the plans of a prominent gay Malaysian to marry in New York  and celebrate the wedding back in his home country.

title: Books and Backpacks From Blackstone
description: Students will be clamoring over the hottest fall fashions as they head back to school this month. But thanks to the Blackstone Group, 150 New York students will be able to one-up classmates by showing off their private equity connections.

title: Dollar Stores: Shelf by Shelf
description: The ubiquitous dollar store is the American dream writ small.

title: Could Things Break Any Worse for AMC?
description: It was just this May that an article in New York magazine described AMC as the fastest-rising network in America and wondered if that cable channel could survive its own success. Three months later that question seems more pressing and prophetic than ever. After rapidly building its brand of original programming around prestigious and much-lauded series like Mad Men and Breaking Bad, AMC has been roiled by behind-the-scenes disputes and controversies at every one of its signature shows  even the ones it hasnt started broadcasting yet. Although the network received 29 Emmy Award nominations in July (including a fourth consecutive best drama nod for Mad Men), that moment was a rare bright spot amid months of developments that were often as gloomy as the art direction for The Walking Dead.

title: A Happy 200th to The Timess First Publisher, Whom Boss Tweed Couldnt Buy or Kill
description: I dont think the devil will ever make a higher bid for me than that.

title: Trout Fishing in a Climate-Changed America
description: As difficult as it is to predict precisely how the planet will warm over the next century or so, it is even harder to refine predictions of how those changes will affect specific species. Thats because warmer temperatures alone are not the only driver of what happens to, say, four varieties of trout.

title: Injury to Turner Leaves Jets Thin on Line
description: 6:46 p.m. | Updated

title: Syrian Enclave of Palestinians Nearly Deserted After Assault
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  United Nations officials said Tuesday that as many as 10,000 residents of a Palestinian refugee neighborhood in the Syrian port city of Latakia had fled during a four-day assault, as security forces carried out more arrests and intimidation in what residents said was a government attempt to rebuild a wall of fear in one of Syrias largest cities.

title: Asked and Answered | Mary Wilson
description: A Supremes fanatic gets to quiz a musical idol.

title: Soft Serve in a Small Town
description: A local Dairy Queen serves as a gathering place to beat the heat of summer.

title: The Real San Marzanos
description: A can of San Marzano tomatoes is an icon for food lovers: with red, concentrated flesh, plum-shaped San Marzanos are often the only kind deemed acceptable by chefs and cookbooks.

title: If Not Christie, Then Who?
description: Daniel Larison and Jonathan Chait, among others, are dismissive of my suggestion that the prospect of a Mitt Romney-Rick Perry showdown should inspire Chris Christie to take another look at the presidential race. Heres Larisons counterargument:

title: Contractors Are Accused in Large-Scale Theft of Food Aid in Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Beyond freelance gunmen, Islamist militants, cholera, malaria, measles and the staggering needs of hundreds of thousands of starving children, aid agencies scrambling to address Somalias famine now may have another problem to reckon with: the wholesale theft of food aid.

title: The Legend of Zhayi Zhaga
description: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

title: Thinking About a Double Dip
description: Watching the debt-ceiling talks and the stock markets gyrations the last few weeks, along with the resulting fears that we may be entering another recession, has reminded me of something that happened many years ago.

title: Israeli Air Strike Hits Gaza After Rocket Fire
description: GAZA  A Palestinian militant was killed early Tuesday in an Israeli airstrike on Gaza that was mounted in response to rocket fire from the enclave, which is controlled by Hamas, a militant Palestinian political group.

title: Love Blessed by Lady Liberty Lives On
description: One question went unanswered last week when the National Park Service announced it would shut down the Statue of Liberty for renovations in October: What happened to the couple who got engaged in the crown when the statue reopened on July 4, 2009?

title: Large Account Loss Leads to Layoffs at DraftFCB Agency
description: The loss of the giant SC Johnson & Son account is leading the DraftFCB advertising agency to lay off hundreds of employees.

title: Ron Paul: He Who Shall Not Be Named
description: Is Ron Paul getting a raw deal? Jon Stewart, host of The Daily Show, thinks so.

title: After Dropping PBS, Los Angeles Station Makes Deal of Its Own
description: KCET, the Los Angeles public television that quit carrying PBS shows Jan. 1 because it said the dues were too high, has found a new source of original programs that it will get free.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 16
description: The day in sports included cricket in Sri Lanka, rugby in France and the Palio of Siena horse race in Italy.

title: LinkedIn Targets Mobile Users
description: LinkedIn hopes to capture some of the frenzy surrounding social networking on smartphones with a series of major updates announced Tuesday on the companys Web site.

title: Meal Plan
description: Ian Marber, the well-known London-based nutritionist and author (a k a the Food Doctor), helps his celebrity clientele stay slim and healthy using a revolutionary technique. I dont blind people with science, he says. I simply teach them how to eat.

title: What to Call a Half-Sibling?
description: What to call one another when forming a family? It used to be simple: wife took husbands name; kids did, too. But it hasnt been for a long time.

title: Two Rick Perry Books Are on the Way
description: The entrance of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas into the Republican presidential race may be bad news for Mitt Romney and Michele Bachmann, but so far it seems to be good news for the book business. On Tuesday, two publishers announced forthcoming books on Mr. Perry, The Associated Press reported. Metropolitan Books will publish a work, with an unprintable title, by James C. Moore, the co-author of Bushs Brain, and the Texas political consultant Jason Stanford in early 2012. The book, to be subtitled Why Rick Perry Will Make America Miss George W. Bush, will describe Mr. Perry as an ideologue with scant interest or success in governing, according to the publishers announcement. Crown, meanwhile, said it would publish Rick Perry and his Eggheads, by Sasha Issenberg, as an e-book next week. The e-book, about Mr. Perrys successful 2006 re-election campaign, is based on Mr. Issenbergs larger work, The Victory Lab, which is expected in the fall of 2012 and is to explore how social science and statistical analysis are changing political campaigning.

title: Seeing Chicago Through a Theatrical Scrim
description: The Australian theater company One Step At a Time Like This has brought its introspective walking tour to Chicago from Melbourne this summer in en route, presented by Chicago Shakespeare Theater.

title: Recipes for Ice Cream
description: Recipes for dinner-worthy desserts.

title: Criticism Is Growing Over Shells Response to Oil Leak
description: LONDON  Pressure mounted on Royal Dutch Shell to explain how 1,300 barrels of oil could have leaked from a pipeline into the North Sea in a spill that has tarnished Britains reputation for avoiding such problems.

title: Adolescent Health | Sex and Teenage Pregnancy
description: Its never easy to talk about sex, but weve tried to make it as easy as possible with this collection of resources, our second installment in Adolescent Health Week.

title: Mediterranean Dream Trip Higher-Lights
description: 4:55 p.m. | Updated

title: See You Soon, Yemens President Promises Supporters
description: Ali Abdullah Saleh, the embattled president of Yemen, looked remarkably healthy as he stared defiantly into the camera during his third television appearance in less than a week and promised his supporters on Tuesday that he would see you soon in the capital, Sana.

title: In Vietnamese Village, Stitching the Wounds of Human Trafficking
description: HOP TIEN, Vietnam  Rare visitors to Hop Tien often catch a first glimpse of this sleepy village in a blur as they career, white-knuckled, around a hairpin turn high in the mountains above.

title: Group of Robbers Sought in 3 Bronx Attacks
description: The police are looking for a group of young men who have been robbing and beating people in Fordham Heights in the Bronx. In a surveillance video released on Tuesday, a 64-year-old man is seen holding open the vestibule door at 2100 Creston Avenue on Aug. 8 for a youth who then grabs him by the neck, throws him to the ground and proceeds to beat and kick him with the help of two confederates.

title: Paula Vogel Will Leave Early as Head of Yales Playwriting Program
description: The playwright Paula Vogel is leaving and staying. Ms. Vogel, the chairwoman of the playwriting department at the Yale School of Drama, has decided to step down at the end of the 2011-12 academic year, a year before her five-year term was scheduled to conclude. But she will remain a member of the faculty, which she joined in 2008, and will continue teaching at the school as she works on two projects.

title: Poll Finds Bloombergs Approval Rating the Lowest in 6 Years
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs job approval rating among New Yorkers has hit its lowest point in six years, with residents conveying widespread anxieties about the citys economic prospects, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Off the Shelf | The Wanderings of Odysseus
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#71", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Whats Behind the Hefty Motorola Breakup Fee
description: Google proved itself willing to pay up for Motorola Mobility, agreeing to buy the cellphone maker for $12.5 billion, a 63.5 percent premium.

title: Fox Wins Viewers With Food
description: The chef Gordon Ramsay led Fox to a ratings victory on Monday with new episodes of Hells Kitchen and MasterChef, both setting season highs for the night in total viewership, at 6.8 million (Hells Kitchen) and 6 million (MasterChef) viewers. It was Foxs most-watched Monday with summer programming in more than three years. An absence of competition certainly helped, as Bachelor Pad on ABC was the only other show on the broadcast networks not in reruns. It averaged 6.3 million viewers over two hours, dropping 9 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with last weeks premiere.

title: A Slow Start For Anderson Cooper At 8 P.M.
description: Anderson Cooper moved into the most important time slot on cable news, 8 p.m., last week. But he didnt receive a very warm reception from viewers.

title: The Industry With the Most Steadfast Retirement Savers
description: What is it about utility workers? They apparently are among the countrys most dedicated retirement savers, according to new research from Vanguard.

title: No Cover for Perry From Bush Team
description: In this hyper-partisan age, there is typically a circle-the-wagons mentality when a politician says something as controversial as Rick Perry did when he called the actions of the chairman of the Federal Reserve almost treasonous.

title: Reviewing Danji
description: Hooni Kim opened Danji, at 346 West 52nd Street, in December.

title: Feel Free to Graze but Just Be Quick
description: DANJI is a wee little restaurant on West 52nd Street, done up in whitewashed brick and blond Ikea stylings, naked bulbs, extension cords and a lot of wooden spoons artfully displayed, as if by David Rockwell on a $200 budget. The crowds are fierce.
