title: TimesCast | August 16, 2011
description: Palestinian refugees flee Latakia, Syria during a four-day assault by government forces; France and Germany hold economic talks; and President Obama and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas campaign in Iowa.

title: Big City Book Club | Coming Soon
description: From Bartleby, the Scrivener to The Bonfire of the Vanities New York has been a compelling character in American letters. The Big City Book Club aims to generate lively online discussion of works, classic and current, obvious and obscure, fictional and non, in which the city features centrally.

title: For Fringe Festival Playwright, Porgy Brouhaha Has a Familiar Ring
description: Even before Stephen Sondheim weighed in angrily on planned revisions to Porgy and Bess, the show, its permutations and how African-Americans are depicted in theater had been on the mind of the playwright Leah Maddrie.

title: Tighter Qualifications for School Bus Drivers
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed legislation on Tuesday expanding the kinds of criminal convictions that bar people from driving school buses.

title: Giants Re-Sign Grant for Depth at Safety
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Deon Grant lost a couple of things in his brief time away from the Giants. He lost his uniform number, which has been worn by the rookie safety Jarrard Tarrant for the first three weeks of camp. He lost his portable stereo, which he donated to charity at the end of last season.

title: Ron Paul Rolls Out New Campaign Ad
description: Ron Pauls supporters might be frustrated by the lack of news media coverage for his presidential campaign, but at least he can keep up with the competition in the world of paid media.

title: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Somalia, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Yemen.

title: Accounting Board to Seek Comments on Rotating Auditors
description: WASHINGTON  An accounting oversight board agreed on Tuesday to seek public comment on whether companies should be required to change their auditors every few years, a move that supporters say they believe would strengthen the independence and objectivity of accountants that inspect corporate ledgers for accuracy.

title: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Somalia, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Libya.

title: Wheelies: The Sinking-Feeling Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: More Surgeries for James Levine
description: James Levine, the Metropolitan Operas music director, has received two previously undisclosed back operations since the spring, when he canceled a Met tour to Japan and his schedule at the Tanglewood Music Festival, his brother said on Tuesday. But now, without the excruciating pain that has plagued him over the last several years because of back problems, Mr. Levine is planning to begin rehearsing at the Met right after Labor Day and has not canceled any performances, said his brother, Tom Levine. The surgeries have done what theyre supposed to do, he added.

title: In Vietnam, Healing a Village Wounded by Trafficking
description: A textile cooperative started for women rescued from the sex trade is thriving, lifting a small Vietnamese village near the border with China.

title: Bank of America in Talks With Blackstone Over Merrill Real Estate
description: Bank of America is in talks to sell a major portion of Merrill Lynchs real estate portfolio to the Blackstone Group for up to $1 billion, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday, as the bank seeks to raise additional capital.

title: A 17-Year-Old Beanstalk From a Wholesome 70s Family Is Eager to Go Far Out
description: The Talls, by Anna Kerrigan, is the rare play about an American family in reasonable working order. True, mother is a little remote, and preoccupied with her best-friendship with a Roman Catholic nun. Perhaps father is distracted from the kids big games by his forthcoming campaign for comptroller of the city of Oakland, Calif. Still, by the standards of American drama of the last half-century, the Clarke family is positively wholesome, almost ready for a prime-time sitcom of the 1960s.

title: Pete Pihos, Eagles Hall of Fame Receiver, Dies at 87
description: Pete Pihos could do just about anything on a football field. A member of both the College and Pro Football Halls of Fame, he was an outstanding pass-catcher, a powerful runner and a formidable blocker, helping to take the Philadelphia Eagles to two consecutive National Football League championships in the 1940s.

title: A Camera Bag That Actually Looks Good
description: Camera bags usually get short shrift when it comes to design and fashion-forward thinking. While laptop bags often look like little purses complete with fancy buckles and handsome materials, most camera bags are one step up from a fanny pack in styling.

title: BBC Radio 1 Returns (Sort of) to Satellite Radio
description: Less than a week after it replaced BBC Radio 1 with a channel devoted to the disco hits of the Studio 54 era, Sirius XM, the satellite radio broadcaster, announced that the British music channel will return to its regular lineup  but only online.

title: Critics Notebook: Next, in Chicago
description: Now appearing: a restaurant in footlights.

title: Now Appearing in Chicago, a Restaurant in Footlights
description: CHICAGO

title: Dell Posts Flat Sales but Its Profit Rises 63%
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dells sales flattened in its latest quarter as government spending declined and the company pared low-margin sales, but its net income rose 63 percent.

title: TimesCast | Leaders Meet About Euro Zone
description: As weak economic data hit Europe's two largest economies, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany announced proposals aimed at stabilizing the euro zone.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: A Magician Pulling Strings to Prove a Point: Love Stinks
description: Handels opera Orlando has had a peculiar life. It was little more than a footnote in Handels day. He composed it in 1732, to an anonymous libretto based on Ariostos Orlando Furioso. He performed it only 10 times in 1733, then dropped it entirely, never bothering to revive it. It languished until the 20th century, when conductors (mostly of the period-instrument persuasion) began to nudge it into the repertory alongside Alcina and Ariodante, Handels two other works based on Ariosto.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Starting Them Young

title: The Cannibal Next Door? No Reason to Be Afraid
description: The owners of Resto, a Belgian-accented restaurant known for its whole-animal feasts and nose-to-tail specialties, needed more space for butchering. An adjacent storefront was just the ticket. By day, starting Friday, they will sell terrines and fresh sausages made by the chef, Michael Berardino, above, as well as sandwiches, ground beef from Pat LaFreida and other cuts of fresh meat. In the evening it will turn into a restaurant with small plates and whole animal feasts using pigs, lambs or goats. They have some 350 beers to quaff with food or to take out. The Cannibal was the nickname of a Belgian cyclist, Eddy Merckx, so the owners, Christian Pappanicholas and Bobby Hellen, will sell bicycling gear along with blood sausage.

title: Dear Leader, Ive Made a Friend in the South
description: What Chekhov said about the gun on the wall also applies to the cute white puppy in the street in Park Jungbums Journals of Musan, winner of the best new narrative director award at the Tribeca Film Festival this year. When we see it introduced early on as the only real friend of the miserable North Korean defector Seung-chul (played by Mr. Park), we can be pretty sure that it will be used to manipulate our emotions cruelly before the film is over.

title: Choose a Tiramis or Construct Your Own
description: Nadia Tade, a tiramis enthusiast from Italy, and her partner, Alessandro Radici, who is in the graduate business school at Columbia, hope to make tiramis the next gelato. With Dolce Vizio Tiramis, which opened on Saturday, they have tapped into what appears to be a growing trend in Italy: variations on tiramis, the traditional Venetian dessert made with a type of ladyfinger layered with a mascarpone custard and flavored with espresso and cocoa. A tiramis shop opened in Milan three weeks ago, Ms. Tade said. They beat us to it, but not by much. Their airy shop sells tiramis in six flavors, including lemon, berries and chocolate, with the option to assemble your own. Fabrizio Ferrari, a Michelin-starred chef from Bergamo, was in New York helping to fine-tune the recipes. Portions are sold to eat at tables, with a cup of espresso perhaps, or to take away in plastic containers.

title: A Wild Maine Blueberry Unlike Its Cousins
description: Small, dark, tangy wild blueberries from Maine, below left, seem to bear little relation to the typically fleshy cultivated berries, right. They are terrific in pancakes, muffins and scones. Lynn Thurston, who is a kind of blueberry broker, gets berries that farmers gather from wild bushes on their land and distributes them in the Northeast through her company, Blue Sky Produce. It gives the farmers an alternative to selling them for the frozen market, she said. Dry pint containers hold about two and a half cups. Thats anywhere from 800 to 1,200 berries, she said. I know because I once counted them.

title: Champagne by the Case
description: The bubbly flowed, the diamonds too. For one good-time girl in 70s L.A., it seemed as if the party would never end. Adapted from Loose Diamonds  and Other Things Ive Lost (and Found) Along the Way, to be published by William Morrow in September. Some names have been changed.

title: Illustrious Local Compatriot Contributes to a Troupes New York Visit
description: The dancers of Cisne Negro, the Brazilian company appearing this week at the Joyce Theater, are so glowingly amiable, youthful, attractive, enthusiastic and musical that you wish the programs choreography made them look better. The three pieces they are presenting here this week, however, tend to show their limitations, obscure their virtues and saddle them with clichs. At the end of each dance you dont feel inclined to applaud much. Since these performers merit affection and deserve encouragement, its a frustrating experience.

title: Excerpt: 'Olive and the Bitter Herbs'
description: From left, Dan Butler, Richard Masur and Marcia Jean Kurtz in a scene from Charles Busch's new play "Olive and the Bitter Herbs," at 59E59 Theaters. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: A Peek at Apples Plans for Grand Central Store
description: After putting up considerable resistance, Apple executives finally let the Metropolitan Transportation Authority release renderings Tuesday of the Apple store planned for Grand Central.

title: A Village Person Tests the Copyright Law
description: The prefab, gaudily costumed 1970s group the Village People and its big hit Y.M.C.A. are enduring symbols of the disco era. But now this campy and eternally popular song has become the centerpiece of what could be a significant test of copyright law.

title: A Diners Magic in a Vanishing Act
description: M. WELLS, the celebrated little diner in Long Island City, Queens, that opened last summer and announced at the start of August that it would close at months end, has been throwing farewell dinners on Friday and Saturday nights. The first was an evening devoted to the fruits of the Fulton Fish Market in the Bronx. There was another devoted to the joys of melted cheese. On Saturday night, the theme was caviar and magic. Seats ran $200 a head.

title: A Victory in Court for the Author of The Help
description: Its been a pretty good few days for Kathryn Stockett. The movie version of her mega-best-selling book, The Help, did well at the weekend box office and on Tuesday a lawsuit alleging that she had based a character in the book on a real person without permission was thrown out by a Mississippi judge.

title: Williams Reaffirms $5.5 Billion Bid for Southern Union
description: For those who thought that the Williams Companies had walked away from the fight for the Southern Union company, think again.

title: TimesCast | Refugees Attacked in Syria
description: August 16, 2011 - As Syria continues suppressing anti-government protests, a Palestinian refugee camp is caught in the crossfire.

title: Untitled
description: Untitled is the restaurateur Danny Meyers second foray into the art world.

title: A Unified Berlin
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite the Odds, a Jazz Label Finds a Way to Thrive
description: Steve Coleman and Five Elements were deep into one of their horizonless, hypnotic inventions at the Newport Jazz Festival this month, and the tent-sheltered crowd seemed duly absorbed. Mr. Colemans alto saxophone slashed through the air, often in off-kilter counterpoint with the vocalist Jen Shyu. The shifting rhythmic base was punctuated by the drummer Tyshawn Sorey, who called to mind an octopus, limbs moving in steady flow. It was all a vivid barometer reading from Mr. Colemans pressure system and, by extension, a reflection on Pi Recordings, his current label home.

title: Children of Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Silence, Please, for the Electric Camaro Drag Racer
description: Huge clouds of smoke rolled off the giant slicks of Ron Adamowiczs 1981 Chevrolet Camaro as he prepared for a quarter-mile attempt earlier this month at New Yorks Lebanon Valley Dragway. Nearby fans, aware of the powerful roar that accompanies the burnout ritual, raised hands to ears. That proved unnecessary, as the only sound to be heard was generated in the paddock by gassers awaiting their turn. On the track, all was silent but for the the hum of electric motors and spinning wheels.

title: Cancer Drug Shortages: 2 Senators View
description: To the Editor:

title: Bachmanns Elvis Tribute, Slightly Off
description: Before making her pitch for the Republican presidential nomination in Spartanburg, S.C., on Tuesday Representative Michele Bachmann paused to show some respect.

title: Children With Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles P. Murray Jr., Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 89
description: Charles P. Murray Jr., who received the Medal of Honor for single-handedly preventing 200 German soldiers from attacking an American battalion while leading a scouting mission in France during World War II, died Aug. 12 at his home in Columbia, S.C. He was 89.

title: The New York Times/CBS News Poll, August 2011
description: The results of a poll conducted in August, 2011.

title: A Befuddling Sound, but Danceable Nonetheless
description: In what was his first live performance, Clams Casino was hunched over a minimal setup: an iPad connected to what appeared to be an iPhone with a cracked face. He didnt look up much, if at all, maybe because he didnt know what to make of the scene in front of him: the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, on a Saturday afternoon, teeming with people trying to make sense of the music he was playing, figuring out what it was supposed to do to their bodies.

title: Panoramas: Expanding the Shortcut Between the Seas
description: In the first expansion in the 100-year history of the Panama Canal, crews are starting to build a new set of locks that will handle much larger ships.

title: M.L.S. Tweaks Designated Player Rule
description: Major League Soccer on Tuesday announced a change to its designated player rule that is intended to entice its clubs to spend money on younger players with the potential to turn into international stars  instead of on aging players who have their best years behind them, as many currently do.

title: Dinner and a Show
description: A seat at the chefs-table at Aldea offers a front-row seat for the frenzied drama of high-end food preparation.

title: Bits Pics: Anonymous Protests in San Francisco
description: More than a dozen masked members of the hacker group Anonymous disrupted service on the Bay Area Rapid Transit system on Monday to protest the killing of a 45-year-old man by police officers last month.

title: Cigarette Companies File 2nd Suit Over Warnings
description: Five tobacco companies filed a lawsuit in federal court in Washington late Tuesday challenging the constitutionality of regulations and graphic warning labels under the 2009 law that imposed federal regulation on tobacco.

title: Testimony Challenged in the Phone Hacking Scandal
description: Documents released recently appeared to contradict News Corporation executives statements in July and previous claims about the phone hacking at The News of the World. On Tuesday, a letter written in 2007 by a former reporter, Clive Goodman, challenging his dismissal was released, with redactions, by lawmakers.

title: How the Bloomberg Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times/CBS News poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 9 through Aug. 15 in New York City with 1,027 adults. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

title: Mitt Romney, Political Surfer
description: BERLIN, N.H.  So, just what did Mitt Romney learn while he was running for president four years ago?

title: Manchester United Nears Stock Sale on Asian Exchange
description: Manchester United, the English Premier League soccer power that is already the most valuable sports team in the world, is preparing to sell shares on the Singapore stock exchange that could raise about $1 billion, according to a person familiar with the plan who declined to be identified before the details of the sale were made public.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,723 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Dr. Phil Lands Interview With Anthony Grandparents
description: The daytime television host Dr. Phil McGraw will conduct the first interview with Cindy and George Anthony since their daughter Casey was acquitted of killing her daughter Caylee, CBS said Tuesday.

title: Jets Backup Plan on Offensive Line Needs a Backup
description: Jets Coach Rex Ryan has spoken throughout training camp about the importance of roster depth. After one preseason game, however, the depth of the offensive line could suddenly be a concern.

description: Nearly 1 million Somalis have fled the country, while about 3.2 million of those who remain need immediate help, 2.8 million in the south.

title: Should the Wealthy Pay Higher Taxes?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voracious Outsider Grabs a Toehold, and That Means War
description: Like many of their old-timey contemporaries, the residents of Whiskeytown, a Gold Rush garrison in the mountains of Northern California, were a bit skeptical of outsiders. Filled with prospectors and the entrepreneurs who mined them, Whiskeytown had folks who looked after one another, but also looked long and hard at anyone intruding on their claims or their community.

title: Yemens Leader Vows to Return Soon and Defies Calls for His Ouster
description: Ali Abdullah Saleh, the embattled president of Yemen, promised his supporters on Tuesday that he would see you soon in the capital, Sana, in his third television appearance in less than a week.

title: More Unwed Parents Live Together, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The number of Americans who have children and live together without marrying has increased twelvefold since 1970, according to a report released Tuesday. The report states that children now are more likely to have unmarried parents than divorced ones.

title: Panama Adding a Wider Shortcut for Shipping
description: COCOL, Panama  For now, the future of global shipping is little more than a hole in the ground here, just a short distance from the Pacific Ocean.

title: Theres a Doctor in the Paddock
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Dr. Gerald Bortolazzo, or Doc, as he is known, has some story to tell about a horse, his new career as a horseman and how he, if he did not exactly cheat death, fooled it but good.

title: Musing on the Prospects of a Microsoft Counterbid for Motorola
description: Ted S. Warren/Associated PressA Windows Phone 7 at a Microsoft store.

title: A Battered Paterno Sees No Reason to Relax
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Penn State Coach Joe Paterno was on campus Tuesday, after a blindside hit on Aug. 7 sent him to the hospital, and said he planned to be back on the sideline when the Nittany Lions open their season Sept. 3 against Indiana State.

title: Romney View of Perry: Just Another Opponent
description: LITTLETON, N.H.  Gov. Rick Perry has plans to eat his way through Mitt Romneys New Hampshire backyard this week  a politics and eggs breakfast in Bedford on Wednesday, a coffee meet-and-greet in Portsmouth and a lunch in Dover on Thursday, as well as two tours of local businesses. Yet to watch Mr. Romney, who on the campaign trail brushed off several opportunities to directly challenge Mr. Perry, the Texas governor could not be further from his mind.

title: Attacks in Iraq Heighten Political Tensions
description: BAGHDAD  One day after insurgents unleashed the most lethal series of attacks in Iraq this year, political tensions flared as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki appointed a member of his governing coalition as acting defense minister.

title: Facing the Loss of a Little Building, Much More Than a Place for Stamps
description: NORTH HOOSICK, N.Y.  In the center of this hamlet sits a tiny building the color of the sky. It is a blue so bright and so rich, it seems more suited to a Caribbean beach bungalow than to the rural hills of upstate New York.

title: BlackBerry Maker RIM Again Subject of Takeover Talk
description: OTTAWA  Ever since the introduction of its first BlackBerry more than a decade ago, Research in Motion has defied expectations that it would be gobbled up by a larger rival and has effectively created the market for smartphones.

title: White Picket Fence? Not So Fast
description: THE United States spends more than $100 billion annually to subsidize homeowners. Renters get no breaks; homeowners get tons of them. Their mortgage rates are subsidized through the government-sponsored enterprises Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac; they get a big deduction on federal income taxes for mortgage interest payments and for state and local property taxes; and they even get favored treatment on capital gains from the sales of primary residences.

title: H.P.-Palm Deal Looks Better With Time
description: Hewlett-Packards $1.2 billion acquisition of Palm last year suddenly looks smarter. Googles $12.5 billion deal to buy Motorola Mobility this week, and the earlier frenzied bidding for Nortels patents, have revealed the riches in mobile computing intellectual property. And H.P. snatched one of the most important troves for a price that now looks cheap. Yet, it could be challenging for H.P. to cash in.

title: Phillies Latest Ex-Astro Adds Big Bat to Winning Lineup
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Gundlach Says 2009 Firing Had Roots In 2001
description: The bond fund manager Jeffrey E. Gundlachs clash with his former employer, Trust Company of the West, began as early as 2001 and intensified in the months leading up to his firing, he testified on Tuesday.

title: Perry Links Federal Reserve Policies and Treason
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa  Gov. Rick Perry did not back down on Tuesday, but he did not repeat his suggestion that the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve were potentially treasonous and could warrant ugly treatment should the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, ever pay a visit to Texas.

title: Making Low-Interest Auto Loans Work
Players Death Follows Bouts of Depression
description: Rick Rypien, the scrappy 27-year-old Winnipeg Jets forward who was found dead Monday, was considered perhaps the best pound-for-pound fighter in the N.H.L. But for more than a decade he battled depression, a disorder that caused him to take two leaves of absence from the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Before Voting, Russian Leaders Go to the Polls
description: MOSCOW  Every Thursday, a bearded, bespectacled man arrives at the Kremlin bearing a sheaf of data for Vladislav Y. Surkov, the governments chief ideologist. There, a roomful of decision makers are gathered to hear the latest installment of What Russia Thinks.

title: Crashing the Tea Party
description: GIVEN how much sway the Tea Party has among Republicans in Congress and those seeking the Republican presidential nomination, one might think the Tea Party is redefining mainstream American politics.

title: A Farm Around the Corner
description: It is sweet corn and ripe tomato season, a time for freshly picked garlic, luminous carrots, crisp cucumbers and (as far as were concerned too much) zucchini.

title: Madoff Decision Is Significant Setback for Owners of Mets
description: From the moment they were sued last year for $1 billion by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs fraud, the owners of the Mets have fought every aspect of the enormous claim.

title: Swiss Banks, Aiding and Abetting
description: Despite all of the I.R.S.s efforts, wealthy American tax cheats are still able to hide their money because Swiss banks are still eager to help them.

title: Serena Williams Adds Fitness to Her Game, and Wins Keep Coming
description: MASON, Ohio  The only upset in Serena Williamss first-round match on Tuesday against Lucie Hradecka was registered in the stands, well above the court, when one female fan turned to another and said, Serenas legs look skinny.

title: Field of Dashed Dreams
description: PEOSTA, Iowa

title: A Summer of Italy, Music and Pasta
description: WHEN Barilla, the pasta company formed in Italy in 1877, was first nationally advertised in the United States in 1996, it turned out to be less an introduction than an invasion. In just three years, Barilla bested familiar brands like Ronzoni and Muellers to become the top-selling dry pasta in the country. Even when the pasta category contracted at the height of the low-carbohydrate diet craze from 2002 to 2004, Barilla continued to boil over with year-over-year gains.

title: In Albany, a Labor Pact Without Attacks on Unions
description: ALBANY  A day after the states largest public-workers union agreed to accept wage and benefits concessions, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and labor leaders said the vote demonstrated that fiscally troubled states could cut work-force costs without attacking collective bargaining.

title: Midwest States Where Obama Faces New Challenges
description: A rattled economy and Republican gains in the House have changed the economic and political landscape of the Midwestern states that helped propel President Obamas campaign in the 2008 election.

title: Since Milestone Hit, Jeter Has Taken Off
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Derek Jeters teammates were not surprised at all to see him collect three hits and knock in three runs on Monday. Watching Jeter take command of the game with a couple of clutch hits, including a rocket to the right-center-field gap for a two-run triple, looked very familiar to them.

title: Suffolk Seeks Safety Zone Barring Gang Members
description: WYANDANCH, N.Y.  Fed up with unrelenting violence by two factions of the Bloods gang, Suffolk County officials have embraced a novel legal strategy that, if approved by a judge, would bar specific gang members from a two-square-mile safety zone.

title: Quest for Patents Brings New Focus in Tech Deals
description: Wall Street bankers and technology executives have been busy with their calculators in the wake of Googles $12.5 billion offer for Motorola Mobililty.

title: Meteorologists Who Offer Not Forecasts but Testimony
description: After the last of the record-setting rain had fallen in the New York area, those in the business of delivering weather forecasts on television got back to their normal routines, calling for mostly sunny days or the like.

title: Hurricane Players and Recruits Accused of N.C.A.A. Violations
description: At a time when the ideal of amateurism in college athletics appears shakier than ever, Yahoo Sports reported Tuesday that University of Miami players and recruits received thousands of benefits in violation of N.C.A.A. rules from a booster from 2002 through 2010.

title: New Farmers Find Their Footing
description: North Haven, Me.

title: Battle for Libya | August 16, 2011
description: A funeral in Benghazi, and rebel forces face sniper fire in Zawiyah.

title: Obama and Perry Tour Iowa
description: President Obama and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas campaigned simultaneously in the state.

title: His Anger Is a Start
description: Faced with a divided Congress and an economy in desperate straits, President Obama tried bargaining with Republicans, he tried adopting some of their ideas and he pleaded with them for reasonable policies to help stave off disaster. For his efforts, he got nothing but a cold shoulder and the country got a credit downgrade.

title: Highway Fight Widens Gulf Between State and Seneca Nation
description: IRVING, N.Y.  The westernmost spur of the New York State Thruway is a lonely four-lane road, lined by leafy sugar maple trees and little else.

title: Obama Presses His Case in Crucial Iowa, but Perry Is Close on His Heels
description: PEOSTA, Iowa  President Obama pulled up to a bucolic community college here in his $1.1 million black armored bus on Tuesday and spent much of the day closeted in a conference with farmers and small-business owners, hoping to sell them on his message that he could revive the listless job market.

title: A Bull Market in Tech Patents
description: Google was willing on Monday to pay $12.5 billion for Motorola Mobility in no small part because of its stockpile of 17,000 patents. The patent portfolio, some analysts estimate, could represent more than half of the value of the deal, or more than $400,000 a patent.

title: Giants Sign Lloyd as Kicker Insurance
description: With Lawrence Tynes sidelined because of a bruised thigh, the Giants signed kicker Rhys Lloyd on Tuesday.

title: 3 Charged in Plot to Aid Smuggling
description: Three people, including a Manhattan lawyer, have been charged with helping to smuggle hundreds of illegal immigrants into the country, the United States attorney in Manhattan said on Tuesday.

title: Fight for a Jobs Agenda
description: Come September, President Obamas aides say he will roll out more programs to put Americans back to work. What we are hearing so far doesnt go nearly far enough.

title: TimesCast | Obama Tours Midwest
description: August 16, 2011 - On his bus tour through the Midwest, President Obama visits must-win states for re-election next year.

title: Lottery Numbers
Wednesday: Have a Hearty Laugh
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Hindsight is always 20/20, they say, and while it took me a while to understand where Michael Black was going with this tricky-for-a-Wednesday theme, I have to say that my post-solving reaction was along the lines of, Of course. Why didnt I see that going in?

title: Co-Ops Old Crank Finds a Fresh Spirit
description: To live is to kvetch, to kvetch to live, for the cranky title character in Olive and the Bitter Herbs, the acidly funny but decidedly ramshackle new play by Charles Busch that opened on Tuesday night at the 59E59 Theaters in a Primary Stages production.

title: Amazon Set to Publish Pop Author
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amazon moved aggressively Tuesday to fulfill its new ambition to publish books as well as sell them, announcing that it had signed Timothy Ferriss, the wildly popular self-help guru for young men.

title: Ambitious Plans for a Building Where Sears Served Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  As large as 20 Wal-Mart stores, the cavernous former Sears building now known as City Hall East towers above a motley assortment of restaurants, underground dance halls and a strip club a few miles northeast of downtown. The building, which at 2.1 million square feet is the largest brick structure in the South, according to its owners, has been mostly vacant since Sears left in 1989.

title: A Suburban Town Sees Housing Where Retail Rules
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J.  Jordan Eppolito has taken a liking to his new home here in the Morris County seat, about 30 miles west of New York City. Mr. Eppolito, a 28-year-old entrepreneur who plans to open a pizza shop this fall on South Street, lives in a new condominium overlooking the Morristown Green, the historic park at the center of town.

title: Ralph Albertazzie, Nixons Pilot, Dies at 88
description: Ralph D. Albertazzie, the pilot of Air Force One during the Nixon administration, who flew  the president on a historic trip to China and flew the Nixon family home to California after his resignation, died on Monday at his home in Falling Waters, W.Va. He was 88.

title: Disney Fires Three Over Resort Fees Fiasco
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Companys new resort in Hawaii, built at an estimated cost of $850 million, is off to a slower-than-expected start as a result of bungled time-share fees.

title: Facing Flurry of Lawsuits, a Governor Loses a Round
description: MIAMI  Gov. Rick Scott, a Republican conservative, took office this year on a promise to shake things up. That he did, and now the aggrieved  teachers, prison workers, food stamp recipients, doctors  are plastering him with lawsuits.

title: For Mets, Different Approach Pays Off
description: SAN DIEGO  After the Mets revamped their front office last fall, their approach to Major League Baseballs draft this summer became one of the most discussed issues among the new general manager Sandy Aldersons staff.

title: Federal Policy Resulting in Wave of Deportations Draws Protests
description: A program that is central to President Obamas immigration enforcement strategy has drawn protests by Latino and immigrant organizations in six cities in the last two days, as those groups stepped up their confrontation with the administration over the fast pace of deportations.

title: Pledge for Euro Unity May Not Be Enough to Satisfy Markets
description: PARIS  The leaders of France and Germany on Tuesday promised to take concrete steps toward a closer political and economic union of the 17 countries that use the euro, but it was unclear whether their proposals would be sufficient, or come quickly enough, to satisfy markets anxious over Europes debts and listless economies.

title: Rodriguez Could Rejoin Yankees on Thursday
description: MOOSIC, Pa.  In his gradual climb back to the major leagues after arthroscopic surgery to repair a torn meniscus in his right knee, Alex Rodriguez played six innings at third base for the Scranton/Wilkes-Barre Yankees of the International League on Tuesday night in a 2-0 loss to the Durham Bulls.

title: Isringhausens Milestone Augurs Changes in the Mets Bullpen
description: SAN DIEGO  Mets Manager Terry Collins said Tuesday afternoon that he would begin experimenting with different combinations of relievers out of his bullpen, now that Jason Isringhausen has his 300th save.

title: On Economy, Raw Data Gets a Grain of Salt
description: WASHINGTON  When the government announced in April that the economy had grown at a moderate annual pace of 1.8 percent in the first quarter, politicians and investors saw evidence that the nation was continuing its recovery from the depths of the financial crisis. The White House called the news encouraging and the stock market extended its bull run.

title: Schools Restore Fresh Cooking to the Cafeteria
description: GREELEY, Colo.  The idea of making school lunches better and healthier has gathered steam in many parts of the nation in recent years, but not equally for every child. Schools with money and involved parents concerned about obesity and nutrition charged ahead, while poor and struggling districts, overwhelmed by hard times, mostly did not.

title: China: Railroad Spokesman Fired
description: The Railways Ministry said Tuesday that it had dismissed its spokesman, Wang Yongping, making him the fourth ministry official to be fired since a high-speed train collision on July 23 near Wenzhou killed 40 people and injured 191. Mr. Wangs performance in answering the news medias questions about the crash had made him a target of public ridicule. Asked why workers had buried a train car at the site before an inquiry had begun, he said the wreckage had to be cleared for rescuers. Whether you believe it or not, I believe it anyway, he said.

title: France: Lagarde Inquiry Opens
description: A court formally opened an investigation on Tuesday into charges that Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, abused her power as Frances finance minister in 2007 when she intervened in a legal conflict in which a prominent businessman was awarded hundreds of millions of dollars in state funds. Earlier, a court had thrown out the case brought by the businessman, Bernard Tapie, a friend of President Nicolas Sarkozy and himself a former minister, who accused a state-owned bank of defrauding him in a 1993 transaction. Ms. Lagarde ordered the case sent to an arbitration panel, which awarded Mr. Tapie a settlement of about $580 million.

title: Corrections: August 17
description: FRONT PAGE

title: New Limits on Bus Drivers for Schools
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed legislation on Tuesday expanding the kinds of criminal convictions that bar people from driving school buses.

title: 2 Wisconsin Democrats Re-elected
description: Two Democrats kept their seats in the Wisconsin State Senate on Tuesday, drawing an end to an unprecedented series of recall elections that had distracted the state all summer.

title: Detective Stole Cash and Cigarettes, Complaint Charges
description: Late last month, a longtime Bronx detective showed up at a home in Fordham Heights around midnight, wearing a New York Police Department jacket and flashing a badge and a piece of paper he said was a search warrant, according to a criminal complaint.

title: Judge Rejects Groups Effort to Remove Bike Lane
description: A judge on Tuesday dismissed an effort by Brooklyn residents to remove a hotly contested bicycle lane installed by the city on Prospect Park West, in one of the most closely watched controversies over a signature policy of the Bloomberg administration.

title: Yanks Pile Up Runs to Make Up for the Ones Nova Allows
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  All the fuss and concern over the Yankees six-man rotation, and who should eventually be lopped from it, have recently been rendered moot by two developments: a small cut on Freddy Garcias finger, and the large abrasions the Yankees hitters are inflicting on baseballs these days.

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/17/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/17/2011

title: Are Crunches Worth the Effort?
description: For a study published this year, researchers at Indiana State University had a group of healthy, young adults squat, lunge, twist, crunch and hold a rigid plank position to measure the hardiness of their back, abdominal and side muscles, the area generally known as the core. The same volunteers then completed a battery of physical performance tests, including leaping off the ground while tossing a medicine ball backward over the head and sprinting through a short obstacle course.

title: Remembering Horton Foote
description: A look at the career of the playwright and screenwriter, who died at age 92.

title: Word of the Day | orator
description: orator \r--tr, r-\ noun

title: Mets Succumb Meekly to Padres Rookie
description: SAN DIEGO  One of Terry Collinss main objectives, as he endeavors to extract a dose of meaning from the remainder of the Mets season, will be to figure out if there is a pitcher somewhere in his bullpen with the mettle to be a major league closer.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 17, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Carmakers Back Strict New Rules for Gas Mileage.

title: Aug. 17, 1969 | Woodstock Festival Ends
description: On Aug. 17, 1969, the Woodstock Music Festival ended.

title: Jonathan Woodgates Eternal Upside
description: What if is a big question for anyone.

title: News Quiz | August 17, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Modern-Day Gold Rush
description: Are todays volatile stock market and wobbly global economy presaging a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis? Or is the Great Depression of the 1930s more apt analogy?

description: WHERE is the Semakau Landfill?

title: Should Rich People Have to Pay More Taxes?
description: Warren E. Buffett, an investor who is one of the wealthiest people in the world, wrote an Op-Ed article in The Times this week arguing that the super-rich should be required to contribute more to the United States economy in the form of taxes, and says that most wealthy people wouldnt mind doing so. Do you agree or disagree?

title: Q&A: Slamming the Door on Twitter Spam
description: Q.

title: SABMiller Goes Hostile in Pursuit of Fosters
description: 9:46 p.m. | Updated SABMiller, one of the worlds largest brewers, said on Wednesday that it would take its $10 billion bid for rival Fosters Group directly to shareholders, two months after the board of the Australian beer maker rebuffed an initial offer.

title: The Early Word: Battleground
description: Todays Times

title: 2011 Jacksonville Jaguars Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He starts his look at the A.F.C. South with the Jaguars.

title: Exceptions to Keynesian Theory
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Throw Couplets at Bill
description: A happy consequence of Bill Kellers latest column, which suggested that the logjammers in Washington start reading more poetry, is that people have been filling his inbox with reading suggestions. Some, like this one from R. Ford Reid, have directly addressed his political points:

title: Cooling Off the Berlin Summer With Artisanal Ice Cream
description: When it came to creative ice cream options, there was a time when Germans might have had to settle for spaghetti-eis, thin strands of vanilla ice cream smothered in a (supposedly) fruit-based syrup. But Berliners palates have become more demanding, prompting many high-quality ice cream parlors to open around the city. For the traveler, this means that Berlin now offers some great new ways to cool off with cone or cup.

title: Deal Would Free Indian Activist and Allow Protests
description: NEW DELHI  The protest leader Anna Hazare appeared to strike a deal with the police early Thursday morning that would enable him to leave a local jail and begin staging a hunger strike against corruption later in the day, according to a close aide and reports in the Indian news media.

title: A Bad Night in August
description: Thursday, Aug. 4, 2011. Remember this date, boss. Go home and drink a bottle of wine and circle this day on your calendar. You wont see another one like it.

title: A Tribute to Ads That Made an Impression and Then Wouldnt Leave
description: Remember the frothing pitchman for the now-defunct Crazy Eddie chain of electronics stores who screamed in television commercials that were inescapable in the 1970s and 1980s about prices that were insaaaaaane?

title: Indictment in Hariri Assassination Is Published
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the assassination of a former Lebanese prime minister in 2005 released the full indictment on Wednesday against members of Hezbollah named in the killing, a move that could deepen tensions in a country polarized by the repercussions of the investigation.

title: Do You Suffer From Decision Fatigue?
description: Editors note: As you navigate a world of choices, revisit this 2011 magazine story on the paralyzing effects of decision fatigue.

title: Dinner Theater, Starring the Kitchen
description: When people say that a restaurant provides an evening of good theater, they are almost always referring to the high quotient of air kissing among a clientele with a high media profile. The people in the banquettes, not the dishes on the plates, are really the show at places like the Waverly Inn and the Monkey Bar and the Minetta Tavern.

title: What Would Hillary Clinton Have Done?
description: In the worst of the Democratic primary campaign in 2008, the angry end of the thing, when I had become a devoted Hillary Clinton supporter and was engaged in bitter arguments with people with whom I often agreed, I used to harbor a secret fear, the twin of my political hope: I worried that Hillary Clinton would win her partys nomination.

title: Getting Noticed at the Fringe: Fourteen Flights
description: It can be tough to stand out among the almost 200 shows in this years New York International Fringe Festival, which runs through Aug. 28. (Ending the title of your show with the words The Musical! is so 10 years ago.) One way to stop passers-by in their tracks is to design eye-catching artwork  to be used online and in print  that says Look at me. Come see the show. If its not good, keep me as a bookmark.

title: Pulse Points
description: NYTD.hotSpotsFactory.createMap("map2", 592, 750, false, chameleonData);

title: Manchester United Plans to Raise $1 Billion
description: Manchester United, the Premier League power that is already the most valuable sports team in the world, is preparing to sell shares on the Singapore stock exchange that could raise about $1 billion. The deal would allow the Glazer family, which owns the team, to reduce the clubs debt and presumably free up more money for Alex Ferguson (and his successor, if he ever quits) to spend. Read Ken Belsons article here, and come back to comment.

title: Photo Turns U.S. Envoy Into a Lesson for Chinese
description: BEIJING  The word on the street these days, whether in Washington or Beijing, is that the United States is on the decline and China is on the ascent. But it has taken nothing more than a cup of coffee and a backpack to show that American officials can still evoke awe, respect and envy among Chinese, even if unwittingly.

title: Wednesday Reading: Are Abdominal Crunches Worth It?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Pledge of Euro Unity May Not Be Enough to Satisfy Markets
description: PARIS  The leaders of France and Germany on Tuesday promised to take concrete steps toward a closer political and economic union of the 17 countries that use the euro, but it was unclear whether their proposals would be sufficient, or come quickly enough, to satisfy markets anxious over Europes debts and listless economies.

title: Wholesale Costs Increased More Than Expected in July
description: Wholesale costs in the United States rose more than forecast in July, led by higher prices for tobacco, trucks and pharmaceuticals, the Labor Department said Wednesday.

title: Remembering Pete Pihos, Pioneering Tight End
description: A few thoughts about Pete Pihos, one of pro footballs first great pass-catching tight ends. After a long battle with Alzheimers disease, Pihos died Tuesday in a nursing home in Winston-Salem, N.C., at age 87.

title: Morning Buzz
description: For more local news from The Times, including disappointing poll numbers for the mayor, a dispute between New York State and the Seneca Nation of Indians and a new approach to curbing gang violence in Suffolk County, see the N.Y./Region Section.

title: Stocks Close Flat as Investors Parse Quarterly Results
description: The stock market wavered on Wednesday and ended mixed, weighed down by corporate results related to the technology and consumer sectors.

title: Say Kse!
description: If you think Polaroid cameras are old school (and expensive), try the Imago 1:1.

title: Ground Force One, a Custom-Made Ride
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa  As President Obama sets off on the last day of his three-day road trip across the Midwest, his high-tech, black, armored bus has become a familiar presence on the highways and byways here  or at least, a less ominous presence than when it first pulled up next to Air Force One in Minneapolis.

title: New York Moves to Crack Down on Abuse of Disabled
description: Moving to end the states lax oversight of the developmentally disabled, the Cuomo administration on Wednesday announced an agreement with the State Police to establish guidelines for reporting possible crimes against the disabled to law enforcement authorities.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Pondering Perrys Electability
description: The speech by Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to announce his presidential candidacy on Saturday got generally favorable reviews, but it did not take long for some influential Republicans to become overtly skeptical about what Mr. Perry might do for the party in November.

title: Open Secret | LN-CC Boutique
description: A hidden basement boutique in Londons Dalston district takes destination shopping to the next level. View interactive feature >>

title: StumbleUpon Gets More Specific
description: StumbleUpon has long been one of the most powerful tools for those who revel in the Webs randomness. A user chooses a few things hes interested in  say, writing, American football and science  and the service pulls up a new Web site of interest every time he presses Stumble! So, perhaps, that user would find a site with a list of 30 Books to Read Before Youre 30, followed by one with 10 Quirky Science Tricks for Parties, followed by a page containing just a map of the United States made out of the football helmets of the local N.F.L. teams.

title: Head of Nets Address System to Leave
description: Rod Beckstrom, chief executive of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, which oversees the Internet address system, plans to leave the organization next July.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: A Gift From the Musical Gods
description: ON Friday, March 19, 1965, Maria Callas returned to the Metropolitan Opera after a seven-year absence. The work was Puccinis Tosca; it was one of the most anticipated nights in Met history.

title: Putin and Medvedev Go Fishing, and a Camera Tags Along
description: As my colleague Ellen Barry reports, Russias leaders are inordinately obsessed with how the public perceives them. Polling data have become an important part of government, which relies heavily on the personalities of the men at the top  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin and President Dmitri A. Medvedev.

title: Crowd-Sourcing for Travel Advice
description: LOOKING back at my favorite vacation spots, several have one vital thing in common: they were suggested by friends.

title: Cameron Ends Bid to Hire Ex-New York Police Chief
description: LONDON  In the wake of Britains brief exploration of the possibility of appointing a former New York City police commissioner to the countrys top police post, the government settled Wednesday on a short list of four senior police commanders  all of them British nationals.

title: The Sweet Side of Sibling Rivalry
description: Cute is probably the last word that comes to mind when we contemplate sibling rivalry, followed closely by endearing, charming and sweet. But those are just the words to describe two new picture books about warring siblings aimed at the youngest readers and rivals.

title: A More Subdued Perry on the Trail in N.H.
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas sounded like a sheepish schoolboy at the Granite States Politics & Eggs breakfast on Wednesday morning, when he told a bipartisan crowd of 200 that hed gotten a real talking to the day before.

title: Musical Couple Turn to Aviator and His Wife
description: TONIO and Consuelo, the wanderlusty aviator and the exotic widow at the center of the new musical Saint-Ex, give voice to their tempestuous relationship by singing, Love is not a gaze thats shared/But years spent gazing outward together.

title: Champions League: Fast Start for L.A. and Seattle
description: It may be only one game, but two teams in Major League Soccer  the Los Angeles Galaxy and the Seattle Sounders  got off to roaring starts Tuesday night as group play opened in the Concacaf Champions League.

title: The Printing Press Mystery
description: John Plender at the FT seems mystified by something that has become obvious lately: bond vigilantes are only going after countries that no longer have their own currencies. He writes:

title: LinkedIns Social-Ad Misstep
description: Move over Facebook. Its time to pay attention to privacy on LinkedIn.

title: Notre Dames Kelly Wants Season to Be About Football Again
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  The Notre Dame football coach, Brian Kelly, may be a devout Red Sox fan. But when he sat down with Yankees Manager Joe Girardi before the Irish played at Yankee Stadium last year, they bonded over the challenges inherent in overseeing an iconic brand in sports.

title: Morgan Freeman and Anthony Edwards Will Appear in 8 Reading on Broadway
description: A new play by Dustin Lance Black, about a trial to overturn Californias voter-approved ban on gay marriage, has found its first cast members for a one-time staged reading on Broadway. Morgan Freeman and Anthony Edwards will be among the actors performing in 8, written by Mr. Black, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of Milk, and adapted from reporting and trial transcripts from the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger, in which a federal judge in San Francisco struck down Californias Proposition 8 in 2010. (The ruling is currently being appealed.)

title: Smashing Bridges to Build Them
description: The metaphor of building bridges is often used to note a rite of passage or a step toward the future. But while many schools at this time of year are focused on building metaphorical bridges for their students, like helping them transition to high school, students at City Polytechnic High School of Engineering, Architecture, and Technology in Brooklyn were doing the opposite this week.

title: SABMiller, From Local Brewer to Global Leader
description: SABMillers $10 billion hostile bid for the Fosters Group may be the brewers largest. But it is only the latest in a history of global deal-making at the company.

title: Obama Plans Jobs Speech After Labor Day
description: President Obama plans a major speech on jobs after Labor Day in which he will lay out new proposals for jump-starting the economy and specific plans for legislative efforts to cut spending, White House officials said.

title: Leading Off: Jailed Booster Imperils Miami Sports Programs
description: The scandal now pummeling the University of Miami should be the last straw. With a Yahoo.com report detailing the Shermans March that a rogue booster did through the N.C.A.A. rule book in providing just about every immoral inducement to Miami athletes, it would seem to end college sports ability to drape itself in pompoms and pretend it is a worthwhile part of our educational system. Unless this entire story turns out to be a figment of the jailed boosters imagination  and there is no early indication that is the case  is anybody going to pretend there is a single ethical leg for this whole enterprise to teeter on?

title: If You Can Vacation Here
description: Its been more than a decade since Ive spent an entire summer, straight through, in New York City. Its a brutal prospect, what with the steaming pavements and bone-wilting humidity, but if it has to be done, it should be done right. So this summer, armed with my girlfriend and my Metrocard, I set out to design the perfect balance of work, play and sunshine. Herewith I give you my staycation story, a real New Yorkers guide to not losing your mind between May Day and Labor Day weekend. Part 1: the Red Hook pool, the Bronx Zoo, Coney Island and Far Rockaway.

title: Two Groups That Help Nonprofits in a Merger
description: GOOD, a fast-growing publishing and marketing business that promotes social causes, is acquiring Jumo, a social networking site that raises money and support for nonprofit groups.

title: Loving the Hostile
description: Deal makers appear more willing to let slip the dogs of war these days.

title: Philip Glass to Write Memoir
description: The composer Philip Glass, 74, a pioneer of the Minimalist style of composing, has signed a contract to write a memoir, according to the publisher W.W. Norton & Company. The book will be published by the Norton division Liveright & Company. The publishing date was not disclosed. The publisher said Mr. Glass would explore his youth and musical influences, including working in his fathers record store in Baltimore and collaborations with Ravi Shankar and Allen Ginsberg.

title: Marshall Islands Denies Culpability in Gulf Spill
description: A report released on Wednesday by the Marshall Islands, the flag state for the drilling rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico last year, says that a review shows that a crews deviation from established protocol and its failure to react to signs of an imminent blowout were the main factors that led to the disaster.

title: Joplin Defies Odds, Just by Opening Schools
description: JOPLIN, Mo.  When the schools here were reduced to red-brick rubble in the deadly tornado three months ago, abruptly ending classes just before final exams, district leaders made a promise that seemed like a long shot: the new school year would start on time.

title: Amid Skepticism, Debt Panel Is Pressed for a Deal
description: WASHINGTON  There is a joke in this town that goes something like this: If you want to guarantee that a problem does not get solved, convene a committee to study it.

title: ING Directs Paperless Account Now Offers Paper Checks
description: Even as payments become increasingly electronic, the need for paper checks persists. Just ask the folks at the online bank, ING Direct, which touts its Electric Orange checking account as paperless  but which just began offering its customers the option to use, well, paper.

title: Kiss Booted From Michael Jackson Tribute Concert
description: Organizers of a tribute concert for Michael Jackson in Britain scratched the rock band Kiss from the lineup on Tuesday after fans complained that the bands front man, Gene Simmons, had called Mr. Jackson a child molester, according to wire service reports.

title: Insider Trading Defendant in Disney Case Fights Back
description: A California man accused of insider trading  is fighting back with his own batch of allegations and insults, issuing a stinging statement late Tuesday that called the Securities and Exchange Commissions lawyers bumbling and their case against him riddled with omissions, distortions and inaccuracies.

title: Wendy and the Lost Boys
description: THE FAMILY WASSERSTEIN

title: The Descendants, With George Clooney, Will Close New York Film Festival
description: The Descendants, Alexander Paynes first feature since his 2004 film Sideways, will be the closing night selection of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced on Wednesday along with the roster of 27 films that will be presented in the festivals main slate.

title: And Now, Wendy Gets Her Chronicles
description: Wendy Wasserstein had a contract to write her memoir when she died, in 2006. The question she had asked herself, putting off the job, was: Could she reach that kind of depth? The more obvious question for those acquainted with this Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright: Was there anything left to tell?

title: Resistance Transforms a Once Mute Syrian City
description: HOMS, Syria  The narrower the streets of this city, a caldron of revolt and resistance against four decades of rule by the Assad family, the blunter the graffiti becomes. It is scrawled on walls, garbage bins, phone booths, doors and even tree trunks, as a city that was long quiescent declares these days that it will no longer stay quiet.

title: Asthma More Likely Among Children of Overweight Mothers
description: Women who are overweight or obese when they become pregnant may be more likely to have children who develop asthma as teenagers, new research shows.

title: McGraw-Hill Explores Education Spinoff or Sale
description: 8:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Notes From Homs: A Reporters Trip to One of Syrias Most Rebellious Cities
description: For nearly five months, Syrian authorities have tried to crush a nationwide popular uprising, killing an estimated 2,000 demonstrators and jailing thousands more. They have also blocked foreign journalists from entering the country. Most of the reports emerging have been spread by local people relying on cellphones and social media networks.

title: Ahead of Frankfurt, Jaguar Previews C-X16 Concept
description: Having coasted for a year on the strength of its C-X75 hybrid concept, which is headed into production as a supercar costing upwards of $1.5 million, Jaguar has its predatory eyes on a less rarefied market segment with the C-X16 concept, scheduled to have its debut at the Frankfurt auto show next month.

title: Katy Perry Makes Some Billboard History
description: Katy Perry became the only second artist in the last 53 years to have five songs from a single album reach the top spot on Billboards Hot 100 chart, as her track Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.) has reached No. 1, Billboard reported on Wednesday. The only other singer to pull off that feat was Michael Jackson, who had five songs from Bad go to the top of the charts in 1987 and 1988.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Le Gourmand, or Gluttony!
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festivals close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Young Entrepreneur Sees Little Help In Washington
description: One day last month, Neil Blumenthal, who is a young entrepreneur, found himself in an ornate room on Capitol Hill listening to a parade of politicians  Senator Charles E. Schumer, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand and Senator John McCain, among others  talk about how important young entrepreneurs were to the economy. Mr. Blumenthal, 31, one of the founders of Warby Parker, an online eyewear company that sells designer frames for less than $100, was among 150 young chief executives invited to Washington by Our Time, a youth advocacy group, to help start Buy Young, an initiative that encourages consumers to support companies owned by members of the millennial generation.

title: Are Young Entrepreneurs Getting Enough Help?
description: Weve just published an interview with Neil Blumenthal, a young entrepreneur who recently went to Capitol Hill to talk about how important young entrepreneurs are to the economy. One of the founders of Warby Parker, an online eyewear company based in New York, Mr. Blumenthal and Hannah Seligson discussed, among other things, what politicians dont understand about business, what he had to promise the Small Business Administration he wouldnt do with his borrowed money, and what the Bloomberg administration is doing right. (You can read more small-business conversations here.)At one point, Mr. Blumenthal noted that his company had struggled to get a loan backed by the Small Business Administration because the company did not yet have two years of tax returns.

title: Profile in Style | Erica Reid
description: Every fashion-loving gal has that one piece she just cant part with. For Erica Reid, its a cozy old Joseph turtleneck: Ive had it for 14 years. Its been with me through my girlfriend, fiance, wife, pregnancy and mother stages. (Shes married to the record executive L.A. Reid.) When Erica, a budding author, isnt swaddled in her security sweater, she rocks fierce pieces from Alexander McQueen, Preen, Erdem and Norma Kamali (so old school) as well as a vintage collection that would make Kate Moss weep. She opts for high street style from the likes of H&M and Topshop when the mood strikes. Theres no shame in my game, she says. I am not a slave to labels.

title: The Caucus | Obama Bus Tour Wraps Up
description: The photographer Doug Mills reflects on President Obama's economic tour; Michael D. Shear on the candidates' transportation mode of choice, the bus.

title: Debate Over Social Media Incitement as Flash Mobs Strike
description: Prime Minister David Cameron called it a tough message, but the harsh sentences being handed down by British courts in the wake of last weeks rioting have sparked an outcry, divided his governing coalition and raised questions about the proper response to incitement in the social media age.

title: Pebble Beach Stars, Minus a Couple Zeroes
description: Given the presence of bespoke Testa Rossas, prewar Mercedes-Benz roadsters and custom-painted M1s, Pebble Beach this week may not seem like a place to go bargain hunting, particularly at the events produced by silk-stocking auction houses like Gooding, Bonhams and RM Auctions. Nevertheless, if savvy but budget-minded enthusiasts look hard enough, theyll find some interesting cars with pre-auction estimates of under $50,000.

title: Plenty of Time Left to Regret Rodriguezs Contract
description: Moosic, Pa.

title: Caucus Video: The Presidents Midwest Tour Wraps Up; A Look at Campaign Buses on the Trail
description: The photographer Doug Mills reflects on the presidents economic tour this week. Also, Michael D. Shear on the candidates transportation mode of choice: call it the battle of the buses.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 17
description: The day in sports included sailing in France, winter sports in New Zealand and dressage competitions in the Netherlands.

title: Tech Moguls Find a Fashion Champion in Ashton Kutcher
description: THE September issue of Details, which shows Ashton Kutcher in a somewhat bland black sweater on the cover, nevertheless offers an interesting example of how a fashion magazine can grab the attention of a social-media-savvy generation: ask someone who knows social media.

title: Gingrich Turns Focus to Hawaii
description: It may not make for the best political strategy, but Newt Gingrich is laughing all the way to the beach.

title: Rising Political Star in Germany Plummets After Affair With Teenager
description: BERLIN  German voters may be willing to tolerate a politicians having an affair with a teenager, but not when that politician  a leading conservative, no less  met her on Facebook, where he also flaunted immodest details of his life.

title: Parents Choose Cohabiting Over Marriage
description: American children are more likely to have parents who never married than parents who are divorced.

title: That Remake of AOL? Its Still Being Written
description: SAN FRANCISCO  AOL hit a hard bump on its road to becoming a digital media company.

title: Buy Local, the Mayor Says
description: But what about New Jersey tomatoes?

title: Madoff Trustee Gets a Green Light on Clawbacks
description: Ramin Talaie/Bloomberg NewsIrving H. Picard, the Madoff trustee, can pursue his clawbacks.

title: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Uganda, Somalia, Israel and Spain.

title: A Modern Cabin on Salt Spring Island
description: A two-bedroom house overlooking Welberry Bay and the open ocean is the market for $2.15 million.

title: House Hunting in ... British Columbia
description: A TWO-BEDROOM OCEANFRONT HOUSE OFF THE COAST OF BRITISH COLUMBIA

title: Discrimination Suit Against Bloomberg L.P. Is Rejected
description: In a major victory for Bloomberg L.P., the financial and media services giant founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a federal judge has dismissed claims that the company engaged in a pattern of discrimination against pregnant women and new mothers returning from maternity leave.

title: Jay-Z and Kanye West Top Billboard Chart
description: On the music charts this week, Jay-Z and Kanye West reached No. 1 with fewer album sales than expected, and Katy Perry tied Michael Jackson for the most No. 1 songs from one album.

title: Wipe on, Wipe Off: March of the Towelettes
description: WANT to simplify your beauty routine? Wish you could zoom through airport security without a Ziploc bag of little bottles?

title: Ruling Dismissing Case Against Bloomberg L.P.
description: A federal judge dismissed a class-action lawsuit filed by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Yeast Nation
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festivals close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: A Truck Dangled in Queens
description: A 15-ton salt-spreading truck burst through the wall of a sprawling Sanitation Department repair depot in Queens on Wednesday morning and hung precariously in the air  30 feet above the ground  until rescuers could free its driver, the authorities said.

title: An Epidemic of Rhino Poaching
description: As if a rhinos life wasnt already hard enough.

title: Another View: Icahn Defends His Record
description: Carl C. Icahn is the chairman of Icahn Associates.

title: Adolescent Health | Drugs, Alcohol and Tobacco
Some Lesser Mediterranean Lights
description: If you read through the highlights of my Mediterranean summer trip, you might think I spent every waking moment on gorgeous Albanian beaches, taking in stunning Croatian vistas, listening to live Turkish folk music, hiking the picturesque Spanish coast and downing luscious Neapolitan pizzas. I wish. There was also the sleepless night on the ferry, the almost-sleepless night on the French Riviera and the scourge of tourist-clogged cities, to name just a few hiccups.

title: Up and Down From Ground Zero
description: New office towers are rising at the World Trade Center, which also serves as a memorial and a transportation hub.

title: A Tattered Theater Nears Return to Glory After Years of Delays
description: MOSCOW  Plcido Domingo climbed carefully up a shaky metal ladder onto the newly rebuilt stage of the Bolshoi Theater  white shirt, white pants, white shoes  and with a sweep of his arm broke into song, the first performer to test the acoustics of the grand and newly renovated theater.

title: Getting Noticed at the Fringe: Never Look in the Mirror When Youre Dancing
description: Over the next two weeks ArtsBeat will take a look at some of the most clever, mysterious and strikingly designed postcards created to draw attention among the nearly 200 productions in this years New York International Fringe Festival.

title: Beautiful Minds | Extra Credit
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#689", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Turkey Vows Retaliation for Kurdish Ambush
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish warplanes bombed suspected Kurdish insurgent positions inside northern Iraq late Wednesday for the first time in a year, news services in Turkey reported, hours after an insurgent ambush on a military convoy in southeast Turkey left at least eight dead.

title: Newly Released Books
description: This month murder and romance are on tap, sometimes in the same novel. And while theres no shortage of heartache in this selection of fiction, these authors arent shy about unabashed happy endings.

title: Homes for $435,000
description: An 1896 house in Salt Lake City; a contemporary in Houston; and a log house in Montana.

title: Warning Raised on European Union Plan to Change Rules for Insurers Investments
description: LONDON  The worlds largest financial institutions warned Wednesday that proposed rule changes in the European Union could encourage insurance companies to invest in riskier assets like bank debt and sovereign bonds, and they called for reconsideration of the measure.

title: What You Get for ... $435,000
description: SALT LAKE CITY

title: Dog Run
description: Many animals aren't allowed on the subway. Transportation services like Pet Chauffeur are here to help.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Aug. 18
description: The top color for fall; shopping for a fall chapeaux; sales at Project No. 8, Realm and Dannijo; store openings and pop-ups in New York City.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Raise the Gas Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Abercrombie Wants Off Jersey Shore (Wink-Wink)
description: Brands have pursued product placement for years, cutting deals to get sodas and sports cars in movies and on television. Some have even insisted on the opposite, having their logos and labels blurred by the camera when associated with the bad guy, for instance.

title: Two Stars and Two Early Exits Before Open
description: MASON, Ohio  Two of the top contenders for the womens singles title at the United States Open hit significant snags in their preparation Wednesday. Serena Williams, a three-time Open champion, withdrew from the Western & Southern Open, her final tuneup for the Open, shortly before her second-round match against the Australian Samantha Stosur. She said he had a toe injury on her surgically repaired right foot.

title: TimesCast | August 17, 2011
description: More than 10,000 take to the streets of New Delhi to protest corruption; soaring gold prices mean brisk business for Manhattan jewelers; and the photographer Doug Mills on Obama's Midwest trip.

title: Former SpongeBob Artist Sued for Allegedly Arranging Attack on His Art Dealer
description: According to a lawsuit filed last week in Superior Court in Los Angeles, a former lead artist on the cartoon SpongeBob SquarePants hired accomplices to attack his art dealer and take over her gallery in order to gain control of the sale of his work  claims the artist denies.

title: Can a New Form Make Health Insurance Decisions Easier?
description: The world of health insurance is complex and loaded with jargon. Pre-existing conditions! Family deductibles! Out-of-pocket maximums! Ugh. Its no wonder people get confused when trying to compare plans.

title: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Uganda, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Somalia.

title: Gadgetwise: LinkedIns Social-Ad Misstep
description: Gadgetwise reports that LinkedIn users are not happy after the company quietly introduced a new site feature called social ads. The new form of advertising commandeers a users name and picture for product endorsements, but does so without asking users to opt-in to the new ads. Read the entire post here.

title: Russia Is Better Prepared for a Possible Global Downturn
description: MOSCOW  During previous bouts of financial volatility, Russia could be reliably found on the edge of the violent extremes. In 2008, for example, the Russian stock market was the worst performing of any major stock exchange in the world. The ruble collapsed. And the rich industrialists known as the oligarchs suffered $230 billion in paper losses.

title: New Commissioner for Citys Environmental Protection Agency
description: Carter H. Strickland Jr., who has helped lead the Bloomberg administrations efforts on environmental sustainability, has been named commissioner of the citys Department of Environmental Protection, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Wednesday.

title: Liberty Considers Range of Options for Barnes & Noble
description: Liberty Media is considering a range of options for Barnes & Noble, which include taking a minority stake in the bookseller instead of buying it outright, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: The Failure of Liberal Bioethics
description: Heres a telling passage from this Sundays Times Magazine story on selective reduction  the increasingly commonplace practice whereby twin pregnancies are reduced to single babies via abortion:

title: Fox and NBC Battle in Tuesday Ratings
description: Jennifer Behm was declared the winner during the two-hour season finale of MasterChef on Tuesday on Fox. This competitive cook-off reached series highs in total viewers  with 7 million  and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. But it was enough to give Fox a victory in the 18-to-49 category for the night among the broadcast networks, according to Nielsen data. NBC claimed the top spot in total viewers despite another disappointing outing for Americas Got Talent. That show hit a summer low in the demographic and and was down in total viewers, as well, averaging 10 million over a two-hour period.

title: A Big Big Lebowski Cast Reunion
description: The Big Lebowski cast reunites for one night onstage? Dude!

title: A Monumental Occasion
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art unveiled in its Great Hall a colossal statue of a pharaoh, on loan from the Egyptian Museum in Berlin for 10 years.

title: Bladder Cancer a Growing Concern for Smokers
description: Smokers have much higher odds of developing bladder cancer than previously believed, and the changing makeup of cigarettes may be a factor, new research shows.

title: Weather Alerts Are Imperiled, NOAA Warns
description: Without money to build a new satellite, the federal government will no longer be able to forecast severe weather events far enough in advance for communities to take life-saving action five years from now. That was the message that Jane Lubchenco, the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, delivered on Wednesday at a town-hall-style meeting in Denver.

title: Caution: Women Playing
description: I DONT wear shorts in public! shouted Sophie Franks Staub, a rangy 41-year-old stay-at-home mother, from her spot on a sand court on Pier 25 in Hudson River Park. Yet she was indeed wearing them, as were two dozen other women in their 30s and 40s, all barefoot as they learned to play beach volleyball on a buttery night in July.

title: In Crisis, Reminders of Disputes in Euros Founding
description: LONDON

title: Managing social-media overload; the Flame Index; augmented reality; tech news.
description: Stephanie Rosenbloom of The Times offers tips for wrangling personal time back from multiple social-media Web sites. John Jones of The Flame Index explains how the site ranks companies that are battling negative events in the news. The weekly discussion of technology news includes a look at Googles deal for Motorola Mobility and a new blog about Windows 8.

title: Tudous First-Day Fizzle
description: The Chinese video site Tudou managed to break into the public markets on Wednesday  but it wasnt pretty.

title: Was It Worth It? Theater Makers Who Showed Their Stuff in Edinburgh Add It Up
description: 4:57 p.m. | Updated  Getting noticed at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is a matter of numbers. Some 2,500 events make up the multi-arts extravaganza, which continues through Aug. 29, and according to a recent article in The Scotsman, 188 of them are American theatrical productions, many of which originated in New York. (Thats about the same number of shows, in total, playing at the New York International Fringe Festival, which finishes up this week.)

title: Malpractice Anxiety
