description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated At least three people died and 71 were injured Thursday when a stage collapsed during a storm at an outdoor music festival in Belgium, according to The Associated Press.

title: Fall Trends | Maxi Coat
description: T Magazine's Ethel Park discusses how she styled a photo shoot for the Fall Women's issue. Directed by Patrick Sher.

title: TimesCast | August 18, 2011
description: Militants kill seven Israelis near a Red Sea resort; the United States calls on Syria's president to step down; and Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen on the implications if Bashar al-Assad resigns.

title: Jobless Rate Holds at 8.7%, but Many Have Given Up Looking
description: New York Citys job market continued to putter along in July, as thousands of residents gave up looking for work and the unemployment rate held steady at 8.7 percent, the states Labor Department reported on Thursday.

title: Obama, on Midwest Tour, Moves to Regain Mantle of Campaigner
description: ALPHA, Ill.  On the final stop of a Midwestern bus tour, after President Obama faced a rolling reality check about the precarious state of the nations economy, a young man offered a parting word of encouragement.

title: Behind Googles Huge Breakup Fee in Motorola Deal
description: It is certainly big. But is there any chance that it will be paid? Im talking about the $2.5 billion reverse termination fee that Google agreed to pay Motorola Mobility if its proposed takeover fails to obtain antitrust clearance. This fee is about 20 percent of the $12.5 billion deal value and is significantly higher than the $375 million Motorola Mobility must pay Google if it accepts another bid.

title: And a Frog Shall Lead Them: Hensons Legacy
description: COOKIE MONSTER has an important lesson for Don Draper.

title: Fiat 500 by Gucci Revives Long, if Inglorious Tradition
description: For all the brands recent strides upmarket, Hyundai does not offer color-matched Salvatore Ferragamo luggage. Maserati, however, does. Chevrolet has yet to affix headliners embossed with the Versace logo on the roof of a Malibu  perhaps because Lamborghini beat them to it.

title: Fewer Youths to Be Deported in New Policy
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration announced Thursday that it would suspend deportation proceedings against many illegal immigrants who pose no threat to national security or public safety.

title: Shark Attacks Shock Russian East
description: MOSCOW  When a young man lost both his arms this week in the waters off Russias east coast, officials and residents initially had trouble believing what had happened. But a day later, when a teenagers legs were ripped up in the same waters, all doubt vanished.

title: Hewlett-Packards Rocky Deal History
description: 6:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Lahti, Birney Join the Cast of Adam Rapps New Play
description: Christine Lahti (God of Carnage) and Reed Birney (Dream of the Burning Boy) will star in the Atlantic Theater Companys production of Dreams of Flying Dreams of Falling, a new play by Adam Rapp, the theater announced Thursday.

description: Photographs from Somalia, Afghanistan, Libya and Israel.

description: New Museum

description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is eager to stand out. Just not too much.

title: Beneath the Suit, a Melodic Champion
description: Chris Ullman is a mild-mannered executive at one of the world's biggest private equity firms. But beneath the facade lurks an unorthodox musical virtuoso. DealBook's Kevin Roose investigates.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 19-25
description: Art

title: Easy Ratatouille
description: Mark Bittman cooks ratatouille, the more-difficult-to-pronounce-than-make dish of summer vegetables.

title: The Minimalist: Easy Ratatouille
description: Ratatouille, as many now know thanks to the 2007 animated film, is the more-difficult-to-pronounce-than-make dish of summer vegetables  tomatoes, zucchini and eggplant primary among them. The French verb touiller means to stir or to toss; rata is an old-fashioned French military term for a mixed vegetable dish.

title: Puckering Up, With a Piano Concerto at His Lips
description: Christopher W. Ullman still remembers the day when he realized he was a serious whistler.

title: Mapping Antarctic Ice In Motion
description: Put the arguments over how fast Antarctic ice is melting to one side for the moment. The latest study of the southern continent, by a group of scientists led by Eric Rignot of the University of California, Irvine, shows how fast the ice rivers are moving and where they are going.

title: Candids From a Global Mammal Study
description: More than 100 mammal species, some threatened or endangered, were captured by remote camera traps from seven protected areas around the world.

title: Liberty Buys a Stake in Barnes & Noble for $204 Million
description: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

title: Food for Beer Lovers, Tennis Lovers and Lovers, Period
description: The digital mailman stomped through the rains early this week to deliver questions from almost-newlyweds, the tennis-obsessed and a reader with a food allergy. I put on my writing gloves and tried to help. As ever, you may send questions about restaurants in New York City to dinejournal@nytimes.com. Or find me on Twitter: @samsifton.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Did you ever want to be an Alpha Phi Alpha stepper? Maybe youve always wanted to be a Dapper Dan of the Roaring Twenties? With admission prices as easy to swing as the Charleston, this weeks events let you experience a moment in American popular culture.

title: TimesCast | Calls for Assad to Resign
description: August 18, 2011 - On Thursday, in a coordinated effort, the United States, Canada and several European countries called for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to resign.

title: The Cause Is Familiar, but the War Is Less So
description: Although John Sayless new film, Amigo, is set in what seems to be a remote time and place  a hamlet called San Isidro, in the Philippines, around 1900  it bridges the gap in a hurry. This is not the kind of movie, and Mr. Sayles is not the type of director, to linger in the picturesque past, savoring antique details and restaging bygone conflicts.

title: If Assad Steps Down
description: Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen discusses the regional implications should Syrian President Bashar Al-Assad resign.

title: Keep Hold of Your Head, Lest He Lop It Off With the Others
description: A heavy-metal fantasia scrawled in red, Conan the Barbarian now comes with 75 percent more gore. Thats only an estimate, though to judge by the gruesome opener that features the title character as a boy gouging enemy flesh and lopping off heads, its a fair guess. Having entered a forest for a newbie warrior rite of passage, baby Conan (Leo Howard) has returned to his village and its leader, his brawny, bushy father (Ron Perlman, surprise), splattered in blood and dangling several severed heads from his wee mitts. They look like grotesque puppets or maybe yo-yos, but, really, theyre just playthings for a growing barbarian.

title: You Must Remember This
description: Kevin Jerome Eversons short films about ordinary African-American life are completely unordinary. Yet despite their frequent appearance in film festivals and on museum film programs, they have yet to sink fully into art world consciousness. Even when Mr. Eversons striking seven-minute Emergency Needs was in the 2008 Whitney Biennial, it was sidelined, as biennial films often are, by the objects in the galleries.

title: Darkness Visible, and Palpable
description: In the land of the blind  as you learn in the exhibition Dialog in the Dark, which opens on Saturday at the South Street Seaport  the one-eyed man hasnt a chance.

title: Removing an Iranian Group From the U.S. Terror List
description: To the Editor:

title: No Sign of Calm in Market Outlook
description: The fear of a euro zone sequel to the Lehman Brothers collapse has whipsawed stocks, bonds and just about every other market. Thursdays action followed the same pattern. Major European and American stock indexes slumped as much as 6 percent, while safe-haven Treasuries and gold rose. As long as policy makers and fundamentals alike offer no conviction, global volatility is set to stay high.

title: House Tour: Stanfordville, N.Y.
description: This 1890s farmhouse is across the road from the Buttercup Farm Sanctuary, with its miles of nature trails and more than 500 protected acres.

title: House Tour: Stanfordville, N.Y.
description: HOW MUCH $795,000. Taxes: $14,700.

title: A Bequest of Modernism Enriches Two Museums
description: In a buying spree that lasted just half a decade, John R. Eckel Jr. built a collection of Modernist furniture and paintings that museums craved. Mr. Eckel, a Houston energy tycoon who died in 2009, focused on a few American designers and artists, including Paul Evans, Harry Bertoia and Edward Wormley.

title: A Printed Matter | Mary Meyer
description: The designer Mary Meyer has been churning out tribal-inspired prints since long before they became trendy. But the moment seems auspicious for the inauguration of Meyers first brick-and-mortar store, which opened in late July in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: The Downside of a Free Lunch
description: My boss buys our small staff lunch every Monday, which he eats with us. We dont discuss business at these meals, which make them seem unnecessary. And his eating habits are atrocious: loud, open-mouth chewing. No one says anything about it. Id rather avoid watching this and go to lunch on my own, but that would be frowned upon. Any suggestions?

title: Online Privacy: How U.S. and Europe See Eye to Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: Stopping Traffic Downtown With a Subcontinents Movements
description: Each August now brings one of the highlights of the New York dance calendar in, of all places, the Financial District at lunchtime: namely, the Erasing Borders Festival of Indian Dance open-air performance. Its held as part of the Battery Dance Companys annual Downtown Dance Festival and presented by the Indo-American Arts Council.

title: The Advisers Behind H.P.s Autonomy Deal
description: 12:00 a.m. | Updated How many advisers does it take to put together a $11.7 billion technology deal? More than a dozen, apparently.

title: Ashton Kutcher Could Face Questions About Disclosure
description: 1:30 p.m., Aug. 19 | Updated  See our followup post on this subject. The F.T.C. said Friday that it did not plan to investigate Mr. Kutcher.

title: Violations Found in Nearly 60% of Supermarket Inspections
description: Nearly 60 percent of supermarket inspections in the last year turned up violations of consumer protections, an increase over the year before, even amid a high-profile city crackdown, the Department of Consumer Affairs said.

title: An Alarm Clock for Congress
description: Via Mashable, I see theres a new iPhone app that donates money to charity every time you hit snooze on your phones alarm clock.

title: Abiding by Mexican Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: The Magic of Movies, Born From a Single Snapshot
description: If and when you tire of the hyperactive playground of Talk to Me, the Museum of Modern Arts summer design blockbuster, make your way downstairs to Projects 95: Runa Islam. There you will find the restorative whirr of film projectors and the passive diversions of old-fashioned cinema.

title: Old World Charm Endures at Contes Market
description: Contes Market, a butcher shop and grocery, is frequented by customers and music lovers.

title: A Regulator, a Lawmaker and a Quandary
description: Its the kind of thing that the Securities and Exchange Commission might want to look into. First the company froze out investors with small holdings, cashing them out at a very low price. Within days, it began confidential talks seeking to find a buyer. It took a few months, but the net result was that the company was acquired for more than five times the price the small investors were forced to accept.

title: Sculptural Surprises Grace the Streets
description: It is the outdoor art season in New York and therefore a good time to ask what makes for a successful piece of urban public art. When art ventures away from the nurturing shelter of the white-walled gallery, it must contend with all kinds of distractions: huge buildings; noisy vehicular and pedestrian traffic; spectacular, sexy commercial signs with dizzying video imagery; unpredictable weather; the verdant beauty of a park; and the sheer interestingness and variety of so much else that in the artificial and natural fabric of the city.

title: A Market for Meat and Melodies
description: MOST of the old Yorkville is long gone  the beer halls, sausage bars and other haunts that once distinguished this Upper East Side neighborhood as an outpost of old-world charm.

title: The Director Congressman
description: My column this week discusses a company founded by Representative Darrell Issa, Republican of California, who remained on its board until it was acquired by a private equity firm a few weeks ago. About the same time that the company decided to look for a buyer, it forced small investors to sell for a fraction of what larger shareholders would soon receive.

title: A Market for Meat and Melodies
description: Most of the old Yorkville is long gone  the beer halls, sausage bars and other haunts that once distinguished this Upper East Side neighborhood as an outpost of Old World charm.

title: Restoring Faith in Credit Ratings
description: To the Editor:

title: A Spotlight on Drone Strikes in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Islands Naval Base Stirs Opposition in South Korea
description: GANGJEONG, South Korea  Dozens of banners adorn this village on the southern coast of South Koreas southernmost major island, trumpeting anxieties that have invaded this otherwise idyllic community and divided it so deeply that residents say some fathers and sons have stopped talking to one another.

title: President Obamas upcoming jobs creation speech; Ron Pauls apparent shift in campaign strategy; and the election season already in full swing.
description: President Obamas upcoming jobs creation speech; Ron Pauls apparent shift in campaign strategy; and the election season already in full swing. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, assistant politics editor Paul Volpe, and Caucus blog editor Megan Liberman join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: Yanks Abroad: Edu No Longer the Lone Ranger
description: The new manager of Glasgow Rangers, Ally McCoist, clearly has an affinity for American soccer players.

title: Port Authority Proposes Less Drastic Toll Increase
description: 8:58 p.m. | Updated In a sharp but widely predicted reversal, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Thursday unveiled a revised slate of toll and fare increases on the major Hudson River crossings, one far less steep than the agency initially proposed.

title: More Than One Kind of Deadline
description: War is like a toothless old whore  disgusting, mainly, but every once in a while she gives it to you like nobodys business, chortles Dutchman (Val Kilmer), a loudmouthed roving war correspondent doing his Hemingway thing early in Renny Harlins 5 Days of War.

title: Muppets and More
description: Images from Jim Hensons Fantastic World at the Museum of the Moving Image.

title: Capturing the Idling of the Motor City
description: RISING nearly 20 stories above the surrounding neighborhood in southwest Detroit, Michigan Central Station is an imposing leviathan of another era. The disembarkation point for countless Motor City migrants seeking a decent wage in Henry Fords factories, it was Detroits Ellis Island for the journey toward middle-class life.

title: Love in Detroits Ruins
description: The photographer Andrew Moore is ardently capturing the blighted glories of Motown.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Biden Visits China
description: The Times's Edward Wong gives a behind the scenes look at Vice-President Biden's trip to China.

title: Those Good, Old Vampires, and Now Theyre in 3-D
description: It is inevitable that Fright Night, a 3-D remake of a tongue-in-cheek, tooth-in-neck frightener from 1985, includes a mocking reference to Twilight, the vampire juggernaut that serves as both its target and its reason for being. Two estranged friends, Charley (Anton Yelchin) and Ed (Christopher Mintz-Plasse), are snooping around in an empty house, and Charley is teasing Ed, his geeky boyhood pal, for believing in undead, fanged predators, implying that he is a closet fan of Stephenie Meyers swoony books and the movies they have spawned. How dare you? Ed sputters, in the midst of trying to explain that real vampires are nothing like the effete and sensitive immortals played by Robert Pattinson and his colleagues.

title: Her Life Since Then: Different Views of It
description: 2000: Jane Fonda tacitly agrees to let Patricia Bosworth write a biography of her. But she is not willing to speak directly with Ms. Bosworth because she is at work on her own book, the memoir My Life So Far.

title: Outdoor Art Season
description: A look at some of the cuddly, colorful and surprising public artworks in New York City.

title: Steve Brills Report Card on School Reform
description: Steven Brill is a graduate of Yale Law School and the founder of Court TV, and in his new book, Class Warfare, he brings a sharp legal mind to the world of education reform. Like a dogged prosecutor, he mounts a zealous case against Americas teachers unions. From more than 200 interviews, he collects the testimony of idealistic educators, charter school founders, policy gurus, crusading school superintendents and billionaire philanthropists. Through their vivid vignettes, which he pieces together in short chapters with titles like  Colorado Says Half of You Wont Graduate  and A Shriek on Park Avenue, Brill conveys the epiphanies, setbacks and triumphs of a national reform movement.

title: Fall Trends | No. 3: The Retro Dress
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#918", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: A Meek Superhero Bravely Awaits S.O.S.
description: At once familiar and gently twisted, the Australian film Griff the Invisible centers on a man who yearns to be a superhero. If the movie didnt carry a 2010 date, you might think that its titular character, a hobbyist who plays at superhero, would have to spend much of his time fighting copycat charges and not villainy. In rough outline it recalls two American films, Kick-Ass (2010), about a teenager who wants to be a superhero and hooks up with a gun-toting girl, and Super (also 2010, but released last March), about a diner cook turned avenger who raises a wrench against line-cutting moviegoers and other miscreants.

title: Behind the Prickliness Lies a Generous Heart
description: Paloma Josse (Garance Le Guillermic), the blas narrator of Mona Achaches film The Hedgehog, is a precociously articulate 11-year-old girl from an upper-class Parisian family who sneaks around with her fathers old camcorder as if she were a spy in her own household. Peering owl-like over her John Lennon glasses, she airily disparages her affluent fishbowl existence. Its not for her, she announces. Thats why she is planning her suicide on the day she turns 12, using her mothers pills, which she stockpiles, one at a time.

title: The Other Child in Papa Mozarts Musical Troupe
description: Mozarts Sister has just started when the French director Ren Fret makes the point that his fictional look at the early life and times of Wolfgang Amadeus isnt interested in the pretty manners and nostalgia of many period movies. In truth, the film has little to do even with Wolfgang, a side note in a story focused on his only sister whos first seen squatting on the side of a road taking care of business at a short distance from her similarly engaged father, mother and brother. This is the Family Mozart, Mr. Fret seems to declare with this scene, stripped down and at their most human.

title: Rodriguez Hopes to Be in Lineup on Saturday
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Alex Rodriguez was back with the Yankees on Thursday as they began a four-game weekend series with the Twins. He worked out, said he felt good and said he was hoping to return to the starting lineup on Saturday.

title: Vacation May Provide a Break from Washingtons Woes
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass.  President Obama slipped out of Washington on Thursday to join his family for a nine-day vacation on Marthas Vineyard, leaving behind the most dismal stretch of his presidency and looking to recharge for what is sure to be an epic political battle this fall over the nations finances.

title: U.F.C. Lands a Seven-Year Deal With Fox Sports
description: Fox Sports is adding the Ultimate Fighting Championship, the dominant brand in mixed martial arts, to its collection of sports programming. The seven-year deal will include four fights a year on broadcast television in prime time and will pay the U.F.C. at least $100 million annually.

title: Massachusetts: Bulger Companion Pleads Not Guilty
description: Catherine Greig pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges that she assisted her companion, the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger, during their 16 years on the run. Ms. Greig, who smiled and laughed with her lawyers before the short proceeding, pleaded not guilty to one count of conspiracy to harbor and conceal a fugitive, which carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Prosecutors said she used false identification, posed as Mr. Bulgers wife and tried to prevent his arrest. Mr. Bulger is charged with 19 murders and other crimes. Ms. Greigs lawyer, Kevin Reddington, told reporters outside the federal court in Boston that Ms. Greig would not cooperate with the authorities and that she was an excellent candidate for bail.

title: The Serial-Killer Story Takes a New Twist
description: Twisting the serial-killer story into an unexpectedly novel shape, Adam Wingards film A Horrible Way to Die is a restrained, ripely atmospheric thriller that relies more on mood than on special effects.

title: Iraq Leader Says the Arab Spring Benefits Israel
description: BAGHDAD  While Western leaders including President Obama called on President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to step down, Iraqs prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, warned Arab leaders in a speech on Thursday that Israel would benefit the most from the Arab Spring.

title: Straining Credibility, Not Only Hamstrings
description: MASON, Ohio

title: 2 Clowns and the Surreal Pursuit of Love
description: Brilliant, bizarre, dazzling and utterly demented, The Last Circus views Franco-era Spain through the crazed eyes of two clowns doing battle for the love of one magnificent woman. The metaphor may be unsubtle, but the jaw-dropping brio of its execution takes the breath away: resisting its lunatic spell would probably require full-body sedation.

title: Leon Schipper, Physicist and Iconoclast, Dies at 64
description: Leon J. Schipper, a physicist whose passion for data led him to question the value of popular energy policies, like government subsidies for ethanol and for electric cars and the cash for clunkers program, died Tuesday in Berkeley, Calif. He was 64.

title: Customers Feel Some Ripples From the Verizon Strike
description: As a strike by 45,000 Verizon workers approaches the two-week mark, the companys customers are beginning to feel the impact  and are complaining about it.

title: Ruth Brinker, Who Gave AIDS Patients Meals, Is Dead at 89
description: Ruth Brinker, who founded one of the first social service agencies dedicated to providing meals to AIDS victims too weak or impoverished to feed themselves, died Aug. 8 at her home in San Francisco. She was 89.

title: RIM Reported to Be in Talks for Music Deal
description: Research in Motion, the maker of BlackBerry smartphones, is in the process of signing deals with the major record companies to develop a limited digital music service for its subscribers, according to several people briefed on the talks.

title: Bloggingheads: Flash Mob Violence
description: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate the sources of flash mob violence.

title: Missing a Wedding and a Fiance
description: MASON, Ohio  Serena Williams was not the only tennis player invited to this weekends royal Hollywood wedding. Also on the guest list was Maria Sharapova, whose fianc, Sacha Vujacic, played on the Nets with Kris Humphries, who is marrying the reality TV star Kim Kardashian.

title: Libyan Rebels Increase the Pressure
description: In the past week, rebel forces have mounted new attacks on strategic cities and pushed toward Tripoli.

title: Engineering Food for All
description: Washington

title: Unlikely Echo of Gandhi Inspires Indians to Act
description: NEW DELHI  In a new India often obsessed with wealth and status, where cricket batsmen and Bollywood movie stars are wildly idolized, Anna Hazare is a figure from an earlier, seemingly discarded era. His pointed white cap and simple white cotton clothes evoke a Gandhian simplicity. His rural, homespun demeanor ordinarily might elicit snickers from Indias urban elite.

title: File Disposal Still an Issue for S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON  More than a year after a whistle-blower said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was illegally destroying records of preliminary investigations, the commission has yet to agree with government archivists on which records to keep and which to discard.

title: Cutting Costs the Montana Way
description: Helena, Mont.

title: Formula One Set for Austin in Fall 2012
description: FORMULA ONE auto racing is still set to return to the United States next year at a new track under construction outside Austin, Tex.

title: Powers of Hidden Persuasion
description: Filled with old people spouting ancient news, Jeff Warricks Programming the Nation? takes a jaundiced look at so-called subliminal techniques in advertising and mass media.

title: Save the Savings Bond
description: FOR generations of children, the idea of saving first became real when a savings bond landed in a birthday or holiday card, the image of a famous American staring out from the elaborate, earth-tone etching on a stately certificate. These fond memories may explain why this year nearly 50,000 Americans  the vast majority of them modest wage-earners  decided, under a new I.R.S. policy, to buy savings bonds with a portion of their precious tax refunds.

title: Chinese Athletes Say No to the System
description: BEIJING  Perhaps it was the latest bruise turning purple, or those final flecks of spit wiped away while walking off the court, or the curses echoing off the bleachers. Whatever the reason, the members of Chinas national junior basketball team decided one day in April that enough was enough. So they wrote down their plea in teenager scrawl, signed their names with ink-stained fingerprints and sent it to the Chinese Basketball Association.

title: Seattle, After Decade of Debate, Approves Tunnel
description: SEATTLE  For all its gentle reserve, this city has generated more than a few bold notions, from commercial jets to $5 coffee. Its Next Big Thing is similarly unconventional: a huge act of redevelopment intended to be all but invisible.

title: Boxing in the Blood and Bones
description: Merging immigrant hunger and Olympic dreams, Born and Bred offers a vrit portrait of three young Mexican-American boxers in East Los Angeles.

title: Birthdays Are Still Big in Buyout Land
description: When the billionaire buyout titan Stephen A. Schwarzman gave himself a boom-era-defining 60th birthday party in 2007, the global economy was soaring.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,729 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Protests of a Plan for a Mosque? That Was Last Year
description: The silence this time was thunderous.

title: Alabama Nuclear Reactor, Partly Built, to Be Finished
description: The directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority unanimously approved a plan on Thursday to finish the partly built Bellefonte 1 nuclear reactor, a project on which the authority spent billions of dollars in the 1970s and 80s but dropped in 1988 because of cost overruns and declining estimates of power demand.

title: The Question-Driven Life
description: Rift Valley, Kenya

title: Jets Dial In to Pipeline for Punters
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets history with Australian punters is believed to date to 1997, when Eric Mangini, then an assistant with the team, took time out of a vacation in Melbourne to put a young athlete with a big leg through a makeshift workout in a cow pasture.

title: The Wrong Idea
description: Stocks on Wall Street dropped sharply on Thursday, with investors spooked, again, about the euro-zone debt crisis and the sputtering United States economy.

title: Battle for Libya | August 18, 2011
description: In Zawiyah, rebel fighters gain complete control of the oil refinery.

title: Hey, Were Robbing This Bank! No, We Are!
description: Whats funnier than a gang of armed robbers? Two gangs. Or so goes the thinking in Flypaper, a mildly entertaining caper comedy that asks the cinematic question: What happens when competing sets of criminals  one super slick, the other backwoods bumpkins (Peanut Butter and Jelly, theyre called)  rob the same bank at the same time?

title: Truth About Syria
description: It took too long, but President Obama has finally  and unequivocally  called for the Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad to step down and end his murderous war against the Syrian people. In another belated but welcome move, Mr. Obama also ordered a stiff new array of sanctions, including freezing all Syrian government assets in the United States and banning American citizens and corporations from doing business with the Syrian government.

title: Companies Point Fingers as Students Protest Conditions at Chocolate Plant
description: HERSHEY, Pa.  A day after hundreds of foreign exchange students walked off their jobs at a plant packing Hersheys chocolates to protest low pay and physically draining work, executives at the Hershey Company and three other companies involved in the plant scrambled to sort out which one was responsible for the conditions that prompted the students complaints.

title: Perspective Adjusted, Kiwanuka Is Back
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Mathias Kiwanuka says he takes nothing for granted. Not after he saw his older brother Benedict get into a crash and be thrown 100 feet from his motorcycle. And certainly not after a neck injury forced Kiwanuka to sit down and compose a list of possible post-football plans a lot sooner than he expected.

title: Not the America They Expected
description: On Wednesday, 300 foreign students walked off the job and staged a protest rally at a packaging warehouse for Hersheys chocolates, saying this wasnt the America they had paid to see. It was not a good day for the State Departments efforts to promote a positive image of the United States through cultural exchanges.

title: When Murder Is Just Another Film Pitch
description: The writer-director Todd Berger parades his stylistic chops with his self-satisfied, vrit-ish comedy The Scenesters, a tepid show-business satire. When someone starts murdering trendy young adults in Los Angeles, two filmmakers  a humorless director (Mr. Berger) and his supercilious producer (Jeff Grace)  pursue their breakout project by following a crime-scene cleanup specialist (Blaise Miller) with ideas about the killer.

title: Tying a Century-Old Record
description: Baseball is dependent on its numbers and has legions fascinated with its statistics, but it turns out some of those numbers were written in pencil. One hundred-plus years ago.

title: Nadals Tough Day Presents Opportunity for Fish
description: MASON, Ohio  If Mardy Fish ever is going to beat Rafael Nadal, this week may be his best opportunity. Fish, who is winless in six matches against Nadal, advanced to the quarterfinals of the Western & Southern Open with a 7-5, 7-5 victory against Richard Gasquet on Thursday.

title: Some Very Good Sense
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey often goes too far, whether its bullying teachers or rejecting much-needed federal financing for a tunnel under the Hudson. Last month, however, the bluster was aimed at the right targets: ignorance and religious intolerance. He erupted in outrage at critics who attacked his decision to nominate Sohail Mohammed, a Muslim lawyer, to be a state judge.

title: The Future of Freedoms Fortress
description: Fort Monroe, Va., 2011

title: Lottery Numbers
With Gas Out, Days of Takeout and Chilly Baths
description: Cold showers. Spoiled fish. Wet or dirty laundry.

title: At This Girls Camp, Crafts Take a Drill Press
description: RIVER GROVE, Ill.  Forget tie-dyed shirts, lanyards and water games. At summer camp this year, Nautika Kotero, 13, learned to use a drill press, solder electrical wires and build a lamp.

title: Claudio Castiglioni, Motorbike Executive, Dies at 64
description: Claudio Castiglioni, a motorcycle enthusiast who resurrected the struggling Italian brands Ducati and MV Agusta and developed exciting new models like the Ducati 916 and the MV Agusta F4, died on Wednesday in Varese, Italy. He was 64.

title: Mets Get Poor Mileage Out of Their Broken-Down Bullpen
description: This season, the sight of a Mets reliever jogging toward the mound has often felt like a harbinger of bad things to come. And the numbers support that view.

title: After Shutdown, Storefronts Crumble
description: Off-Track Betting parlors were shuttered earlier this year, and the storefronts are now empty.

title: Girardi Trusted Umpire in Opting Not to Protest
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Joe Girardi came away with a one-run loss and a feeling of helplessness after an umpiring gaffe in Kansas City on Wednesday night. But he also learned a valuable lesson when he declined to play the rest of the game under protest. From now on, Girardi said Thursday, he will take a more cynical approach.

title: Friday: You Might Keep a Watch On It
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  You learn all sorts of things from solving crossword puzzles. One of the things I learned today is that Patrick Berry thinks differently than other people, and perhaps thats why his puzzles are so enjoyable.

title: Russia: Rivers Sturgeon Population Dips Drastically
description: The sturgeon population in the lower Volga River  historically the worlds chief source of black caviar  has dipped by 99 percent in the past 15 years, the head of the Federal Fisheries Agency said Thursday. According to a report by the Interfax news agency, the official, Andrei Krainy, said almost all Russian sturgeon are now grown at six fisheries in the Astrakhan region in southern European Russia, where the Volga empties into the Caspian Sea. The decline began decades ago with the building of dams and with pollution that choked waterways. It has accelerated since Soviet times with organized illegal fishing and the corruption that allows it to flourish. Scientists say the surviving fish are overwhelmingly male because fishermen harvest females for their prized eggs.

title: Killing Shocks and Puzzles a Quiet New Jersey Town
description: BOONTON, N.J.  Cyril Wekilsky, the 72-year old mayor of Boonton, said he could not recall the last shooting death before this week in his community, a small town of under 9,000 people some 30 miles from Manhattan.

title: Once Again, Fear Sends Stocks Down
description: After starting out the week with hopes of newfound stability, stock market investors ended up experiencing another ugly week as worries about the global economy resurfaced.

title: China: Officers Surround Monastery After Suicide
description: In the days since a Tibetan Buddhist monk in southwestern Sichuan Province set himself on fire to protest Chinese policies, the authorities have sent as many as 1,000 armed police officers to surround the monks monastery and have restricted telephone and Internet access, according to advocacy groups. The monk, Tsewang Norbu, was the second this year to kill himself by self-immolation. The suicide of the other monk, Phuntsog, at the Kirti Monastery, in a nearby prefecture in Sichuan, set off a violent standoff between local residents and paramilitary police, who eventually detained 300 monks. Before his suicide on Monday morning, Tsewang Norbu reportedly handed out leaflets demanding the return of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader, and calling for an end of the repression that has intensified in the area since the clashes at Kirti Monastery.

title: As the Tolls Keep Rising, Some Still Pay Nothing
description: For eight years, Alfred Buono had made it a twice-weekly occurrence: He would drive his car across a bridge from New Jersey to Staten Island and not pay the toll  doing so a total of 998 times, authorities said.

title: Bloomberg Discrimination-Suit Ruling Renews Work-Life Debate
description: A few pages from the end of a 64-page legal decision dismissing claims that Bloomberg L.P. had engaged in a pattern of discrimination against new mothers and mothers-to-be, Judge Loretta A. Preska set aside the legalese to offer some blunt remarks on a topic dear to the hearts of many working parents (and those who choose not to be).

title: Baltimore Fixes Its Streets for 175 M.P.H. Speed Limit
description: BALTIMORE

title: A Race in Montana May Again Be Crucial to Senate Control
description: LINCOLN, Mont.  A few election cycles ago, before the recession, the debt crisis and the Tea Party movement redefined American politics, a species called the New Western Democrat emerged in places like Montana.

title: Wig-Wearing Bad Hair Bandit Was Prison Nurse, Officials in Idaho Say
description: She had a penchant for clumsy wigs, traveled with her cat and worked as a prison nurse in Idaho  when she was not crisscrossing the Pacific Northwest robbing banks.

title: Teenagers Get Wild Cards Into U.S. Open
description: Lauren Davis, fresh off a victory in the girls 18s national championships, was awarded one of eight wild cards into the womens main draw of the United States Open. Davis, 18, will play in her second Grand Slam event. She won a wild-card playoff for a berth in the Australian Open in January, when she lost in the first round.

title: Brazil: Agriculture Minister Resigns; 4th Official to Fall
description: Brazils agriculture minister, Wagner Rossi, resigned Wednesday amid accusations of influence peddling leveled in the news media. Mr. Rossi is the fourth official to fall  and the third to step down because of corruption accusations  since President Dilma Rousseff took office just eight months ago. Accusations in the past 30 days have been false and without any proof of improper or illegal actions, Mr. Rossi said in his resignation letter.

title: Liberty Win in Overtime
description: Cappie Pondexter scored 27 points as the host Liberty rallied to beat the Connecticut Sun, 84-81, in overtime. Kia Vaughn added 17 points and 11 rebounds for the Liberty (15-11), who outscored the Sun by 22-7 in the fourth quarter to force the overtime.

title: The Challenging, Lasting Career of the Artists Model
description: Carla Kandinsky began her career as a muse almost 50 years ago, when the art school graduate from whom she was renting a room in Berkeley eyed her as a potential life-drawing subject.

title: Warnings, but Not Really, on Cellphone Antennas
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Young Indian-American Stakes Claim for Central Valley House Seat
description: At 24, he may not be quite old enough to serve, but that has not stopped Ranjit Gill from raising a lot of money in his bid to win a seat in the United States House of Representatives.

title: Number of Green Jobs Fails to Live Up to Promises
description: Flanked by a cadre of local political leaders, Mayor Chuck Reed of San Jose used a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a solar power company last week to talk up the promise of the green economy.

title: A Different Kind of Corporate Breakup
description: David Greising writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Yanks Have Power to Support Sabathia
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The Minnesota Twins honored Jim Thome on Thursday night before his first game back at Target Field since he hit his 600th home run. They showed video tributes from Hank Aaron, Willie Mays and Commissioner Bud Selig. Alex Rodriguez, the lone member of the 600 club present, popped out of the Yankees dugout and shook Thomes hand.

title: A Friday Night Fight, and His Name on the Line
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Amalgamated Hires a New Chief Executive
description: ANEW YORK agency that changed hands last year is bringing in a new chief executive in a bid to spur further growth.

title: 2011 Indianapolis Colts Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. This week, he is analyzing the A.F.C. South.

title: Are They Not Staying Long Enough at the Fair?
description: Presidents once made a point of visiting the Illinois State Fair, where dusty tractors rambled past carnival rides and farmers showcased prized cattle. But when Republicans and Democrats had their pep rallies on the state fairgrounds this week, attendance by leaders from both parties was lackluster.

title: Aug. 19, 1934 | German Voters Approve Hitler as Fhrer
description: On Aug. 19, 1934, the German public voted 90 percent in favor of Chancellor Adolf Hitler becoming Fhrer und Reichskanzler (leader and chancellor), a new title created after the death of President Paul von Hindenburg earlier in the month.

title: Use of Health Management Consultants Draws Fire
description: When its chief operating officer, Tony Tedeschi, handed over his responsibilities at the troubled Cook County Health and Hospitals System last month to Carol Schneider, the two had something in common besides serving in thatjob: Both work for private consulting firms that have played a major role in the sprawling systems highly controversial restructuring.

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/19/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/19/2011

title: Off the Cuff, Into the Headlines
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Word of the Day | roil
description: roil \ri(-)l\ verb

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Bank of America Plans Big Layoffs to Cut Costs
description: Bank of America is set to eliminate at least 3,500 jobs in the coming months, as the beleaguered financial giant seeks to cut costs and restructure amid deepening shareholder dissatisfaction.

title: Prison Closing Pleases City and Helps State Budget
description: SUGAR LAND  Across the street from a manicured subdivision and just down the road from a growing regional airport is one of the oldest prisons in Texas, its stark white exterior and razor wire jutting out from a maze of oak trees.

title: Just an Ordinary Overachiever in Paint Creek
description: PAINT CREEK Of all the stories Paint Creek natives tell about Little Ricky Perry, the mischief-making, overachieving hometown boy turned Republican presidential contender, the favorite (and possibly apocryphal) tale involves a six-man high school football game in which he was knocked flat by an opponent. When the coach knelt over him to check for injuries, local lore has it, the young Mr. Perry said: Im O.K., coach. But how are the fans taking it?

title: 2 Car Bombs Lead Off Taliban Siege of a British Office
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Militants attacked a British cultural relations agency in a residential neighborhood of Kabul early Friday, setting off huge car bomb explosions and killing at least eight people in a standoff with the police that lasted several hours while agency employees hid inside, British and Afghan officials said. At least one international soldier was among the dead, officials said.

title: Gualtiero Jacopetti, Maker of Mondo Cane, Dies at 91
description: Gualtiero Jacopetti, a filmmaker who titillated and disgusted moviegoers by roaming the globe to document bizarre, not to say creepy, phenomena  a chicken that smokes cigarettes, for instance  in the movie Mondo Cane and its sequels, died on Wednesday at his home in Rome. He was 91.

title: Corrections: August 19
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Bob Sherman, a Force Behind Shock Jock Radio, Dies at 69
description: Bob Sherman, who as executive vice president of the New York radio station WNBC in the late 1970s and early 80s played a role in fomenting the irreverent, boisterous and sometimes profane shock jock genre by hiring Howard Stern and rehiring Don Imus, died on Aug. 14 in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 69.

title: Ohio: Union Groups Reject Call to Cancel Referendum
description: A coalition opposing a law limiting rights for public employee unions rejected Gov. John Kasichs offer to negotiate to avoid a Nov. 8 referendum, saying the measure must first be repealed. The coalition We Are Ohio, which includes labor representatives and Democrats, responded Thursday to a letter from Mr. Kasich and other Republican leaders suggesting a session to reach an agreement. A repeal must occur prior to any meeting, Melissa Fazekas, spokeswoman for We Are Ohio, said in a statement. The law allows 360,000 public employees to bargain only for wages, hours and work conditions. It is on hold after We Are Ohio submitted signatures to put it to a vote. The deadline to remove the issue from the ballot is Aug. 29. The Republicans letter said, We are prepared to move forward immediately with legislative action to implement any agreement on changes we are able to reach together. We Are Ohio and union groups asked Mr. Kasich and legislative leaders to call the Legislature into session to repeal the law.

title: Chinese Premier Sounds Confident Note on U.S. Economy
description: BEIJING  After widespread criticism among Chinese of Washingtons recent debt-ceiling gridlock and with expanding fears of another recession that could imperil the value of Chinas huge stake in American debt, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Chinese leaders labored on Friday to cast the American economys weakness as a passing phase.

title: Israelis Hit Gaza and Militants Fire Rockets After Deadly Attacks
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli warplanes launched air strikes on Gaza and militants fired more than 10 rockets into Israel, the Israeli authorities said early Friday, a day after armed attackers, described by the authorities as Gazans who had crossed into Israel from Egypt, carried out multiple deadly attacks near the popular Red Sea resort of Eilat.

title: Nivea Pulls Ad After Online Outcry
description: Nivea, the skincare and beauty products company, said Thursday it would halt its advertising campaign that suggested black men re-civilize themselves, after an outcry erupted Wednesday on Twitter.

title: North Korea Agrees to Talks on Searching for Remains of Missing U.S. Soldiers
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Friday that it had agreed to talks with the United States on searching for and returning the remains of American soldiers killed during the Korean War in the early 1950s.

title: Japanese Prime Minister, Under Pressure to Quit, Drops Plan to Meet With Obama
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Naoto Kan has scrapped plans to meet with President Obama in Washington next month as pressure builds on the unpopular Japanese leader to resign in the coming weeks.

title: News Quiz | August 19, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Newly Free, an Activist Urges India to Action
description: NEW DELHI  After walking out of jail into the cheering embrace of thousands of supporters, the anticorruption crusader Anna Hazare arrived on Friday at a vast public ground in the heart of Indias capital. He said a few words, waved a national flag and nodded as others gave speeches. Then he sat down.

title: Radiation Discovered in Rice Near Tokyo
description: TOKYO  Japanese inspectors found the first case of radioactive contamination in rice, the national grain, on Friday, adding it to the list of foods harmed by the accident at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.

title: The Devil and Demian Bichir
description: You can learn a lot about a man by the way he disembowels an avocado.

title: Awesome Wrongness
description: I hear that there was some action in the markets yesterday.

title: Rock Paper Scissors, 2011 Style
description: For generations, this childrens game has helped settle some profound conflicts. So Ive created a few additional hand gestures that might be helpful for our representatives in Washington.

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 19, 2011
description: Todays question was written by Shannon Doyne. Her question comes from the article Oh, Kahuna, What Became of That Endless Summer?

title: What Do You Hope to Get Out of High School?
description: A study found that attending New York Citys highly competitive exam schools (where entrance is determined by a test) has little to no effect on students SAT scores and other measures of achievement. How do you define achievement with respect to your high school career? What would you like to be able to achieve as a result of your high school experience?

title: Finally, Someone to Run Against Wall Street
description: One of the truly amazing things about American politics in the Lesser Depression is that nobody in political life has been willing to run as the champion of ordinary Americans against the financial wheeler-dealers who brought this disaster on us. Republicans wont, of course, because their worldview says that greed is good and government the only source of evil. But Obama has also been almost weirdly unwilling to express even the slightest populism.

title: Tip of the Week: Going from E-Mail to Chat
description: Going back and forth over a subject in e-mail messages is one way to make decisions, but it can be slow. But if you want to speed things up with your correspondentand you both use the same Webmail serviceconsider jumping to chat to speed up the process. Gmail, for example, offers a Reply by chat at the bottom of a message if you are both logged into the Gmail Web site and available to chat.

title: Germany and Michigan
description: This post by Jon Cohn made me think of something I wrote, to fairly general derision, last year.

title: Student Exchange Protest
description: WHY did hundreds of foreign students walk off their jobs on Wednesday?

title: The Early Word: Pressure
description: In Todays Times:

title: In Paris, an Open-Air Theater Festival
description: Every summer in Paris, wandering theatrical troupes present over 30 outdoor performances all over the city in the festival called Treteaux Nomades. Skilled at improvisation, commedia dellarte, burlesque, music and poetry, the adventurous actors set up a wooden stage, or treteaux, and offer contemporary versions of traditional and modern plays, as well as storytelling and clown and mime acts. This years festival will run from Aug. 22 through Sept. 4.

title: When Readers Jump Into the Story
description: In June, the magazine published my article about a mob-killing in a shantytown near Johannesburg. The grisly scene had been recorded on video by a friend of mine, Golden Mtika, a freelance journalist who lived in the impoverished community. Golden himself was poor, the article explained, and he was saving money so that he could one day move his family to a safer place. The article also mentioned that he was a devout Mormon.

title: John Williams Lets His Muses Carry Him Along
description: 10:59 a.m. | Updated LENOX, Mass.  It would be hard to live in America and not know some of John Williamss music. After six decades of working in Hollywood, much of that time in collaboration with the director Steven Spielberg, he has produced an opus  121 film scores, a symphony, a dozen concertos and other symphonic works  that would intimidate many composers. He has won five Academy Awards, four Golden Globes, five Emmys and 21 Grammys. He wrote the music for all the Star Wars and Indiana Jones movies and the first three Harry Potter films. He was the one who wrote the fearsome two-note motif from Jaws, and the famous five-note intergalactic message he composed for Close Encounters of the Third Kind. At 79, he is still going strong and recently finished scores for two more Spielberg movies, The Adventures of Tin Tin and War Horse.

title: Candid Camera for Mammals at Risk
