title: Dozens Dead After Bomb Explodes in Pakistan Mosque
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  At least 47 people were killed in the main hall of a mosque in northwest Pakistan on Friday when a suicide bomber detonated himself during midday prayers, local officials said.

title: Chaos Theory
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#127", 592, 360, true, chameleonData);

title: Bank of America Layoffs Continue
description: The pain continues at Bank of America.

title: What Spooks the Masters of Horror?
description: ONE of the great things about childhood is how easy it is to access the distinct delight of being scared out of your mind. Adults just have more trouble getting goosebumps. Thats because experience is the enemy of true terror. You may shriek the first time you see A Nightmare on Elm Street, but the second or third time you might only shudder. Thats why dedicated horror fans sometimes have a hard time finding a really nerve-rattling movie. Theyve already seen it all.

title: Paper Chase
description: The artist Vik Muniz turned two million paper cranes into one symbol of strength for Japanese earthquake victims.

title: Last of the All-Nighters
description: As Darshak Sanghavi explains, its clear that the issue of medical errors is complicated by concerns like incomplete work-rulescompliance, as well as by demonstrably poor practices like handoffs. But unconscionable hours, a major component of medical hazing, has been dealt an initial blow, and medicine will be the better for it. Physicians undergo extended and exhausting hazing, which many of them identify as dangerous and central to the eroding of their empathy and their sympathy, distancing them from patients. LEE KARR, Venice, Fla.

title: Sleeping Arrangement
description: I rented my bedroom out through a Web-based vacation-rental service. It became apparent that the guest and I had some sexual chemistry. The first night I slept on my futon in another room. The next day we slept together  this was entirely consensual and not solely instigated by me  in my bedroom. Do I refund her the rental fee and, if so, for one or both nights? NAME WITHHELD, SAN FRANCISCO

title: Wayne Coynes Oklahoma Compound
description: Behold the compound of the Flaming Lips frontman Wayne Coyne: four houses with connected backyards in Oklahoma City.

title: Danny Meyer on a Roll
description: On Dec. 22, 1995, my husband and I received five days notice that our 4-month-old daughter, Sophie, was due to arrive from Korea. What better way to celebrate becoming parents for the first time than going to Union Square Cafe? But the night before Sophies arrival was the day after Christmas. New York was full of tourists and the Union Square Cafe was fully booked. I explained the reason for our last-minute reservation, and not only did the hostess find us a table, but when it came time for dessert, we were served a chocolate cake with Congratulations! written on it and a candle burning.I will always remember the graciousness of the staff and how they shared in our joy. That sense of graciousness is instilled by Meyer, and these long years later, it still comes through. NANCY ALISBERG, West Hartford, Conn.

title: Its Not U, Its Me :(
description: I read Benoit Denizet-Lewiss essay with a mix of trepidation and curiosity. I, too, just navigated the waters of a breakup that involved who will change their Facebook profile picture of us as a couple first. The rub, however, is that I am 41 years old and divorced. I hate to break it to those kids in the (very well-meaning) conference, but nothing changes. Awkwardness, varying rules of etiquette, sexual boundaries  none of it gets all that much easier in future decades. Perhaps these teenagers will be more prepared than me and my peers for the commingling of technology and romance, for they are digital natives. Their ideas of privacy and even propriety are better suited for the age of online dating.

title: The Mad Scientist of Smut
description: Do I need to tweet every sentence of this N.Y.T. profile of Nicholson Baker, or will you all just promise to read it? Wow. @JOFIEFA, Aug. 4, Twitter

title: Another Thing to Sort of Pin on David Foster Wallace
description: Ten years ago, David Foster Wallace admitted in Tense Present, one of his best and most charming essays, to being a SNOOT, which he defined as a really extreme usage fanatic, the sort of person whose idea of Sunday fun is to look for mistakes in Safires columns prose itself. He outed himself while writing in Harpers on Bryan A. Garners Dictionary of Modern American Usage, a book, he says, that serves to confirm its authors SNOOTitude while undercutting it in tone.

title: Dimming the Red Lights in Turkey
description: On a Sunday afternoon earlier this summer, hundreds of Turkish men disappeared down a short alleyway just a five-minute walk from the Istanbul Modern art museum. Some flicked prayer beads around their fingers. The younger ones arrived in small groups, flashing nervous grins and smoothing their hair down with spit. They strode by a pile of garbage bags holding wadded-up tissues and cigarette butts before reaching a metal gate that separated the alley from their destination: Kadem Street, a narrow cul-de-sac and one of the countrys few remaining red-light districts.

title: Kwame Kilpatricks Latest Chapter
description: You were just released from a Michigan prison, where you served just over 14 months for probation violations. Youve also spent time in solitary confinement, or the hole. Tell me what thats like.  The hole is just like on TV. I could sit on my bed and touch all four walls. Nobody comes by. Nobody talks to you. They slide your food through a slot. Im a people guy, always on teams. So to be alone was an ordeal within itself, but it actually helped me. I didnt know how low I could fall until I was sitting in that hole crying, like: Wow. Im on a cement floor. This is it.

title: Wayne Coynes Oklahoma Compound
description: Behold the compound of the Flaming Lips frontman Wayne Coyne: four houses with connected backyards in Oklahoma City.

title: Obama Isnt the Only One to Take a Break
description: He left Washington in the midst of an economic crisis in the country. The stock market was plummeting. The jobs picture was worsening. And he started his vacation by playing golf.

title: Friday Reading: How Bill Clinton Became a Vegan
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Lets Talk About Charisma
description: Lets talk about charisma. You know it when you see it, right? But can you describe what it is youre seeing? Its hard to do.

title: Icahn Seeks to Replace Clorox Board
description: 6:13 p.m. | Updated

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Japan Quake Is Causing Costly Shift to Fossil Fuels
description: YOKOSUKA, Japan  The half-century-old, oil-fueled power generators here had been idle for more than a year when, a day after the nuclear accident in March, orders came from Tokyo Electric Power headquarters to fire them up.

title: Tracking Species as They Flee Ever Higher
description: In the early nineties, a young PhD student at the University of Texas in Austin spent four and a half years following a small black butterfly with red and yellow spots up and down the west coast, from southern California in March to Canada in August. In 1996 she published the results of her laborious fieldwork in a paper titled Climate and Species Range in the journal Nature.

title: Syria Said to Fire on Protest in Defiance of Global Rebuke
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Friday to call for the downfall of President Bashar al-Assad, keeping up the pressure in the five-month uprising a day after an alliance led by the United States toughened sanctions against his government and publicly called on him for the first time to step down. At least 18 people were reported killed, including some soldiers who disobeyed orders to shoot at protesters.

title: Exclusive Video: Stephen Malkmus
description: "No One Is (As I Are Be)" is from "Mirror Traffic," the new album by Stephen Malkmus and the Jicks, produced by Beck Hansen. It comes out on August 23. The video is directed by Steve Doughton.

title: Watch the Video for No One Is (As I Are Be) By Stephen Malkmus and the Jicks
description: In an interview for an article in this Sundays Arts & Leisure section, Stephen Malkmus spoke about how he began writing the songs on Mirror Traffic, his latest album with his band the Jicks and their first to be produced by Beck Hansen (a musician you might know better simply as Beck).

title: Deal Frees West Memphis Three in Arkansas
description: JONESBORO, Ark.  The end, if it can be called that, came all of a sudden.

title: Higher Bridge, Tunnel and PATH Rates Approved
description: A steep toll increase on the bridges and tunnels that cross the Hudson River was approved Friday morning by the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the culmination of a two-week dance among the agency, politicians and the public.

title: Son of Evangelical Royalty Turns His Back, and Tells the Tale
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.  In every line of work, there are family businesses. But no business is more defined by dynasties and nepotism than evangelical preaching. Lyman Beecher, Bob Jones, Billy Graham, Oral Roberts, Robert H. Schuller, Jim Bakker: all had sons who became ministers.

title: How the Google Deal Hampers Motorola
description: I previously pointed out some reasons why Google may have been O.K. with paying a large reverse termination fee in its deal to buy Motorola Mobility for $12.5 billion.

title: Death Toll at Belgian Music Festival Rises
description: The death toll at the Pukkelpop music festival in Belgium, where heavy winds toppled three stages on Thursday, has risen to five, and the number counted as injured has nearly doubled to 140, Belgian officials said on Friday.

title: Le Shack
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#869", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Barclays Backs H.P.s Deal With a Big Loan
description: While Hewlett-Packards $11.7 billion deal for Autonomy was put together in part by two boutique investment banks, Barclays Capital has shown five billion reasons why it was involved.

title: Videos Capture Chinas Brawling Side
description: As my colleague Andrew Jacobs reports, Chinas senior leaders were not happy with the countrys most popular mens basketball team  whose players are drawn from the army  after a brawl Thursday night with a visiting team from Georgetown University.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Culture Pilgrims in Santiago de Compostela
description: ON a cloudy June afternoon after midday Mass in the ornate granite cathedral in the Spanish city of Santiago de Compostela, the adjacent plaza heaved with tourists, many toting walking sticks and bulging backpacks. For centuries, self-proclaimed pilgrims have trekked dozens and sometimes hundreds of miles to get here, having traveled the ancient Christian pilgrimage routes collectively known as the Camino de Santiago, or Way of St. James, as it is believed that the cathedral houses the remains of the apostle St. James.

title: N.F.L.-N.C.A.A. Merger, Hypocrisy Division
description: The fiasco that is college sports certainly cries out for someone to be in charge. If the scandal now enveloping Miami has taught us anything, its that the N.C.A.A. long ago lost any hint of control over this roost and its rule book would go to better use lining hamster cages. But no one person is going to stand in front of that money train and do anything but get flattened. Ethics? Morals? Level playing field? Good luck with that.

title: Inspiring Reluctant Readers
description: The best-selling authors James Patterson and Rick Riordan talk about the challenge of encouraging children, particularly boys, to love reading.

title: Boys and Reading: Is There Any Hope?
description: At an American Library Association conference in 2007, HarperCollins dressed five of its male young adult authors in blue baseball jerseys with our names on the back and sent us up to bat in a panel entitled In the Clubhouse. We were meant to demystify to the overwhelmingly female audience the testosterone code that would get teenage boys reading. Whereas boys used to lag behind girls in reading in the early grades, statistics show, they soon caught up. Not anymore.

title: The Squashes of Summer
description: The Recipes for Health columnist, Martha Rose Shulman, asked Facebook followers what kind of recipes they wanted to see. Dishes using zucchini and other summer squashes led the list  no surprise at this time of year. Here are five light and flavorful ways to prepare summer squash.

title: Summer Scouting
description: Instead of Groundhog Day, the Bill Murray movie, we now have Fashions Night Out. It never ends. On Sept. 8, designers will be at their posts, just as they were this time last year, and you can go through the madness all over again. This is truly the age of reiteration.

title: Newborn Girl Abandoned in Box on Queens Street
description: Updated, 5:27 p.m. | A newborn girl with her umbilical cord still attached, wrapped in a towel and placed in a box, was left outside a house on a side street in Astoria, Queens, on Friday morning, the authorities said.

title: After Brawl, China Irked by Its Basketball Team
description: BEIJING  The Chinese Communist Party has long cherished competitive sports as a conduit for geopolitical dtente. For decades, the slogan Friendship First, Competition Second, guided the nations approach to international sporting events. It was dueling table tennis teams, after all, that 40 years ago paved the way for the historic thaw in relations with the United States.

title: Nightie Aphrodites
description: How to pull off a heartbreakingly romantic evening gown? Just use your head. Solange Knowles, Corinne Bailey Rae, Juno Temple and Hlene and Clia Faussart, a k a Les Nubians, pair afros with evening dresses. Photographs by Alice OMalley.

title: Spains City of Culture
description: Santiago de Compostela is proudly crowing about a new and decidedly modern draw: a spectacular structure called the City of Culture of Galicia.

title: Amy Waldman's "The Submission"; Holland Cotter on the Los Angeles art scene in the 1960's; back-to-school reading; best-seller news
description: This week: a conversation with Amy Waldman about her 9/11 themed novel, "The Submission"; and the Times's Pulitzer Prize-winning art critic, Holland Cotter, discusses the Los Angeles art scene in the 1960's. For our back-to-school issue, we have a discussion with James Patterson and Rick Riordan about young reluctant readers; Patricia Cohen with interesting new data on public education; and Jennifer Schuessler on first read programs for incoming college freshmen. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: More Sticks and Stones
description: I couldnt help noticing a Huffington Post item about Kim Kardashians wedding, and comments from readers professing to be appalled that she has reportedly asked her guests to wear black or white. Actually, thinking how nothing seems far-fetched these days, some of the comments are pretty funny in the abstract. Here are two: Who does she think she is, asking the guest (sic) to dress a certain way? The Queen of England? and Can you imagine waking up everyday thinking the world revolves around YOU?

title: Belarus Suspends Pact to Give Up Enriched Uranium
description: MOSCOW  Belarus said Friday that it would suspend an agreement to give up its supply of highly enriched uranium, torpedoing, at least temporarily, what was considered a significant victory by the Obama administration in curtailing the spread of dangerous nuclear material.

title: Cadillac Ciel Concept: A Hybrid Flagship Docks at Pebble Beach
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  Cadillac retreated to the Scrabble letter pile for its new Ciel concept, a four-door, four-seat convertible unveiled Thursday evening on the grounds of this weekends Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: Your Voice Mail May Be Even Less Secure Than You Thought
description: For all of the palace intrigue recently about who in Rupert Murdochs News Corporation kingdom knew what about phone hacking when, one fundamental question about the scandal has gone mostly unanswered:

title: What About the Reluctant Reader?
description: This week the Book Review introduces a Back to School issue, with nine pages dedicated to the latest books being published for children, many of them eagerly anticipated by parents and children. But what about those children who arent so eager to start reading?

title: Fracking Oversight Raises Staffing Questions
description: A panel charged with advising New York officials on regulating a controversial form of natural gas extraction known as hydrofracking will first examine whether the state government has enough staff members to properly monitor and enforce new drilling regulations.

title: Big Deal | Selling at $23 Million, and Taking a Loss
description: A five-story, 12,000-square-foot town house on the East Side, which sold for $23 million after more than two years of being on and off the market, was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.

title: There Ought to Be a Law
description: Back in April the city was rocked by a scandal so scandalous that New Yorkers everywhere emitted a simultaneous Whaaa? I didnt even know that was illegal. Numerous police officers, it appears, may have been fixing traffic tickets for friends, relatives, cronies, friends of relatives cronies.

title: Clinical Trials Neglect the Elderly
description: The randomized clinical trial, long the gold standard of medical research, supposedly provides the most reliable data regarding which drugs, devices and procedures prove effective on real patients and which dont. But when the people enrolled in the trial are quite different from those who will actually use the drug or device or undergo the procedure, the data are far less reliable.

title: Caller ID Spoofing and Your Privacy
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I look at the question of whether United States consumers are vulnerable to the sort of phone shenanigans that tabloid reporters in Britain seem to have been engaged in for some time.

title: Letter From an Inmate
description: A letter sent to Michael Wilson by Dempsey Hawkins from Mount McGregor Correctional Facility, July 31, 2011.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: The latest installment of Hey, Mr. Critic! can be found here, with Sam Siftons restaurant recommendations for almost-newlyweds, the tennis-obsessed and a vegetarian reader on a gluten-free diet. Send your questions to dinejournal@nytimes.com, or find Sam on Twitter: @samsifton.

title: The Hidden Dangers In Safe Havens
description: AS Europes debt troubles intensified earlier this month and United States debt was downgraded, many people rushed into gold and Treasury securities as a safe haven. It was the latest sign that in uncertain times, investors act in ways that can hurt them in the long run.

title: Lexus GS 350 Secures Prime Real Estate for Pebble Beach Debut
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  Lexus, Toyotas luxury arm, is one of many brands here hoping to stir the wealthys interest in new products. The automaker certainly picked a rarified patch of green for the global debut of the 2013 Lexus GS 350 on Thursday afternoon: the grounds to be used for the weekends Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: The Risk of Gold and Treasury Bills Right Now
description: This weekends Wealth Matters column opens with a bold statement about people who have sold stocks and are buying gold or United States Treasury bonds.

title: Looks Illustrated
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#29", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Exploring the 15-Year Loan
description: WHEN deciding to refinance a home, some people look first at the new monthly mortgage payment and the money they might save, while others focus on the interest rate.

title: Socialist Hellhole Blogging
description: Every time I read someone talking about the collapsing welfare states of Europe, I have this urge to take that person on a forced walking tour of Stockholm. If you believed what the right says, a country with Swedens level of both taxes and social benefits should be a wasteland. Strange to say, thats not what it looks like, to say the least.

title: On Project Runway, Judges Steal the Show
description: Project Runway has taken a while to regain its stride ever since moving from Bravo to Lifetime in 2009. The initial decision to move the show to Los Angeles, the odd mix of contestants, even the eventual winners the last couple of years have all contributed to a slightly off-kilter viewing experience.

title: Can You Get There From Here?
description: ACCESS to public transportation is vital in New York City. But for those considering a move to the city  or even just to a new neighborhood  proximity to a subway station is only the first step in determining how easy it will be to get around. You will also need to know how frequently and reliably a subway runs, and whether youll be plagued by weekend service interruptions or reroutings.

title: What Annoying Behavior Should Be Banned in New York?
description: What New York City needs is more offenses for which people can be fined, writes City Critic Neil Genzlinger in this weeks Metropolitan section.

title: Injured Clijsters Withdraws From U.S. Open
description: Kim Clijsters, winner of the past two United States Open titles, has withdrawn from this years tournament because of an abdominal strain.

title: Shakespeare and Austen, Updated
description: One of the manifold ways our culture fails girls is in its refusal to honor or even acknowledge their deep interest in romance. A girls world is drenched in romance, and the process by which she negotiates that deep emotional need with the countervailing force of sexuality  with all its power, pleasure and danger  is the great work of female adolescence. But our present moment is terrible for anyone who is thoughtful or private or introspective, and thus terrible for girls. The impossible music, the normalization of hard-core pornography, the explicitly sexual nature of even supposedly family friendly entertainment  everything about modern life mocks the romantic impulse.

title: Falling for Hamlet
description: PROLOGUE

title: In New York, a Sprinkling of Higher Prices
description: BEFORE the financial markets most recent drubbing, New York Citys real estate prices had been flat for the better part of a year. But over the spring and summer, prices in certain pockets of property sprinkled around Manhattan and Brooklyn had rebounded to or beyond pre-recession levels.

title: After Four Decades, Finishing a Planned City
description: THE last two empty parcels at Battery Park City have been developed, more than four decades after this innovative neighborhood-from-scratch, built on fill from the original World Trade Center site, was proposed.

title: U.S. to Offer Oil Leases in the Gulf
description: WASHINGTON  Making good on a promise, the Interior Department announced Friday that it had scheduled its first sale of offshore oil leases in the Gulf of Mexico since the Deepwater Horizon disaster last year. But it is changing some of the rules to ensure that leased parcels are actually drilled and not hoarded.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Dystopia Gardens
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festivals close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Ice cream fans have a trio of events to choose from this weekend. On Sunday, the New Amsterdam Market, 100 Peck Slip (South Street), at South Street Seaport will hold an Ice Cream Sunday benefit. At least 10 pastry chefs and ice cream makers are scheduled to take part, and each will offer up to four flavors. A $35 entry fee pays for early admission, which begins at noon. Otherwise, its $25 to sample the ice cream, from miniature sugar cones, at 1 p.m. Theres also an ice cream crawl on Sunday that begins at 3 p.m. in Chelsea Market, 425 West 15th Street (Ninth Avenue). The group will meet inside the market by Peoples Pops and make stops at LArte del Gelato and more. Expect to spend $15 to $25. At Rosa Mexicano Union Square, 9 East 18th Street (between Fifth Avenue and Broadway), there will be a cooking demonstration at 10 a.m. on Saturday as part of the Rosa Mexicano Ice Cream Festival through Sept. 4. Guests will learn how to create flavors like Mexican corn truffle ice cream, during the demo, which is $30 per person or $15 for children and includes a three-course lunch afterward. Call (212) 397-0666 ext. 27 to register.

title: Giants Umenyiora Undergoes Surgery, Will Miss 3-4 Weeks
description: 10:35 p.m. | Updated EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Just as it appeared that Osi Umenyioras tribulations had come to an end, his preseason took another unexpected turn when the Giants announced that he had arthroscopic knee surgery Friday morning and was expected to miss three to four weeks.

title: A Long Peace Is Threatened in Israel Attack
description: CAIRO  A cross-border terrorist attack and an Israeli retaliation that left three Egyptian officers dead are threatening to undermine a decades-old cold peace between the two countries that had already begun to fray since the revolution that ousted President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

title: New Fighting Outside Tripoli as Foreigners Seek an Exit
description: ZAWIYAH, Libya  Rebel soldiers fought running street battles on Friday with troops loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in the heart of this strategically important city, just a half-hours drive from the Libyan capital of Tripoli, and there were new signs that worried foreigners in Tripoli were urgently trying to leave.

title: Spicy Chicken Liver Salad? How Un-French of You
description: FOOD in a traditional bistro in France  there are still some left  is anything but fancy, but can be undeniably satisfying. The dishes are simple, the wine is agreeable, the pace is brisk, and everyone is happy. All the classics are there. Steak tartare. Leeks vinaigrette. Choucroute with garlicky sausage. Thick slices of pt. Crisp duck leg confit and pan-fried potatoes. And its all good. At least in my dream bistro or in my bistro fantasies.

title: Garam Masala: Many Recipes, and Even More Uses
description: Garam masala, a warm and pungent spice mixture with a lot of fragrance, makes its way into many an Indian dish, but everyone makes it a little differently.

title: Some Porsche Purists Like It Hot, and Theyre Sweating to Prove It
description: TESTED 2012 Porsche Cayman R

title: When Art Happened to L.A.
description: For contemporary art in the 1950s and 60s, there was New York and that was it. So the old story goes. But its wrong. If theres one thing that recent globally minded art history has taught us, its that after World War II, new art, and lots of it, was turning up in cities everywhere. Los Angeles was one, and in the late 50s, almost to its own surprise, it had a big art moment. That moment, which lasted about a decade, is the subject of Rebels in Paradise: The Los Angeles Art Scene and the 1960s, by Hunter Drohojowska-Philp. The book has much to recommend it: its fast-paced, well researched, accessibly anecdotal. But as an account of a still understudied episode in American postwar culture, its oddly lopsided. It corrects one imbalance  the only in New York idea  but ignores others.

title: Rebels in Paradise
description: Chapter One

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE FAMILY FANG  By Kevin Wilson  Ecco/HarperCollins, $23.99.

title: Nasty School and Other Poems
description: NASTY SCHOOL

title: Editors Choice
description: HOUSE OF HOLES: A Book of Raunch,  by Nicholson Baker (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Bakers hilarious, extremely dirty novel is an episodic assortment of fantasies  part Platos Retreat, part Fantasy Island  that celebrate desire, frailty and the comedy of life.

title: Up Front: Shel Silverstein
description: Shel Silverstein  art school dropout, Playboy magazine cartoonist, composer of Johnny Cashs Boy Named Sue, poet responsible for Homework Machine and the line  I cannot go to school today, / Said little Peggy Ann McKay  may not be the first person most parents think of as an authority on education.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MEMORY PALACE,  by Mira Bartok (Free Press, $15.) At the center of this unsparing memoir is Bartoks schizophrenic mother: The Memory Palace begins in the final days of her mothers life, when Bartok, an artist and the author of numerous childrens books, learns that the woman she has not seen in 17 years is dying.

title: Consider the Weed
description: To the Editor:

title: Scenes From a Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Guided by Greed
description: To the Editor:

title: A Novel of Grief, Memorials and a Muslim Architect in Post-9/11 America
description: When, in December 2009, The New York Times first reported plans for a Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan, there was little controversy. Only subsequently, as a result of protests organized by groups like the Freedom Defense Initiative and Stop Islamization of America, did the project become the subject of passionate debate. It was they who named the community center the ground zero mosque. In the months that followed, other vociferous opponents of the project emerged, among them not only conservative politicians like Newt Gingrich and some of the families of victims of 9/11, but also a number of Muslim leaders, who felt that the choice of site was insensitive and would complicate Muslim relations with the broader community. The controversy gave rise to a media frenzy that reached its height in the late summer of 2010. One imagines that the former New York Times journalist Amy Waldman heard these arguments with a combination of recognition and, perhaps, faint dismay: the general topic of her as yet unpublished first novel, The Submission, was proving disturbingly prescient. Her carefully imagined fiction was in the process of becoming fact.

title: Last Lullaby for My Son
description: I was afraid Id hurt him. Before he was born, I was afraid that I would hurt my son, Kelle Groom writes of her infant child in her memoir, I Wore the Ocean in the Shape of a Girl. For decades, Groom did not ask for details about Tommy, the son shed had at age 19, whom shed given up to her aunt and uncle to raise, and who died from leukemia at 14 months.

title: Are All of Our Leaders Mad?
description: After examining the psychological histories of a few living leaders and a whole little power necropolis, Nassir Ghaemi, director of the Mood Disorders Program at Tufts University Medical Center, is ready to proclaim a link between madness and achievement that is usually reserved for poets, not prime ministers: Depression makes leaders more realistic and empathic, and mania makes them more creative and resilient. It may be fine to like Ike during periods of smooth sailing, but Lincoln and a little lunacy are the ticket when seas get rough: For abnormal challenges, Ghaemi insists, abnormal leaders are needed. The text makes only one reference to the current president, warning us that while  No drama Obama might be considered the epitome of mental health, we must remember that psychological moderation is not the prescription for greatness.

title: A Tale of a Highly Articulate Cuckold
description: Anyone reading William Giraldis first novel, Busy Monsters, will be struck by its narrative voice. So lets start there, with some excerpts. Heres the narrator on the fatigue of his labors: So much to celebrate, and me standing there a spiritual syphilitic, mangled mental-wise from too much tumble.

title: Seeds, Germs and Slaves
description: Theres a chain of events in this best of all possible worlds, Dr. Pangloss says at the end of Voltaires Candide. If you hadnt been caught up in the Inquisition, or walked across America . . . you would not be here eating candied fruit and pistachio nuts.

title: Middle School Mischief
description: Wouldnt it be nice if Diary of a Sweet-Natured Kid were the best-selling young adult book of the last couple of years? Instead, weve got this horrible little human being, Greg Heffley, protagonist of Diary of a Wimpy Kid. Not really wimpy, hes better described as a deceitful, self-absorbed, scheming, arrogant, callous kid.

title: Being the New Kid Isnt Easy
description: Will you be my friend? With the possible exception of Does this look infected?, there is no more off-putting question. Friends are like handkerchiefs: everybody needs them, but the sight of someone asking for one is so mortifyingly vulnerable that you want to avert your eyes from the whole mess. As with handkerchiefs, its probably best not to look at friendship too closely, at least until youve had it around for a while. We stick with our friends for an entanglement of reasons, and three new picture books, while ostensibly feel-good tales about making friends, turn out to be much closer to the complicated and murky truth than one might guess from their cheery covers. Also, two of the books have splendid artwork.

title: Middle School Angst
description: Over the course of his amazingly prolific and varied writing career, James Howe, perhaps best known for his Bunnicula vampire rabbit series, has established himself as a beloved and elegant voice in childrens literature. The first two of his Misfits books  2001s The Misfits and 2005s Totally Joe  were masterworks of middle school angst, powerful in their ability to impart lessons about difference and empathy in highly readable stories that Disney-jaded preteens could both enjoy and relate to.

title: Tales of a Fourth-Grade Something
description: At a certain point in our lives something terrific happens  the stops and starts of reading begin to flow and we are able to turn our complete attention to the text itself. For many children at this stage, the familiar rules: they take particular pleasure in reading about someone in a school with routines and structures not unlike their own and enjoy meeting, in a series, their beloved characters again and again. Unconventionally designed books appeal as well  say an ersatz journal filled with just the sorts of notes and sketches the young reader could imagine making herself. Back in 1995, Marissa Moss successfully used all three of these elements in Amelias Notebook. Now, 23 books later, as her title character makes her way through middle school, she has a series for younger readers, Daphnes Diary of Daily Disasters.

title: Divided by Date Rape
description: In the classic star-crossed romance, a crime forces a choice between youthful passion and family loyalty. For Romeo and Juliet, its the murder of Mercutio; for Tony and Maria, its the knife fight between Sharks and Jets. This is how tentative adolescent love turns into high drama. Parents dont object to boyfriends or girlfriends for being taciturn or tattooed. They object because of a blood feud.

title: Elephants in the Room
description: Few creatures can compete with elephants when it comes to being both magnificent and ungainly, but human children, if were being honest with ourselves, come close. This sense of distant kinship, plus the fact that trunks are the coolest appendages this side of opposable thumbs, may be why elephants have been a staple of childrens literature since the days of Rudyard Kipling and Jean de Brunhoff. True, theyre not quite so numerous on the bookshelf as bunnies, mice and ducklings, but they outnumber squids by a long shot, and, what with their tree-stump legs, bulky bodies, sail-like ears and those sinuous trunks, elephants are surely more fun for illustrators to draw than just about anything, aside from explosions. So elephants: bring em on!

title: Shy, Bookish and Beastly Creatures
description: For young children, making that first friend bears all the weight and tension that wooing a potential sweetheart does for 17-year-olds. And if youre shy, bookish or beastly, the task is all the more awkward, as three delightful picture book debuts make expressively and tenderly clear.

title: Chanda Ouk and Matthew Wolf
description: LOWELL, Mass., represented two very different things to the teenagers Matthew Wolf and Chanda Ouk. But for both, it became a place for hope, and eventually love, to blossom.

title: Childrens Bookshelf: Back to School
description: Picture books about school and imaginative play.

title: Bookshelf: Back to School
description: KINDERGATORS: HANDS OFF, HARRY!  Written and illustrated by Rosemary Wells 40 pp. Katherine Tegen/HarperCollins. $14.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: Next Up: W.P.S. Championship Game
description: Ive been part of an underdog team thats defied the odds.

title: Big Three Increase Their Financial Footprint on Woodward Dream Cruise
description: DETROIT  After a lengthy spell in the doldrums, and encouraged by improved sales, domestic carmakers are stepping up involvement in the Woodward Dream Cruise, suburban Detroits annual paean to all things automotive.

title: Tweet Birds of Youth
description: Tweets from TahrirThe New York artist Michael Waughs T features, at a glance, three gorgeous, menacing eagles intertwined to form the rather gothic moniker of this magazine. What is less apparent is that every line, every feathery stroke of Waughs pen and ink drawing, contains words, and specifically the words that were tweeted from Tahrir Square last February, which preceded the fall of Hosni Mubarak and his government. Scroll across the work above and glimpse an account of a revolution in progress.

title: Adolescent Health | Nutrition, Healthy Weight and Eating Disorders
description: To wrap up Adolescent Health Week, here is our collection of materials on nutrition, healthy weight and eating disorders, including coverage of Michelle Obamas antichildhood obesity initiative and growing criticism of many school lunch programs.

title: F.T.C. Says It Will Not Investigate Ashton Kutcher
description: It looks like Ashton Kutcher is in the clear.

title: Tomato Water (Remember That?) Charms Once Again
description: IN the 1990s, chefs around the country seemed mesmerized by an intense translucent liquid, a nectar of the vegetable garden: tomato water. Brightly flavored yet almost invisible, it was the clear essence of summer in spoonable form.

title: H.G.H. Testing in N.F.L. Not in Place, Union Says
description: Two weeks after the N.F.L. announced that, starting this season, every player would be tested for human growth hormone at least once a year, and possibly many more times, its players union says there may be no H.G.H. testing at all.

title: An Inmates Letter Recalls a Certain Summer
description: I was in London for a moment, the letter began. Just long enough to learn how to walk and talk and gather a few memories before leaving for Staten Island, where I grew up. Grew up too fast in some respects but not fast enough to outgrow the adolescent flaws and shortcomings of character to which I would steadily succumb in a bad way.

title: Confidence in Obama, and in the Economy, Declines
description: Markets go up and down, the White House press secretary Jay Carney noted this month. So do presidential approval ratings. But the trendline for President Obama has been poor.

title: In Quiet End to Career, Drury Retires From N.H.L.
description: Chris Drury, the low-key and widely admired former captain of the Rangers, retired Friday, less than two months after agreeing to a buyout from the team, and one day before he turned 35.

title: Benzs Biturbo V-8s: Red-Hot and Greener
description: IN recent decades, luxury automakers in particular have been criticized  and in some cases, heavily fined  for obsessing over power at the expense of fuel economy.

title: Beauty Contestants With Curves, Talent and German Accents
description: ONE carmaker after another is proposing an answer to a question: how do you show off lavish wheels without looking like, well, a show-off?

title: Caucus Video: Perry on the Campaign Trail; Presidential Vacations
description: Jeff Zeleny on the opening week of Rick Perrys campaign, and a report from Marthas Vineyard on President Obamas working vacation.

title: The Caucus | Rick Perry's Up & Down Week
description: Aug. 19, 2011 - Jeff Zeleny on Rick Perrys opening week of the campaign, and a report from Marthas Vineyard on President Obama's working vacation.

title: Another Luxury Hotel Perk: A Car at Your Disposal
description: Free chocolates on the pillow are nice, but some luxury hotels are upping the ante with fancy cars for guests to use at no charge. Misty Ewing, the director of public relations for Virtuoso, a luxury travel network, said it was a huge convenience for guests and helps in building traveler loyalty.

title: Doctors, Tired and Well Rested, Weigh In
description: Many doctors wrote into the comments section for our article on doctor training hours.

title: Why Not Ryan?
description: Earlier this week I promised a post explaining why I think Chris Christie would make a better late-entering challenger in the Republican field than Paul Ryan. Since then the chatter surrounding a Ryan run has increased, but at the same time a number of writers have highlighted obvious difficulties with his potential candidacy. (See Byron York, Philip Klein, Allahpundit, Daniel Larison, Jim Antle and Ed Kilgore, among others.) Rather than recapitulating all of their points, I just want to draw three Christie-Ryan contrasts.

title: Husband Admits He Set Up Killing of Wife in Street, the Police Say
description: BOONTON, N.J.  After his wife had been shot to death on the street and he had been wounded, Kashif Parvaiz told the police here in her quiet hometown in New Jersey that three men had accosted them and, before opening fire, called them a name that is offensive to Muslims in America: Terrorist.

title: A Paradise for Plant Diversity
description: Paola Pedraza, assistant curator of the Institute of Systematic Botany at the New York Botanical Garden, writes about her recent expedition to catalog the flora of Las Orqudeas National Park, Colombia.

title: Bossy Pants
description: Whether two-tone, textured or regimentally striped, the new trouser dictates the look.

title: A Prime-Time True-Crime Spree
description: MURDER is in retreat in the United States, down from a high of more than 24,000 killings in 1991 to just over 15,000 last year.

title: A Confection of Pop, and Newport Chops
description: Sam Yahel

title: It Happened One Night at the Cheetah
description: EARLY in the salsa documentary Our Latin Thing (Nuestra Cosa), a 40th anniversary version of which will be released Tuesday, the master percussionist Ray Barretto is asked what he wants the movie to accomplish. He responds that he hopes it will become a vehicle through which our Latin music and culture goes out all over the world.

title: Chevrolet Small-Block V-8: the Little Engine That Still Can
description: Chevrolet, marking its 100th anniversary this week with its sponsorship of metro Detroits Woodward Dream Cruise, announced on Thursday that it would build the 100 millionth version of its small-block V-8 engine this year.

title: Distracted at the Concert Hall
description: James Oestreich, a critic for The New York Times, set out last month to review a concert at Lincoln Center featuring the works of Mozart and Stravinsky. But Mr. Oestreich found himself more focused on the man seated directly behind him, who was connected to an oxygen cart or similar medical device that emitted what he called a steady  and apparently disruptive  ticking sound.

title: The 30-Minute Interview | Andrew Barrocas
description: Mr. Barrocas, 32, is the chief executive of the brokerage firm MNS, formerly known as TDG/Tregny, after the 2009 merger of the Developers Group and the Real Estate Group New York. The company, which changed its name last spring, provides in-house marketing for its residential listings, including new developments like One Brooklyn Bridge Park and the Edge in Williamsburg .

title: Q & A
description: A Co-op Neighbor Becomes Abusive

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 19
description: The day in sports included hot air ballooning in Poland, kayaking in Hungary and BMX racing in London.

title: Trader in Insider Case Speaks Out Again
description: Most people accused of insider trading hunker down and let their lawyers do the talking.

title: Copyright Lawsuit Against Ryan McGinley Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a copyright lawsuit filed against the photographer Ryan McGinley by another photographer who claimed that he relied too heavily on her work for his inspiration.

title: Clip: 'Circumstance'
description: A scene from the film "Circumstance," about teenage women coming of age in Tehran.

title: Green Respite for a Bustling Delhi Suburb
description: Amid the high-rise office buildings, towering apartment complexes and sprawling construction sites, green pockets are hard to find in Gurgaon, a New Delhi suburb that is home to the back-office operations of some of the worlds biggest companies. So the local government, private companies and citizens have banded together to plant a million trees.

title: Questioning the Dogma of Tax Rates
description: Warren Buffett pays a lower tax rate than his secretary and the 19 other people who work in his office. He pays a much lower rate than I do, and, I suspect, lower than nearly everyone reading this column. So, no doubt, do a long list of American billionaires, including Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone and the hedge fund king John Paulson.

title: Inside the List
description: ODD COUPLES: Dog books have long been a staple of the best-seller list. But has the world ever seen as probing a work of zoological investigative reporting as Unlikely Friendships: 47 Remarkable Stories From the Animal Kingdom? Jennifer S. Hollands irresistible volume, No. 7 in its sixth week on the paperback nonfiction list, features heartwarming stories of interspecies love and adorable photographs that are heart-stopping in more than one sense. Everything seems copacetic between the nearsighted deer and the black poodle shown canoodling on a bed in Canal Fulton, Ohio, but one wonders about the long-term stability of the relationship between the polar bear and the sled dog shown cavorting in the Canadian Arctic, not to mention the lioness and baby oryx shown strolling together in Kenyas Samburu National Reserve.

title: Living and Loving Underground in Iran
description: SHORTLY before she began shooting the film Circumstance, her first experience in front of a camera, the law student and soon-to-be actress Sarah Kazemy flew from her home in France to visit relatives in Iran. She anticipated that the movie, which focuses on the lesbian romance of two Tehran teenagers rebelling against a puritanical Islamic theocracy, would make it difficult for her to return there for the foreseeable future, and she wanted to say her farewells to people and a country that she loves.

title: Banks Ease Stance on Short Sales
description: STANDING by while her mother was evicted from her home in Tinton Falls for the few thousand dollars she owed in mortgage payments in the 1990s had a big influence on Kim Hale and her career choices. A new nursing school graduate at the time, Ms. Hale said she had had no idea how to help her mother, who was too embarrassed to reach out to anyone.

title: Reports: New Meadowlands Soon to Be MetLife Stadium
description: New Meadowlands Stadium will be renamed for MetLife, the insurance company, possibly as early as next week. The Jets and Giants, who have been without the income from a naming rights deal, would split $17 million to $20 million annually over 20 years, according to published reports.

title: New Mini Coupe Contends With a $52,000 Distraction at Pebble Beach
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  A limited-edition Mini Cooper model, packed with luxury appointments usually reserved for Rolls-Royce cars, siphoned some of the excitement from the North American debut of the Mini Coupe.

title: Market Boos for Hewlett Transformation
description: If Thursday was Day 1 of the transformation of Hewlett-Packard, Day 2 was something much less inspiring.

title: Living In | Roseland, N.J.
description: A place that still feels a lot like a farm town, Roseland is affordable, especially for Essex County.

title: Streaming Videos Emerging Bounty
description: AT this point in its evolution streaming video can still feel like your neighborhood VHS rental shop, circa 1985.

title: Where the Taxes Are Below Average
description: CLAUDIA REIS and her husband, Scott Gorman, loved the comforts and convenience of condo living in Springfield, in Union County. But that changed somewhat when the couple, lawyers who commute to Morristown (her) and Hackensack (him), had their first child three years ago. They decided they needed a house  and a town  in which a family could nestle.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Ghost Stories
description: The manga list has the only new arrival this week and it is a three-in-one edition of Bleach, a series about Ichigo Kurosaki, who sees dead people and must usher them safely into the afterlife. This reprint edition collects three volumes of the regular manga series and arrives at No. 7. In the latest twist, Mr. Kurosaki must cope with a reality show that features live exorcisms.

title: Couch Potatoes
description: Siri Tollerd and Meghan Collison lounge around in a mix of two-tone, striped and textured trousers. A film by Julian De Zorzi.

title: Ecclestones Bluesy Gift to His Daughter
description: It is no coincidence that Bernie Ecclestone has hired Eric Clapton and the Black Eyed Peas to perform at the marriage of his daughter, Petra. Formula One racing  and auto racing in general  goes together with music, especially rock music. And in recent years, the Formula One paddock has played host to a lot of musicians who are also fans.

title: Ecclestones Bluesy Gift to His Daughter
description: It is no coincidence that Bernie Ecclestone has hired Eric Clapton and the Black Eyed Peas to perform at the marriage of his daughter, Petra. Formula One racing  and auto racing in general  goes together with music, especially rock music. And in recent years, the Formula One paddock has played host to a lot of musicians who are also fans.

title: For Some Banks, Prices Are Below 2008
description: Which banks dont you trust?

title: Letters: Keeping Data Fees Low
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column (Aug. 14): I recommend the Amazon Kindle 3Gs free international service. Not only can I download books (very nice to avoid carting around a dozen travel guides), but I also can check e-mail while riding the Hong Kong subway and find directions to my hotel, like when a New Delhi cabbie got lost. I think the only country I visited where Amazon didnt have coverage was Vietnam.

title: Lost in the Odyssey
description: SING to me of the man, O Muse  that cleverest of men, most favored by the gods, most frustrated by them, too. Sing to me of endlessly lost Odysseus, whose 10-year journey home, from the scorched and blood-stained plains of Troy to the Ionian island of Ithaca, was a decade of disaster. Sing to me of the Cyclops, the Sirens, Calypso and Circe, Scylla and Charybdis, of challenges confronted and conquered, destiny delayed and at long last achieved.

title: Design Ateliers Set Up Shop in Istanbul
description: ON an unseasonably warm day last winter the tap-tap of a jewelers hammer mingled with the clink of espresso cups in Istanbuls Galata neighborhood. Just a few strides from the neo-bohemians idling at tables outside the cafe-cum-boutique Mavra, the jewelry designer Janset Bilgin hunched over a workbench in her tiny atelier fusing silver, gray labradorite and strips of silk into a bold, chunky necklace.

title: Restaurant Report: Lous Food Bar in Denver
description: Denver residents who have been to one of the six restaurants and bars run by Frank Bonnano would most likely agree that the experience means good food and service to match. With Lous Food Bar, which opened late last year, the 43-year-old chef has broadened his repertory with an American rendition of a French bistro that has quickly helped to add more followers to his already loyal customer base.

title: Letters: The High Cost of Dialing Abroad
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column (Aug. 7): Whenever I go abroad, I take out my old, junky unlocked Motorola (which I got from a used-phone dealer in Queens) and buy a local SIM card for my destination, which is usually available via mail-order online (so that you have the phone number before you leave town). The result? Full use of a phone in Scotland for two weeks, including calls home: total price, around $30 ($20 for the card, plus a fill-up). The only time I ever had to buy a card at my destination was in Iceland, and there I got hooked up for around $45 total. If you need smartphone features, tote along a tablet that is Wi-Fi enabled and get your local instant maps and such that way.

title: Bivouacking in Oregons Back of Beyond
description: ON a chilly afternoon in late June, we stood contemplating our options in an icy Oregon rain that pricked our skin like needles. The canyons 300-foot-high walls of chocolate rhyolite had corralled the river into a pool too deep to wade through, too cold to swim in. Turning back would mean a grueling two-day retreat upstream. If we pushed ahead we could be out in a day. The decision was painful but clear: time to strip and swim.

title: Hotel Review: House Hotel Bosphorus, in Istanbul
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Step by Step, Hut by Hut in Colorado
description: DURING a recent trek along a mountain trail in the central Colorado Rockies, I found signs of those who had come before me. These werent fellow hikers, though, but soldiers. One patch near the trail was pitted with foxholes  scooped-out hollows, with one raised side, like a shield, the whole thing grown over with grass.

title: For the Closets of Kuala Lumpurs Style Obsessed
description: One of Kuala Lumpurs oldest suburbs, Bangsar is bringing hip boutiques in stylish malls to the area.

title: Oregons Outback
description: A four-day, 50-mile exploratory hike through Louse Canyon in southeastern Oregon.

title: In Odysseus Footsteps
description: Matt Grosss plan was to stumble in his footsteps and try to get a glimpse into his psyche as he tried and failed and tried again to reach Ithaca.

title: This Is Not Their Lives. Really. Its Not.
description: NED is a patsy, a goof, an innocent: a naf in a striped tank top and red Crocs, trying to navigate a world populated by tricksters. He loves his dog (a grinning golden retriever named Willie Nelson), cultivating organic vegetables, taking the occasional toke and playing charades with his mom and sisters. He is often seen scratching a cascade of wavy brown hair or reading a book about aromatherapy. He spent time in jail for handing a baggie of weed to a uniformed cop, but only after the officer said hed been having a hard week.

title: A Year Full of Weather Disasters and an Economic Toll to Match
description: The weather this year has not only been lousy, it has been as destructive in terms of economic loss as any on record.

title: In Rajasthans Push for Sterilization, Tata Nano Is Offered as an Incentive
description: The prospect of winning a Tata Nano city car is one of the incentives being used to attract Indians to a sterilization program in the Jhunjhunu district of Rajasthan, roughly 130 miles west of New Delhi.

title: Sexy Beast
description: The photographer Danko Steiner and his wife, the stylist Ana Steiner, dress their femme fatale, a k a Hanaa Abdesslem, in falls wildest all-over and to-the-floor furs.

title: From Convertibles to Rentals
description: Port Jefferson Station

title: Steps-From-Work Housing
description: WINDSOR

title: Raoul Ruiz  In Memoriam
description: The great filmmaker Raoul Ruiz, died this morning in Paris, at 70, from a lung infection. Just six short weeks ago, A.O. Scott interviewed him for this magazine, in anticipation of the release of his most recent film, Mysteries of Lisbon, which has been hailed by many critics as a masterpiece. Ruiz was in poor health for some time, following the discovery of a cancerous tumor in his liver. It is a testament to his spirit that he made time to sit and talk, ranging in his conversation across eras and disciplines, just as he does in his remarkable films. As Scott wrote:

title: The Caucus | Presidential Downtime
description: Aug. 19, 2011 - Mark Landler reports from Martha's Vineyard on President Obama's working vacation.

title: Lawyer Tied to Galleon Case Gets 3-Year Prison Term
description: The governments vast insider trading investigation of Raj Rajaratnam, the now-convicted billionaire investor, has ensnared prominent management consultants, corporate executives and hedge fund managers.

title: Nearing 1,000 Feet, 1 World Trade Center Joins the Skyline
description: From New Jersey especially, but even in mid-Manhattans canyons, 1 World Trade Center has asserted itself among the citys skyscrapers.

title: Adventure Beyond the South Pole
description: ON a stormy summer afternoon Ethan Stiefel sat in a noisy Mexican restaurant a few blocks south of Lincoln Center wearing a T-shirt with the words Wisconsin. We conserve.

title: Ackman Moves to Raise His Stake in J.C. Penney
description: William A. Ackman likes a good sale.

title: Sixth Death Is Reported in Indiana Stage Collapse
description: A 22-year-old Indiana woman died Friday of injuries sustained at the stage collapse at the Indiana State Fair last week, becoming the sixth person to die as a result of the accident.

title: 'Our Latin Thing (Nuestra Cosa)'
description: The Larry Harlow orchestra and Johnny Pacheco performed "Lamento de un Guajiro" in "Our Latin Thing (Nuestra Cosa)." A 40th anniversary edition of the 1971 documentary is being released on DVD.

title: Community Stands Strong to Block an Eviction
description: From inside Mary Lee Wards small and sparsely furnished living room in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, it sounded Friday as if a block party was in full swing in the street below. Cars and trucks honked their horns as they passed and almost 200 voices could be heard cheering and chanting.

title: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 19
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Detective in Phone Hacking Inquiry Is Arrested
description: LONDON  A Scotland Yard detective has been arrested on suspicion of leaking details about the phone hacking case to the news media, the police said on Friday.

title: Kin of Norway Victims Visit Scene of Shootings
description: OSLO  Relatives of victims killed on the Norwegian island of Utoya last month traveled to the site of the massacre for the first time on Friday, and with the aid of the police, clergy members and counselors, were able to walk through their loved ones last moments.

title: Big Deal | A SoHo Pad That Screams Bachelor
description: Brokers have to be quite careful when choosing the language in real estate listings.

title: A Smattering of This Weeks Food Links
description: Slow Food USA is issuing the $5 Challenge to take back the value meal. Want to participate? On Sept. 17, get together with family and friends and cook a slow food meal that costs no more than $5 per person. Ive been saying it for years: cooking, even with great ingredients, can be soooo cheap.

title: A Ratings Victory for Fox Football
description: Another nationally televised preseason National Football League game, another victory in the ratings. The nastiness caused by the owners lockout does not appear to have dimmed football fans ardor for the game, even for preseason games. The Fox telecast of the the Pittsburgh Steelers and Philadelphia Eagles exhibition game drew an estimated average of 8.7 million viewers in the 8 p.m. to 9 p.m. hour and 9.1 million during the the rest of prime time. The broadcast was up 45 percent compared to a game last year at this time, and helped Fox win a night when its stiffest competition was Big Brother on CBS (8 million total viewers) and both NBC and the CW were in repeats.

title: From Philadelphia, Slowdown News
description: DID the American economy hit the brakes this summer?

title: Aug. 21  27
description: Theater

title: Troubled Markets; A Bidding War for Internet Analysts; Declining Productivity; A Silver Lining for Stocks
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Graham Bowley and Floyd Norris on the troubled markets, Susanne Craig on a bidding war for Internet analysts, Tyler Cowen on declining productivity, and Paul Lim on a silver lining for stocks.

title: The Jam | Koudlam
description: The French symphonic composer Koudlam is known for his otherworldly electronic beats, pulled from classical music to tribal, creating a psychedelic something from the future, maybe even space. Here he offers up this weeks playlist, which ranges from David Bowie to the relatively unknown Japanese musical cult Geinoh Yamashirogumi, headed by the scientist Tsutomu Ohashi. Sean Hanratty was introduced to Koudlam, which is French slang for knife stab, through the very talented visual artist Cyprien Gaillard, with whom Koudlam regularly collaborates. (Gaillards Fight Club-esque film, Desniansky Raion, which Koudlam scored, was coveted at the 2007 Basel Art Fair.) I have been a huge fan of Koudlams for so many years, says Hanratty of Koudlam, who is constantly traveling around the world, a hobby that no doubt influences his music. His music has this immediate sensibility that is beautiful and detached.

title: TimesCast | August 19, 2011
description: An anticorruption activist in India is released from jail; Syrian forces fire on protesters; and China's press plays down a brawl between American and Chinese basketball teams.

title: Battle of the Swoopy Sedans
description: The Audi A7 and Mercedes-Benz CLS550 both deliver in terms of looks and performance. But one gives a little more.

title: The North Dakota Miracle
description: Forget the Texas Miracle. Lets instead take a look at North Dakota, which has the lowest unemployment rate and the fastest job growth rate in the country.

title: Norilsk Offers Share Buyback to End Long Dispute
description: MOSCOW  The management of Russias largest mining operator, Norilsk Nickel, offered on Friday to buy most of the shares held by one of the companys two feuding owners and thus resolve the dispute.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Aug. 19
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Deciding Whether to Have More Children
description: Melissa Fay Greene thought her family was complete. By 1994, she had four children, ranging in age from 2 to 13. She toyed with the idea of having a fifth, setting the arbitrary deadline of giving birth before she turned 43, which was 11 months away. Looking for answers, she spent some time in a therapists office, which she describes in this months Motherlode Book Club, No Biking in the House Without a Helmet:

title: Infiniti JX Crossover Concept: a Plush People Mover at Pebble Beach
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  Never mind the distracting one-off Testa Rossa prototypes and Shelby Cobras. For visitors to the Monterey peninsula intent on glimpsing the latest in seven-passenger crossover technology from Japan, Infiniti has brought just the thing: the JX concept.

title: Getting Noticed at the Fringe: As the Boat Approaches
description: ArtsBeat is taking a look at some of the most clever, mysterious and strikingly designed postcards created to draw attention among the nearly 200 productions in this years New York International Fringe Festival.

title: Tomato Water: What to Do With the Rest of the Tomatoes
description: After making tomato water, youll be left with a colander full of ruddy tomato flesh that is just begging not to be thrown out. I made mine into a quick tomato sauce. I smashed a few garlic cloves, bronzed them in some oil, then added the tomato solids and let it all bubble for about 15 minutes. Spooned over pasta with a few blobs of ricotta and torn basil leaves, it made a fine dinner.

title: Relationship Status: In a Stayover
description: THE GIST Stayovers are a new, low-commitment form of cohabitation among young adults.

title: Palin Keeps an Eye on Iowa
description: Sarah Palin has not forgotten about Iowa.

title: Downtown Regains Its Compass in the Sky
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response) {data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: '+ data +', cropType: 'blog480', appendTo: 'embeddedSlideshow', showHeadLine: 'false'}

title: Armed With PowerPoint and Monty Python Jokes, Saab Executive Addresses Owners Club
description: PARSIPPANY, N.J.  Timothy Colbeck, the Saab Cars of North America president and chief operating officer, was the keynote speaker at the sponsors dinner on Thursday for the Saab Club of North America owners convention, which runs through Sunday here at the Hilton hotel.

title: Gunshots Ring Out in Videos From Syria
description: Syrian activists said that at least 18 people were killed on another Friday of mass protests against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, as my colleague Nadi Bakri reports.

title: A Dead Sons Namesake, and the Road Not Taken
description: When Carmen Rivera bore a son 36 years ago and considered a name, she thought of a book she had recently read, Run Baby Run. It was the gangs-to-God story of Nicky Cruz, once a self-described warlord of a New York City gang who found religion in his early 20s and began evangelizing against crime.

title: After a Suicide, Bravo Tries for On-Time Start of Housewives Season
description: The Bravo network denied a report on Friday that it had decided to delay the start of the new season of The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills because of the recent suicide of a character in the show. Instead, the network said, it would re-edit the program in hopes of starting on schedule on Sept. 5.

title: At Pebble Beach, Hennessey Venom GT Sets Bait for Bugatti Veyrons
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  Attendees at last Junes Goodwood Festival of Speed in England were treated to the formal introduction of the Venom GT from Hennessey Performance, the tuning shop based outside Houston. The first unit of the $950,000 vehicles that sold to an American customer was delivered at the McCalls Motorworks Revival here on Wednesday.

title: Payrolls Increased in 31 States in July, but Jobless Rate Rose in 28, New Data Shows
description: Payrolls climbed in 31 states in July, led by New York and Texas, while the jobless rate increased in 28, painting a mixed employment picture for last month.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Gaza City, Pakistan, and Afghanistan.

title: Ford Unveils the Original Edsel at Pebble Beach
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  A memento from Ford Motor Company history, Edsel Fords personal Model 40 Special Speedster, was unveiled Friday at the Lodge at Pebble Beach after undergoing a three-year process to refurbish it to its original state.

title: Boy Crazy
description: Take the shirt off his back, but add your own feminine charms (and by that we mean earrings, brooches, and pendant necklaces). The photographer Hedi Slimane captures a stunning boy-meets-girl moment, convincing models Susannah Liguori, Margarita Kallas and Cecily Manson to (gasp) chop their hair.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Gaza City, Pakistan and Afghanistan.

title: Bronfman Takes Over As Chairman Of Warner
description: The Warner Music Group, which was sold to the holding company Access Industries in May for $3.3 billion, has made several changes to its board as it prepares a bid to buy EMI Music, which is being auctioned by Citigroup.

title: Book Review Podcast: Steven Brills Class Warfare
description: On the cover of this Sundays Book Review, Sara Mosle reviews Steven Brills new book, Class Warfare: Inside the Fight to Fix Americas Schools, in which he tackles education reform and mounts a zealous case against Americas teachers unions.

title: After H.P.s Rich Offer, Deal-Making Spotlight Swings to Data Analysis
description: Hewlett-Packard is paying big money to join the data analysis party. But one question now is whether anyone will try to spoil the festivities.

title: Federal Officials Reject Citys Plan to Ban Food Stamps for Soda
description: A version of this story with additional details can be found here

title: In a Race to Out-Rave, 5-Star Web Reviews Go for $5
description: In tens of millions of reviews on Web sites like Amazon.com, Citysearch, TripAdvisor and Yelp, new books are better than Tolstoy, restaurants are undiscovered gems and hotels surpass the Ritz.

title: Kathryn Hobbs, Anna Paskausky
description: Kathryn Virginia Hobbs, a daughter of Jane P. Hobbs and Robert J. Hobbs of Newton, Mass., was married Saturday to Anna Louise Paskausky, a daughter of Delores Paskausky of Fort Worth, and the late David F. Paskausky. Nellie Taylor, a friend of the couple, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the home of Ms. Hobbss parents.

title: Jean Kim and Aaron Lichtig
description: Jean Ji-Hyun Kim, a daughter of Young-Ja Kim of New Haven and Tae-Dong Kim of Seoul, South Korea, was married Saturday evening in New Haven to Aaron Robert Lichtig, a son of Christine A. Lichtig and Benson M. Lichtig of State College, Pa. The Rev. Callista S. Isabelle, a pastor of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America and an associate university chaplain at Yale, performed the ceremony at Battell Chapel on the universitys campus.

title: Christina Parajon, William Skinner Jr.
description: Christina Nicole Parajon and William Polk Skinner Jr. were married Saturday in the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Thomas J. Mullelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

description: Mary Elizabeth McAnaney Fay, a daughter of Joan M. Fay and David B. Fay of New York, was married Saturday to John Alexander Urquhart III, a son of Judy Urquhart and Alex Urquhart of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Charles L. Stapleton, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Conanicut Yacht Club in Jamestown, R.I.

title: Anna Schwab, Brian Matthews
description: Anna Adger Schwab, a daughter of Marjorie Moses Schwab and Nelson Schwab III, both of Charlotte, N.C., was married Saturday to Brian Whittlesey Matthews, the son of Jane Hanser Matthews of Richmond, Va., and L. White Matthews III of Ivy, Va. The Rev. Henry H. Edens, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the brides fathers vacation home in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

description: Miri Ilana Cypers, a daughter of Jackie Tavelman and Michael L. Cypers of Los Angeles, is to be married Sunday evening to David Jacob Rosenbaum, the son of Janine Rosenbaum and Rabbi Jay Rosenbaum of Mercer Island, Wash. The bridegrooms father is to officiate at Vibiana, an event space in Los Angeles.

title: Lauren Hunt, Blake Brogdon
description: Lauren Ashley Hunt and William Blake Brogdon were married Saturday in Fort Worth. The Rev. Dr. Alan L. Lobaugh, a Disciples of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at University Christian Church.

title: Kimia Mousavi, Terence Steed
description: Kimia Mousavi, a daughter of Rayhaneh Maleknia and Ahmad Mousavi of Harriman, N.Y., was married Thursday to Terence Patrick Steed, a son of Marion M. Steed and Patrick Steed of Eden, N.C. Thomas Hickey, a minister of Universal Ministries, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Grandview in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Carlisle Brigham, Anthony Champalimaud
description: Carlisle Vose Brigham was married Saturday to Anthony Lindley Champalimaud. The Rev. Edward B. Mulligan IV, an Episcopal priest and a chaplain of St. Georges School in Middletown, R.I., performed the ceremony in the schools chapel.

description: Tracey Elise Herman and Benjamin Moshe Shababo were married Saturday evening at Alder Manor, a 1912 mansion in Yonkers. Cantor Leslie Friedlander officiated.

title: Allison Johnson, Ehren Joseph
description: Allison Kathleen Johnson and Ehren Joseph were married Saturday at the vacation home of the brides family in Aspen, Colo. The couple performed the ceremony themselves under Colorados self-uniting marriage statute.

title: Kate Gulliver, Samuel Spirn
description: Kate Sarah Gulliver and Samuel Whiston Spirn were married Saturday at the summer home of the brides family on Peaks Island, in Portland, Me. The author Robert Greenfield, a friend of the brides family and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

description: Richard Patrick Palermo and Stephen Paul Mazza were married Saturday at Studio 450, an event space in New York. The Rev. Callie R. Janoff, a minister of the Church of Craft, officiated.

Steve Hollaway, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Harbor Church, where he is pastor, with the assistance of the Rev. Caroline Jinkins, a Presbyterian minister.

description: Dr. Emily Sarah Meltzer and Dr. Christopher Scott Jones were married Saturday at Tendenza, an event space in Philadelphia. The couple had a Quaker-style ceremony, under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute, that incorporated Jewish traditions.

description: Jill Amanda Renaud, a daughter of Jeanette Smith of Jackson, N.J., and Bob Renaud of Sayreville, N.J., was married Saturday to Edward Fu, a son of Janet Fou of Flushing, Queens, and Joe Z. Smith, in Jackson.

McLaughlin of Midland, Tex. Rabbi Dr. Arthur C. Blecher officiated at the Clifton Inn in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Robert C. White, a permanent deacon ordained by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington, took part in the ceremony.

title: Kendall Kulper, David Toniatti
description: Kendall Alexandra Kulper and David Michael Toniatti were married Saturday in St. Lucy Fillippini Chapel at Villa Walsh Academy, a middle and high school, in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Martin Rauscher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

description: Lesley Ann Peterson and Kevin Robert Johannsen were married Saturday at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford. The Rev. Michael J. Dolan, the Roman Catholic chaplain at the college, performed the ceremony.

title: Nadia Abji and Corry Rush
description: Nadia Minaz Abji and Corry Michael Rush were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Dr. Arnold I. Thomas, a minister of the United Church of Christ, led the nondenominational Christian ceremony at Riverside Church. The Rev. Adam Burt, an evangelical Christian minister, also took part.

title: Laura Turano, Jeffrey Hostettler
description: Laura Catherine Turano, a daughter of Karen L. Turano and Jerome D. Turano of Fort Myers, Fla., and Jeffrey Allan Hostettler, a son of Susan L. Hostettler and Harold S. Hostettler of Edinboro, Pa., were married Saturday. The Rev. Lisa A. Grant performed the ceremony at the Edinboro United Methodist Church, where she is the pastor.

title: Marlo Hunter and Ted Slevin
description: Marlo Taryn Hunter, the daughter of Nancy J. Hunter and Brian A. Hunter of Boston, was married Thursday evening to Ted Bennet Slevin, a son of Debbie J. Slevin and Jeffrey D. Slevin of Fort Lee, N.J. The bridegrooms father, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Manhattan Penthouse, an event space, in Manhattan. The ceremony included Jewish traditions.

title: Corinne LeTourneau, Jonathan Werbell
description: Corinne Marie LeTourneau and Jonathan Alexander Werbell were married Saturday at the Olympic Club Lakeside Clubhouse in San Francisco. Rabbi Yeshaia Charles Familant performed a ceremony that combined Jewish and Roman Catholic traditions. The Rev. Josh Favalora, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted.

title: Rachel Levine, Adam Rilander
description: Rachel Levine, a daughter of Elizabeth and Louis Levine of Thornhill, Ontario, was married Saturday evening to Adam Scott Rilander, the son of Nancy and Kenneth Rilander of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Robyn Epstein, Jason Kreiner
description: Dr. Robyn Jennifer Epstein and Dr. Jason Douglas Kreiner were married Saturday evening at the Carltun, an event space at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Jonathan L. Hecht officiated.

title: Tracy Nissenbaum, Adam Paley
description: Tracy Blair Nissenbaum and Adam James Paley were married Saturday evening by Cantor Wayne S. Siet at Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Aug. 19
description: More Photographs

title: Where Hearing the Parts Whirl Is the Point
description: Bienestan, which made its live debut at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, is a group with a strong concept and a clear point of view, but that doesnt mean that it lays itself out for comprehension. Early in its sold-out first set, an enveloping piece called Human Feel underscored that idea.

title: On the Merits of Parks and Bluefish
description: I owe an apology to regular readers  and comment contributors  on having Dot Earth go silent for the past week without hanging out a Gone Fishing (and camping and swimming) sign.

title: The Night Is Young
description: WHERE is the school bus to pick up all of these kids? a 27-year-old man was wondering aloud around 11:30 p.m., in a parking lot outside the nightclub SL East on Three Mile Harbor Road in East Hampton, N.Y. It was a hot Saturday night in July, and around him girls who appeared to be about 18 were huddled together, illuminated by a chandelier and the sickly hue of their smartphones.

title: 'West Memphis Three' Speak Out
description: After three men convicted of killing three 8-year-old boys in a notorious 1993 murder case were freed from jail on Friday, they spoke to the press.

title: The Week That Was, in Verse
description: Wall Streets bulls got mauled again, but there were other stories that may have brightened up the week for some. We recount a few in poetic form:

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: The Gift of Going

title: Now Online | T Womens Fashion Fall 2011
description: The fall season begins on a high note with our cover star: the jazz singer Esperanza Spalding. It continues with a trend report on the fully lined, feline eye, a look at street style in London, Cairo and Japan, and a sartorial tutorial on how to wear novelty knits, maxi coats and retro dresses. Along the way, The Selby finds Nordic foragers in Stockholm, Amy Ephron recalls her 1970s party days and Alex Kuczynski sits down with the actor Demian Bichir. In Nightie Aphrodites, Solange Knowles and Corinne Bailey Rae, among others, show off how to pair Afros with evening gowns. And dont forget to meet the model students in Beautiful Minds and the women who lost their hair for Hedi Slimane in Boy Crazy.
