Finally, to relax a bit  vicariously, at least  drop by the rustic retreat of the designers Isabel Marant and Jerome Dreyfuss in Le Shack. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Finally, Fish Topples Nadal
description: MASON, Ohio  Mardy Fish extended his arms and then wrapped them around his body, as if trying to embrace the whole stadium. The fans at Center Court had thrown their full-throated support behind him, and Fish channeled their energy Friday into a 6-3, 6-4 victory against Rafael Nadal in the quarterfinals of the Western & Southern Open.

title: All Deliberate Speed for Nuclear Reforms?
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is moving forward on recommendations made by an internal task force studying the Fukushima Daiichi triple meltdown. But it is not moving quite the way its chairman wanted.

title: Long Story Shortlist: Mommy and Me
description: Baby Makes Four, and Complications,by N.R. Kleinfeld (June 19, 2011)At the apartment in Brooklyn where George Russell spends four nights each week, he checked the clock: 7:09 p.m. Wasnt it 7:05 about 20 minutes ago? Never had time moved so slowly. Was the clock even working? Read more

title: Eight Is Probably Enough
description: Ryota Igarashi, who is in the final season of a two-year, $3 million contract, had another ineffective relief outing for the Mets on Wednesday, allowing a walk and two doubles in the ninth inning of a 7-3 victory over San Diego.

title: Corinne & Jonathan
description: In this homemade video, Corinne LeTourneau recalls being set up by her roommate, a co-worker of Jonathan Werbell.

title: Allison & Ehren
description: In this homemade video, Allison Johnson and Ehren Joseph recall meeting 5 and a 1/2 years ago at a bar on the Lower East Side over a shot of tequila.

title: This Sunday: Who Are Those Oily Guys?
description: The idea for the cover package this week seemed simple enough. Inspired by the gorgeous forthcoming book on three decades of the magazines photography, I thought it would be fun and possibly enlightening to pick a bunch of our favorite pictures and find out what happened to the people in them.

title: On the Street | Olden Days
description: Participants in the Commonwealth Vintage Dances relish dressing in costumes from the 1850s, the Gilded Age and the ragtime years, and often make their own clothes.

title: With New Official T-Shirts, City Shoots for the Hip
description: Forget I  NY. Thats old. Thats dull. Thats been done.

title: Heat Seekers Flock to Miami
description: An off-season boom is transforming the city into a hot spot for those looking to unwind and enjoy lazy summer days.

title: Miamis Rising Tides
description: MIAMI BEACH

title: Very Busy Mom Faces a Bigger Mission
description: Give me back my Carla Gugino. Thats what I couldnt help thinking every time Jessica Alba  lovely to look at, utterly ordinary to watch  appeared on screen in Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D. The fall-off in sexiness, soulfulness and wittiness from Ms. Gugino and Antonio Banderas, the parents in the first three Spy Kids films, to Ms. Alba and Joel McHale is whiplash steep.

title: Beach-Ready, Even in Rain
description: Jayma Cardoso, 35, began her night life career as a part-time hostess while attending Fordham University. She now owns the Surf Lodge in Montauk, N.Y., and GoldBar in SoHo and is a partner in Lavo New York, a Midtown favorite. Ms. Cardoso is engaged to Scott Campbell, 38, a broker at Phoenix Partners Group, and is planning their wedding in her native Brazil for next February.  BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: Chic in Review | Victoria Beckhams Five Hands of Food
description: Abercrombie & FitchPays the Jersey Shore star Michael Sorrentino to stay away from its clothing brand. The aftermath  or the situation, if you will  is that its stock has now dropped by 8 percent!

title: Vicky Tiels 40-Year Career in Fashion
description: IF you are famous for dressed-to-spill goddess gowns beloved by women like Joan Collins and Halle Berry  steel stays radiating pitilessly from the diaphragm  then deciding what to wear to pick up a reporter at a train station in upstate New York might pose a challenge.

title: The High Price of Looking Like a Woman
description: ZAIRA QUISPE, 42, said she knew as a child that she was a girl, though she had been born male. She picked up a photo that she kept on the windowsill above her bed and held it out as proof. Its a picture of herself as a smiling baby, naked and with legs crossed, concealing genitals. Look, she said, even then I was trying to hide it.

title: Farewell to My Summer Tan
description: I GREW up in New Jersey in the 1980s. I wish I could buck the clichs and say that I spent my summers sneaking into seminars at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, but the truth is that I frittered away the days laying out, as it is ungrammatically termed, in my backyard on a deck chair. Wearing a Walkman and sipping a Capri Sun, Id barbecue my skin with sheets of tinfoil carefully positioned on either side of my face.

title: Love Blessed by Lady Liberty Lives On
description: ONE question went unanswered this month when the National Park Service announced it would shut down the Statue of Liberty for renovations in October: What happened to the couple who got engaged in the crown when the statue reopened on July 4, 2009?

title: Scouting the City for Her Characters
description: A SUMMER afternoon in Chelsea, and Sarah Jones was on a recon mission, searching for ... she did not know what, exactly. An accent, for starters. An ethnic wild card. Hybridity, she said, using a word she uses often to describe her field of urban study.

title: Cubs Chairman Says Time Ran Out on Hendry
description: CHICAGO  A late August Cubs-Cardinals series has been a high point in dozens of baseball seasons on the North Side. But the Cubs two-year slide into National League Central irrelevance has removed much of the juice from this weekends three-game set at Wrigley Field.

title: A Slam Winner in Toronto
description: While the Spingold Knockout Teams was taking place at the Summer Nationals in Toronto, there were secondary events for lower master-point holders.

title: A New Breed of Lawyers Focuses on Bicyclists Rights
description: AT the law firm Rankin & Taylor, everybodys a cyclist.

title: Street Style Photos: Unique Glasses
description: The best of readers street fashion submissions for the week of Aug. 15.

title: How Can We Get Businesses to Hire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviewing the Audi A7 and Mercedes-Benz CLS550
description: In this Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Audi A7 and Mercedes-Benz CLS550, a pair of sleek four-door coupes hoping to catch the eye of luxury car buyers. In this beauty contest, Mr. Ulrich writes, there are no losers:

title: Republicans and the E.P.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 19
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the potential closing of a tiny post office, a cat fashion show and a movie in Bryant Park.

title: Shots Out of the Rough
description: After he studied photography at graduate school, Ryan Gauvin didnt follow the path that young photographers so often go on. He didnt photograph gangs. He didnt photograph trailer parks. He didnt photograph transsexuals, the suffering in Africa or any immigrants crossing the border.

title: More Women Behind Bars
description: To the Editor:

title: Bachmann and Dont Ask
description: To the Editor:

title: Walking Her Cats and Playing Guitar
description: The landscape artist April Gornik has been devoting as much energy lately to her new acoustic guitar as to her work. On Sundays, the guitar wins out. Ms. Gornik, 58, has paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum; her next solo show is in October at Danese in Chelsea, which represents her. Though she and her husband, the artist Eric Fischl, 63, have a loft and studio space in New York City, they live most of the time on five secluded acres in North Haven on Long Island with their two Bengal cats, Hooper and Bebop. ROBIN FINN

title: Two Voices Are Heard After Years of Futility
description: TOKYO

title: Antibacterial Chemical Raises Safety Issues
description: The maker of Dial Complete hand soap says that it kills more germs than any other brand. But is it safe?

title: A Lawyer in Minnesota Challenges the Accuracy of D.W.I. Breath Tests
description: For nearly five years, the accuracy of drunken driven tests administered with a breath testing device used by Minnesota law enforcement agencies has been in question.

title: Until Labor Day, Dining With a View
description: As the city has worked to expand the dining options in its parks, Brooklyn Bridge Park, which is being developed along a stretch of piers on the East River, has become a lively food destination. Pier 6 at the south end, near Atlantic Avenue, has its own collection of spots  including Bark and Milk Truck, new this summer  and roof deck seating. Pier 1, at the end of Old Fulton Street, has an outpost of Ditch Plains, a cart from Calexico, Blue Marble ice cream and a wine bar. Open only through Labor Day, the concessions draw crowds of people looking to have a lobster roll, a chipotle pork taco or a glass of prosecco. Sweeping views of the harbor and the skyline are also part of the appeal. On Wednesday afternoon, the crowds included two friends discussing Ghana and microlending. DIANE CARDWELL

title: Two Oklahoma Indian Tribes Contest State for Water Rights
description: The Choctaw and Chickasaw Indian tribes in Oklahoma have filed a federal lawsuit to protect water rights they say derived from long-ago treaties and to prevent exports of water from their traditional homelands without their permission.

title: Outsourcing Chores Made Easy
description: APP TaskRabbit

title: Research on Chimps
description: To the Editor:

title: Review of Census Data Reveals Information Tied to Schools
description: WASHINGTON  It is August, and the Census Bureau is counting things again. This time it was items associated with school, which is just around the corner for children across the country.

title: Frustrating View of Game Day
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Forty people  coaches, well-wishers and players past, present and future  gathered Friday in a dark video hall in Nsambya, a poor working-class neighborhood here to watch the Little League World Series game between Canada and Saudi Arabia.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,730 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: For District Attorney, Political Fallout May Follow Decision on Strauss-Kahn
description: With Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, seemingly poised to announce on Tuesday whether he will seek dismissal of the charges in the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, it is clear that his decision has the potential to carry political ramifications.

title: Answers to Questions About New York City
description: Shipping News

title: The Wrong Way to Help Veterans
description: Washington

title: Straight Out of the East Bay, With Aspirations and Swag
description: In the 2011 hip-hop artifact time capsule, certainly the YouTube clip Video Unacceptable This Chick Gets Loose With the N Word But She Spittin With the Hoodest Bars gets prime placement. In it V-Nasty, a white female rapper from East Oakland, Calif., raps for about a minute, awkwardly but with attitude, and manages to use a certain epithet twice  not violently, but casually, as if it were any other word.

title: Music, Activism and the Peruvian Cabinet
description: Success was a long time coming for Susana Baca, the Afro-Peruvian folk singer who was recently named minister of culture for the new populist government of President Ollanta Humala of Peru. She is the first black member of the Peruvian cabinet and the first musician to hold the position.

title: Folk Art Museum Considers Closing
description: The financial picture has grown so bleak at the American Folk Art Museum that its trustees are considering whether to shut it down and donate its collections to another institution, said a person involved in the discussions, who requested anonymity because the talks are confidential.

title: Ral Ruiz, Prolific Director of Cryptic Films, Dies at 70
description: Ral Ruiz, a Chilean director who presented a labyrinthine, cryptic picture of individual psychology and social relations in Mysteries of Lisbon and more than 100 other films, died on Friday in Paris. He was 70.

title: Bloggingheads: Libya Politics
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Eli Lake of The New Republic debate how the Libyan intervention could play politically in 2012.

title: A Romp Through the Barn
description: How many layers are there to human thought? Sometimes in art, just as in peoples conversations, were aware of only one at a time. On other occasions, though, we realize just how many layers can be in simultaneous action, and were given a sense of both revelation and mystery. When a choreographer responds to music  when one artist reacts in detail to another  the sensation of multilayering can affect us as an insight not just into dance but into the regions of the mind.

title: Secrets of Survival: To Be Used When Summer Doldrums Fade
description: Things started to get weird last week when the following invitation from a public relations firm arrived in Nocturnalists in-box: Last night while rioting ensued on the streets of London, it began, the companys client, a stylist, caused a riot of his own at a hip Manhattan bar, with the stylists fabulous fashion advice and adorable monogrammed pocket squares.

title: What He Did (or Not) on His Australian Vacation
description: With his long, lean physique and thin, angular face, Steven Hauck seems destined to play Don Quixote someday. In the meantime, hes making do with Louis de Rougemont, the somewhat quixotic memoirist who thrilled Victorian England with his ripping yarns and ended up in a sideshow as The Greatest Liar on Earth.

title: U.S. Rejects Mayors Plan to Ban Use of Food Stamps to Buy Soda
description: Federal officials on Friday rejected Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposal to bar New York Citys food stamp users from buying soda and other sugary drinks with them.

title: Regional Sports Networks Show the Money
description: In the 1970s, regional sports networks began to offer fans a new way to watch games on TV.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Questions on a Bank Merger
description: Representative Barney Frank, a Democrat of Massachusetts, got it exactly right this week when he asked the Federal Reserve to do more than just rubber-stamp the proposed purchase of the online bank, ING Direct, by the Capital One Financial Corporation.

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: Warning from the health care industry about jobs; anxiety over Europe roils markets; Nordstroms new effort in New York; and a summer camp introducing girls to manufacturing.

title: Clemens Prosecutors Request a New Trial
description: WASHINGTON  Federal prosecutors overseeing the Roger Clemens perjury case said Friday that they made an unintentional error when showing jurors inadmissible evidence that led to Clemenss mistrial last month. The prosecutors asked a judge to allow a new trial.

title: Podcast: Eurobonds, Star Analysts and Productivity
description: Financial markets have been showing more signs of stress. The daily swings of stock markets have been growing wider, and investments presumed to be safe, like Treasury bonds and gold bullion, have been rising sharply in price.

title: Music Hall of Fame Gets Home of Its Own
description: THE Long Island Music Hall of Fame was organized seven years ago to start trumpeting the fact that all these amazing people come from Long Island, according to the chairman of its board of directors, James Faith, of Miller Place.

title: But I Really Want to Act (Never Mind the Stage Fright)
description: In a play loaded with clever words, the funniest scene is one about not being able to get any out. Thats largely because Josh Grisetti, the appealing young star of Enter Laughing, the Musical, mimes stage fright so expertly that his struggle becomes as comical as a well-crafted line.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Flying? Increasingly for the Birds
description: Ill be passing the back of my hand over your buttocks and then come up the insides of your legs up toward the private parts. Is that O.K.?

title: No U.S. Trip for Students From Gaza, Hamas Says
description: GAZA  The Islamist group that governs Gaza barred a group of students this week from traveling to the United States for a year of study, officials of the group, Hamas, said.

title: Staging a Classic, Retooled and Slimmed Down
description: When Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein II wrote Show Boat, they also rewrote the rules for musicals, adding serious themes and complex characters to a genre that had been all fluff. And just as our notion of serious themes and complex characters has evolved since 1927, when it opened, so has Show Boat.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Judging a Paperbacks Cover by Its Painter
description: The Beatles immortalized the plight of an aspiring author in their 1966 song Paperback Writer. But what about the paperback painter? A comprehensive view of that lot can be found in The Painting World of James Avati at the Monmouth Museum in Lincroft, an intriguing show that surveys the life and work of Americas premier mid-20th-century paperback-cover artist.

title: Innocent Parties
description: In the past few weeks Ive hawk-proofed my chicken yard. Its now covered by a net, as though a trapeze artist who missed his hold might come plummeting into it. Ive also fox-proofed the yard with fencing, but I forgot about weasels because theyve never given me any trouble. Last week, I walked out to the yard and there, in the chicken house, lay the bodies of 24 pullets. Instead of the early morning clatter of a chicken flock, silence greeted me. It was a characteristic weasel kill  all the birds dead but none removed or eaten.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Lawyer Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
description: A federal judge sentenced a personal-injury lawyer, Jason C. Goldfarb, to three years in prison for his role in an insider trading scheme that involved a hedge fund trader and two corporate lawyers. Mr. Goldfarb, who worked at Brecher Fishman Pasternack Walsh Tilker & Ziegler, pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme with Zvi Goffer, a former trader at the Galleon Group, the hedge fund run by Raj Rajaratnam. He admitted to receiving tips about impending corporate mergers from Arthur Cutillo and Brien Santarlas, two low-level associates at the law firm Ropes & Gray, and then passing them to Mr. Goffer. During an April court appearance, Mr. Goldfarb, who earned college and law degrees from Villanova, said that Mr. Goffer, a friend, approached him shortly after his law school graduation and asked if he knew any corporate lawyers. Mr. Goldfarb said he eventually introduced Mr. Goffer to Mr. Cutillo, his college roommate. Both Mr. Cutillo and Mr. Santarlas have pleaded guilty to leaking information about takeovers involving 3Com and Axcan Pharma. Mr. Goffer took his case to trial and was convicted by a jury in June.

title: As PCs Wane, Companies Look to Tablets
description: Although the world is dependent on personal computers, making them has not been a great business for most American companies for almost a decade.

title: Toward Immigration Sanity
description: The White House has just taken a large step toward a more sensible and lawful policy on illegal immigration. The administration said that it would stop deporting illegal immigrants who pose no threat to public safety or national security so that it can focus on catching and expelling criminals who do.

title: Judge Hinting at Trial in Case of Mets Owners
description: A federal district judge on Friday raised the prospect that all or part of the $1 billion lawsuit brought against the owners of the Mets by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs epic fraud could wind up being decided in a public trial before a jury.

title: A Study in Judicial Dysfunction
description: Harsh state judicial campaigns financed by ever larger amounts of special interest money are eating away at public faith in judicial impartiality. There are few places where the spectacle is more shameful than Wisconsin, where over-the-top campaigning, self-interested rulings, and a complete breakdown of courthouse collegiality and ethics is destroying trust in its Supreme Court.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Scrambling to Ease Shortage of Vital Medicine
description: WASHINGTON  Federal officials and lawmakers, along with the drug industry and doctors groups, are rushing to find remedies for critical shortages of drugs to treat a number of life-threatening illnesses, including bacterial infection and several forms of cancer.

title: Rick, Rattle and Roll
description: Consider the Rick Perry paradox: in a G.O.P. field notably bereft of experience in elected office, he has won nine back-to-back elections and spent the last decade as governor of Americas second-most-populous state. And, though the Thread has yet to see him in person, he is apparently the Red State equivalent of Kal-El. Or so says this rapturous lede from Politico:

title: Uncertainty in Courthouse Fogs the View at the Stadium
description: It is a sad state of affairs when the big events are being played in courtrooms rather than ballparks. But that is the plight of the Mets, who are trying to stay competitive on the field and solvent off the field.

title: A Close to the Cow Treat
description: With summer on the wane, anyone who has yet to achieve the perfect ice cream moment should plot a course for Lighthouse Ice Cream and Coffee, on the Tarrytown waterfront. With its jaunty nautical theme, this new venture honors the old-fashioned virtues of vanilla, chocolate and strawberry while delighting patrons with the likes of Meyer lemon, pomegranate and pineapple-basil sorbets.

title: At Enduring Trattoria, Dessert Is High Point
description: NOW in its third year, TuttaBella Trattoria seems to have dispelled any notion that the building it occupies, on the corner of Route 22 and Wilmot Road, is somehow unlucky.

title: If Phones Ring, Obama Is Here, With Cell Power
description: CHILMARK, Mass.  To the slamming screen door, happy vacation chatter and other noises at the Chilmark General Store, add a less expected one this month: ringing cellphones.

title: For President at Play, Family Outings, Golf and Lots of Advisers
description: CHILMARK, Mass.  When President Obama boarded Air Force One this week for his vacation on Marthas Vineyard, he was conspicuously accompanied by John O. Brennan, his chief counterterrorism adviser. Next week, a top economic adviser, Brian Deese, will arrive to prep Mr. Obama for his speech on the economy after Labor Day.

title: Flavors of Australia
description: The winemaker Russell Hearn left his native Australia in 1985, but he hasnt left Australia behind.

title: Report Finds Vast Improvement at the Citys Beaches
description: It may not be this summers most gripping beach read, but a civic organizations new 27-page report should bring smiles to New Yorks swimmers and sunbathers.

title: Views of Peconic Bay, Tastes of Local Bounty
description: FOR around 15 years, until its closing in 2009, the Seafood Barge at the Port of Egypt Marina in Southold was one of the North Forks best restaurants. A Lure Chowder House and Oysteria, which opened in the Seafood Barges waterfront space in May, is a worthy successor.

title: Principal to Resign Following Grade-Altering Inquiry
description: The principal of a Bronx high school who was found to have improperly changed student grades has agreed to resign from the school, but will continue to work for the Department of Education, possibly advising principals and teachers on curriculum and other matters, city officials said Friday.

title: 9/11s White Elephant
description: There is nothing wrong  and much that is right  with building a national monument to memorialize the nearly 3,000 people killed in the 9/11 attacks a decade ago. The awful events of that day traumatized the country  and changed it. The dead deserve to be remembered. Far be it from me to suggest otherwise.

title: Qaddafis Hold in Tripoli in Doubt as Rebels Advance
description: CAIRO  Six months after the outbreak of the revolt against his 42 years in power, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis hold on his Tripoli stronghold shows signs of slipping.

title: Five Days of Market Volatility
description: A look at multiple indexes over the past five days.

title: Falling Off the Bone
description: Little Marks Big BBQ in Vernon, a 60-seat restaurant that opened in 1990, occupies a pale blue freestanding building of the sort often favored by fast-food chains. But there is nothing quick about the way its meats are barbecued. Prolonged smoking at a low temperature  cooking times are from 6 to 12 hours  is the norm in Southern barbecue, which is offered here with a variety of sauces and rubs.

title: Where Sushi Is Good, but Rarely Simple
description: WE listened agog as our waiter inventoried the elements in the lobster tempura sushi roll, a special that night at Feng Asian Bistro in Hartford. The list was lengthy, a daring amalgamation of lobster tempura, avocado, lettuce and mango, glazed with Parmesan cheese and finished with barbecue eel sauce and spicy mayonnaise. It was a surprise hit, the cheese providing a sharp, savory note that brightened the lobster and avocado.

title: Our Politics Are Sick
description: We have a tendency to elect presidents who seem like the antitheses of their immediate predecessors  randy young Kennedy the un-Eisenhower, earnest truth-telling Carter the un-Nixon, charismatic Reagan the un-Carter, randy young Clinton the un-H.W. Bush, cool and cerebral Obama the un-W.

title: Getting Ribs Right, Slowly
description: For Mike Cassidy, an owner of the pig-themed Hickory Hog restaurant in Point Pleasant, barbecue is an art and a science.

title: Kosher Dishes, Straight From India
description: I WANTED to love Mysore Woodlands. Its kosher, so I could bring the leftovers into my home. Its Indian, so it would please my masala-loving wife, whose heart sank when a kosher-vegetarian South Indian place, Udupi Village, closed down two months after we moved to Montclair.

title: Saturday: A Special Puzzle From Lollapuzzoola
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert! There will be a Notepad on the Sunday puzzle that reads: When this puzzle is done, look for a name (hinted at by 37 Down) hidden 17 times in the grid, each reading forward, backward, down, up or diagonally, word search-style.

title: Reyes Makes an Appearance but Is Not Quite Ready to Return
description: Jose Reyes gave every indication on Friday afternoon that he was ready to rejoin the Mets. He stabbed ground balls, took batting practice and jogged across the grass at Citi Field before the team hosted the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Battle for Libya | August 19, 2011
description: Rebels continue to fight in Zawiyah as Qaddafis hold on Tripoli shows signs of slipping.

title: In California, Victims Families Fight for the Dead
description: SAN DIEGO  The other day, at the sprawling state prison here, Linda and Alfred Tay sat in a cramped, windowless room, just feet from the man serving time for murdering their son.

title: New York Police Officer Charged With Rape While Off Duty
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was arrested in Upper Manhattan on Friday after he grabbed a woman who was on her way to work, showed her he had a gun and raped her in the backyard of a nearby building, the police said.

title: Corrections: August 20
description: FRONT PAGE

title: New York City, in the Dawns Early Light
description: Librado Romero, a staff photographer for The New York Times, explores the citys early morning hours.

title: Obama in the Valley
description: In 1970, the Japanese roboticist Masahiro Mori coined the phrase uncanny valley. In the field of robotics, and increasinglyin computer animation, it refers to the theory that people feel good about robots  up to a point. When they start to look almost real, but not quite, we experience an eerie and unsettling sense of revulsion.

title: Turkey: Army Strikes Kurdish Rebels
description: The Turkish military carried out airstrikes in northern Iraq for a second day in pursuit of Kurdish separatist rebels suspected of attacking Turkey from bases in the mountainous border region. Warplanes hit 28 rebel locations, and artillery shelled 96 targets, the army said Friday. Meanwhile, the rebels  from the P.K.K., or Kurdistan Workers Party  struck two military posts in Siirt Province, in the southeast, killing two soldiers and wounding three civilians, the semiofficial Anatolian Agency reported. More than 40 people have been killed since separatist violence escalated in July, which led to this weeks intense military operations.

title: Jones Listens to His Mother, Opens His Stance and Recovers His Stroke
description: MINNEAPOLIS  After a disappointing first half of the season in which he batted only .195, Andruw Jones received important advice from one of his personal batting coaches, and it seems to have had quite an impact on his second-half production.

title: Is That Review a Fake?
description: Researchers at Cornell University have been analyzing Web reviews to detect fake ones.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Long Climbs to No. 1
description: Over the past two decades, there have been four books that spent 20 weeks or more on the list before reaching the top spot.

title: Pennsylvania: Three Dead in Pittsburgh Flooding
description: Flash floods in Pittsburgh left three people dead and one person missing on Friday, city and county officials said. According to the Allegheny County medical examiners office, two of the dead were children.

title: Twang and Job Title Might Be the Same, but Perry and Bush Keep Their Distance
description: Sharing a last name with George W. Bush has no doubt contributed to the decision by his younger brother Jeb to stay out of the Republican presidential fray. But can sharing a Texas twang with the last president hurt Gov. Rick Perrys chances of becoming the next one?

title: His Place in the Rotation Secure, Hughes Shows Why He Deserves It
description: MINNEAPOLIS  After weeks of uncertainty surrounding the Yankees starting pitching rotation, Fridays game provided a night of clarity. In the span of a few hours the Yankees placed Freddy Garcia on the disabled list with an injury he said had healed, and then watched as Phil Hughes produced a dominating start.

title: For Mets, More Waiting and Nothing to Show for It
description: The Mets return home Friday was defined by a tantalizing series of fits and starts. During batting practice, the injured Jose Reyes looked ready to rejoin the club, but he remains days away. Then rain delayed the start of the game for 2 hours 46 minutes.

title: Nations Race to Defuse Crisis Between Egypt and Israel
description: CAIRO  Diplomats scrambled to avert a crisis in relations between Egypt and Israel on Saturday, and the Israeli government issued a rare statement of regret for the killing of three Egyptian security officers by an Israeli warplane.

title: Fancy Theorists of the World Unite
description: A number of people have pointed me to this remarkable editorial by Stephen Moore in the WSJ. Whats remarkable isnt the views; its the all-out embrace of anti-intellectualism. It actually denounces fancy theories and rejects them because they defy common sense.

title: Spains Players Go on Strike
description: The Spanish League season will not start as scheduled this weekend after the players and team owners failed to reach an agreement on a new collective bargaining agreement. Raphael Minder of the I.H.T. laid out some more details on the black cloud over La Liga on Thursday. Read his article here, and come back to comment.

title: Swede Talk, Swede Talk
description: A few random notes:

title: Heavy Fighting Reported in Tripoli; Rebels Encircle City
description: ZAWIYAH, Libya  For the first time in months, witnesses in Tripoli reported heavy fighting across the capital late Saturday night, even as rebel forces claimed to have encircled the city by taking major towns to its east, west and south.

title: The Weekend Word: Texan
description: Todays Times

title: Star Analysts Are Back (No Autographs, Please)
description: THEY are the new tastemakers of Web investing, the supposed seers of Bubble-Tech 2.0. And despite the stock markets recent craziness, they are almost as hot as some of the stocks they cover.

title: Leadership Doesnt Rest on Your Title
description: This interview with  Terri Ludwig, president and chief executive of Enterprise Community Partners, a nonprofit housing finance organization, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Iran Sentences 2 Hikers to 8 Years in Jail
description: The Revolutionary Court in Iran sentenced two American hikers imprisoned since July 2009 to eight years in jail for espionage and entering the country illegally, Tehrans prosecutor, Abbas Jafari Dolatabadi, told a news conference Sunday.

title: Silicon Valley Entrepreneurs
description: Tech professionals are optimistic.

title: In Silicon Valley, the Night Is Still Young
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.

title: A Generous Gift
description: The Cleveland Indians were in Boston this month when Jack Hannahan, a reserve infielder, learned that his wife, Jenny, had gone into labor. She had been on bed rest since the 24th week of her pregnancy, and this was Week 28.

title: Finger-Pointing in the Fog
description: UNEARTHING the story of the financial crisis is like conducting an archaeological dig. New shards keep emerging from the dust.

title: Just Give Me the Right to Be Forgotten
description: THE marketing pitch came by e-mail: Would you like to make an appointment with your dentist to have your teeth cleaned? And while youre at it, how about recommending him to a friend, or posting a review of your dental care?

title: High-Tech Product, Low-Tech Pitch
description: ZERO percent financing on a new car. A mattress sale blowout. Storewide discounts at the local hardware. These are the types of pitches that people expect to hear on the radio. Not commercials for the Barracuda Load Balancer, which sounds vaguely automotive but is actually software related to managing Web site traffic.

title: Of Management and Mosquito Nets
description: CORPORATE chieftains tend to have an overarching faith in the curative powers of modern management  goal-setting, incentivizing, metrics, accountability, the whole shebang. People like Ross Perot and Mitt Romney have sought to introduce this kind of thinking into government circles, with mixed results.

title: Three Weeks Into Camp, Teams Are Starting to See Things
description: If you spend too much time in the August heat of training camp, you may start to experience football-related hallucinations.

title: Is Manning One of Elite? Numbers Muddle Issue
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For a Super Bowl-winning quarterback in the countrys largest news media market, Eli Manning routinely tiptoes around the spotlight, rarely making headlines. It is not by accident. His public image is carefully managed, devoid of the irreverence and swagger that made his older brother, Peyton, one of the leagues most popular and marketable stars. Eli Mannings interviews sound more like depositions: short, direct, lawyerly, with a hint of goofiness.

title: The Sad Statistic That Trumps the Others
description: THERES been a lot of bad economic news lately, yet we may be overlooking the most disturbing development of all: our economic productivity has been weakening. This isnt just a problem for the United States. Because America remains a leader in technology and innovation, it is also a matter of concern for the entire world.

title: Who Says Companies Arent Spending?
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom says the unwillingness of businesses to spend and employ more workers is holding back the economy and the stock market.

title: The Boundaries of Marriage and Work
description: When husband and wife work next to each other, can they truly keep their home life outside the office? Lisa and Michael Pallen, executives at VerveLife, a music marketing agency in Chicago, say its working out so far.

title: All the Kings Horses
description: A day in the life of North Americas top trainer: hot walking, hand holding and a heart-thumping victory.

title: All the Kings Horses
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  He watched on the dusty television hanging from the ceiling of a cramped office that is always full of people and that perpetually smells of the horses that snort and whinny and shuffle in the adjacent stalls. It was 5:31 p.m. on a recent Saturday, and Todd Pletcher was back in the same barn where his day had begun 13 hours earlier, with him checking feed tubs and taking the temperatures of nearly 100 racehorses.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  The Puns & Anagrams puzzles that we know and love in The New York Times go all the way back to Feb. 15, 1942. Underneath The Times first Sunday crossword was a Puns & Anagrams puzzle titled Riddle Me This by the maddeningly named Anna Gram. No one today knows for sure who the pseudonymous Anna Gram was, although Will Shortz tells me that he has always suspected Margaret Farrar. In fact, you can read a brief PandA history written by our puzzlemaster here.

title: Pirates Rely on Draft
description: In the midst of their tumble from the top of the National League Central, the Pittsburgh Pirates made a significant investment in their future at Mondays deadline to sign drafted players. The Pirates gave $13 million to two Scott Boras clients: $8 million for pitcher Gerrit Cole, the No. 1 overall pick, and $5 million for outfielder Josh Bell, the 61st.

title: College Footballs Ugly Season, Facing Scandals of Every Stripe
description: College football is set to start its new season Sept. 1, but a kind of dispirited consensus has taken hold about a sport that has been played on American campuses since 1869: its reputation has never been more damaged.

title: 50 Years Later, Mariss 61-Homer Season Looks Even Better
description: Ever since people began to wonder what was happening during the Large Ball Cap Generation, Roger Maris has been having a terrific decade.

title: Tracking the Flow of Money
description: An example of how state grants appear to be paying dividends for some major Perry contributors.

title: Farewell, Aching Feet
description: WHEN I was 15, I moved from Taipei, Taiwan, where I was born, to live in the United States. Education was very important to my parents, so they sent my sister and brother and me to Wilmington, Del., to live with my grandparents and attend school there.

title: Arsenal May Covet a Red Bull on the Rise
description: In the last month, Red Bulls defender Tim Ream has turned out for Major League Soccers All-Stars against Manchester United and helped lead his team to a surprise victory at the Emirates Cup in London.

title: Iraq Militants Say Violence Is to Avenge Bin Laden
description: BAGHDAD  One of the most powerful insurgent groups in Iraq, Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, released a statement on Saturday, warning that it had launched a 100-attack campaign to exact revenge for the United States killing of Osama bin Laden.

title: Verizon Workers Plan to End Strike, Agreeing to Revive Talks Toward a Contract
description: Leaders of the unions that have been on strike against Verizon Communications announced on Saturday that they were ending the walkout even though the two sides had not reached an overall settlement for a new contract.

title: Thomes Success Rooted in a Simple Suggestion
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Jim Thome and Ryan Howard come to the plate, they dig their spikes into the left-handers batters box, keeping the left foot closer to the plate than the right foot. They extend their right arm, pointing the bat menacingly to some distant spot beyond the center-field wall, like a samurai offering his sword to the pitcher.

title: Economic Lessons From World War II
description: To the Editor:

title: Concussion Suit Seeks Better Health Monitoring
description: As the attention paid to head injuries in the N.F.L. has increased in recent years, much of the emphasis has been on the plight of retired players, many of whom are now facing a number of serious ailments.

title: To Your Right, the Frenzied Capital of Finance
description: Tourists have flocked to the Wall Street area to have their pictures taken outside the Exchange even as the markets continue their fluctuations inside.

title: Sharing a Tournament, but Not a Culture
description: MASON, Ohio  Jelena Jankovic was struggling to fend off Francesca Schiavone on Thursday at the Western and Southern Open. She might as well have been trying to extricate a bulldogs teeth from her leg.

title: Two Teams Race to Forget the Past
description: Detroit

title: With North Korea in Need, Kim Jong-il Goes to Russia
description: MOSCOW  North Koreas reclusive leader, Kim Jong-il, rumbled across the border into Russia aboard an armored train early Saturday amid growing hopes for a resumption of talks over ending his countrys nuclear weapons program.

title: In Labor Deals Minutiae, No Xs or Os, but a Few Zzzzzs
description: The recently ratified N.F.L. collective bargaining agreement has all the makings of a literary masterpiece. It is much talked about, unquestionably important, somewhat controversial, epic in scope and thematically complex. And only the tiniest percentage of the population will ever read a word of it.

title: With Klaus Obermeyer
description: At 91, Klaus Obermeyer remains the energetic patriarch of the family-owned skiwear company he founded in 1947. As an early ski instructor in Aspen, Colo., Obermeyer realized that his comforter stuffed with goose feathers, packed by his mother when he left Germany for North America, could provide the template for one of the first down parkas. Among Obermeyers other notable innovations are high-altitude sun lotion, double-paned goggles, the nylon windshirt and the dual-layer ski boot. Over the years, Sport Obermeyer has been in the forefront in developing ski gear that keeps skiers warmer, dryer, comfortable and safer on their skis. With winter inching closer, Obermeyer, an aeronautical engineer by training, is itching to get back on the slopes as he recovers from an accident last March that resulted in a broken femur in his right leg, his first serious injury in 88 years on skis. JACK BELL

title: Lawyer for Strauss-Kahns Accuser Expects Charges to Be Dropped
description: Manhattan prosecutors will meet with the woman who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault on the eve of a court appearance in which they are expected to announce whether they will proceed with the case. The womans lawyer, who received a letter from the district attorneys office requesting the Monday afternoon meeting, said he believed it to be a clear indication that prosecutors would seek to have a judge dismiss all or some of the charges at the court hearing on Tuesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: After Cellphone Action, BART Faces Escalating Protests
description: Early last month, a BART police officer shot and killed a knife-wielding homeless man at the San Francisco Civic Center station. The incident provoked a series of small protests that drew little attention until Aug. 11, when the transit agency took the unusual step of shutting down cellphone service for several hours as activists prepared for another rally.

title: Colliding, With Nuance
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For those who have come to know John Conner beyond his controlled violence, it is not surprising that the most brutal hitter on the Jets  a man whose devastating blocks have been featured on Hard Knocks and immortalized on YouTube  also enjoys bowling and the occasional womens soccer game.

title: Casualties on Both Sides as Israel and Gaza Trade Fire
description: JERUSALEM  Palestinian militants from Gaza fired rockets at cities deep inside Israeli territory on Saturday, killing one person. And Israel struck a squad that was firing mortars from northern Gaza as violence continued in the wake of an attack on Thursday that killed eight Israelis, Israeli officials said.

title: Keeping Score: Looking Past Mere Wins and Losses
description: Luck, or if you prefer a less loaded term, randomness, plays a significant role in any major league baseball game. A line drive caught by the third baseman might be rattling around the left-field corner if it had hit the bat just a few millimeters higher. A borderline strike three might be ball four with just a tiny change in the pitchers grip. Usually all of these events that could go one way or another balance out over 162 games and the season ends with the best teams at the top of the standings, but only usually.

title: Nature Without the Nanny State
description: Teanaway Valley, Wash.

title: Leopard Rider Fuglsang Leads Vuelta After Day 1
description: Jakob Fuglsang is the early leader of the Vuelta a Espaa after his Leopard team won the opening-day team time trial Saturday.

title: Immigrant Struggles to Stay in Britain and Honor a Sacrifice
description: In 2005, Antonio Bravos father committed suicide in a desperate attempt to avert his sons deportation to Angola.

title: In Fathers Memory, Fighting to Stay in Britain
description: CLAPHAM, England  The boy was 13 when a dawn immigration raid abruptly ended his fathers four-year quest for political asylum in Britain. By nightfall of that day in 2005, father and son were hundreds of miles from home, locked in the privately run Yarls Wood Immigration Removal Center here, scheduled for deportation to their native Angola in the morning.

title: Atop a Training Empire, the Days Are Full
description: The daily routine of North Americas top horse trainer, Todd Pletcher, is a feat of choreography, in which high-tech wizardry is as necessary as plain old horse sense.

title: The Grand Staircase, City Hall
description: The majestic stairs to the Ceremonial Rotunda and the Board of Supervisors Chambers were built with economic stimulus money after the previous City Hall was destroyed in the 1906 earthquake. Designed by graduates of the University of California, Berkeley, the building was constructed in three years  without power tools  opening in 1915.

title: A Big Hollywood Movie Is Coming, and a Novelist Cries Foul
description: In 1998, Joe Quirk, a Bay Area novelist, wrote Ultimate Rush, a thriller about an adrenaline-fueled messenger who tears through the city on rollerblades as he tries to deliver a mysterious package. Mr. Quirks novel, his first to be published, sold well and was optioned by Warner Brothers. A screenplay was commissioned, and Mr. Quirk became a client of the powerful C.A.A. agency. But nothing ever came of it  or so Mr. Quirk thought.

title: Ice Cream Pilgrimage, With Shopping and the Arts
description: If ice cream is your religion, then Brenham is mecca. On any given day, up to 2,000 people visit the Blue Bell Creamery (1101 South Blue Bell Road, 800-327-8135, bluebell.com), the birthplace of every true Texans favorite frozen treat. Cheerful guides spice up the tour with fun facts  Blue Bell is sold in 20 states, and most of the cookies and wafers are made in house  while ushering guests through elevated hallways overlooking mixing and packing rooms. The tour clocks in at a third of a mile with two flights of stairs, which means you shouldnt feel guilty devouring the generous helping of ice cream served at the end.

title: Suggesting A Few Extras For a Park With Loyalists
description: Dolores Park sprawls across 14 sloping acres between the Mission and Castro neighborhoods in San Francisco, with spectacular views of the Bay Bridge and beyond. On warm weekends, the park fills with families and nearly nude sunbathers, fitness fanatics and Chardonnay-sipping picnickers, plus a roving man selling pot truffles.

title: Conservatives Eye Senate and Anticipate a Battle
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Perry and the Tea Party: Depends on Whom You Ask
description: WACO  He was Tea Party before Tea Party was cool, the darling of the ultra-conservative right wing. That is how many news analysts described Gov. Rick Perry as he leapt into the national spotlight announcing his bid for the presidency.

title: As Governor, Perry Backed Wind, Gas and Coal
description: In the opening days of his presidential campaign, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has railed against a favorite target, the Environmental Protection Agency, and declared himself a skeptic on the subject of humans as the cause of global warming.

title: Gary Lures Hollywood With a Bounty of Decay
description: Inside City Methodist Church in downtown Gary, Ind., mushrooms grew next to a pile of rubble and a wooden cross. Old theater seats were scattered about, the backs snapped from their cushioned seats as if a giant had smashed them in a fit of rage.

title: Locust Souffl, Anyone? Its a Start
description: Grasshopper fajitas, mealworm fried rice, Bee-LTs and similar delicacies will be on the menu for a public tasting buffet in October at the University of Chicago. The insect-dominated bill of fare is the idea of Matthew Krisiloff, a sophomore from California who last year founded Entom Foods, a start-up that seeks to make bugs a staple of the American diet.

title: Briefly the New Frontier, Exurbs See a Bust After Boom
description: Far west suburban Yorkville scarcely looks as if it was once one of Americas hottest boomtowns. In some subdivisions, lots for big homes are patches of scrub grass and rocky soil. Weeds crawl up around some curbs. A mere handful of houses dot the barren landscape.

title: Antigraft Activists in India Intensify Drive for Reform
description: NEW DELHI  With his hunger strike reaching a fifth day, the protest leader Anna Hazare maintained pressure on the government on Saturday as his advisers demanded that their version of legislation to create a national anticorruption agency be introduced in Parliament on Tuesday and passed by the end of the month.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 20
description: There were trips, slips, kicks and flips during a busy day in sports.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, August 21
description: Participants and spectators from both sides of the 2012 campaign will appear on the Sunday shows to talk strategy for either securing a second term or beginning a first. Three governors will also weigh in to discuss what the consecutive rabble-rousing in Washington means for state and local elections.

title: If I Were President ...
description: We've heard from the media and from experts  incessantly. What if we entered a pundit-free zone?

title: In Defense of Secrecy
description: Julie Salamon is the author of Wendy and the Lost Boys: The Uncommon Life of Wendy Wasserstein.

title: Of Dystopias and Alphas
description: WASHINGTON

title: Jews in a Whisper
description: London

title: Surely They Can Read a Spreadsheet
description: When the federal government was on the brink of default and the economy hung in the balance, the nations business leaders had a chance to step forward and push for a long-term solution. They could have supported a grand bargain that cut spending and raised tax revenue. They could have warned House Republicans that it was far too risky to use the debt ceiling for political leverage.

title: An Empty Regard
description: William Deresiewicz is an essayist and critic, and the author of Solitude and Leadership, an address delivered at West Point in 2009 and widely taught in the armed forces.

title: The Debate on Fracturing
description: The argument over hydraulic fracturing  a technique used to extract natural gas from deep shale formations  has become increasingly polarized. Some environmental groups have demanded a nationwide moratorium because of complaints about polluted drinking water in wells. Meanwhile, industry officials and many politicians, including Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, extol fracturing and insist there is already more than enough regulation.

title: Fairies, Witches and Supply and Demand
description: Motoko Rich is an economics reporter for The New York Times.

title: As Farmers Markets Go Mainstream, Some Fear a Glut
description: FLORENCE, Mass.  John Spineti started selling plump tomatoes and shiny squash at farmers markets in the early 1970s and saw his profits boom as markets became more popular. But just as farmers markets have become mainstream, Mr. Spineti said business has gone bust.

title: Farmers Markets Spring Up
description: As farmers markets boom, some see a glut in the making.

title: Google Goes Hardware Shopping
description: Steve Lohr is a technology reporter for The New York Times.

title: Think Youre Smarter Than Animals? Maybe Not
description: Alexandra Horowitz is the author of Inside of a Dog: What Dogs See, Smell and Know. Ammon Shea is the author of The Phone Book: The Curious History of the Book That Everyone Uses But No One Reads.

title: The K.G.B.s Bathhouse Plot
description: Victor Sebestyen is a Hungarian-born journalist and the author of Revolution 1989: The Fall of the Soviet Empire.

title: If You Really, Really Wanted a Girl ...
description: Pam Belluck is a science reporter for The New York Times.

title: Penny Foolish
description: David L. Ganz is a member of the Board of Freeholders of Bergen County, N.J., and a former president of the American Numismatic Association.

title: Not Mincing Words Over Asylum
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Fearing a Planet Without Apes
description: John C. Mitani is a professor of anthropology at the University of Michigan.

title: Sex Offenders: The Last Pariahs
description: Roger N. Lancaster is a professor of anthropology and director of the cultural studies program at George Mason University, and the author of Sex Panic and the Punitive State.

title: Kathryn Stockett
description: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

title: Mr. Demirajs Nightmare
description: Edmond Demiraj is trapped. An Albanian gangster, Bill Bedini, wants to kill him and harm his family. The United States wants to deport Mr. Demirajs wife and teenage son from Texas to Albania, where they will no doubt be in great danger from Mr. Bedini. Mr. Demiraj keeps pleading with the federal authorities for help, and keeps losing.

title: Will Health Care Reform Survive the Courts?
description: The legal battle over the constitutionality of the health care reform law will determine how far government can go in helping to improve peoples lives. Ultimately, the Supreme Court will have to decide this question. Until then, the pileup of lower federal court rulings  responding to some of the more than two dozen lawsuits filed against the law  is confusing and sharply divided, especially on the requirement that individuals buy or obtain health insurance or pay a penalty.

title: Sunday Dialogue: The Tax When You Fill Up
description: With the federal gas tax due to expire on Sept. 30, readers debate whether to raise it, and the effects an increase would have.

title: Campaign Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: Migrants in United Arab Emirates Get Stuck in Web of Debt
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  Before she arrived in this mecca of migrant labor at age 48, Evelyn Naces, a Filipino nurse, had never owned a credit card. Soon she had 14 of them  and like thousands of other foreign workers here, a trip to debtors prison.

title: Summer Wins Again
description: Henry Alford writes for Vanity Fair and will publish a book about manners in January.

title: The Stomachs of Strongmen
description: Ann Louise Bardach is a writer at large for Newsweek and the author of Without Fidel: A Death Foretold in Miami, Havana and Washington.

title: Sunday: Underwater Search
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Never say that The New York Times doesnt give you anything for free.

title: Murray Stops Fish; Will Face Djokovic in Final
description: MASON, Ohio  Andy Murrays forehand service return Saturday on his second match point against Mardy Fish appeared good. So much has gone right for Fish during this hard-court season, he challenged the linesmans call, anyway, figuring he had nothing to lose but the match.

title: Humble Service With a Side of Swag
description: Id love to see Meryl Streep win another Oscar, I pray for the invention of fat-burning ice cream and I share many a pageant finalists dewy dream of world peace.

title: Nuns, a Dying Breed, Fade From Leadership Roles at Catholic Hospitals
description: ST. LOUIS  When Sister Mary Jean Ryan entered the convent as a young nurse in 1960, virtually every department of every Catholic hospital was run by a nun, from pediatrics to dietary to billing. After her retirement on July 31 as the chief executive of one of the countrys largest networks of Catholic hospitals, only 11 nuns remained among her companys more than 22,000 employees, and none were administrators.

title: Murray Is Not Checking His Phone
description: MASON, Ohio  The Scotsman Andy Murray makes an inviting target for the British tabloids, especially during the Wimbledon fortnight when his every move  from his cheese pizza delivery order to his stepping out to the London theater  is reported.

title: Clair George, Spy and Iran-Contra Figure, Dies at 81
description: Clair E. George, a consummate spymaster who moved the chess pieces in the Central Intelligence Agencys clandestine games of intrigue before being convicted of lying to Congress about the Iran-contra affair, died Aug. 11 in Bethesda, Md. He was 81.

title: The World This Week, Part 2
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: The World This Week, Part 1
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: With Age Came Patience to Wait Out Passing Frenzy
description: There they were, on a swarm of motorcycles, rumbling down Interstate 10 heading for the Pacific coast on a glorious afternoon. Their gray hair and beards suggested that this was not a chapter of the Hells Angels, as did the insignia on their leather jackets: Geezers M.C.

title: Battle Begins for the Libyan Capital
description: The Lede followed the first effort by Libyan rebels to capture the countrys capital, Tripoli, on Saturday.

title: Mets Closers Past and Present Dont Come Through
description: In his time in New York, Francisco Rodriguez burnished a reputation for unpredictability on the field and volatility away from it. But the Mets bullpen has been shakier in the nearly six weeks since he was traded to the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Laser Advances in Nuclear Fuel Stir Terror Fear
description: Scientists have long sought easier ways to make the costly material known as enriched uranium  the fuel of nuclear reactors and bombs, now produced only in giant industrial plants.

title: Jokes on Sharapova as Djokovic Goes Blond
description: MASON, Ohio  With a match record of 57-1 this year, Novak Djokovic is doing a pretty fair imitation of Roger Federer five years ago when he finished with a record of 92-5. His impression of Maria Sharapova, on the other hand, could use some work.

title: Perry Mines Texas System to Raise Cash for Campaigns
description: Two years ago, John McHale, an entrepreneur from Austin, Tex., who has given millions of dollars to Democratic candidates and causes, did something very unusual for him: he wrote a $50,000 check to a Republican candidate, Rick Perry, then seeking a third full term as governor of Texas. In September 2010, he did it again, catapulting himself into the top ranks of Mr. Perrys donors.

title: To Senior Players, Fifth Major Doesnt Really Feel Like One
description: HARRISON, N.Y.  Fred Couples, the 1992 Masters champion, is one round from his second major professional title, the Champions Tours Senior Players Championship.

title: Dmitri Dmitrov, a Hollywood Anachronism
description: As the matre d of the Tower Bar, Mr. Dmitrov caters to stars and film executives, including Johnny Depp, Sherry Lansing, Sean Penn and Jennifer Aniston.

title: A Hollywood Anachronism, Serving Stars but Never Gossip
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Jennifer Aniston is Table 24, a coveted perch with a view of the piano yet screened from prying eyes by a bank of Casablanca lilies. Anderson Cooper is Table 11, with its panoramic view across the dining room. Sean Penn is Table 20, except on those nights when a certain agent hes at war with is in the house. A major studio executive who dines on successive nights with his daughter, wife and mistress is guided to cozy spots at Tables 21, 22 and 12.

title: Young Generations Best Skip a World Title Event
description: At the recent World Junior Chess Championship in Chennai, India, Dariusz Swiercz of Poland, 17, won the overall title, and Cori T. Deysi of Peru, 18, captured the girls crown.

title: Corrections: August 21
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Battle for Libya | August 20, 2011
description: Rebels encircle Tripoli.

title: Alex Rodriguez Expected to Return on Sunday vs. Twins
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Barring any setbacks, achiness, dizziness or rain, Alex Rodriguez could finally make his return to the Yankee lineup Sunday. After missing 38 games with a torn meniscus in his right knee, Rodriguez went through another rigorous workout Saturday and proclaimed himself ready.

title: Lottery Numbers
In New Jersey, 4 Teenage Boys Die in Crash of an S.U.V. Carrying 8
description: Four teenage boys were killed and four other boys injured when the sport utility vehicle they were in crashed and rolled several times on the Garden State Parkway near Egg Harbor Township, in southern New Jersey.

title: Burnett Leaves Early in Anger, and Girardi Heatedly Defends Him
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Yankees Manager Joe Girardis support of A. J. Burnett went to a new level Saturday when he angrily lashed out at questions about the pitchers most recent debacle after the Yankees 9-4 loss to the Minnesota Twins.

title: The 2011 Report Card on Beaches
description: A 27-page report from New Yorkers for Parks says the citys municipal beaches have shown a vast improvement in recent years.

title: Deadly Airliner Crash in Canadian Arctic
description: OTTAWA  A Boeing 737 crashed in Canadas high Arctic on Saturday, killing 12 of the 15 people on board, the government transportation agency said.

title: Ghosts of Learning
description: The Erasmus Hall Academy, a landmark building in Brooklyn, sits unused in a state of decay.

title: Overview: Rolls-Royce 200EX
description: Maintaining a powerful presence while downsizing to a more rational scale is a challenge for designers.

title: Overview: 2009 BMW 7 Series
description: The new 7 Series is a double delight, whether in standard or stretched-out guise.

title: 2009 Acura TL
description: An overview of the new 2009 Acura TL SH-AWD sedan.

title: Brazil Wins Under-20 World Cup
description: Brazil won the FIFA Under-20 World Cup for the fifth time on Saturday night, beating Portugal, 3-2, in extra time in Bogota, Colombia.

title: Czanne and Beyond
description: A show at the Philadelphia Museum of Art intersperses the works of 18 modern and contemporary artists among works by the prolific master.

title: Fallons Comedy Career
description: Jimmy Fallon, the former Saturday Night Live comedian, brings his act to Late Night fives time a week.

title: Arrrr!
description: Raising the sails on the schooner, yesterday:

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Watchmen
description: Zack Snyder, the director of Watchmen, narrates a look at a scene from the film. The directors cut is now on DVD.

title: 2011 Houston Texans Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He wraps up the A.F.C. South today with a look at the Houston Texans. He wrote previously about the Colts,  the Titans and the Jaguars.

title: Londons Notting Hill Carnival Still on Despite Recent Rioting
description: Because of the million or more people who attend it, the Notting Hill Carnival, an annual celebration of Caribbean culture, can feel overwhelming to say the least. Sprawling over roughly 20 miles of West London, the carnival is often cited as one of the largest street festivals in Europe. This years festival takes place on Aug. 28 and 29, from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m.

title: California Court Weighs Proposition 8
description: A ballot initiative that outlawed gay marriage faces a legal test in the California Supreme Court. The hearing has drawn supporters and opponents of the measure.

title: Taking Baby Photos Youll Drool Over
description: Babies dont take direction very well (if they did we should start by getting them to shush on airplanes), but Me Ra Koh has made a specialty of coaxing warm, memorable photos from infants, newborns and children. She has had her work showcased on Oprah, written how-to books such as Your Baby in Pictures, and teaches womens workshops.

title: A Memorial to Colonial Life
description: The convent in southern France that will house a controversial memorial to the pieds noirs.

title: First Peek Inside Citi Field
description: The Mets new stadium is nearing completion as the baseball season nears.

title: Russia Trip Hints North Korea Is Ready to Do Business
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An armored train carried the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il to a hydroelectric plant in Siberia on Sunday, according to news reports and two South Korean officials, amid signs that Mr. Kim might be seeking a lucrative role in relaying Russian energy sources to South Korea and Japan.

title: Pope Urges Pilgrims in Spain to Stay True to Their Beliefs
description: MADRID  Pope Benedict XVI closed the religious ceremonies of World Youth Day on Sunday with a giant Mass in which he told young people to swim against the tide and abide by the principles of the Catholic Church despite broader changes in society.

title: Seeking a Functioning Parliament, Afghan Panel Upends Vote Results
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The beleaguered election commission here declared on Sunday, after months of intense political pressure, that it would change the results of the latest parliamentary elections.

title: German Leaders Reiterate Opposition to Euro Bonds as a Way to Ease Crisis
description: FRANKFURT  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Sunday re-emphasized her opposition to issuing bonds backed by all the euro zone countries, a position that will be greeted enthusiastically by many of her fellow citizens but could unsettle investors at the beginning of what could be another difficult week in global financial markets.

title: Huntsman Calls His Rivals Unelectable
description: WASHINGTON  Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former Utah governor who has been stuck in the second tier of candidates for the Republican presidential nomination, took an aggressive new tone during a televised interview on Sunday, saying that recent remarks from two of his major rivals were extreme and unrealistic.

title: Former Oasis Singer Sues His Brother
description: The battling Gallagher brothers are it again, and this time the feud is heading to court. Liam Gallagher, erstwhile singer of Oasis, is suing his brother and former bandmate, Noel, for saying last month that Liams hangover forced the band to cancel a concert two years ago.

title: Show Goes on for Petkovic, Even in Defeat
description: 3:01 p.m. | Updated MASON, Ohio  The line tennis players straddle between entertaining their fans and their own best interests was illustrated poignantly Saturday night by Andrea Petkovic, who played her semifinal against Jelena Jankovic at the Western and Southern Open with a meniscus tear in her surgically-repaired right knee.

title: Jubilant Rebels Control Much of Tripoli
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis grip on power dissolved with astonishing speed on Monday as rebels marched into the capital and arrested two of his sons, while residents raucously celebrated the prospective end of his four-decade-old rule.

title: Conan Proves Weaker Than He Looks
description: It was a weekend of carnage at the box office, but not in the way that Conan the Barbarian had hoped. That gory remake, financed by Nu Image for about $90 million and distributed by Lionsgate, took in an anemic $10 million in North American theaters. A variety of factors probably contributed, including a lack of interest by women in the subject matter, terrible reviews and a release date when consumers were distracted with vacations or back-to-school preparations. Two other new films also flopped. A $30 million remake of Fright Night (DreamWorks Studios) sold $8.3 million in tickets, while the $15 million drama One Day (Focus Features) took in $5 million.

title: Fans Flock to Disney Expo in California
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Fans are by their nature hyper-enthusiastic. But throw red meat at them  as the Walt Disney Company did to devotees here over the weekend, previewing new movies and theme park rides  and the clamor can be downright daunting, especially for buttoned-up Disney executives.

title: Team Claims It Has Found Oldest Fossils
description: A team of Australian and British geologists have discovered fossilized, single-cell organisms that are 3.4 billion years old and that the scientists say are the oldest known fossils on earth.

title: John J. Kelley, Marathon Champion, Dies at 80
description: John J. Kelley, a former high school English teacher who won the 1957 Boston Marathon and eight consecutive national marathon championships, died Sunday in North Stonington, Conn. He was 80.

title: Rebels Close In on Tripoli
description: As rebels crept to within 10 miles of the Libyan capital, they vowed to combine forces with insurgents who have waged intense battles inside Tripoli.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Infectious Opportunity
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festivals close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: 1928 Coventry Eagle, Rival of the Brough Superior, Sells for $265,000 at Pebble Beach
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  One of the top sales over all on Thursday, and the highest-grossing motorcycle sold during the week of collector vehicle auctions around the 2011 Pebble Beach Concours dlgance, was a 1928 Coventry Eagle Flying-8. It went across the block at Bonhams for $265,000, including commission.

title: Pixar Announces Two Original Films
description: Pixar Animation Studios, battered a bit by critics of late for its embrace of sequels like Cars 2, announced two new original films over the weekend, although details were spare and both are still untitled.

title: Aug. 21 Updates on the Battle for Tripoli
description: On Sunday, The Lede is following the battle for the Libyan capital, Tripoli, as rebel forces seek to push Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from power after nearly 42 years.

title: South Jersey Stunned by Deaths of 4 Teammates
description: Those stunned and saddened by the loss of four high school football players in a crash on the Garden State Parkway continued to stop by their school on Sunday, dropping off flowers and football balloons and searching for solace.

title: Confessions of an Ex-Moralist
description: The day I became an atheist was the day I realized I had been a believer.

title: Finding a Way Home via Soccer
description: It has been the summer of cups in 2011.

title: Portraits Redrawn: J.A. Reynolds
description: When it comes to remembering his son, J.A. Reynolds likes to spend time in the community garden they both built.

title: A Conservative Beachhead in the Sunshine
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  The mid-90s were rough on Democrats, especially here in this beachhead of fabulously wealthy political donors. Their money wasnt enough to keep the Democratic Party in control of Congress. The famous Kennedy estate on North Ocean Boulevard, known as the Winter White House during the administration of John F. Kennedy, was sold to a New York banker who now holds Republican fund-raisers there.

title: Airstrike Kills 7 in Northern Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Seven Iraqis traveling in a pickup truck were killed in an airstrike on Sunday in Iraqi Kurdistan, the semiautonomous region in northern Iraq, according to local officials. Two of the victims were children, they added.

title: Efforts Seek to Restore Calm Between Israel and Hamas
description: JERUSALEM  A fragile cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, appeared to be taking hold on Monday after days of intense rocket fire from Gaza and Israeli airstrikes on the Palestinian enclave, actions that have taken casualties on both sides.

title: Dollar Thrifty Asks for Best and Final Takeover Bids
description: 9:19 p.m. | Updated

title: The Struggles They Faced After That Day
description: There were bodies crashing into the street, the man with the goatee recalls. A short-haired woman, her face badly scarred, says, We actually felt the heat coming toward the window, where we are. A teenage boy, his eyes full of pain, thinks back: I remember shaking, just my legs just really just shaking.

title: Mets Offense Offers Little Support to Dickey
description: The cap on Terry Collinss head sat slightly askew. Exasperation was spread plainly across his face.

title: A Charity Case Casting
description: Alysia Reiner (Sideways) will star in A Charity Case, a new play about adoption by the Australian playwright Wendy Beckett. The play, which Ms. Beckett will also direct, is to begin previews at the Clurman Theater on Oct. 28, with an opening night set for Nov. 1. Additional casting has yet to be announced. As described in a news release, Ms. Becketts play examines the adoption triangle between a birth mother, the relinquishing mother and a 17-year-old daughter.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data scheduled to be released this week will include new-home sales for July (Tuesday); durable goods for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and the first revision of second-quarter gross domestic product and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for August (Friday).

title: When a Tornado in Queens Becomes an International Incident
description: The savage tornado that ripped through Brooklyn and Queens last September did not just fell some 3,000 trees and damage many houses.

title: Assad Says He Rejects Wests Calls to Resign
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria dismissed American and European calls for him to step down as meaningless on Sunday, and he declared that Syrias ailing economy could withstand escalating international sanctions.

title: Childhood Images and Wildes Torments
description: As the summer comes to an end Bargemusic is increasing the new-music quotient at its concerts, in preparation for the four-day new-music celebration that has become the barges Labor Day weekend tradition in recent years. The pianist Doris Stevenson offered a teaser for these festivities on Thursday evening, when she played an energetic, bright-edged Here and Now recital.

title: A Championship Is Up for Grabs in Croatia
description: OPATIJA, Croatia  Play in the second World Youth Congress, for players born on or after Jan. 1, 1986, was scheduled to start here on Monday. Nestled in the northwest of the country, this picturesque town on the Adriatic coast about a three-hour drive from Venice makes a great location for a bridge event.

title: Hindu Mythology Comes to Life on the Streets of New York
description: The tourist in me looks forward each year to the Downtown Dance Festivals open-air performances. Some of the dances the festival presents are considerably less equal than others, but every year I know Im going to see companies new to me, often from other parts of the world, all playing against memorable settings in southernmost Manhattan.

title: Girardi Discusses Burnett, Calmly
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Late Saturday night, after A.J. Burnett stormed off the mound with a three-word, double-profanity outburst, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi defended the struggling pitcher with a small outburst of his own during a postgame session with reporters.

title: Let It Rain
description: On Par columnist Bill Pennington doesn't let a little rain stop him from playing golf.

title: The TouchPad Finally Sells  At 80% Off
description: Hewlett-Packard finally found a way to get shoppers to buy its TouchPad tablet  a steep discount  but not until after it had pulled the plug on the device because of poor sales.

title: Rebels Head Toward Tripoli
description: The Timess Kareem Fahim reports from Zawiyah, Libya, where rebels are advancing toward Tripoli.

title: Stravinskys Catalog Yields Tasty Plums
description: The Mostly Mozart Festivals secondary focus on Stravinsky this summer has been a hit, no doubt because the most frequently heard of his works  the three early ballets, the various incarnations of LHistoire du Soldat and Pulcinella  have largely been bypassed in favor of worthy scores that are not programmed continuously through the season.

title: How to Sleep on a Plane
description: More than two million travelers will board commercial airplanes today. Check-in kiosks. Sockfeet at security. Overhead storage.

title: Font Pain and Poetry: So Much Depends on a Curve
description: Font wonks fight. They champion some typefaces and sneer at others. They go ballistic if a system of signage is altered, as when Ikea changed its designated corporate font from Futura to Verdana in 2009. And they show off tribal symbols. A T-shirt that is depicted in Simon Garfields Just My Type: A Book About Fonts is adorned with nothing but the ornate ampersand of the font Caslon. This graphic, Mr. Garfield remarks, is capable of occasionally eliciting a nod from another aficionado, like smug fans of a cool pop band before it becomes famous.

title: Monday: Doughnuts, Topologically Speaking
