description: Prosecutors from the Manhattan district attorneys office formally moved on Monday to dismiss the three-month-old sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, filing a 25-page motion that serves as their intricate and devastating anatomy of a case collapsing.

title: Rebels Assault on Tripoli Began With Careful Work Inside
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Among the rebel leaders it was referred to as zero hour, the moment when residents of Tripoli would rise up against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces after a six-month war in the desert that had failed to break his 42-year grip on power.

title: Raiders Choice of Pryor Is Another Bet on Speed
description: For as long as Al Davis has been the Oakland Raiders owner and all-powerful personnel executive, he has coveted speed in his players, sometimes to the exclusion of other skills and occasionally in the absence of common sense.

title: Rethinking Libya and Oil Prices
description: The endgame in Libya could herald a slump in oil prices. As with the rebel advance into Tripoli, Libyan supplies to the global market could come sooner than expected. Brent crude prices slipped by as much as $3 to almost $106 a barrel at one point on Monday, before rebounding later in the day. A resolution in Libya, coupled with concerns over global growth, means tight markets could soon look oversupplied.

title: Shortchanged by the Bell
description: AFTER a summer of budget cuts in Washington and state capitals, we have only to look to our schools, when classes begin in the next few weeks, to see who will pay the price.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jerry Leiber, Prolific Writer of 1950s Hits, Dies at 78
description: Jerry Leiber, the lyricist who, with his partner, Mike Stoller, wrote some of the most enduring classics in the history of rock n roll, including Hound Dog, Yakety Yak, Stand By Me and On Broadway, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 78.

title: Hip Implant Complaints Surge, Even as the Dangers Are Studied
description: The federal government has received a surge in complaints in recent months about failed hip replacements, suggesting that serious problems persist with some types of artificial hips even as researchers scramble to evaluate the health dangers.

title: Looking for Gas in All the Wrong Places
description: It was a big week in Andes, N.Y. Last Thursday, the New York Post devoted a full page to the small Catskill village, describing in some detail the Andes Hotel, the surrounding rolling corn and hay fields, the affordable housing, the Hunting Tavern Museum, the country store, the coffee shop, the tea shop, the farmers market, the art galleries and antique stores, the occasional celebrity resident, the extraordinary natural beauty  everything that led the Post, in an earlier article about great day-trip destinations, to dub Andes Woodstock-as-it-used-to-be.

title: The Wild Rose of Washington
description: Washington, Aug. 23, 1861 Just before 11 a.m., Rose ONeal Greenhow, a dark-haired, dark-eyed Washington widow in her 40s, walked toward her house on 16th Street. Greenhow circulated among the capitals elite social circles, and her home stood within sight of the White House. Despite the sweltering heat, she stopped to talk with a neighbor. A Union guard, she learned, had been placed in front of Greenhows house earlier that morning.

title: Cut Medicare, Help Patients
description: MEDICARE is going to be cut. That is inevitable. There is no way to solve the nations long-term debt problem without reducing the growth rate of federal health care spending. The only question is whether the cuts will be smart ones.

title: Documents in the Strauss-Kahn Case
description: A collection of court documents and filings pertaining to the sexual assault case involving the former head of the International Monetary Fund.

title: After Uprising, Rebels Face a Struggle for Unity
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  With rebels on the verge of ending Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis long reign, the character of their movement is facing its first real test: Can they build a new government of unity and reconciliation, or will their own internal rivalries mean divisions in the new Libya?

title: The Rugged Altruists
description: Nairobi, Kenya

title: Standard & Poors President to Step Down
description: 11:20 p.m. | Updated

title: How Democrats Hurt Jobs
description: The airplanes aft section arrived early Monday morning. Thats what theyd been waiting for at the final assembly plant in North Charleston, S.C. They already had the wings, the nose, the tail  all the other major sections of Boeings new 787 Dreamliner. With the arrival of the aft, the 5,000 nonunion workers in the plant can finally begin to assemble their first aircraft  a plane three years behind schedule and critical to Boeings future.

title: Qaddafis Final Hours
description: For more than 40 years, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has dominated and terrorized Libya  his image plastered on what seemed like every wall and his goons posted on every corner. Late Monday, with rebel fighters in substantial control of Tripoli, he was nowhere to be found, and his regime seemed to be collapsing.

title: Tuesday: Its a Blessing
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Michael Farabaugh just made his New York Times debut in April (Across Lite, Solution, blog), but he is back today with a list theme that shows us four different ways to think of Bolts.

title: Hell Take You Anywhere You Want to Go
description: Finding your seat at the Atlantic Theater Companys tiny Stage 2 isnt easy. (Hint: the numbers are on the bottoms of the seats.) So when one man is still standing, hovering over the first row, just before the lights go down for the beginning of Simon Stephenss Bluebird, which opened on Monday night, youre inclined to make allowances.

title: Lane Venardos, Ex-CBS News Vice President, Dies at 67
description: Lane Venardos, the executive producer of the CBS Evening News in the 1980s and later the networks vice president for hard news, overseeing its coverage of the protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989 and the Persian Gulf war a year later, died on Friday at his home in Maui, Hawaii. He was 67.

title: Egypt Disavows Threat to Recall Envoy to Israel
description: CAIRO  Egypts foreign minister, Mohammed Amr, said Monday that the plan to recall the nations ambassador to Israel was never on the table, confirming the governments decision to disavow a threat that generated widespread popular support at home but brought the government under intense diplomatic pressure to back off.

title: A City Game
description: Tennis players fill public courts across New York Citys five boroughs.

title: Courts, Characters and a Love of a Game
description: TheUnited States Open starts on Monday, beginning two weeks of elite tennis, expensive eating and celebrity sightings. The rest of the year, though, another kind of tennis tournament unspools in New Yorks public parks  a less structured, less moneyed daily draw that pulls people of all ages and skills onto all or some of the 595 public courts in the five boroughs. Earl Wilson has hit on many of those courts for more than 35 years, refining his ground strokes, running down drop shots and taking his lumps, all the while cataloging his finest moments and the most dubious of court characters. What appears below is some reminiscing, a mix of romance and regret.

title: A Council Speaker Who Tightens the Purse Strings on Dissent
description: To drive down Kings Highway in East Flatbush is to pass block after block of near-identical brick homes, neat gardens, statuary and ironwork.

title: The Top Courts of New York City
description: The city is the home of the United States Open, but also 595 public tennis courts that daily attract players of all ages and skills. Some favorites:

title: Dean of Columbia College Resigns After Two Years
description: The dean of Columbia College has abruptly resigned over what she called administrative changes that would diminish or eliminate her authority, leaving the undergraduate division of Columbia University without a leader two weeks before the start of classes.

title: Its a Flawed Settlement
description: The Obama administration has turned up the heat on Eric Schneiderman, New Yorks attorney general, to go along with a proposed settlement with the nations largest banks over dubious foreclosure practices. Mr. Schneiderman should stand his ground in not supporting the deal. The administration says that a settlement would quickly deliver much needed relief to hard-pressed borrowers, but its doubtful it would provide redress on a par with the banks wrongdoing or borrowers needs.

title: W. B. Kannel, Who Led Historic Heart Study, Dies at 87
description: William B. Kannel, a cardiovascular epidemiologist whose work helped to identify and sought to rout the culprits behind heart attacks, strokes and other cardiovascular diseases, died on Saturday in Natick, Mass. He was 87.

title: View of Future Depends on the Dugout
description: PHILADELPHIA  There was a time not long ago when the Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies would clash fiercely on the field, and then snipe at each other through the news media, to assert their perceived supremacy in the National League East.

title: As U.S. Open Nears, Tennis Channel and Cablevision Are Still Battling
description: The Tennis Channel has, for years, wanted to be carried by cable operators on their most widely available levels. In most cases, that means digital basic.

title: Conservation, Beyond Boundaries
description: Over the past 25 years, the number of conservation areas set aside for the nonhuman species has grown considerably. Globally, there are now more than 100,000 protected areas, including national parks, biological reserves and marine sanctuaries. All told, they protect slightly less than 13 percent of the land on earth and slightly more than a half-percent of the oceans, though only a minute fraction are no-take zones that bar fishing. But can these protected areas do enough to protect biological diversity?

title: Where Crime Is Up Across the Board, More Police but Not Many Jitters
description: Though crime is all around him, Sal Bucak is not afraid of the streets.

title: U.S. Issues New Deportation Policys First Reprieves
description: The call came in the morning to the lawyer representing Manuel Guerra, an illegal immigrant from Mexico living in Florida who had been caught in a tortuous and seemingly failing five-year court fight against deportation.

title: Where History Casts a Fearsome Shadow, Murmurings About the Far Right
description: STUTTGART, Germany  The swastika is illegal here, as is the Hitler salute. Germans have learned after decades of fighting their expression that the ideas behind them cannot be outlawed.

title: Florida Psychic and Her Family Cheated Clients of $40 Million, Prosecutors Say
description: MIAMI  The promise of good karma did not come cheaply for devotees of a South Florida psychic whom federal prosecutors have portrayed as the matriarch of a fortune-telling family with a lust for luxury.

title: Qaddafis Family Tree
description: As Libyan rebels closed in on Tripoli, they claimed to have captured three of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis sons. A look at the rest of the beleaguered leaders family tree.

description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy has used the crisis over the euro and his relationship with the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, to set a potential political trap for the Socialist opposition less than nine months before the French presidential election.

title: Nora Bredes, Who Fought Long Island Nuclear Plant, Dies at 60
description: Nora Bredes, the primary organizer of the grass-roots campaign that kept the Shoreham nuclear power plant on the North Shore of Long Island from opening in the 1980s  a campaign that prompted the plant to become known, in the words of the local power authority, as Americas first stillborn reactor  died on Thursday in Rochester. She was 60 and lived in Pittsford, N.Y.

description: Joshua Foust, left, of the American Security Project and Daniel Serwer of Johns Hopkins University debate maintaining order in Libya.

title: Super Disclose Them
description: Washingtons influence-peddlers are already out in full force, circling the new deficit-cutting supercommittee. Now Congress needs to make sure that lobbying  and every dollar of campaign contributions to the committees members  is fully and immediately disclosed.

title: Editor Said to Receive Pay After He Took Tory Post
description: LONDON  The former News of the World editor Andy Coulson received hundreds of thousands of dollars in severance pay from his former employer after joining now-Prime Minister David Camerons Conservative Party as director of communications in 2007, according to a British Broadcasting Corporation report on Monday evening.

title: Amid Heckling, Candidates in Queens Discuss Spending
description: Bob Turner, the Republican candidate in the Sept. 13 special election in New Yorks Ninth Congressional District, planted his hands on his hips and scowled. Government spending was out of control, he said, and something had to be done.

title: Big Victory, but Huge Loss in the Secondary
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J  In a game that featured a blocked punt, the Giants first offensive touchdown of the preseason and one of the prettiest jukes Brandon Jacobs has shown in some time, the lasting moment Monday night came on a nondescript screen pass from Bears quarterback Jay Cutler to running back Marion Barber.

title: Nick Ashford, of Motown Writing Duo, Dies at 70
description: Nick Ashford, who with Valerie Simpson, his songwriting partner and later his wife, wrote some of Motowns biggest hits, like Aint No Mountain High Enough and Aint Nothing Like the Real Thing, before they remade their careers as a recording and touring duo, died on Monday in New York City. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

In a speech that might begin, When I was your age , the grown-up describes how life, or at least his or her memory and perception of it, used to be. Have you had these sorts of conversations? If so, what the adults say? What are the biggest differences they perceive between today and back in the day?

title: Fantasy Focus: Mostly Lesser Known Keeper Targets
description: Over time, Ive come to the realization that I cant win each and every league Im a part of, so by this point in the year, Im focusing on 2012 in several cases. A couple of my leagues have a rule that unless a minor league prospect is drafted and held on a roster, he cannot be picked up on the waiver wire until hes promoted to the big leagues. In many keeper leagues, there is a provision for allowing a certain number of minor leaguers to be drafted. Therefore, top prospects like Mike Trout, Julio Teheran and Eric Hosmer didnt come up on waivers because they were already on rosters in such leagues.

On Sept. 17 and 18, however, hundreds of the famous buildings, bridges, and towers that pepper the citys skyline will welcome visitors as a part of the Open House Weekend. The number of sites and events listed for the weekend includes more than 700 individual locations, including behind-the-scenes tours of the Bank of England, a look at a liveaboard community of houseboats, and walking or biking tours of many architecturally significant neighborhoods.

title: Wild Man Willey, the Player and the Legend
description: A few thoughts about Norm Willey, one of the forgotten players of the pre-television age. Over the years, his performance against the Giants in a 1952 game has become the stuff of myth and legend. Willey died Thursday at age 83.

description: Jonathan Sorrell, a top executive at Goldman Sachs, will join the Man Group as head of strategy for the European hedge fund giant, a spokesman for Goldman Sachs confirmed.

title: Daphne Rubin-Vega and Wood Harris Set for Streetcar Revival on Broadway
description: Theyve played some of the toughest characters that New York and Baltimore had to offer, and now Daphne Rubin-Vega and Wood Harris are headed into a famously rugged depiction of New Orleans in a 2012 Broadway production of A Streetcar Named Desire, its producers said on Tuesday. Ms. Rubin-Vega, who originated the role of Mimi in the New York Theater Workshop and Broadway incarnations of Rent, will play Stella, the timid wife of Stanley and sister of Blanche DuBois. Mr. Harris, who played the drug kingpin Avon Barksdale on the HBO drama The Wire, will play Mitch, Stanleys muscle-building pal who develops an attraction to Blanche. Blair Underwood and Nicole Ari Parker were previously announced to play Stanley and Blanche in this latest Streetcar revival, the first time that the Tennessee Williams play has been presented on Broadway since 2005. It will be directed by Emily Mann, the artistic director of the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., and presented in the spring at a theater to be determined. It is produced by Stephen Byrd and Alia M. Jones of Front Row Productions, who produced the 2008 Broadway revival of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof that featured an African-American cast.

title: Fewer Banks in the U.S. Considered to Be at Risk
description: The number of banks on the governments list of institutions most at risk for failure fell in the second quarter, the first drop since before the financial crisis began.

title: Leading Off: Raiders Strike Again
description: There is something oddly satisfying about having the Raiders in the N.F.L., setting aside for the moment their fans part in the violence at Candlestick Park last weekend, because staying satisfied involves not attending any actual Raiders games. But they play such a great role in poking a hole in the N.F.L.s carefully cultivated image of order and precision, the facade of being run by civic-minded, forthright businessmen. The Raiders are like the crazy aunt the otherwise mostly respectable N.F.L. cant uninvite to Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Asked & Answered | Vera Farmiga
description: For Vera Farmiga, a Ukrainian-American actress whose reputably selective film career includes Down to the Bone, The Departed and 2009s Up in the Air, which garnered her an Academy Award nomination, the movies are a family affair. In her directorial debut, Higher Ground, based on the novel by Carolyn S. Briggs and opening on Aug. 26, Farmiga handles a solid cast of actors, which includes her younger sister Taissa Farmiga and John Hawkes (American Gangster and the forthcoming drama Martha Marcy May Marlene), as she recounts the story of a woman named Corinne Walker  a mother and wife and child of God  who struggles with doubt and disbelief as she searches for her identity, her instrument. I wanted to make sure that what pervaded the film was the character of music and its capacity to unite people, says Farmiga of her hymn-heavy picture, produced by Farmiga and her rocker husband, Renn Hawkey, of the band Deadsy. Just days before the films opening, Farmiga spoke to The Moment about family, how she came upon Higher Ground and what separates the girls from the women.

Why would anyone want to go back to a conflict, let alone one that has been raging for almost 10 years, first as front-page news and now as a side story to political discussion about the national debt? title: Lighting the Way
description: The Blind Barber in the East Village loves a good surprise. On the surface it operates as a classic barbershop, piles of shorn hair on the floor and all, but it also houses a secret speakeasy in the back room offering banquette seating, live D.J.s and top-shelf whiskey. Now, not even their canisters of barbicide can be trusted. Teaming up with Joya, the New York company that makes all-natural fragrances for Rodarte and Opening Ceremony, the Bind Barber has crafted a signature soy wax candle thats packaged to look just like the antiseptic used to keep combs and scissors minty fresh. Notes of lavender, smoke and leather echo the scents of an old-fashioned cut and shave. Now thats sharp.

title: Spanish Leaders Back Constitutional Amendment to Limit Debt
description: MADRID  Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero on Tuesday won support from a key opposition leader for a constitutional amendment that would limit deficit levels and the amount of debt that the Spanish state could take on.

title: Romney Condemns Bidens Comments on Chinas One-Child Policy
description: 3:45 p.m. | Updated  Though Mitt Romney is waiting until the fall to lay out most of his serious policy proposals, he has started weighing in on international issues (Syria, Libya) from the campaign trail in recent weeks. On Tuesday he condemned Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for comments that seemed to condone Chinas controversial one-child policy.

title: Facebook Aims to Simplify Privacy Settings
description: Didnt mean for your boss to see a picture of you on the beach that day you called in sick? Maybe you hadnt meant for the police to know you were mobilizing your friends to join a public protest? Had you bargained on your high school principal seeing Facebook photographs that they considered so risqu they kicked you off the cheerleading squad?

title: USA! USA! USA!
description: Or, more precisely, New Jersey! New Jersey! New Jersey! You got a problem with that?

title: A New Roost for Angry Birds: Your Television
description: As more and more content is crammed into our little mobile phones, one tech company is going in the opposite direction, putting the ubiquitous cellphone app Angry Birds onto our big screen TVs.

title: Earthquake Is Felt in New York
description: Updated, 2:48 p.m. | The vibrations of an earthquake centered in Virginia were felt in New York City on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Good Odds of First U.S. Hurricane Strike Since 2008
description: Theres a solid, though by no means assured, chance that the United States within a few days will experience its first coastal strike from a hurricane since September 2008. (In the last few days, the trend in storm tracks for Hurricane Irene has been ever more to the east, leading to a chance the storm will end up skirting the East Coast. Click on the animated sequence of National Hurricane Center forecasts to see the easterly trend.)

title: Above All Else, Eastern Quake Rattles Nerves
description: Of all the things there are to worry about, earthquakes are fairly low on the list for those on the East Coast. So it was startling, just as the lunch hour was ending Tuesday and workers in a broad area of North America were settling back into their cubicles, when floors began to shake and chairs rocked.

title: Earthquake Shakes Eastern United States
description: The Lede is providing updates on the aftermath of a 5.8 magnitude earthquake that struck the eastern United States on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Businessmen and Macroeconomics
description: Matt Yglesias is mildly upset over a report that Obama is turning to Warren Buffet and Alan Mulally for economic advice. Its not clear how much to make of the report. But its always good to remember that businessmen  even great businessmen  dont necessarily know much about how to make the macroeconomy work.

title: Net-a-Porters Fashion at the Click of a Mouse
description: MY first encounter with luxury fashion came at age 15, when my dapper father took me past the fragrance counters of Saks Fifth Avenue, up the mirrored escalators to whichever floor was then housing the gilded designer salons (instead of the jammed racks of so-called better dresses, with all that ominously implies). Hitherto I had shopped at the humbler, now-defunct Gimbels on Lexington Avenue, supplementing my meager haul with the occasional vial of mascara shoplifted from the even more cut-rate Woolworth down the street. But here, in the hushed confines of Calvin Klein, we happened upon a camel-hair cape whose price tag, to my youthful astonishment, displayed four figures.

title: Egypt Names Antiquities Chief to Replace Hawass
description: A month after Egypts controversial antiquities chief, Zahi Hawass, was ousted in a cabinet reshuffle, Egypts prime minister, Essam Sharaf, has appointed a successor. Mohamed Abdel Fattah, the head of the antiquities sector at the Supreme Council of Antiquities, will become the councils secretary general, the position Mr. Hawass held before former President Hosni Mubarak elevated the council to a ministry. Mr. Sharaf had previously indicated that he planned to return the council to its former status.

title: Reviewing Robertas
description: Reviewing Robertas

title: Ninja Warriors Improve NBCs Ratings
description: With a title like American Ninja Warrior, one cant help but raise an intrigued eyebrow, and that curiosity turned into solid ratings for NBC on Monday when the season finale of the obstacle course program reached nearly four million total viewers. Its audience actually grew in the second hour, averaging 4.3 million viewers and winning the 10 p.m. time slot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. It was the highest-rated program in that advertiser-coveted category for NBC in that time slot since the Macys Fourth of July Fireworks Spectacular.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: The Mountain Song
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festivals close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Tennessees Summitt Reveals Dementia Diagnosis
description: Pat Summitt, the longtime womens basketball coach at Tennessee who has won more games than any other major college coach, said she forgot things at crucial points in games at times last season and struggled to keep track of when meetings were scheduled. She grew so confused that on a few days she simply stayed home from work.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 23
description: The world judo championships kicked off in Paris, and Dirk Nowitzki was back on the basketball courts in Germany, his home country.

title: New Porsche 911 Is Previewed Ahead of Frankfurt Auto Show
description: Porsche previewed its 911 Carrera and Carrera S on Tuesday in advance of their formal reveal, scheduled for the Frankfurt auto show in September.

title: A Weekend in Madrid
description: The Frugal Traveler Breaks the $100 Limit

title: Off the Shelf | Art Forms in Nature
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#427", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: With False Tale About Gang Rape, Strauss-Kahn Case Crumbles
description: For those who thought, as I did, that the best way to resolve the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case was to have a jury decide his guilt or innocence, the brief filed this week by the office of the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., shows in powerful detail why that approach almost certainly would have been unethical and a fools errand.

title: TimesCast | Strauss-Kahn Free
description: A judge on Tuesday dismissed the sexual assault case at the prosecution's request.

title: Fears About Bid Rock Temple-Inlands Shares
description: Shares of Temple-Inland, the target of a $3.3 billion hostile offer by the International Paper Company, plunged on Tuesday after a lawsuit accused Temple-Inland of helping cause the failure of a Texas bank.

title: Allies of Strauss-Kahn Express Relief, but His Role in France Remains Unclear
description: PARIS  Prominent members of Frances Socialist Party expressed relief that Dominique Strauss-Kahn would soon be a free man after he was cleared Tuesday of charges of attempted rape in New York. But his political career is clearly damaged by the months of investigation and notoriety, and no one publicly urged him to run for the presidency, even though a party primary is only seven weeks away.

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company Goes Back to Work
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the ninth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from a week off in New York City.

title: Travel Groups Withdraw From Charity Give Back Group
description: Several major travel companies, including Westin Hotels and Resorts, Expedia.com and Hotels.com, have withdrawn their advertisements from the Charity Give Back Group, formerly the Christian Values Network, a Web site that allows consumers to give a percentage of each purchase they make from retailers advertising on the site to one of its participating charitable organizations.

title: Gaps in Cellphone Service After Earthquake
description: 3:37 p.m. | Updated  Adding Verizon and T-Mobile comments.

title: The MAC Is Back, but Does It Kill a Deal?
description: The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management and its partner, the Chatham Lodging Trust, say they have terminated their $1.1 billion acquisition of 64 hotels from Innkeepers USA Trust, arguing that a material adverse change has occurred. A deal-breaking move like this makes it feel like we are back in the financial crisis, when these attempts were all too common.

title: Claes Oldenburgs Paintbrush Erected in Philadelphia
description: Paint Torch, a 51-foot-long sculpture of a paintbrush by the artist Claes Oldenburg, was installed on Saturday in Lenfest Plaza at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia. Mr. Oldenburg, 82, was present for most of the installation process, which took all day and ended with the careful positioning of a giant paint glob near the foot of the sculpture.

title: Fear, Empathy and Parenthood
description: A 7-year-old boy drowned on a beach in Nantucket, Mass., on Monday, The Cape Cod Times reported on Tuesday. He could have been any of our children. He could certainly have been Amber Hindss little one, which she realized Monday night as she tucked her 2-year-old daughter, Nora, into bed on the same island, having just learned the reason for the sirens she had heard that afternoon.

title: White House Announces Plans to Overhaul Business Regulations
description: The White House on Tuesday unveiled plans to loosen the regulatory burden for American companies, announcing cuts in regulations that administration officials said would save more than $10 billion over five years.

title: The Guests Who Never Left Strauss-Kahns Hotel Room
description: And you thought all you had to worry about when you checked into a hotel was bedbugs.

title: Making the Most of a Stove
description: THE waiter was on his second shirt. It was early evening on a deep-summer Sunday in Bushwick, Brooklyn, in the dining room of Robertas, one of the more extraordinary restaurants in the United States.

description: Map showing shake zones and damage reports from the Aug. 23 quake in Virginia.

title: Eastern Earthquake Provides Useful Warning
description: 5:17 p.m. | Updated Its great to see the widespread coverage of the eastern earthquake, despite its modest strength (although Im not sure some of the underwhelming video coverage was worthwhile).

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Afghanistan, New York and India.

title: At 90, Fashions Latest Pop Star
description: HER spectacles, as round as soup tureens, lend Iris Apfel a startled look. If she seems surprised, she has good reason. Mrs. Apfel, the subject of a string of museum exhibitions, a coffee table book and even a fashion advertising campaign, has long been a magnet to aficionados, those devotees of fashion who dote on her style  a more-is-more mix of haute couture and hippie trimmings that appears at a glance to have been blended in a Cuisinart.

title: Taking Stock of Campus Sustainability
description: Colleges and universities across the country have quickly taken to measuring their environmental footprint: energy efficiency, consumption levels, renewable energy targets, number of green buildings, recycling rates, water use and even the prevalence of sustainability curriculums. But in this rush to go green, two of the three sustainability pillars have remained largely in shadow.

title: East Coast Quake Interrupts Regulators Day
description: While Wall Street barely flinched when the 5.8-magnitude earthquake struck the East Coast on Tuesday afternoon, the industrys regulators literally trembled. In fact, many officials had to leave their Washington office buildings.

title: The Caucus Click: Rattle in the Capital
description: An unknown number of people were at the top of the Washington Monument when an earthquake shook the nations capital on Tuesday. Sergeant David Schlosser of the United States Park Police, interviewed at the site, said the agency received reports of bricks and mortar falling from the tower.

title: The Prodigy Burned Out. Why Not Blame Mom?
description: Few artists willingly give up their art. Remember Nureyevs continuing to dance despite a damaged body that could no longer take him to the heights? Young artists who make a splash are even less likely to change course, typically seeking to climb higher, the faster the better.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Afghanistan, New York and India.

title: Bending the Rules on Bacteria
description: PEPPERED as we are by government warnings about the potential health hazards of eating and drinking just about everything, it was refreshing (and perplexing) to see a widely respected food writer assert recently that people are unnecessarily afraid of bacteria in the kitchen.

title: Barley and Farro Risotto With Red Peppers
description: In your freezer, keep a supply of sturdy grains that take a while to cook; you can use them to quickly make dishes like this one. Thaw the grains overnight in the refrigerator or microwave them. High in vitamin C, vitamin A and lycopene, peppers are abundant right now in farmers markets.

title: TimesCast | Defacing Qaddafi's Symbols
description: As rebels climbed over a statue of a giant fist crushing a fighter jet inside Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi's compound, they were defacing a symbol with a long history.

title: Glee Cast Helps Fashionistas
description: It is a long way from William McKinley High School in Lima, Ohio, to Manhattan, Milan or Paris. But the glee-club members of McKinley High are helping the fashion industry promote its annual shop-till-you-drop evening.

title: Bank of America Names Top Real Estate Banker
description: Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch has named Jeff Horowitz global head of real estate, gaming and lodging, replacing Ron Sturzenegger, according to an internal memo obtained by DealBook.

title: Berlin, With Extra Hot Sauce
description: Last summer, Billy Davis, a music producer based in Berlin, invited his family, from Texas, to pay him a visit. This place is great, they observed of the German capital. The people are really nice. But wheres the taco truck? A little light went off in Daviss head.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Serves and Serving

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Down-Home Food, Hold the Hush Puppies
description: Springtime apricot salad! That sounds good.

title: Director of International Center of Photography to Step Down
description: Willis E. Hartshorn, director of the International Center of Photography since 1994, announced on Tuesday that he would step down for health reasons. No successor has been named, and Mr. Hartshorn, known as Buzz, said he would remain in his post until the institutions board of trustees completed what it said would be an international search for a new director.

title: Private Equitys Top Lobbyist Steps Down
description: Private equitys chief lobbyist announced on Tuesday that he was stepping down from his job, creating a leadership void in Washington at a crucial time for the industry.

title: Real Estate Is Looking Up
description: Images of the Utah house that was inspired by the film Up.

title: Toyota Says Camry Is Reinvented for 2012
description: Thats the most excitement that weve ever had for the introduction of a new model, Bob Carter, the Toyota division group vice president and general manager, said from a production lot at Paramount Studios in Hollywood, Calif. A troupe of dancers, skateboarders and contortionists had taken their leave just seconds earlier. Mr. Carter did not specify, however, whether the excitement was generated by, or for, the new model in question.

title: A Roadie With a Whisk
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Up, Up and Away
description: HERRIMAN, Utah  Cute is the Walt Disney Companys stock in trade, but there is nothing soft and cuddly about how it protects its intellectual property.

title: Why Another Democrat Wouldnt Do Better Than Obama in 2012
description: You know that a president is having a rough time when you start to see speculation that his party would be better off if it replaced him on the ticket.

title: A Zac Brown Band Eat and Greet
description: The Zac Brown Band dishes up an eat and greet for a few quick-on-the-computer-keyboard members of their fan club.

title: A Bailout Like No Other
description: So, I return from vacation to find that the restructuring of Greece continues to be very much a work in progress. Indeed, it now appears much more likely that Lehman Brothers will confirm a Chapter 11 plan before the European Union will work out its similar issues regarding Greece, Portugal, Ireland, Italy and Spain.

title: Paint Torch
description: The fourth large public sculpture by Mr. Oldenburg in Philadelphia was installed on Saturday.

title: Documentary on Shipbreakers, and Where Tankers Go When They Die
description: The huge container ships and tankers that cross the worlds oceans are crucial to the functioning of the global consumer economy, and yet they are also curiously marginal to our perception of the world. Many of us take for granted the goods they transport, and perhaps we think about how those goods reached us only when we fly over a major port city and catch sight of maritime giants docked under the cranes in the harbor.

title: A 9/11 Victim Is Identified by the Medical Examiner
description: The New York City medical examiners office said on Tuesday that it had identified the remains of Ernest James, 40, a victim of the World Trade Center attack.

title: Simple Vegetable Paella
description: You dont have to make this vegetable-rich dish in a paella pan, though if you do, youll get a nice layer of crusty rice on the bottom. Serve it as a main dish or as a side.

title: Lentil and Bulgur Pilaf
description: Uncooked, soaked red lentils have a refreshing flavor and a sproutlike crunch. They also retain their beguiling salmon hue, contributing welcome color to this pilaf.

title: Bells and Whistles for a Few E-Books
description: In the film versions of Pride and Prejudice the music jumps and swells at all the right moments, heightening the tension and romance of that classic Jane Austen novel.

title: Lemon Risotto With Summer Squash
description: Lemon risottos of any kind always delight guests. The lemon juice and zest are added to this comforting mixture at the end of cooking.

title: Senate Convenes Unusual Session After Earthquake
description: For a pro forma session of the Senate, it was anything but routine.

title: After Accidents, a Call for Regulation
description: Its been a tough summer for the outdoor concert business: four stage collapses, two of them fatal. The spate of accidents has shaken promoters and focused a spotlight on the lack of uniform standards in the United States for building temporary stages and for evacuating people at outdoor concerts in severe weather.

title: How Many Species? A Study Says 8.7 Million, but Its Tricky
description: In the foothills of the Andes Mountains lives a bat the size of a raspberry. In Singapore, theres a nematode worm that dwells only in the lungs of the changeable lizard.

title: Igniting a Revolution, Starting with Hound Dog
description: It was a rock n roll shot heard round the world: the quasi-accusatory snarl of Elvis Presley growling, You aint nothin but a hound dog.

title: Pataki Visit Stirs Speculation About Presidential Bid
description: Former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, who has considered running for president in the past, is again mulling a bid for the Republican nomination and is planning a high-profile appearance in Iowa this weekend.

title: Love with Staying Power
description: An element always in short supply around pop music is emotional realism as salve, rather than as shock or cudgel or propaganda. Crazy love often makes a good three-minute single. Patient love often doesnt.

title: Drawbacks of an Elite Moment
description: Eli Manning and Plaxico Burress will likely never reach the same high as they did in Super Bowl XLII.

title: After the Revolution, Hurdles in Reviving the Oil Sector
description: HOUSTON  When a new government finally takes hold in Libya, it will have every incentive to get oil production back up and running. But if history is any guide, that task will not be as simple as restarting oil wells and reopening pipelines.

title: In a Rite of Late Summer, Naumburg Concerts Finish
description: The Naumburg Orchestral Concerts had planned to present free performances by three ensembles in its four-concert series this summer, but only one  the Knights, an enterprising young chamber orchestra  made it through its programs as planned. That ensemble opened the organizations 106th season in June, with a lineup that included a commissioned work by Lisa Bielawa and the Beethoven Fifth Symphony. And the orchestra closed this summers festivities on Monday evening in Central Park with a program split between works of Schubert and Liszt.

title: Video: Drawbacks of an Elite Moment
description: Eli Manning and Plaxico Burress will likely never reach the same high as they did in Super Bowl XLII, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Teaching Gorillas, Gently, How to Be Perfect Patients
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Lying flat on his oversize silver back near the exhibit glass at Disneys Animal Kingdom, Gino gazed far into the distance, well beyond the curious gawkers. Yes, his eyes seemed to say, I am fabulous and mighty and infinitely photogenic so snap away at my 385-pound, muscle-bound physique.

title: Goldman and Citigroup Hire Moodys to Salvage Bond Sale
description: 8:11 p.m. | Updated

title: The Hazards of Success in American Banking
description: To hear the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tell it, the banking industry is returning to fine fettle. The number of institutions on the agencys problem list fell for the first time in nearly five years. Bank failures are down. Loan books even grew slightly. So the crisis in Americas financial system is officially coming to an end.

title: 5 Deaths Reported in Syria as U.N. Investigates Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Even as a United Nations human rights team was investigating the violence in Syria, activists said Tuesday that security forces killed at least five more civilians in an assault on the suburbs of Hama, one of the countrys most restive cities.

title: Carlos Slim Adds to Stake in Times Company
description: Carlos Slim Hel, the Mexican billionaire who is by some accounts the worlds richest man, has added to his holdings in The New York Times Company.

title: Rodriguez Scratched From Yankees Lineup
description: Alex Rodriguez was scratched from the Yankees lineup Tuesday with what he described as a jammed left thumb two hours before the Yankees played the Oakland Athletics at Yankee Stadium.

title: In the Colombian Jungle, a Journeys End
description: After decades of trying, an American managed to visit the site deep in the Colombian jungle where a plane crash killed his older brother and 39 other people in 1962.

title: Ryan Says He Gave Gholston a Chance
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The underachieving former Jets lineman Vernon Gholston, now with the Chicago Bears, told reporters after Mondays preseason game against the Giants that Rex Ryan did not give him a fair chance to succeed. Not surprisingly, Ryan felt differently.

title: Rebels Storm Qaddafis Compound
description: Libyan rebel fighters overwhelmed Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis sprawling compound in Tripoli on Tuesday.

title: La Esquinas Salsa Comes Home
description: The salsa with a kick and whisper of smoke served at La Esquina restaurants in NoLIta and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is now for sale. Beyond chips and tacos, it can dress grilled fish.

title: Ashford & Simpson
description: A look at the dynamic songwriting duo of Nick Ashford and Valerie Simpson.

title: Sports Defer to TV, but Not to Athletes in Need of Relief
description: Time waits for no one. Especially when it is time to go to the bathroom.

title: Out West, Eye Rolls and Jeers for East
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Here in California, August has been just another average month in terms of earthquakes, with scores of tremors everywhere, from near the northern city of Eureka (which had an adorable little shake on Saturday) to around the Mexican border (which jittered with an even cuter temblor on Monday afternoon).

title: China Overtakes U.S. in PC Shipments
description: China has reached yet another milestone in its rise as a consumer of technology by becoming the biggest market for personal computers.

title: As Qaddafis Grip on Libya Loosens
description: To the Editor:

title: In Feds Move on Capital One Deal, a Test of Dodd-Frank
description: Capital One is the latest bank accused of being too big to fail.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: A National Health Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: A 50-Year Journey for a Proper Farewell
description: MICORA, Colombia  All that remained here, on a drizzle-shrouded ridge in the Choc jungle, was a rusting cross and some crumpled fuselage. No wonder Gordon Radley feared that the tragedy that took his brothers life five decades ago was at risk of being lost in the mists of time.

title: Swiss Banks and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: New Nordic Cuisine Draws Disciples
description: NO one saw this coming.

title: Reindeer Blood and Sheep Sorrel: New Nordic Cooking
description: A few of the chefs who have embraced the new Nordic cuisine.

title: The Value of Government
description: To the Editor:

title: In Return to Mound, Strasburg Displays Promise and Rust
description: HAGERSTOWN, Md.  On a cool, breezy night, about 76 miles northwest of the stadium where he made his mark last year as the Washington Nationals rookie pitching phenomenon, Stephen Strasburg did his best to reproduce his past brilliance.

title: Federal Inquiry Is Latest to Clear Assailed Climate Scientist
description: The National Science Foundation has found no evidence of research misconduct by Michael Mann, the Pennsylvania State University climatologist who has faced waves of attacks from foes of action to curb greenhouse gases.

title: J.P. Morgans Fortress, Long Vacant, Looks For Upscale Tenants
description: The intersection of Wall and Broad Streets, when J. P. Morgans headquarters at 23 Wall Street glowered sternly over a daily parade of stock brokers and tourists, was the epicenter of the financial world.

title: Some Builders Are Ready for the Wave of Seniors
description: EAST NORTHPORT, N.Y.  When the housing market collapsed in 2008, construction of retirement and assisted-living housing ground to a halt, just as it did in most commercial real estate sectors, as access to capital evaporated. But a few companies kept their development teams intact in the recession, and are now building new facilities and expanding their operations. And as lending loosens, they say, they are poised to benefit from the housing needs of Americas aging population.

title: Gluten-Free Flour From the French Laundry
description: It started about a year ago, when customers at the French Laundry in Yountville, Calif., began requesting gluten-free versions of some of Thomas Kellers specialties, like the flaky cornets filled with salmon tartare, or the lush little gougres. Lena Kwak, the restaurants culinary researcher, developed a gluten-free flour. Now she and Mr. Keller are partners in a company called Cup4Cup, so-named because its flour, C4C, can replace the regular all-purpose variety for cakes and pastries. It is a blend of flours from white and brown rice, tapioca and potatoes, with potato starch, cornstarch and milk powder.

title: A Diagnosis of Cancer: Two Stories
description: To the Editor:

title: Injuries Leave Giants With Holes to Patch and Spirits to Boost
description: Tom Coughlin opened his conference call Tuesday by musing that it would be significantly more pleasant for him to simply discuss Monday nights preseason game  a 41-13 victory over the Chicago Bears  than to update the injury report.

title: Pakistans Bitter, Little-Known Ethnic Rebellion
description: GENEVA  A slim figure in a dark suit, Brahumdagh Bugti, 30, could pass for a banker in the streets of this sedate Swiss city. But in truth he is a resistance leader in exile, a player in an increasingly ugly independence war within Pakistan.

title: The Faded Voice of Sports Calls Past
description: There he sits, buckled into his wheelchair, near the table with the 17 bottles of pills. Old age often sketches people in caricature, and Dom Valentino is 82 now, his face a bit scrunched up after two strokes. His balance is wobbly, his memory porous. A pacemaker adjusts the tom-tom of his heart.

title: Airstrikes More Difficult as War Moves to Tripoli
description: WASHINGTON  The NATO air campaign that was instrumental in helping the rebels advance into Tripoli is hamstrung in many ways now that the fighting has turned into complex house-to-house urban warfare, American military and allied officials said Tuesday.

title: Obama, Tiger, Golf and Politics
description: Despite the carping by critics, Im glad the president went on vacation because one of the most useful things he could do right now is play golf  a lot of golf  but not that friendly foursome thing with his aides that he usually does. No, real golf: Match play, head to head, with real money on the line. Match-play golf is a great teacher. As any good golfer will tell you, the first rule of match play is this: Never play not to lose. Do not wait and hope for your opponent to make a mistake. Always play the course, always play to win and always assume your opponent will do well  will make that long putt  so you have to do better.

title: Dutrow Filly Is Raced 4 Times in 12 Days, Prompting Concern
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The story of Richard Dutrow Jr., already fighting to keep his trainers license in New York and Kentucky, took another controversial twist after a filly he trained, Indian Tale, was put on the stewards list after failing to finish a race on Aug. 18, her fourth in 12 days.

title: Libyas Bloody Road to Freedom
description: Ottawa

title: Can We Judge Economic Success? Perry Versus Obama
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: New Equipment Rules for 2012 Alpine Season Are Criticized
description: New rules announced last month by the International Ski Federation prompted such harsh criticism from skiers, coaches and manufacturers that a meeting is scheduled for Wednesday to discuss them.

title: Waves of Disinformation and Confusion Swamp the Truth in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Truth was first a casualty in Libya well before this war began, and the war has not improved matters at all, on any side.

title: Jewish Museum Picks Director From Art World
description: The Jewish Museum has chosen Claudia Gould, director of the Institute of Contemporary Art at the University of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia, as its new director, succeeding Joan Rosenbaum, who is retiring after 30 years.

title: A Pledge to End Fraternity Hazing
description: Ithaca, N.Y.

title: New S.&P. Chief Knows Crisis and Change
description: The new president of Standard & Poors is used to dealing with crises, including mollifying angry government officials and navigating complex new regulations.

title: Addressing the Justice Gap
description: Most low-income Americans cannot afford a lawyer to defend their legal interests, no matter how urgent the issue. Unless they are in a criminal case, most have no access to help from government-financed lawyers either.

title: 777 School Employees Will Be Let Go, in the Largest Layoff Under Bloomberg
description: Nearly 780 employees of the New York City Education Department will lose their jobs by October, in the largest layoff at a single agency since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took office in 2002.

title: Sell Big or Die Fast
description: Seven weeks after it was put on sale, Hewlett-Packard killed its TouchPad tablet, the companys competitor to Apples iPad.

title: The Strauss-Kahn Case
description: Long after Tuesdays dismissal of sexual assault charges against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, people will still be debating the facts and how the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr., handled the high-profile case. What seems clear is that Mr. Vance was right to notify Mr. Strauss-Kahns lawyers and the court in July about troubling inconsistencies in the account of the accuser, Nafissatou Diallo, and to drop the charges this week.

title: Go West, Young Confederacy
description: In the blistering August heat of 1861, an ambitious 45-year-old officer arrived in the dusty streets of San Antonio to organize one of the most daring Confederate offensives of the Civil War.

title: In PGA Playoff Opener, a Shorter and More Interesting Finishing Hole
description: EDISON, N.J.  Set against all the talk about the urgent need to add length so that venerable courses can still test todays elite players is a classic case of addition by subtraction: the shortened  and improved  18th at the storied Plainfield Country Club.

title: Libyans Rejoice in a Castle Filled With Guns and the Trappings of Power
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Its impenetrable walls breached at last, the people stripped the colonels home of its treasures. They sauntered on the grassy grounds as if it were a public park, and swung on his statue of a fist crushing a plane, a symbol of defiance, as if it were a jungle gym.

title: License Access in New Mexico Is Heated Issue
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  New Mexico is one of just two states, the other being Washington, that allow in-state residents who are illegal immigrants to get the same drivers licenses given to citizens, as long as they pass a written test and successfully show they can turn and stop and park.

title: As Await Film, but Without the Ending They Wanted
description: The Oakland Athletics close their home schedule Sept. 22, and the next day they open their run in theaters everywhere. The movie version of Moneyball, about the rise of the As under Billy Beane, will depict a moment in time that is much different from today. Its inspiration will watch in that context.

title: Cleaner Harbor Has a Downside: Pests That Plague Park Construction
Mosquitoes and West Nile Virus Reports? They Dont Keep New Yorkers From Summer
description: Brown water rippled across a sludgy puddle, about 20 yards wide, along a walkway in Prospect Park. Hundreds of insects dotted the surface.

title: Many in India See Danger in Hunger Strikers Anticorruption Plan
description: NEW DELHI  Aruna Roys two cellphones were ringing before breakfast on Tuesday as she braced for another day in the media storm of the Anna Hazare anticorruption movement. Ms. Roy, a pillar of Indias civil society who has fought for greater government accountability, has been appearing on television to talk about Mr. Hazares populist campaign, which includes his current hunger strike. She might seem a natural ally.

title: F.B.I. Focusing on Security Over Ordinary Crime
description: WASHINGTON  Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been more likely to be hunting for potential threats to national security than for ordinary criminals in recent years, but much of the time found neither, according to newly disclosed internal information.

title: Theyre in the Back Room
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York has taken a strong stand against gerrymandering. He put forward a good bill that would create an independent commission to draw political districts and promised to veto any new maps that are partisan. Albanys pols are not giving up.

title: Oil Reserves Sidestep U.S. Vessels
description: WASHINGTON  In its hurry to transport millions of barrels of oil from federal stockpiles to stabilize world oil prices earlier this summer, the Obama administration has repeatedly bypassed federal law by allowing nearly all the oil to move on foreign-owned vessels, drawing protests from domestic maritime operators.

title: California: 45 Are Arrested in Transit Protests
description: Police officers in San Francisco arrested 45 people Monday evening during a protest at commuter train stations organized largely online by a group of computer hackers called Anonymous. The demonstration was the latest since transit officers shot a 45-year-old man to death on July 3. Demonstrations involving more than 100 protesters began around 5 p.m., closing two stations during peak commuter hours and snarling traffic downtown for more than three hours. During an Aug. 11 protest, transit officials shut off cellphone service in transit stations in an effort to thwart protesters. The move angered online activists, who retaliated by hacking the Bay Area Transit Authoritys Web site and releasing the personal information of users.

title: Giants-Jets Home Now MetLife Stadium
description: One after another, MetLife was asked to buy stadium and naming rights. And each time, it said no.

title: Andy Samberg Plays McEnroe, Agassi, Borg and More
description: Photographer Walter Iooss Jr. and comedian Andy Samberg take a look back at several iconic mens tennis champions.

title: Andy Samberg Prepares for His Matchups
description: The New York Times Magazine asked the photographer Walter Iooss Jr. and the comedian Andy Samberg to take a look back at several iconic men's tennis champions.

title: The Fierce Intimacy of Tennis Rivalries
description: Rafael Nadal was working his way into a point about tennis rivalries. It was near the end of the third day of the Wimbledon Championships in late June, and Nadal, an hour or so earlier, efficiently dispensed with his second-round opponent, the hard-hitting but chronically inconsistent American Ryan Sweeting, in straight sets. Now, freshly showered, his longish hair going its own way, his biceps stretching the sleeves of his tight-fitting polo shirt, Nadal, at that moment the No. 1 mens tennis player in the world, was seated behind a table in a small auditorium at Wimbledons press center, weighing what to say. He looked down, toyed a bit with the bottle of water in front of him, brought his hands together, slowly lifted his head and tilted it, then began a smile but shut it down as he looked at me.

title: Man Randomly Stabs Four, One Fatally, Then Slashes Himself, the Police Say
description: A naked man with a knife unleashed a torrent of violence inside the building where he lives in Upper Manhattan on Tuesday, randomly stabbing four residents, one fatally, before running outside and slashing himself, the police said.

title: Former Manhattan Sex Crimes Chief to Join Private Security Firm
description: A career prosecutor who until recently worked as the chief of the sex crimes unit in the Manhattan district attorneys office is leaving to join a security and investigations company.

title: An American Songbook
description: The death of Jerry Leiber, the lyricist who brought us Stand by Me, Yakety Yak and other early rock n roll classics, gives us a moment to pause and give thanks for sugar cane. Sugar cane led to a great wave of Chinese immigration to Cuba, which, through a roundabout process of musical pollination, put an idea into the heads of Mr. Leiber and his collaborator, Mike Stoller, when they were still teenagers breaking into the business in Los Angeles.

title: Three Quickly Discontinued Technology Products
description: The TouchPad, Kin 1, Kin 2 and Foleo all were yanked by their companies after brief appearances in the consumer market.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Lines at a courthouse are kind of like hurt feelings in a divorce: they are expected, they are unavoidable, but, hopefully, they are dealt with quickly.

title: Moodys Cuts Japans Rating One Notch, Citing Its Giant Debt
description: TOKYO  Moodys, the credit ratings agency, lowered Japans credit rating by one notch on Wednesday, warning that frequent changes in administration, weak prospects for economic growth and its recent natural and nuclear disasters made it difficult for the government to pare down its huge debt.

description: FoodCorps, which started last week, is symbolic of just what we need: a national service program that aims to improve nutrition education for children, develop school gardening projects and change whats being served on school lunch trays.

title: Mets List of Injuries Grows, as Does Skid
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets comically lengthy disabled list grew longer still Tuesday.

description: Manchester Uniteds search for a replacement for the retiring goalkeeper Edwin Van der Saar covered countless countries, leagues and candidates, with goalkeeping coach, Eric Steele acting as chief scout in an operation that lasted over a year.

title: Yemen: Prime Minister Returns From Saudi Arabia
description: Prime Minister Ali Mujawar returned to Yemen on Tuesday after weeks of recuperating in Saudi Arabia from injuries sustained in a deadly attack on the presidential compound in Sana in early June, said a spokesman for Yemens government, Mohammed Albasha. Mr. Mujawar is the first high-ranking official to return from being treated in Saudi Arabia after the attack, which also wounded President Ali Abdullah Saleh and a handful of other high-ranking officials.

title: Rodriguez Sits Out, and Yankees Come Up Short
description: Two days after Alex Rodriguez played his first game in six weeks, he was out of the Yankees lineup again Tuesday, scratched two hours before they opened a grinding stretch that includes 17 games in 16 days. His surgically repaired right knee was not the problem.

description: Two of Twitters founders are back in the start-up game.

title: Time Warner to Subsidize Subscribers TV Device
description: Time Warner Cable, one of the nations top cable and Internet providers, said on Tuesday that it would subsidize some purchases of a set-top box called Slingbox that allows users to watch their home television programming from anywhere, like a vacation home or a mobile phone.

title: Hertz to Begin Renting Electric Cars in China
description: HONG KONG  In the West, electric cars appeal to a do-it-yourself environmentalist personality, one who believes in taking individual actions to help address the collective problems of air pollution and global warming.

title: New Camry, Spruced Up but Still Free of Flash
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  Toyota unveiled a revamped, lower-priced Camry on Tuesday that it hopes will retain its nearly decade-long dominance as the best-selling car in the United States and help the company regain some of the respect and momentum that has evaporated in recent years.

title: Salvadoran Tied to Killings Faces Immigration Charge
description: A former Salvadoran military officer who has been charged in Spain with crimes against humanity for killings in El Salvador during that countrys civil war appeared in United States District Court in Boston on Tuesday after he was arrested and accused of immigration violations. The former officer, Inocente Orlando Montano, who has been living in Everett, Mass., is one of 20 people indicted in Spain for the 1989 slayings of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. Nine other men named in the Spanish indictment turned themselves in this month in El Salvador and are expected to fight extradition to Spain. Mr. Montanos arrest clears the way for Spain to seek his extradition.

title: The Challenge of Restoring Oil Production
description: Crude oil production in Iraq and Libya has not reached earlier highs.

title: Lawyers Defending Suspect in Boys Death Are Scolded
description: The judge in the case of Levi Aron, the Brooklyn man accused of murdering an 8-year-old Borough Park boy in July, upbraided Mr. Arons lawyers on Tuesday for their handling of his defense and questioned whether they were experienced enough to handle such a complex case.

title: After Stillbirth, Courts Try to Put a Price on a Mothers Anguish
description: Eight months pregnant, suffering from abdominal pain, the woman had been sent home after three visits to Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn with a prescription for a painkiller. She lost her baby during labor at home when the head got stuck in the birth canal. A court upheld a $1 million malpractice verdict this year, ending lengthy appeals by the hospital.

title: John Howard Davies, TV Comedy Producer, Dies at 72
description: John Howard Davies, who as a sweet-faced, trembling-lipped child actor played the title role in the 1948 David Lean film Oliver Twist and who went on to become a producer and director of some of British televisions most popular comedies, including Fawlty Towers, died on Monday at his home in Blewbury in southern England. He was 72.

title: Ross Barbour, a Founding Freshman, Dies at 82
description: In 1947, Ross Barbour and three other freshmen decided to take a years break from college to take their barbershop quartet on the road. They soon morphed into the Four Freshmen, a close-harmony, jazz-inflected vocal group that is still going strong  albeit with performers who were not even born at the inception.

description: NATIONAL

title: Samuel Menashe, New York Poet of Short Verse, Dies at 85
description: Samuel Menashe, a Greenwich Village poet whose jewel-like, gnomic short verse won him an ardent following in Britain and belated recognition in the United States when the Poetry Foundation gave him its first Neglected Masters Award in 2004, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 85.

description: A new study reports that beer is an excellent recovery beverage for marathon runners. But you may not want to start a raucous celebration just yet. The beer was effective only if it was nonalcoholic.

title: Years Later, and Chumleys Is Still Not Back on Its Feet
description: It was the storied bar whose name everybody knew, even though it had no sign: Chumleys, in Greenwich Village. A speakeasy during Prohibition and a destination for tourists seeking a snapshot or New Yorkers seeking a nightcap, Chumleys has been closed since a wall collapsed in April 2007.

title: A Strategy for Learning From Mistakes
description: Eight years ago, we made a mistake that weve only recently stopped paying for. As mistakes go, this one was hardly disastrous, and in some ways it even helped me clarify my understanding of why mistakes happen and what we can do to avoid them. I have found that most mistakes fall into one of three categories: planning, procedures, or performance. Its important to understand what kind of mistake has been made before you try to deal with it.

This is a purely aesthetic  i.e., pointless  pleasure, but if I am out walking or cycling, this fondness for court-spotting has obvious practical advantages. Over time, in London, I have discovered every public court within a playable distance of home.

title: Ristretto | Los Angeles Coffee Crawl
description: The intrastate rivalry between Los Angeles and San Francisco doesnt make much sense if you live outside of California. Or really, if you dont live in the Bay Area. title: What Should We Have Known About Fiscal Stimulus?
description: Ive noticed a number of people arguing that the original Obama stimulus was underpowered because at the time nobody realized how deep a hole the economy was in. And its true that revised GDP numbers have shown that the 2007-2009 recession was even deeper than we thought. But the basic line of thought here is wrong: there was plenty of information in January 2009 indicating that the economy needed a lot more help than it was about to get.

title: Unflappable, but a Little Shaken
description: You could tell almost right away that the earthquake that rattled New York on Tuesday was not really a big deal. If it had seriously disrupted the rhythms of the city, dont you think the mayor would have urged people to do something like take in a Broadway show?That, you surely recall, was his tin-eared recommendation in December when much of the city was brought to a standstill by the Great Blizzard of 2010 and many New Yorkers couldnt dig their way out of their own streets, let alone make it to the theater. So the absence of any such suggestion this time was reassuring, a clear signal that we would be all right.

title: Turning It On and Off for Politics
description: On Monday, a researcher named Lisa Diamond, who works on issues of sexuality and sexual identity, claimed that her work is being misconstrued and distorted by John Boehners legal team. Boehners lawyer cited Diamonds research in a lawsuit defending the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act. (A woman named Edie Windsor has sued, claiming the law is unconstitutional.) The Boehner brief makes the case for the Defense of Marriage Act in part by quoting a study by Diamond that said, 50 percent [of respondents] had changed their identity label more than once since first relinquishing their heterosexual identity.

title: When Teenagers Fly Alone
description: IT was with a sense of relief that I set out to book my two teenage childrens airfares to camp last month. With Florence now 15, I knew I would no longer have to pay the $200 round-trip fee required by airlines like Delta and US Airways for children younger than 15 traveling without an adult. I also assumed that because Florence would be flying with Charles, her 14-year-old brother, from Detroit to Boston, he, too, would be exempt from the fee since she would be accompanying him.

title: Summitts New Opponent

The timing seemed fitting, suggesting perhaps even tectonic plates relied on the idea that Pat Summitt, the Tennessee womens basketball coach, was indestructible. Having watched her will her way to so many things, lifting not only her own program and womens basketball to a new level, but also womens sports. Certainly she wasnt subject to things like the law of gravity or human illnesses like Alzheimers, right?

title: Where Has All the Genetic Diversity Gone?
description: Last week, I wrote about the latest meta-analysis documenting the steady march of species away from the equator and up the mountain slopes in response to a warming world. This week, a study from the Biodiversity and Climate Research Center in Germany, highlighted a new layer of complexity to consider when it comes to conservation efforts in the face of climate change  the almost invisible erosion of genetic diversity because of climate-induced range contractions. The paper, titled Cryptic Biodiversity Loss Linked to Global Climate Change, was published online in Nature Climate Change.

title: So This Is the Wilderness (Forget the Stuff)
description: To come clean, this year in the woods series was all my idea. Two years ago, I said to my husband, Craig, Lets go live in the woods for a year, somewhere beautiful, and he was up for it. After renting our house in the New Jersey suburbs and finding a place in Maine, here we are in an off-the-grid cabin on a gorgeous lake with our three boys and two cats.

(Simulations show, by the way, that chance plus selection can indeed create an eye, in a relatively short time as evolutionary history goes).

title: Who Made That Dummy Text?

Lorem Ipsum (shorthand for the entire, seemingly endless body of Latin text) is the green screen of the publishing world  placeholder copy used by designers to replicate how a block of text will look and how many words it will fit before swapping in the fully written article. This apparent gibberish, however, has been used for this purpose since the 1500s, and its foundation goes back even further. According to lipsum.com:

title: Libya: The End and the Beginning
description: For months, almost every development out of Libya seemed to confirm my initial pessimism about our quasi-war against Muammar Qaddafi. But happily thats changed in the last week, with the sudden collapse of his regime and the apparent victory of the rebels. As in post-Saddam Iraq and post-Taliban Afghanistan, many of the scenarios for what comes next in Libya could ultimately pose as many risks to American interests as Qaddafi himself ever did, and I agree with all the voices pointing out that the tyrants fall doesnt necessarily vindicate our intervention, to say nothing of the dubiously legal means by which America was taken to war in North Africa. But I also think its important for critics of the war to acknowledge the significance of the last few days events. While few intervention skeptics maintained that we could not possibly defeat the regime (as Ramesh Ponnuru puts it), many of us worried that the administrations (understandably) risk-averse approach to the conflict might create a permanent stalemate, leaving an armed-and-dangerous Qaddafi in power in Tripoli while Western warplanes circled impotently overhead. Qaddafis defeat doesnt necessarily promise a happy outcome in the long run, but at the very least it guarantees that we will be spared that particular worst-case scenario, while holding out the possibility of a Libya unified and at peace  rather than a Libya partitioned and perpetually patrolled by Western forces, which is where we seemed to be headed a month ago. Declarations of victory are ridiculously premature, but for a country and a White House starved for any sort of good news, the fall of Qaddafi should because for (suitably restrained) celebration.

title: Sylvia Waters, Longtime Artistic Director, to Retire From Ailey II
description: Another changing of the guard is taking place at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Sylvia Waters, the longtime artistic director of Ailey II, will retire on June 30, 2012, the company plans to announce on Thursday. Ms. Waters began her career with the company as a dancer in 1968 and Mr. Ailey chose Ms. Waters to lead the junior troupe in 1974. She went on to guide and train young dancers for nearly four decades, including Robert Battle, the companys new artistic director. Ms. Waters has named Troy Powell, a teacher, choreographer and former dancer, as her successor. Mr. Powell has served as the associate artistic director for Ailey II since 2003.

title: Does America Need Manufacturing?
description: You can drive almost anywhere in the state of Michigan  pick a point at random and start moving  and you will soon come upon the wreckage of American industry. If you happen to be driving on the outer edge of Midland, youll also come upon a cavern of steel beams and ductwork, 400,000 square feet in all. When this plant, which is being constructed by Dow Kokam, a new venture partly owned by Dow Chemical, is up and running early next year, it will produce hundreds of thousands of advanced lithium-ion battery cells for hybrid and electric cars. Just as important, it will provide about 350 jobs in a state with one of the nations highest unemployment rates.

title: Loud Fury and Passion, Served Up on Schedule

Behind him drums and bass pumped in machinelike overdrive amid a gnarl of distorted guitar. Before him, the crowd swayed in heaves, half soaked with spilled beer. Scheduled to go on at 11:30, the band had started precisely on time.

I pointed to everything on the table, cups, plates, even salt shakers, and politely reminded my friends that each of these objects was designed by a person.

title: The Montelargo Banquette From Casa Midy
description: Casa Midys Montelargo banquette ($1,250), like many of the companys pieces, is an amalgam of French and Mexican references reflecting the owners backgrounds. Anne-Marie Midy is French, and the banquettes silhouette is inspired by park benches from that country, while Jorge Almadas Mexican heritage is evident in the way the saddle leather is affixed to the frame, with belts and tassels. My dad was an amateur bullfighter, and would wear leather chaps called zahones that are fastened with straps to the body, Mr. Almada said. The idea was to fasten the leather panel to the frame in the same manner. Information, in Mexico: 011-52-415-15-2-04-03 or casamidy.com.

title: Got a Good Idea? Ben Kaufman of Quirky.com Will Be the Judge of That

Founded by Ben Kaufman, a 24-year-old inventor and entrepreneur, the company solicits ideas for new products on its Web site, bringing the most popular suggestions to life with the help of in-house product designers and an online community, and then sharing the profits.

title: In Hollywood, a Modernists Tag Sale

This Hollywood neighborhood, on the National Register of Historic Places, is filled with Mediterranean-style homes, some very grand. Yet its where Jonn Coolidge, a photographer specializing in interiors, decided to move after a decade of living in houses by Edward H. Fickett, the late Los Angeles architect known for his modernist work.

title: Childrens Wall Decal Puzzles From Blik
description: The wall decal company Blik has introduced interactivity to its graphics with a new line of adhesive puzzles. Made from a thick low-tack film that can be stuck onto and peeled off walls without damaging paint, the puzzles function as both a game for children and decorative accents for a room. Once you get it on your wall, its this beautiful thing, said Scott Flora, one of Bliks owners. But at the same time, it requires some assembly, and youre teaching your child about how things go together.

But on one stretch of 95th Street, sandwiched between two ordinary apartment buildings, sits a home that sometimes makes passers-by do a double take: a three-story clapboard mansion from the 19th century that looks as if it were Photoshopped into the streetscape.

title: For PGAs White, Return to Plainfield Evokes Memories
description: EDISON, N.J.  Viewers of golf on television have seen the PGA Tour official Carlton White many times advising a player on a ruling. They may see that situation play out again this week at the Barclays at Plainfield Country Club.

description: 7:37 p.m. | Updated  Adding analyst comment.
