title: Top Fashion Looks for Fall
description: Cathy Horyns suggestions for your fall fashion investments.

title: Bloggingheads: Hooray For Failure!
description: Jamelle Bouie, left, of The American Prospect and Peter Suderman of Reason debate the supercommittee.

title: The Five Things You Need for Fall
description: HAVE you noticed those Ferragamo ads with Daria Werbowy reclining in a houndstooth-check dress with matching heels that look like ice picks? No? Shes clutching a matching purse with her red nails, shes wearing sheer black stockings, and frankly  I love Daria Werbowy  she looks like a lady bucking for 30 years to life.

title: Jive Software Files to Go Public
description: While the market for public offerings has been dicey, the technology backlog continues to grow.

title: House Hunting in ... Germany
description: A TWO BEDROOM APARTMENT IN A HAMBURG MANOR HOUSE

title: Marco Rubio Says No to Ticket, but Finds Skeptics
description: Marco Rubio, the freshman Republican senator from Florida, seems to many in his party an ideal candidate for vice president, having demonstrated appeal in a key swing state while drawing Hispanic voters to his party. But at a speech at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif., Tuesday evening, Senator Rubio said he would not seek that job.

title: Officials Warn of Threat From Hurricane Irene
description: The authorities warned Wednesday that in the worst case scenario Hurricane Irene could reach New York City this weekend as a Category 1 hurricane, with winds surpassing 72 miles an hour that produce a storm surge of 6 to 12 feet.

title: The Plight of Small States Left After the Soviet Breakup
description: To the Editor:

title: With Departure of Jobs, Will Apple Warm to Deal-Making?
description: As Steven P. Jobs steps down as chief executive of Apple Inc., the iPhone maker will lose the leader who rescued it from near-death and built it into a technology colossus.

title: Perspectives on the Finale to the Strauss-Kahn Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Text of Jobss Resignation Letter
description: Apple released this letter from Steven P. Jobs on Wednesday as it announced that he was stepping down from the post of chief executive.

title: After Strauss-Kahn, Fear of Rape Victim Silence
description: She seemed to be the perfect witness. She came forward right away, disclosing detail after damning detail of a sexual attack that, backed by forensic evidence, seemed airtight. She stuck to her story. But then her case fell apart after prosecutors questioned her credibility. The charges against the man she accused, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, were dropped.

title: Steven P. Jobs Leaves Chief Executive Role at Apple
description: Apple said that Steven P. Jobs, its co-founder and chief executive, would step down, but wants to remain chairman. Tim Cook, the chief operating officer, will take over the position.

title: After Players Death, a Question of Privacy
description: It has been a little more than a week since Winnipeg Jets forward Rick Rypien was found dead at his home in Coleman, Alberta. There was a funeral attended by 1,000 mourners. Fans paid tribute to him on the Internet and outside Rogers Arena, where Rypien, who suffered from depression, played for parts of six seasons with the Vancouver Canucks. The N.H.L., upon word of his death, said that it would review its substance-abuse and behavioral-health program, under which Rypien received treatment.

title: Tricking Out Your iPhone Photos
description: A sample guide to photo manipulation by Brian Roberts, a master of iPhone photography.

title: In Denmark, a Sanctuary by the Sea
description: A 5,400-square-foot house north of Copenhagen is perched on a grassy slope overlooking the tranquil Oresund strait.

title: A Sanctuary on the Danish Riviera
description: HUMLEBAEK, Denmark  Claus Moeller is used to uphill battles. As a biomedical researcher, and the chief executive of the Danish pharmaceutical company Azanta, he has helped create cancer-fighting drugs. But nothing prepared Dr. Moeller for the trials of constructing a home in a shoreline suburb nearly 20 miles north of Copenhagen.

title: Romney Undeterred by Perry, or by Poll Numbers
description: LEBANON, N.H.  Mitt Romney, trying to brush off questions about Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, his Republican competitor in the 2012 presidential contest, offered a clear description of his campaign strategy during a press briefing in Claremont, N.H., on Wednesday.

title: Strolling Artists, Bearing iPhones
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At first glance, it looked like another throng of tourists passing through San Franciscos Chinatown. Yet one thing made this group stand out: everyone was taking pictures, but no one was using a traditional camera. No heavy D.S.L.R.s weighed down neck straps. No point-and-shoot cameras dangled from wrists.

title: Qaddafi Leaves Behind Little to Guide Libya in His Absence
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis stranglehold on Libya appears to have ended after 42 years, even if his whereabouts remain elusive. But through countless erratic decrees and iron-handed purges, he carved deep scars into every facet of Libyan life. The mystery and speculation swirling about him marked a fitting close to a quixotic reign.

title: A Field Guide to Outerwear
description: The fall runway collections made a fairly convincing case for rethinking the role of outerwear in our wardrobes.

title: Questions About Gene-Modified Foods
description: To the Editor:

title: Colts Sign Collins and Raise a Question
description: The Indianapolis Colts made a very good move, but delivered a very bad signal Wednesday, luring the veteran quarterback Kerry Collins out of retirement to be their backup quarterback.

title: Germanys Capital Burns Bright, and Without Explanation
description: BERLIN  At night all over the city, cars are burning on the streets of the German capital.

title: Starting Anew in New York, Giants Tackle Takes His Shot
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Jimmy Kennedy won the 1996 New York state football championship with Roosevelt High School in Yonkers, he was one of 20 players. One very big player.

title: Chamber of Commerce, on Business and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind the Glittery Web Start-Ups, Investors See Other Gold
description: While the spotlight of the latest technology boom has been focused on a cluster of popular consumer applications like Facebook, Groupon and Zynga, investors are increasingly taking a shine to the start-ups building the infrastructure for those Internet powerhouses.

title: A Rare Bustle in the Lab as Seismometers Quiver
description: New Yorkers most likely will remember Aug. 23, 2011, as the day the earth hiccupped for a matter of seconds, providing a worthy conversation piece but, ultimately, a fleeting interruption.

title: Jobs Steps Down at Apple, Saying He Cant Meet Duties
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, whose insistent vision that he knew what consumers wanted made Apple one of the worlds most valuable and influential companies,is stepping down as chief executive, the company announced late Wednesday.

title: Look Back in Envy: The 70s Take the Runway
description: ON The Marc and Myra Show, on SiriusXM radio, the writer Bob Colacello recalled visiting Studio 54 in the 1970s when Yves Saint Laurent strolled into the room. Halston, on glimpsing his idol, sprang from his chair to embrace him. Taking in the scene, Truman Capote was heard to tell a companion: You have just witnessed one of the great moments in the history of fashion. That is, if you care about the history of fashion.

title: Recapturing the Mood of the 1970s
description: The 70s have been revisited time and again in more recent decades, but not with the conviction demonstrated on the runways of late.

title: Two Old Friends, in Bronze
description: HOUSTON  Those who stand in a downtown park and stare into the eyes of a statue of James A. Baker III might wonder what has caught the former secretary of states gaze. Upon turning around, they squint and realize that it is his friend and former boss, George Bush, the 41st president of the United States.

title: In Mountain Village, Cuomo Finds Respite
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.  The first sighting came in March: there he was, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, forsaking his usual suit and tie for blue jeans and a pair of Oakley sunglasses, pumping gas at a Mobil station here.

title: After Arab Revolts, Reigns of Uncertainty
description: DJERBA, Tunisia  The idealism of the revolts in Egypt and Tunisia, where the power of the street revealed the frailty of authority, revived an Arab world anticipating change. But Libyas unfinished revolution, as inspiring as it is unsettling, illustrates how perilous that change has become as it unfolds in this phase of the Arab Spring.

title: Americas Sweatshop Diplomacy
description: ACCORDING to the State Department, the J-1 visa Summer Work Study program, which allows foreign students to work in the United States for a few months, is meant to promote lasting and meaningful relationships between the students and Americans.

title: In New Jersey, Rules Are Changed on Witness IDs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, acknowledging a troubling lack of reliability in eyewitness identifications, issued sweeping new rules on Wednesday making it easier for defendants to challenge such evidence in criminal cases.

title: Bright Red, Yet So Hard to See
description: Scattered along the citys sidewalks are 15,000 emergency-help boxes, though most people interviewed said they took no note of them. Including, Eddie Colon, 52, of Harlem, who was leaning his bicycle against one at the northwest corner of 125th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard/

title: A History of Fearlessness
description: When Pat Summitt became head coach of the Tennessee Lady Vols in 1974, she drove the team van and began to shift gears on the long uphill climb for womens sports.

title: Over the Cliff
description: I fell into a Supreme Court time warp the other day. Preparing to teach a seminar this fall on the court under Chief Justice Warren E. Burger  the court of the 1970s to mid-80s  I picked up for the first time in many years a decision from 1978, First National Bank of Boston v. Bellotti. The case is not well-known today, although it should be. It was the decision that really opened the door to corporate money in politics, leading 32 years later to a very well-known case: Citizens United.

title: How to Fix Our Math Education
description: THERE is widespread alarm in the United States about the state of our math education. The anxiety can be traced to the poor performance of American students on various international tests, and it is now embodied in George W. Bushs No Child Left Behind law, which requires public school students to pass standardized math tests by the year 2014 and punishes their schools or their teachers if they do not.

title: Twitter Reactions to Jobs Stepping Down
description: [View the story Tracking Jobs News on Storify]

title: Still City Fixture, Many Call Boxes Overstay Their Welcome
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response) {data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: '+ data +', cropType: 'blog480', appendTo: 'embeddedSlideshow', showHeadLine: 'false'}

title: Yes, He Sold Fakes. They Are Supposed to Be Fake.
description: The items, mostly copies of luxury objects, inside the little shop in downtown Manhattan are made of thin cardboard and might not even pass muster deep in the background of a movie set.

title: Perry Surges in Polls, Testing Romneys Strategy
description: Primary polls can be erratic, so the rule is not to get too worked up about any one set of numbers. But now there have been five surveys conducted since Rick Perry announced his presidential campaign  one each from Gallup, Rasmussen Reports and Public Policy Polling, and two from YouGov. Each shows Mr. Perry having vaulted into a lead over Mitt Romney.

title: China Faces Obstacles in Bid to Rebalance Its Economy
description: CHENGDU, China  A casual glance out the window is all it takes to witness the blistering growth that has become the signature feature of this provincial capital and of other cities in the vast Chinese interior. A phalanx of half-finished office and apartment towers flanked by yellow cranes rises above the brown waters of the Jinjiang River.

title: A Jubilant Return Home
description: DAVISON, Mich.  A quarter-mile from where he used to sell apples from a roadside stand to help his family make ends meet, Tim Thomas stood on the 50-yard line at his old high school football stadium Wednesday  the Stanley Cup, the Conn Smythe Trophy and the Vezina Trophy in the foreground  facing bleachers full of fans, friends and family.

title: Without Its Master of Design, Apple Will Face Many Challenges
description: Steven P. Jobs, one of the most successful chief executives in corporate history, once said he never thought of himself as a manager, but as a leader. And his notion of leadership revolved around choosing the best people possible, encouraging them and creating an environment in which they could do great work.

title: When Libya Grew Wings
description: Tripoli, Libya

title: For State Teachers Union, a Victory on Evaluations
description: A judge ruled Wednesday that the New York State Board of Regents overreached in its interpretation of a new law on teacher evaluations, offering a victory to the state teachers union.

title: Still No Deal on Testing for H.G.H.
description: Negotiations between the N.F.L. and its players union over testing for human growth hormone continued to stall Wednesday, with the union upset that it did not receive the scientific documents it requested from the World Anti-Doping Agency regarding the test for H.G.H.

title: Gov. Perrys Cash Machine
description: The exchange of campaign contributions for government contracts, favors or positions is all too common in Washington and around the country. It has been developed to an especially high art  or more to the point, a low art  by Gov. Rick Perry in Texas. For a presidential contender who insists that big government is the countrys biggest problem, it is particularly cynical.

title: Wild Ride Expected on the Slopes at the Barclays
description: EDISON, N.J.  Approach with caution, and putt with it, too.

title: Europe Accuses Iranian Force of Aiding Syrian Crackdown
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The European Union announced on Wednesday that it was leveling sanctions against Irans Al Quds military force, saying it had given technical and material support to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria in his efforts to crush the five-month-old uprising against his rule.

title: The Negative Side of Share Buybacks
description: Share buybacks are creeping back into fashion. Lowes and CVS Caremark divulged plans for $9 billion worth between them this week. Such repurchases become more enticing when markets are on their knees. But boards have too often sanctioned programs that destroy value. They need to resist the rising temptation.

title: Judge Suppresses Statements in Arms Trial
description: In a rare pretrial victory for Viktor Bout, a Russian accused of conspiring to sell arms to a terrorist organization, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday that certain statements Mr. Bout made after his 2008 arrest in a sting operation in Thailand cannot be used at trial.

title: Release Shane Bauer and Joshua Fattal
description: The American hikers Shane Bauer and Joshua Fattal have spent 755 days in Irans brutal Evin prison. They never should have been arrested, much less held for so long. With the Muslim world celebrating the holy month of Ramadan, Iranian officials should show compassion, and true respect for justice, and let them return home.

title: Tomlinson Is Turning Heads, if Not Turning Back Clock
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Once and only once this summer has the Jets running backs coach Anthony Lynn thought about LaDainian Tomlinsons age, and it happened during practice last week.

title: Libyans Face a New Challenge: Expelling the Fear That Qaddafi Instilled in Them
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  When rebels broke through the gates of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis compound this week, Abdul Rahman Sharif was so moved that despite the gunfire he took his daughters, ages 11, 15 and 18, with him to see it for themselves. Then after dark he returned with his wife. And the next day, as more bullets flew, he visited the compound with his 90-year-old mother.

title: N.B.A. and Union to Hold a Rare Bargaining Session
description: Lead negotiators for the N.B.A. and its players union will hold a bargaining session next week  just the second since the lockout began  with an unofficial deadline fast approaching to save the start of training camps. Four people involved in the talks said the sides planned to meet in New York, although the day and the location were still being arranged. They might not be in a conciliatory mood when they arrive.

title: Cheney Says He Urged Bush to Bomb Syria in 07
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Dick Cheney says in a new memoir that he urged President George W. Bush to bomb a suspected Syrian nuclear reactor site in June 2007. But, he wrote, Mr. Bush opted for a diplomatic approach after other advisers  still stinging over the bad intelligence we had received about Iraqs stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction  expressed misgivings.

title: U.S. May Back Refinance Plan for Mortgages
description: The Obama administration is considering further actions to strengthen the housing market, but the bar is high: plans must help a broad swath of homeowners, stimulate the economy and cost next to nothing.

title: Thursday: Magic 8 Ball Answer
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Any puzzle by Patrick Blindauer and Francis Heaney, either individually or as a collaboration, is O.K. by me. They are both terrific guys and two of the most creative constructors around today, in my opinion. You dont have to fold their puzzles into the shape of a pterodactyl or spend all of your time Googling answers in order to solve them, but there is usually some visual or verbal element in each of them that makes me feel like I wish I had thought of it first.

title: Why Is That a Secret?
description: A former top official in charge of ensuring that real secrets are kept secret has delivered a stunning repudiation of the Obama administrations decision to use the Espionage Act against a whistle-blower attempting to expose government waste and abuse.

title: Money Is Now at Fore of Strauss-Kahn Case
description: When Dominique Strauss-Kahn was arrested more than three months ago on sexual assault charges, the sensational accusations carried an intriguing subplot: money.

title: U.S. Checks Conditions for Workers in Walkout
description: The Department of Labor and the State Department opened investigations this week of job conditions at a Pennsylvania packing plant for Hersheys chocolates where several hundred international exchange students walked off their jobs last week, protesting low pay and strenuous work.

title: Phillies Turf Becomes the Mets No-Fans Land
description: PHILADELPHIA  If the 22  games separating the teams in the standings and the blowouts on Monday and Tuesday were not enough to indicate the gulf between the fading Mets and the first-place Philadelphia Phillies, then a peek into the sea of red in the stands should have done it.

title: The Tobacco Companies Just Keep Trying
description: Tobacco companies are back in court trying to prevent the government from imposing new regulations that will require bold warning labels on cigarette packages and advertisements. They lost a similar federal lawsuit in tobacco-friendly Kentucky last year. Now they are suing in Federal District Court in Washington.

title: Search for Answers as a 2nd Stabbing Victim Dies
description: As a second victim of a stabbing rampage at an Upper Manhattan building died on Wednesday, residents described a close-knit community and questioned what brought on the attack, which the police said was committed by a lifelong neighbor.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Official Warns About Chinas Military Buildup
description: WASHINGTON  The pace and scope of Chinas military buildup is potentially destabilizing in the Pacific, a top defense official warned Wednesday as the Pentagon released an annual report cataloging Chinas cruise missiles, fighter jets and growing, modernizing army.

title: From California, Advice for Next Time: Stay Inside
description: The earthquake on Tuesday rattled many New Yorkers enough to make them evacuate glass-encased office towers.

title: Trinidad and Tobago Declares Emergency Over Drug Crimes
description: MEXICO CITY  The island nation of Trinidad and Tobago has imposed a nightly curfew and sent troops to cope with a rash of violent crime associated with gangs, one of the starkest signs of worry in the Caribbean region over a spike in drug trafficking.

title: With Burnett and Colon Struggling, Yankees Pitching Remains Unsettled
description: The Yankees have grown weary of questions relating to their potential playoff pitching rotation, and for good reason. The team cannot even be certain who will be healthy and performing well a week from now, let alone in a month.

title: Quake Leaves Cracks in Washington Monument, Closing It for Now
description: WASHINGTON  While the angst over whether this countrys political system is broken seems likely to go on for the foreseeable future, it gave way to some degree Wednesday to more immediate concerns about how badly the Washington Monument had been cracked.

title: Monthly Visitors to the Washington Monument
description: The Washington Monument doesnt average as many visitors as it once did.

title: Rabbi Fabricated Swashbuckling Tales of Saving Holocaust Torahs, Prosecutors Say
description: He described himself as a risk-taking rabbi who had been beaten up, thrown in jail and gone $175,000 into debt on expeditions to Eastern Europe. He said his mission was to rescue and restore Torahs that had been wrenched from their communities during the Holocaust and place them with congregations that would look after them.

title: Same-Sex Couples Since 1990
description: The number of same-sex couples has risen dramatically since 1990.

title: Car Bomb in Iraq Kills 7 at a Ramadi Checkpoint
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber driving a car packed with explosives attacked a police checkpoint west of Ramadi on Wednesday night, killing seven people, including five police officers, and wounding four other officers and a civilian, according to local officials.

title: Unsavory Culinary Elitism
description: Anthony Bourdain, the part-time chef and full-time celebrity, has a tongue on him. Its the sharpest knife in his set. He has used it to carve up vegans, whom he called the Hezbollah-like splinter faction of vegetarians, and the culinary moralist Alice Waters, whose rigidity is very Khmer Rouge.

title: An Original Journalism Blogger Logs Out
description: He was an aggregator before it became a dirty word. He was a blogger before there were blogs.

title: Trying to Recapture Glory Before Seasons End
description: EDISON, N.J.  Vijay Singh was a lone figure on the far end of the three-tiered practice range at Plainfield Country Club on Wednesday, smashing shot after shot high into the afternoon sky with almost metronomic consistency.

title: Unlikely Power From As Sends Yankees to Second Consecutive Loss
description: Coco Crisp is known for many things, including his talent as a center fielder, his ability to hit from both sides of the plate, and of course his name. With only 72 home runs in his 10-year career, however, he is definitely not known as a slugger.

title: Billions in Home Loans
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac guarantee nearly $2.4 trillion in mortgages with interest rates above 4 percent.

title: Geologists Sharply Cut Estimate of Shale Gas
description: WASHINGTON  Federal geologists published new estimates this week for the amount of natural gas that exists in a giant rock formation known as the Marcellus Shale, which stretches from New York to Virginia.

title: If Texas A&M Is the SECs 13th Team, Whos No. 14?
description: After a week of revelations involving Ponzi schemes, prostitutes and illicit payments, college athletic directors, presidents and television executives are now focusing on the really ugly mess facing college sports.

title: Joey Vento, Founder of Cheese-Steak Institution, Dies at 71
description: Joey Vento, the founder of Genos Steaks, a stand-in-line takeout establishment that is one of the pillars of the cheese-steak mecca of South Philadelphia, died Tuesday at his home in Shamong, N.J. He was 71.

title: Steven P. Jobs, Apple's Innovator
description: Steven P. Jobs co-founded Apple Computer 35 years ago.

title: Former Oriole Flanagan Found Dead
description: Mike Flanagan, a former pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles and the Toronto Blue Jays, was found dead at his home in Baltimore County, Md., on Wednesday.

title: Shares Fall as Hopes Fade for New Action by Fed and Jobless Claims Rise
description: Traders have been overwhelmed by the prospects of a global economic slowdown, a euro zone debt problem and other issues. On Thursday, there were new developments to contend with: the resignation of Steven P. Jobs as chief executive of Apple and the investment by Berkshire Hathaway, which is run by Warren E. Buffett, in Bank of America.

title: Budd Hopkins, Abstract Expressionist and U.F.O. Author, Dies at 80
description: Budd Hopkins, a distinguished Abstract Expressionist artist who  after what he described as a chance sighting of something flat, silver, airborne and unfathomable  became the father of the alien-abduction movement, died on Aug. 21 at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Recipes: Lobster With More Than Just Melted Butter
description: A dozen ways to transform lobster into salads, bisque, chowder, sandwiches or kebabs.

title: Lobster With More Than Just Melted Butter
description: The pleasure of eating lobster is intense, and the reward-to-work ratio is unsurpassed, all of which is fun to talk about. Whats not so fun to talk about is lobsters and pain, which is why Im going to avoid it. All of us lobster eaters do. (If you want a full consideration of the lobster/pain issue  one that resolves absolutely nothing but grapples with it beautifully  read David Foster Wallaces hilarious essay Consider the Lobster.)

title: New Numbers, and Geography, for Gay Couples
description: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del.  So much for San Francisco.

title: Insurance Company Rebrands Itself as Kemper
description: It is not unprecedented, but it is unusual: a company that makes an acquisition sheds its own name to take the name of a product or brand it has acquired.

title: The Most Accurate Fantasy Football Rankings
description: David Kim is the co-founder of FantasyPros, a site that aggregates and organizes advice from all the top fantasy football sources. You can follow FantasyPros on Twitter.

title: Steve Jobss Patents
description: The 317 Apple patents that list Steven P. Jobs among the group of inventors offer a glimpse at his legendary say over the minute details of the companys products.

title: Word of the Day | pandemic
description: pandemic \pan-de-mik\ adjective and noun

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/25/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/25/2011

title: Online Enterprises Gain Foothold as Path to a College Degree
description: Harvard and Ohio State are not going to disappear any time soon. But a host of new online enterprises are making earning a college degree cheaper, faster and flexible enough to take work experience into account. As Wikipedia upended the encyclopedia industry and iTunes changed the music business, these businesses have the potential to change higher education.

title: Weekly Prompts From a Mentor
description: Fifteen years ago, bemoaning the high cost of higher education, the governors of 19 Western states decided to start a nonprofit online institution to help meet their need for a trained work force. The result, Western Governors University, offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in education, business, the health professions and information technology. Everything is online except for student teaching and some nursing requirements.

title: Open Courses, Nearly Free
description: After the earthquake in Haiti destroyed much of the countrys higher-education infrastructure, the University of the People decided to set up three computer centers there, inviting English-speaking students from nearby tent cities to come and work for four hours a day.

title: A Way to Speed the Pace
description: Burck Smith, who previously started an online tutoring company, founded Straighterline in 2008 to challenge the high cost of college.

title: Receiving Credit for Job Experience
description: Started in January, Learning Counts is a project of the Council for Adult and Experiential Learning, the American Council on Education and the College Board, in which older students take an online course that teaches them to prepare a portfolio that shows what they have learned from work and life experience. The portfolios  one for each subject area in which they are seeking credit  are then submitted to an outside evaluator, who decides whether they should get academic credit.

title: Corrections: August 25
description: NEW YORK

title: A Short-Lived Test, Even With Coaching
description: The first question on the screening test for an online class I signed up for was not a hard one, but my most recent exposure to math had been in high school decades before, and I didnt remember how to solve even easy equations.

title: Business Studies Become Environmentally Friendly
description: Through the roof is how Adam Zak, an executive recruiter, describes the demand for workers with sustainability-related job skills.

title: Steven P. Jobs Leaves Chief Executive Role at Apple
description: Apple said that Steven P. Jobs, its co-founder and chief executive, would step down, but wants to remain chairman. Tim Cook, the chief operating officer, will take over the position.

title: News Quiz | August 25, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Imagining Apple Without Steve Jobs
description: WHO is Steve Jobs?WHO will succeed him at Apple?

title: Inside a Libyan Hospital, Proof of a Revolts Costs
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Word raced through Tripoli Central Hospital as fast as the bloody gurneys rushing through the entrance on Thursday carrying wounded fighters from the front: perhaps this was Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis last stand.

title: Aug. 25, 1944 | Paris Is Liberated After 4-Year Nazi Occupation
description: On Aug. 25, 1944, Allied and French Resistance forces entered Paris and drove out the last significant Nazi opposition, liberating the city after four years of Nazi occupation. On all sides the liberating French and Americans were greeted by hungry Parisians, mad with joy, who had fought alone against the German oppressors since they were called to arms last Saturday, reported The Associated Press in an article printed in The New York Times.

title: Asking Candidates Tougher Questions About Faith
description: If a candidate for president said he believed that space aliens dwell among us, would that affect your willingness to vote for him? Personally, I might not disqualify him out of hand; one out of three Americans believe we have had Visitors and, hey, who knows? But I would certainly want to ask a few questions. Like, where does he get his information? Does he talk to the aliens? Do they have an economic plan?

title: Stephen Crowleys Monument to Washington
description: On Tuesday afternoon, the Washington Monument  that postcard-perfect symbol of the capital  fell victim to a 5.8-magnitude earthquake that shook the East Coast.

title: More Transparent Bank Stress Tests Are Needed
description: 1:41 p.m. | Updated Adding news of Warren Buffetts investment in Bank of America.

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 25, 2011
description: Todays question was written by Shannon Doyne. Her question comes from the article Worthy Rivals for the Crown in Smartphones.

title: Do You Like Horror Movies?
description: In the video The Horror, The Horror, Jason Zinoman says that people watch scary movies for the really intense emotional experiences and that you never feel more in the moment than when terrified at a horror movie. Do you agree? Do you watch horror movies? Which are your favorites?

title: Behind the Scenes With Andy Samberg
description: The stars were aligned for the cover-story photo shoot in this Sundays magazine. To accompany The Fierce Intimacy of Tennis Rivalries, by Gerald Marzorati, the former editor of the magazine, the current editor of the magazine, Hugo Lindgren, suggested putting a modern face on some familiar tennis icons from the not-too-distant past. So we enlisted the comedian and Saturday Night Live regular Andy Samberg and the photographer Walter Iooss Jr., whose work has been appearing in Sports Illustrated for decades (indeed, Iooss had shot all of our original subjects), along with an ace styling team and crew. (We also brought in a digital team to stir its magic into the images, but more about that in a later blog post.) As the magazines photo director, Kathy Ryan, put it, the day was pure pleasure, which we hope some of these behind-the-scenes photographs will reveal.

title: A Chief Executives Attention to Detail, Noted in 313 Patents
description: When people in the technology industry speak of Steven P. Jobss knack for design, they often have Apples iconic products in mind: the early all-in-one Macintosh computers, the first iMacs with their brightly colored and translucent cases, and more recently, the various iPods, iPhones and iPads.

title: The Early Word: Projections
description: In Todays Times:The debt plan that lawmakers agreed to this month would sharply reduce budget deficits over the next decade, but the extension of the Bush-era tax rates would more than consume those savings, the Congressional Budget Office warned on Wednesday. Jackie Calmes writes that the report underlines the high stakes for the special bipartisan panel created to devise a plan by December for how to achieve up to $1.5 trillion in savings promised by the deal over 10 years.

title: London Version of Woyzeck Combines Puppetry and Animation
description: Best known for its award-winning production of War Horse, the Handspring Puppet Company will next lend its unique approach to theater with a revival of Woyzeck on the Highveld.

title: India Seeks Deal to End a Hunger Strike
description: NEW DELHI  Indias Parliament met a major demand of the protest leader Anna Hazare on Thursday by agreeing to consider his proposed anticorruption legislation, but it remained unclear whether Mr. Hazare would finally end a hunger strike that has spawned a nationwide popular movement and deeply shaken Indias government.

title: Economic Research Institute Created in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  The leader of one of the most influential business families in Hong Kong announced Thursday that the familys foundation was setting up a nonprofit research group here to analyze economic and corporate issues from an Asian perspective.

title: A Mirror of Greatness, Blurred
description: WASHINGTON  It is a momentous occasion. Into an honored array of presidents and soldiers  the founders and protectors of the nation  has come a minister, a man without epaulets or civilian authority, who was not a creator of laws, but someone who, for a time, was a deliberate violator of them; not a wager of war but someone who, throughout his short life, was pretty much a pacifist; not an associate of the nations ruling elite but someone who, in many cases, would have been prevented from joining it.

title: If Cinderella Had a BlackBerry...
description: If Aline Brosh McKenna were to write a script about her life, it might open with McKenna, wavy-haired and underdressed, hopefully showing her work to a series of unsmiling magazine editors in New York. Discouraged but not defeated, she eventually screws up her resolve and decides to take a course in screenwriting. Cut to a classroom where student after student offers high-flown ideas for films that will never be made, until at last McKenna speaks: I want to make a caper comedy about two girls, and one falls in love with someone she thinks is a criminal who turns out to be an F.B.I. agent.

title: Steve Jobs Reshaped Industries
description: When Steve Jobs resigned as the chief executive of Apple on Wednesday, his note to the public and the Apple board was short and classy. The gist was this: I have always said if there ever came a day when I could no longer meet my duties and expectations as Apples C.E.O., I would be the first to let you know. Unfortunately, that day has come.

title: Foreign Workers Stranded Without Money or Visas
description: BAGHDAD  For months, they have sat here, half a block from the prime ministers palace in the Green Zone, essentially captives with little food, drinking water or electricity.

title: East Coast Battens Down for Arrival of Hurricane Irene
description: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C.  John H. Woolard, who is 79 years old, cannot remember how many hurricanes he has confronted at his home, also 79, which sits on stilts overlooking the Atlantic Ocean here. Is it 12? Or 14?

title: Italy Cost Cutting Shines Light on Obscure Entities
description: ROME  For more than 400 years, the Accademia della Crusca has kept an eye on the transformation of the Italian language to ensure its survival. But in these austerity-driven times, the Florentine institution is itself at risk.

title: Five Trillion Dollars
description: A couple of notes on the most recent Congressional Budget Office Projections:

title: Pre-reading for Jackson Hole
description: Im not at Jackson Hole  Ive been blackballed for a decade, ever since I started criticizing the great Greenspan  so I wont get to hear Bernankes speech. But like everyone else in econoland, Im anxiously waiting to hear what he says.

title: Buffett Invests $5 Billion in Bank of America
description: 1:04 p.m. | Updated Warren E. Buffett comes to the rescue, again.

title: With a Civil Trial Pending, the Strauss-Kahn Case Is Hardly Closed
description: There may be no second acts in American lives, assuming that F. Scott Fitzgerald got it right with that oft-quoted observation, but they surely exist in American jurisprudence. So for those of you who want still more of Dominique Strauss-Kahn and his accuser, Nafissatou Diallo, another chapter may be in store. If this were a movie, it might even be called Hot Spots! Part Deux. While the criminal charges of sexual assault and attempted rape have been dismissed, Mr. Strauss-Kahn still faces a lawsuit brought by Ms. Diallo, seeking unspecified damages for the violent and sadistic attack that she says she endured in the Midtown hotel where she cleaned rooms.

title: Aug. 25 Updates on the War in Libya
description: On Thursday, The Lede continues to follow developments in Libya, where there are still pockets of resistance in the capital, Tripoli, the search for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi continues, and regime loyalists are fighting to hold on to the city of Surt, the deposed Libyan leaders birthplace.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Remembering 9/11
description: With the tenth anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks just a few weeks away, the staff at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum is preparing to open this new site for visitors in Lower Manhattan. Sean Anderson, the chief technology officer for the organization, drops in to The New York Timess Tech Talk podcast discuss the Explore 9/11 mobile app for those who want to understand the event more clearly. Mr. Anderson also outlines the other online educational materials the museum offers, including an interactive timeline, a virtual tour of the site with Google Earth, and the 9/11 Memorials Web site.

title: Android Is No. 1 Target of Mobile Hackers

title: How Steve Jobs Reshaped Industries
description: Its hard to imagine that well ever see another 15 years of blockbuster, culture-changing hits like the iMac, iPod, iPhone and iPad, from Apple or anyone else, David Pogue writes on his blog, Pogues Posts. Read more >>

description: As my commuter train glides past the National Tennis Center, in snow or rain or sunshine, I count down the time to the United States Open, my favorite sports event in New York.

title: Young and Jobless
description: Since 1948, the Labor Department has been keeping track of how many young people find jobs during the summer, when employment of 16-to-24-year-olds typically peaks. Last month, the share of young people who were employed was just 48.8 percent, the lowest July rate on record.

title: New Rules Seen as Aid to Efforts to Unionize
description: The National Labor Relations Board issued new regulations on Thursday that require companies to put posters on their bulletin boards that inform employees about their rights to unionize under federal law.

title: Millions at Risk After Shift in Track for Hurricane Irene
description: 3:21 p.m. | Updated Millions of residents of the East Coast for whom a hurricane strike is, at best, a dim memory now face a serious threat from Hurricane Irene. For days computer simulations of the long-term trajectory of the storm had been shifting a bit to the east day by day.

description: This week: the salsa pianist and bandleader Larry Harlow, on a transformative night at the Cheetah club in 1971; rear-view props for the great American songwriters Jerry Lieber and Nick Ashford; and new CDs. Ben Ratliff, host.

description: Chris Colfer, Aziz Ansari, Amy Poehler, Nancy Pelosi and Richard Dawkins will be among the actors, performers, comedians, politicians, bigwigs, authors and atheist contrarians appearing at the 2011 New Yorker Festival, hosted by that magazine and running from Sept. 30 through Oct. 2, its organizers said on Thursday.

title: Hewlett-Packards Look-East Strategy
description: No one is giving Hewlett-Packards chief executive, Lo Apotheker, high marks for the new strategy he presented last week. It seemed a flip from the corporate game plan Mr. Apotheker had championed only a few months earlier. H.P. is paying a high price for a business software company. And it may have undermined the value of its personal computer business by saying it was considering selling it off.

title: Libyan Rebels Battle Loyalists
description: With Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi still at large, rebel fighters traded fire with their adversaries in Tripoli.

title: Los Angeles River Tries On New Role, as Waterway
description: LOS ANGELES  As they stood on the bank, the small and eager group exchanged the requisite disparaging jokes about the Los Angeles River, best known for its uninviting concrete channels that make many think of a drainage ditch.

title: Summer Cinema Worth Debating
description: FOR those of us who believe that any movie worth seeing is worth arguing about  and vice versa  summer can be a season of malaise. Screens are booked with consensus in mind, and the box office numbers are interpreted to deliver what look like unambiguous judgments. The conventional wisdom of 2011 is that everyone liked Bridesmaids and Rise of the Planet of the Apes, while nobody much cared for Friends With Benefits or Cowboys & Aliens.

title: The Best Deal You Ever Got, Just by Asking
description: Many personal finance experts will tell you they subscribe to the belief that everything is negotiable. It certainly doesnt hurt to ask, at least.

description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He concludes his analysis of the N.F.C. North with a look at the Vikings.He previously wrote about the Packers, the Bears and the Lions.

title: Face Time | Dagmara Dominczyk
description: Dagmara Dominczyk, a curvy brunette bombshell who was born in Poland, appears in the movie Higher Ground, which opens tomorrow. Shes far from dull  she still has a crush on her husband, Patrick Wilson, adores her two sons, Kalin and Kassian, and has a great knowledge of products, potions and cosmetics, Polish and otherwise. Her passion and energy are contagious.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Technodoulia Dot Com
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festivals close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Choosing Between Profits and Growth
description: In a venture-backed company like TerraCycle, there is an explicit expectation of aggressive revenue growth. So far, we have succeeded on that front, growing to more than $16 million in projected annual revenue this year  with a 103-percent yearly compounded growth rate since our inception. While this has put us on the Inc. 500 list, it hasnt always synched with that other very important line on our profit-and-loss statement: the profit.

description: A look at some of historys most polarizing films.

title: Last Man Running
description: DAEGU, South Korea  The fastest men and women from Jamaica filed out of the bus in single file Thursday: Olympic gold medalists like Veronica Campbell-Brown and Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce. But those gathered outside were waiting for one sprinter and one sprinter only. As Usain Bolt emerged last with his green ballcap perched at a jaunty angle, he was soon back in familiar formation  at the heart of a fast-moving pack of cameras, boom microphones, security guards and officials as he flashed three fingers to his public.

title: Farm-to-Table Meals, on European Farms
description: Outstanding in the Field, the organization that pairs local chefs and farmers to produce extravagant dinners amid orchards and fields, is driving its roving bus around Europe this fall. Founded in 1999, Outstanding in the Field has held sold-out, farm-based meals across the United States with cooking stars like Gabrielle Hamilton, Claudia Fleming, Charlie Parker and Evan Kleinman. A sort of cross between picnic, art happening and statement about sustainability, the meals celebrate the farmers who grow our food and literally connect diners to the land.

Cook, his successor, sent an e-mail to Apples staff reassuring them that Apple is not going to change. His message is a mix of cheerleading and an homage to the man he described as his mentor. title: Europe Braces for a Shift in the Arts

title: Classical Streamings Fitful Baby Steps
description: FOR innumerable music lovers in America, the world changed on July 14. That was the day that Spotify, a Swedish Internet music-streaming service founded in 2008 and eagerly adopted by millions of registered users in Europe, began operating in the United States after years of arduous negotiations with the big four major recording companies: Universal Music, Sony, Warner Brothers and EMI.

title: Let the Fun Begin
description: This Sunday, the seventh floor of the Museum of Art and Design will be transformed into a 1990s vortex of cyberpunk phosphorescence, Web 1.0 social networking and conceptual snacking (e.g., scented high-potency oxygen). Snack the Planet kicks off the museums Fun fellowship, which gives local night-life innovators carte blanche to create outsize party experiences at the museum. Lauren Devine and Patrik Sandberg, who masterminded the event, were inspired by the seminal Angelina Jolie film Hackers (1995) and its credo to hack the planet, but promise to collude with the present as well, with performances by the up-and-coming acts Pictureplane, Teengirl Fantasy and Mykki Blanco; an immersive multimedia entertainment zone designed by Thunder Horse Video; and advanced tweeting modalities engineered by DIS Magazines Nick Scholl, whose colleagues are supplying the souvenir branded condoms. Next up, Gag!, the long-running night at Metropolitan gay bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn hosted by Cameron Cooper and Zach Cole, will host what it is billing as a free store (in fact it will operate on a barter system) specializing in homegrown hipster esoterica during Fashion Week.Snack the Planet: Saturday, Aug. 27, 12-5 p.m. and Sunday, Aug. 28, 12-10 p.m. Bands play on Sunday only, starting at 5 p.m.

title: Killing Sea Lions to Save Salmon, Again
description: This summer, federal fisheries officials took away the hunting license they had awarded to state officials in Oregon, Washington and Idaho who wanted to kill the sea lions that are eating endangered salmon.

title: The Huntsman Gambit

This prompts Jim Antle to ask the obvious question: If Huntsman actually has more right-wing street cred on abortion, guns, taxes, you name it than the frontrunning Romney (or the ex-frontrunning, based on the latest polls), then why has he decided to run to Romneys left?

title: Summer Style | Sweater Weather?
description: Maybe its the temporary dip in temperature, or the imminent threat of hurricane Irene along the Northeast. Or, maybe women are just looking for an excuse to wear the gorgeous texture-heavy fall sweaters that recently arrived in stores. The actress Anne Hathaway pairs a crochet pattern with a pink tee and conceptual cargos, while Rachel Bilson goes cozy in a nubby cable with baggier boyfriend jeans and Claudia Schiffer takes a leaner approach with leggings and over-the-knee boots.

title: Traveler Insurance and the Hurricane
description: Travelers should double-check their travel insurance policies as Hurricane Irene makes its way to the East Coast, possibly touching down this weekend. If your trip is cut short because your home suffers damage, a little-known benefit in most travel insurance policies could allow you to file a claim for lost travel expenses.

description: PACK up the 10-gallon hats and the dirty, worn-thin Wranglers: the tough guys lost.

title: Casting Reality TV? Its Now Difficult To Find Real People
description: ITS going on two decades since MTV came out with The Real World, considered the first series to take ordinary, unknown people and focus cameras on them 24/7 until they became famous. Back in those relatively innocent times, before a bachelorette had handed out a single rose or any New Jersey housewife had flipped a table for a national audience, the concept of reality television was new enough that potential participants had no clue what to expect. Or what riches they could acquire in the process.

title: Compass Has Closed, Will Be Reborn as Loi
description: Compass, which famously defied its name by so often losing its way, as Frank Bruni wrote in a review in 2005, when the Upper West Side restaurant had already cycled through five chefs in less than four years, is heading off in a new direction again. (And three-pound lobsters for $45 are a thing of the past.)

title: Times API Class at General Assembly Next Monday, August 29
description: beta620 is excited to point you to next Mondays class, Use the News! An Introduction to the New York Times API, taking place at General Assembly. The 90-minute session starts at 6 p.m. General Assembly is a city-backed hub for design and technology skill-building, innovation and entrepreneurship. It opened its door this past January and regularly hosts events and classes and is located at 902 Broadway (at 20th St), 4th Floor in New York City. Instructor, Zoe Fraade-Blanar, has projects with the Times and teaches interactive design at NYU. The course description:

title: A Fan of Fantasy and Cartoon Squid
description: After nearly 40 years as a model of downtown cool, its still possible to find Debbie Harry, the longtime Blondie frontwoman, out at a tiny New York club, looking for some new momentum. I like to go out dancing and dance around to stuff, and sometimes that will really inspire a phrase, she said. You can just, you know, feel it. I love it. Ms. Harry, 66, who was wearing dresses made of double-sided razor blades decades before Lady Gaga plied a piece of beef, also has mainstream tastes. I love a lot of the music thats out, she said. I love Rihanna and I love Gaga and I love LMFAO. Ive always been a person who pays attention to the charts as well as the counterculture and sort of the underground stuff.

title: Running a Restaurant Is No Joke
description: A priest, a rabbi and a chicken walk into a restaurant. They sit at the bar. The priest orders a Bloody Mary and some oysters, the rabbi orders a garden salad and bluefish au poivre, and the chicken orders the five-course prix fixe.

Here are a couple of ideas along those lines from the worlds of poetry and science, with a poem by David Wagoner, provided by the Poetry Foundation, paired with a Science Times article by Carl Zimmer.
