title: 36 Hours in Portland, Ore.
description: WITH its celebrated bike culture and obsession with all things independent and artisan, Portland is a small-scale metropolis with an outsize cultural footprint. Spread across the twin banks of the Willamette River, this provincial hub of the Pacific Northwest has more than its share of natural beauty and an earnest, outdoorsy reputation. But in recent years, the city has emerged as the capital of West Coast urban cool, earning it a television series, IFCs Portlandia, devoted to satirizing its aesthetic and progressive social bent. Indeed, Portland  whose nicknames include Beervana and Soccer City, USA  is easy to poke fun at. Its also hard to resist.

title: TimesCast | August 25, 2011
description: Fighting for Tripoli intensifies; Warren E. Buffett to invest $5 billion in the Bank of America; and Steve Jobs's legacy as a C.E.O.

title: A Calamitous Convergence of Tracks for Hurricane Irene
description: 6:49 p.m. | Updated  The video of Hurricane Irene above was shot by astronauts aboard the International Space Station, 230 miles overhead.

title: Spending the Summer Behind a Book
description: So, you think you did a lot of summer reading this year?

title: New Yorkers, Are You Ready for the Hurricane?
description: We hope for the best, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Thursday, as Hurricane Irene headed north, but we prepare for the worst.

title: The Minimalist: Tomato Jam
description: The new Minimalist videos are on vacation, and so heres a vintage one, perfect for high summer: tomato jam.

title: Lumire | All the Tea in Paris
description: Megumi Ibusuki poured the cool liquid from an iron pot into a squat glass. She placed it, gently, on a square of striped raw silk set in a dark wood square tray. She urged me to sniff the aroma and observe the liquids color before I brought the glass to my lips. The liquid  the palest celadon  tasted like, well, Mount Fuji evanescence. I was sitting in a boutique on one of the chicest corners of Pariss Sixth Arrondissement, at the bottom of the rue de Seine, across the street from Grard Mulot, the luxury traiteur. But spiritually, I was in Japan.

title: U.S. Open Dining: Game, Set, Munch
description: The mailbox this week groaned with queries about where to eat during the United States Open tennis tournament, which kicks off in Queens on Monday and runs until Sept. 11. I did my best to give good counsel. As always, you may direct your questions about what restaurants you should visit in New York City to dinejournal@nytimes.com. You can also find me on Twitter: @SamSifton.

title: Ex-R.B.S. Chiefs Reign of Temper Tantrums
description: LONDON  Frederick A. Goodwin, the disgraced former chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland, used to lose his temper because of biscuits and sent the banks staff into panic mode because of a broken model airplane, according to a new book.

title: Tips for Watching the Qualifying Tournament
description: Here are some tips for wringing the most out of the qualifying tournament for the United States Open, based on my experience Tuesday.

title: RIM to Start a Music-Sharing Service
description: OTTAWA  Research In Motion on Thursday announced a new music sharing system based on its BlackBerry Messenger instant messaging system.

title: Circling the Unisphere, a Boroughs Backyard
description: HERE is a typical scene for a newcomer to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, in Queens.

title: Japan Lifts Ban on Beef From Disaster Area
description: TOKYO  Despite continuing fears over the safety of food from the area of the disaster-stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, Japan has lifted a ban on beef shipments from there that it had imposed just a month ago, when meat contaminated with radioactive material was found to have reached Japanese supermarkets.

title: Burmese Wary of Democracy, After Decades of Oppression
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Five months after a nominally civilian government took power in Myanmar, the country is awash in uncertainty about who is really in charge.

title: Political Cartoonist Whose Work Skewered Assad Is Brutally Beaten in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Masked gunmen severely beat Syrias best-known political cartoonist on Thursday, breaking his hand and leaving him to bleed on the side of a road in Damascus, activists said.

title: On Madison Avenue, Talk of Jobss Legacy
description: The news that Steven P. Jobs would step down as chief executive of Apple has generated an outpouring of comments from senior managers of agencies about his decades at the helm of the company as well as what might come next there.

title: New Revenue and Better Management Help Cherry Lane Theater
description: The artistic director of the Cherry Lane Theater said on Thursday that she no longer planned to sell its building in Greenwich Village to pay down debts, and added that the theaters recently precarious financial situation had been eased due to new rental income and changes to business practices.

title: TimesCast | Fighting for Tripoli
description: August 25, 2011 - It was one of the heaviest days of fighting in Libya's capital, as rebels and loyalists to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's regime continue to fight for control.

title: Buffett's $5 Billion BofA Bet
description: On Thursday, Berkshire Hathaway, run by Mr. Buffett, announced plans to invest $5 billion in Bank of America, a vote of confidence for the beleaguered financial firm.

title: Putt, Putt, Putt, Putt, Putt: Perez Sputters on 17
description: EDISON, N.J.  While most of the field found conditions ideal for scoring during Thursdays first round of the Barclays, Pat Perez shot an eight-over-par 79 that included taking five strokes on Plainfield Country Clubs 17th green.

title: Vaccine Cleared Again as Autism Culprit
description: Yet another panel of scientists has found no evidence that a popular vaccine causes autism. But despite the scientists best efforts, their report is unlikely to have any impact on the frustrating debate about the safety of these crucial medicines.

title: In a Twist, the Williams Sisters Can Play Bracket Busters at the Open
description: For all of the Williams sisters ups and downs with injuries and tour absences over the years, it was still normal to see at least one of them with a high seed next to her name when United States Open draws were announced. But this years draw was revealed on Thursday with Serena Williams seeded 28th and Venus not seeded at all.

title: Texas A&M Acts on a Possible Move
description: In a step that appears to start the process of Texas A&Ms move to the Southeastern Conference, the universitys president, R. Bowen Loftin, sent a letter to the Big 12 on Thursday announcing that Texas A&M was exploring our options for conference movement.

title: Buffetts $5 Billion Bet
description: Susanne Craig looks at Warren E. Buffetts decision to invest $5 billion in Bank of America, a vote of confidence for the beleaguered financial firm.

title: Monday, So Good to Me
description: WHEN my husband and I moved to New York for several months in August 2009, we were told repeatedly that nobody was in the city in August. We wandered around the crowded streets, marveling at the number of nobodies everywhere.

title: G.M. Link-Up With LG Chem Will Range Beyond Batteries
description: General Motors and South Koreas LG Group are teaming up to develop electric vehicles, though to what extent the two companies will collaborate is not yet known. The automaker announced an agreement to jointly design and engineer plug-in cars with LG Chem, a subsidiary of the South Korean conglomerate, on Thursday.

title: Whats Green and 154 Feet High?
description: Jackson, N.J.

title: Screams Standing Up
description: A closer look at Green Lantern, the newest roller coaster at Six Flags Great Adventure.

title: Like Cagney, Two Guys Square Off Against Dirty Rats, and Mean It
description: Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd and friends busted New York Citys ghosts. Prosecutors like Rudolph W. Giuliani busted the mob, or tried to. Trustbusters, gangbusters, chartbusters, mythbusters  pretty much everything the city harbors has been busted by someone. But rats continue to thrive.

title: Leaving Regrets to Others, Cheney Speaks
description: In an interview on NBCs Dateline, former Vice President Dick Cheney says that his new book, In My Time, will have heads exploding all over Washington. Whatever readers think of Mr. Cheneys politics, their heads are more likely to explode from frustration than from any sense of revelation. Indeed, the memoir  delivered in dry, often truculent prose  turns out to be mostly a predictable mix of spin, stonewalling, score settling and highly selective reminiscences.

title: The Job Jobs Did
description: From our archives: Notable designers, critics and editors offer thoughts on Steve Jobss legacy and his most significant contributions to design.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Higher Ground'
description: Vera Farmiga, the director and star of "Higher Ground," discusses a scene from her film.

title: Postcards From the Edge
description: Erik Piepenburg on low-budget marketing for the New York International Fringe Festival.

title: Revolutionary Brooklyn, Opera and Coney Island Strongmen
description: Whether patriots of the American Revolution, opera stars or a man who can lift and bend things with his hair, all kinds of extraordinary people are the focus of events around the city this weekend.

title: Like a Bodega, but Nestled in the Hills
description: The Hawthorne Valley Farm Store is not really the kind of place discovered by accident.

title: Angies List Files for I.P.O.
description: Add another one to the list.

title: Artists Rise to an Occasion for Reflection
description: SAMUEL Beckett might have been right about the fundamental tension between human frailty and the expressive instinct of human culture. If you really get down to the disaster, he once observed, the slightest eloquence becomes unbearable. But it has never kept humans from seeking refuge in art and turning to it to try to comprehend tragedy. And in the coming days and weeks surrounding the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, the outpouring of music, film, visual art, theater, books and public forums revisiting the events and the victims of that Tuesday morning will be not only immense but also powerful and richly diverse.

title: A Meek Rose Amid the Mods and Rockers in an English Resort Town
description: A nighttime image of the sea crinkling like a black plastic garbage bag sets the bleak tone of Brighton Rock, Rowan Joffes pungent adaptation of Graham Greenes classic crime novel from the late 1930s. If you strip away the books Roman Catholicism, which the movie mostly does, its story fits right into the nihilistic mood of today.

title: 9/11 in the Arts: An Anniversary Guide
description: An updated selected listing of events related to the 10-year anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, the Bahamas, the Dominican Republic and Gaza.

title: New Faces Appear Amid All the Mozart
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival has taken justifiable pride in its programming innovations in recent years, with this summers focus on Stravinsky as a case in point. But the festival still maintains some of its more time-honored strengths. From its early days, for example, Mostly Mozart has introduced conductors and soloists who have not been heard before hereabouts. The festival presented one of each  Jrmie Rhorer in his New York conducting debut, and Bertrand Chamayou, a pianist, in his United States debut  on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Irregular Economics
description: Im a bit late to this, but via Mark Thoma, David Glasner has a take-down of Robert Barros latest op-ed, in which Barro dismisses Keynesian economics for not being like regular economics.

title: Charles Schwab Sues Banks Over Rate Manipulation
description: Charles Schwab, the brokerage firm and investment manager, sued 11 major banks on Tuesday, claiming they conspired to manipulate a borrowing benchmark used to set interest rates.

title: Free-Trade Agreements Stuck in Obama-Republican Impasse
description: WASHINGTON  Even with almost zero common ground between them, President Obama and Republicans in Congress generally concur on the need for free-trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama. But they disagree on whose fault it is that those agreements  years in the making  have still not been approved.

title: Surgeon General Calls for Health Over Hair
description: The United States surgeon general has a new message for American women: It is O.K. to have a bad hair day.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, the Bahamas, the Dominican Republic and Gaza.

title: Where the Personal Is the Intensely Political
description: At one point in Circumstance, Maryam Keshavarzs swirling and sensuous melodrama of forbidden love in modern Tehran, four young Iranians slip into a clandestine video club in the back of a store. The walls are lined with Hollywood DVDs, and the friends discuss the possibility of dubbing two recent American movies into Persian: Milk and Sex and the City.

title: Giving Jesus a New Face
description: PHILADELPHIA  In the mid-1650s, Rembrandt was nearly bankrupt, and a court ordered the contents of his house in Amsterdam to be inventoried for sale. Among the works in his possession were three small paintings of Jesus, one listed as Head of Christ, done from life.

title: Discovery and Conservation of Plants
description: Paola Pedraza, assistant curator of the Institute of Systematic Botany at the New York Botanical Garden, writes about her recent expedition to catalog the flora of Las Orqudeas National Park, Colombia.

title: U.S., Canada Name Rosters for International Matches
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national team, on Thursday released his 24-man roster for two coming friendly matches  against Costa Rica at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif., on Sept. 2 and at Belgium in King Baudouin Stadium in Brussels four days later.

title: Navigating Between Faith and Skepticism
description: There is something remarkable  you might even say miraculous  about the way Higher Ground makes its gentle, thoughtful way across the burned-over terrain of the American culture wars. The film, directed with disarming grace and sharp intelligence by Vera Farmiga (who also stars in it), is about the conflict between skepticism and religious faith, but it does not treat that battle as an either/or, winner-take-all proposition. Movies about belief and believers frequently succumb to woozy piety or brittle contempt, but Higher Ground belongs, along with Robert Duvalls Apostle and Michael Tolkins underappreciated Rapture, among the elect. Focused with sympathetic intensity on the ordeal of a single soul, it illuminates, as though from within, a complex spiritual struggle.

title: Obama Vacation Nears End as Hurricane Irene Approaches
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass.  Perhaps fearing approaching rains in advance of Hurricane Irene, the Obama family spent nearly five hours at a private beach on Marthas Vineyard on Thursday, under increasingly cloudy skies, as their vacation neared its end.

title: Music For The Zero Lower Bound
So Whos the Help?
description: I am a dark-skinned Mexican woman with a baby who has the lighter skin of her American dad. We live in an apartment building on the Upper East Side. Often, I find myself on the elevator with residents whose comments make clear that they assume I am the nanny or a maid on my way to work. Granted, Im not in my best clothes, but I find this assumption racist. Should I say something to convey my irritation or just ignore them?

title: Preparing for Irene: Where to Get Advice and Information
description: There are a range of organization and agencies offering advice on preparing for Hurricane Irene as it moves toward New York City and the surrounding areas.

title: Just the Two of Us, When One Toddles
description: SEVERAL years ago, when my son Skuli was about 3, the two of us flew back to New York City early from visiting relatives in the Midwest so I could attend a big bash for my friends Jenny and Sara Jane, who were celebrating five years together.

title: Unfiltered Images, Turning Perceptions Upside Down
description: Harun Farockis film and video work is almost too interesting to be art. The fascinating subject matter of Serious Games I-IV, the main attraction in Harun Farocki: Images of War (at a Distance) at the Museum of Modern Art, would warrant a straightforward documentary. It deals with video-game technology used to train soldiers in practices of high-tech modern warfare.

title: Misguided Moments in Medical History
description: Visitors sometimes winced a little when they walked into one room at the home of Dr. Robert Megna, a physician in suburban Dallas. He and his wife, Bridget, lined the walls with surgical saws, forceps, tonsil slicers and wood-handled cranks for pulling teeth.

title: A Collections Contest of Objects
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  Some exhibitions are almost too smart for their own good. Especially in these days of post-post-everything, relational aesthetics, institutional critique and endless interventions, art shows can be so cerebral and self-conscious, so full of high-concept attitude, that the art is lost in the shuffle.

title: Time to Start Work on a Panic Button?
description: For two decades, the worlds governments have failed to meet their own commitment to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gas. As frustration builds among scientists, some of them have begun to argue for research on a potential last-ditch option in case global warming starts to get out of control. It is called geoengineering  or directly manipulating the Earths climate.

title: President Obama and his strategists deciding how boldly to take on Congress
description: President Obama and his strategists deciding how boldly to take on Congress. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear and White House Correspondent Helene Cooper join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: For One Family in Serenity, Ohio, It Seems Life Is Anything but Serene
description: The only reason I can think of to watch Vivi Friedmans flat, satirical farce The Family Tree  and its not a good enough reason  is the opportunity to play a game of spot the semi-star. Look! Theres Dermot Mulroney playing Jack, the glum, dazed paterfamilias of the Burnetts, a flamingly dysfunctional (sorry about that word) all-American family in Serenity, Ohio.

title: Excerpt: 'The Leftovers' (from the audiobook for \'The Leftovers\', published by Macmillan Audio)
description: An audio selection from "The Leftovers" by Tom Perrotta.

title: The Eerie Aftermath of a Mass Exit
description: Given the subject of his new novel, The Leftovers, probably no one followed the story of the noted evangelical (and former Internet hottie) Harold Camping more closely than Tom Perrotta, a novelist who is to the suburban enclaves of America what Sherwood Anderson was to Ohio. Im betting that reviews of The Leftovers that do not link Perrotta and Camping will be few and far between.

title: Numbers Favor Verlander for M.V.P., but the Votes Are Likely to Go Elsewhere
description: Fair or not, the most valuable player debate often comes down to the delicate balance between individual brilliance and team success.

title: Beats, Bikes, Skateboards and the Big Time
description: JANELLE MONE was somewhere on the Adriatic coast, sipping coconut juice and watching Oprah, but she was thinking about a parking lot in Brooklyn.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: Movies

title: Theater Listings: Aug. 26  Sept. 1
description: Theater

title: Its All in Your Head or in Your Bed
description: Isabelle Huppert is at it again. In Special Treatment, this mesmerizing French star with a history of playing sexually transgressive women (a sadomasochistic musician in The Piano Teacher, an incestuous mother in Ma Mre) portrays Alice Bergerac, a haughty prostitute whose clients engage her in elaborate role-playing fantasies. For a pedophiliac john, Alice dresses up as a little girl, clutches a teddy bear and sucks on a lollipop. For another client, who is not shown, she dons a blindfold and crams a ball gag into her mouth while awaiting his arrival.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: UPDATE: Many events have been postponed or canceled because of concerns about the approach of Hurricane Irene. Please see ArtsBeat for an evolving list of schedule changes for cultural events planned for this weekend.

title: In Consecrated Company
description: Photos of the Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial in Washington.

title: Friday Update: M.L.S. Postpones 3 Games
description: 11:34 a.m. | Updated Friday morning, M.L.S. announced that it had also postponed the D.C. United-Portland Timbers match, which had been rescheduled for a 2 p.m. start on Saturday. No new date was announced.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: Jazz

title: New York Region Prepares for Hurricane Irene
description: With Hurricane Irene threatening a full-force hit, New York City on Thursday ordered the evacuation of nursing homes and senior centers in low-lying areas and made plans for the possible shutdown of the entire transit system.

title: Interpreting the Contrasts of Mozart
description: The pianist Artur Schnabel once described Mozarts sonatas as too easy for children but too difficult for adults, referring to the relative ease of simply mastering the notes and the challenge of playing them well.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: Classical

title: They Have Coveted Christmas Meat, Now How Do They Eat It in Peace?
description: Its only a matter of degree. The absurdities of Tales From the Golden Age, a facetiously titled anthology of six urban legends of Romanian life in the waning days of the Ceausescu dictatorship, arent that much crazier than everyday existence anywhere else in our paranoid world. Consider that in a typical episode of The Office you will find a gentler, miniature version of the same kind of dissembling, bureaucratic idiocy and hierarchical kowtowing. The difference, of course, is that the employees of the Dunder Mifflin Paper Company of Scranton, Pa., dont risk prison or worse after inadvertently offending a higher-up.

title: Asco: Elite of the Obscure
description: An obscure Dadaist collective in Los Angeles finally gets its due some 40 years later.

title: Chicano Pioneers
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 2
description: Dance

title: Archdiocese Lists Priests Accused of Abuse
description: BOSTON  The Archdiocese of Boston on Thursday published a partial list of clergy members accused of sexual abuse, nearly a decade after a scandal erupted here involving widespread abuse by priests and revelations that the archdiocese had been shielding molesters for years.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: Art

title: Spare Times for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: Around Town

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: ARTHUR ASHE KIDS DAY

title: In Memoir, Cheney Addresses Controversies
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney offered his view of the political, legal and policy debates that arose over his storied career.

title: Tripoli, the Morning After
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Wednesday, the day after Tripolis liberation, was special. That morning, the suns rays shone more intensely and the salty water of the Mediterranean turned into pure honey.

title: Asteroid Dust Confirms Meteorites Origins
description: Last year, a Japanese spacecraft brought asteroid dust back to Earth for the first time, and now researchers analyzing the dust report that most meteorites on Earth originate from stony S-type asteroids like the one sampled, confirming what scientists have long theorized, but had never been able to prove.

title: A Renovation Uncovers Nastier Things Than Dust
description: More bump-in-the-night than blood-on-the-ground, Dont Be Afraid of the Dark is an old-fashioned spooker suggesting that dysfunctional families might benefit more from malignant demons than from a benign therapist.

title: Buried Treasure Doesnt Pay Off for Fox
description: In what is becoming a common occurrence, a broadcast network tried to cash in on a cable channels success on Wednesday night, with decidedly mixed results. The premiere of Foxs entry into the pawn-reality genre, Buried Treasure, hosted by the professional appraisers Leigh and Leslie Keno, drew just 3.6 million total viewers. Thats a number that would barely cover even half of the audience that Pawn Stars typically enjoys on the History Channel.

title: In Korea, the Game of Trading Has Rules
description: Is finance a game, or is it much more important than that?

title: Time to Make Way for Pedestrians and Mass Transit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Grand Slams Erase a Poor Start in Record Fashion
description: No team in major league history had hit three grand slams in a game before Yankees center fielder Curtis Granderson strode to the plate in the bottom of the eighth inning Thursday, the crowd at Yankee Stadium having been thinned, but the bases loaded one more time.

title: Pursuing Madoff, Long Before His Ponzi Scheme Collapsed
description: In 2000, Harry M. Markopolos made a presentation to a senior enforcement lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission. The topic: Bernard L. Madoff Securities, an investment business with remarkably steady returns. He offered possible explanations for the firms uncanny success, including an explosive one.

title: She Walks in Beauty, and Brings Along a Bazooka
description: Refusing to believe what the evidence is telling him, the F.B.I. agent chasing the implacable killer in Colombiana snarls: Were not looking for a woman. Its not possible.

title: The High Human Cost of Following the Money in the Madoff Fraud Case
description: On Dec. 11, 2008, Bernard L. Madoff confessed to F.B.I. agents that he was running an immense Ponzi scheme, involving tens of billions of dollars from investors all around the world. That might have been a day of triumph for Harry Markopolos, the whistle-blower who for years had tried to get the Securities and Exchange Commission, as well as several business publications, to investigate Mr. Madoffs activities. Instead, the arrest provided only momentary relief. As set out in the documentary Chasing Madoff, Mr. Markopolos panicked, thinking it would be only a matter of time before embarrassed S.E.C. agents would break into his home in Whitman, Mass., seeking to erase his records of their incompetence. Of course, as with everything else in this case, the S.E.C. did nothing.

title: Joke Is on the Siblings of a Modern Holy Fool
description: Our Idiot Brother blends two of the staples of modern screen comedy: its a bittersweet, indie-ish study of grown-up sibling relations, and also a raucous celebration of male immaturity. At its center are three sisters  variously wanton, manipulative and unfulfilled  and their sweet, goofy man-child of a brother. At first it is the brothers inability or refusal to behave like a grown-up that seems to be the big problem, but by the end he functions as a kind of holy fool, exposing the hypocrisy and unhappiness of everyone around him.

title: In Towns Along the Road to Tripoli, Anxieties Compete With Exuberance
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The road to Tripoli begins at Dehiba, a backwater Tunisian town made prominent by the revolution across its border. Free Libya, the flags read, hoisted on cars passing customs in a gesture driven by pride as much as fear.

title: Subject: Steve Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Bittersweet Revenge
description: Drenched in testosterone and festering grudges, A Proper Violence struggles mightily to overcome the claustrophobic confusion of its first 30 minutes. That it eventually  if barely  succeeds is due more to the resilience of its actors than to the discipline of its makers.

title: Mike Flanagan, Former Orioles Pitching Star, Dies at 59
description: Mike Flanagan, the Baltimore left-hander who won the 1979 Cy Young Award as the American Leagues leading pitcher and who later worked as an Orioles executive, coach and broadcaster, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound on Wednesday outside his home in Sparks, Md., the authorities reported. He was 59.

title: China to Sue ConocoPhillips Over Oil Spills
description: BEIJING  The Chinese maritime authority is preparing to sue ConocoPhillips, the American oil company, over two oil spills in June that engulfed large swaths of Bohai Bay in north China, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.

title: Ex-Lehman Officials to Pay $90 Million to Settle Suit
description: Jim Young/ReutersRichard S. Fuld Jr., Lehmans former chief, is among those being sued.

title: C.I.A. Demands Cuts in Book About 9/11 and Terror Fight
description: WASHINGTON  In what amounts to a fight over who gets to write the history of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath, the Central Intelligence Agency is demanding extensive cuts from the memoir of a former F.B.I. agent who spent years near the center of the battle against Al Qaeda.

title: A Timely Bank Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: A Feminist Spin on the Sexploitation Genre
description: Pitched somewhere between after-hours cable soft-core and an overambitious student art film, Stripped Down is bad in so many ways I cant help but feel a slightly tender affection for it.

title: U.S. Widens Role in Mexican Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has expanded its role in Mexicos fight against organized crime by allowing the Mexican police to stage cross-border drug raids from inside the United States, according to senior administration and military officials.

title: Romney Continues Charm Offensive With Personal Stories
description: EXETER, N.H.  Mitt Romney continued his rollout of the warmer, sunnier, more effusive Mitt Romney here on Thursday morning, opening his speech by saying, rather directly, I thought today Id tell a couple of personal stories.

title: Next Makeover for a New No. 1 Is in Marketing
description: MONTREAL  Pressed against a barricade, fans glimpsed Novak Djokovic and readied their cellphones. Necks craned. Cameras flashed. Djokovic, the Serb now deep into a historic tennis season, had created an impromptu mosh pit at a recent tournament here.

title: Corporate Influences on Children
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Purchase for Bloomberg
description: Bloomberg L.P. is sparing no expense for its first big deal. The company started by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York  a rival to Thomson Reuters, the parent company of Breakingviews  agreed to buy the Bureau of National Affairs, a niche publisher, for about $1 billion in cash.

title: The Cost of Going to College, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Pandora Gains on Subscriptions and Mobile Ads
description: In its first quarterly earnings since going public, Pandora Media, the company behind the Internet radio service, reported increased revenue on Thursday, as well as growth in subscriptions and mobile advertising.

title: Flanagans Off-Field Legacy: He Cherished the Joy of New Life
description: Strange how we remember a particular athlete, what resonates most in the end. Mike Flanagan won 167 major league games, including 23 in 1979 when he was the American Leagues Cy Young Award winner. But nothing he ever did as a crafty left-hander stayed with me quite like the look on his face when he spoke of first knowing that fatherhood was imminent.

title: Casey Ribicoff, Senators Widow and a Style Leader, Dies at 88
description: Not long after doctors had determined in 1994 that Ronald Reagan was suffering from Alzheimers disease, his wife, Nancy, found an unexpected ally. Casey Ribicoff was coping with the same mental decline in her husband, Abraham A. Ribicoff, the resolutely liberal former senator from Connecticut.

title: She Hopes to Help a Dove Campaign Become a Hit
description: UNILEVERS Dove brand, which made its advertising mark in real beauty commercials with women who were not models, is showcasing women disc jockeys to attract young consumers to its newest deodorant products.

title: August 29: Times API Class in NYC
description: Next Monday, August 29, General Assembly will be hosting a 90-minute class on using the the New York Times APIs. We take no credit for the undertaking; all credit goes to the talented Zoe Fraade-Blanar and the good people at General Assembly. We are, however, thrilled to see our APIs put to use.

title: Stop Waiting for Superman
description: Hope and audacity hung in the winter air those early months of the perilous presidency of Barack Obama, a time when street vendors were selling pictures of him as Superman, complete with an S across his chest.

title: U.N. Releases $1.5 Billion in Frozen Qaddafi Assets to Aid Rebuilding of Libya
description: WASHINGTON  Even with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi still on the run, the nations that aided Libyas rebellion moved swiftly Thursday to release billions of dollars of cash needed for the difficult  and, for some foreign companies, potentially lucrative  task of rebuilding the country after six months of fighting.

title: When Schools Depend on Handouts
description: EARLIER this month, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that he and five other wealthy individuals had raised $1.5 million to reinstate the January Regents exams, which New York State had canceled because of budget cuts.

title: Labor Board to Reproach Restaurant in Park
description: The strike at the Boathouse restaurant in Central Park has lasted more than two weeks, with 60 waiters, cooks and dishwashers picketing, chanting and drumming outside day after day. But now the strikers are getting some long-awaited outside support.

title: A Not-Quite Nation Happy in Russias Embrace, but Wanting a Little Wiggle Room
description: SUKHUMI, Georgia  Three years after Russia defied international consensus and unilaterally declared a breakaway enclave of Georgia called Abkhazia to be a sovereign nation, the areas leaders continue to struggle with the price of that recognition.

title: Judge Still Weighing Conviction on Obstruction in Bonds Case
description: More than four months after Barry Bondss perjury trial, a federal judge in San Francisco announced Thursday that she still had not decided whether to drop his obstruction of justice conviction.

title: Buffetts Bank of America Stake Is Viewed as a Seal of Approval
description: Lucas Jackson/ReutersWarren E. Buffetts investment has a guaranteed payout.

title: Buffett to Invest $5 Billion in Shaky Bank of America
description: Warren E. Buffett, the legendary investor, is sinking $5 billion into Bank of America in a bold show of faith in the countrys biggest, and most beleaguered, financial institution. It comes amid deepening worries about the long-term health of the company, which has already had to set aside roughly $20 billion to atone for its mortgage misdeeds at the height of the housing bubble.

title: Where Some Earn Enmity, Jobs Won Affection
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs  domineering, short-tempered and anything but warm and fuzzy  has done something few business people in history have ever accomplished: engender genuine affection.

title: Big Shoes at Apple, but Maybe Not Unfillable
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Proposition 1: Steven P. Jobs is a visionary who ranks among the greatest American inventors. Proposition 2: Apple will keep churning out the hits under his successor, Timothy D. Cook.

title: Lottery Numbers
With Hurricanes, There Is Plenty of Time to Evacuate, and Thats the Problem
description: When it is time to go, it is probably too late.

title: In Britain, a Meeting on Limiting Social Media
description: LONDON  British officials and representatives of Twitter, Facebook and BlackBerry met Thursday to discuss voluntary ways to limit or restrict the use of social media to combat crime and periods of civil unrest, while trying to dodge charges of hypocrisy and censorship that trailed Prime Minister David Camerons call to restrict use of the networks after this months riots.

title: The Star-Spangled Bummer
Bernankes Perry Problem
description: As I write this, investors around the world are anxiously awaiting Ben Bernankes speech at the annual Fed gathering at Jackson Hole, Wyo. They want to know whether Mr. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, will unveil new policies that might lift the U.S. economy out of what is looking more and more like a quasi-permanent state of depressed demand and high unemployment.

title: Stoops Applauds N.F.L.s Ruling on Pryor
description: NORMAN, Okla.  So where does Bob Stoops, coach of the preseason No. 1 Oklahoma Sooners, stand on the issue of players paying for sins committed in college even as they seek penalty-free refuge in the pros?

title: Grand Slams and Pinstripes
description: Theres something about the Yankees and grand slams.

title: On Trail, Casual Friday Versus Boardroom Cool
description: LEBANON, N.H.  When Rick Perry popped in for popovers at a Portsmouth, N.H., cafe recently, he cheerfully dismissed the bevy of protesters awaiting him and the two women haranguing him about Social Security. He handled the skeptics with aplomb, grinning at the hecklers and displaying a self-assured ease with everyone from the littlest of children to the angriest of voters.

title: Do They Want to Know Less?
description: Understanding what is happening in the economy is essential in hard times. Yet House Republicans have proposed budget cuts that could cripple or end government surveys. The surveys are used to generate timely and accurate data and answer such basic questions as: Is the economy descending into another recession?

title: Start Time for Jets-Giants Game Is Moved
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants announced Thursday night that the kickoff for Saturdays preseason game against the Jets would be moved up five hours, from 7 p.m. to 2 p.m., in response to forecasts calling for bad weather related to Hurricane Irene.

title: For the C Trains Rickety and Rackety Cars, Retirement Will Have to Wait
description: There is the telltale wheeze, then an ominous rattle. And then the C train, that least loved of New York City subway lines, rumbles sadly into the station, its faded tin-can siding a dreary reminder to passengers of an earlier subterranean era.

title: Donalds Chance to Go One Better Than Woods
description: EDISON, N.J.  Because he leads the money lists of both the PGA and the European Tours, the Englishman Luke Donald was asked this week at the Barclays about the possibility of becoming the first player to finish a season as the top money winner on both.

title: Robbers Kill at Least 12 in Nigeria
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Armed robbers killed at least 12 people and possibly more in attacks on a bank and police station in northeastern Nigeria on Thursday, according to a government official, a local clergyman and news reports.

title: The Shortage of Vital Drugs
description: A widespread shortage of prescription drugs is hampering the treatment of patients who have cancer, severe infections and other serious illnesses. While some Republican politicians have railed against the imaginary threat of rationing under health care reform, Congress has done nothing to alleviate the all-too-real rationing of lifesaving drugs caused by this crisis.

title: Friday: Its a Quigley!
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  By now, I think Ive made it pretty clear that Im very happy about the arrival of Baby Girl Donovan-Quigley, daughter of todays constructor Brendan Emmett Quigley and his wife Liz Donovan. They are a terrific couple, and Wordplay wishes them happiness as they start this new adventure in parenthood. Mr. Quigley constructed a special puzzle in honor of the birth of his daughter, and if you havent done it yet, I highly recommend it. You can find it here.

title: With Storm Expected, Barclays May Need to Be Cut to 54 Holes
description: EDISON, N.J.  Bright sunlight shined on the Barclays tournament director, Slugger White, as he walked toward a news conference at Plainfield Country Club on Thursday night. But his mood  and the outlook for completing play on schedule in the first event of four in the FedEx Cup playoffs  was darkened by the specter of Hurricane Irene spinning up the Eastern Seaboard toward a possible landfall on the New Jersey coast.

title: A Lifeline for Homeowners
description: Help may finally be on the way for borrowers stuck in high-interest-rate mortgages. Shaila Dewan and Louise Story reported in The Times that the White House is considering a proposal that would ease refinancings for millions of underwater homeowners whose loans are owned or backed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-controlled mortgage companies.

title: Calling Industrys Bluff
description: The historically chummy relationship between the oil industry and the federal government changed radically after the Deepwater Horizon explosion in 2010. The Interior Department reorganized its enabling bureaucracy and wrote new regulations to govern exploration and drilling.

title: A Ride on the C Train
description: The C train wends its way from Chambers Street to Fulton Street on Tuesday evening, August 23.

title: President Rick Perry?
description: A few weeks ago it was possible to believe that Mitt Romney would win the New Hampshire primary and cruise easily to the Republican nomination. Its harder to see that now.

title: New Look at City Lapses in Adoption Abuse Case
description: More than 30 years ago, a Queens foster mother was investigated and cited for scalding a boy in her care. But despite that finding, the city did nothing in the decades that followed to prevent the woman, Judith Leekin, from carrying out one of the most brazen and disturbing child welfare schemes in recent memory.

title: Jacobs Accepts No. 2 Role in the Giants Backfield
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A year ago, Brandon Jacobs seemed combative and frustrated, his disappointment about the role he was given in the Giants running game evident. This season, Jacobs has appeared more accepting and at ease, giving the impression that, as he prepares to enter his seventh season, he has found some measure of peace.

title: Dr. King Weeps From His Grave
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: For Some in G.O.P., a Tax Cut Not Worth Embracing
description: WASHINGTON  It is hard to find a tax cut that Congressional Republicans dislike. Unless it is a tax cut pushed by President Obama.

title: Notable Financial Investments by Buffett
description: Warren E. Buffetts investments have so far paid off handsomely.

title: Arson Fire Kills 52 in a Casino in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Armed men burst into a casino in the northern Mexican city of Monterrey on Thursday and set a fire that killed at least 52 people and injured several others, the authorities said.

title: Young Hispanics College Enrollment Rose 24% in Year, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  Hispanics in the United States have registered significant gains in education, with college enrollment among young Hispanics up by 24 percent from 2009 to 2010, a new report shows.

title: In Echo of Pancho Villa, Modern Raid Shakes a Town on the Edge of Extinction
description: COLUMBUS, N.M.  An armed raid in the wee hours of the morning nearly a century ago has long defined this town. There is a Pancho Villa State Park here, a Pancho Villa Cafe and historical markers pointing out where Villa, a revolutionary leader from Mexico, crept across the border with a group of men and opened fire here.

title: 13 Plants Felt Earthquake, but Reactors Were Spared
description: WASHINGTON  The earthquake Tuesday in the Eastern United States was felt at 13 locations with nuclear power plants, from North Carolina to Michigan, but reactors shut down at only one, North Anna in Virginia, 10 miles from the epicenter. There was no damage to nuclear systems at any of the sites, according to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Meant to Ease Fears of Deportation Program, Federal Hearings Draw Anger
description: A task force set up by the Obama administration to ease political tensions over a deportation program has held the last of four public hearings, which instead served largely to galvanize vocal protests against the policy.

title: Seoul Mayor Resigns After Losing School Lunch Referendum
description: SEOUL, South Korea Mayor Oh Se-hoon of Seoul said on Friday that he was resigning after the failure of his campaign to end free lunches for all 810,000 elementary and middle school students.

title: TEST
description: Annotator test video

title: An Office for Day Laborers Waiting on the Corner
description: Every morning, rain or shine, Miguel used to head for the corner of Belmont and Milwaukee Avenues and wait at an informal gathering spot of day laborers in hopes he would be hired to set tile, pour concrete or lay sod.

title: Casino Bill Invites Questions About Growth
description: Questions surrounding a gambling bill that is headed to Gov. Pat Quinns desk have focused on regulation and on how much new casinos could raise for state coffers.

title: Word of the Day | willful
description: willful \wil-fl\ adjective

title: While Pushing Through the Longer School Day, Some Things to Keep in Mind
description: On Monday, when Chicagos mayor revealed a 53-item checklist to self-assess his first 100 days, one notable campaign promise  Lengthen planets shortest school day/year  wasnt on it.

title: Free Music Schools Cost: A Week on the Sidewalk
description: Rebecca Tirado arrived six days early to enroll her 7-year-old twins at the Peoples Music School. With a tent, an air mattress and a cooler stocked with Gatorade and yogurt, she and her husband were ready for an extended sidewalk stakeout.

title: Out to Lure Audiences to Liszt et al.
description: On a recent morning, Michael Tilson Thomas listened to a reporter recite the bad news about classical music. Its audience was disappearing. It couldnt compete with pop music. It was out of tune with modern living.

title: The Struggle at Candlestick to Keep Peace Among Fans
description: As the fan violence escalated at Saturdays preseason N.F.L. game between the Raiders and the 49ers at Candlestick Park, security officials received a message through Badfan, a system in the stadium that allows people to text tips about unruly behavior and fights.

title: Water Use by Vineyards Is Challenged
description: The dense forests of redwood, oak and Douglas fir that once covered much of Sonoma County have for many decades been giving way to pastures, orchards, subdivisions  and vineyards.

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/26/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/26/2011

title: A Year of Rising Suicides on Bridge and Tracks
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: GTT
description: AUSTIN

title: Saying Goodbye to a Teammate
description: Football players from Mainland Regional High School attended the funeral of a teammate, Edgar Bozzi, 16, in Goshen, N.J. He was one of four Mainland players killed in a crash on the Garden State Parkway on Saturday.

title: Despite His Current Vehemence on Taxes, Perry Has a More Nuanced Record
description: To hear him tell it on the presidential campaign trail, Gov. Rick Perry has never met a tax increase he liked.

title: Corrections: August 26
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Rhino Horns Put Europes Museums on Thieves Must-Visit List
description: IPSWICH, England  TheIpswich Museum contains many alluring and potentially theft-worthy items, including a spectacular 2,000-year-old gold-leaf Egyptian death mask on loan from the British Museum and a rare Hawaiian cape featuring feathers from the extinct oo bird. But when two thieves forced their way in after midnight on July 28, they were seeking something else entirely.

title: Tareque Masud, Bangladeshi Filmmaker, Is Dead at 54
description: Tareque Masud, the first director from Bangladesh to be honored at the Cannes Film Festival, died in a bus accident near Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Aug. 13. He was 54.

title: Frank Potenza, Foil for Kimmel, Is Dead at 77
description: Frank Potenza, a onetime New York City policeman who became Uncle Frank, a regular comic foil for his nephew Jimmy Kimmel, the ABC late-night host, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 77.

title: Forget First Impressions; Perry Isnt Bush 2
description: Watching Rick Perry can cause flashbacks. He sometimes does that head bob  the clucking chicken thing  that George W. Bush used to do during speeches. Hes got a twang  theres no mistaking him for a Michigander. Both he and Mr. Bush wear boots with suits. The Texas way of saying things is there, too, as in this coinage: If you want to live in a state and in a country that

title: Assessing Climate Change in a Drought-Stricken State
description: Texas has endured its worst one-year drought in recorded history. And the hottest July. August is on course to be hotter still, setting another record.

title: Prime Ministers Departure Underscores Japans Search for Leadership
description: TOKYO  Three months ago, Japans unpopular prime minister, Naoto Kan, seemed to have a chance at a comeback, winning applause from Japans now nuclear-phobic public by facing down the powerful atomic energy establishment and ordering the shutdown of a nuclear plant in a risky earthquake fault zone.

title: A Stone of Hope
description: WHERE is the new Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. memorial?

title: Aug. 26, 1920 | 19th Amendment Takes Effect, Giving Women the Vote
description: On Aug. 26, 1920, eight days after it had been ratified, the 19th Amendment was declared in effect by Secretary of State Bainbridge Colby, giving female citizens the right to vote in all American elections.

title: Lewis Hine: Photographer, Activist, Character
description: This month, James Estrin met with Alison Nordstrom, the curator of a major retrospective of more than 150 Lewis Wickes Hine photographs that opens Sept. 7 in Paris at the Henri Cartier-Bresson Foundation. Ms. Nordstrom is also the curator of photographs at George Eastman House International Museum of Photography and Film in Rochester, where the two talked. Their conversation has been edited.

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 26, 2011
description: Todays question was written by Shannon Doyne. Her question comes from the article Folk Art Museum Considers Closing.

title: Do We Need a New Way to Teach Math?
description: Students not planning to become engineers or mathematicians are known to complain that they dont need certain math classes. Are you among them? Have your math teachers included practical, everyday applications of the principles and theorems you learn in class? What are some examples?

title: News Quiz | Aug. 26, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: The Early Word: Substance and Style
description: In Todays Times:

title: Gunmen Seize Son of Slain Pakistani Official
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Gunmen abducted the son of a slain former governor from the eastern city of Lahore on Friday, relatives and police officials said.

title: China Announces New Top Official for Tibet
description: BEIJING  Chinese leaders have appointed a new Communist Party leader to govern the vast and sometimes restive region of Tibet, where economic development has been rapid but tensions between indigenous people and immigrants from Chinas Han majority have been high, and where human rights have been an abiding concern.

title: Dick Stanfel and Jack Butler for the Hall
description: The Hall of Fame seniors committee named Dick Stanfel and Jack Butler on Wednesday as finalists for election in the class of 2012. To be elected, they need the same 80 percent support as the modern era finalists when the full selection committee meets in Indianapolis on Feb. 4, the day before Super Bowl 46. A few thoughts about the nominees:

title: For Heritage Days, Access to Hidden Paris
description: Paris is full of sumptuous mansions and secret gardens, hidden from outsiders by sober stone facades and closed coach doors. But on the weekend of Sept. 17 and 18, as part of Les Journes Europennes du Patrimoine, or European Heritage Days, doors will swing open to reveal some of the citys hidden jewels.

title: Impact of Gulf Spills Underwater Dispersants Is Examined
description: In the wake of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, BP sought and obtained permission to use dispersants, detergent-like compounds, to break up the 200 million gallons of Louisiana sweet crude, into tiny droplets that would mix throughout the water column, trying to lessen the immediate impact of the oil slick on fragile coastal ecosystems.

title: Recovering From a Balance-Sheet Recession
description: 10:04 p.m. | Updated to clarify time frame for estimate of economic growths effect on government revenue.

title: Grim Evidence of Fightings Toll Becomes Clearer in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  As the fighting died down in Tripoli on Friday, the scope and savagery of the violence during the nearly weeklong battle for control of the capital began to come into sharper focus.

title: Hurricane Irene Puts East Coast in Line for Fury
description: WILMINGTON, N.C.  Hurricane Irene began lashing the North Carolina shore on Saturday, foreshadowing with brutal authority what is to come as this vast storm, its most forceful winds stretching outward for 90 miles, churned north toward New York.

title: A New York Hurricane Could Be a Multibillion-Dollar Catastrophe
description: Time to think about the unthinkable. What if a major hurricane were to pass close to New York City, as several forecasting models now suggest that Hurricane Irene might?

title: Impasse Lingers Between Indian Hunger Striker and Government
description: NEW DELHI  The impasse between the anticorruption campaigner Anna Hazare and Indias government continued Friday as Mr. Hazare vowed to maintain his hunger strike until leaders in Parliament agreed to key elements of his proposal for an independent anticorruption agency.

title: Stocks End a Volatile Week With Strong Gains
description: Stocks on Wall Street surged on Friday, leading to a weekly gain of more than 4 percent after a volatile wait for word on whether there would be new economic stimulus from the Federal Reserve.

title: Rio Tinto and Mitsubishi Raise Bid for Coal and Allied
description: Rio Tinto and the Mitsubishi Corporation raised their offer to acquire all of Coal and Allied Industries to roughly $131 a share, from $128, in a deal that values Coal and Allied, an Australian mining company, at around $11.6 billion.

title: Memories of Great Gams of the Past
description: EVERY Broadway musical has its originalists, the devotees who judge every subsequent production against the memory of the first one. The you-had-to-be-there contingent is particularly strong for Follies, Stephen Sondheim and James Goldmans 1971 collaboration with the directors Harold Prince and Michael Bennett. Goldmans book and Mr. Sondheims music and lyrics use the reunion of showgirls from a fictitious Ziegfeld Follies-style revue to juxtapose the dazzling heyday of Depression-era Broadway with the decades of ambivalence and regret that followed. The latest revival  directed by Eric Schaeffer and featuring Bernadette Peters, Jan Maxwell, Ron Raines and Danny Burstein  will undoubtedly generate its own share of memories when it opens on Sept. 12 at the Marquis Theater. Until then here are a handful of Follies reminiscences from people who have seen em all (but particularly the original one) and are still here.

title: In Egypt, the Lure of Leaving
description: The first time I met Ayman, he insisted on picking me up in his shiny black Chevrolet sedan outside the King of Shrimp, a popular fish restaurant in the Cairo neighborhood of Shobra. It was April, and he had just returned from Berlin, where he attended a conference on tourism (the worlds biggest) for his job. A brand new I Love Berlin key chain dangled from his rearview mirror. Also dangling was a small metallic cross, along with I Love London and, of course, I Love New York. As a procurement manager at a multinational company, he travels a great deal. I have a busy passport, he told me during that first meeting, handing me his overfull visa pages to inspect.

title: The Road to Tripoli
description: On the trip from Dehiba, Tunisia, to Tripoli, the war-torn capital of Libya, there is anxiety and competing exuberance. Anthony Shadid reports.

title: ABN Amro to Cut 2,350 Positions
description: The ax falls again in finance.

title: Suicide Bomber Attacks U.N. Building in Nigeria
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  A suicide bomber detonated a vehicle packed with explosives outside the United Nations headquarters in the Nigerian capital of Abuja on Friday, destroying several floors in a thunderous blast that left at least 18 people dead, witnesses and officials said.

title: Academic Debate, Real Consequences (Wonkish)
description: With all eyes on Jackson Hole, it may be worth talking a bit about the intellectual history that lies behind some of the policy debate.

title: Rove Turns Rhetorical Fire Toward Republicans
description: For the better part of a decade, Karl Rove has seemed to relish his role as the man liberals loved to hate  in their view, a political mastermind who did whatever he could to advance the Republican agenda.

title: Putting the Spark in Arcade Fire
description: For Arcade Fire devotees, Regine Chassagnes sparkly dresses  gold stripes and disco stardust at the Grammys, tarnished sequins atwirl on Saturday Night Live  are as much a signature as the bands exuberant sound; even from the cheap seats, Chassagne shimmers. Get a little closer, and the finely wrought frocks, designed by the Montreal-based artist and fashion designer Renata Morales, 36, reflect another unique talent at work.

title: 2011 Cincinnati Bengals Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He kicks off a look at the A.F.C. North with the Bengals.

title: Softbank Offloads Yahoo Stake to Repay Citigroup Loan
description: TOKYO  The Japanese Internet and telecommunications company Softbank said Friday that it would offload most of its 4 percent stake in Yahoo to Citigroup to pay off a $1.1 billion loan.

title: Target New Jersey
description: Theres a scene in The Longest Day in which Major Pluskat excitedly calls his superior to report thousands of Allied ships offshore. His skeptical commander asks where those ships are heading  and Pluskat yells, Straight at me!

title: Once Again, No Candidate Pataki
description: 1:51 p.m. | Updated  The latest possible presidential bid by former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York has gone the way of his previous possible bids: it ended before it began.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Buffetts Bank of America Stake Is Viewed as a Seal of Approval | Warren E. Buffett snatched up shares of Goldman Sachs and General Electric during some of the darkest days of 2008, injecting life and funds into the companies and turning a handsome profit later. On Goldman alone, Mr. Buffett netted $1.7 billion.

title: A Puzzle Times Two
description: Q. There is a very curious pair of houses in Cecil Everss 1914 book The Commercial Problem in Buildings. Where were they? ... Andrew Alpern, Manhattan

title: 20 Years Later, Artists Apply Healing Touch to Crown Heights
description: On Aug. 18, 1991, Tim Okamura arrived at LaGuardia Airport from Edmonton, Canada, with a couple of suitcases, art school ambitions and a wide-eyed view of New York City that included little more than museums, graffiti and hip-hop.

title: Leo to Gravitate to New York From Edinburgh
description: Leo, a solo show featuring a gravity-defying performance by Tobias Wegner, is the winner of the 2011 Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh award, to be presented at a ceremony on Friday in the Scottish capital. The show, one of more than 800 theater productions in the Edinburgh Festival Fringe this year, is presented by the German company Circle of Eleven and will receive a fully mounted production in New York next winter.

title: Helen Mirren: The Reluctant Libertine
description: You once said that you have no maternal instincts whatsoever, which I thought was interesting considering that your mother once dangled you out of a window in an effort to stop your crying.  A little bit of a Michael Jackson. I was a baby, so I dont really know, but my mother said to me: At one point I almost threw you out the window. I held you out there thinking, If I drop her, maybe shell shut up. Many mothers would be very sympathetic to that. I dont think she particularly wanted to be a mother. I think she adored my father, I think she loved sex and it was in the days of no birth control. And the direct result of loving sex is very often having children. She did everything that was required, but I think she would have liked a little more freedom.

title: Secret History
description: I didnt find out for years, but I fathered a child with a woman in my neighborhood who was, and still is, married to another man. The girl does not know about any of this. Neither does the husband. At the mothers request, I have had nothing to do with the girl, though I offered to tutor her. Does she have a right to know her true parentage upon reaching adulthood? Sooner? Over the objection of the mother? Only when the husband dies? Who can make these decisions and when? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: The Letting Go
description: It had rained heavily the night before. The steep stone steps of the ghat are slick and slippery, and when my father pulls me onto the boat, the water feels more stable than the ground. The boatman rows out toward the open river, and the city of Varanasi swings into full view.

title: The Two-Minus-One Pregnancy
description: I cant help worrying that such a public bemoaning of what should be a private decision serves only to give ammunition to those who would take away a womans right to a safe, legal abortion.

title: Morgan Freeman Goes From God to Science
description: One of the many things Ive learned from watching the Science Channel documentary series Through the Wormhole With Morgan Freeman is that someday, maybe, quantum physics will tell us conclusively whether God exists. If that happens, well be able to put that question aside and devote ourselves full time to pondering the existence of Morgan Freeman.

title: A Fire Department Under Pressure to Diversify
description: IT was heaving rain two weeks ago when Salvatore J. Cassano, New York Citys fire commissioner, showed up on a Sunday to pitch his department to the congregants at Concord Baptist Church of Christ on Marcy Avenue in Brooklyn. No doubt because of the weather  people had stayed home at Bedside Baptist, the pastor joked  Mr. Cassano, gamely dressed in pinstripes, was confronted by empty pews. A trumpeter had just played hymns to some restless boys, a few old men and clumps of hatted matrons. From a microphone, the commissioner delivered to the half-filled room what had become the most important, and thorniest, public message of his career.

title: Bernanke Blames Politics for Financial Upheaval
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Friday that the political battle this summer over the federal governments borrowing and spending had disrupted financial markets and probably the economy as well.

title: As Irene Approaches, so Does Challenge of Heeding Warnings About Rare Threats
description: As Irene makes its way up the coast, areas that have rarely, or never, had to activate emergency hurricane plans, including New York City, are doing so. In such storms, threats ranging from coastal and inland flooding to flying glass can kill. (The City Room blog has a post on where to find storm information around New York. Also visit Ready.gov.) David Ropeik, a consultant in risk communication and author of How Risky Is It, Really?, has offered a Your Dot contribution exploring what makes people discount or respond to information on an impending disaster:

title: A Virus Movie Determined to Get Real
description: The new thriller Contagion revisits a conundrum that has bedeviled many filmmakers over the years: how do you make a movie about a virus, a villain that isnt even visible? Epidemic movies have sidestepped the problem by focusing on the aftermath of a deadly plague, as with The Omega Man (1971) and 12 Monkeys (1995), both set in postapocalyptic wastelands. Another option is to invent a disease with outlandish symptoms, as in The Crazies (1973), in which the infected turn homicidally insane, or 28 Days Later (2002), in which they become zombies.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Dont Panic, Mitt Romney!
description: Right now, David Brooks writes today, in the wake of Rick Perrys surge to the front of the G.O.P. field, the Romney camp is passively hoping [Perry] implodes. That seems unlikely  Sooner or later, Romney is going to have to prove his own toughness by taking Perry on directly.

title: The French Dylan. Also Beatty, Stern, Johnny Rotten ...
description: THE young Serge Gainsbourg is sauntering through Occupied Paris when he pauses before an anti-Semitic poster. In a moment its hideously caricatured Jewish face jumps off the wall to chase him down the street.

title: Treatment for Concussions in War Zones
description: Commander Earl Frantz is the officer in charge of the Concussion Restoration Care Center at Camp Leatherneck in Afghanistan, the first multidisciplinary concussion rehabilitation clinic set up in a war zone.

title: The Fox, the Owl and Labor Unrest
description: Strike

title: Friday Reading: Demand Seen for Workers With Sustainability Skills
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: City Web Site Overloaded as Hurricane Nears
description: Talk about bad timing.

title: The City Stirs | Rockaway Beach, 5:30 A.M.
description: I didnt say it first but its so true: The calm before the storm.  Salvatore Vente, a Rockaway Beach resident

title: China Says Lady Gaga, Beyonc and Other Pop Stars Are a Threat
description: Lady Gaga, Beyonc and Katy Perry have been deemed threats to cultural national security in China.

title: Apps to Track Hurricane Irene
description: As Hurricane Irene makes its way up the East Coast, you may be tempted to hunker by the TV or computer with your three-day supply of batteries, water and MREs to track the storms progress.

title: Tartare Meets Carpaccio at the Ocean
description: YOU might think that gloried dishes like beef carpaccio and steak tartare can be had in only a restaurant. In fact, they are easily made at home  all you need is spanking-fresh fish. Got that?

title: With This App, a Souvenir Without the Stand
description: The T-shirt, the hat, the oversize tennis ball: buying one or many of these are a rite of passage for the tens of thousands of fans who attend the United States Open each year. But on hot, humid days, there is little appeal in walking around with a sticky plastic bag of these goodies.

title: Sense and Scensibility
description: Theres nothing stale about Freshs new retail concept. The beauty brands fragrant flagship in Manhattans Union Square has been completely redesigned by Mapos, a young architecture firm headed up by two former Peter Marino disciples. Inspired by Old World bakeries, laboratories and apothecaries, the space is bisected by a massive reclaimed walnut kitchen table that contains stacks of vintage botanical books and offers a comfy place to perch while testing products. Custom and antique details abound, including an old English communal wash basin, a unique Sensorial Bar, (where discontinued fragrances are available on tap) and a large glass display case that makes Freshs prettily packaged soaps look like confections in a pastry shop.

title: How to Not Cook a Fish
description: This weeks City Kitchen is about raw food, but not the vegetarian kind. Apologies in advance to those who dont approve. I am a huge fan of vegetables.

title: With Hurricane Irene Near, 370,000 in New York City Get Evacuation Order
description: New York officials on Saturday urged residents in evacuation areas to leave immediately as Hurricane Irene started to pummel the North Carolina coast.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: Serena Williams
description: Liz Robbins explains why Williams was a great Open champion and why she would defeat Monica Seles in a hypothetical Open match.

title: To Judgeship in Caribbean From Referee in Nassau (County)
description: When Marston C. D. Gibson came to the United States from Barbados in 1987, he was looking for a fresh start, a change of scenery, something new.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: Monica Seles
description: Thomas Lin explains why Seles was a great champion and how she could defeat Serena Williams in a hypothetical Open match.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: John McEnroe
description: Lynn Zinser explains why McEnroe was a great Open champion and how he would defeat Andre Agassi in a hypothetical U.S. Open match.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: Andre Agassi
description: Liz Robbins explains why Agassi was a great Open champion and why he would defeat John McEnroe in a hypothetical Open match.
