description: The separation anxiety test was not going well: Subject barked at the door, charged over to a red rubber toy, raced back to the door, barked again, more loudly this time, and then squatted and left a puddle in front of the door.

title: Tom Perrotta's "The Leftovers"; Erica Heller on her father, "Catch-22" author, Joseph Heller; best-seller news
description: This week, conversation with Tom Perrotta about the fictional Rapture in his new book, "The Leftovers"; Erica Heller reminisces about her father, Catch-22 author, Joseph Heller; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Aug. 26 Updates on Hurricane Irene
description: On Friday, The Lede tracked preparations for the expected landfall of Hurricane Irene, a powerful storm heading for the northeastern United States.

title: Beach Hopping Along Lake Michigan
description: A family car trip along the lake, from New Buffalo to Ludington, included stops at lively beach towns along the way.

title: Memory-Making on Michigans Beaches
description: I KNEW my mission was achieved when my oldest daughter sailed past me on her stomach, shouting, Its like an ocean without saltwater! Her sister was close behind, riding another wave. Though I spent my childhood summers boating and swimming in Lake Michigan, my two teenage daughters, Harriet, 19, and Florence, 15, had never known the joys of plunging into the clear, cool, open waters of a Great Lake. Therefore, it seemed only fitting that our mother-daughter trip last month should be to my old stomping, or rather swimming, grounds. Rather than take a nostalgic trip to the top of Michigans mitten, I decided we should instead hit what would be virgin territory for me as well and head to the west coast, where I had heard that a half-dozen beach towns could easily be visited in a four-day period, thanks to 170 miles of gentle lakeside highway.

title: Canada Halts Trading in Sino-Forest of China
description: 7:44 p.m. | Updated

title: Keynes/Bernanke
description: John Maynard Keynes:

title: Quick and Easy Cooking With Grains
description: For simple, healthful and fast meals, the solution may already be in your pantry, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health:

title: Cleaning Up Brand Names Supply Chains
description: Competition is heating up among the worlds leading sportswear manufacturers, but not to see who can introduce the hottest new running shoe. Since the advocacy group Greenpeace released its Dirty Laundry report in July, Nike, Puma and Adidas have been racing to respond to charges that their suppliers are polluting Chinese waterways.

title: F.C.C. Restarts Clock on Review of AT&Ts T-Mobile Deal
description: The Federal Communications Commission said on Friday that it had restarted its review of AT&Ts proposed $39 billion takeover of T-Mobile USA, after pausing the process to demand more information about the deal.

title: Pet Chauffeur Tries to Adapt to Tough Economy
description: The recession has not been kind to the pet industry. While their finances are in flux, pet owners are less likely to splurge on toys or grooming, and fewer vacations spell empty kennels at the boarding house. In fact, prospective owners are less likely to take on the financial burden of a new dog or cat to begin with.

title: Easy 18, but Not That Easy, Apparently
description: EDISON, N.J.  The drivable par-4 18th hole at Plainfield Country Club has created a buzz at the Barclays this week. But while there have been plenty of birdies at the 285-yard hole, there has been just one eagle through the completion of the first round Friday morning.

title: Idols Worship
description: This weeks What They Were Thinking column features a photo from Idols, the 1973 cult-classic photo book by Gilles Larrain that chronicled the gender-bending New York arts scene in the early 70s. Long out of print, Idols is being reissued next month by powerHouse Books. The reissue has even more photos than the original, and includes more popular musicians, like Nina Hagen and members of the New York Dolls. Everyone looks great.

title: Make That 15 Seconds of Fame
description: Cecil Beaton produced a torrent of work, not unlike Andy Warhol and Takashi Murakami, who collaborated with Marc Jacobs at Louis Vuitton. In a new book, Cecil Beaton: The New York Years (Skira/Rizzoli), Donald Albrecht suggests that Beatons methods of working in a variety of media, his blurring of the lines between art and commerce, and his promotional skills made him remarkably prescient.

title: A Veteran Baseball Novel Comes Off the Bench
description: Baseball is a sunshine sport, in essence a daytime game whenever its played, but there is something of the night about it: a darkness that resonates in the deepest part of the American psyche. For the batter, of course, its a game defined by failure most of time, but on a grander scale too our national pastime often seems free of what William James called our national disease: the exclusive worship of the bitch-goddess success. Failure gives baseball its pleasing, melancholic tang; the boys of summer are always in ruin, after all, and the dirge of the Cubs forever drowns out the anthem of the Yankees. It seems somehow fitting that one of the worst diseases imaginable is named after one of the greatest baseball players. It breaks your heart, the former president of Yale and commissioner of Major League Baseball A. Bartlett Giamatti said of the game. It is designed to break your heart.

title: What We Do to Books
description: There has always been a lot of discussion about the effect that reading books has on us. Far less attention has been paid to the effect that we (the readers) have on them (the books). I dont mean on the reputations or royalties of the authors who wrote the books but on the actual physical objects themselves.

title: Deaths in the Family
description: Count on it. Whenever people lose faith in their political leaders, the popular culture reflexively responds by killing off parents. Younger heroes, from Harry Potter to baby X-Men, are easily redirected to reliable surrogate authority figures, but in troubled times mature protagonists like police officers and lone-wolf detectives are more often left reeling from the deaths of fathers and the treachery of mentors.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: POX  An American History By Michael Willrich Penguin Press, $27.95.

title: The Enigma of Joseph Heller
description: Oh God, this is a calamity for American literature, Kurt Vonnegut said on learning of Joseph Hellers death in 1999. John Updike was less alarmed: Heller wasnt top of the chart as a writer, he reflected, though he was a sweet man and his first novel, Catch-22 was important. Note the Updikean judiciousness of important: he didnt say he liked the book, but it was a great cultural bellwether as novels go, and it has endured. Despite mixed reviews on publication in 1961, Catch-22 was soon adopted by college students who recognized a kindred spirit in Yossarian, the bombardier who rebels against a materialistic bureaucracy hellbent on killing him. Better Yossarian than Rotarian became a popular slogan, all the more so with the timely (for the novels sake) military escalation in Vietnam, which became the real subject of Catch-22 and partly accounts for its sales of more than 10 million copies to date. Its hard to argue with that kind of importance.

title: Interpreting the Latin American Soul
description: Enrique Krauze is a well-known historian in Mexico. He is also a documentary filmmaker and television talking head renowned for his mellifluous basso voice, a publisher of elegant coffee-table books and a canny operator within the upper murks of Mexican politics. He is the editor of a glossy highbrow magazine called Letras Libres. There are corners of the Spanish-speaking universe in which he is omnipresent, and even a few corners of the English-speaking universe in which his byline is hard to miss. I have been following his work for decades. I subscribe to his magazine. Occasionally I contribute to it. He has always seemed to me a keen and judicious political observer, worldly and instinctively liberal. But now it occurs to me that he is also marked by a rare and attractive gift for noticing the several ways that, under the bright sun of the imagination, the kingdom of politics and the kingdom of literature sometimes merge.

title: Coming to America, Lured by a Photo
description: In the Japanese art of sumi-e, strokes of ink are brushed across sheets of rice paper, the play of light and dark capturing not just images but sensations, not just surfaces but the essence of what lies within. Simplicity of line is prized, extraneous detail discouraged. Although Julie Otsuka was born and raised in California and trained as a painter in the Western tradition, she seems perfectly attuned to the spirit of sumi-e. Otsuka claims to have been a failure as an artist, but she might only have erred in choosing the wrong medium. Proof arrived almost a decade ago, long after shed traded painting for writing, with the publication of her first novel, When the Emperor Was Divine, a spare but resonant portrait of one Japanese-American familys daily life, at home and in the internment camps, during World War II. Now she returns with a second novel, also employing a minimalist technique, that manages to be equally intimate yet much more expansive.

title: What Wendy Wasserstein Wrought
description: Along with Law & Order reruns and British detective novels, celebrity profiles rank high on the list of so-called guilty pleasures. Peering, via the magazine article, into the psyche of a rising starlet or fading rock musician, we lose our pained awareness of the subway car or the waiting room where we most crave distraction. What gentle anesthetics they are, these mini-biographies deftly combining interviews, gossip, pop psychology, pithy quotations from well-known sources and the always soothing reminder that the problems of the rich and famous are far worse than our own.

title: Further Adventures of a Magician From Brooklyn
description: Sure, youve heard of the freshman 15. But what about the Fillory 15?

title: Poems of Childhood, Grief and Deep Space
description: I wont blame you for not believing this: The photograph on the cover of Tracy K. Smiths Life on Mars is the same one I see every day on my computer desktop. Its a dramatic and vivid picture from the Hubble Space Telescope, with colors I imagine J. M. W. Turner would have admired, of the Cone Nebula, a pillar of dust and gas some 2,500 light-years from Earth. Scientists say its an incubator for baby stars. Ive long used the image as an efficient and emphatic corrective for solipsism. I look at it when I find myself fretting about, say, book review deadlines or my spotty gym attendance. You cant simultaneously contemplate the vastness of the universe and take such problems seriously.

title: The Power of Pronouns
description: When President Obama addressed the nation after the killing of Osama bin Laden in May, some conservative reactions to his rhetoric were all too predictable. On National Review Online, Victor Davis Hanson highlighted the 15 times that Obama used I, me or my in the 1,400-word speech, and asserted that these first-person pronouns . . . reflect a now well-known Obama trait of personalizing the presidency. A few weeks later, when Obama gave a speech at the C.I.A.s headquarters in Langley, Va., the Drudge Report offered the headline, I ME MINE: Obama praises C.I.A. for bin Laden raid  while saying I 35 times.

title: Deprived of Music in a Tar-Dark World
description: Of the many prominent conventions in dystopian novels  from Huxleys Brave New World to Bradburys Fahrenheit 451 to Vonneguts Player Piano  the most ironic is the urban future that looks like a sepia shot from the hinterlands of time. Our so-called advances have backfired, transporting us to a medieval perdition, rendering us cannibalistic and crazed. Progress  often a bugaboo called capitalism, as in Jack Londons novel The Iron Heel  eradicates good sense and civility, while violence is endemic in every town.

title: A Sort-of Love Story, With Pie Charts
description: Anyone who suffers from writers block  if only more were afflicted!  will appreciate the raw agony of the creative process laid bare in Patricia Marxs new novel, Starting From Happy. To reach her target word count, the constitutionally and often brilliantly economical Marx pads her text with, among other enhancements, pen-and-ink illustrations; pie charts; footnotes; graphological analysis, even of her own signature; a catalog of punctuation; another of pasta shapes; a supposed survey from her publisher; letters from cranky readers; and 26 desperate lines of barn-animal noises, recalling Humbert Humberts command in Lolita: Repeat till the page is full, printer.

title: Beginning Infinity: Culture vs. Geology
description: To the Editor:

title: Fantasy Ascendant
description: To the Editor:

title: OKeeffe Unbrushed
description: To the Editor:

title: Up Front: Dan Kois
description: Dan Kois, who writes about books, movies, music and comics for publications including Slate and New York magazine, is also one of the foremost (adult) experts on Harry Potter, having chronicled the exploits of the young wizard since around the time Harry learned to cast the Cruciatus Curse. I created Ron Weasleys Facebook page. I wrote an obituary for Hedwig the owl, Kois wrote recently in The Times Magazine. Indeed, his Potter-mania once threatened to overtake my ability to function as a grown human being. So he seemed a natural choice to review Lev Grossmans latest novel, The Magician King, the second in a series often described as a Harry Potter for grown-ups.

title: Editors Choice
description: CLASS WARFARE: Inside the Fight to Fix Americas Schools,  by Steven Brill (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Brill makes a vigorous case against teachers unions and conveys the epiphanies, setbacks and triumphs of a national reform movement.

title: Paperback Row
description: LETS TAKE THE LONG WAY HOME: A Memoir of Friendship,  by Gail Caldwell (Random House, $14.) Caldwell, a Pulitzer-winning literary critic, and Caroline Knapp had a lot in common: both were dog lovers and recovering alcoholics (Knapp wrote the memoir Drinking: A Love Story). This chronicle of Knapps terminal cancer  she died in 2002  is a tribute to their bond. When it came to matters of the soul and the psyche, Caldwell writes, we each knew how to tend to the other.

title: The Rain in Belgium Falls Mainly in Spa
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium  Friday was a day of mixed fortunes for the drivers, spectators and the weather at Spa as Formula One returned from its summer break to torrential summer showers. That, of course, is typical for the Spa circuit, so no one was surprised by the weather.

title: The Rain in Belgium Falls Mainly in Spa
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium  Friday was a day of mixed fortunes for the drivers, spectators and the weather at Spa as Formula One returned from its summer break to torrential summer showers. That, of course, is typical for the Spa circuit, so no one was surprised by the weather.

title: A Fish Tale
description: We came, we shucked, we concurred with the Gentle Island tag line. Prince Edward Island, a crescent-shaped patch of land off the coast of New Brunswick, and Canadas smallest province, is the kind of place where the dinner rush starts at 4:30. During the high season, which runs from May to October, its one big seafood banquet: oysters, clams, mussels, halibut, lobsters, haddock, salmon and scallops are all on the menu, and all from just down the road. The seafood used to hit your plate deep fried beyond recognition, but these days your fish could come grilled, your steamers actually steamed. Last month, my husband, our 1-year-old son and I set off in search of fishy stuff and found plenty, along with a few other simple summer pleasures, like the local classic-rock radio station (hello, Queen!).

title: U.S. Offers Key Support to Canadian Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department gave a crucial green light on Friday to a proposed 1,711-mile pipeline that would carry heavy oil from oil sands in Canada across the Great Plains to terminals in Oklahoma and the Gulf Coast.

title: 15,500 Navistar School Buses Recalled for Possible Fire Hazard
description: Nearly 15,500 school buses are being recalled because of a possible fire hazard, according to a report filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Commission Raises N.Y. Judges Pay 27% Over 3 Years
description: A state commission decided on Friday to increase the pay of the more than 1,200 New York State judges by 27 percent over three years, ending a decade of battles in Albany and the courts, and giving judges their first raise in 12 years.

title: After the Mayors Go Bag List (Its Here), Whats in Yours?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has encouraged New Yorkers to prepare a go bag as Hurricane Irene churns toward the city.

title: Inside the List
description: MAN BITES GOD: God, No!, new at No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list, isnt a reaction to the news that George R. R. Martin has decided to abandon his Song of Ice and Fire series and take up extreme knitting instead. Rather, its a profanity-laced memoir-cum-manifesto from the magician and outspoken atheist Penn Jillette, the taller and louder half of Penn & Teller. The book is structured around Jillettes alternatives to the Ten Commandments (take the Lords name in vain all you want, but be sure to say what you mean, even when talking to yourself), but we also get reminiscences about his moderately Congregationalist childhood in Massachusetts, his conflicted admiration for Siegfried and Roy, and the atheist baptisms held at his Las Vegas home, the Slammer, which tend to involve lots of bacon, nude cornstarch wrestling and a fat Elvis impersonator. We also learn some good post-show lobby pickup lines: he laughed hardest at the woman who asked, Is your name Debbie? but married the one who started talking about Richard Dawkins. As for their children, his wife may be Jewish (or, as he puts it, a nonbeliever whose forebears happened to be Jewish), but they are atheist and their culture is Vegas  and even thats too much tribalism for me.

title: Big Deal | $30 Million at the Ritz-Carlton
description: A full-floor condominium at the Residences at the Ritz-Carlton at 50 Central Park South, selling for $30 million, was the highest sale for the seven days that ended Wednesday, according to city property records.

title: New York Surge From Irene Looks Bad, But Not Off Charts
description: 9:11 p.m. |Update

title: Obama Warns of Historic Storm and Cuts Short Vacation
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass.  President Obama will cut short his Marthas Vineyard vacation because of Hurricane Irene and return Friday night, and he urged Americans along the Eastern Seaboard to take precautions against the potentially historic hurricane making its way toward the coast this weekend.

title: Russell Wilson Puts Wisconsin on Target for Title Run
description: MADISON, Wis.  The legend of Russell Wilson as a Wisconsin quarterback began with a dare from Badgers receiver Nick Toon on the 30-yard line of Camp Randall Stadium: Bet you cant hit the crossbar from here.

description: WHEN Paula Derrow was 44, she gave herself a diamond ring.

title: At Worlds, Sprinter Faces Possible Hurdle
description: DAEGU, South Korea  After years of fighting the system and then struggling against his own limitations, Oscar Pistorius, the South African sprinter, double amputee and champion Paralympian who runs on carbon fiber blades, has finally succeeded in earning a place at a major able-bodied championship event.

title: Houston City Council Votes to Shut Off Red-Light Cameras
description: Despite the threat of a $25 million lawsuit, Houston officials voted to shut down the citys unloved and controversial red-light camera program. In doing so, the city council breaks a contract with American Traffic Solutions that has three years remaining on it.

title: After Fatal Casino Attack, Mexican Officials Focus on Organized Crimes Link
description: MEXICO CITY  An arson attack on a casino in northern Mexico on Thursday that left 52 people dead has thrown a spotlight on the growth of gambling houses throughout the country and their role in organized crime.

description: You can help protect the worlds natural and cultural resources.

description: 4:33 p.m. | Updated  The current version of Verizons iPad does not require a MiFi, that is only the case for the first-generation Verizon iPad.

title: Ileana & Alex
description: In this homemade video, Ileana Ferreras and Alex Lacamoire recall meeting after someone cut in front of them when they were both in line to greet a mutual friend.

title: Kuchar Leads Shortened Barclays; Third Round Is in Doubt
description: EDISON, N.J.  What may or may not have been the last shot anyone had to catch Matt Kuchar at the Barclays fizzled when Vijay Singhs approach shot from the right rough plopped onto the soft green at his final hole on Friday, some 40 feet from the cup.

title: From the Food Court to the Compost Pile
description: At sporting events like the United States Open, garbage is garbage, whether it organic or inorganic: at the end of the day, it has to be hauled away.

title: The Minimal Risks of Vaccines
description: In a new report, a panel of scientists assembled by the Institute of Medicine reviewed the risks of some of the most common vaccines. The panel found no evidence that a popular vaccine causes autism, a subject that has ignited debate for years. But it did find that the chickenpox vaccine carries some potential for side effects that can crop up years after the shot is administered.

title: On Travers Day, Biggest Name Is on the Undercard
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

description: 1. Domestic Engagements

title: After Decades of Brassy Civic Advocacy, Sally Goodgold Dies at 82
description: Sally Goodgold was the Ethel Merman of land use: bold, brassy and capable of sounding notes that could be heard over any orchestra. An Upper West Sider in the traditionally outspoken mold, and a civic leader of the old Progressivist school, she believed New Yorkers deserved affordable housing and accommodating public environments; that private development ought to help create these things, not eradicate them; and that it was the job of city officials to prod, not coddle, powerful builders.

title: Hurricane Irene Heads For the East Coast
description: The warning for Hurricane Irene that was put into effect in North Carolina on Thursday was extended on Friday, and much of the Northeast was placed under watches.

title: The Caucus | Mitt Romney's Challenge
description: Op-Ed Columnist David Brooks on the landscape ahead for the former Massachusetts governor and the 2012 field. Michael D. Shear reports on the next Congressional battle: payroll taxes.

title: Sienna & Christa
description: In this homemade video Sienna Baskin and Christa Douaihy recall meeting at CUNY School of Law in Queens.

title: Big Asset Sale Near at Bank of America
description: Bank of America is completing plans to sell more than half of its stake in the China Construction Bank in a deal that could raise nearly $10 billion, just a day after Warren E. Buffett invested $5 billion in the beleaguered American financial giant.

title: Caucus Video: Op-Ed Columnist on the 2012 Field; the Upcoming Fight Over Payroll Taxes
description: Op-Ed Columnist David Brooks on the landscape ahead for the former Massachusetts governor and the 2012 field. Michael D. Shear reports on the next Congressional battle: payroll taxes.

description: The day in sports included preparations for the I.A.A.F. world championships in South Korea and the continuation of the world judo championships in Paris.

description: An interactive map of evacuation zones from the citys Office of Emergency Management.

title: In N.Y. Apartment Buildings, Bicycles Muscle In
description: BRIAN WHITELEY loves his bicycle, a black fixed-gear Schwinn that he rides around New York City almost every day. His landlord, however, does not share this affection, fearing scuffed floors and chipped paint. And that has become a problem.

title: China State TV Deletes Video Implying Hacking of Western Sites
description: BEIJING  The main Chinese state television network has deleted from the Internet a video that some foreign military and Internet security analysts say implies China has engaged in hacking attacks on Web sites in the West.

title: On Warming and U.S. Hurricane Strikes
description: Aug. 27, 2:09 p.m. | Updates at end of piece |The author and climate campaigner Bill McKibben, fresh from protests over the proposed Keystone XL pipeline, wrote today, Irenes got a middle name  and its global warming.

title: When Income Is Freelance
description: WITH the job market still soft, many people have turned to contract or freelance work to pay the bills, which increases the challenges involved in qualifying for a home mortgage.

title: The 30-Minute Interview: Ric Clark
description: Mr. Clark, 53, is the chief executive of Brookfield Office Properties, a real estate investment trust that owns and operates roughly 18 million square feet of office space in the New York area, including the World Financial Center buildings downtown. Work on its newest development, Manhattan West, near the Hudson Yards, is set to begin early next year.

title: The Moneymooners: Registering for Cash, Not Dishes
description: WHILE wedding guests can scour registries and rattle their imaginations to come up with an ideal gift, what many a bride and bridegroom want most, particularly in these times, is perfectly simple  money.

title: The Sweet Smell of, Well, Sweets
description: IF residents were to describe something sweet about Greenwood Heights, a waterfront community in western Brooklyn, they might be speaking literally. The sugary scent emanating from the various candy, chocolate and dessert manufacturers in this neighborhood of about half a square mile is unmistakable.

title: The Post-Roommate Stage
description: STEVE SIDDELL paid just $700 a month for his share of the rent on a three-bedroom apartment in Crown Heights.

title: Messing With the Bankruptcy System
description: So the private equity firms have struck again, invoking a material adverse change clause in their deal to buy certain properties from Innkeepers USA Trust. The deal was a major component of Inkeepers already confirmed Chapter 11 plan, and the latest word is that Inkeepers is opposing the private equity firms request for their deposit back.

title: On Project Runway, a Team of Rivals
description: The official theme of Thursday nights team challenge on Project Runway was to create several outfits to go with a line of sneakers that Heidi Klum had designed for New Balance. But the real theme turned out to be Two Against One.

title: Restaurant Report: Le Filet, Montreal
description: In Montreal, it can sometimes seem that the dining scene is all about animal products: the smoked meat sandwich at Schwartzs, and the Melting Pot of meat at Au Pied de Cochon, not to mention its entire foie gras menu section. Theres even a popular (and very good) restaurant called Joe Beef.

title: Hotel Review: Soho House, in Berlin
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Japanese Island as Unlikely Arts Installation
description: ON a chilly night last November on the tiny island of Naoshima in the Seto Inland Sea of southern Japan, I found myself alone in a dark concrete gallery, a sweater pulled over my pajamas. I was staying at the Benesse House Museum, a 10-room hotel set inside a contemporary art museum, on the islands craggy southern coast, and still battling jet lag. So instead of tossing in bed, I visited the deserted galleries of the museum  guests of the hotel are permitted to wander beyond closing time. Before long, I was transfixed by Bruce Naumans art installation, 100 Live and Die, a neon billboard of flashing phrases.

title: Letters  Traveling Along the Mediterranean
description: To the Editor: Re Mediterranean Dream Trip Higher-Lights, Aug. 21: I am lucky enough to live in Vienna, and I try to get down to the Croatian coast  the Istrian Peninsula, the Kavner coast and Dalmatia  at least once a year. You are right. It is breathtakingly beautiful. Istria is like Tuscany, but with beaches and gorgeous towns nearby. Southern Dalmatia is a dream and still has places where you can avoid the crowds. Edward Serotta

title: Berlin Galleries Newest Home
description: THE art scene in Berlin can sometimes seem like a big game of musical chairs, as galleries migrate from neighborhood to neighborhood in search of undiscovered spaces, low rents and artist-friendly locals. The latest move, though, is a little different.

title: Los Angeles Adds Amusement to Art
description: A no-mans land of factories, warehouses, cracked streets, peeled paint and broken glass has exploded with restaurants, bars, galleries and boutiques  not to mention artists.

title: E-Biking in Switzerland
description: While in the United States electric bikes are slowly becoming popular, the Swiss have embraced the concept with the most imagination.

title: Over the Alps on a Bike With a Boost
description: THE road east out of Srenberg rears up into a series of steep turns that climb the Glaubenbielen Pass, the high point of a road the Swiss Army punched through the Alps more than 60 years ago. Though the occasional car and bus make the journey to the top, these days much of the road belongs to cyclists.

title: Decoding the Foreign Buyer
description: IN her office at Bronxville-Ley Real Estate, Leah Caro, a former president of the Westchester/Putnam Board of Realtors, always keeps her agencys well-worn copy of Kiss, Bow or Shake Hands close at hand. A manual on how to do business in more than 60 countries, it is indispensable not only in the corporate world but in the real estate industry as well  especially with the increase in foreign buyers.

title: A New Face on Good Bones
description: Brookville

title: Local Data Becomes Hyperlocal
description: THE more specific the facts an agent has at his disposal  facts, for instance, about what has sold just down the street, and for how much, and how long it took  the likelier he will probably be to persuade a seller to set a realistic price. Therein lies the usefulness of data-packed Web sites like Zillow, Trulia and Streeteasy, which can be mined by the tech-savvy for the level of detail that will be most persuasive to their clients.

title: Q & A
description: Who Pays to Move The Outdoor Plants?

title: Electric-Car Makers Quest: One Plug to Charge Them All

title: Scrapbooking Big-Screen Memories
description: THE Fox Venice Theater in Los Angeles  a boxy, pale-blue building topped by a jaunty red sign  opened in 1951 with a single movie screen and 1,003 seats; it was shuttered in the late 1980s and now houses an indoor swap meet. In a note posted more than 20 years after its closing on the Web site Cinema Treasures, a former patron credited the theater with a string of personal triumphs. I went from being an uneducated warehouse worker to a therapist with a masters degree, the commenter wrote. The movies at the Fox showed me that there were possibilities in life. I sat there and learned from all of it.

title: The Jam | Marianne Faithfull
description: The legendary English singer-songwriter Marianne Faithfull, who is also an actress, presents us with her playlist this week. Its heavy in the cornerstone classics of music, says the Jams curator, Sean Hanratty, of the list, which includes Leonard Cohen and the Clash. Its full of the timeless stuff that you never really lose, the records you own and would never part with. Faithfulls first hit, As Tears Go By (1964), which Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and the Rolling Stones manager Andrew Loog Oldham helped write, remains one of the best ballads of all time. The song, along with her highly publicized relationship with Jagger, put her on the map as one of rocks biggest stars. You Cant Always Get What You Want, on the Stones album Let It Bleed, released in 1969, was one of many songs written about Faithfull. I think some people forget  certainly not me  that she also co-wrote Sister Morphine,  says Hanratty of the track on the Stoness 1971 Sticky Fingers album. (The song is reportedly about her life and battles with drug abuse, specifically heroin.) For the past five decades, we have seen Faithfull reinvent herself as a performer and musician, in collaborations with the likes of David Bowie, Tom Waits, Emmylou Harris, Nick Cave and others, while keeping her place as one of the most influential female singer-songwriters of all time. With the impending hurricane and Virginias earthquake, we are kind of in need of the classics, Hanratty says. Faithfull will perform her classics, as well as songs from this years album, Horses and High Heels, at Manhattans City Winery on Dec. 18.

title: This Sunday: The Dirtiest Pictures
description: There are many things to like in this weeks issue  Gerry Marzoratis cover story on tennis rivalries, the wonderful impersonations of tennis greats by Andy Samberg, Bill Kellers final column for the magazine and Jon Gertners examination of Obamas stealth industrial policy. But the one that I want to especially direct your attention to is the Look feature. I hope that youre familiar with the section. In the print magazine, its three pages toward the back, a single opener with a small picture and a bit of text, then a giant spread of a single image. Sometimes, on our Web site, we show more pictures that didnt make the cut, as we do this week with the joyous, mud-drenched photographs by Peter Bohler of a Polish music festival based on Woodstock. Take some time to flip through the entire slideshow  its incredible fun. And then scroll down to see pictures from each of the Look features weve run since the section made its debut in March. Its a great display of the talents of our photographers and the dedicated editors who work with them.

description: Many retailers and schools are advocating waste-free options for back-to-school shoppers this year, especially when it comes to lunch. School lists call for Tupperware instead of Ziplocs, neoprene lunch bags instead of brown paper ones, and aluminum water bottles, not the throwaway plastic versions.

title: Unrest Builds as India Adds a Slowing Economy to Its Corruption Woes
description: MUMBAI, India  For much of the last month, India has been gripped by a raging public debate about how to tackle corruption, which is seen by many here as the countrys most important challenge. But a slowing economy may soon overtake corruption as a more pressing problem.

title: Obama Declares State of Emergency for New York
description: President Obama declared a state of emergency for New York State about 5 p.m. on Friday in anticipation of Hurricane Irene, a Category 2 storm, making landfall on the East Coast. Philip E. Parr, a former member of the New York City Fire Department and former federal coordinator for relief efforts after Hurricane Katrina, was named the coordinating officer.

title: Coping With 9/11, Riding on Two Wheels
description: Its hard to remember now, but in the days after the attacks of 9/11, a back-to-basics sort of thing took hold in New York. People returned to out-of-favor practices like checking up on neighbors, talking to strangers, using courtesy and concern as their default modes rather than snark and indifference.

title: Germans Start to Question Their Economic Resilience
George Hendry, a Young and Old Table Tennis Master, Dies at 90
description: Call George Hendry the comeback kid.

title: Bloggingheads: Has Apple Peaked?
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Philip Elmer-DeWitt of Apple 2.0 debate Apple Inc.'s future.

title: Theres One on Every Corner, but None Like This
description: SEATTLE  The sun is not yet up but the baristas are, a blur of busy hands wiping down counters and smoothing black aprons. Chipper and precise, they work at Starbucks, but it is probably not like the one near where you live. Among the 17,000 Starbucks that caffeinate the planet, this one is special.

title: Stories of 9/11 and Its Aftermath
description: NEXT months 10th anniversary of 9/11 has inspired a dozen or more collections of heart-breaking reminiscences by New Yorkers who survived the attack and then endured a decade of denial, doubt and rebuilding. Here is a sampling:

title: Britain Goes Nimby
description: LONDON

title: A Teenage Killer, Now 51, Recounting His Crime
description: The 16-year-old boy had settled on a plan on how to kill his girlfriend. There was a blighted section on the north shore of Staten Island called Port Ivory, overgrown coastline facing the industrial banks of New Jersey. The land was pocked with holes leading to small underground rooms, like bunkers.

title: Appetite for Racing, and for Winning
description: When the greatest champion of any sport comes to town, it seems like a good idea to take a look at him up close.

title: A Dog at the Funeral Captured on Video
description: A video of a dog apparently mourning the death of his owner at a funeral has gone viral, prompting an outpouring from viewers around the world.

title: Big City Book Club
description: From Herman Melvilles Bartleby, the Scrivener to Tom Wolfes Bonfire of the Vanities, New York has been a compelling character in American letters. The Big City Book Club intends to generate lively online discussion of works  classic and current, obvious and obscure, fictional and non  that centrally feature the city.

title: Tracking the Euro Zones Crisis
description: The latest economic and policy developments from countries in the euro zone.

title: Teaching Psychiatric Patients Writing, and Hope
description: Wearing her clerical collar and lugging a tote bag of supplies, the Rev. Bonnie McDougall Olson strode down the halls of Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens. She was due, moments later, to conduct a weekly writing workshop for three patients. It was the means for her mission, a way of bringing grace and mercy to the broken.

title: As Suspensions Add Up, Luster Is Leaving a College Football Showcase
description: As an off-season of relentless scandal inundated college football, coaches and university administrators repeated the mantra that they could not wait for the season to start.

title: Apple Ends Its TV Episode Rental Service
description: Nearly a year after Apple persuaded the television networks to try out a television episode rental service through its iTunes store, it has quietly taken the service down. Customers, it seems, did not want to rent TV episodes through an online store.

title: Living for the Nighttime
description: Hard rocker, founding partner of the club Santos Party House in Manhattan and host of the Cartoon Network show Destroy Build Destroy, Andrew W. K., 32, spends most of his days doing what comes naturally: hiding from the sun. On Sundays, though, he likes venturing out from his apartment in Midtown Manhattan to nearby restaurants with his wife, Cherie Lily, a fitness instructor, dancer and singer. He also likes making music in their home studio, reading mind-blowing books and, invariably, staying up until dawn.

title: Mr. Bernankes Warning
description: Its what journalists call burying the lead. More than halfway through his speech on Friday to central bankers meeting in Jackson Hole, Ben Bernanke said the recession would not cause lasting damage to the economy if  and I stress if  our country takes the necessary steps to secure that outcome.

title: Top Basketball Recruit Is Headed to UConn
description: With one Twitter message Friday night, the Connecticut mens basketball teams chances to repeat as national champions increased exponentially.

title: The Sisterhood of Netball
description: ANDREA KIDD often gets puzzled looks when she tells people she spends her summer weekends playing netball.

title: What Did They Really See?
description: In a landmark decision this week, the New Jersey Supreme Court set new guidelines for how courts and juries must assess eyewitness identification of criminal suspects. The laudable decision applies only in New Jersey but could have a national impact. It provides a thorough, science-based explanation of how eyewitness evidence can become tainted and offers a judicious template for the United States Supreme Court and other states to follow.

title: As Qaddafi Forces Retreat, a Newly Freed Imam Encourages Forgiveness
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Like many Libyans, Sheik Abdul Ghani Aboughreis had reason to feel bitterness toward supporters of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi as he led the first Friday Prayer service since rebels flooded into the city here.

title: Strip Club Pole Tax Is Upheld in Texas
description: HOUSTON  The Texas Supreme Court ruled Friday that the states pole tax  a $5-per-customer fee that strip clubs that serve alcohol are required to pay the state  did not violate the clubs free-speech rights, overturning a lower court decision that declared the fee unconstitutional.

title: Case of 8,000 Menacing Posts Tests Limits of Twitter Speech
description: Even the Buddha of compassion might have been distressed to be on the receiving end of the diatribes that William Lawrence Cassidy is accused of posting on Twitter.

title: An Outdoor Exhibition of Cow-Proof Art
description: GARRISON, N.Y.

title: Evacuation of Citys Low-Lying Areas Begins Ahead of Storm
description: As she and other customers picked the shelves bare on Friday afternoon at a supermarket in Breezy Point, Queens, Jackie Fede said she planned to abide by the official order to evacuate before Hurricane Irene hit. But she had yet to convince her mother to go.

title: Relief for Student Debtors
description: Since the start of the recession, record numbers of Americans have enrolled in college in search of new skills that would improve their employment prospects. Unfortunately, far too many students enrolled in expensive for-profit schools end up dogged by ruinous debts, with little in the way of skills or credentials to show for their efforts.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Going to the Videotape
description: Last year, the United States Supreme Court blocked the broadcasting of the nonjury civil trial on the constitutionality of Proposition 8, Californias voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage. That August, the measure was struck down by Judge Vaughn Walker of Federal District Court, who presided at the trial. The case is pending appeal.

title: With Williams Sisters as Model, Prospect Tries to Find Her Way
description: The scene in Flushing was familiar: a female African-American player with a loud, aggressive playing style attracting a large crowd, which included Richard Williams in the third row. She pumped her fist and let out a Come on! Lets go! with each hard-fought winner.

title: Tracing the Legacy of a Controversial Master Builder
description: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.

title: Obamas Non-Doctrine Doctrine
description: With the stock market gyrating, the Atlantic churning and D.S.K. walking free, it was easy to miss what some are calling a turning point in American foreign policy: the fall of Libyas Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Thing is, no one can agree on what exactly that turning point represents.

title: This Storm, Bloomberg Responds Differently
description: Around 8 a.m. on Friday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg received this startling piece of meteorological data: Instead of hitting New York at 3 a.m. on Sunday, as forecasters had predicted, Hurricane Irene was expected to strike six hours ahead of schedule, at 9 p.m. on Saturday.

title: What Makes Steve Jobs Great
description: I think I have five more great products in me, Steve Jobs said a very long time ago.

title: Podcast: Bernanke, the Budget and Steve Jobs
description: Ben Bernankes speech at Jackson Hole, Wyo., was sketchier than it might have been about monetary policy but strikingly detailed about fiscal policy.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Teams Run for Cover as Irene Approaches; Jets-Giants Postponed
description: Weekends and sports are about as American as apple pie, except when extreme weather gets in the way.

title: Out of Position in a Play Inside a Play
description: All three characters in The Understudy have taken jobs they normally wouldnt. The stage manager of the play-within-a-play is an actress reduced to working backstage. The title character is an actor too good to be anybodys standby. The action-movie star is slumming by doing a Broadway play. The question is which one we care about most.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Digging In, or Just Getting Out of the Way
description: Stocking Up, And Staying Home

title: A Secret Parisian Picnic, Where Romance Reigned
description: In about five minutes, Ill have an even better story for you, a man whispered to Nocturnalist on Thursday night as we stood in a sea of about 1,800 people all clad in white evening wear. They were dining al fresco on the edge of the Hudson River in Battery Park City.

title: Failing Forward
description: Sometimes I push back on my heels, look at this country and wonder aloud: What on earth are we doing?

title: As Trade Volumes Soar, Exchanges Cash In
description: The latest financial market convulsions have been tough for almost everyone, including traders caught on the wrong side of another big swing and pained everyday investors watching their dwindling holdings go down and up  and down again.

title: Lottery Numbers
South African Goes From Never a Sip to Vineyard Fame
description: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa  When Ntsiki Biyela won a winemaking scholarship in 1998, she was certainly a curious choice. She had grown up in the undulating hills of Zululand, living in a small village of huts and shacks. People tended their patches of pumpkins and corn. The only alcohol they drank was homemade beer, a malt-fed brew that bubbled in old pots.

title: Saturday: Like Bending Over Backward
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Well, thats an interesting way to start off a crossword puzzle. Im sure you know what Im talking about, Ashton Anderson. Im talking about 1 Across, which also happens to be making its debut today. And how accidental could it be that X-RATED is right there, dangling, so to speak, from that SEXCAPADE that started us off? This is The New York Times, for goodnesss sake. You should be ashamed of yourself.

title: Populism, Technology and Interactivity
description: Make no mistake: Grounds for Sculpture, the 42-acre public sculpture park in Hamilton, aims to be populist. Its mission, according to the organizations Web site, is to promote an understanding of and appreciation for contemporary sculpture for all people.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Battle for Libya | August 26, 2011
description: Rebels investigated the Abu Salim Prison, and dozens of bodies were piled up in an abandoned hospital in Tripoli.

title: With All Eyes on Weather, Capuano Fires Strike After Strike Past the Braves
description: The Mets did not have long to savor their 6-0 win over the Atlanta Braves on Friday, which featured a nearly flawless outing from starter Chris Capuano. Some players had to worry about where they would be sleeping this weekend.

title: China: North Korean Leader Repeats Offer for Nuclear Talks
description: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, reiterated Friday that he would return to the so-called six-party talks on his countrys nuclear program with no preconditions, Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency, reported. Mr. Kim made his remarks in Heilongjiang Province, which borders North Korea, after meeting with the Russian president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, in Siberia on Wednesday, where he first offered to return to the talks. The United States, a leader in the talks, has expressed skepticism over the use of holding more of them. In China, Mr. Kim met with Dai Bingguo, the senior foreign policy official.

title: A Taste of Colombia
description: You can get terrific brownies at Brownie Restaurante y Panaderia  rich and dense, with a thick coating of chocolate icing  but thats not the best reason to visit this Colombian restaurant and bakery in White Plains.

title: The Subtle Complexities of a Kitchen Standby
description: THIS one comes from California and has hints of strawberry, the server said. This one is more floral. And this one is the most complex. It has layers of almond with an artichoke finish.

title: A White With Clout
description: A white made on Long Island from Finger Lakes grapes, Martha Clara Vineyards medium-dry 2010 riesling ($19.99), was voted the states best wine in the New York Wine and Food Classic this month.

title: Unabashedly, and Exclusively, Thai
description: THE restaurant Frankly Thai in Franklin Square is aptly named, describing the kind of place it is and is not. It is not Asian fusion or Pan-Asian; General Tsos chicken is not on the menu; and there is no sushi bar in the corner. This year-old storefront is unabashedly Thai and only Thai.

title: New Jersey Ruling on Witnesses May Prod New York to Change
description: Although a New Jersey Supreme Court decision this week that set new rules for witness identification procedures in criminal cases does not directly affect New York City, some legal analysts and officials say it may quicken the pace of possible changes the city is now studying.

title: Schedule Is Shifted, but Not to Yankees Liking
description: BALTIMORE  With Hurricane Irene bearing down and a state of emergency already declared here, the Baltimore Orioles rejected a proposal by the Yankees to play their scheduled doubleheader Friday instead of Saturday, leaving the Yankees frustrated by what they saw as the Orioles intransigence.

title: The Death of Joe Hill
description: Joe Hill, a songwriter and labor activist, was executed in 1915 after being convicted of murder.

title: Libyan War Goes a Long Way to Improve the Pentagons View of France as an Ally
description: WASHINGTON  Eight years ago the French were called the cheese-eating surrender monkeys who opposed the Iraq war. They inspired freedom fries and jokes meant to boost American military morale. Have you heard about the new French tank? a United States Marine commander asked his men in Kuwait in March 2003, only days before his unit crossed the border into Iraq. Its got six gears  all in reverse.

title: Turkey: Plot Suspects Are Charged
description: After more than five months in jail, 12 suspects, including 2 prominent journalists, were formally charged Friday with supporting a terrorist network accused of plotting a coup, the semiofficial Anatolian news agency reported. The journalists, Nedim Sener and Ahmet Sik, both vocal critics of the governing Justice and Development Party who were also known for opposing a coup, were arrested in March without charges, because of prosecutors fears that they might flee. Media freedom advocates have protested the detentions, which they said were aimed at silencing government opponents, an allegation the governing party denied.

title: Sweet Treats, European-Style
description: Volta Gelateria Creperia is no run-of-the-mill ice cream shop. It is, rather, a European-style cafe, with plenty of outdoor seating, its white marble tables shaded by large striped umbrellas.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Small-Plate Italian, in a Lively Setting
description: THERE is much to like at Zaza, a restaurant and bar in downtown Stamford: great variety on the menu, an upbeat staff, moderate prices and a perfect location for business lunches, after-work drinks and tapas or a full meal in lively surroundings.

title: France: Paris Project Is Approved
description: The government has approved plans for a $30 billion public works project dubbed Le Grand Paris, which President Nicolas Sarkozy hopes will prove a durable legacy of his leadership. The project, whose approval was noted in an official decree published Friday, will include the construction of more than 100 miles of automatic subway lines and 57 new stations, linking the suburbs around Paris in a massive figure 8. Mr. Sarkozy had aspired to remake the capital and solicited proposals from renowned architects, who offered extravagant visions of airborne parks, expansive greenery and futuristic towers. But his ambitions ran up against political and financial limits. The first new subways are planned to be in operation by 2018, according to the Socit du Grand Paris, the state authority in charge of the project.

title: For Wozniacki, a Win and a Kiss From McIlroy
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.  The worlds No. 1 player, Caroline Wozniacki, may end up being one of the favorites at the United States Open after all. As some players hunkered down in New York City to stay safe from Hurricane Irene, Wozniacki was at the New Haven Open at Yale, hoping to win her first tour title since April.

title: Call it Mexi-Cali-Jersey
description: The sign above the door reads, 10th Ave. Burrito Co.  Mexi-Cali Cuisine, which is both misleading and informative. The restaurant is no longer on 10th Avenue in Belmar, having moved in 2009 to a larger space in Belmar Plaza, where the bright yellow dining room is decorated with works by local artists and a television showing films of lucha libre, freestyle wrestling.

title: Classic Vietnamese, Where the Pho Reigns
description: ONE of the first things you notice at Simply Vietnamese, a bustling storefront spot in Tenafly, is the high chopstick-to-fork ratio among the diners. Thats an excellent omen. Its a polyglot crowd  young and old, families and couples, and at least half Asian on several recent visits  and everyone seems comfortably familiar with the task at hand.

title: Examining a Labor Heros Death
description: At Woodstock, Joan Baez sang a famous folk ballad celebrating Joe Hill, the itinerant miner, songwriter and union activist who was executed by a Utah firing squad in 1915. I never died, said he is the songs refrain.

title: Star Scientific Loses Bid for Patent Royalties
description: Star Scientific, a maker of tobacco products, lost a bid for a new trial in its decade-long effort to extract patent royalties from Reynolds American on a way to reduce carcinogens in cigarettes. Losing the bid set off a 40 percent decline in its share price Friday. While the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington today upheld the validity of two Star patents, the panel said there was no need to retry the infringement case against Reynolds that Star lost in 2009. Judge Randall Rader said in the 2-to-1 opinion that a new trial would not change the outcome as there was substantial untainted evidence before the jury to support a verdict of noninfringement. The patents cover a curing process that prevents bacterial activity in tobacco leaves, resulting in the lowest levels of cancer-causing nitrosamines, according to Star. Stock in the company, which is based in Glen Allen, Va., fell $1.19, or nearly 40 percent, to $1.81 a share.

title: Stopping Trains, to Store Them Safely
description: What does it take to shut down the nations largest mass transit network? Hundreds of workers, dozens of exotic maintenance vehicles, and at least eight hours of preparation will be required to do all manner of tasks, including storing subway trains in underground caverns and securing the wooden gates on grade-level crossings in Long Island.

title: One Lost Day Follows Another
description: BALTIMORE  In the wake of another disastrous outing by A. J. Burnett on Friday night, and with a compressed schedule of games coming up because of Hurricane Irene, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was asked if Burnett would still make his next scheduled start against the hard-hitting Boston Red Sox next week.

title: Corrections: August 27
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: 30 Seconds: Kirk Herbstreits Heart Stays in Columbus
description: Kirk Herbstreit, a former Ohio State quarterback and captain, recently made headlines when he announced that, amid a scandal rocking the Buckeyes football program, he and his family would move from their longtime home in Columbus, Ohio, to Nashville.

title: Assault Case Spurs Debate, but Sharpton Stays Silent
description: In the three months that the city and a good portion of the world buzzed about the hotel housekeeper and the French man of power, voices big and small spoke up for one side or the other, or simply urged that justice be found in a courtroom. There were news conferences, rallies, protests, cable-TV exhortations.

title: China: U.S. Report Denounced
description: Chinese defense officials denounced Friday a Pentagon report that called Chinas military buildup potentially destabilizing, Xinhua reported. The Pentagon report, released Wednesday, asserted that Chinas military modernization could lead to regional tensions and instability. The report does not hold water as it severely distorted the facts, a Chinese Defense Ministry spokesman, Yang Yujun, said in a statement. He added, China unswervingly adheres to the path of peaceful development, and its national defense policy is defensive in nature.

title: Conviction of Bonds on Obstruction Charge Is Upheld by Judge
description: A federal judge in San Francisco on Friday denied Barry Bondss request to drop his obstruction of justice conviction, upholding that jury verdict and also rejecting Bondss request for a new trial on that charge.

title: Hurricane Irene  The Endgame
description: The National Hurricane Centers final 3-day projected track for Hurricane Irene keeps the powerful storm centered on the populous metropolitan corridor from the suburbs of Washington, D.C., through New York City  showing the storm still maintaining hurricane strength as it approaches the New York coastline. The track is very similar to that of Hurricane Floyd in 1999, except that storm weakened to a tropical storm before reaching New York.

title: Introducing ... the Bucketeers
description: Some of the members of the Red Bucket Films collective.

title: Readers Photos of Hurricane Irene
description: Times readers submitted their photos of early evacuations, storm scenes and damage.

title: Top Recruit Drummond Is Headed to Connecticut
description: Andre Drummond, considered the top big-man prospect in the country, announced Friday on Twitter that he would be playing for defending national champion Connecticut next season. Drummond had originally planned to attend prep school at Wilbraham & Monson Academy in Massachusetts next year. Drummond, a 6-foot 10-inch, 275-pound center, will head to Connecticut for what is expected to be a one-year stay. He joins Jeremy Lamb, the breakout star of last years N.C.A.A. tournament, and the star forward Alex Oriakhi.

title: When Tennis Was Golden, or Was It?
description: Seen through the haze of history, the golden age of modern professional tennis emerged between 1980 and 1990, when rivalries and racket sales signaled a surge of worldwide interest and affection for the sport.

title: New to English
description: Students learning English, labeled as English Language Learners by education officials, are among the nations fastest-growing group of students.

title: The Driest Place on Earth
description: Quillagua in northern Chile is an oasis town whose population has shrunk as its water supply dwindled.

title: For Students Learning English, a World Apart
description: At Cecil D. Hylton High School in Woodbridge, Va., which has seen a tremendous influx in immigrants, students in a program specifically tailored to non-English speakers rarely interact with other students at the school.

title: Dreamgirls in South Korea
description: An American producer has gone to Seoul to develop and stage a new version of the hit musical.

title: The Art on the Library Walls
description: A foundation has built colorful new libraries in public schools, luring well-known artists and illustrators to create works for their walls.

title: Taking the Impossible Photograph
description: David Yoder is not an art historian. Nor is he a physicist. In fact, Mr. Yoder said, Im positive I would have failed any physics course.

title: 2011 Baltimore Ravens Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. Next up: The Ravens.

title: Damage and Flooding Scar Atlantic Seaboard
description: This article was reported by   Kim Severson,  Dan Barry and  Campbell Robertson and was written by Mr. Barry.

title: Updates on Hurricane Irene
description: On Saturday and Sunday, The Lede tracked the impact of Hurricane Irene as it swept north.

title: A Break on Your MetroCard Because of the Storm? M.T.A. Says No
description: It may not be the first question on the minds of New Yorkers as Hurricane Irene moves into the region on Saturday. But judging from Twitter and e-mails from readers, many cannot help but wonder:

title: Homeless World Cup: Soccer, Statistics and Social Change
description: 1:10 p.m. | Updated On Sunday, Scotland defeated Mexico, 4-3, to win the mens title and Kenya beat Mexico by the same score to win the womens crown in Paris.

title: Leaving Red Hook, or Moving to Higher Ground, Vinyl and All
description: In Red Hook, Brooklyn, Saturday morning, sidewalks and parks were lined with dogs enjoying their last walks before the evacuation. Three boys finished a game of handball on King Street before returning indoors. Cars rolled slowly past a bus stop on Dwight Street, which still bore an advertisement from the spring: Judgment Day, it read. May 21, 2011.

title: Alas, Babylon Line
description: I see that Nassau County, Long Island south of Sunrise Highway is being evacuated. Thats my homeland! In Merrick, Sunrise was the big east-west drag, with the Babylon Line of the Long Island Railroad running alongside. Our house was around a mile south of there, although its gone now, replaced with a McMansion. Anyway, given the canals running through that area, I can easily see how it might end up underwater.

title: Hurricane Irene Lands on East Coast
description: Even after being downgraded to a Category 1storm, the hurricane still packed winds of around 90 miles an hour as it hit the North Carolina coast.

title: The Obvious Video
Bloomberg Warns of Electrical Shutdowns
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned residents to prepare for the possibility of an electrical shutdown in Lower Manhattan, saying New York City officials were expecting a strong storm with winds 55 to 75 miles per hour to move into the region on Saturday night.

title: Vettel Leads Crazy Wet and Dry Qualifying in Spa
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium  It was an amazing qualifying session in Spa-Francorchamps today with the changing weather conditions from wet to dry  forcing cars out on the track throughout the sessions to ensure the fastest lap by the end of the sessions.

title: Vettel Leads Crazy Wet and Dry Qualifying in Spa
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium  It was an amazing qualifying session in Spa-Francorchamps today with the changing weather conditions from wet to dry  forcing cars out on the track throughout the sessions to ensure the fastest lap by the end of the sessions.

title: Why Not Let 18-Year-Olds Head Straight for the Pros?
description: The XFL closed its doors, after one season, more than 10 years ago. I was the head coach of the leagues Birmingham Thunderbolts franchise. That experience forever changed the way I look at both college and professional football.

title: Receiver Victor Cruz Is No Longer a Novelty
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The lingering image from the last time the Giants and Jets met is of Eli Manning, face bloodied and eyes glassy, staggering around the field after his helmet was knocked off in a collision last August.

title: Falcons Get Their Man, Julio Jones
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  Atlanta Falcons General Manager Thomas Dimitroff, his hair spiked and his shoulders often hunched over racing bicycle handlebars, has a youthful bearing that might connote impetuous decision-making without the benefit of historical context.

title: Popularity and Pedigree Matter in the B.C.S.
description: A 12-game college football season almost certainly isnt enough to differentiate the teams from one another to any degree of satisfaction. This is particularly so given contemporary scheduling patterns in which fewer competitive nonconference games are scheduled, lest teams risk a black mark on their records.

title: Gnarly Moves and Nonstop Adrenaline
description: It was not the need for speed or the opportunity to impress girls that initially drew Rob Dyrdek to skateboarding. I idolized my sisters boyfriend, Dyrdek said. He wore four bandanas on each arm and each leg, and a spiked belt across his chest and waist. He was the sickest dude ever, and I was like, If hes a skater, I gotta be a skater.

title: Transportation System Shuts Down
description: 1:03 p.m. | Updated New York Citys mass transit network, the nations largest, was closed at noon on Saturday, with subway, bus, and commuter rail service winding down throughout the region.

title: Scenes From Staten Island
description: Runners, walkers and cyclists all hit the boardwalk on Staten Islands South Beach Saturday morning, the water so calm, the breeze like a whisper. Only the hair-curling humidity, as steamy as a Turkish bath, indicated that a storm was approaching.

title: Assembling More Than a Football Program at T.C.U.
description: FORT WORTH  Gary Patterson wears a whistle. Listen to folks here talk about Patterson, Texas Christians football coach, however, and you start to believe he should put on a hard hat and drive an armored truck for all the money he has brought to this oak-lined campus in one of Americas most famous cow towns. While Ohio State Buckeyes and Miami Hurricanes bemoan the decline and fall of the big-time college football civilization, here in Horned Frogs nation, a renaissance is in full bloom.

title: Iran Calls on Syria to Recognize Citizens Demands
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iran, Syrias closest ally, called on the government in Damascus to recognize its peoples legitimate demands on Saturday, in the first such remarks to come from the Persian country since the five-month-old uprising against President Bashar al-Assad started.

title: Trawling the N.F.L.s Bargain Basement
description: Smart shoppers know that the remainder bin always contains bargains, assuming one is not too picky about quality. That is also true on the N.F.L. free-agent market.

title: Joe Bucks Voice Lands on the D.L.
description: One day in mid-February, Joe Bucks voice abandoned him. A virus had struck the laryngeal nerve in his left vocal cord and what remained was a thin, raspy sound that was barely audible across a room. This was far scarier than the laryngitis that rendered him mute two days before the 2004 N.F.C. title game.

title: Ingredients of Shady Origins, Posing as Supplements
description: BOSTON

title: Getting People, and Dogs, to Safety
description: Gantry Plaza State Park, on the waterfront in Long Island City, Queens, stood virtually deserted, save for a group of tourists from Spain who arrived by bus and spent a few minutes by the water, photographing Manhattan.

title: A Lasting Memory, a Remarkable Achievement
description: DETROIT  Lloyd McClendon coaches hitting at the highest level of baseball. He knows, acutely, that hitting is too hard for one to be successful every time. No player, whatever his skills, should be able to swat five home runs in five at-bats.

title: Terrorist Group Suspected in Nigerian Suicide Attack
description: Nigerias president visited the site of the United Nations building hit by a deadly suicide bombing in the capital, Abuja, pledging Saturday to bring to justice an Islamist group called Boko Haram that has claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed at least 18 people.

title: Lessons About Not Leaving

title: Long and Belly Putters Win Events and Converts
description: EDISON, N.J.  After three PGA Tour players  Adam Scott, Keegan Bradley and Webb Simpson  used a belly putter or a long putter to win a tournament in recent weeks, it is no surprise that amateur players are suddenly eyeing the clubs with increasing curiosity. It is among the sports oldest traditions: what works for another player, golfers think, could work for me.

description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  If you love to play with words, the wisdom and etymology of words in languages besides English has to hold some appeal as well.

title: In Russias Shadow, Abkhazia Elects President
description: SUKHUMI, Georgia  Aleksandr Z. Ankvab has been elected president of Abkhazia, a rebel enclave of Georgia still struggling for legitimacy three years after Russia unilaterally declared it a sovereign nation.

title: Out of Debt Ceiling Fight, Some See a Bit of Stability on Federal Spending

title: Few Treatment Options for Afghans as Drug Use Rises

title: Writings on the Wall (Art Is, Too, for Now)

The opposite of furtive, these tattooed artisans laugh as they brandish spraypaint cans for an audience of curious passers-by. Tagging may be illegal in New York, but not on this extraordinarily colorful industrial block beneath the shriek of the No. 7 subway line.

title: Readers and Unemployment
description: As my Sunday column appears, Ill be in transit to Libya, inshaallah. But this column grew out of my family vacation this summer back in Yamhill, Oregon, where I grew up. Like everyone in journalism, I had been focused on the debt ceiling debates, but what I saw in Yamhill was a different economic scourge: unemployment. It really puzzles me that 25 million Americans could be unemployed or under-employed, and yet the issue has never really gotten much traction. In the last month or two, it has gained more visibility and President Obama says he is pivoting to jobs  but none of the proposals on the agenda come close to matching the severity of the unemployment picture.

title: Sunday: Pardon E Interruption
description: Administrivial Vacation Alert: Barring any weather complications, I will be on vacation starting Sunday, August 28 and will be back with the Monday, September 5 post. Fear not, however, because in my absence Wordplay will be written and steered by the very able and extremely brave Thomas Gaffney. Tom is a New York Times news assistant and is an excellent solver with a terrific point of view. I hope you will all welcome him. Please be gentle.

title: Hurricanes and Climate Change
description: I have a short piece going into Sundays paper on the question of whether hurricanes are getting stronger because of climate change. In it, I outline the views of Kerry Emanuel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who takes the position that they are, and Thomas R. Knutson of the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory, who believes it would be premature to conclude they are getting stronger over a long stretch of time.

description: Price Berkley, the founder, editor and longtime publisher of Theatrical Index, the weekly trade publication that for nearly half a century has been consulted by anyone wanting to produce, finance, write about or possibly avoid a Broadway show, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan.
