title: A New Civilian Conservation Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: June Wayne, Painter and Printmaker, Dies at 93
description: June Wayne, a painter and printmaker who helped revive the fortunes of fine-art lithography in the United States when she founded the Tamarind Lithography Workshop in 1960 in Los Angeles, died on Tuesday at her home there. She was 93.

title: Nadal Enters Open in Djokovics Shadow
description: Rafael Nadal is 25 years old and ranked second in the world. He holds 10 career Grand Slam titles and a 53-10 record in 2011. By all accounts, he will begin his defense of the United States Open title this week ranked among the favorites, but he seems especially vulnerable.

title: As Losses Pile Up, Burnett Keeps Hope
description: BALTIMORE  In the quiet moments in the visitors clubhouse at Camden Yards after another awful start Friday, A. J. Burnett became rather philosophical. What else could he really do, considering that he had again disappointed his Yankees teammates with a dreadful performance by allowing six runs in the second inning, and nine over all?

title: New Friends Fight Off Cabin Fever at a Hotel Turned Shelter
description: SWANSBORO, N.C.  The air inside the rooms at the Hampton Inn here is getting so thick, people are propping doors open with trash cans.

title: Two Big Tournaments in the Two Biggest Cities
description: The biggest tournaments in the United States are usually held in places like Philadelphia and Las Vegas, not New York and Los Angeles. The reasons are cost (rents for tournament sites are higher in New York and Los Angeles) and convenience (inland tournaments tend to be easier to get to).

title: Johnson Charges to Sodden Victory at the Barclays
description: EDISON, N.J.  On a Saturday when fear of Hurricane Irene was utmost on the minds of people along the East Coast, most of the players at the Barclays continued to attack Plainfield Country Clubs soaked golf course in the third and final round of the rain-shortened tournament.

title: Hurricane Irene: What You Need to Know in New York
description: 11:47 p.m. | Updated Latest updates on the city after the storm are here.

title: An Emotional Day Ends on a High Note as Stay Thirsty Captures the Travers
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Mike Repole was bummed. Uncle Mo, last years 2-year-old champion, had run his heart out every step of the way for seven furlongs and was a stride away from punctuating a triumphant comeback with a victory in the Kings Bishop on Saturday. Repole was ready to hug his grandmother, Assunta; his mother, Annie; and his wife, Maria, all of whom were surrounding him in his box.

title: Corrections: August 28
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Bachmann Promises Fast Economic Turnaround With Tax Cuts
description: How hard will it be to spur strong job growth in an economy mired in a seemingly endless funk of high unemployment?

title: Battle for Libya | August 27, 2011
description: Libyans examined the Bab al-Aziziya complex, which housed Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family in Tripoli.

title: Talib and Britt Avoid Suspensions
description: The N.F.L. said it would not suspend Tampa Bay cornerback Aqib Talib or Tennessee receiver Kenny Britt for any games this season, even though they had significant brushes with the law during the lockout. The decision by Commissioner Roger Goodell was being closely watched because the league had insisted throughout the lockout that players would still be subject to consequences under the personal-conduct policy.

title: New York Feels Irenes Fury
description: The streets of New York were nearly empty as residents heeded warnings about the storm.

title: Lottery Numbers
Pageantry and Penalties
description: The college football season begins under a cloud of scandal, with Jim Tressels resignation at Ohio State acting as a mere warm-up to the salacious allegations that came out of Miami. Is the sport out of control? Four people, with four very different perspectives, assess the problems in college football and suggest how they can be addressed.

title: Readers Photos of Hurricane Irene
description: A selection of photos by Times readers.

title: Hells Kitchen, 7:11 p.m.
Evacuate? Not Us
description: Residents in Rockaway, Queens, battened down the hatches and stocked up on provisions as Hurricane Irene approached, ignoring a mandatory evacuation order.

title: Flash Win W.P.S. Title, but Will They Get a Chance to Defend?
description: Ashlyn Harris dove to save the final penalty kick  the only one not converted in the penalty shootout  to give the Western New York Flash a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Independence on Saturday in the Womens Professional Soccer championship game in Rochester.

title: Taking Irene Lightly
description: While most bars around Manhattan are closed, Lillie's near Union Square welcomes Irene with a hurricane party.

title: Outside of Berlin, Bauhaus-Themed Fun
description: In the decade or so before the Nazis came to power in Germany, the Bauhaus school was known for its groundbreaking modern art, architecture and design  and its terrific parties. In fact, Walter Gropius, the Bauhaus founder, decreed that wild theme parties  where students and professors would dress up, recite poetry, show what they were working on, and generally have a good time  were to be part of the curriculum. These days, a version of those parties, called Farbfest, held at the Bauhaus building in Dessau, about an hour and a half outside of Berlin, are back. This years festivities will be on Sept. 2 and 3.

title: Live Blog: As Irene Passes, City Exhales
description: New Yorkers awoke Sunday morning to torrential rains, heavy winds and fears that Hurricane Irene would carve a path of destruction through the city.

title: Down Atlantic, a Refrain: It Could Have Been Worse
description: This article was reported by  Kim Severson,  Campbell Robertson and  Kevin Sack and was written by Mr. Sack.

title: Recovery Is Slower in New York Suburbs
description: Tropical Storm Irene swept through the desolate streets of New York on Sunday, flooding low-lying areas and leaving millions of homes without power along the Eastern Seaboard as it continued on to New England. Most New Yorkers emerged from their makeshift bunkers to find little of the widespread devastation the authorities had feared.

title: Could the N.B.A. Invade the U.S. Open?
description: With the N.B.A. lockout opening up the possibility that there will be no 2011-12 season, many of the worlds greatest athletes are looking at some extended unemployment. This has led to some players, like Deron Williams of the Nets, agreeing to play abroad. More interestingly, some have begun to look into other careers that suit their skill sets, with Kevin Love of the Timberwolves choosing beach volleyball.

title: Boston Symphony Orchestra Performance Is Canceled
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra has canceled its performance of Beethovens Ninth Symphony scheduled for Sunday afternoon at the Tanglewood Festival in Lenox, Mass., because of the approach of Hurricane Irene. The performance of the Ninth Symphony, which traditionally ends the orchestras season at the festival, was to have been conducted by Lorin Maazel. All other Tanglewood events scheduled for Sunday have also been canceled, but the Tanglewood Jazz Festival is still scheduled to run from Thursday to next Sunday. The orchestra says that this is the first time it has canceled a concert in its 75-year residence at Tanglewood, despite occasionally heavy weather in the surrounding Berkshire Hills. Refunds will be available. Information can be found online or, as of Monday, at (617) 638-9395.

title: Irene Lashes New York Area
description: Irene, now downgraded to a tropical storm, pushed into the New York area on Sunday morning, unleashing rain and wind on a city girded for the worst.

title: Will New York Be Lulled by Moderate Hurricane Surge?
description: 11:50 a.m. | Updated This was the view at the south tip of Manhattan this morning, as Irene, now a tropical storm, headed north mainly as a Floyd-like rainmaker on its way toward Canada. (Having covered Tropical Storm Floyd in 1999, I noted similarities in a post on Tuesday.) Theres a lot more minute-to-minute input on the City Room blog on regional impacts. In the Hudson Valley the winds are picking up but the powers still on.

title: Irene Lashes New York Area
description: Irene, now downgraded to a tropical storm, pushed into the New York area on Sunday morning, unleashing rain and wind on a city girded for the worst.

title: Family Values
description: Catching a wave with a royal clan of surfer outlaws.

title: On a Houseboat in Queens, Dry and Unimpressed by a Storm
description: On Sunday morning, as New York City was feeling the brunt of what had become Tropical Storm Irene, Billy Drankwater, 57, was leisurely buttering a piece of white bread, in the cozy, dry cabin of his 33-foot wooden boat, docked off the north shore of Queens, in Flushing Bay.

title: Trial Shows Blockbuster Potential for Blood Clot Pill
description: An experimental pill to prevent blood clots exceeded already high expectations as a better therapy for millions of people with atrial fibrillation, according to final results of a worldwide study released Sunday.

title: Multigen Family Floor 1
description: Multi-generational family - floor 1

title: Sunday Morning With Irene
description: As the height of the storm hit New York City on Sunday morning, we asked our Twitter followers on @NYTMetro what they were doing to occupy themselves besides tracking the news. Below, our call for #Ireneindoors tweets and a selection of the responses we received.

title: Finland Could Upend Fragile Consensus on Greece
description: FRANKFURT  France and Germany may effectively run the European Union, but Finland has demonstrated how even a small country can disrupt their grand designs.

title: Off the Court, Nadal Wears Chefs Whites
description: If this were Wimbledon, Rafael Nadal would have been cooking while riding out the hurricane.

title: After Hurricane Irene
description: The storm moved north, leaving a trail of damage, degree and flooding from North Carolina to Pennsylvania.

title: Wireless Phone Networks Stood Up Well to Hurricane
description: Wireless phone networks held up well against Hurricane Irene despite widespread losses of power.

title: Irene Hits the Rockaways
description: Residents ventured on to the boardwalk as Irene made landfall on the Rockaway peninsula in Queens. Waves broke through the boardwalk in areas, flooding local streets.

title: Sino-Forest Corp. Says Its Chief Has Resigned
description: OTTAWA  The Sino-Forest Corporation, a Chinese company that is the focus of a Canadian securities investigation, said on Sunday that its chairman and chief executive, Allen T.Y. Chan, had resigned.

title: The Let: Reassessing the Tale of the Tape
description: The fuzzy yellow ball hurtles through the air at top speed, so you move your feet and get your racket back. Suddenly, the ball nicks the tape at the top of the net, changing its pace, height and even direction.

title: Life in a Storm Shelter in Brooklyn
description: By early evening on Saturday, an evacuation center set up in a middle school in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, was nearly full of people seeking shelter from the storm. Some of them had arrived on Friday  leaving areas of the city that officials had warned were likely to see heavy rain and flooding.

title: New Movies Struggle Amid Hurricane Irene
description: Three new releases with dim box-office prospects going into the weekend were additionally pummeled by Hurricane Irene, which shuttered theaters in the all-important East Coast movie market. The Help (DreamWorks Studios) repeated as No. 1 for a third weekend, taking in an estimated $14.3 million for a new domestic total of $96.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.Colombiana (TriStar) performed the best of the three newcomers, placing second with about $10 million in ticket sales, a total that its distributor positioned as better than expected. Third place went to Dont Be Afraid of the Dark, which took in about $8.7 million; Film District notably marketed this thriller on the back of Guillermo del Toro, one of its writers and producers (and a type of fanboy pied piper for his Hellboy series.)

title: Does New York City Need Surge Protection?
description: Erik Baard*, a founder of the Long Island City Community Boathouse in the borough of Queens, reacted to my piece exploring New York Citys potential responses to moderate waterfront flooding from Irene by noting Mayor Michael M. Bloombergs reaction to a question about waterfront high-rises and storm surge barriers for the city at a news conference earlier this year. It merits a Your Dot post (Ive added a couple of contextual links):

title: Friendly Fire: The Lethal Serve in Doubles Tennis
description: The serve in doubles tennis can function as an assault weapon, among other things. And occasionally, it misses its intended target. Bob and Mike Bryan, the defending United States Open mens doubles champions, find this funny. Well, Bob does. Not so much Mike.

title: In Tennis, Top Returners Rely on Instinct and Observation
description: Nikolay Davydenko won the coin toss before his second-round match against Mardy Fish at the Western and Southern Open in Ohio this month, and, to Fishs surprise, elected to serve. Like the Jets, Davydenko is known for his defense.

title: Manchester United 8, Arsenal 2
description: Sundays one-sided result at Old Trafford in the English Premier League was pretty well summed up by my son:

title: Burnett Will Stay in Rotation to Face Red Sox
description: BALTIMORE  Joe Girardi announced his coming pitching rotation Sunday, and he said A.J. Burnett would make his next start Thursday at Fenway Park against the Boston Red Sox. But there are no guarantees Burnett will remain in the rotation after that because the Yankees are expected to trim down from a six-man rotation to five after the series in Boston.

title: New York Subway Running in Time for Morning Commute
description: The New York City subway, whose closure in the lead-up to Tropical Storm Irene was perhaps the most unsettling element of a prodigious storm preparation effort, reopened on a limited schedule on Monday morning.

title: Twitter Becomes a Playground During Hurricane Irene
description: 1:13 p.m. | Updated Revising timing of some hoax images shared on Twitter.

title: No Favorite Emerges in Race for Japanese Premier
description: TOKYO  In the brief race to choose Japans next prime minister, five candidates vied Sunday for support within the governing Democratic Party, but none of them appeared to have a decisive lead going into Mondays vote.

title: Doubles Standouts Talk About Culture and Collaboration
description: Vania King, Sania Mirza and Aisam-ul-Haq Qureshi, three of the best doubles players in the world, participated in a roundtable discussion about tennis and culture on Friday in front of more than 50 New York Times staffers. King, 22, a Taiwanese-American from Monterey Park, Calif., and Boynton Beach, Fla., is the defending doubles champion at the United States Open and winner of the Wimbledon doubles title in 2010. Qureshi, 31, of Lahore, Pakistan, reached the doubles finals of the U.S. Open last year, where he and Rohan Bopanna, of India, lost to Bob and Mike Bryan in two tiebreakers. Mirza, 24, who was born in Mumbai, India, and currently lives in Dubai, was a doubles finalist at the French Open this year.

title: When is a Road Not a Road?
description: Answer: After a torrential deluge from a deteriorating hurricane.

title: The Meaning of Utopia
description: The modern world was inaugurated by two books with opposing perspectives, published at the same time in the early years of the 16th century: Machiavellis The Prince and Thomas Mores Utopia. Modernity came to a close with the collapse of all those attempts, both collective and liberal, that had been made to bring utopia about in history. Here I should like to reflect on that beginning and that end, insofar as they involve the status of utopia.

title: Irene Forces Mostly Mozarts End, and Unfinished Works Are the Focus
description: You would not have guessed that it was the eve of Hurricane Irene weekend from the placid scene at Lincoln Center on Friday night. The weather was humid but mild; there were people buying gelato, tourists taking photos of the plaza and music lovers heading into Avery Fisher Hall for what was supposed to have been the next-to-last performance of this summers Mostly Mozart Festival, with Louis Langre, the festivals music director, conducting the festival orchestra in works by Stravinsky, Schubert and Mozart.

title: Vettel Returns to Victory, at Belgian Grand Prix
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium  Sebastian Vettel returned to the highest step of the podium for the first time in four races, as the German driver for the Red Bull team won the Belgian Grand Prix, driving from pole position to victory.

title: Vettel Returns to Victory, at Belgian Grand Prix
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium  Sebastian Vettel returned to the highest step of the podium for the first time in four races, as the German driver for the Red Bull team won the Belgian Grand Prix, driving from pole position to victory.

title: A Young Scientist, Waiting for the Baboons to Do Something
description: On one side of the glass, an 11-year-old male hamadryas baboon sits on a miniature hillside. He sits some more. He sucks on his right hand, then cleans the toes on his right foot, which rests on an artificial rock.

title: Turkish Leader Says He Has Lost Confidence in Assad
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  After trying for months to engage with Syria in an effort to ease the violence there, Turkeys president declared Sunday that he had lost confidence in the government in Damascus, and he stopped just short of calling on President Bashar al-Assad to step down.

title: The Power and Glory of Cheesy TV Commercials
description: I recently saw a list of cheesy local TV commercials that got me laughing and thinking. Why exactly do these spots have such a time-honored place in our culture?

title: Legislator Calls for Clarifying Copyright Law
description: Arguing that Congress has an obligation to preserve fairness and justice for artists, the senior Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee has called for a revision of United States copyright law to remove ambiguities in the current statute about who is eligible to reclaim ownership rights to songs and sound recordings.

title: Irene Goes Relatively Easy on Manhattan
description: Hurricane Irene came and went past Manhattan relatively quickly on Sunday.

title: After Storm, Markets Plan for Business as Usual
description: The nations stock exchanges, after consulting with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Sunday that they planned to open as usual on Monday morning. Wall Street banks said they, too, would be open for business as usual, and the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association said bond markets were on schedule as well.

title: Portraits Redrawn: Iliana McGinnis
description: Since losing her husband a decade ago, Iliana and her daughter, Caitlin, have had many ups and downs.

title: Who Can Beat Bolt in the 100? Himself
description: DAEGU, South Korea  Usain Bolts biggest rivals were absent with injuries, and despite a subdued season by his exclamation-point standards, he had cruised through the first two rounds of the 100 meters at the track and field world championships looking confident and comfortable.

title: Pistorius Advances to 400 Semifinals at Worlds
description: DAEGU, SOUTH KOREA  There was a shortage of witnesses to history Sunday morning when Oscar Pistorius stepped into Lane 8, the carbon fiber blades that he uses for legs bending as he shifted his weight in anticipation.

title: After Being Shut Down in Opener, Yankees Find Power in Nightcap
description: BALTIMORE  Curtis Granderson has been at the forefront of this hurricane-interrupted series as the Yankees player representative charged with presenting the Yankees position on the rescheduling of lost games.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Reports this week will include personal income and spending for July, and pending home sales for June (Monday); S.& P./Case-Shiller housing price index for June and the second quarter; consumer confidence for August (Tuesday); ADP employment for August; Chicago P.M.I. for August, and factory orders for July (Wednesday); revised second-quarter productivity; weekly jobless claims; I.S.M. manufacturing index for August; and construction spending for July (Thursday); unemployment for August (Friday).

title: G.E. to Produce Short Films About Innovation
description: LOS ANGELES  General Electric just cant stay away from the movies. Barely eight months after ceding control of NBC Universal and its Universal Studios to Comcast, G.E. is diving into the documentary world as the financial backer of 30 three-minute films by directors including Morgan Spurlock (POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold), Joe Berlinger (Crude), Barbara Kopple (Shut Up and Sing) and Alex Gibney (Magic Trip: Ken Keseys Search for a Kool Place).

title: In Practice Match, Fish and Federer Begin to Focus
description: Two questions:

title: Problems Building for Chinese Banks
description: Chinas five biggest banks raised their combined earnings by 37 percent during the first half of 2011. Lending margins and fees rose, while bad debts fell. In a sign of flush times, some big banks are now even offering their best customers private jet services. Yet there is still plenty to worry about, and that explains why their shares have fallen roughly a quarter from this years peak.

title: Driving While Undead
description: MTVs Death Valley, a hyperbolically gory but otherwise innocuous new comedy-horror series about an outbreak of zombieism, vampirism and werewolfism in the San Fernando Valley, is like a freeway pileup of current television trends.

title: Aces of Game
description: Geoff Macdonald rates the top servers in history:

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Classic That Still Vexes as It Pleases
description: LENOX, Mass.  On Friday evening a hurricane raged toward the Atlantic coast. At the same time one roared onstage here at the Tanglewood Festival, threatening the lives of the inhabitants of Catfish Row, the South Carolina ghetto that is the setting of George Gershwins opera Porgy and Bess.

title: Gumshoe on Capital Asphalt
description: The Cut is the series kickoff that introduces Spero Lucas, a brand new George Pelecanos creation. Spero is a fit, athletic 29-year-old ex-Marine who roams Washington and its environs. He works as a freelance retriever of stolen property, taking a 40 percent cut on the value of anything he finds.

title: Mystery Is Set for a Free-Range Audience
description: Bring comfortable shoes and a high threshold for frustration to the Woodshed Collectives sprawling production The Tenant, the latest in a proliferating mini-genre of immersive-spookhouse mood pieces.

title: Lockerbie Planner Reported Near Death
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  An official with the rebel government on Sunday ruled out extraditing the former Libyan intelligence officer convicted as the mastermind of the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 and released from a Scottish prison two years ago on the ground that he was near death.

title: Prime Time Ambitions
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  In October 2001, an exasperated Howard Stringer, the chief executive of Sony, ordered a substantial downsizing at the companys studio here.

title: How the Serve Went Over the Top
description: Imagine, in your minds eye, Serena Williams serving, facing break point. She toes the line, bounces the ball and takes a deep breath. She draws the racket back almost languidly, coils her body and vaults skyward, her legs driving the racket head at blinding speed as she clobbers an ace up the T at 120 miles an hour. The best server in the history of womens tennis pumps her left fist and yells, Come on!

title: A Vision of How People Should Live, From Desert Revelers to Urbanites
description: GERLACH, Nev.  How many city planners get to see their ideas take shape all around them?

title: Ethereal Hip-Hop, With a Slightly Bent Perspective
description: The Internet makes for strange bedfellows and stranger encounters. Only the Internet  and its twisting, unlikely corridors of influence  could have led to the first New York performance by the young Oakland, Calif., hip-hop duo Main Attrakionz  Squadda B and MondreM.A.N.  on Friday evening in the basement lecture hall of the New Museum.

title: Monday: How Appetizing!
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Greetings everyone!

title: Revamping Reality
description: Reality television needs reformation.

title: Islamic Group Says It Was Behind Fatal Nigeria Attack
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Investigators searched the rubble of the shattered United Nations headquarters building here in the Nigerian capital on Sunday as the number of deaths climbed to at least 21 and questions lingered about who bore responsibility for Fridays suicide car bombing, even as men who said they were representatives of a radical Islamist sect claimed it.

title: Collegiate Chorale Announces Season
description: The Collegiate Chorale has announced its 2011-12 season, highlighted by a new production of Gilbert and Sullivans comic opera The Mikado, featuring the three-time Tony nominee Kelli OHara (South Pacific, The Pajama Game, The Light in the Piazza). Set to open in April, the operetta represents another direction for Ms. OHara, right; it will follow her already announced role as Regan in the Public Theaters production of King Lear. The Chorales 70th anniversary season is also scheduled to include Rossinis Mose et Pharaon (Nov. 30) and A Child of Our Time by Michael Tippett paired with Bruckners Te Deum (Feb. 3). All three productions are to be performed at Carnegie Hall.

title: Cond Nast Deepens Its Social Connections
description: Readers of the online versions of Cond Nast publications will have to look no further than the bottom of their screens to see what content other readers have deemed worthy of a Tweet on Twitter or a like on Facebook. And right below that social media will be a hefty dose of advertising.

title: Tom Jones Cancels Concert
description: Tom Jones was recovering in a hospital in Monaco on Sunday and said that severe dehydration had forced him to cancel a concert, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Jones, below, apologized to his fans on his Web site and denied British press reports that a heart scare had forced the cancellation. There are no heart problems, as has been reported in the press, said a statement on the Web site. Mr. Jones, 71, blamed a long tour in which many of the shows were in locations that were in the throes of high summer heat. The Web site statement indicated that doctors had ordered him to cancel the show, which was to have been the end of his three-month Praise & Blame tour. A spokesman for the Princess Grace Hospital in Monaco told The A.P. that Mr. Jones was admitted on Saturday night and was doing well.

title: Staying Focused
description: On Par columnist Bill Pennington gets a little too distracted while on the golf course.

title: Mel Gibson Settles With Former Girlfriend
description: Whatever the peace settlement contains, the fight is over. At an unusually late hour  after 8 p.m. on Friday  Los Angeles County Superior Court disclosed in a statement that Mel Gibson and his ex-girlfriend Oksana Grigorieva had reached an agreement resolving the many issues between them. They had been engaged in an epic court battle over custody of their young daughter, and related financial matters. The fight involved claims of abuse by Mr. Gibson and of extortion by Ms. Grigorieva. But the court said there is a deal between the two, the terms of which will be reviewed at a hearing scheduled for 8:30 a.m. Wednesday in the courtroom of Judge Peter D. Lichtman. The court hears custody issues behind closed doors. But issues concerning the financial agreement between Mr. Gibson and Ms. Grigorieva will be reviewed in an open hearing, the courts statement said.

title: On Court 4, Intense Lessons in Competition
description: I returned to Flushing Meadows Friday planning to watch the later stages of the qualies, only to be informed that, avant le deluge, those scheduled to play second-round matches faced, should they win, a third match that same evening, and with it the possibility of playing as many as six hard-fought sets, split between two opponents, in one very long day. Then again, as one of the better tennis-playing literary men, Randall Jarrell (team captain at Vanderbilt in the 1930s) once observed, the really damned not only like Hell, they feel loyal to it.

title: Anchor to Leave PBSs Need to Know
description: PBSs Friday newsmagazine Need to Know is losing Alison Stewart, the second of its original co-anchors to depart, when it switches to a half-hour format on Sept. 16.

title: Sampras vs. Agassi, 2001: An Open Classic Endures
description: Ten years ago, nobody knew that American tennis was close to being broken. To make the case that the sport here was alive and kicking, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi played a quarterfinal match at the United States Open in which neither broke serve.

title: Norwegian Team Squeaks Past American Players in Croatia
description: OPATIJA, Croatia  The Board-a-Match Teams at the second World Youth Congress ended here on Saturday evening. It came down to the final board, which was played simultaneously at all tables.

title: Irene Adds to a Bad Year for Insurance Industry
description: The total damage inflicted by Hurricane Irene may reach $7 billion by the time the storm dissipates in the coming days, making one of the insurance industrys worst years even tougher, according to an early estimate by the Kinetic Analysis Corporation in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Keeping Score: Giving Foes the Runaround
description: In 2009, Ivo Karlovic served 78 aces against Radek Stepanek in a five-set Davis Cup semifinal to set a record for the most aces in a match. Karlovic lost.

title: Photos of Hurricane Irene
description: Irene, now downgraded to a tropical storm, pushed into the New York area on Sunday, unleashing rain and wind on a city girded for the worst.

title: Victorious Hunger Striker Shakes a Political Status Quo
description: NEW DELHI  For the nearly two weeks that Anna Hazare staged his hunger strike, the question hanging over India had been, When would it end? After Mr. Hazare triumphantly broke his fast on Sunday, a different question arose: What now?

title: Masked Protesters Aid Time Warners Bottom Line
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Anonymous, the hacker group, has jostled with the Iranian government and the Church of Scientology and has briefly shut down the Web sites of Visa, MasterCard and other global corporations.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament
description: The Timess tennis experts debated, and the results are in: readers chose Roger Federer and Steffi Graf as the greatest Open champions from the past 30 years.

title: A Subtle Emotional Appeal to Luxury Travelers
description: DESPITE an unsettled economic climate, the Luxury Collection, an upscale brand of Starwood Hotels and Resorts, is updating its advertising to attract new guests.

title: Serve and Return: Feeding the Masses at the Open
description: When youre feeding 700,000 people in two weeks, youre running a sizable food-service operation. When many of those people spend 10 or more hours on your premises, youre feeding them a lot. When half of them are New Yorkers and much of the remaining half are people well-heeled enough to spend days at a time visiting and paying for not-cheap tickets, you have to try to feed them at least decently.

title: A Map of Readers' Photos of Hurricane Irene
description: Times readers submitted their photos of early evacuations, storm scenes and damage.

title: Public Relations a Concern as N.B.A. Millionaires Spar
description: N.B.A. players make a lot of money, but they spend a lot of money, and when times are tough, they might sell their luxury cars.

title: In Unsettled Times, Media Can Be a Call to Action, or a Distraction
description: THE mass media, including interactive social-networking tools, make you passive, can sap your initiative, leave you content to watch the spectacle of life from your couch or smartphone.

title: Product Placement Rises in Networks Telenovelas
description: Viewers who tuned in to watch the Telemundo telenovela Mi Corazn Insiste last week may have seen a new type of cliffhanger, one that directed them to a Web site with exclusive content sponsored by JPMorgan Chase.

title: Airports Resume Service in Northeast, but Backups Could Persist for Days
description: Airlines haltingly began to resume some flights on Sunday in the northeastern United States after the destruction left by Hurricane Irene, but travelers still faced widespread cancellations into Monday and backups well into next week.

title: Nepal Elects a Maoist as Prime Minister
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  The deeply fractured Parliament of Nepal elected a Maoist as the countrys new prime minister on Sunday, after weeks of efforts to form a national unity coalition proved fruitless.

title: Not Just a Sport, but a Window to the Soul
description: It has been said a million times. You have probably heard it, too:

title: Turkish Government to Return Seized Property to Religious Minorities
description: ANKARA, Turkey  The Turkish government said it would return hundreds of properties that were confiscated from religious minorities by the state or other parties over the years since 1936, and would pay compensation for properties that were seized and later sold.

title: Teachers Get Little Say in a Book About Them
description: Can an education reform movement that demeans and trivializes teachers succeed? Its hard to imagine, but that is what is going on in parts of America today.

title: Profits Falling, Banks Confront a Leaner Future
description: Battered by a weak economy, the nations biggest banks are cutting jobs, consolidating businesses and scrambling for new sources of income in anticipation of a fundamentally altered financial landscape requiring leaner operations.

title: In Pakistan, Court Moves to Punish Ex-President
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani court has ordered that former President Pervez Musharrafs property be seized and his bank accounts frozen in connection with the legal case concerning the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.

title: 28 Are Killed in Bombing at a Mosque in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber mounted a devastating attack in one of the largest Sunni mosques in Baghdad on Sunday, killing at least 28 people, including a member of Parliament, and wounding dozens more, according to security officials.

title: A Fine Line on Foot Faults
description: In tennis, the thin white line runs underneath the server, out of sight but never out of mind. If the rubber toe of the servers shoe so much as glances that line, the rest of the motion, the toss, the body contortions, the follow-through, no longer matter.

title: When Roommates Were Random
description: EAGER to throw off my nerdy past and reinvent myself at college, I wrote party animal on my roommate application form where it asked incoming freshmen whether they wanted to bunk with a smoker or a non-smoker. When I told my mother about this later, she laughed and bought me a T-shirt that sported the image of Spuds MacKenzie, the 1980s Budweiser beer mascot, under the words the original party animal.

title: Dangerous White Stereotypes
description: Davis, Calif.

title: The Nations Cruelest Immigration Law
description: The Alabama Legislature opened its session on March 1 on a note of humility and compassion. In the Senate, a Christian pastor asked God to grant members wisdom and discernment to do what is right. Not whats right in their own eyes, he said, but whats right according to your word. Soon after, both houses passed, and the governor signed, the countrys cruelest, most unforgiving immigration law.

title: Tripping Over Their Tongues at the Open
description: Lleyton Hewitt

title: There Has to Be a Better Way to Grade Tests
description: A task force appointed by the New York State education commissioner, John King Jr., is to report next month on ways to improve the integrity of the states educational testing system. New York has thus far escaped cheating scandals like the one that exploded in Atlanta. But troubling new developments have shown weaknesses in New Yorks testing system that need to be fixed.

title: Didnt They Learn Anything From Whitey Bulger?
description: Cutting deals with criminal informants may, at times, be a necessary if unsavory part of law enforcement. But the benefits must outweigh the costs, and it is not clear the F.B.I.s Boston office has mastered that balance.

title: Independents Candidates Really Love
description: There was no little dog Toto to pull back the curtain, but the fiction was clear when the presidential candidate Mitt Romney dropped by an event run by a political Super PAC with the Oz-like name of Restore Our Future.

title: Where Missing a Signal Can Result in a Trip to an Imaginary Morgue
description: Nick Feldaverd stood in the middle of a large parking lot the other day and, all of a sudden, threw his arms in the air. The motorcyclist who was headed in his direction, a trainee just learning to operate his bike, rolled past Mr. Feldaverd, a veteran instructor.

title: American Theocracy Revisited
description: During George W. Bushs presidency, many liberal and secular Americans came to regard religious conservatives not merely as their political opponents, but as a kind of existential threat. The religious right, they decided, wasnt a normal political movement. Rather, it was an essentially illiberal force, bent on gradually replacing our secular republic with what Kevin Phillipss 2006 best seller dubbed an American Theocracy.

title: Republicans Against Science
description: Jon Huntsman Jr., a former Utah governor and ambassador to China, isnt a serious contender for the Republican presidential nomination. And thats too bad, because Mr. Hunstman has been willing to say the unsayable about the G.O.P.  namely, that it is becoming the anti-science party. This is an enormously important development. And it should terrify us.

title: Jeter Scratched From Second Game of Doubleheader
description: BALTIMORE  Derek Jeter was scratched from the second game of Sundays doubleheader with a contusion of his right knee.

title: Trying to Make Red Zone Sanchezs Comfort Zone
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The best red-zone quarterback Trent Dilfer said he ever played with was Matt Hasselbeck, who on a weekly basis would conquer that chaotic, compressed and critical area inside the oppositions 20 by flashing what Dilfer called the brass of a burglar and the discretion of a doctor. Hasselbeck would handle every snap believing that no defense could stop a perfect throw, Dilfer said, and if the coverage was tight, he felt no shame dumping a pass to his running back or tight end or tossing away the ball to avoid disaster.

title: Enigmatic in Power, Qaddafi Is Elusive at Large
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  It was perhaps only fitting that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi would be as unpredictable on the lam as he was in power for 42 eccentric years.

title: Heads Held High on a Team Laid Low
description: Divide this latest lost Mets season into three parts. The beginning, mercifully, was brief, a 5-13 start. Then, for more than half the season, the Mets went 50-38. That stretch took them through July 29, the day after they traded Carlos Beltran. Since then, they are 10 games under .500.

title: A Warning for Some, Entertainment for Others
description: NAGS HEAD, N.C.  Standing where he warned others not to tread, the beach on the Outer Banks during Hurricane Irenes landfall, Mike Seidel had sand in his teeth, his pockets and his ears. He was soaking wet, barely able to hear  and he was beaming.

title: For Some Medical Evacuees, Safety Brought Its Own Difficulties
description: David Clark sat in an ambulance for hours late Saturday night in front of the Park Slope Armory in Brooklyn. Mr. Clark, who is 48 and relies on a wheelchair because of diabetes and a leg injury, was late to receive his medicines. But he still had not even been admitted to the armory, which was a designated shelter for patients with special medical needs who had been displaced because of the storm.

title: U.S. Tactics in Libya May Be a Model for Other Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  It would be premature to call the war in Libya a complete success for United States interests. But the arrival of victorious rebels on the shores of Tripoli last week gave President Obamas senior advisers a chance to claim a key victory for an Obama doctrine for the Middle East that had been roundly criticized in recent months as leading from behind.

title: In Nevada, Apathy Is a Front-Runner
description: RENO, Nev.  Do not come here expecting to find optimism. Unemployment in the state is at 13 percent, and foreclosure rates remain among the highest in the country. Ask people about the future, and they speak of fear and dread. They may have come to the state with big dreams, but these days they are just trying to get by.

title: This Time, Mostly Praise for Mayor on Storm Response
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was a ubiquitous scold, appearing on camera four times in 24 hours to tell grizzled urban dwellers that, yes, they had to take the threat of dangerous weather seriously.

title: Lottery Numbers
Silicon Valley Scion Tackles Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES  Annapurna, a Hindu goddess of nourishment, has her name on a section of the Himalayas. Annapurna Pictures operates from a cluster of three multimillion-dollar homes in the Hollywood Hills.

title: School Gym Shelters Evacuees From Irene
description: They took a corner in the schools gymnasium, finding forest green city-issued cots for themselves and their four children. They unfolded their blue city-issued fleece blankets, stamped with the citys official seal, opened their paper cartons of water and settled in for the night.

title: From Coastline to Mountains, Water Fast and Lethal
description: In southern New Jersey, a 20-year-old woman called her boyfriend early Sunday to tell him that she was trapped in her car with water that was up to her neck. Then she called the police. Her body was found about eight hours later, still inside her car, which had been swept away during a flash flood on Route 40 in Salem County.

title: The Union Finally Lands a Victory
description: The North Carolina Coast, Aug. 28, 1861 As 318 seasick soldiers staggered through the booming surf near Forts Hatteras and Clark, the Unions invasion of the coastal South seemed to be literally stuck in the sandy spits of North Carolinas Outer Banks. The soldiers who made it to shore were thirsty and nearly defenseless, their ammunition spoiled by the crashing waves. Out at sea, more than 500 potential reinforcements were stranded on two troop transports, unable to brave the swells.

title: Players to Watch at This Years Open
description: Three women and three men who may make a run at this years United States Open.

title: At a Marina, Enduring the Rain, Wind and Tedium
description: COINJOCK, N.C.  When the eye finally came and the torrent turned off like a faucet and it became so quiet that a lone bullfrog could be heard, the dock here turned into something of a social club. Captains emerged from their boats, standing barefoot on the wet planks and chatting with the crew at the marina. Ice chests were restocked, and legs were stretched.

title: Playing in Pinstripes
description: Derek Jeter became the Yankees career leader in games played on Sunday.*

title: U.S. Open Set to Begin as Planned
description: The United States Open will begin as scheduled, at 11 a.m. on Monday, on a majority of the courts. The biggest change is at Arthur Ashe Stadium, where the first match will begin at 1 p.m. instead of 11 a.m.

title: Hurricane Lost Steam as Experts Misjudged Structure and Next Move
description: It began as something far off and dangerous  a monster storm, a Category 3 hurricane that packed winds of 115 miles an hour as it buzz-sawed through the Caribbean last week, causing more than a billion dollars of destruction in the Bahamas alone.

description: Sally Goodgold was the Ethel Merman of land use: bold, brassy and capable of sounding notes that could be heard over any orchestra.

title: Some Hurricane, New Yorkers Grumble as Danger Passes
description: On Saturday, when the word was that Hurricane Irene had New York City in its sights, Mike Fenton was proud of himself: I bought the last loaf of bread on the West Side.

description: The storm moved north, leaving a trail of damage, debris and flooding from North Carolina to Pennsylvania.

title: Spreading Diplomacy on Two Wheels While Weathering Traffic and Shouts

title: 5 Suggested Techniques to Aid in Identifying Suspects
description: It is no surprise that eyewitness identification  these days usually conducted with photo arrays  can be impaired by factors like stress, poor lighting and difficulty recognizing people of other races. Less known are issues having to do with how memory itself is shaped and tainted. Researchers and law enforcement officials say several techniques can increase the accuracy of identification.

title: Police Lineups Start to Face Fact: Eyes Can Lie
description: The decision by New Jerseys Supreme Court last week to overhaul the states rules for how judges and jurors treat evidence from police lineups could help transform the way officers conduct a central technique of police work, criminal justice experts say.

description: AUSTIN, Tex.  As Gov. Rick Perry of Texas begins his presidential campaign, he is working hard to position himself as the leading Republican champion of states rights, using his high-profile battles with Washington and his book on the dangers of federal power to build an ideological and constitutional rationale for his fierce anti-Obama message.

title: Dr. Charles C. Edwards, Influential F.D.A. Commissioner, Dies at 87
description: By the early 1970s, public alarm over health threats had prompted Congress to pass a barrage of laws requiring the government to ride closer herd on the multibillion-dollar food and drug industries. Dr. Charles C. Edwards, as head of the Food and Drug Administration, led the regulatory charge.

description: Libyans continued to search the Bab al-Aziziya complex and rebel fighters continued their slow push toward Surt.

title: Fishing for Salmon That Like a Crowd
description: BALLINA, Ireland  Rotating my two-handed rod and snapping it forward, I unfurled a long cast across the Ridge Pool on the River Moy, the most desirable stretch of water on Irelands most plentiful Atlantic salmon river. As my fly, a No. 12 Cascade with double hooks, swung across the current, salmon rolled in the river before me, at once beguiling and maddening. I took two steps downstream and prepared to cast again, but my concentration was broken by a series of staccato beeps from a procession of cars passing over Upper Bridge downstream.

title: After Hurricane Irene: What You Need to Know in New York
description: Most of New York Citys agencies shut down service in anticipation of Hurricane Irene. Now that the tropical storm has passed through the five boroughs, heres what you need to know.

title: A Soaked Vermont Awaits Even More Flooding
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  Much of Vermont was paralyzed Sunday by treacherous flooding in the wake of Tropical Storm Irene, with scores of state and local roads closed, homes underwater, bridges wiped out and at least one person dead after being swept into a rushing river.

title: Aug. 29, 1991 | Soviet Parliament Suspends Activities of Communist Party

Have you experienced any of these events or similar incidents? What was it like? How did you stay safe?

title: Qaddafis Wife and 3 of His Children Flee to Algeria
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Algeria said Monday that it had allowed a two-vehicle caravan of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis relatives, including his second wife and three of his children, into the country. The flight of his relatives provided powerful new evidence of surrender by the Qaddafi clan as rebels consolidated their hold on Tripoli, the capital.

title: Mustang Boss 302 TracKey Package: A Skunkworks Effort From Ford
description: ROMEO, Mich.  Sitting behind the wheel of a gently rumbling 2012 Ford Mustang Boss 302 here on the tarmac apron at Fords proving grounds, I put my foot on the brake, pushed the speed controls Set button and watched the tachometer needle sweep through its range. With Jeff Seaman, the Mustang program manager, providing instruction from the passengers seat  a brave man, he  I released the Set button, then used the plus and minus controls to set the tach to 4,200 r.p.m. When the needle returned to idle, I pressed the speed controls On button to lock in the r.p.m. setting.

title: Alan Krueger Chosen as Obamas Top Economic Adviser
description: President Obama will nominate Alan B. Krueger, a Princeton University labor economist, to be his top economic adviser, a White House official said Monday.

title: Exit Stage Left
description: Lizzie Owens knows how to dress performers. From psychedelic woodsmen to hip-hop street kids, Owens, a Utah native, has costumed an array of bands, like MGMT, the Cool Kids and Brandon Flowers from the Killers. Her third and most fully conceived collection for Highland, which she started with partners and childhood friends Cramer Tolboe (above left) and Mike Franks (right), features rugged, wearable clothes for the everyday man. Highland showcases mixed prints, unconventional details (like detachable pockets) and classic outerwear in surprising materials (like a teddy-bear car coat) that combine the theatricality of her past with what appears to be a practical future.

title: Storms Push North Leaves Punishing Inland Floods
description: CHESTER, Vt.  While most eyes warily watched the shoreline during Hurricane Irenes grinding ride up the East Coast, it was inland  sometimes hundreds of miles inland  where the most serious damage actually occurred. And the major culprit was not wind, but water.

title: Monday Reading: Rules Vary When Teens Fly Alone
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: For Suburban Commuters, Train Service Slowly Returns
description: With no commuter rail trains running to New York City from Connecticut, New Jersey and Westchester County on Monday morning, many residents of the suburbs faced a day stranded at home, tens of thousands of them without electricity. Those who ventured out encountered snaillike traffic conditions on clogged parkways and country roads blocked by fallen trees and standing water, part of the damage left by Tropical Storm Irene.

description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

description: Two ratings agencies on Monday slashed their ratings on Sino-Forest, the Chinese forestry company that Canadian securities regulators have accused of fraud.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Markets to Open as Usual, After Storm | The New York Stock Exchange and other equity markets plan to be up and running on Monday, following Hurricane Irene, The New York Times reports. Wall Street banks said they, too, would be open for business as usual, and the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association said bond markets were on schedule as well.

title: For Zvonareva, a Tropical Storm Is No Obstacle
description: Vera Zvonareva, the No. 2 seed in the womens draw at the United States Open, will be talking with Straight Sets about her experiences throughout the tournament. On Sunday, Zvonareva, who is 26 and was born in Moscow, spoke about what she does to prepare to play; she will face Stephanie Foretz Gacon on Monday at Louis Armstrong Stadium.

title: Bank of America Sells Stake in China Construction Bank
description: 6:58 p.m. | Updated

title: I Me Mine: The Beatles and Their Pronouns
description: James W. Pennebakers new book The Secret Life of Pronouns, which I reviewed in The Times Book Review on Sunday, makes it hard to stop thinking about pronouns and the other little function words that Mr. Pennebaker, a social psychologist at the University of Texas at Austin, sees as the keys to the soul. Mr. Pennebaker is admirably omnivorous when it comes to looking for material that will show how these stealthy words  which include articles, prepositions, conjunctions and auxiliary verbs  reflect our social psyche. One of his more unexpected sources is the lyrical canon of the Beatles.

title: Back on the A-List: New Absolutely Fabulous Episodes Are Coming
description: Theyre coming back, sweeties: Patsy Stone and Edina Monsoon, the foul-mouthed, fashionably wasted ladies portrayed by Joanna Lumley and Jennifer Saunders in the comedy series Absolutely Fabulous, will return to television in a series of anniversary specials, the BBC said on Monday.

title: Sex Change
description: The name is synonymous with glamorous, exotic-skinned heels (thanks to one too many Sex and the City puns), but Jimmy Choos debut collection for men is thoroughly, surprisingly, masculine. The line ranges from Alfie-worthy Chelsea boots and crocodile monk-strap shoes to modern street-wear classics like the leopard-print high-top featured here on Tamara Mellon, Choos founder. Men started going in and buying the big sizes of the womens sneakers, Mellon says. It was like an aha moment  it made sense.

title: Stuffed Vegetables for Late Summer
description: Travel anywhere in the Mediterranean region, and you will find stuffed vegetables. In Provence, they tend to be filled with meat (a way to stretch leftover stews), but in the Middle East and Greece rice and grain fillings prevail. Regional cooks make abundant use of fresh herbs like parsley, dill and mint, and sweet spices like cinnamon and allspice.

title: Welcoming Monks and Wild Horses, in North Dakota

title: A Comparison of Student Checking Accounts
description: Are you or your children heading off to college? You may want to shop around for a checking account that wont siphon hefty fees from your school budget.

title: Being and Weather
description: Two nights ago, Hurricane Irene was taking her sweet time, making her painfully slow path up the East Coast towards New York. And everyone, but everyone, was talking about the weather. New Yorkers, many of whom ordinarily exhibit a strong aversion to small talk, had given themselves carte blanche to do so until after the storm weakened and passed on to irrelevant Canada.

description: HURRICANE IRENE had long since passed, but a lot of people who were hoping to get on airplanes as airports in the Northeast reopened Monday were not going anywhere anytime soon.

description: In Washington, the Obama administration took pains to avoid comparisons with Hurricane Katrina. In the New York area, elected officials displayed radically different approaches to the storm.

title: Nations Hope Veil Lifts From Libyas History of Terrorism
description: LONDON  Television footage of the only man convicted in the Lockerbie bombing lying in bed, purportedly comatose with advanced prostate cancer at his Tripoli home, has provided a focal point for a question asked with new urgency in places far from Libya: With Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis government in ruins, what reckoning is likely for the terrorist bombings that were once a signature of the former Libyan leaders war with the Western world?

title: Venus Williams Shows Rust and Resolve
description: By the time Venus Williams took the court at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday night, one top-five womens seed, Petra Kvitova, had been catapulted from the United States Open and another, the 2006 champion Maria Sharapova, had endured a bumpy ride into the second round.

Rick Perry for his attack on global warming science:

title: Handing Over the Keys
description: Patients find end-of-road care in RVs.

title: Preseason Football Lifts NBC on Sunday
description: Although coverage of Hurricane Irene dramatically affected the early numbers for the broadcast networks, an overall ratings picture for Sunday is clear. NBC easily emerged as the victor with its presentation of a preseason football game between the New Orleans Saints and the Oakland Raiders, pulling in an estimated average of 7.3 million total viewers during the night. (The Saints won the game, 40-20.) Second place belongs to ABC, with 20/20: The Sixth Sense, up 23 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic category when compared with last week. The show averaged just under 6 million total viewers during a two-hour period.

title: Michele Bachmann Jokes About Hurricanes
description: At a rally in Sarasota, Michele Bachmann humorously said the recent natural disasters are God's way of getting politicians' attention. (Video from NBC)

title: At the End of the Road
description: Faced with the usual options for senior housing and elder care, some older adults are inventing their own grass-roots versions  do-it-yourself senior living thats friendlier, more autonomous and less expensive. Fellows in the News21 program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism are posting video reports on four of these: a shared housing arrangement in White Plains, a senior cohousing development in Virginia, an urban village in Chicago and an R.V. community in East Texas.

title: Original Model T | Kamau Patton
description: Kamau Patton designs a T for the Moment blog.

title: Courtside: Day One at the Open
description: Hurricane Irene failed to delay the start of the U.S. Open, with Roger Federer and Venus Williams set to headline the first night.

title: Courtside: Day 1 at the Open
description: Hurricane Irene failed to delay the start of the U.S. Open, with Roger Federer and Venus Williams set to headline the first night. Lynn Zinser reports.

title: New Worries in Europe Over Pace of Growth
description: BRUSSELS  Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, acknowledged on Monday that growth in the euro zone could be weaker than expected, suggesting that the central bank might be more reluctant to raise interest rates again.

title: Events in Libya: A Chronology
description: Aug. 24 Buoyed by their seizure of Col. Qaddafis compound, rebels sought to strengthen their control of Tripoli, placing a nearly $2 million bounty on the Libyan leaders head and dispatching fighters toward one of his last bastions of support, his tribal hometown of Surt.

title: Lehman Legal Problems Appear to Be Fading
description: Two settlements of investor securities fraud claims against former officers and directors of Lehman Brothers provide another sign that the federal government is unlikely to pursue criminal or civil charges stemming from the firms collapse in 2008.

title: The Tenor Jonas Kaufmann Keeps Plans Despite Surgery
description: Jonas Kaufmann, a major international tenor who has become an increasingly important presence at the Metropolitan Opera, plans to go ahead with an Oct. 30 recital at the house just two months after undergoing chest surgery, the Met said on Monday. He also remains committed to a run as the title character in a new production of Gounods Faust, which opens on Nov. 29, and to appearances in the Ring cycle in the spring, the Met said. Jonas Kaufmann has assured the Met through his management that he plans to sing all of his scheduled performances here this season, according to a company statement. Mr. Kaufmann said on his Web site that he needed to have an operation to remove a node from his chest. I do not wish anyone to become alarmed reading this, but my physicians have ordered me to have the surgery done as soon as possible, and it will take place after my appearance in Stockholm on Sept. 2, he said. He is scheduled to sing in the Jussi Bjrling gala that day at the Royal Opera. Mr. Kaufmanns Web site lists five other performances in October, starting on Oct. 10.

title: The Height Equation
description: Q. Is there an upper limit to human growth? Why does one generation grow taller than the last?

title: With HX1, Peugeot Adds a Plug-In to Its Diesel-Hybrid Program
description: Sleek and sensuous, the Peugeot HX1 concept, which is expected to have its debut at the Frankfurt auto show next month, is a six-seat, plug-in diesel hybrid that attempts to meld design elements of sedan and wagon. It follows the 508 RXH, the brands first mass-produced diesel hybrid, which is expected to go on sale in Europe next spring.

title: A Toddlers Tale of Bedbugs
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Should Parents Ban Fraternities?
description: Much of the conversation here over the past few days about gender roles on campus has included mentions of fraternities and sororities. It is not coincidence, many of you said, that all the incidents I described in my Sunday Styles article, about why young women have moved past stereotypes in the classroom but not in relationships, involved Greek life.

title: The New Yorker and Francis Schaeffer
description: My column today endorses asking politicians serious questions about their religious beliefs, but also warns against several problems that I think are endemic to media coverage of conservative Christians. Ryan Lizza, the author of a recent New Yorker piece on Michele Bachmanns intellectual formation, tweets in response:

title: Fresh and Direct From the Garden an Ocean Away
description: Charles C. Mann has faced up to the locavores dilemma. At his home in the Berkshires, he likes to eat food that has traveled directly from his own garden: heirloom tomatoes, eggplant, bell peppers, kale, chard, lettuce and other foods for his table. He and his family belong to a farm-share program in which they advance money each year to a farmer a few miles away in return for the farms crops. He loves local food, but he knows too much about it to be a truly devout locavore.

title: Fish Dominates in Opening Round
description: Shrugging off nerves in the opening minutes, Mardy Fish of the United States cruised to victory over Tobias Kamke of Germany, 6-2, 6-2, 6-1, on Monday to move into the second round of the 2011 United States Open.

title: Arizonas New Post-Partisan: Charles Barkleyism
description: Some people show their discontent with the two main political parties by registering as independents. But in Arizona, disgruntled voters go further than that.

title: Critics' Picks: 'In a Lonely Place'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Nicholas Ray's 1950 film.

title: Teaching 9/11 | Why? How?
description: Both the start of the new school year and the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, are upon us. Many teachers address 9/11 as part of United States history, while others want to commemorate the anniversary with their students. And there are teachers out there who are hesitating, wondering how to teach about 9/11 in an appropriate and meaningful way, or whether to mention it at all.

title: Bronx Boater, 68, Is Citys First Irene-Related Death
description: The authorities linked the drowning of a man in the waters off City Island to Tropical Storm Irene, in what they are describing as the first Irene-related death discovered in New York City.

title: U.A.W. Urges Automakers to Raise Entry-Level Pay in New Labor Deal
description: DETROIT  Contract talks between the United Automobile Workers and the Detroit carmakers are entering a more intense phase, with the union pressing for wage increases for entry-level workers as a critical part of a new national labor agreement.

title: Really? The Claim: Sea Salt Is Lower in Sodium Than Table Salt
description: THE FACTS

title: Smart Choices to Ensure Safety at Lunch
description: If you, like me, distrust school cafeterias, you pack homemade lunches for your children, as I did until my sons finished high school. But in the rush to get youngsters up, dressed, fed and off to school on time, the safety of that packed lunch easily can be overlooked.

title: TimesCast | August 29, 2011
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's wife and three of his children have fled to Algeria; inside the homes the Qaddafis left behind; and in Vermont, flooding damages roads and iconic covered bridges.

title: It Was a Dark and Sort of Stormy Night
description: Friday was too balmy to trust. We brought all our plants inside and made cardboard blockades so my 9-month-old son Zev couldnt munch all the dirt. Bought some batteries and candles. A special treat for my 2-year-old, Sonya. Our snack drawer was full and wed just splurged for our first month of HBO. Our Brooklyn apartment is in a converted Catholic school nowhere near water and were on the first floor in a courtyard so quiet we often wake to wind chimes.

title: In an Upset, Kvitova Loses to Dulgheru
description: No. 5 seed Petra Kvitova was upset in the first round of the 2011 U.S. Open, falling to 49th-ranked Romanian Alexandra Dulgheru 7-6(3), 6-3.

title: Introducing Fech
description: Ten years ago, the Federal Election Commission introduced electronic filing for political committees that raise and spend money to influence elections to the House and the White House. The filings contain aggregate information about a committees work (what it has spent, what it owes) and more detailed listings of its interactions with the public (who has donated to it, who it has paid for services).

title: A Peaceful Penthouse That Turmoil Calls Home
description: The western penthouse at 37 Riverside Drive soars above the park and the Hudson River, offering sweeping sunset views across the Palisades and past the George Washington Bridge, conjuring a feeling of country in the city and respite from the hubbub of Manhattan far below.

title: Shocking Trout to Protect Them
description: Pennsylvania fishery biologists are wrapping up the second year of a major effort to explore wild trout streams they have never before assessed, in areas increasingly vulnerable to impacts from development.

title: At the VMAs
description: The 2011 MTV Video Music Awards were held at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on Sunday night.

title: Slain Boys Father Sues Accused Killer and His Father
description: The father of Leiby Kletzky, the 8-year-old boy who in July was kidnapped in Borough Park, Brooklyn, and then murdered and dismembered, is suing both the accused killer and his father, court documents in Brooklyn State Supreme Court show.

title: Congress Returns for Another Round on Jobs, Spending
description: So, when we last met on the Hill, Republicans were focused on undoing a slew of federal regulations, many of them created by the Obama administration, as the foundation of their job creation strategy, while the White House was pushing for the extension of a payroll tax cut and tax credits for employers. The two sides were also fighting over how best to reduce the deficit.

title: Packing a Safe School Lunch
description: The start of the school year always brings a fresh round of worries for parents of schoolchildren. This week the Personal Health columnist Jane Brody takes a look at the hazards of home-packed meals, which are often consumed after spending hours unrefrigerated.

title: New York Cabbies Receive Low Marks for Friendliness
description: Londons black cabs have been voted the best in the world for the fourth year in a row, despite being the most expensive, according to the annual taxi report by Hotels.com, the online booking site.

title: Now Playing | Portamento, the New Album by the Drums
description: Less than two years ago, the Drums, a Brooklyn-based indie rock band, appeared out of nowhere to quickly become critical darlings and fan favorites on both sides of the Atlantic. No one called them extraordinary or groundbreaking, but that was the point. They were upfront about wanting nothing more than to get on stage and be themselves.

title: Hunting for a Mass Killer in Medieval Graveyards
description: Beneath the Royal Mint Court, diagonally across the street from the Tower of London, lie 1,800 mute witnesses to the foresight of the city fathers in the year 1348. Recognizing that the Black Death then scourging Europe would inevitably reach London, the authorities prepared a special cemetery in East Smithfield, outside the city walls, to receive the bodies of the stricken.

title: As Storm Exits, Paths Lead to Open
description: After all the bluster of the storm, it was wonderful to see a great orange glow lighting up the United States Open, right on schedule.

title: The New Generation of Microbe Hunters
description: It was Tuesday evening, June 7. A frightening outbreak of food-borne bacteria was killing dozens of people in Germany and sickening hundreds. And the five doctors having dinner at Da Marco Cucina e Vino, a restaurant in Houston, could not stop talking about it.

title: The Appraisal: Is Co-op Living Worth the Hassle?
description: This weeks Appraisal describes a fight between the owners of a Riverside Drive penthouse and their co-op board over extensive renovation plans. The fight is now the subject of a lawsuit against the board that is working its way through State Supreme Court, which could have repercussions for frustrated co-op owners throughout the city.

title: Critics Picks Video: In a Lonely Place
description: Anger, fear and sadness dominate the emotional landscape of Nicholas Rays 1950 film noir In a Lonely Place. The film stars Humphrey Bogart as Dixon Steele, a screenwriter who is accused of murdering a hat-check girl. Gloria Grahame also stars as Laurel Gray, the actress who provides Dixon an alibi, and with whom he quickly begins a romance.

title: Intensity of Hurricanes Still Bedevils Scientists
description: The past week was a busy one for Frank Marks, the director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrations hurricane research division in Miami. There were scientists to supervise, V.I.P.s to greet  and on Friday and Saturday mornings he had to fly into the heart of Irene.

title: CoreLogic Hires Greenhill to Explore a Potential Sale
description: CoreLogic, a data analytics company, said on Monday that it had hired Greenhill & Company to consider a potential sale or other strategic alternatives.

description: August 29, 2011 - Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi's wife and three of his children have fled to Algeria, according to Algeria's government.

description: Images from the opening day of the United States Open in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: At 35,000 Feet, a Russian Image Problem
description: MOSCOW  Airlines are a cautious lot, slow to trust a new airplane maker with multibillion-dollar orders and passenger lives. It took Embraer, a Brazilian maker of regional jets, two decades to become a major supplier to the industry.

title: As Expected, Hurricane Fallout Puts a Damper on Broadway Box Office
description: Broadway musicals and plays grossed only $11.6 million last week, a sharp drop from overall tickets sales of $20.1 million during the previous week  the result of New York Citys shutdown over Hurricane Irene, which led to the cancellation of typically profitable performances on Saturday and Sunday. Nearly 131,000 people saw Broadway shows before theaters went dark for the storm, compared to about 218,000 the week before.

title: Long Road Back for Greek Banks
Even in Defeat, Yani Hears the Cheers
description: American Michael Yani, who lost his first-round match to Bernard Tomic of Australia Monday, was signing autographs after the defeat when a young boy told him he was his favorite player.

description: Astronauts will abandon the International Space Station, probably in mid-November, if rocket engine problems that doomed a Russian cargo ship last week are not diagnosed and fixed.

title: Ideals Are Easy; Living Up to Them Isnt
description: STRATFORD, Ontario  Heroism is not a career to be undertaken lightly, as the two musical revivals at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival here this season make clear. King Arthur, the legendary English leader of knights and founder of the Round Table, finds the task of shaping a chivalric code to be easier than living up to its ideals in the 1960 musical Camelot. And his burden is a mere feather compared to that of Jesus himself, the martyred founder of a worldwide faith in Jesus Christ Superstar, first staged on Broadway in 1971.

title: A Writer Deals With Success as Not the End of the World
description: BELMONT, Mass.  The Rapture came at a good time for Tom Perrotta.

title: Testing Water Along the Path of Irene
description: Beyond flooding and destruction, Hurricane Irene is likely to have caused less visible environmental damage by dumping sewage, pesticides and other contaminants into waterways along the East Coast, federal officials said.

title: In Southampton, Irene Blew In the First Hints of Fall
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.  It was fall on Monday in this seaside resort village, temperature in the 70s, not a drop of humidity, the wind virtually silent. Ideal conditions to rake the leaves.

title: Doctors With Plenty of Time for Patients
description: Standard outpatient medical care affronts all logical time management. You wait for an appointment, you wait to be seen, and then comes the hectic series of milliseconds that constitutes the medical encounter itself. Before you remember half your agenda, you are firmly ushered on your way, down the exit chute to start the process all over again.

title: Sharapova Struggles but Prevails
description: Troubled by a faltering focus that produced 58 unforced errors, Maria Sharapova of Russia nearly squandered a 4-1 lead in the final set but moved into the second round of the U.S. Open Monday with a 3-6, 7-5, 6-3 victory over unseeded Heather Watson of Great Britain.

title: TimesCast | Vermont Flooding
description: August 29, 2011 - In Vermont, flood waters have largely receded, but roads are damaged and some of the state's iconic covered bridges have washed away.

title: Zvonareva Sweeps Through the First Round
description: While other top seeds on the womens side struggled, No. 2 Vera Zvonareva swept through her first match at the 2011 U.S. Open, winning the final eight games of the match to cruise to a 6-3, 6-0 win over French qualifier Stephanie Foretz Gacon. The win improves Zvonarevas career record in the first round of the tournament to 9-0.

description: Coriander (cilantro, when the leaves of the plant are used fresh) is a popular spice widely used in Asian, Latin American and Mediterranean cooking.

title: Eustace Tilley vs. Waxy Derek Jeter
description: We liked Kevin OCallahans  design of a Derek Jeter birthday candle for our cover story so much, we made a softball jersey out of it. Tomorrow we play our annual game against The New Yorker in Central Park, provided Irene hasnt rendered the field unplayable. Its our only game of the year, so its kind of a big deal. At least for some of us. What we lack in batting and fielding skills, we will make up for in sartorial flair. And beer consumption.

description: Thats the thing about ideas: Theyre so cheap that anyone can have them. Theyre ubiquitous sparks. Theyre democratic.

description: The tenor Salvatore Licitra, who made a splash with a last-minute substitution for Luciano Pavarotti at the Metropolitan Opera in 2002, was severely injured in a motor-scooter accident in Sicily on Saturday night and was in serious condition with severe head injuries, according to news reports and his Web site.
