title: Poets Visions of America From the Inside and Out
description: American writers eventually come face to face with the barnacle-encrusted myths that we use to invent ourselves: Manifest Destiny, the Greatest Generation  and lets not forget Honest Abe and plucky little Betsy Ross stitching together the first Stars and Stripes. Each poet in these collections wrestles with our American myths: Kathleen Ossip waves her red-white-and-blue cape at the mad bull of the cold war; in a country that prefers truth in black and white, Jane Hirshfield drapes herself in grays; Tracy K. Smith vanishes into outer space as last frontier; Dilruba Ahmed ponders her roots in Ohio and Bangladesh; and William Carlos Williams is himself myth incarnate.

title: Cholera: Climate Change Isnt a Culprit in Increasing Outbreaks, Study Finds
description: Cholera outbreaks seem to be on the increase, but a new study has found they cannot be explained by global warming.

title: Bachmann Takes Her Tea Party to Florida
description: MIAMI  In her nearly five years in Congress, and just over two months as a declared presidential candidate, Representative Michele Bachmann has demonstrated time and again that she knows how to fire up the base. Her four-day, six-city swing through Florida has been no exception, as Mrs. Bachman, a Minnesota Republican, addressed stalwart Republican groups of retirees, Cuban-Americans and Tea Party members, who repeatedly answered her speeches with lusty cheers.

title: Risks: Infections Follow Rise in Cardiac Implants
description: The number of implantable cardiac devices in use has doubled since 1993, and the number of infections associated with them has more than tripled, a new study has found.

title: Trailer: 'One Day on Earth'
description: Two fledgling filmmakers have involved more than 7,000 people in documenting one day all over the world.

title: Prevention: Evidence of Heart Benefits From Chocolate
description: An analysis of studies including more than 100,000 subjects has found that high levels of chocolate consumption are associated with a significant reduction in the risk of certain cardiovascular disorders.

title: Nutrition: Breast-Feeding Does Not Prevent Eczema
description: Prolonged breast-feeding is widely believed to protect infants against developing eczema and other allergic diseases. But a new study has found no evidence for the belief.

title: Tallying the Benefits of Chocolate
description: Chocaholics may have more reason to indulge in a chocolate truffle or two today. New research from scientists at the University of Cambridge suggests that the heart-healthy benefits chalked up to regularly indulging in chocolate treats may not be all hype. The research involved more than 100,000 subjects and included data from a half dozen studies.

title: Hurricane News, Mostly Uninterrupted by Ads
description: THE effects of Irene  as hurricane, tropical storm or wet and wild troublemaker  had marketers, agencies, media companies and retailers scrambling all weekend and into the new workweek.

title: No Evidence That Breast-Feeding Prevents Eczema
description: Many parents who breast-feed believe it can boost a childs immunity, protecting against a number of allergies. But that widely held belief has not always been borne out in studies. Now, researchers in Britain have found that breast-feeding may not protect infants against developing eczema and other allergic diseases.

title: Sybil Jason, Cherubic Child Actress, Dies at 83
description: Sybil Jason, a cherubic child actress signed by Warner Brothers to compete with Shirley Temple in the 1930s, died on Aug. 23 at her home in Northridge, Calif. She was 83.

title: Against Craybas,  Madison Keys Plays Like a Veteran
description: Sixteen-year-old Madison Keys, playing in her first main draw at Flushing Meadows, defeated tour veteran Jill Craybas in straight sets, 6-2, 6-4. Keys raced to a 4-1 lead in the second set, hurting Craybas by playing with a near perfect blend of patience and aggression.

title: After Panhandler Says Police Harassed Her, a Judge Tells Them to Stop
description: On Fifth Avenue, somewhere between the University Club and Tiffany, Sojourner Hardeman sat before an empty storefront recently, displaying a cardboard sign that detailed her abilities as a typist and her familiarity with computer software.

title: Harrison Cant Control His Serve, or His Temper
description: American hopeful Ryan Harrison, who upset No. 15 seed Ivan Ljubicic in the first round of the 2010 tournament, was unable to repeat the effort Monday on Louis Armstrong Stadium, falling in straight sets to Marin Cilic despite having opportunities to serve for both the second and third sets. Cilic, the No. 27 seed, won 6-2, 7-5, 7-6(6).

title: For the Mets, a Long Days Journey Ends Promisingly
description: The Mets hosted the Florida Marlins on Monday for a twi-night doubleheader that essentially functioned as a showcase of inconsequential baseball. Still, although the games may have been an afterthought, the Mets managed to have a promising evening.

title: Storms Worst Deluge Swamped the Mountains in the Northeast
description: In the end, the storm made more waves in the mountains than it did along the shore.

title: Yankees Will Head to Boston Short-Handed
description: BALTIMORE  It will be a short-handed Yankees club that begins a three-game series with the Boston Red Sox on Tuesday night at Fenway Park.

title: Statistics, Beloved by Mayor, Show a Slump in City Services
description: In God we trust, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is fond of saying, before invariably adding a caveat: Everyone else, bring data.

description: To the Editor:

title: At Open, Petzschner Is a Marathoner Again
description: With every minute that went by in his first-round match Monday at the United States Open  and those were a lot of minutes, 264 of them, to be exact  Germanys Philipp Petzschner tried to evaluate the body language of his opponent, Albert Ramos of Spain.

title: Holden Set for Return
description: The American midfielder Stuart Holden, who has missed six months because of a knee injury, is set to play for the first time since last season, suiting up Tuesday for Boltons reserves in a game against Fulhams reserves. Michael Bradley, another American midfielder, is expected to sign with Chievo of Italy.

title: The Keystone XL Pipeline

title: Madden NFL 12 Adds Depth to the Franchise
description: The very best video games are those that permit gamers to dwell inside a world in which they would never otherwise be allowed. In particular, sports games give those of us born without superhuman speed or strength the chance to dominate when we would normally be asked to pay a stunning sum just for the privilege of sitting up close.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: Steffi Graf
description: Lynn Zinser explains what made Graf a great U.S. Open champion and why she would defeat Venus Williams in a hypothetical Open match.

title: Australian Arrives With a Game Thats Growing
description: Bernard Tomic, the youngest player in the mens singles field at the 2011 United States Open, is fairly certain he has stopped growing.

title: Hes Not an Immortal Time-Traveler, but He Plays One on TV
description: IM a bad flier. But the aircraft itself is fascinating to me and I have actually read a lot about planes. But as far as being a passenger, Im never totally relaxed.

title: Alabama: Judge Delays Tough Immigration Law
description: A federal judge in Birmingham has temporarily halted a tough state immigration law from taking effect on Sept. 1, saying she needed more time to consider challenges to it. The judge, Sharon L. Blackburn, ordered a stay until Sept. 29,saying she would rule by then on a longer suspension that opponents of the law are seeking. Alabamas law to crack down on illegal immigrants has been described by supporters and opponents alike as the toughest in the nation. Among others, the Obama administration and four Alabama bishops have brought lawsuits to stop it.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: Venus Williams
description: William C. Rhoden explains why Venus Williams is a great Open champion and how she could defeat Steffi Graf in a hypothetical Open match.

title: For Egypt, a Symbol of Boldness Is Disputed
description: CAIRO  As a modern Egyptian legend, it lasted just under a week.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,733 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Plenty of Good Seats Unavailable
description: The run began on May 15, 2003, when Pedro Martinez beat the Texas Rangers, 12-3. It continues this week as the Yankees visit Boston for a three-game series that begins Tuesday. And appropriately, Fenway Parks sellout streak is scheduled to hit 700 games on Friday night when the Rangers will again be Bostons opponent.

title: The Annals of Extreme Surgery
description: THE heat is on again in the world of cancer treatment, both literally and figuratively.

title: A Stigma Lifts for Luxury Hotels
description: Two years ago, corporations clamped down on employee travel and canceled meetings in droves. The chilling effect was most pronounced at luxury hotels, which were eschewed entirely by many companies in the wake of the disclosures about a lavish retreat held by the American International Group right after it accepted a government bailout.

title: Knicks, as Part of Effort to Boost Defense, Add Ex-Hawks Coach as Assistant
description: When the Knicks set out to hire another assistant, preferably one with a head for defense, Coach Mike DAntoni concentrated on one name: Lawrence Frank. With local ties, a solid reputation and success with the Nets, Frank had the right profile.

title: New Mexico Governor Rushes to Undo the Agenda of Her Predecessor
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  When Gov. Susana Martinez of New Mexico handed over the keys of a state-owned jet to a wealthy businessman and his wife for $2.5 million last week, she was eliminating one more remnant of her predecessor, Bill Richardson.

title: Unlike Banks, This Wall St. Group Embraces Dodd-Frank
description: While the United States military has Defcon, the tiered alert system used during times of national crisis, Wall Street has fashioned a critical event of its own, Sefcon.

title: WikiLeaks Leaves Names of Diplomatic Sources in Cables
description: WASHINGTON  In a shift of tactics that has alarmed American officials, the antisecrecy organization WikiLeaks has published on the Web nearly 134,000 leaked diplomatic cables in recent days, more than six times the total disclosed publicly since the posting of the leaked State Department documents began last November.

title: Five Years of Successes and Strife
description: In Oakland, Terrelle Pryor prepares to begin a five-game suspension for violating N.C.A.A. rules. In Tampa and Nashville, Aqib Talib and Kenny Britt just learned that they will not join Pryor on the sideline for violating the N.F.L.s personal conduct policy during the lockout. And in New York on Thursday, a week before the league kicks off a wildly anticipated season, Commissioner Roger Goodell will mark his fifth anniversary in the job.

title: Manufacturing a Recovery
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: The First Emancipation Proclamation
description: On Aug. 30, 1861, Maj. Gen. John C. Frmont, commander of the Union Western Department in St. Louis, issued a proclamation of martial law. All persons who shall be taken with arms in their hands, he announced, shall be tried by court-martial, and if found guilty will be shot. This was harsh, but perhaps to be expected in the strife-torn region. But Frmont went further. The property, real and personal, of all persons in the State of Missouri, who shall take up arms against the United States, or who shall be directly proven to have taken an active part with their enemies in the field, is declared to be confiscated to their public use, and their slaves, if any they have, are hereby declared freemen.

title: Smart Collar in the Works to Manage Wildlife Better
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  The collar of the wild is coming.

title: Open Rookie Has Queens Roots
description: Anna Tatishvili was a 7-year-old from Tbilisi, Georgia, when she visited her aunt in New York with her father in 1997. They went to Juniper Valley Park in Middle Village, Queens, so she could hit some tennis balls, the way she had done since she was 4 and her sister had given her a racket.

title: Labor Boards Exiting Leader Responds to Critics
description: WASHINGTON  Rarely has a federal agency been attacked with as much vitriol as the National Labor Relations Board now faces.

title: Increasing Drug Violence in Brazil
description: The number of murders in Bahia state grew 430 percent to 4,709 between 1999 and 2008.

title: Defense Tack in Family Killings Promises More Harrowing Jolts
description: For weeks last fall, until Steven J. Hayes was sentenced to death, Connecticut was riveted by testimony describing the nightmarish fate of the Petit family in Cheshire. The mother was strangled in 2007 after an ordeal that began when two men burst into the home, and her two girls, 11 and 17, died after being tied to their beds and the house was set ablaze.

title: The Mystery of Steve Jobss Public Giving
description: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg NewsSteve Jobs, a founder of Apple, has focused on his work to improve the lives of millions of people through technology.

title: 2 in Florida Are Charged In $22 Million Ponzi Scheme
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued two Florida men, claiming that they had defrauded teachers and retirees in a $22 million Ponzi scheme by posing as a private equity fund while enriching themselves.

title: As Prosperity Rises in Brazils Northeast, So Does Drug Violence
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  Jenilson Dos Santos Conceio, 20, lay face down on the rough concrete, his body twisted, sandals still on his feet, as the blood from his 14 bullet wounds stained the sloped alleyway.

title: Edgar M. Cullman Sr., Who Helped Turn Cigars Into Objects of Desire, Is Dead at 93
description: Edgar M. Cullman Sr., a cigar maker who worked to broaden the appeal of his product in the late 20th century, helping transform its public image from an unwieldy mobsters appendage to a cool and slim object of desire, died on Sunday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 93.

title: I.R.S. Loses Tax Case Against Lay of Enron
description: The United States Tax Court rejected a bid by the Internal Revenue Service to collect $3.9 million from the estate of the former Enron chief Kenneth L. Lay and his wife.

title: Casinos Find Latin Niche
description: Primm Valley Casino Resorts is betting that aggressively courting Latinos in Southern California will help lead them to success.

title: Casino Town Puts Its Money on Hispanic Market
description: PRIMM, Nev.  For decades, a patch of casinos on the western edge of Nevada has relied on geography to lure California gamblers reluctant to drive the extra 45 miles for the glamour and glitz of Las Vegas.

title: The Haimish Line
description: Recently I did a little reporting from Kenya and Tanzania before taking a safari with my family. We stayed in seven camps. Some were relatively simple, without electricity or running water. Some were relatively luxurious, with regular showers and even pools.

title: Falser Words Were Never Spoken
description: Bronxville, N.Y.

title: In Catskill Communities, Survivors Are Left With Little but Their Lives
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y.  It chewed up Moores Trailer Park, sweeping up homes and discarding them in devastating piles of wood, plastic, orphaned automobile wheels and broken childrens toys. It tore apart painstakingly maintained Victorians, their pastel-colored and gingerbread-style exteriors cracked and caved-in, their front lawns, porches and sidewalks replaced by muddy lagoons.

title: A Cheering Section, and a Support Team
description: Novak Djokovic scanned his guest box at the 2010 United States Open and was struck by the same feeling many couples experience when they glance at their wedding guest list. He wondered who some of the people were and why they were sharing his stage.

title: NATOs Teachable Moment
description: The hunt for Muammar el-Qaddafi goes on, but his tyrannical 42-year rule over Libya is finished. The Libyan people bore the brunt of the fighting and dying that brought him down. But NATO air power played an important role. Airstrikes in March stopped Colonel Qaddafis forces from storming Benghazi and slaughtering its inhabitants. Continued pounding degraded the regimes firepower, giving the rebels time to organize and train. NATOs refusal to back away  and its decision to bring the fight to the skies over Tripoli  helped push Qaddafi cronies to switch sides.

title: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Steffi Graf vs. Venus Williams
description: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? Its up to you to decide, with a little help from The Timess tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section.

title: China Takes Aim at Rural Influx
description: BEIJING  Xie Zhenqing spent 12 years transforming a collection of ramshackle houses into Red Star, a privately run, low-cost school for 1,400 children of migrants from poor rural areas. It took just a few hours this month for a government-dispatched demolition crew to turn the place into a jagged pile of bricks.

title: Tuesday: Aint She Sweet?
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Ladies and gentlemen, you are witnessing history.

title: Targeting Women
description: A lawsuit filed in Kansas this month has opened a new front in the legal war over womens reproductive rights. Since last year, 13 states, including Kansas, have enacted laws banning insurance coverage of abortion in the health insurance exchanges created by the federal health care reform law. Some states have gone even further, aggressively restricting abortion coverage even in private insurance plans sold outside the exchanges.

title: At the Open, Two Players from Ireland Make History
description: When Novak Djokovic steps onto the court for his first round match at this years Open, itll be his New York debut as world number one, but it will be the unfamiliar player on the other side of the net who will be making history. That man is Conor Niland, a 29-year-old Irishman, who, together with countryman Louk Sorensen, will be the first Irish players ever to compete in the main draw of the U.S. Open.

title: A Couples Big Break Thats Not So Lucky
description: Whats the No. 1 thing couples fight about? Money. And a hard-luck pair is doing so with bedraggled elegance in Temporal Powers, another fine revival of a Teresa Deevy play by the Mint Theater Company.

title: The Cost of Business Lost and Property Damaged
description: A day after Tropical Storm Irene blew through, New York City wrung itself out on Monday under a blue sky and started getting back to business.

title: White House Issues Guides on Sept. 11 Observances
description: WASHINGTON  The White House has issued detailed guidelines to government officials on how to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, with instructions to honor the memory of those who died on American soil but also to recall that Al Qaeda and other extremist groups have since carried out attacks elsewhere in the world, from Mumbai to Manila.

title: Pulling Out of a Debate, Over a Storm Long Gone
description: The politicians had carefully prepared. The organizers had booked the room. The audience was lined up.

title: Down and Out at the Post Office
description: Neither rain nor snow may stop the United States Postal Service, but will the abysmally divided Congress? The service is reeling toward default and urgently needs the Capitols help to modernize and pay its bills.

title: David Honeyboy Edwards, Delta Bluesman, Dies at 96
description: David Honeyboy Edwards, believed to have been the oldest surviving member of the first generation of Delta blues singers, died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 96.

title: End the Slush
description: All members of the New York City Council have long enjoyed a slush fund, an annual allowance that is supposed to go to a soup kitchen or senior center or other nonprofit social program in the district. The amount of money for each district seldom depends on need; it comes courtesy of the Council speaker, who holds the purse.

title: Lottery Numbers
Subsidiary of News Corp. Loses Deal With State
description: The New York State comptrollers office has rejected a $27 million contract with a News Corporation subsidiary to build a data system for tracking student performance, as fallout widens against the international media conglomerate due to a phone hacking scandal in Britain.

title: Uneven Night for Quarterbacks and Their Teams
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  At various points during the past month, Eli Manning and Mark Sanchez have drawn attention for things they have said. First, Sanchez revealed (in a GQ interview) that he once wanted to fight Coach Rex Ryan last season, then Manning opined (in a radio interview) that he believed he was one of the five best quarterbacks in the N.F.L.

title: Arsenals Embarrassment Leads to Free Ticket Offer
description: Arsenal Manager Arsne Wenger began Sundays late-afternoon disaster in Manchester wearing his familiar full-length down parka. By the end of the game, the coat was gone as Manchester United turned Old Trafford, often called the Theater of Dreams, into Wengers unabashed house of horrors.

title: Venus Williams Returns With a Victory
description: Stepping back into tournament competition after an extended absence since the Wimbledon Championships in June, Venus Williams of the United States powered her way to victory over Vesna Dolonts of Russia, 6-4, 6-3, to gain the second round of the U.S. Open at Flushing Meadow on Monday night.

title: Bloggingheads: Libya's Non-Lessons
description: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com debate whether there are lessons to be learned from Libya.

title: ABC Unveils Dancing With the Stars Cast
description: The prosecutor-turned-cable-TV-shouter Nancy Grace was the most noteworthy of the 12 contestants announced Monday for the 13th season of ABCs Dancing With the Stars.

title: From a Few Iraqis, a Word to Libyans on Liberation
description: BAGHDAD  The men sat around a small plastic table at an outdoor cafe here on Friday evening, playing chess, smoking cigarettes and reminiscing about when Saddam Husseins regime fell and they felt free for the first time in their lives.

title: Yankees Salvage a Split but Lose Some Strength
description: BALTIMORE  A long, wet and almost costly weekend came to a satisfactory conclusion for the Yankees, who beat the Baltimore Orioles, 3-2, Monday night behind a masterly performance by Freddy Garcia, then headed to Boston for a three-game series against the division-leading Red Sox.

title: Corrections: August 30
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Nuclear Panel Expanding Team to Check for Quake Damage
description: WASHINGTON  The earthquake last Tuesday in Virginia may have produced stronger shaking at the North Anna nuclear plant than the reactors were designed to withstand, and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has sent additional inspectors to determine what steps are needed to determine if there is damage. No significant damage has been identified so far.

title: Texas A&M Closer to Withdrawing From Big 12
description: Texas A&Ms departure from the Big 12 Conference drew closer to reality on Monday when the universitys president, R. Bowen Loftin, called the Big 12 board chairman, the Missouri chancellor Brady Deaton, notifying the league that the Aggies would formally withdraw  very likely on Tuesday  according to two college officials with direct knowledge of the decision.

title: Qaddafi Gave Us Dignity, a Captured Loyalist Says
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Faraj Mohamed cast his eyes across the hospital room with the furtive anxiety Tripoli residents used to display when they spoke ill of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Al Qaeda Affiliates Growing Independent
description: WASHINGTON  At some point in coming days, a shadowy group of Al Qaeda operatives in Pakistan who make up the networks General Command is likely to announce a replacement for Atiyah abd al-Rahman, the Libyan chief of operations who was killed last week in a drone strike launched by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: McHale Gets Off to a Rousing Start
description: Christina McHales hardcourt season has included an upset of the womens world No. 1, Caroline Wozniacki. But without a victory Monday night in her opening match at the United States Open, all the good vibrations of the summer would have evaporated in the night air.

title: Germany's Non-Nuclear Future
description: The Times's Elisabeth Rosenthal looks at how Germany has transitioned away from nuclear power in the wake of the Fukushima accident.

title: Germany Dims Nuclear Plants, but Hopes to Keep Lights On
description: BIBLIS, Germany  Not since the grim period after World War II has Germany had significant blackouts, but it is now bracing for that possibility after shutting down half its nuclear reactors practically overnight.

title: Monfils Mixes in Some Drama
description: While thrilling, watching Gael Monfils can be a decidedly exhausting experience.

title: U.S. Open Fantasy Tournamet
description: Naila-Jean Meyers on why Pete Sampras was a great Open champion and how he would defeat Ivan Lendl on the hardcourts of the Open.

title: Word of the Day | consequential
description: consequential \kn(t)-s-kwen(t)-shl\ adjective

title: Stetson Kennedy, Who Infiltrated and Exposed the Klan, Dies at 94
description: Stetson Kennedy, a folklorist and social crusader who infiltrated the Ku Klux Klan in the 1940s and wrote a lurid expos of its activities, I Rode With the Ku Klux Klan, died on Saturday in St. Augustine, Fla. He was 94.

title: New Road Signs Will Now Wait
description: It is a sign of the times: The Obama administration is planning to yield to strapped states and local governments who urged them to slow or be prepared to stop federal safety requirements that they replace thousands of road signs with bigger, brighter, more legible signs by 2018, arguing it would be the wrong way to make them to spend their limited money.

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/30/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/30/2011

title: Flooding in Irenes Wake
description: Up and down the East Coast, Irenes impact was felt in rising waters and submerged homes.

title: Vietnam: Warning on Bird Flu
description: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations on Monday warned of a possible major resurgence of the H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus in the coming months. The virus had been fading since 2006, but migratory birds now seem to be carrying it to infect poultry in more countries, while a variant of the virus has emerged in Vietnam and China that is not easily stopped by vaccines, the F.A.O. said. The resurgence of the virus poses unpredictable risks to human health, the agency said.

title: Iraq: Turks Report Kurdish Deaths
description: The Turkish military said Monday that it had killed more than 150 Kurdish separatists this month with artillery fire and airstrikes in northern Iraq that were carried out in retaliation for increased cross-border violence. The rebels, who are fighting for autonomy in southeast Turkey, often operate out of bases in northern Iraq, where the Iraqi Kurds have achieved a level of autonomy of their own. The rebels  from the P.K.K., or Kurdistan Workers Party  have refused to stop fighting unless demands like the release of a jailed leader and public education in the Kurdish language are met by the Turkish government.

title: Russia: Space Mission Delayed
description: Russias space agency has delayed the launching of the next rocket and crew to the International Space Station until October or November. The delay will give engineers more time to study why an unmanned Russian rocket of the same type tumbled into a Siberian forest after launching last week. A representative of a small, indigenous tribe that lives in the region where the spaceship fell said she intended to sue the Russian space agency for spilling fuel in the forest, though officials said most of what was in the cargo spaceships tanks probably burned up on the way down.

title: Federer Defeats Giraldo in Straight Sets
description: Roger Federer beat Santiago Giraldo in straight sets, in a briskly played match that looked more like a relaxed practice match than an opening round of a Grand Slam.

title: Ecuador: Journalist Flees to U.S.
description: Emilio Palacio, a senior journalist at the newspaper El Universo, has disclosed that he has fled to the United States after he and three of the newspapers board members were sentenced to three years in prison in a dispute over coverage of President Rafael Correa. A judge also ordered the four men to pay Mr. Correa $30 million in damages and imposed a $10 million fine on El Universo over a column questioning Mr. Correas handling of a police uprising last year. Mr. Palacio, El Universos op-ed editor, and the board members were appealing the ruling. One would have to be blind not to understand that they want me behind bars, Mr. Palacio, who is in Miami, wrote in a public letter.

title: Close Calls and Controversy at the Track and Field World Championships
description: A disqualification in the mens hurdles led to an appeal, and a mere two inches separated the first and second place hammer toss.

title: Photo Replay: U.S. Open Day 1
description: The first day of match play at the U.S. Open saw former U.S. Open champions advance and the reigning Wimbledon champion fall.

title: Gunman Shoots 3 People, Including 2 Children, in the Bronx
description: A gunman fired wildly into a small group of people in the Bronx on Monday evening, wounding three people, including two small children, witnesses and officials said.

title: Battle for Libya | August 29, 2011
description: Residents returned to assess damage in Tripoli.

title: Japanese Parliament Backs Noda as Prime Minister
description: TOKYO  Yoshihiko Noda, a down-to-earth fiscal conservative, was elected prime minister by the Japanese Parliament on Tuesday in the sixth change of leaders in five years, a period of mounting economic and social challenges to the worlds third-largest economy.

title: News Quiz | Aug. 30, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Aug. 30, 1963 | Communications Hot Line Connects Soviet and U.S. Heads of State
description: On Aug. 30, 1963, a direct line of communication between Washington and Moscow, dubbed the Hot Line, became operational. The Hot Line was established after previous methods of communication were found to be dangerously cumbersome.

title: Macarthur Coal Accepts Increased Takeover Bid
description: 7:31 p.m. | Updated

title: The Waste-Free Lunch
description: WHAT kinds of products are some schools putting on their students supplies lists?

title: Joao Silva: This Is What I Do. This Is All That I Know.
description: Photographs by Joao Silva are on exhibit at the Visa Pour lImage photojournalism festival in Perpignan, France. Mr. Silva spoke at the Bronx Documentary Center on Aug. 2, during his first visit to New York since he was injured in Afghanistan. The following week, he went into surgery. He is doing well.

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 30, 2011
description: Todays question was written by Susan Behrens, who is a professor at Marymount Manhattan College and the author of Grammar: A Pocket Guide. Her question comes from the article Politicians and Protesters Assail British Police.

title: Syrian Security Forces Fire on Worshipers as Ramadan Ends
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Tuesday after prayers that signaled the end of the holy month of Ramadan, defying a broad deployment of security forces across Syria that has made August one of the bloodiest months of the uprising.

title: Who Has the Power in School Social Life?
description: In the Motherlode blog column After Class, Skimpy Equality, Lisa Belkin observes that in the classroom, female students are often confident, but socially, equality, respect and self-worth often go out the window. Is the gender dynamic at your school or college like this?

title: South Africans Protest Over Hearing for Zuma Rival
description: The police in South Africa on Tuesday confronted crowds of angry demonstrators supporting Julius Malema, the firebrand leader of the governing partys influential youth league, as he attended a disciplinary hearing that could sway both his own political career and that of President Jacob Zuma before party elections next year.

title: Fantasy Focus: Season Awards
description: As this will be my last post in the fantasy baseball series for 2011, lets give out some season-long awards.

title: Ahead of Baltimore Grand Prix, Pit Row Is Filling With Lawsuits
description: BALTIMORE  As reported by The Times on Aug. 18, potholes and other undesirable obstacles are being paved over for the Baltimore Grand Prix, which will be held on city streets here over Labor Day weekend. Yet two recent lawsuits have called into question whether the promoters that persuaded IndyCar and the American Le Mans Series to stage races here can actually foot the bill.

title: What to Watch on Tuesday
description: At 5-foot-9, and without a single dominant stroke, David Ferrer is hardly the prototypical top-five player. Yet, here he is again, ranked fifth in the world and seeded fifth here.

title: Visiting a Historic, and Hidden, Area of Mumbai
description: Khotachiwadi, a historic area of Mumbai, is like Platform 9 3/4 in the Harry Potter series: invisible to all but those who know exactly where it is or are determined to find it. The narrow lane leading into the wadi, or hamlet, does nothing to inspire confidence and, like Harry and his friends, you need to take a leap of faith and enter.

title: The Case Against a Payroll Tax Cut
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

title: On Day 2, Commuter Trains Limp Back
description: On the second day back to work after Tropical Storm Irene, things are looking better, though still problematic, for people heading in from the suburbs and beyond. There will be limited commuter train service and some difficult road conditions, but PATH trains, as well as subways and buses, are up and running again.

title: Macarons and Ice Cream, Direct from Paris to the Upper East Side
description: Before you say Not another macaron shop! consider that this newcomer to the Upper East Side from Paris brings almond meringue cakes with a pedigree like none other. Ladure, which first established a tea room just steps from the Place de la Concorde in 1862, is said to have originated French macarons as we know them: not the little round cakes, but the idea of sandwiching a pair of them with a creamy filling.

title: Why Red Iguana Built Red Iguana 2 Right Next Door
description: Last week, we published a case study that looked at a choice facing Red Iguana, a Salt Lake City Mexican restaurant that was deciding where, and how, to expand. Founded in 1985 by Ramn and Mara Cardenas, the 130-employee company offers sit-down restaurant service as well as catering and fast-food operations.

title: Building a Model New York, Only to Burn It
description: On Thursday, New York City will burn to the ground.

title: In Mens Doubles, Looking Beyond the Bryan Brothers
description: Even sports fans who dont follow doubles know all about the Bob and Mike Bryan, the twins have become synonymous with the game. Their level of fame is well deserved: after all, theyre favored to win their fourth United States Open which would also give them a record 12th Grand Slam title.

title: Qaddafi Forces Given Deadline to Surrender
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Saying that they had a good idea where Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was hiding, the Libyan rebels on Tuesday gave the colonels recalcitrant loyalists four days to surrender or face military action against holdout towns.

title: Italys Cost of Borrowing Falls in Latest Bond Sale; Central Bank Action Is Credited
description: Despite a backdrop of weakening growth in the euro zone, Italy on Tuesday was able to sell a slice of debt at a lower interest rate than at its previous auction.

title: Heroic Past Erodes in Present
description: The Debt, John Maddens remake of a 2007 Israeli thriller, shuttles back and forth between a dim, creaky East Berlin apartment in 1965 and the sunshine of elite Tel Aviv a little more than 30 years later. The film, written by Matthew Vaughn, Jane Goldman and Peter Straughan, is interested in the ways that the truth of the past can be shaded and illuminated by the imperatives of the present, and it probes, with perhaps more energy than clarity, the ethical and psychological complications that can lie hidden beneath a story of simple heroism.

title: 2012 Campaign: What to Watch For in September
description: With summer over and Labor Day approaching, the 2012 campaign is set to enter its most important phase yet: the fall primary season.

title: Tuesday Reading: How To Ensure Lunchbox Food Safety
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Sara Lee Names Chief for Beverages Spinoff
description: Sara Lee said on Tuesday that it had named an executive to head the planned spinoff of its international beverage business.

title: Smooth Operators
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#802", 592, 400, false, chameleonData);

title: In National Politics, Not Exactly an Empire State
description: Since you were surely distracted by the former hurricane known as Irene, you may not have noticed one of the weekends major nonevents. George E. Pataki, once New Yorks governor, announced that after indulging in his quadrennial routine of dropping flirtatious hints of a presidential run, he would once again not seek the Republican nomination.

title: Hurricane Cost Seen as Ranking Among Top Ten
description: Hurricane Irene will most likely prove to be one of the 10 costliest catastrophes in the nations history, and analysts said that much of the damage might not be covered by insurance because it was caused not by winds but by flooding, which is excluded from many standard policies.

title: NBC Taps Today Producer for 2012 Olympics
description: NBC is to announce on Tuesday morning that it has given the top production job for its coverage of the 2012 Olympics to Jim Bell, executive producer of the networks most important news program, the Today show.

title: Behind Googles $500 Million Settlement With U.S.
description: The Justice Departments settlement of a criminal investigation of Google for allowing Canadian pharmacies to advertise drugs for distribution in the United States reflected an effort by prosecutors to extend the reach of federal drug laws. This may present future challenges to Internet search companies over their advertisements.

title: Shares Edge Higher on a Mixed Bag of Economic Reports
description: Stocks closed higher on Tuesday, despite new reports on consumer attitudes and housing that showed a mixed economic recovery.

title: The TV Watch: Sharpton Brings His Pulpit to MSNBC
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton began his new career as an official MSNBC talk show host on Monday by telling viewers not to expect James Brown.

title: Notes From the Underground | Ziyoou-vachi
description: A little punk, a little glam, and with more than a touch of Gaga and Patricia Fields, Ziyoou-vachi (Queen Bee) is not the type of act youd expect to find on a major record label, but Sony Music Japan snapped up the gender-bending teenage quartet this past year. Celebrating the impending release of their new album at New Japan in the seedy neighborhood of Shinjuku, Tokyo, the band sashayed down a stripper-ish catwalk in the center of the club  not one of them in any less than five-inch heels  and threw themselves into a heavy, energetic set. The drummer and lead singer, Luli-chan and Avu-chan (17 and 19 respectively), are siblings of African-American and Japanese descent. Avu, 6-foot-3 in heels and weighing no more than 110 pounds, is a natural performer. Wearing a dress of her own creation, she captivated the crowd of masked fans with songs sung in Japanese in both male voice and female voice as she dangled from a spinning handle in the ceiling and coyly hid behind a fan.

title: Former SpongeBob Artist Sues His Art Dealer After She Sues Him
description: A former lead artist on the cartoon series SpongeBob SquarePants, who faces a lawsuit from his art dealer concerning what she says was his hiring of accomplices to burglarize her gallery, has fired back with his own suit, accusing her of fraud.

title: The Frugal Travel in Segovia
description: A day trip to Segovia for 30 euros.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Exxon Reaches Arctic Oil Deal With Russians
description: MOSCOW  Exxon Mobil won a coveted prize in the global petroleum industry Tuesday with an agreement to explore for oil in a Russian portion of the Arctic Ocean that is being opened for drilling even as Alaskan waters remain mostly off limits.

title: The City Stirs | Coney Island, 5:40 A.M.
description: I have a seashell collection; maybe youve seen it? I keep it on beaches all over the world.  Steven Wright

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: U.S.: Waiting for Fabian Johnson
description: United States soccer fans will have to wait just a bit longer to catch a glimpse of Fabian Johnson, 23, the most recent German-American to figure in the plans of the mens senior national team, in a U.S. jersey.

title: Romney, in Perry Territory, Faults Career Politicians
description: 12:53 p.m. | Updated  Apparently, just setting foot in Texas imbued Mitt Romney with a bit of that Lone Star swagger.

title: Stamp Act
description: Harris Tweed, the flecked hand-woven wool from Scotland, is celebrating the centennial of its trademark stamp: a Maltese cross atop an orb. An ancestor to the counterfeit wars raging today, the stamp was implemented in 1911 to distinguish the genuine cloth from machine-milled knockoffs. This fall, designers are offering special-edition pieces in tweed as a tribute to those original weavers, our fashion brave hearts.

title: Drawing Dance: The Merce Cunningham Company in Mexico City
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 10th in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Mexico City.

title: Ground Zero Now
description: New office towers are rising on the site, which also serves as a memorial and a transportation hub.

title: Sweet Bird Wont Fly on Broadway This Fall; Franco No Longer Involved in Revival
description: The movie star James Franco (Rise of the Planet of the Apes) is no longer linked to a planned Broadway revival of the Tennessee Williams drama Sweet Bird of Youth, Mr. Francos publicist said on Monday, and the production itself will not happen this fall as previously reported, according to the director attached to the project.

title: Wheelies: The Halo Caddy Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Lens: Joao Silva on Loss, Perseverance and Being the Human Behind the Camera
description: If you read one thing today, make it Joao Silvas post over at the Lens blog. Mr. Silva is a New York Times photographer who was severely wounded in October 2010 when he stepped on a mine while on patrol with American soldiers in southern Afghanistan. Reading his sometimes wry words now, you might be surprised by how seriously he was injured. Legs gone, still taking pictures, Mr. Silva remembers, I knew it wasnt good, but I felt alive.

title: Honor Guard Scripts for Veterans' Funerals
description: Traditional scripts used by some Veterans of Foreign Affairs groups in funerals.

title: Defining the Newest Generation of Parents
description: Every group of parents rediscovers the role. Like brides and widowers, the unemployed and college students, newly fledged parents plunge into a universal experience with a vague sense of disbelief that anyone has experienced exactly this before.

title: G.O.P. Staff Member Picked to Run Deficit Panel
description: Leaders of the new Congressional deficit-reduction committee have chosen a veteran Senate Republican staff member to take over the challenging job of running the panel.

title: Pairings: Spaghetti With Crab Meat, Cherry Tomatoes and Arugula
description: There was plenty of warm sunshine in the dry rieslings from Alsace. These were not the first rieslings that suggested crab meat to me, or the first time that mellow crab meat suggested riesling. Several weeks ago, before the ballet at Lincoln Center, I cleaned my plate of spaghetti tossed with crab meat, tart-sweet cherry tomatoes, arugula and bread crumbs at Nick & Tonis Cafe. About a week later, the recipe in hand, I served it at home with Alsatian riesling for an elegant pas de deux.

title: Alsatian Rieslings Return to Form
description: FEW things have made me as happy recently as the wine panels tasting of dry rieslings from Alsace. Not only did we absolutely love many of the wines, but also the rieslings actually tasted pretty dry.

title: Final Resting Place, and Battleground
description: Every week, thousands of veterans are buried at national cemeteries, often to the sorrowful sound of a bugle. Yet even for families that quietly mourn their dead, these can be the most public of private affairs, taking on deep meaning  about politics, war and religion  to others, particularly other veterans.

title: All Eyes on Spain as EuroBasket Tips Off
description: Every two years the best national basketball teams in Europe battle it out for continental supremacy at EuroBasket. This years edition should be typically intense and, given the current lockout, there will be no shortage of N.B.A. players. Part N.B.A., part Euroleague, mixed in with some soccer-style fan fervor; heres what to look for at when EuroBasket 2011 tips off Wednesday in Lithuania:

title: Thinking Cap: When Foul Language Brings Fouls
description: May I Curse a Referee? Swear Words and Consequences, by Andrea Praschinger and Christine Pomikal, freelance scientists, and Stefan Stieger, who teaches psychology at the University of Vienna. This article appeared in the June issue of the Journal of Sports Science and Medicine.

title: Seoul Brothers
description: Emerging from the shadow of that other stylish, innovative Asian city (ahem, Tokyo), Koreas capital has become an epicenter for trends  particularly for men. The evidence is in popular street style blogs like Your Boyhood, Street Peeper and even The Sartorialist (which has featured the model Bae Jung Nam, who,  la Kate Moss, has turned into a style sensation and is the basis of Bae Jung Nam-style). Korean men, in fact, have started to outshine the women in terms of experimentation and overall expression, wearing everything from Opening Ceremonys kookiness to the elegant homegrown designer Wooyoungmi.

title: Indias Identity Project
description: India is undertaking an ambitious project: collecting the biometric information of 1.2 billion people and assigning each of them a unique 12-digit ID number. Heres are the thoughts of a few of those who will be assigned.

title: Buffett Defends Tax Bill on Bank of America Deal
description: Warren E. Buffett has a bone to pick with The Wall Street Journal.

title: Dancing With the Models
description: Heres Raquel Zimmermann, Karen Elson and other models in the fall Lanvin video, to Pitbulls I Know You Want Me. Wait for the end!

title: Award Show Sets MTV Audience Record; Beyonc Sends Twitter Aflutter
description: Just how many people were fascinated/flustered/baffled by Lady Gagas gender-bending turn on the MTV Video Music Awards? Well 12.4 million people were watching on Sunday night, the biggest viewership for any show in the 30-year history of the cable channel and continuing the upward ratings trend for the annual awards. Last years VMAs drew 11.4 million viewers.

title: In Dot-Com Lawsuit, a Blast From the Past
description: 8:04 p.m. | Updated

title: Long a Small L Landmark; Now Its Official
description: The former Citizens Saving Bank at the Bowery and Canal Street is designated a New York City landmark.

title: Adaptation and Survival of the Fittest
description: Paola Pedraza, assistant curator of the Institute of Systematic Botany at the New York Botanical Garden, writes about her recent expedition to catalog the flora of Las Orqudeas National Park, Colombia.

title: Kvitovas Loss Worse Than Advertised
description: When Petra Kvitova lost in the first round on Monday, word spread quickly that she was the first reigning Wimbledon champion not to make it to the second round of the United States Open. In truth, her loss might have been more historic than that.

description: Serena Williams makes her Open debut on the second night of the tournament, with a wide-open womens field to work with. Lynn Zinser reports.

title: How Airlines Fared in the Hurricane Irene Test
description: Because of survey errors by StellaService, weve published an updated post with new numbers relating to the Twitter test.

title: Lehman Bankruptcy Takes Big Step Toward an End
description: Oli Scarff/Getty ImagesA Lehman Brothers logo in a sale at Christies auction house in London in 2010. In Wall Streets mind, the bank ceased to exist after it filed for bankruptcy in 2008.

title: Toyota Sets Electric Lap Record at the Nrburgring
description: Toyota has yet to mass-market a purely electric vehicle, but the German division of the brands motorsport program has not been waiting around for a donor powertrain.

title: At This Match, Its Spectators Who Make Too Much Noise
description: The noise Tuesday morning during Victoria Azarenkas 6-1, 6-3 victory against Johanna Larsson at the United States Open was off-putting. Azarenkas grunts, which can be louder than a car horn, werent the problem.

title: Good Soles
description: Steven Tiller, a co-founder of the retro SoCal sneaker brand SeaVees, was driving to work recently when he heard on NPR that the 50th anniversary of the Peace Corps was coming up. Initiated by an executive order issued by President John F. Kennedy, the Peace Corps Act was passed in 1961, instituting an army of volunteers to aid those in developing countries. Sensing an opportunity right in line with SeaVeess revisionist design philosophy and midcentury aesthetic, Tiller and his business partner, Derek Galkin, began sifting through old photos of Peace Corps volunteers. On their feet? Narrow plimsolls, a common canvas and rubber sneaker for that era. The idea was to go back in time, reimagine these shoes and hopefully make them cooler, Tiller said. The resulting slim-lined sneaker in salt-washed canvas has a contrast suede stripe around its rims and a distinct vintage look. Donations to the National Peace Corps Association will be made for each pair sold exclusively at seavees.com and jcrew.com.

title: Film Series in Washington Square Park to Feature New York Musicals
description: To celebrate the opening of the renovated Washington Square Park, the IFC Center and the citys Department of Parks and Recreation are presenting three free outdoor screenings of New York-centric musicals there in September.

title: An East Village Symbol of Survival Succumbs to Irene
description: Hundreds of trees were toppled when Tropical Storm Irene moved through New York City.

title: Battle Over Prayer in Veterans Funerals
description: This summer, a lawsuit filed against the Department of Veterans Affairs has turned the national cemetery in Houston into a battleground over the role of prayer in veterans burials.

title: Gordon Murray, Designer of the McLaren F1, Joins Lotus
description: The ambitious and indefatigable Dany Bahar, the chief executive of Group Lotus, who arrived from Ferrari to revitalize the company, has added another nameplate to the Lotus Advisory Council, his board of auto-world consiglieri.

title: Obama Draws Line on Possible Cuts to Veterans Programs
description: MINNEAPOLIS  President Obama vowed on Tuesday that he would not allow cuts in programs for veterans as Congress and the administration look for ways to balance the budget.

title: In Iraq and Afghanistan, War-Weary Eyes Turn Toward Libya
description: At War asked four journalists from Iraq and Afghanistan to share their observations about the revolt in Libya.

description: Many residents of New England on Tuesday faced mountains of mud and a daunting cleanup, even as some remained stranded by floodwater that continued to surge in places.

title: Ebersol to Rejoin NBC Sports as a Senior Adviser
description: The absence of Dick Ebersol from his long-time home at NBC Sports proved to be unexpectedly brief. He will be rejoining the production efforts at NBCs sports as a special adviser to the network, several senior NBC executives said this week.

title: Can Clearer Language Clear Up Climate Disputes?
description: Earlier this summer I taped a series of discussions on climate, energy and other topics with Piya Chattopadhyay of The Agenda, the excellent Canadian public affairs program on TVO. The pieces are running all this week along with the networks coverage of options for the worlds energy menu through 2030, built around a summit that took place at the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in June. (The show ran an in-depth series on climate science last year that I covered here.)

title: Straight-Set Wins and Shrugs From Nadal and Serena Williams
description: The last time the Arthur Ashe Stadium crowd beheld Rafael Nadal, he was facedown on the court, his body convulsing in sobs. The occasion was the 2010 United States Open final, where Nadal defeated Novak Djokovic in four sets to complete a career Grand Slam.

title: Teenager Wins Gold in 400 Meters for Tiny Grenada
description: DAEGU, South Korea  Track and field is on an inclusive run at the midpoint of these world championships in which Usain Bolt has yet to win a medal and athletes from Botswana, Brazil and the small Caribbean country of Grenada have won gold for the first time in their nations histories.

title: And PSE&G Said, Let There Be Light
description: And there was light  and internet access, too.

title: Norwegian Painter Sentenced to Prison for Tax Evasion
description: Norwegian officials have sentenced the painter Odd Nerdrum to two years in prison on charges that he evaded paying the full amount of taxes on $2.6 million that he made selling artwork between 1998 and 2002.

title: Burresss Return Is Still a Work in Progress
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was late Monday, and Plaxico Burress had somewhere else to be. So he shoved some sneakers and a pair of sandals into his green equipment bag, fist-bumped a member of the Jets media relations staff and ambled out of the locker room, his responsibilities at MetLife Stadium fulfilled  for about two more weeks.

title: Ferrer Comes Back to Defeat Andreev
description: After losing the first set to 78th-ranked Russian Igor Andreev 6-2 in 29 minutes, No. 5 seed David Ferrer of Spain looked in jeopardy of becoming the biggest upset victim on the mens side of the 2011 U.S. Open thus far. Ferrer hit only three winners in the opening frame, committing 14 unforced errors.

title: What Did You Do in the Hurricane, Daddy?
description: How did you spend the hurricane?

title: Fed Divisions Led to a Compromise on Interest Rates
description: No one knows what to do to fix the economy.

title: Evos: Fords New Direction
description: The company has released images of the Evos concept, a fastback-style sedan with gullwing doors that introduces Fords new design language.

title: College Athlete Died of Head Trauma, Father Says
description: A 22-year-old football player for Frostburg State University in Maryland has died from head trauma sustained on the field, his father said.

title: Can Water Treaties Be Climate-Proofed?
description: For centuries, water has been a potent weapon between warring states. When Pisa was at war with Florence, Leonardo da Vinci and Machiavelli planned to divert the Arno and leave Pisa dry.

title: Market Driven, Oaxaca-Style
description: OAXACA, Mexico  The market is not for shopping, Pilar Cabrera said.

title: Smithsonian Plans Exhibition on Jefferson and Slavery
description: The Smithsonians National Museum of African American History and Culture wont open until 2015, but it is already mounting exhibitions. Next up, the museum announced on Tuesday, is an exhibition on Thomas Jefferson and slavery, organized with the Thomas Jefferson Foundation at Monticello.

title: Preparing for the Next Disaster
description: The gods must be crazy, or at the very least they seem extremely perturbed this year. Each season of 2011 has been one for the record books as far as weather events. Here in the state of Arkansas we had record cold and snowfall this winter, followed by historic flooding and tornado damage in the spring. In states throughout the south central United States, the Mississippi river went on a flooding rampage the likes of which had not been seen since the 1930s. A tornado outbreak ripped across several states, with Alabama bearing the brunt. Texas and Oklahoma are still being oppressed by relentlessly hot temperatures, and now Irene has come barreling up the eastern seaboard. Dare I ask whats next?

title: Bank of America Settlement Faces Growing Challenges
description: 7:39 p.m. | Updated

title: Fancy Batteries in Electric Cars Pose Recycling Challenges
description: HOBOKEN, BELGIUM  With fleets of electric cars starting to hit the roads, the next big mother lode for salvage companies is expected to be the expensive, newfangled batteries powering them.

title: Gun Inquiry Costs Officials Their Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday replaced two top Justice Department officials associated with an ill-fated investigation into a gun-trafficking network in Arizona that has been at the center of a political conflagration.

title: The Finale of Mostly Mozart
description: The final evening of the Mostly Mozart Festival featured a collection of famous unfinished works.

description: I found irresistible large dark green and yellow pattypan squash at my farmers market last week, perfect for stuffing with this simple mixture of squash, corn, a little onion and a very light custard.

title: Israeli Columnist Is Fired for Writing That Palestinian Terrorism Is Justified
description: In a brief Note to Readers published Tuesday on the front page of The Jerusalem Post, the newspaper announced that it had parted ways with a columnist who wrote last week on his blog that terrorist attacks on Israelis were justified because Palestinians living under Israeli occupation since 1967 have a right to resist.

title: Controversial Airport Is Planned for Costa Rica
description: In a region of Costa Rica that harbors 3 percent of the worlds known biodiversity, a proposed international airport is eliciting concern about ecological consequences and potential damage to an existing and exemplary network of ecotourism lodges.

title: S.E.C. Recoups Bonus of Former Beazer Executive
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that it had reached a settlement with the former chief financial officer of Beazer Homes USA to recover $1.4 million in bonus and stock profits.

title: Israel Intensifies Training of Settler Security Teams
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military has stepped up training for more than 100 settler security teams in the West Bank in anticipation of Palestinian popular protests and possible mass disturbances accompanying any Palestinian bid for United Nations recognition in September, settler leaders said on Tuesday.

description: The second day at the U.S. Open saw most top players hold seed, although defending French Open champion Li Na was upset by Simona Halep.

title: Wozniacki Wins in Straight Sets
description: W.T.A. No. 1 Caroline Wozniacki turned in an impeccable first round performance in her opening round match at the 2011 U.S. Open, charging to a 6-3, 6-1 victory over Spanish doubles specialist Nuria Llagostera Vives in 80 minutes.

title: The U.S. Open in Photos: Day 2
No Hurricane Worries as Viewers Flock to Jersey Shore
description: While the MTV Video Music Awards did set an audience record for largest viewership in the cable channels 30-year history, the once-a-year event cant quite compare to the steady ratings dominance coming out of New Jersey (by way of Italy these days).

title: At Winstons Champagne Bar, 100 Ways to Fill Flutes
description: Luxurious is the word for Winstons Champagne Bar, which opens next Tuesday with as elite a list of high-end bubbly as you are likely to see, more than 100 choices from 20 houses.

description: Gadzookz. Would Zhakezpeare wonder, Whatz in a name, anyway?

description: Photographs from Bangladesh, New York, New Jersey and Libya.

title: Day-Tripping in Segovia (and Counting Euro Pennies)
description: If youve never peered into 12th-century churches, meandered down cobblestone streets or pretended to dump boiling oil over ancient city walls onto barbarians below, a day in Segovia is a piece of frugal cake. Figure 20 euros for the 27-minute train from Madrid, 10 euros for lunch and another 4.50 to enter the celebrated castle. Voil: youve got a day trip for around 35 euros per person (or about $50 at $1.42 to the euro).

title: On Dams, Gutters, Floods and Climate Resilience
description: New York City and the communities downstream of one of the citys reservoirs in the Catskills may have dodged a disaster as the swirling remains of Hurricane Irene dumped between 9 and 13 inches of rain across the valleys feeding that part of the citys water supply. At the Gilboa dam on the Schoharie River over the weekend, evacuation sirens sounded after the reservoir exceeded the highest levels recorded there. But inspections of the aging dam, which had seen stopgap repairs recently and is poised for a $350 million rebuild, found no structural problems. (The image above was shot as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo toured the region on Sunday.)

title: Hurricane Insurance Claims: All About Falling Trees
description: Now that Hurricane Irene has passed, the thoughts of homeowners turn to filing claims for damage caused by the storm. Several Bucks readers had questions about damage caused by trees, so we spoke with representatives of the Insurance Information Institute for some answers.

title: World Athletics Championships: Day 4
description: Photos from Day 4 of the International Association of Athletics Federations world athletics championships in Daegu, South Korea.

title: Weather Channels Ratings Surge With Irene
description: By television ratings standards, Hurricane Irene was the biggest storm system in the Weather Channels 29-year history.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bangladesh, New York, New Jersey and Libya.

title: TimesCast | August 30, 2011
description: Libyan rebels set a deadline for forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to surrender Surt; uncovering Qaddafi's family pictures; and WikiLeaks releases documents without redacting names.

title: Strauss-Kahn Apologizes to I.M.F. Staff
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn returned to the International Monetary Fund in Washington on Monday to say farewell, a week after the Manhattan district attorney dropped sexual assault charges against him. In a 15-minute speech delivered without notes, Mr. Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the organization, said repeatedly that he wanted to apologize for what he said was a mistake on my part, according to news reports. Read the full story here.

title: Yemen, Amid Political Turmoil, Is Embracing a Holiday
description: SANA, Yemen  The dusty streets of this ancient capital were jammed with cars as Yemenis ran last-minute errands before the start of Id al-Fitr, the joyous holiday that began Tuesday with the end of the holy month of Ramadan. Men stood in lines outside tiny barber shops, waiting patiently for their holiday trim, and, for a moment at least, the city tried to focus on something other than a lingering political and economic crisis.

title: Djokovic Winsin 44 Minutes
description: In a dream season in which Novak Djokovic has beaten 57 of the 59 opponents hes faced, just about the only thing he hasnt done is beat a player from Ireland. Now hes done that too, taking just 44 minutes to demolish 29-year-old Conor Niland, who had to retire down 0-6, 1-5 due to illness.

title: Zabars No-Lobster Salad Has a New Name
description: After being called out by a reporter for The Times-Picayune of New Orleans earlier this month for selling lobster salad that contains no lobster, Zabars has renamed it zabster zalad,  City Room reports. The main ingredient remains the same: wild freshwater crayfish.

title: Jagger
description: The T.A.M.I. Show was all about showcasing the new.

description: LONDON  Echoing a call by Warren E. Buffett, members of the European wealthy elite are urging their governments to raise their taxes or enact special levies to help reduce growing budget deficits.

title: Disaster Relief Economics
description: In a way, I may be wasting my time doing any kind of rational analysis of Eric Cantors demand that any disaster aid in the wake of Irene be offset by spending cuts elsewhere. Cantor is, of course, being totally hypocritical; where were the demands for offsets to the cost of invading Iraq?

title: Settling a Score, and Matters of Manhood, on Behalf of Rock Royalty
description: The Rolling Stones Bigger Bang album included a song called Oh No, Not You Again. A lot of readers may join in on that refrain at the news that the Stones are back on the bookshelves with Jagger, another rehashing of grievances between a certain snake-hipped singer and a louche guitar man. Next year these two will hit their golden anniversary and be able to celebrate 50 years at each others throat.

title: Wikileaks Releases New Cache of Files
description: WikiLeaks,the antisecrecy organization, releases documents, including many that name confidential sources.

title: Your Reflections on 9/11
description: The New York Times and YouTube invite you to submit a video discussing your perspective on the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11. Go to youtube.com/september11 for details and to upload your video.

title: Court Grants Citadel Restraining Order Against Employee
description: An Illinois circuit court has granted a request by the hedge fund Citadel for a temporary restraining order against an employee accused by the firm of sneaking highly sensitive information off its computer servers.

title: A Series of Second Acts Prepares to Open on a Harlem Street
description: The Victoria Theater on 125th Street in Harlem has been home to vaudeville shows, Off Broadway productions and Hollywood movies. But its terra cotta facade has been mostly dark since 1989 when, after failing as a five-screen multiplex, it shut its doors.

title: CNN Acquires Zite, an iPad App Company
description: Putting an emphasis on personalization tools for the Web, CNN on Tuesday said it had acquired Zite, a company that markets an iPad app that learns what its users want to read and view.

title: Je TAime, He Sang, to His Women and Himself
description: Singer and writer of songs, lover of women, prodigious smoker of cigarettes  Serge Gainsbourg was an indelible, unavoidable figure in French culture in the postwar years until his death in 1991. Equal parts icon and iconoclast, he shocked respectable opinion even as he seemed to embody the contradictory moods of his era. He could, sometimes within a single song, appear suave and profane, cynical and romantic, a personification of existential ennui and an avatar of down-and-dirty passion.

title: Double Vision
description: In order to come up with a full audience for Andy Sambergs impersonations of tennis players, we asked the digital wizards at Picturehouse to blend our studio photographs by Walter Iooss Jr. with his own photographs from the 1970s and 1980s, when he covered tennis for Sports Illustrated. In the sequence below, you can see the original picture of John McEnroe lying on Center Court at Wimbledon, from the final he lost to Bjorn Borg in 1980, followed by Samberg on the green screen and then the composite of the first two shots. Doing it this way meant we didnt have to ask Samberg to play all those blurry folks in the stands. And that left him more time to personify tennis greatness, as seen in the outtake at bottom.

title: Preaching Gospel, Not Singing It
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton began his new career as an official MSNBC talk show host on Monday by telling viewers not to expect James Brown.

title: 456 Shanghai Cuisine
description: ROUGHLY 200 years ago, in the 1970s, there was a nice little restaurant on Chatham Square in Chinatown called 456, which served mild, salty-sweet southern Chinese specialties accompanied by gallons of hot tea: cold sesame noodles, dim sum, pork in brown sauce, stir-fried greens with garlic.

title: After 9/11, Grappling With Grief and Rage
description: The next two weeks will bring lots of stories updating the lives of 9/11 survivors or of those who lost loved ones in the attacks, but few are likely to exhibit the care and persistence of Rebirth, a documentary by Jim Whitaker that stands as both a tribute and a study in healing.

title: Who You Gonna Bet On, Yet Again (Somewhat Wonkish)
description: Todays FT has a piece on famous financial managers having a bad year; among them are John Paulson and Bill Gross. Regular readers may recall that back in 2010 Business Week ran an article contrasting my views with Paulsons, with the tone of the article clearly conveying the message that we should trust the billionaire, not the silly academic. You might also recall that I was highly critical of Pimcos assertions that the end of quantitative easing would lead to a spike in interest rates.

title: Mad Scientists, Real and Fictional, Giving Birth to Troubling Theories
description: Normally, Dark Matters: Twisted but True, a cornball documentary series starting on Wednesday on the Science Channel that tells unsavory stories of scientific research, wouldnt merit much attention. Its a standard show of its kind, relating urban legends, conspiracy theories and sensational more-or-less-true stories with the help of cheap special effects and hilariously cheesy re-creations.

title: Heroes Take Flight, Again
description: When the latest issue of Justice League is released on Wednesday by DC Comics, it will be scrutinized like no other installment in the 76-year history of that publisher of superhero adventures.

title: Honduras: Coach Surez, Najar, Klinsmann and Brazil 2014
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Luis Fernando Surez took the helm of the Honduras national soccer team last March, and will try to steer the Central American nation to a return trip to the World Cup in 2014. It will face Cuba and the winners of Groups C and D in the semifinal round of the Concacaf region qualifying.

title: Nevada Says Bank Broke Mortgage Settlement
description: The attorney general of Nevada is accusing Bank of America of repeatedly violating a broad loan modification agreement it struck with state officials in October 2008 and is seeking to rip up the deal so that the state can proceed with a suit against the bank over allegations of deceptive lending, marketing and loan servicing practices.

title: TimesCast | Libyan Rebels Set Deadline
description: August 30, 2011 - Libya's rebels set a Saturday deadline for forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to leave Surt.

title: H.P. Plans to Make a Few More TouchPads
description: 6:48 p.m. | Updated  Adding pricing information.

title: Facebooks New (New) Privacy Controls
description: Over the weekend, Facebook began rolling out a new interface that gives members much more direct control over who can see what they post, as well as when theyre tagged by others. Some of the options were already available, but you had to click through multiple pages and pop-ups to use them. There are also two new important options.

title: Rapper Returns, With Punch Lines but Little Soul
description: There goes Lil Wayne, wearing bleached leopard-print skinny pants  womens pants, as it happens  and stalking the stage of the MTV Video Music Awards with Iggy Pop attitude. There goes Lil Wayne, riding a skateboard and falling off. There goes Lil Wayne, who cant sing worth a lick, taking a ballad, How to Love, into the Top 10 of the Billboard pop chart.

title: A Ramapo River Spill is Being Addressed
description: As hurricane cleanup continues, many residents of hard-hit areas are worrying about ancillary damage, like toxic runoff from businesses that were hit by Irene.

title: Cuomo Asks Obama to Declare Disaster in New York State
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, warning that several emergency shelters had been rendered unreachable by flooding and that dams were at risk of failing, asked President Obama on Tuesday to declare a major federal disaster in New York State.

title: Another Upset: Li Loses to Halep in Straight Sets
description: Following on the heels of Wimbledon champion and No. 5 seed Petra Kvitovas upset loss yesterday, French Open champion and No. 6 seed Li Na crashed out of the 2011 U.S. Open in the first round, falling 6-2, 7-5 to 53rd-ranked Romanian teenager Simona Halep.

title: A Tribute to Jackson Riles Fans and Family
description: It seems that nothing involving Michael Jackson or his fractious family is ever free of controversy, even two years after his death.

title: When Should a Case Be Brought to Trial?
description: To the Editor:

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Back to School
description: To the Editor:

title: A Portraitists Eye Gazes on Fashion
description: DAVID ARMSTRONG and his cat were splayed on a chaise. Mr. Armstrong wore black Levis, a denim cowboy shirt and Ray-Ban Wayfarers with prescription lenses. The outfit, appropriate for a hipster 40 years his junior, completely suited him, although he might not think so.

title: Legal Help for the Poor: The View From the A.B.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits of Fresh Cooking in Schools, and Food Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Deflate a Gold Bubble (That Might Not Even Exist)
description: Gold is caught in a frenzy.

title: Livonia, a Detroit Suburb, Tops List of Worst Cities for Speed Traps
description: Drivers with heavy right feet might want to steer clear of Livonia, Mich., according to a list of American and Canadian cities with the highest number of reported speed trap locations over the last two years.

title: Charities Struggle With Smaller Wall Street Donations
description: Operation Hope built a nonprofit powerhouse over the last decade, spinning a stockpile of donations from Wall Street firms into 27 financial education centers across the country.

title: Long Braids Take Center Court at U.S. Open
description: THERE were high-pitched grunts and moans during this years Wimbledon three-set semifinal match between Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic and Victoria Azarenka of Belarus, but the hair remained under control. Both players, in white headbands and long dramatic braids, seemed to have torn a page out of the bohemian-chic playbook.

title: Around Bee Rescue, Honey and Rancor
description: Tropical Storm Irene moved through New York City on Sunday knocking out power, causing flooding in some neighborhoods and knocking over many trees.

title: N.B.A. and Union Will Talk on Wednesday
description: The first critical bargaining session of the N.B.A. lockout will take place on Wednesday in Manhattan, with negotiators facing an ever-shrinking window to make a deal. It is unclear if either side will make a new proposal.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,737 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Protests in Iran Over Disappearing Lake
description: The raw YouTube clips, of Iranian protesters filling the streets and clashing violently with members of the security forces on motorcycles, might seem familiar to readers who followed the wave of unrest over Irans disputed presidential election in 2009, but the anger in the city of Tabriz this time has a more local cause: the governments failure to halt the gradual disappearance of a vast salt lake that is crucial to the regions economy.

title: NBC Picks Executive Producer of Today to Run London Olympics Coverage
description: Nearly three months ago, Comcast agreed to pay $4.38 billion for its NBC Universal subsidiary to carry the four Olympics from 2014 to 2020. On Tuesday, NBC made a critical hire, naming Jim Bell, the executive producer of the Today show, as its top Olympic producer for the 2012 London Games.

title: The Ballet of Movement in Grand Central
description: Every hour brings a juxtaposition of energy and stillness to the cavernous terminal.

title: Water Still Rises in New Jersey and Connecticut
description: As many people in the path of Tropical Storm Irene struggled to recover, floodwaters continued to rise on Tuesday in New Jersey and Connecticut, forcing thousands of evacuations, even two days after the storm swept through the region.

title: Rodriguez Is Likely to Miss Boston Series
description: BOSTON  Alex Rodriguez received a cortisone shot Monday for his sprained left thumb and said he did not expect to play in any of the three games here against the Red Sox. But he held out hope that he could play Friday against the Toronto Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Dining Calendar
description: Paella Compromise

title: Ladure Brings Its Macarons to New York
description: Before you say, Not another macaron shop! consider that this newcomer to New York from Paris brings almond meringue cakes with a pedigree like no other. Ladure, which first established a tea room near the Place de la Concorde in 1862, is said to have originated the French macaron as we know it: not the little round cakes, but the idea of sandwiching a pair with a filling. That happened some 60 or so years ago.

title: Jersey Tomatoes? Jersey Ketchup!
