description: This Labor Day, you can let loose those locavore instincts and slather your burgers with new seasonal ketchup made from New Jersey tomatoes. First Field, a company in Princeton, makes the ketchup from sustainably grown tomatoes seasoned with onions, cider vinegar, organic sugar, soybean oil, salt and spices. It is not quite as silky as the supermarket icon, and its flavor is a bit more robust. And after September, it will be gone until next year.

title: Mediterranean Supplies, Downtown
description: For years, diners at Il Buco, a rustic Italian restaurant just off the Bowery on Bond Street, have been able to buy the olive oils, vinegars and salt that Donna Lennard, an owner, imports from Italy for the restaurant. Now she is formally going into the retail business, with a market set to open on Friday.

title: Former Territory Inciting Violence at Border, Sudan Tells the U.N.
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The Sudanese government has filed a complaint with the Security Council that South Sudan, its newly independent neighbor and former territory, is inciting violence and instability in the Nuba Mountains region of Sudan, a volatile border area where United Nations officials warn that war crimes may have been committed in recent months.

title: On the Court, Bubka Looks for His Own Fame
description: It used to bother Sergei Bubka, the tennis player and son of the legendary Ukrainian pole vaulter with the same name, when reporters would ask him about his father.

title: Admiral Defends Use of Elite Unit in Calamitous Raid
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The new commander of American Special Operations forces has defended the use of commandos in a Navy Seals unit to back up a raid in Afghanistan earlier this month that ended in tragedy when a Chinook helicopter was shot down, rejecting criticism that planning for the operation was different from other missions that had been carried out successfully, as many as a dozen on a typical night.

title: Unfamiliar Path Unfolds at Tennessee
description: Mickie DeMoss had been away from the Tennessee womens basketball program for seven years, working as a head coach and an assistant elsewhere, when she gave in to Pat Summitts entreaties to come back last year as an assistant. It was a chance to go home, to return to the place she had worked for 18 years for her beloved mentor. But when DeMoss started work, she was immediately struck by changes she saw in Summitt.

title: Panel Hears Grim Details of Venereal Disease Tests
description: Gruesome details of American-run venereal disease experiments on Guatemalan prisoners, soldiers and mental patients in the years after World War II were revealed this week during hearings before a White House bioethics panel investigating the studys sordid history.

title: Latest Trial Set to Begin in Insider Trading Inquiry
description: A former salesman at a Silicon Valley research company is set to go on trial Wednesday on insider trading charges, the latest in the federal governments sprawling investigation.

title: On a Postindustrial Potomac, an Old Plant Gives Way
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  For much of the history of this city on the Potomac, industry has dominated its waterfront, from its postcolonial role as a port for the nations capital, to the World War I era when torpedoes were made here, to more recent years when a Ford plant handled parts distribution and warehouses stored newsprint delivered by boat.

title: Zone for 9/11 Compensation in Lower Manhattan Is Expanded
description: The special master of a fund created to compensate people who became sick after being exposed to the toxic cloud from ground zero has announced that the fund will enlarge the zone considered part of the 9/11 crash site to cover all of Lower Manhattan south of Canal Street.

title: Casting a Long Shadow
description: John Isner appreciates, but does not celebrate, or elevate, the marathon tennis match that continues to define him. He views it as a feat of endurance, a historical quirk, but not much more.

title: The Advantages of Breaking Up
Chinese Telecom Executive Sentenced to Death for Bribery
description: SHANGHAI  A former executive at China Mobile, one of this countrys biggest state-owned telecommunications companies, was sentenced to death with a two-year reprieve Tuesday for accepting bribes, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

title: Coming Up at the 21 Club, Beer on Tap in a Swivel Stool
description: TRADITION relinquishes its grasp but slowly in the power-dining precincts of that 81-year-old former speakeasy, the 21 Club. Still disputed is the reconfiguration of its 32-foot-long mahogany bar in 1997. In 2006, there was the much-debated banishment of the brass spittoons (only one holdout has survived, by the lobby stairs). There was the controversial revocation of the dinnertime necktie rule in 2009.

title: One-Hour Texas Chili
description: Adapted from The Homesick Texan Cookbook by Lisa Fain (Hyperion)

title: A Great Big Texas Helping of Home
description: AN unexpected highlight of my summer reading was a book featuring a hot and juicy threesome: jalapeo, cilantro and lime. Lisa Fain calls these the Tex-Mex trinity, which is a recurrent combination in her Homesick Texan Cookbook (Hyperion, $29.99), to be published on Sept. 13.

title: Fantasy U.S. Open: Stefan Edberg
description: Jeffrey Marcus explains why Ivan Lendl was a great Open champion and how he could defeat Pete Sampras in a hypothetical Open match.

title: At N.L.R.B., Flurry of Acts for Unions as Chief Exits
description: The National Labor Relations Board on Tuesday released a decision that would make it easier to unionize nursing home workers.

title: Nights and Weekends
description: 1 Bedford Avenue (Manhattan Avenue), Greenpoint, Brooklyn; (718) 383-5349; nightsandweekendsny.com.

title: Covering 2012, Youths on the Bus
description: WASHINGTON  A group of five fresh-faced reporters from National Journal and CBS News clicked away on their MacBooks one recent afternoon, dutifully taking notes as seasoned journalists from the campaign trail shared their rules of the road.

title: Gulbis Forgoes Partying Well for Playing Well
description: Tuesday was Ernests Gulbiss 23rd birthday, an occasion he commemorated with a commanding 6-2, 6-4, 6-4 upset of Mikhail Youzhny, the 16th seed at this years United States Open and a singles semifinalist a year ago. It was the first Grand Slam match victory in more than two years for Gulbis, a first-rate moneyed player from Latvia frequently undone by a second-rate everyday work ethic.

title: Bi Lokma
description: 212 East 45th Street (between Second and Third Avenues); (212) 687-3842; bi-lokma.com.

title: Republican Staff Member, Steeped in Tax Law, Is Chosen to Lead Deficit Panel Staff
description: WASHINGTON  Even in the silence of the August recess, the special Congressional committee focused on deficit reduction has begun to hum to life. On Tuesday, the panel announced it had chosen a veteran Senate Republican staff member to take over the challenging job of running the bipartisan panel and its staff.

title: New Claims Against Man Accused of Framing His Ex-Girlfriend for Robberies
description: Last December, a Queens woman was released from prison after prosecutors said her former boyfriend, Jerry Ramrattan, had framed her for a series of brazen armed robberies that never took place.

title: The Value of an Ace Like Sabathia
description: BOSTON

title: Avastin Injections Are Reported to Cause Blindness
description: At least 16 people in two states have gotten severe eye infections, and some have been blinded, from injections of the drug Avastin, according to health authorities and to lawyers representing the patients.

title: High Above the Hog
description: Asheville, N.C.

title: On the Move, Athletically, Against Arthritis
description: THE Arthritis Foundation is taking a new tack with its public service advertising, introducing a hard-hitting campaign that urges people to take up exercise as a weapon against pain.

title: Players Question New Tests for H.G.H.
description: Negotiations toward establishing a testing program for human growth hormone are at a standstill, the players union said Tuesday, and expectations are dimming that a program can be put in place to start testing by the start of the regular season next week.

title: Tight Budget? Look to the Cloud
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Tripoli Divided as Rebels Jostle to Fill Power Vacuum
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Fighters from the western mountain city of Zintan control the airport. The fighters from Misurata guard the central bank, the port and the prime ministers office, where their graffiti has relabeled the historic plaza Misurata Square. Berbers from the mountain town Yafran took charge of the citys central square, where they spray-painted Yafran Revolutionaries.

title: Surge in Global Migration Expands Scale of an Aid Groups Influence
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  As global migration has rapidly expanded, so has the influence of a little-known group whose eclectic work shapes migrants lives across six continents.

title: David Ferrer Makes Up for Height Disadvantage With Speed
description: After winning his first-round match at the United States Open on Tuesday, the Spaniard David Ferrer flung his soaked white headband onto the court and jogged to greet his opponent, his longtime friend Igor Andreev.

title: Trouble at a Bar, a Suspected Break-In, Then a Fatal Standoff With the Nassau Police
description: There was trouble at the Buoy Bar, a dockside hangout in Point Lookout, N.Y., and Kurt Doerbecker was the apparent cause.

title: What Price Life?
description: So the big, bad storm huffed and puffed and didnt blow all the houses in.

title: In Latest Breach, Hackers Impersonate Google to Snoop on Users in Iran
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hackers passed themselves off as the Internet giant Google with the apparent goal of snooping on people using Google services in Iran, the company said.

title: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Pete Sampras vs. Ivan Lendl
description: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? Its up to you to decide, with a little help from The Timess tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section.

title: The New Resentment of the Poor
description: In a decade of frenzied tax-cutting for the rich, the Republican Party just happened to lower tax rates for the poor, as well. Now several of the partys most prominent presidential candidates and lawmakers want to correct that oversight and raise taxes on the poor and the working class, while protecting the rich, of course.

title: Federal Austerity Changes Disaster Relief
description: WASHINGTON  As Senator Bernard Sanders toured Vermont by helicopter on Tuesday to assess the damage from what he said could be his states worst-ever natural disaster, the idea of cutting other federal programs to aid towns pummeled by Hurricane Irene was stoking his outrage.

title: Christine Lagardes Tough Message
description: Less than two months after being chosen to lead the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde shook up last weekends conference of central bankers in Jackson Hole, Wyo., with an urgent, much needed plea for bolder economic policies in the United States and Europe to head off a looming double-dip recession.

title: Wednesday: Sting Like a B
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Todays creation from Peter A. Collins floats like a butterfly and stings like a B, in a puzzle that incorporates boxing, bullfighting and the Beach Boys.

title: Safety Report on Vaccines
description: A comprehensive evaluation of eight common childhood vaccines has found that any adverse effects from vaccines are very rare or very minor. The report, issued last week by a panel of experts assembled by the Institute of Medicine, said there is no evidence that childhood vaccines cause autism, diabetes, facial palsy or episodes of asthma, as some people fear.

title: For Congress in New Yorks Ninth District
description: When Representative Anthony Weiner resigned in disgrace in June, he left his diverse district without a voice in the House of Representatives. On Sept. 13, voters in that Queens and Brooklyn district can choose his replacement.

title: Bullying Law Puts New Jersey Schools on Spot
description: Under a new state law in New Jersey, lunch-line bullies in the East Hanover schools can be reported to the police by their classmates this fall through anonymous tips to the Crimestoppers hot line.

title: Despite Risks, Romney Presses Grim Picture of Obama
description: Mitt Romney warned on Tuesday that America was on the brink of profound economic misery, the latest effort by the Republican presidential candidate to paint an unrelentingly grim picture of the country under President Obamas leadership.

title: With Help Online, French Farmers Now Playing the Field
description: LASSAY-LES-CHATEAUX, France  Patrick Maignan, a robust gray-haired farmer, lives alone on his farm, surrounded only by the freshly plowed wheat fields of this lonely corner of northern France.

title: Mismanagement Blamed for Bay Area Gas Disaster
description: WASHINGTON  The main cause of the natural gas pipeline rupture in San Bruno, Calif., that killed eight people and burned three dozen houses last September was 54 years of bad management by the Pacific Gas & Electric Company, and state and federal regulators who did not notice the problem, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.

title: Old Hand at Hurricanes, Cuomo Leads Response
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has seen his share of disasters.

title: Brave, Foolhardy and Just Unlucky: The Lives Lost in a Storms Watery Fury
description: In the Bronx, Jose Sierra ignored his sisters warning not to check on the boat his wife had gotten him as a gift. In Bristol, Conn., Shane Seaver and a friend could not resist the impulse to view the storms destruction from a canoe. In Princeton, N.J., Michael Kenwood waded into angry waters to try to save someone who might have been trapped in a car.

title: Parks Rules on Scarves Are Cited in a Melee
description: A scuffle broke out at an amusement park in Westchester County on Tuesday when a group of Muslims there to celebrate the end of Ramadan were told that women could not wear their head coverings on certain rides, park officials and witnesses said. Fifteen people were arrested.

title: Lottery Numbers
Profits Before Environment
description: I wasnt surprised when the administration of George W. Bush sacrificed the environment for corporate profits. But when the same thing happens under a Democratic administration, its depressing. With little or no public input, policies that benefit corporations regardless of the consequences continue to be enacted.

title: Cursing and Consequences
description: The ArtsBeat blog has a post on the consequences of swearing in soccer. The rules say it should produce an automatic red card from the referee, but a study found thats not always the case. Read the entire post here, and share your comments.

title: Upstate Farmers Find That a Fertile Flood Plain Is a Two-Edged Sword
description: Like many other growers in the Hudson Valley, John Gills grandfather established his farm along the banks of a creek  in his case, the lower Esopus in Hurley, N.Y.  because the land was so fertile, with topsoil penetrating 10 to 30 feet into the earth.

title: Evans Showcases Abilities by Taking Advantage of Increased Playing Time
description: When Terry Collins decided last week that Lucas Duda would close out the season as the Mets everyday right fielder, he acknowledged that it would occasionally leave the team with a less-than-optimal lineup.

title: Ford Previews the Evos Concept Ahead of Frankfurt Auto Show
description: On Wednesday, Ford released the first images of the Evos concept, a fastback-style sedan with gullwing doors expected to be unveiled at the Frankfurt auto show next month.

title: As the Transfer Window Closes
description: Come to think of it, that would be a good name for a soap opera. Will the mysterious Russian billionaire lavish any new gifts on his suave new Portuguese coach? Should Harry and Luka make up at Tottenham? Is Owens career in low-budget Internet films over? Can Arsne buy true love, or at least a midfielder who wont stomp on his heart or opponents calves? Tune in tomorrow to find out. For now, heres a recap of what happened on Tuesday.

title: Western Officials Seek Softer Approach to Militants in Nigeria
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Amid increasing evidence that the Nigerian governments heavy-handed strategy for containing a radical Islamist sect has failed, some Western officials are urging a new and less militarized approach.

title: Kansas City School District Loses Leader Who Began Turnaround Effort
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  John Covington arrived here two years ago with the promise of transforming a district that had become synonymous with the failures of urban education. He even managed to win support for his drastic recommendation to shut down nearly half its schools, saying it was a necessary step to achieve desperately needed stability.

title: Town Draws Together in the Midst of Losses
description: WILLIAMSVILLE, Vt.  The gas lamp and candles that Melvin and Norma Shakun had prepared for Hurricane Irene are still sitting on the kitchen table in their 200-year-old home here.

title: Tatishvili Has Few Answers on Home Court
description: There was no home-court advantage for Anna Tatishvili on Tuesday.

title: Palin Adds New Hampshire to Labor Day Itinerary
description: Sarah Palins political itinerary over Labor Day weekend is becoming clearer, even if her intentions are not.

title: Kenya: Officials Cases to Go Forward
description: Kenyas government has lost its bid to block the prosecution of senior politicians before the International Criminal Court in The Hague. On Tuesday, appeals judges ruled that they had found insufficient evidence that Kenyas government was investigating the cases, as it had long claimed. The prosecutor has accused six Kenyans, including the deputy prime minister, two former ministers and a former police chief, of orchestrating large-scale violence after the 2007 elections. More than 1,200 people died and several hundred thousand fled their homes. The decision means that the next stage of the criminal proceedings, confirmation of charges, can go ahead in The Hague this week.

title: Rivalry Heats Up as Yankees Draw Closer in the Division Race
description: BOSTON  Another spark was thrown into the combustible rivalry between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox Tuesday, when players fumed, benches emptied and coaches were ejected.

title: China: Sentence in Monks Suicide
description: A Chinese court sentenced a Tibetan monk to 11 years in prison on Monday for his role in the death of a fellow monk who set himself on fire in March to protest government policies, according to Xinhua, Chinas official news agency. The Chinese court found the 46-year-old monk, Drongdru, guilty of intentional homicide in the death of his nephew, a 16-year-old monk, in Sichuan Province. Prosecutors say that after the teenager immolated himself, Drongdru and two other monks hid him and delayed emergency treatment.

title: AT&T Plans to Bring Back Jobs Sent Abroad
description: AT&T, its $39 billion deal to buy T-Mobile USA under pressure from multiple fronts, is now seeking to promote one benefit of the blockbuster deal: jobs.

title: NYT: Front Page for 08/31/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 08/31/2011

title: As Refugees From Haiti Linger, Dominicans Good Will Fades
description: CHENE, Dominican Republic  They have been blamed for spreading cholera, taking jobs and driving up crime, and now, with memories of the earthquake and the bonhomie it generated rapidly fading, this country is taking action: it is deporting Haitian refugees, turning them away from the border and generally making their lives difficult.

title: Wheel Comes Off in Mets Loss
description: Blame was assigned. Blame was professed. Blame was deflected.

title: Corrections: August 31
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Prescribing Exercise to Treat Depression
description: Can a stroll help ease depression? That question preoccupied Dr. Madhukar H. Trivedi, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, after several of his patients, all suffering from serious depression, mentioned that they felt happier if they went for a walk. The patients in question were taking the widely prescribed antidepressants known as S.S.R.I.s, for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, but not responding fully. They remained, by clinical standards, depressed. Dr. Trivedi and his colleagues began to wonder if adding a formal dose of exercise would increase their chances of getting better.

title: Word of the Day | stupefy
description: stupefy \st-p-fi, sty-\ verb

title: Via Zipcar, Ford Seeks Young Fans
description: DETROIT  It wasnt long ago that car-sharing services like Zipcar were perceived as a threat to the sales volumes of traditional automakers.

title: Minorities Lead Growth in Biggest Cities
description: WASHINGTON  Minorities accounted for 98 percent of the population growth in the nations largest metropolitan areas over the past decade, according to a new report, as the countrys white population continued to stagnate, and in many places, decline.

title: Where Pay for Chiefs Outstrips U.S. Taxes
description: At least 25 top United States companies paid more to their chief executives in 2010 than they did to the federal government in taxes, according to a study released on Wednesday.

title: Poking Fun at the Mayor, El Leadero in el Stormo
description: Rachel Figueroa-Levin has a dog, three cats, five fish, a snake, a turtle, a parakeet, a gecko (like the Geico lizard, she explained) and two sugar gliders (picture little flying opossums). The gliders cage sits beside a screen that streams Sesame Street videos for her 9-month-old daughter, Adiella, whose playpen and bouncer are strategically arranged by the living rooms centerpiece: a Macintosh computer where Ms. Figueroa-Levin blogs, posts messages on Twitter, and writes about, well, anything.

title: Susan Fromberg Schaeffer, Inventive Novelist, Dies at 71
description: Susan Fromberg Schaeffer, a novelist with a gift for evoking complex characters in the grip of extreme psychological stress and physical suffering, notably in The Madness of a Seduced Woman and the Vietnam War novel Buffalo Afternoon, died on Friday in Chicago. She was 71.

title: Patrick C. Fischer, Early Unabomber Target, Is Dead at 75
description: Patrick C. Fischer, a computer scientist whose theoretical work helped make Internet searches possible, but who was most widely known as an early target of the so-called Unabomber, died on Friday in Montgomery County, Md. He was 75.

title: Leonard Harris, Television Critic, Dies at 81
description: Leonard Harris, an arts and theater critic for New Yorks CBS television affiliate who had his own dramatic turn playing a senator in Martin Scorseses classic film Taxi Driver, died on Sunday in Hartford. He was 81.

title: Battle for Libya | August 30, 2011
description: Images from the continuing battle for control of Libya.

title: More Refined Game From Serena Williams
description: Though she has long hated losing matches, Serena Williams now shows a clear disdain at losing even a single point.

title: Australian High Court Rules Out a Refugee Exchange Program
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australias highest court ruled out the governments plans to ship asylum seekers to Malaysia, including unaccompanied children, as part of a refugee swap deal, saying the program would violate both Australias laws and its international commitments.

title: What to Watch on Wednesday
description: Among the many young players carrying the burden of high expectations in this tournament, few have a heavier weight to bear than Laura Robson. The 17-year-old from England is among the games most promising talents, a fact not lost on a country whose last Grand Slam champion was crowned in 1977.

title: Son Denies Rebels Claim That Qaddafi Is Cornered
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A top official of Libyas transitional government said Wednesday that its fighters had cornered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in a desert redoubt 150 miles from the capital and were exhorting him to give up, in what would bring a sense of finality to the prolonged uprising that routed him and his family from Tripoli a week ago.

title: News Quiz | Aug. 31, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Aug. 31, 1997 | Princess Diana Is Killed in Car Crash
description: On Aug. 31, 1997, Britains Princess Diana died in a car crash in Paris at age 36.

title: How Intense Will the Next Hurricane Be? Scientists Arent Sure
description: WHO is Frank Marks?

title: As Refugees From Haiti Linger, Dominicans Good Will Fades
description: As the post-quake good will between the Dominican Republic and Haiti has ebbed, Dominicans want quake refugees to go.

title: Ed Kashi, Seeing Eye-to-Eye
description: Eye Contact, an exhibit of photographs by Ed Kashi, will open Thursday at the VII Gallery in Brooklyn. The show runs through Oct. 7. James Estrin spoke with Mr. Kashi about the unusual exhibit. Their conversation has been edited.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 31, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Review of Census Data Reveals Information Tied to Schools.

title: Fashions Night Out in London Offers Parties and Deals
description: On Fashions Night Out, shops in Londons West End, as in New York and other cities, stay open extra late, treating shoppers to personalized fashion shows, D.J. sets, cocktails and stunning window displays.

title: Preparing for Disaster
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: On Day 3, a Better Picture for Commuter Trains
description: Updated, 6:40 a.m. Prospects for the areas trains, buses and roads are all a little brighter this morning. Getting around New York City is far less problematic than it was before with PATH trains, buses and subways all running. Amtrak is running again between Washington and Boston. Even some suburban lines are springing back to life.

title: Did Your Parents Have a Life Before They Had Kids?
description: Life before childrenevery parent had one. How much do you know about what your parents didand didnt dobefore you came along? How open are your parents with talking about their lives when they were your age? What have you learned from their stories?

title: Etns Axis Power
description: Although its a bit late for disaster preparedness gear, especially post-Irene, the Etn Axis ($70) may be a nice addition to your next hurricane party supply list.

title: Deadly Blast Strikes Near a Mosque in Southwestern Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 10 people were killed Wednesday in Quetta, in southwestern Pakistan, when an explosion struck a crowd in a parking lot near a Shiite mosque, police officials said.

title: In Reversal, Hearing for Zuma Rival to Continue in Johannesburg
description: Despite fierce clashes in central Johannesburg, South Africas ruling African National Congress on Wednesday reversed a decision to transfer a contentious disciplinary hearing for its controversial youth leader, Julius Malema, to a secret venue outside the city, party officials said.

title: A Landmark That Should Have Been, at Last, Is
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response) {data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: '+ data +', cropType: 'blog480', appendTo: 'embeddedSlideshow', showHeadLine: 'false'}

title: New App Taps Into Running Commentary on Football Games
description: Football fans who have added Twitter to their weekend routines may want to check out Sportcaster, a new app that provides a look into what Twitter users are saying about each N.F.L. and N.C.A.A. football game in real time.

title: A Start-Up That Automates the Process of Starting Up
description: Hari Kaur has been teaching yoga for 20 years as a private instructor and at other peoples studios, most recently in New York, but it was only late last year that she decided she wanted to start her own Jazz Yoga school  the worlds first, as far as she knew. What she didnt know was much about how to start and run a business.

title: Will Arizona Scramble the Republican Primary Calendar?
description: One of the looming questions for the Republican presidential candidates  and the political establishment that surrounds them  is this: when will the voting actually begin?

title: Cantor Makes Another Big Bet in Las Vegas
description: Cantor Fitzgerald is on a winning streak in Las Vegas.

title: Both Inflation and Joblessness Hold Steady in the Euro Zone
description: Euro area inflation was unchanged in August and unemployment held steady for a second month in July as economic growth in the region slowed amid a persistent sovereign debt crisis, fresh data showed on Wednesday.

title: The Fashions of Tavi Gevinson
description: A selection of the fashion wunderkinds unique outfits.

title: Back on the Road, Jaziri Makes Tunisia Proud
description: On Monday, Malek Jaziri became the first Tunisian player to ever win a match at a Grand Slam tennis event during the Open era, which began in 1968.

title: Syrias Sons of No One
description: It was past 11 a.m., and Abdullah was finally waking up. The night before had gone late, he and his friends challenging and daring and fleeing from the feared mukhabarat, Syrias secret police, who for the past five months have been bent on crushing dissent here in Homs. With a few hours of sleep behind him, Abdullah rolled off his mattress and began tapping out details of their exploits on his laptop. The clashes had been fierce and lasted hours, past the muezzins call to prayer at dawn. We wont bow to anyone but God, the protesters declared. The mukhabarat replied with tear gas, buckshot and bullets. Hot was how Abdullah described it as he typed.

title: How Sassy Is Tavi Gevinson?
description: When the teenage fashion blogger Tavi Gevinson announced last November that she was joining forces with the editor Jane Pratt to start a magazine modeled after Pratts much-mourned Sassy, the blogosphere lit up with excitement. For a generation of women, Sassy  with its indie ethos and straight talk about weighty topics like feminism and sex  was a seminal magazine: it not only changed their expectations of media, but it also changed how they saw themselves. Gevinson seemed the perfect choice to lend the old-media Pratt some new-media fame. Her precocious blog, Style Rookie, has, in a mere three and a half years, made her a darling of the fashion establishment  she has written for Harpers Bazaar, served as muse for Rodartes Target line, sat front row at the Marc Jacobs runway show and been the subject of a profile in The New Yorker. Even so, a few carped that she intended to edit a publication inspired by one that folded in 1996, the year she was born.

title: The Fluid Human Dance That Is Grand Central
description: Every city has its own choreography, formal or informal. The composer John Cage loved to point out how any street corner is theater of a kind; the dance critic and poet Edwin Denby wrote ardently of how daily life was full of things to see; and when one of Merce Cunninghams dancers asked what a piece was about, he took her to the window, showed her the view of the sidewalk and said, That.

title: Wednesday Reading: Can Exercise Help Treat Depression?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Sony, Hitachi and Toshiba to Merge LCD Units
description: 6:26 p.m. | Updated

title: The Nordic God of the Javelin
description: DAEGU, South Korea  To untangle the mystery of how Andreas Thorkildsen, of all strong-armed men of Viking stock, became the worlds best javelin thrower, it may be helpful to know that his father threw the javelin competitively in Norway and introduced it to him when he was 11.

title: China India Buy Buy
description: India and China are two of the fastest growing economies on earth. The Times spoke to people in Beijing and in Delhi about how they view their neighbors - as competition or collaborators?

title: Huntsman Seeks Far-Reaching Tax Changes
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former governor of Utah, will call for overhauling the tax code and a new focus on American manufacturing when he delivers a speech detailing his jobs agenda on Wednesday, advisers said.

title: India Measures Itself Against a China That Doesnt Notice
description: MUMBAI, India  It seems to be a national obsession in India: measuring the countrys economic development against Chinas yardstick.

title: Vermont Officials Assess the Risks in Towns Lacking Water and Power
description: CALAIS, Vt.  Federal and state environmental teams on Wednesday investigated the extent of health risks related to damaged sewage and water treatment plants in more than a dozen Vermont towns where flash flooding has left thousands of people without electricity or potable water since Sunday.

title: Memo to Exxon: Business With Russia Might Involve Guns and Balaclavas
description: MOSCOW  Exxon Mobil, welcome to the world of the masky show.

title: Lack of Deep Sleep Tied to Hypertension
description: Men who get the least deep sleep each night have a higher risk of hypertension, new research shows.

title: Styled to a T | Nico Landrigan
description: The Trend

title: After Irene, Focusing on Totally Cosmic Matters
description: Upstate New York and other parts of the region absorbed the most severe blows from the weekend storm, and we wish them well. But everything is always about us in New York City, isnt it? So consider some of the ways in which we in the five boroughs have focused on what we consider the truly important stuff.

title: Bus Driver Files Assault Charge Against Lost Star Matthew Fox
description: Heres another outcome that Lost fans arent going to be happy with: Matthew Fox, a star of that twisty-turny, probably made-up-as-it-went-along ABC drama, has been charged with assault by a bus driver who says he punched her outside a Cleveland nightclub, CNN reported. The bus driver, Heather Bormann, said that Mr. Fox tried to board the charter vehicle she was driving early Sunday morning for a bachelor party he was not invited to, and that he became physical when she barred him from entering. I told him, Sorry, buddy, this is a private party,  Ms. Bormann told Cleveland.com.  You get off my vehicle. I told him three times. Mr. Fox, who is in Cleveland shooting the film I, Alex Cross, was allowed to take a taxi back to his hotel.

title: The Role of Values in Driving Climate Disputes
description: Reacting to yesterdays piece on how better definitions of terms could help clarify climate disputes, Oran Switzer of Phoenix, Ariz., posted a comment reminding folks how values, more than data, largely shape positions on the level of risk posed by greenhouse gases. This is a theme stressed by Dan Kahan and other researchers studying cultural cognition.

title: The City Stirs | Greenwich Village, 5:47 A.M.
description: Show me a man with a tattoo and Ill show you a man with an interesting past.  Jack London

title: Indexes Are Up for the Day, Down for the Month
description: Until the end, August was a difficult month for Wall Street.

title: Whats Your Handle
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#303", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Urgent Call for Blood Donations
description: As Tropical Storm Irene approached the city last weekend, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg implored New Yorkers to stay indoors. While that may have been sensible advice, it has a created a crisis for the New York Blood Center, which supplies blood to nearly 200 hospitals in the city.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Sony Rolls the Dice With Two New Tablets
description: Risk-taking is a rare thing among tablet makers. As far as operating systems are concerned (and assuming youre not Apple), your company can try to go it alone, as RIM has done and H.P. tried to do. But most manufacturers have gotten on board the Android bandwagon.

title: Obama Makes a Vow to Veterans, but Can He Keep It?
description: Late summer is the season of annual veterans service organization conventions, and this year, much to the chagrin of other groups vying for his attention, President Obama chose to address the American Legion in Minneapolis. Not surprisingly, with Washington focused on reducing the deficit, the president addressed the issue of possible cuts to veterans programs in his remarks.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: U.S. Moves to Block AT&T Merger with T-Mobile
description: 5:13 p.m. | Updated

title: Green Gold
description: A rule of good olive oil: once you open the bottle, use the contents as quickly as possible. Oxygen is the enemy, and once you break the seal the flavors start to fade so that what tasted sensational one month will be flat the next.

title: Documenting a Collapsing Ice Shelf
description: One of the more dramatic events in the Arctic in recent years was the detachment, in 2010, of a large section of the ice shelf attached to Petermann Glacier, in northwest Greenland. A chunk of ice measuring 100 square miles, about four times the size of Manhattan, broke loose and floated away. The possible connection of this event to global warming drew immediate interest, including a hearing in Congress.

title: U.S. Declares Major Disaster in Areas of New York
description: President Obama on Wednesday declared a major federal disaster in New York State, as dozens of communities upstate struggled to contain floodwaters in the wake of Tropical Storm Irene.

title: Police in Bahrain  Kill 14-Year-Old During Protest, Activists Say
description: Human rights activists in Bahrain, the tiny but strategically important Persian Gulf monarchy, said security forces there killed a 14-year-old boy on Wednesday as they violently dispersed a protest in the oil town of Sitra, just south of the countrys capital, Manama.

title: Why It Shouldnt Have Been a Lost Decade for Investors
description: When people talk about being a buy-and-hold investor these days, they are often confronted by others who declare that the last 10 years were a lost decade.

title: Incoherence at the FOMC
description: There have already been a number of commentaries on the newly released minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee (the people who decide interest rate policy). The most interesting thing, I think, is the description of the arguments raised by the no votes, the people who opposed even the mild easing implied by the Feds sorta-kinda-not-really commitment to keep rates low until mid-2013. For whats remarkable is how flimsy their arguments are:

title: A Wet Month in the City Became the Wettest
description: August was already a wet month long before Tropical Storm Irene swept across New York City.

title: Theres a Dog in My Class
description: With so many recent childrens books built around unruly creatures going to school, its a relief to find a picture book in which the animal in question is reasonably well behaved and well intentioned. Starting school is scary enough for preschoolers and kindergarteners; why unnerve them with the added threat of an aggressive classmate?

title: Share Your Thoughts: Rebuilding Ground Zero
description: How do you feel about the Sept. 11 memorial pools and the rebuilding of ground zero?

title: Another Kind of Liquidity Trap
description: A reader directs me to the Times interactive photo map of Irene, which includes this photo of the pedestrian underpass at Princeton Junction train station:

title: Elite for a Day, in Coach, for a Fee
description: FOR an American Airlines flight to Miami last month, my husband and I and our 16-month-old daughter were treated like celebrities. We were greeted at the curb at La Guardia Airport by an American representative, her hair swept back in a practical ponytail, who checked us in and handled our baggage, and then whisked us through security, bypassing a long line of disgruntled passengers whose looks read, Who the heck are you?

title: Martin Wolf Gets It
description: Just go read his column today, which is very close to my own thinking. And not just on the economics. Martin is usually cautious on matters political, but this time he lets fly:

title: Six Actors No Longer in Search of a Play
description: LIKE a clumsy kid in the schoolyard Shakespeares late play Cymbeline has suffered plenty of bullying. George Bernard Shaw called it exasperating beyond all tolerance. Henry James named it a florid fairy tale. And Samuel Johnson, its chief tormenter, said that to discuss the play were to waste criticism upon unresisting imbecility, upon faults too evident for detection, and too gross for aggravation.

title: The Social Scene Spa-Francorchamps
description: The Spa-Francorchamps circuit where the Belgian Grand Prix took place last weekend is considered one of the best on the Formula One calendar. But the track is in the Ardennes Forest, far from any major city, and bad weather is almost a given during race weekend, so Spa is rarely a very big place in terms of visits from stars or dignitaries, or any other kind of party-like atmosphere.

title: The Social Scene Spa-Francorchamps
description: The Spa-Francorchamps circuit where the Belgian Grand Prix took place last weekend is considered one of the best on the Formula One calendar. But the track is in the Ardennes Forest, far from any major city, and bad weather is almost a given during race weekend, so Spa is rarely a very big place in terms of visits from stars or dignitaries, or any other kind of party-like atmosphere.

title: Broadway Cast for Chinglish Is Announced
description: The Gatz star Gary Wilmes, who played Tom Buchanan in that nearly seven-hour-long Elevator Repair Service adaptation of The Great Gatsby, will be getting less stage time in his next project, though its hardly a demotion. Mr. Wilmes is set to start in the coming Broadway transfer of Chinglish, the David Henry Hwang comedy about an American businessman who encounters linguistic and cultural difficulties on a trip to China, its press representatives said Wednesday. Jennifer Lim, who played a strong-willed Chinese official in the plays Chicago production at the Goodman Theater, will reprise her role on Broadway, as will the cast members Angela Lin, Christine Lin, Stephen Pucci, Johnny Wu and Larry Zhang. Leigh Silverman, who directed Chinglish in Chicago, will also stay on for the Broadway run, which will be presented at the Longacre Theater. It is scheduled to begin previews Oct. 11 and open Oct. 27.

title: Iran Concerned West Will Benefit From Arab Uprisings
description: Irans supreme leader admonished the West and Israel on Wednesday not to seek advantage from the antigovernment uprisings convulsing the Arab Muslim world, delivering the warning in a nationally broadcast speech that appeared to reflect new unease in Tehran over the course of events among its strategic neighbors, particularly Syria.

title: Fordham Game at UConn Is Postponed
description: Days after Hurricane Irene swept through the Northeast, its effects linger and have spoiled at least one of this opening weekends slate of college football games.

title: Hurricane Damage Questions, Part 2: Flooding and Food
description: Bucks readers have raised questions about hurricane claims for water damage and for food that spoiled due to a loss of electricity.

title: Sprint Shares Surge on AT&T Setback
description: 1:26 p.m. | Updated Sprint Nextel may get its way  or at least that is what investors are thinking.

title: Syria Hunts for Leaders of Protests in Hama
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces conducted house-to-house raids in the central city of Hama on Wednesday, hunting for activists involved in the countrys uprising, residents and activists said.

title: Blues From the Desert, Recorded On-Site
description: In the language of the Tuareg nomads who for centuries have roamed the most remote reaches of the southern Sahara, tinariwen means deserts. But ever since the musical group of that name released its first CD in 2001, its members have recorded not on their home turf but in much the same way that American and European bands do: in the artificial environment of a recording studio, in cities like Paris and Bamako, Mali.

title: In Private School World, a Rush to Be International
description: International is all the rage in private, profit-making schools in New York these days.

title: Wheelies: The Figure-S Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Program Hopes to Make Broadway Friendlier to Those With Autism
description: Earlier this month the Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit organization that runs the citys TKTS discount ticket booths, announced that it was starting the Autism Theater Initiative, which aims to make theatergoing accessible to children and adults living on the autism spectrum. The program kicks off on Oct. 2 with a sold-out matinee of The Lion King for what T.D.F., in a news release, calls the first ever autism-friendly performance in Broadway history.

title: Stanfords New Coach Fulfills 2 Dreams
description: Soon after he graduated from Stanford, David Shaw met Kori Bevans. They saw Apollo 13 on their first date, then went to Jack in the Box and ordered two tacos and two fries.

title: Basic Instincts
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#907", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Obama Reschedules Economy Speech at Boehners Request
description: 9:40 p.m. | Updated President Obama acquiesced to a request from Speaker John A. Boehner on Wednesday to move the date of his proposed address to a joint session of Congress to Thursday Sept. 8, after Mr. Boehner all but rejected Mr. Obamas request to speak next Wednesday.

title: G.O.P. Congressman Might Leave Black Caucus Over Remarks
description: Well, it was interesting while it lasted.

title: A Redesigned Brand Hopes to Avoid Tropicana Storm
description: As an up-and-coming beverage brand gets a new look, executives are hoping to avoid a redesign debacle like the one that roiled Tropicana orange juice.

title: Lipitor, Available to Anyone
description: Reading through Twitter recently, I came upon a dramatic tweet from the normally mild-mannered Dr. Ken Covinsky, a geriatrician at the University of California, San Francisco and the San Francisco VA Medical Center. He was reacting to news reports that Pfizer wants to turn its cholesterol drug Lipitor into an over-the-counter medication.

title: Land Rover DC100: a Return to Rugged?
description: The Land Rover Defender, the blocky British off-roader that helped set the table for the modern S.U.V., will re-emerge, if only in spirit, at the Frankfurt auto show next month.

title: The Role of Buildings and Cities in Cutting Energy Waste
description: The Canadian public affairs program The Agenda is running segments all this week on ways to enable human prosperity with less energy. The pieces were recorded at a summit on energy options through 2030, held at the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics earlier this year (which Im thrilled to see has been working on the practical end of physics, too, by hosting this and previous events). Heres todays installment and a summary of the themes:

title: For Nadal, Its All About Finding Solutions
description: The second question of Rafael Nadals post-match press conference Tuesday night pointed out that he had lost his serve six times in his match with Andreiy Golubev, while last year he was only broken five times in the whole tournament. He drew laughter from reporters when he replied, Is impossible to win this year. No, I am joking.

title: Famed Guitar Maker Raided by Federal Agents
description: Tracing what they say is an illegal shipment of Indian hardwood, federal agents raided offices and factories belonging to Gibson Guitar Corporation last week for the second time in two years, seizing documents, computer hard drives, pallets of wood, guitars and tools.

title: Essential Summer Dishes: Submit Your Photos and Recipes
description: Food writers for The Times shared recipes and memories of their essential foods of summer this week. Use this form to share the best dishes youve made since Memorial Day, whether they were grilled or iced, old standbys or fresh triumphs. A selection of the best photos and recipes will be displayed at nytimes.com/dining.

title: A 14-Year-Old Boy Is Killed in Bahrain as Security Forces Break Up a Protest
description: A 14-year-old boy was killed Wednesday as security forces in Sitra, Bahrain, broke up a small protest. Witnesses said the boy was struck in the head by a tear gas canister that the security forces fired directly into the crowd at close range, and died shortly afterward at a hospital.

title: Delay Worth the Wait as Game Tops Album Chart
description: After almost two years of delays for Games newest release, The R.E.D. Album (DGC/Interscope)  and a promotional campaign that included the West Coast rapper sporting a red-dyed mohawk  it opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with 98,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Game narrowly beat Jay-Z and Kanye Wests Watch the Throne (Roc-a-Fella/Def Jam/Roc Nation), which had 94,000 sales in its third week out.

title: Job Insecurity Remains High
description: For the last couple of years, the problem plaguing the job market was that companies have been in a holding pattern: Companies werent laying off workers in high numbers. But if you were already laid off, finding a company willing to expand was impossible.

title: Giants Trim Roster; Jets Stick With Folk
description: GIANTS TRIM ROSTER TO 85 The Giants placed wide receiver Ramses Barden and center Adam Koets on the physically unable to perform list, meaning neither player will be eligible until at least Week 7 of the season.

title: S.E.C. Examines Mutual Funds Use of Derivatives
description: Securities regulators are weighing new rules for mutual funds that invest in derivatives, the complex securities that wreaked havoc on the financial industry during the credit crisis.

title: Karma by the Cup
description: Anyone who has ever been desperate for a cup of coffee will appreciate a new trend cropping up in Berlin.

title: Fantasy Football: Preseason Week 3 Recap
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Mel Gibson and Former Girlfriend Reach Custody Accord
description: LOS ANGELES  After more than a year in court, Mel Gibson and his ex-girlfriend Oksana Grigorieva ended a custody battle over their 2-year-old child, Lucia, with an omnibus settlement much of which was described by a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge at a hearing on Wednesday.

title: Texas A&M Sets a Date to Leave the Big 12
description: Texas A&Ms break from the Big 12 arrived Wednesday morning, the next mile marker in its quest to join the Southeastern Conference.

title: Reacting to Justices Suit Against AT&T
description: As the biggest telecom deal in years, one that could reshape the American wireless landscape, AT&Ts $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA drew scores of supporters and critics alike.

title: The Fine Print: No Bricklin, Excalibur or DeLorean Rentals for Chase Cardholders
description: A few weeks ago, I received a new credit card Id signed up for  Chases Continental Airlines Presidential Plus card. (Just getting the card was a whole other story.) The card comes with a number of perks, including the ability to waive additional insurance when renting a car.

title: Lucasfilm Confirms Change to Blu-ray Release of Return of the Jedi
description: Its an event that seems to happen in the Star Wars world about as often as Wookiees celebrate Life Day, and which fans await with just as much dread. New versions of George Lucass space-fantasy films are released, and with them come changes to the movies  alterations to audio and video, characters actions and even dialogue that is very different from what fans remember seeing in theaters a long time ago and far, far away.

title: Back to the Desert
description: With Tassili, the band Tinariwen has sought to return to its beginnings.

title: The Caucus | Jobs Plans Aplenty
description: A look ahead as President Obama and Republican candidates are set to release their plans for jobs. Also, a report from Capitol Hill as the committee charged with taming the deficit begins work.

title: Myanmar Soccer Fans Given Freedom of Raucous Speech
description: YANGON, Myanmar  The hardships and oppression of living in an authoritarian country like Myanmar all but vanish at the gates of its soccer stadiums. Or so say the fans, who swarm into the grandstands for a carnival of drunken revelry that would never be tolerated outside the stadium walls.

title: U.S. Moves to Block Merger Between AT&T and T-Mobile
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Wednesday sued to block the proposed $39 billion merger between the cellphone giants AT&T and T-Mobile USA, arguing that keeping them separate would preserve competition in the wireless industry and even help save jobs of American workers.

title: Courtside: Roddick Creeping Out of the Spotlight
description: Andy Roddick has played in many prime time matches before, but this year he is not the focus of the American men. Lynn Zinser reports.

title: Even in Defeat, Keys Is Impressive
description: The September issue of GQ magazine features a story that is highly critical of U.S. tennis but anyone who saw 16-year-old American Madison Keys nearly upset Lucie Safarova, the tournaments 27th seed Wednesday, would have to conclude that the future of American tennis may not be quite so bleak. Keys upset bid faltered, 3-6, 7-5, 6-4, but she looked very much like a contender despite losing a dramatic, 2 hour and 24 minute contest to an older and more experienced player.

title: Roddick Is Able to Forge Ahead as Younger Americans Start to Rise
description: Andy Roddick arrived at this United States Open without, really, any serious expectations. His hardcourt season was an odd mix of injury and combustion. His status as a Grand Slam contender was slipping, if not already gone.

title: Courtside: Roddick Out of the Spotlight
description: Andy Roddick has played in many prime time matches before, but this year he is not the focus of the American men.

title: The Cavalier
description: Like Coco Chanel, Pierre-Henri Mattout was born in Saumur, the medieval French town in the Loire Valley famous among wine snobs for its superb cabernet franc appellation, Saumur-Champigny. The town also happens to be an equestrian center of France, home to the Cadre Noir, one of the worlds most prestigious riding schools. Its very uptight, very bourgeois and very elegant, says Mattout, who, as a ptit garon, dreamed not of mounting a Lusitano but of being the academys head tailor. Accordingly, Mattouts latest mens collection  all jodhpur-style chinos, leather elbow patches and whipcord wool blazers in dragoon red  is a paean to his horse-loving hometown. But rather than reboot some bygone vision of aristo chic, Mattout drew on his design experience at Dior Homme, Dunhill and Victorinox. The result is a modern sportswear collection of uncommon elegance, detail-obsessed yet refreshingly remote from the work-wear-inspired stuff thats glutting American runways.

title: Real Housewives of Beverly Hills to Air With Suicide-Prevention Announcements
description: LOS ANGELES  When the second season of The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills has its debut on Sept. 5 it will be accompanied by public service announcements about suicide prevention, the Bravo Media president Frances Berwick said in a statement Wednesday.

title: Caucus Video: Job Plans Aplenty From 2012 Candidates; the Debt Committee Begins Work
description: Jeff Zeleny and Michael D. Shear look ahead as President Obama and Republican candidates are set to release their plans for jobs. Also, Jennifer Steinhauer reports from Capitol Hill as the committee charged with taming the deficit begins work.

title: Evaluation of World Bank Gives Mixed Picture
description: LONDON  The World Bank is doing better at helping poor countries fight corruption and strengthen their institutions, but it has a long way to go toward matching its own ambitions in the area, according to a report released Wednesday.

title: Earliest Signs of Advanced Tools Found
description: One hallmark of Homo erectus, a forerunner of modern humans, was his stone tools, an advanced technology reflecting a good deal of forethought and dexterity. Up to now, however, scientists have been unable to pin a firm date on the earliest known evidence of his stone tool-making.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, China, Libya and Slovenia.

title: NBC Wins Ratings Race on Tuesday
description: NBC was the No. 1 broadcast network on Tuesday, partly because it was the only network that showed a full night of original programming. It averaged just under 8.8 million total viewers. With no real competition, Americas Got Talent was the most-watched show with 10.9 million total viewers, although it was still down when compared with last week, according to Nielsen data. CBS was second in total viewers (8.2 million) with three hours of repeats from its NCIS franchise. The Spanish-language Univision finished second for the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic.

title: Q&A: Separating Messages in Gmail
description: Q.

title: A Minimalist Take on a Cambodian Country Home
description: Built on stilts and surrounded by water and lush greenery, a house in Siem Reap merges tradition with modernity.

title: In Cambodia, a Contemporary Home in a Pastoral Setting
description: SIEM REAP, Cambodia  As a young Cambodian architect in the 1960s, Borath Ros never imagined it would take nearly half a century before he would see his tropical dream house come to fruition. Nor could he have predicted that his son and daughter would help him design it.

title: Kelli OHara Will Star Opposite Matthew Broderick in Nice Work If You Can Get It
description: Kelli OHara will be the leading lady in the new Broadway musical Nice Work If You Can Get It, the producers announced on Wednesday. She will star opposite Matthew Broderick in the show, which includes songs from the George and Ira Gershwin catalog and a book by Joe DiPietro (Memphis). Kathleen Marshall (Anything Goes) will be the director and choreographer.

title: Zvonareva Raises Her Voice, Wins a Round
description: The on-court tantrums and meltdowns that once were the hallmark of her game seemed to have been eliminated when Vera Zvonareva reached her first Grand Slam final at Wimbledon in 2010.

title: Red
description: Photos from the Broadway play about the painter Mark Rothko.

title: For Graduates, a Shrinking Payoff
description: Attention recent college graduates  as well as parents who covered those big tuition bills. You may not want to hear this, but a study released on Wednesday found that entry-level wages for students who graduated from college in 2010 was lower than a decade earlier, after adjusting for inflation.

title: Scientology Strikes Back at The New Yorker
description: The Church of Scientology is certainly no shrinking violet when it comes to defending itself.

title: Hold Everything
description: The actress Anne Hathaway has been living la vita Tods ever since she got her saddle-colored D Bag. Now, Hathaway, whos also the face of the brand, can expect still more baggage as Tods introduces its Signature collection, built around the iconic pebble. There are eight styles to choose from, including envelope clutches and shoulder bags. The Shopper ($2,165), an oversize bag with a drawstring closure, would appear to be the perfect choice for Hathaway, but she seems preoccupied with her new envelope clutch and iPad case in black, she says. Theyre just so sleek.

title: Storms Cost May Reach $1 Billion, Cuomo Says
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y.  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday that he expected damage in the state from Tropical Storm Irene to reach close to $1 billion, though he assured residents that there would be sufficient state and federal financial assistance for the recovery effort.

title: Buffett Investment Could Erode Confidence in Big Banks
description: Last week, our financial Superman, the mild-mannered Midwesterner Warren E. Buffett, swooped in again to save another bank, the financial markets, the American economy and just maybe our precious way of life.

title: Teaching 9/11 | Ideas and Projects From Teachers
description: Sept. 8, 2011 | Updated

title: Imagining the Rolling Stones Without Keith Richards
description: Today in The New York Times Janet Maslin reviews Marc Spitzs new book, Jagger: Rebel, Rock Star, Rambler, Rogue. She liked the book, and so do I. It argues against the prevailing and increasingly boring theory that Keith Richards is the Stones main claim to authenticity, the soul of the band, the principal force of their sound and songcraft, and that Mick Jagger is a shallow socialite poseur. If you were persuaded by Keith Richards strong attitudes in his memoir, Life  which has sold a million copies worldwide in under a year, according to a recent statement by its American publisher  you may believe in this theory yourself.

title: App Smart Extra: 70 Catalogs on One App
description: Last weeks App Smart column, on big-box shopping apps, pointed out the strengths and, more frequently, the weaknesses of the category.

title: Warnings and the Cost of Storms and Climate Change
description: Casey B. Mulligan, an economics professor at theUniversity of Chicago, has a post on the Economix blog that looks at the Northeasts recent weather-related disaster and the long-term trajectory for climate change and expresses confidence that the costs attendingenvironmental threats are lower when they can be anticipated.

title: If You Aint Bleedin, You Aint Leadin
description: Catfish hunters compete in the 12th annual Okie Noodling Tournament that climaxes with a weigh-in of the still-living catfish.

title: Rating the No. 1s: Justice League
description: Times staffers and comic-book fans George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler will review all of the 52 DC Comics titles that have been rebooted as part of a company-wide effort to resuscitate the brand. In the first of five weekly installments they discuss Justice League, which came out on Wednesday. Next week theyll look at 13 other first issues, including Action Comics.

title: A Chance to Peek Inside Yaddo
description: For more than a century, Yaddo, the private artists colony on 400 acres of woods in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has been a haven for writers, painters and composers. In cozy studios there, Patricia Highsmith wrote Strangers on a Train, Aaron Copland created his Piano Variations, and authors like Eudora Welty, Truman Capote and Langston Hughes spent productive time.

title: Justice Departments Complaint in AT&T and T-Mobile Case
description: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit to block the proposed $39 billion merger between AT&T and T-Mobile USA on antitrust grounds.

title: In Yet Another Upset, McHale Defeats Bartoli
description: Christina McHale, an American teenager, toppled eighth-seeded Marion Bartoli of France, smashing an ace up the middle of the court on match point, for a 7-6 (2), 6-2 victory at the U.S. Open.

title: Tea Party Groups to Protest Romney in N.H.
description: Many Tea Party supporters have been less than enthusiastic about the prospect of Mitt Romney becoming the Republican nominee for president in 2012, but now that antipathy is becoming louder.

title: TimesCast | August 31, 2011
description: Floodwaters from Hurricane Irene cover New Jersey's suburbs; the Justice Department moves to block AT&Ts merger; and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof reports from the road  to Tripoli.

title: For Murray, a Convincing Victory
description: Andy Murray of Great Britain rolled into the second round of the U.S. Open on Wednesday with a convincing 7-6 (5), 6-2, 6-3 victory over Somdev Devvarman of India.

title: Unfinished Beach Boys Album Is Set for Release, 44 Years Later
description: One of the most famous unfinished recordings in the history of popular music The Beach Boys Smile sessions  will be released in November, 44 years after it was scheduled to come out, Capitol/EMI records has announced.

title: Off the Shelf | Dorfsman & CBS
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#667", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Despite Keys, Obama Is No Lock
description: Allan J. Lichtman, a presidential historian at American University, has issued a prediction that, given an economy still teetering on the brink of recession and President Obamas 40 percent approval ratings, looks awfully bold.

title: If Deal Is Killed, Wall Street Will Lose Out
description: Some $150 million in advisory fees is at risk if AT&T is thwarted in its bid to buy T-Mobile USA from Deutsche Telekom, Thomson Reuters calculates.

title: Are You as Fertile as You Look?
description: FORTY may be the new 30, but try telling that to your ovaries.

title: A Bungalow Frozen in Time, Till the Storm Washed It Away
description: On Saturday, there were eight wood-frame, century-old bungalows perched above Jamaica Bay on the eastern edge of Broad Channel, the small island community squeezed between the Rockaways and the Howard Beach section of Queens.

title: Wenger at Salamis
description: Why sit you doomed one?

title: Beauty Spots
description: ARGAN MADNESS Argan oil, purportedly rich in vitamins and antioxidants, continues to pop up in products, like the Zinn Beauty Collection (zinnbeauty.com), including a facial cleansing milk, anti-aging cream, body milk and a conditioning treatment for hair and skin (about $25 to $30), now at all Rickys New York stores. Olie Biologique is offering three new essential oils: rose hip, evening primrose and argan ($39 each at oliebiologique.com). And Sally Hershberger (sallyhershberger.com) just introduced Hyper Hydration Super Argan Serum, also infused with amla (Indian gooseberry) and rice bran oils ($15 at Duane Reade, Ulta and other locations).

title: Bus Driver in Bronx Crash That Killed 15 Is Said to Be Indicted for Manslaughter
description: The driver of a bus that crashed and killed 15 people on a return trip to New York from a Connecticut casino in March has been indicted on multiple counts of manslaughter, a law enforcement official said Wednesday.

title: John Paulson Gets a Brief Reprieve
description: The hedge fund magnate John A. Paulson has endured a long, hot summer, with two of his largest funds seemingly in free fall.

title: Bryans Lose in the First Round
description: The reigning Wimbledon champions and the worlds top ranked doubles team, Mike and Bob Bryan of the United States, suffered a first-round upset at the hands of Ivo Karlovic of Croatia and Frank Moser of Germany, 6-4, 2-6, 6-2, on Wednesday at the U.S. Open.

title: The Neighborhood Project
description: INTRODUCTION

title: New Questions, and Old, Surround Palins Iowa Trip
description: Several things might explain why Sarah Palin is scheduled to travel to Iowa and New Hampshire over the Labor Day weekend.

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from China, Pakistan, India and Libya.

title: The Evolution of Binghamton, Block by Block
description: For years the evolutionary biologist David Sloan Wilson paid little attention to Binghamton, N.Y., where he lived and taught. I hadnt joined the PTA, he writes, attended council meetings, given blood, or served turkey to the homeless on Thanksgiving. It was enough, he modestly believed, to raise two healthy kids and work at changing the way the planet thinks about evolution.

title: Share Your Thoughts: A 9/11 State of Mind
description: Do you associate the events of 9/11 with a particular song, book, movie or turn of phrase?

title: J Mays: Evos Styling Will Distinguish Ford Product in Four Months
description: The Ford Evos concept car, which is scheduled to have its debut at the Frankfurt auto show next month, represents a near-term design strategy, said J Mays, the companys design chief, in a telephone interview on Wednesday.

title: What Is That? Let Your Smartphone Have a Look
description: I never carry a point-and-shoot camera. Chances are you dont either. In the last few years, cellphone optics have improved substantially. That means more megapixels, better image sensors and stronger flashes and zooms on the one device most of us carry all the time.

title: TimesCast | U.S. Challenges Telecom Deal
description: The U.S. Justice Department filed a lawsuit Wednesday to stop AT&Ts proposed $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile.

title: Room for a Toddler Act in This Gloomy Circus Life
description: A flame-haired woman searching for her dog finds an adorable child instead in Little Girl (La Pivellina), a documentary-fiction hybrid from the Italian-Austrian filmmaking team of Tizza Covi and Rainer Frimmel.

title: Bank of New York Mellon Chief Resigns in a Shake-Up
description: 9:27 p.m. | Updated

title: Edible Selby | Chez Panisse Turns 40
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#828", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Designers Start to See in Triplicate
description: WITH something like 250 runway shows and parties crammed into the New York Fashion Week that begins Sept. 8, a lot of designers are saying that there must be a better way to show clothes, or at least some way to grab peoples attention for more than a second or two.

title: U.S. Open Replay: Day 3
description: The third day of match play saw Venus Williams withdraw from the tournament and No. 8 seed Marion Bartoli upset in straight sets.

title: Keystone XL Is Self-Destructive. Does the Obama Administration Need to Be Also?
description: So many thoughts after todays column, in which I wrote about the Keystone XL pipeline. If its approved by President Obama, it would carry diluted bitumen  acidic crude oil  1,700 miles from the tar sands in Alberta to refineries on the Texas Gulf Coast. The Times has already come out against the pipeline, citing the risk of spills, spikes in greenhouse gas emissions and massive destruction of Canadas boreal forest. Proponents cite job creation and oil security.

title: Tribute Concert Promoters Fail to Sway Jackson Fan Clubs
description: The promoters of a Michael Jackson tribute concert tried to dispel the concerns of fan clubs Monday during a series of international conference calls on Wednesday, but leaders of some large groups said afterwards they were still opposed to the event.

title: Obama to Visit Paterson on Sunday and the Overflowing Passaic River
description: President Obama will travel to Paterson, N.J., on Sunday to survey the damage from Tropical Storm Irene, White House officials said Wednesday.

title: A Harlow for the New Era
description: Emily Bergl, an incandescent kewpie doll with a bright Betty Boop-inflected chirp, a defiant flounce and a sharp comedic edge, took the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel by storm on Tuesday evening. Her sensational show, Kidding on the Square may have played elsewhere, but arriving at the staid Oak Room it felt like a gust of fresh air that could knock you off your feet.

title: Iraq War Marks First Month With No U.S. Military Deaths
description: BAGHDAD  Under increased pressure from the United States, an Iraqi crackdown on Iranian-backed Shiite militias has helped produce a previously elusive goal: For the first time since the American invasion of Iraq, an entire month has passed without a single United States service member dying.

title: Hes Always Around, Showing Off His Muscles
description: The Hindi-language film Bodyguard has nothing to do with the  Whitney Houston and Kevin Costner love story from 1992, though it does concern an attractive woman and a man hired to protect her, and is a towering geyser of sentiment. But its a bit closer to Jason Stathams Transporter movies, with plenty of over-the-top fight choreography. Except that the male lead isnt tearing across the countryside in a black Audi. And theres frustrated ardor. And music-video-style production numbers.

title: French and Dutch Players Face Off in Croatia
description: OPATIJA, Croatia  The last event of the second World Youth Congress ended here on Tuesday. With three boards to play in the Pairs Championship, the first two pairs were playing against each other. Berend van den Bos and Joris van Lankveld from the Netherlands were leading Aymeric Lebatteux and Simon Poulat from France by 20.28 matchpoints, with 18 available on each board.

title: New headphones from SOL Republic, digital audio in Ubuntu Linux; tech news.
description: Kevin Lee of SOL Republic introduces his companys new line of headphones. Cristian Parrino of Canonical discusses digital audio options in the Ubuntu Linux operating system, including the Ubuntu One cloud service. This weeks tech news includes a look back at the career of Apples Steve Jobs and a new survey on social-media use.

title: Jamaican Kingpin Pleads Guilty in New York
description: Christopher Coke, a Jamaican drug trafficker whose arrest last summer came after a monthlong manhunt that left scores dead in Kingston, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to racketeering conspiracy charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Petraeus Retires, With a Warning
description: WASHINGTON  An era in the American military came to an end on Wednesday when David H. Petraeus, the most influential general of his generation, retired with a 17-gun salute and a warning that coming budget cuts should not lead to the hollow Army that occurred after the Vietnam War.

title: Flooding in New Jersey
description: The Timess Sam Dolnick reports on flooding in Paterson, N.J.

title: Happiness, Philosophy and Science
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: As One Qaddafi Promises Peace, Another Calls for War
description: Two Arab satellite channels broadcast starkly different audio messages on Wednesday from men who both claimed to be sons of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: After 9,382 Performances, Actor to Leave Phantom
description: As the Guinness World Record holder for the most performances in the same Broadway show, George Lee Andrews thought he had seen it all during his 23 years in The Phantom of the Opera, including 12 different actors in the title role and the stunning metamorphosis of a once-seedy Times Square. Yet he was shocked in May when the powers that be at Phantom revealed that they were not extending his six-month contract, which had been renewed more than 40 times before.

title: Gallery Owner Stirs Hamptons Art Crowd
description: THE guests at the recent Ross School benefit at the Gallery Valentine in East Hampton, N.Y., were not necessarily recognizable types. The art on the walls was another matter. With a Hans Hoffman here and a Fernando Botero there, not to mention Sam Francis, George Condo and Damien Hirst, the star power was as bright as the dollar-sign silk screen by Andy Warhol in the back.

title: Fashion Week Is Pruning Its Diesel Generators
description: Fashion Week is back, minus two diesel-powered generators.The events producers said they had plugged into Fordham University and the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center to help power their tents and get rid of two of nine portable generators that drew complaints about noise and fumes from Upper West Side neighbors last winter.

title: OnStar for All Who Have the Wherewithal
description: Most people probably dont think of General Motors as, ahem, the living definition of a technologically nimble company. But deep in the G.M. archipelago of cars, parts and wholly owned subsidiaries there sits a technological gem: OnStar.

title: Saint Vitus, Greenpoint, Brooklyn
description: FEARFUL nafs may assume that heavy-metal bars are cradles of malevolence where depraved longhairs slake their thirst with bats blood. But Saint Vitus, a gothic-themed bar in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, named after a Black Sabbath song, is actually a welcoming spot for downing cheap beers and listening to Pantera.

title: Lets Help Michele Bachmann
description: It ought to surprise no one that Representative Michele Bachmann is writing a memoir. We received the news yesterday in the form of a press release from Sentinel, an imprint of Penguin Group (USA). It read, The book, currently untitled, will go on sale nationwide on November 21.

title: Reference Resources for the Budding Know-It-All
description: You could once gauge a familys intellectual vitality by its living room bookshelves. If your family scored the trifecta of Encyclopedia Britannica, the Oxford English Dictionary and the World Almanac, you were ahead of the pack.

title: For del Potro, a Return to Form
description: Before Wednesday, the last time Juan Martin del Potro of Argentina won a match at the United States Open, he beat Roger Federer in the mens singles final in 2009.

title: Now Playing | The World Premiere of When Saints Go Machines New Video
description: Historically, the D.J. culture of Germany has dominated its little neighbor Denmark, but thats all changing. Pioneering a new and distinctive Copenhagen sound is the band When Saints Go Machine, whose hypnotic electro-pop is held together by the lead singer Nikolaj Manuel Vonsilds soaring falsetto vocals, which have earned him comparisons to Arthur Russell and Antony Hegarty. As the band prepares to embark on a big tour of Britain, Vonsild talked to The Moment about the new video for the hit single Kelly off their latest album, Konkylie.

title: Federal Hurricane Forecasters Did Their Job
description: It seems inevitable to have finger-pointing whenever a hurricane makes landfall. If the storm weakens, there are charges of alarmism and fear-mongering. If it veers or strengthens, hammered communities cry out. With Hurricane Irene, it was mostly the former, as various factions with axes to grind piled on the National Hurricane Center. (A case in point was Patrick Michaels, a climate scientist at the anti-regulatory Cato Institute who last Friday said the storm should be renamed Hurricane Hype, adding that he doubted it would cough up even eight bodies. With the death count far higher, he apologized through the Watts Up With That blog.)

title: Bonds Avoids New Trial on Three Perjury Charges
